title: Diem at the Fulcrum
description: President Kennedy's decision in May deferredbut did not settlethe issue of combat troops for South Vietnam. Throughout the summer and fall of 1961 the Administration's debate on that crucial matter was significantly affected by the attitude of President Diem, according to the Pentagon account. Initially, it relates, Vice President John: son found the South Vietnamese leader reluctant; in midsummer he warmed to the idea somewhat; by fall he was ap pealing to the United States to become a cobelligerent.

title: Correspondent of The Times Ousted From East Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI, June 30 (Reu ters)Sydney H. Schanberg, South Asia correspondent of The New York Times, was ex pelled from East Pakistan to day.

title: NEW HEARINGS SEEN LOCKHEED SETBACK
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)The Senate Banking Committee decided today to hold a new round or public hearings starting next Wednes day on broad legislation de signed to aid other ailing com panies as well as the Lockheed Aircraft Corp.

title: South African Team Jeered
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, June 30 (UPI)  The touring South African rugby team was sub jected to a shower of smoker bombs and, constant taunts and jeers from about 1,000 anti apartheid demonstrators during a match against South Aus tralia today.

title: Let's Declassify
description: More than half a century ago Wood row Wilson called for open covenants openly arrived at. It was a good idea then, although the other statesmen of the time didn't think so. They made a lot of secret deals, and a generation later the world had its biggest war yet.

title: Cable From Taylor to Kennedy On Introduction of U.S. Troops
description: Cablegram from Baguio, the Philippines, by General Taylor to President Kennedy, Nov. 1, 1931.

title: ELLSBERG CALLS DECISION GREAT
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 30 Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, who has said he gave the Pentagon pa pers to the press, praised the Supreme Court decision today as a great one.

title: AirCooled PATH Terminal in World Trade Center Opens Tuesday
description: Spacious, brightly lighted and completely aircondi tioned, the new Port Authori ty TransHudson (PATH) ter minal in the World Trade Center will open Tuesday.

title: Report by Vice President Johnson On His Visit to Asian Countries
description: Excerpts from memorandum, Mission to Southeast Asia, India and Paki stan, from Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson to President Kennedy, May 23, 1961.

title: Memo From Rostow to Kennedy With Nine Proposals for Action
description: Memorandum from Walt W. Rostow, deputy Presidential assistant national security, to President Kennedy, April 12, 1961.

title: Japan Urged to Lift Trade Restrictions In Rogers Speech
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Secretary of State William P. Rogers expressed concern to night that the American trad ing position in Japan was be ing weakened by continued Japanese Government restric tions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Allied Chemical Expands
description: The Allied Chemical Corpo ration, the nation's largest maker of soda ash, announced yesterday that it planned to double production of the chemi cal at its industrial chemical division plant in Green River, Wyo. The multimilliondollar expansion will increase capac ity at Green River to 1.1mil lion tons annually.

title: Schools' Decentralization Is Considered Successful
description: As the city's schools ended their first year of decentralized operations yesterday there was considerable agreement that the transition to greater com munity control of local schools, despite some problems, had generally gone better than had been anticipated.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Ratana, $16.40, Scores in Feature on Aqueduct Turf
description: Gay Ratana, under the guid ance of Chuck Baltazar, carried the silks of Louis Lee Haggin to victory in the main event, a 1 116mile race on the turf, at Aqueduct yesterday. The race for fillies and mares attracted a dozen participants and was witnessed by a crowd of 21,559.

title: Pentagon Papers: Study Reports Kennedy Made Gamble Into a Broad Commitment
description: The Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war concludes that President John F. Kennedy transformed the limitedrisk gamble of the Eisenhower Administra tion into a broad commitment to pre vent Communist domination of South Vietnam.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Telethon Seek Funds To Combat Blood Disease
description: A group of community or ganizations, prominent citizens, politicians and theatrical per sonalities are planning a Sept. 12 telethdn to raise money to combat sickle cell anemia, a committee of the group an nounced yesterday.

title: 96 Navy Addicts Confess
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (AP)  The United States Navy said today that 96 men had turned themselves in during the first Trial month of its dung amnesty program in South Vietnam. The program is being extended indefinitely.

title: 60,000 Jehovah's Witnesses Gather to Begin a FiveDay Assembly at Yankee Stadium
description: Bright parasols in the box seats, picnic hampers, Ther mos jugs and baby strollers and everywhere an endless fanning with paper programs gave Yankee Stadium the air of a lowkeyed, bigcity camp meeting yesterday as an estimated total of 60,000 Jehovah's witnesses from New York and New England began a fiveday district assembly.

title: Creditors Resist Penn Central Moves
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Because of its continuing defi cit cash flow, creditors of the bankrupt Penn Central Trans portation Company are resist ing moves of the railroad's trustees to obtain new equip ment under new lease agree ments.

title: Harkins Message to Taylor Voicing Doubts on Plot
description: Cablegram front General Harkins in Saigon to General Taylor, Oct. 30, 1963.

title: Memo on Washington Meeting In Aftermath of August Plot
description: Memorandum by Maj. Gen. Victor H. Krulak, special assistant to the Joint chiefs of Staff for counterinsurgency and special activities, on a meeting the State Department Aug. 31, 1963. Besides General Krulak, participants were Vice President Johnson; Secretary Rusk; Secretary McNamara; Deputy Secre tary of Defense Roswell L. Gilpatric; McGeorge Bundy; General Taylor; Edward R., Murrow, director of the United States Information Agency; Lieut. Gen. Murshall S. Carter, Deputy Directon of the Central Intelligence Agency; Richard Helms and William E. Colby of the C.I.A.; Frederick E. Notting Jr., former Am bassador in Saigon; Assistant Secretary Hilsman, and Paul M. Kattenburg the State Department, head of the Interdepartmental Working Group Vietnam.

title: U.S. Approval, in 1961, of Steps To Strengthen South Vietnam
description: National Security Action Memorandum 52, signed by McGeorge Bundy, Presidential adviser on national security, May 11, 1961.

title: 2 GAS PRODUCERS DISCUSS MERGER
description: Merger News

title: U.S. SAID TO SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  The United States Government, in a, reversal of an earlier atti tude, was reported today to be preparing to authorize Poland to purchase nearly $60million in advanced oil refinery equip ment.

title: BLACK REALTY MEN FIGHT STATE ORDER
description: An organization of black realestate brokers, the Bed fordStuyvesant Real Estate Board, sought yesterday to re strain the Secretary of State, John P. Lomenzo, from holding a public hearing on block busting.

title: FINAL BATTLE SEEN DURING 1973 BY THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (UPI)  President Nguyen Van Thieu forecast to day a final confrontation be tween South and North Viet namese military forces in 1973 after completion of United States and allied troop with drawls.

title: ANSON BARKER
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., June 30 Anson Barker, a retired edu cator and business executive, died yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived on Quisset Harbor Road.

title: Stewardess Strike Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)  A strike threatened this morning by stewardesses of Universal Airlines was post poned today when the parties in the dispute agreed to meet with mediators. A spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Associa tion, which represents Univer sal's 185 stewardesses, said that there would be a 24hour moratorium on the walkout.

title: An Enlightened People
description: The historic decision of the Supreme Court in the case of the United States Government vs. The New York Times and The Washington Post is a ringing victory for freedom under law. By lifting the restraining order that had pre vented this and other newspapers from publishing the hitherto secret Pentagon Papers, the nation's highest tribunal strongly reaffirmed the guarantee of the peo ple's right to know, implicit in the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

title: Lodge's Response to Rusk On Diem's Closeness to Brother
description: Cablegram from Ambassador Lodge to Secretary Rusk, Aug. 30, 1963.

title: Ombudsman Office Sought
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Senator Jacob K. Javits, Re publicon of New York intro duced legislation today to establish experimental ombuds man programs to aid the poor. Senator Javits said his amend ment to the Economic Oppor tunity Act would establish an Office of Administrative Om budsman in Congress to assist in making the Government more responsive to the needs of the poor and of citizens generally.

title: State Department Study in Late '62 On Prospects in South Vietnam
description: Excerpts from research memorandum from Roger Hilsman, director of the State Department Bureau of Intelligence and Research, to Secretary of State Rush, Dec. 3, 1962. The memorandum bore the title The Situation and Short Term Prospects in South Vietnam and a footnote said that the report was based on information available through Nov. 12, 1962.

title: Copters and Casualties
description: Even before the American decisions on the troop buildup were announced formally on Dec. 14 with a public ex change of letters between Presidents Kennedy and Diem, the first two Ameri can helicopter companies had arrived 400 men with 33 H21C helicopters. On Feb. 5 the press reported that the first helicopter had been shot down by the enemy.

title: Political Decay
description: Until the eruption of Buddhist demon strations against the Diem regime in May, 1963, much of the American pub lic was oblivious to the political de cay in Vietnam described in the Pen tagon account: the atmosphere of sus picion, the pervasive but latent disaf fection with the autocratic Diem regime, the taint of corruption, the suppressed discontent in the Army.

title: Sony Cassette Output Rises
description: The Sony Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had begun massproducing its color video cassette systems at a rate of 2,000 a month. Richard F. O'Brion, vice president, said that by early 1972 the com pany will be able to meet what ever volume the market de mands.

title: American Can Will Buy More Aspen Systems Stock
description: The American Can Company announced that it would ac quire 400,000 additional shares of the Aspen Systems Corpora tion, a Pittsburghbased infor mationprocessing company. The investment will bring American Can's stock owner ship in Aspen to about 38 per cent from the present 6 per cent.

title: Czech Terrier Satisfies Need for Hunting Breed
description: News of Dogs

title: Article 1  No Title
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 30The United States has granted $5.7million to Pakistan for rehabilitation of the East Pakistani area struck by a cy clone and tidal wave last fall and for transportation of food, the Pakistani Radio reported to night.

title: War Foe Balks Grand Jury
description: DETROIT, June 30 (UPI)A second antiwar activist, Ken Kelley, said today that he had refused to answer questions before a Federal grand jury reportedly investigating the bombing of the United States Capitol in Washington. Mr. Kelley, 20 years old, of Detroit, told newsmen he had given the jury only his name, age and address. Yesterday Terry Taube. 18, of Detroit, also refused to answer questions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah C. Abrahams Married to Broker
description: Miss Sarah Catherine Abra hams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Meyer Abrahams of New Canaan, Conn., was married here yesterday to Michael Levinson, a vice president of W. E. Hutton & Co., mem bers of the New York Stock Exchange. State Supreme Court Justice George Postel performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

title: Charles Richards, Expert on Exports, Dies at 89
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Charles A. Richards, the Gov ernment's chief of export li censes in World War I, and later director of small business for the Agency for Internation al Development until his retire ment in 1961, died today in George Washington University Hospital after a short illness: He was 89 years old and lived here.

title: 12 Detroit Panthers Cleared in Slaying
description: DETROIT, June 30Twelve members of Detroit's Black Panther party were acquitted today of charges of murdering a black policeman and con spiracy to murder in a gun bat tle at the Panther headquarters last fall.

title: Cousin Asserts Jerome Johnson Told of Job With Italian League
description: A cousin of Jerome A. John son, who was shot to death at the site of a rally in Columbus Circle after allegedly firing three bullets into Joseph A. Co lombo Sr., said yesterday that Johnson told him several months ago he was working for the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League as a pho tographer.

title: Further Rusk Cable to Lodge On. DiemNhu Relationship
description: Cablegram from Secretary Rush to Ambassador Lodge, Aug. 29, 1963.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein. With 151, Retains Lead in L.I. Golf
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 30  Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks scored 36, 42 78 for a 151 total to retain her threestroke lead over Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Piping Rock in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's 54 hole medal play championship at the Creek Club today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. A brilliant sun cut through the fog in midmorning, gleaming on more than a dozen boats trawling for bluefish several miles off shore.

title: ABORTION PROFITS END FOR AGENCIES
description: Profitmaking abortion refer ral services, more than two dozen of which are now op erating in the city, become il legal today under a new state law prohibiting the sale of med ical referrals.

title: Nixon Says Turks Agree To Ban the Opium Poppy
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 President Nixon announced to day that Turkey had agreed to eliminate within a year her production of opium poppies, which account for about two thirds of the illegal bernin reaching the United States.

title: U.S. SEEKING TO CUT IMPORTS OF BAUXITE
description: Major aluminum producers have been invited to a meet ing today in Washington with officials of the Interior Depart ment. The talks will be aimed at reducing the nation's de pendence on foreign sources of aluminum raw materials.

title: Notes on People
description: If Britannia fails to rule the waves later this month in the Admiral's Cup yacht race, it may be the fault of Prime Minister Heath.

title: Memo From Joint Chiefs Urging A Greater Role in South Vietnam
description: Excerpts from memorandum from the Joint Chiefs of Staff to Secretary of Defense McNamara, Jan. 13, 1962. On Jan. 27, 1962, Mr. McNamara sent memorandum to President Kennedy with a covering letter that said in part: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have asked that the attached memorandum . . .be brought to your attention. The memorandum requires no action by you at this time. I am not prepared to endorse the experience with our present program in South Vietnam.

title: More Social Concern Is Urged by Business
BRONX BLAST LINKED TO FIGHT ON DRUGS
description: A pipe bomb exploded last night outside the apartment of a former college basketball player who has been arrested on narcotics charges. Responsi bility for the bombing was later claimed by a black group that has claimed credit for the shoot ing of Joseph A, Colombo Sr.

title: $7Million U.S. Bills Missing at Bank
description: Seven million dollars in negotiable United States Treas ury bills have turned up miss ing from the operations head quarters of the Bankers Trust Company at 16 Wall St.

title: Most Congressional Leaders Applaud Court Decision
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Congressional leaders today generally applauded the Su preme Court decision on publi cation of material from Penta gon papers.

title: Believed to Have Votes
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Robert E. Short, who bought the Senators three years ago and has been telling Congress that he faces bankruptcy unless a new lease is arranged for the team in Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium, was be lieved today to have the nine votes necessary among Amer ican League club owners to move the team to Texas at least by next season.

title: Continental Telephone Bid For Commonwealth Approved
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation said that share holders of the Commonwealth Telephone Company of Virgin ia had approved its acquisition by, Continental for about 1.5 million shares, of Continental stock valued at $34,875,000. The acquisition by Continental of the Whitney Blake Com pany, manufacturer of rubber and plastic telephone cords and wirecable products, for 353, 000 shares or $84,207,250, was completed today, bringing the total of the transactions to $43,082,250 based on Contin ental's closing market price of 23 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Herbert Biberman Dead at 71; Directed Salt of Earth Film
description: Herbert J. Biberman, a lead ing director for the Theater Guild and director of the awardwinning film Salt of the Earth, died yesterday of bone cancer at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. He was 71 years old and lived at 263 West End Avenue.

title: Italians Seek to Save Hills
description: PORTOFINO, Italy (Reuters) The Italian wildlife fund has announced a nationwide drive to save 30,000 acres of wooded hills overlooking the Gulf of Portofino from building specu lators.

title: Space Funds Gain
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)  The House today voted $18.1billion for housing, vet erans' medical and drug treat ment, and space exploration.

title: Design Error May Shorten The Mission of Mariner 9
description: PASADENA, Calit., Tune 30 (AP)A design error in an electronic circuit may cut three months from the mission of the Mariner 9 spacecraft now speeding toward Mars, officials reported today.

title: DELAYS UNLIKELY IN SKYLAB FLIGHT
description: American space officials said yesterday that the deaths of the three Soviet astronauts should not delay or alter any of this country's planned space flights, including the experi mental Skylab space station project in 1973.

title: Purse Is Bigger and Field Is Better as Canadian Open Golf Starts Today
description: MONTREAL, June 30 A new cosponsor and a new site share the background for the $150,000 Canadian open golf championship that begins here tomorrow. A halfmillion dollars has been spent on promotion toward making the event more attractive to American touring pros, many of whom have by passed it in the last three years.

title: BAN ON BANK LOANS IN ELECTIONS UPSET
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 30 (UPI)A Federal law that pro hibits national banks from making loans to political can didates or organizations is un constitutional, United States District Court Judge Joseph P. Kinneary ruled today.

title: Alabama Adding Police For School Reopening
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 30 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace announced today that he would hire 200 ad ditional state troopers im mediately to insure tran quility this fall when Ala bama schools, closed under Federal court order, are al lowed to reopen on a non discriminatory basis.

title: D. A. Hewitt Weds Phyllis Myers
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 30Miss Phyllis Parker Myers and Duncan Adams Hewitt were married here this after noon.. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee of St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor performed the ceremony on the shore of a pond on the Myers' property in the Lloyd Neck section.

title: East Pakistanis Picket Here Against Shipment of Arms
description: A group of 12 East Paki stanis and sympathizers pick eted Pier 36 on the East River yesterday, carrying signs that said The Shipment of Arms Must Be Stopped.

title: $1.7Million at Antipoverty Agency Unaccounted For
description: About $1.7million in Federal funds paid to a South Bronx antipoverty project was found to be unaccounted for, ac cording to a Federal audit of the program's financial records released last night.

title: MORRIS BERMAN
description: Morris Berman, a former en gineer with the city's Depart ment of Sanitation, died of a heart condition on Tuesday at the New York Infirmary. He was 74 years old and lived at 1055 East 42nd Street, Brook lyn.

title: LeatherNot Picklesin the Barrel
description: Shop Talk

title: Plea in Berrigan Case
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 30 (AP)The socalled Harris burg Eight want a Federal judge to dismiss bombkidnap conspiracy charges against them on the grounds that one of the grand jurors who indict ed them was not qualified. A motion filed by J. Thomas Menaker, Harrisburg attorney, charged that Mrs. Susan Palmer Kline, Marysville, Pa., was not a registered voter in the district on the date her name was se lected for the venire.

title: CHILE PLANS TALKS WITH 8 BANKS HERE
description: Chilean Government officials told a news conference here yesterday that they would hold discussions today with eight New York banks, including some that had cut off Chile's lines of credit last year, follow ing the election of an avowed Marxist, Salvador Allende Gos sens, as president.

title: Sulzberger Expresses Complete Joy at Ruling
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York. Times, said yester day that his reaction to the Supreme. Court's decision was one of complete joy and de light.

title: U.S. Asks Business To Cut Power Use During Peak Loads
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) A Government program call ing for cooperation by busi nesses to reduce their power needs during periods of peak power loads this summer was announced today by the De partment of Commerce.

title: Lodge Cable to Secretary Rusk On U.S. Policy Toward a Coup
description: Cablegram from Ambassador Lodge to Secretary Rusk, Aug. 29, 1963.

title: UNIT OF CHRYSLER WILL SELL NOTES
description: The Chrysler Financial Cor poration, which three months ago faced a crisis of confidence when a unit of Dun & Brad street withdrew its prime credit rating from the company, announced yesterday plans to sell $100million in fiveyear notes.

title: Casper Starts TuneUp
description: SOUTHPORT, England, June ??0 (UPI)Billy Casper arrived oday to prepare for the British Open golf championship at Royal Birkdale July 710.

title: Market Place:
description: Inevitablyand with only the slightest encouragement the brokers have come forth to defend the present commission basis for buying and selling securities.

title: MARKET SURGES 211 DAY IN A ROW
description: The stock market closed out the June quarter with a flourish yesterday as prices rose briskly for the second session in a row.

title: Lansdale Memo for Taylor On Unconventional Warfate
description: Excerpts from memorandum from Brig. Gen. Edward G. Lansdale, Pentagon expert on guerrilla warfare, to Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, President Kennedy's military adviser, on Resources for Unconventional, Warfare, S E Asia, undated but apparently from July, 1961. Copies were sent to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, Deputy Secretary of Defense Roswell Gilpatric, Secretary of State Dean Rush, Allen W. Dulles, Director of Central Intelligence, and Gen. C. P. Caball, Deputy Director of Central Intelligence.

title: C.I.A. Station Chief's Cable On Coup Prospects in Saigon
description: Cablegram from Mr. Richardson to Mr. McCone, Aug. 28, 1963.

title: ACQUITTAL OF TURCO IN KILLING IS ASKED
description: BALTIMORE, June 30The prosecution in the trial of Arthur F. Turco Jr., New York lawyer charged with being an accessory to the 1969 murder of a suspected Black Panther police informer here, ended its case today.

title: R,. Walter Johnson, Doctor, Who Helped Tennis Stars, Dead
description: LYNCHBURG, Va., June 30 (AP)Dr. Robert Walter John son, a physician who was founder of the American Ten nis Association's youth devel opment program, died on Sun day at the age of 72.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Citizens and Southern National Bank, Atlanta, next week will name Richard L. Kattel, 35 years old, president, and Bennett A. Brown, 41 years old, assistant president. Of ficials at the bank said that the moves will be preliminary or transi tional steps to prepare young management to assume top positions in the bank. Mills B. Lane, who has headed C&S for 25 years and is one of the best known bankers in the country, will remain as chief executive of the $1.8billion bank with the title of vice chairman. Mr. Lane is due to retire at the end of 1973. Jack Glenn, chairman of the C&S board, will retire at the end of next year. A bank spokesman said that it is expected that Dick Kattel and Bennett Brown will assume the positions of the chairman of the board and the presidency when both of these retirements have come to pass.

title: Lodge Message to Bundy On Dealings With Generals
description: Cablegram from Ambassador Lodge to McGeorge Bundy, Oct. 25, 1963.

title: Washington: For the Record
MRS. EDWARD A. O'NEILL
description: Mrs. Helen Sampson O'Neill, wife of Edward A. O'Neill, vice president of the Continental Insurance Company of Hono lulu, died on Tuesday at her home in Honolulu after a long illness. She was 57 years old.

title: Soviet Starts an Inquiry Into 3 Astronauts' Deaths
description: MOSCOW, June 30The So viet authorities appointed a special commission tonight to investigate the deaths of their three astronauts who perished this morning when their Soyuz 11 craft was returning to earth after the longest manned space flight in history.

title: Kretchmer Scores Nixon's Bill For Control of Noise Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Jerome Kretchmer, Environ mental Protection Administra tor for New York City, told a Senate Commerce Subcommit tee today that the Nixon Ad ministration's noise control bill would condemn our citizens to continue suffering for years noise levels that could be abat ed by existing technology.

title: He Does Steal Sometimes, But It Means a Feast, Not a Felony
description: All cooks are thieves, said Patrick O'Higgins, emerging from his cellsized East 57th Street kitchen. And he, ought to know. By his own perhaps overly candid admission, he has been stealing recipes since childhood.

title: Prosecutor Cites Ring in Stealing at Daily News
description: Eightysix people have been indicted in the theft of 7.5 mil lion copies a year of The Daily News from the news paper's Brooklyn plant, accord ing to Brooklyn District Attor ney Eugene Gold.

title: McNamara as Speer
description: PARISIn his memoirs, Albert Speer quotes a 1944 article in The London Observer that described him as a type which is becoming increas ingly important in all belligerent countries: The pure technician, the classless bright young man without background, with no other original aim than to make his way in the world, and no other means than his technical and managerial ability. It the lack of psychological and spiritual ballast, and the ease with which he handles the terrifying technical and organizational machinery of our age, which makes this type go far now adays. This is their age; the Hitlers and Himmlers we may get rid of, but the Speers, whatever happens to this particular special man, will long be with us.

title: 13 Women Law Students Here Accuse 10 Large Firms of Bias
description: Women law students from Columbia and New York Uni versities accused 10 law firms here yesterday of discriminat ing against women in their recruiting and hiring.

title: Further Lodge Comments to Rusk
description: Reference Big MinhConein meeting (CAS Saigon 1455). While neither Gen eral Harkins nor I have great faith in Big Minh, we need instructions on his approach. My recommendation, in which General Harkins concurs, is that Conein when next approached by Minh should:

title: Tenants Bar Group That Aids ExConvicts
description: The Fortune Society, a group that helps former pris on inmates get a new chance in life, has been denied a Greenwich Village office Rae because of tenant complaints about having exconvicts in the building.

title: 41 Held in Loitering Drive
description: The police reported yester day that its new unit of patrol men armed with cameras aided the regular midtown police force Tuesday night by arrest ing 41 women, in an attempt to curb the activities of prosti tues. In the past, loitering charges in such cases have been dismissed for lack of evi dence.

title: 9 Jews in Kishinev Get Up to 5 Years
description: MOSCOW, June 30  The Moldavian Supremo Court to day found all nine Jews on trial in Kishinev guilty of anti Soviet actions and sentenced them to prisoncamp terms ranging from one to five years.

title: YIELDS ON BONDS ARE UP SHARPLY
description: Interest rates on lower medi umquality city bonds moved sharply higher yesterday as New York City disclosed defi nite plans to sell $75million of fiveyear bonds to raise mon ey for parity pay for police men, firemen and garbagemen.

title: Jim Garrison Is Arrested; U.S. Says He Took Bribes
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 30 District Attorney Jim Garrison was arrested by Federal agents today and charged with taking bribes to protect illegal pinball gambling in New Orleans.

title: Experts at Geneva Discuss Progress on Blast Detection
description: GENEVA, June 30Experts outlined at the disarmament conference here today progress made toward distinguishing un derground nuclear blasts from natural earth tremors at a dis lance through instruments.

title: Bride:
description: The biggest bridge book in the world, and perhaps the most important, Is now avail able again. It is the Official Encyclopedia of Bridge, pub lished by Crown at $12.50, and it can answer almost any question of general im portance about the game.

title: Jordan Assails Israeli Bid To Pay Jerusalem Arabs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 Jordan today categorically re jected the Israeli offer to com pensate Arabs in East Jerusa lem for property they owned before the creation of Israel in 1948.

title: Remodeling Funds Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The House refused today to accept a Senate amendment adding $1,209,000 to the legisla tive apropriation bill for the fis cal year 1972 to remodel the Old Senate and Supreme Court chambers in the Capitol. House opponents of the remodelling plan said the old chamber on the ground floor of the Capitol was needed for conference ses sions of House and Senate com mittees.

title: I.O.S. Management Loses a Skirmish to Dissidents
description: TORONTO, June 30  The management of I.O.S. Ltd., lost an initial skirmish tonight with an insurgent group of stock holders waging a proxy fight to gain control of the Geneva based international financial conglomerate.

title: Space Tragedy
description: The world today is united in sorrow over the mysteri ous death of three Soviet cosmonauts who had just set a new record for life in space, a pioneering achievement not only for the Soviet Union but for all mankind.

title: Kennedy Position on Coup Plots
description: Cablegram from White House to Ambassador Lodge, transmitted on Central Intelligence Agency channel, Oct. 5, 1963. The Pentagon study says this mes sage emanated from a meeting of the National Security Council.

title: Cable on Diem's Treaty Request
description: Cablegram from the United States Embassy in Saigon to the State Depart ment, Oct. 1, 1961. A copy of the message was sent to the commander in chief of Pacific forces.

title: Police Say Johnson Took Pictures of Colombo Before Shooting
description: The police released a photo graph yesterday showing Je rome A. Johnson taking motion pictures of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., which they said was taken seconds before Johnson was supposed to have shot the re puted Mafia chief three times at an ItalianAmerican civil rights rally in Columbus Circle.

title: Diamond Poaching Easy In a Sierra Leone Town
description: KOIDU, Sierra Leone, June 17Many pedestrians in this seemingly typical African town walk the mud streets with their eyes cast toward the ground. They are looking for diamonds.

title: Conferees Cut Military Pay Rise As Authority to Draft Runs Out
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Nixon Administration won a major budgetary victory to day in the HouseSenate con ference on the draft extension bill.

title: Marathon Manufacturing Sets Refinancing Plan
description: Wayne D. Harbin, president and chairman of the Marathon Manufacturing Company, said yesterday that the company had completed a $32million re financing program involving an insurance company and five banks.

title: U.S. and Diem's Overthrow: Step by Step
description: The Pentagon's, secret study of the Vietnam war discloses that President Kennedy knew and approved of plans for the military coup d'tat that over threw President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963.

title: FRAZIER RETURNS TO GYM ROUTINE IN A HAPPY MOOD
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 30  Joe Frazier appeared healthy and happy today as he resumed his role as world heavyweight champion after nearly four months as a rock singer.

title: LAND DEAL CITED AT HUDSON TRIAL
description: NEWARK, June 30  United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern offered today to place in evi dence records showing that a member of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority had entered into a land deal with the man who was then the executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority that alleg edly netted them $100,000 in profit.

title: Condec Gets Contract
description: The Condec Corporation said yesterday that one of its divi sions had been awarded a $23.7million contract from the United States Army Mobility Equipment Command for am phibious mobile assault bridges.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 30Minute Power Failure Halts Penn Station Trains
description: Thousands of commuters were delayed by a power fail ure at Penn Station yesterday morning that halted trains far 30 minutes. The delay, which began at 7:55 A.M., affected both Penn Central lines from New Jersey and the Long Island Railroad.

title: Class 44: A Sense Ofa Job Well Done
description: With less than 60 minutes left to the school year, Anibal Rosado kept a promise yes terday to Class 44 by softly crooning a solo.

title: A Challenge for the U.S.
description: However serious the problem in South Vietnam, the situation in Laos was far more critical. The Western position was in the process of falling, apart as Ken nedy took office, the Pentagon account says.

title: Dr. Bernard Lefferts Dies; Dentist Taught at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Bernard H. Lefferts, a dentist, died in his sleep at his home yesterday. He was 74 years old and lived at 128 Cen tral Park South.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Edito??:

title: Nixon and Pope Among Leaders Sending Condolence Messages
description: Messages of condolences for the deaths of three Soviet as tronauts were sent to Moscow yesterday from all over the world.

title: Eunice B. Armstrong Is Dead; A Writer and Psychoanalyst
description: SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., June 30Mrs. Eunice. Burton Arm strong, a writer and lay psycho analyst, died of a stroke at her home here yesterday. She was 84 years old.

title: Court Move Hailed At Washington Post; More Articles Due
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  Executives of The Washington Post applauded the Supreme Court's decision today and pub lished in their Thursday issue, three articles based on their partial collection of the Penta gon, papers.

title: Bankers in London Fear Eurodollars Face Restrictions
description: LONDON, June 30London bankers are expressing concern over the possibility that re strictions may soon be applied to the $60billion Eurodollar market that is largely based in London.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Back in the fifties, Mort Sahl used to recite what was then considered a bitter portrayal of the Nixon family at home. Mrs. Nixon, as the story went, was sitting on one side of the fireplace, knitting an American flag. Mr. Nixon was sitting on the other side of the fireplace, reading the Constitution in search of loopholes.

title: Only Slim Political Effect Seen in Post Office Shift
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  In, the first dark days of the New Deal, when jobs seemed as elusive as mirages to many men, the great mahoganyand marble reception room of the Postmaster General was thronged each day with men seeking work.

title: Use of U.S. Troops Decided in April '65
description: President Johnson decided on April 1, 1965, to use Ameri can ground troops for offensive action in South Vietnam be cause the Administration quickly found that sustained bombing of North Vietnam begun on March 2was not going to stave off collapse in South Vietnam.

title: Fighting Intensifies Below DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 1 (AP)Fight ing intensified yesterday along South Vietnam's northern fron tier just below the demilita rized zone.

title: New Omens of Peril
description: In what the analyst calls the first flush of selfsatisfaction, Ambassador Lodge cabled Washington on Nov. 4 pre dicting that the change of regime would shorten the war against the Vietcong be cause of the improved morale in the South Vietnamese Army.

title: Rhodesian Talks Pressed
description: SALISBRY, Rhodesia, June 30 (Reuters)British and Rhode sian officials held another round of talks today aimed at paving the way for toplevel negotia tions to resolve the Rhodesian independence dispute. Both sides were searching for wide enough areas of agreement that could warrant a conference of top officials. A former British colony, Rhodesia unilaterally declared itself independent in November, 1965.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sterner Objective
description: On May 11, two days after Vice President Johnson's departure for Sai gon, President Kennedy made his deci sions. As recorded in National Security Action Memorandum 52, a copy of which accompanies the Pentagon study, the. American objective was stated more bluntly and more ambitiously than in typical public pronouncements. The memorandum said the American objec tive was to prevent Communist domi nation of South Vietnam, whereas six days earlier President Kennedy him self spoke at a news conference of vaguer desire to assist Vietnam to ob tain its independence.

title: Gannet Company, Completes Federated Publications Tie
description: The Gannett Company, Inc., completed its merger with Fed erated Publications, Inc. With the merger, Gannett becomes numerically the largest group of daily newspapers in the Uni ted States with 45 dailies in 12 states and an aggregate circula tion of about 1.8 million readers.

title: Colby, U.S. Chief of Pacification for Vietnam, Gives Up Duties and Returns Home
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30William E. Colby, the chief of the American pacifica tion effort in South Vietnam, gave up his duties today and flew home to Washington be cause of the illness of a daughter.

title: Further Harkins Comments To General Taylor
description: Cablegram from General Harkins to General Taylor, Oct. 30, 1963.

title: BURGER DISSENTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Supreme Court freed The New York Times and The Wash ington Post today to resume immediate publication of arti cles based on the secret Penta gon papers on the origins of the Vietnam war.

title: 26Union Conference Strikes Copper Industry
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 30 A scant 90 minutes before the midnight expiration of in dustrywide contracts, 200 union representatives meeting in spe cial session here unanimously voted tonight to strike the na tion's coper industry. Picketing began at midnight at the Ken necott Copper Corporation's mines and mills 20 miles from here.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS STEEL AND LABOR TO WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 President Nixon has called ne gotiators of the steel compa nies and steelworkers union to meet with him next Tuesday before they sit down to begin contract negotiations, a White House spokesman announced today.

title: 77Day Tax Bills Up At Treasury Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The Treasury auctioned $1.75 billion of 77day tax anticipa tion bills today at an average rate of 5.035 per cent, up from 3.678 at the preceding sale of such bills on March 24 when 23day bills were sold. Today's issue is dated July 6 and comes due Sept. 21.

title: Tass Statement on Deaths
description: Following is a statement distributed yesterday in Mos cow by Tass, the Soviet press agency, on the deaths of the three Soviet astronauts:

title: Nixon Sees End of Permissiveness Era
description: WASHINGTON, June 30  President Nixon asked a group of policemen who graduated today from the National Aced today from the F.B.I. National Academy to take back to their communities this message: The era of permissiveness with regard to law enforcement is at an end.

title: Motorcycles Are Restricted
description: BEAUMONT, Tex. (AP)The City council has passed a law that forbids all motorcycle rid ing except on public roadways and officially designated motor cycle trails. Too many people complained about the noise mo torcycles were making in city parks and along abandoned railroad property.

title: Movies to Return to Parks in Expanded Program
description: Free movies are returning to the city parks, starting on Monday, in an expanded ver sion of last year's summer time hit.

title: Leading Figures at Time of Coup
description: Henry Cabot Lodge

title: City Starting Test of Public Cable TV
description: The city will start today a wideranging experiment aimed at providing the public with free access to its four new cabletelevision channels.

title: Ruggiero Is Indicted on Perjury in Bribery Inquiry
description: Joseph E. Ruggiero, a former official of the New York County Republican party, was indicted yesterday on charges that he lied to a Federal grand jury investigating allegations of corruption.

title: Film:
description: The young man standing in front of me in the line yesterday morning outside the Cinema I, where Carnal Knowledge opened, was quite unremarkable except for the fact that he was carrying a full set of golf clubs.

title: AGNEW REASSURES KOREANS ON CHINA
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 30 Vice President Agnew said today that President Nixon's efforts to relax trade and travel restrictions with China would not endanger South Korea's economic strength or its secu rity.

title: Chess: The Forfeit by Hubner Leaves Some Questions Unanswered
description: In the aftermath of the Seville Affairin which the West German, Robert Hub ner, forfeited his candidates' match against the former world champion, Tigran Pe trosian, of the Soviet Union reports continue to filter in, some contradictory of one another, some selfcontradic tory and all of them confusing.

title: Modern Museum Show Traces Artists' Protests
description: The Museum of Modern Art's major summer exhibi tion, which opens to the pub lic today, gathers together more than 250 paintings, sculptures, drawings and graphics as well as 56 photo graphsall but a few are from the museum's perma nent collectionand is called The Artist as Adversary.

title: Israelis Report Helms Visited Mrs. Meir, Dayan and Eban
description: JERUSALEM, June 30Rich ard Helms, United States direc tor of Central Intelligence, has conferred with Premier Golda Meir and other top Israeli lead ers during his current visit to Israel, the Foreign Ministry an nounced today.

title: Note on a Plan for Intervention
description: Supplemental note to a paper entitled Concept for Intervention in Viet Nam, Oct. 11, 1961. According to the Pentagon history, the paper was drafted mainly by U. Alexis Johnson, Deputy Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, and was either a talking paper for a meeting that included Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Secretary of Defense McNamara or a revision put together later in the day, after the meeting.

title: Evaluation and Conclusions Of Taylor's Report on Vietnam
description: Excerpts from General Taylor's report, Nov. 3, 1961, on his mission South Vietnam for President Kennedy.

title: Saturday Review Talks Confirmed by Cascade
description: The Boise Cascade Corpora tion, which is engaged in the fields of timber, building ma terials, housing, paper and, packaging, construction and recreation, confirmed yesterday that it was holding exploratory, discussions with Norton Simon Industries on the purchase of the Saturday Review magazine. It is published by the McCall Corporation, a Simon subsid iary, and has a circulation of 640,000.

title: Personal Finance
description: Summer is here, and most people who work in hot cities like to leave their of fices promptly in the even ing for a cool drink at home, an outdoor barbecue, per haps a swim in the pool. Sometimes they take with them outoftown visitors in the city on business.

title: State of Emergency
description: The Taylor mission arrived in Saigon on Oct. 18 and was greeted by what the Pentagon study calls a spectacu lar opening shot: President Diem's formal declaration of a state of emer gency. Within the next week General Taylor met twice with the chief of state.

title: Order by Johnson Reaffirming Kennedy's Policy on Vietnam
description: Excerpts from National Security Action Memorandum 273, Nov. 26, 1963, four days after the assassination of President Kennedy, as provided in body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase.

title: C. B. STECKER JR., 47, BELL ENGINEER, DIES
description: Charles B. Stecker Jr., who directed the planning of inter city routes for the Bell Sys tem's nationwide telecommuni cations network, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 10 West 66th Street.

title: White House Cable for Lodge On Response to Gen. Minh
description: Cablegram from White House to Ambassador Lodge, Oct. 6, 1963.

title: Australian Reds Sell War Articles of Times
description: SYDNEY, June 30  Un authorized reprints of parts of the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war carried by The New York Times and three accompanying articles in The Times were sold by the Com munist party of Australia and the Young Communist Move ment at antiVietnam rallies in Sydney today.

title: New Orders Rose 1.1% as Inventories Gained 0.1% in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 New orders received by manu facturers rose 1.1 per cent to a total of $57.9billion in May, continuing the mild zigzag pat tern that has prevailed since the end of the upsurge that fol lowed the settlement of the General Motors Corporation strike late last year.

title: Taylor's Summary of Findings On His Mission to South Vietnam
description: Cablegram from Baguio, the Philippines, by Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, Presi dential military adviser, to Mr. Kennedy, Nov. 1, 1961.

title: Bess Myerson Cleared by City For a TV Show to Help People
description: Bess Myerson, who became the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner after years as a television star, has ben cleared by the Board of Ethics to ap pear on a commercially syndi cated TV show to promote con sumerism.

title: Head of Foundation Center
description: Thomas R. Buckman, former ly librarian at Northwestern University, became president yesterday of the Foundation Center, established here in 1965 to make information about phil anthropic foundations available to the public.

title: Covert Warfare Sponsored by U.S. in '64
description: President Lyndon B. Johnson's Administration, amid his hesita tion and reluctance to take final decisions, was sponsoring co vert South Vietnamese warfare against North Vietnam starting in February, 1964, and drawing up plans that spring for overt war.

title: MISS GOOLAGONG BEATS MRS. KING IN STRAIGHT SETS
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 30  It had to happen sooner or later. For the first time in six years Mrs. Billie, Jean King is out of the AllEngland tennis final.

title: Roundup: Utility With Power
description: For a fellow who thinks the Los Angeles Dodgers are going to win the National League Western Division pennant, Paul Popovich of the Cubs is doing little to make his prognosis accurate.

title: Electra Gets New Twist in Stratford
description: STRATFORD, CONN.It is oddly agreeable sometimes to be proved wrongat least it is if the wrong is on the right side. I must admit I looked forward to the new produc tion of Eugene O'Nell's Mourning Becomes Electra by the American Shakespeare Festival Theater with the gloomiest of forebodings.

title: 38 Representatives Protest Migrant Worker Program
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) A bipartisan group of 38 Representatives from Northeast ern and Middle Atlantic states protested today the exclusion of their sections from a new $20million Federal manpower program for migrant workers.

title: Defense Treaty With Britain Is Declared Invalid by Malta
description: VALLETTA, Malta, June 30 (AP)  Prime Minister Dom Mintoff's Government declared today that Malta's 1964 de fense treaty with Britain no longer is in effect. A state ment said new arrangements must be made if British troops were to remain on the strategic Mediterranean island.

title: 8 Concerns Agree Not to Fix Prices Of Their Gasolines
description: NEWARK, June 30  The Justice Department filed a con sent agreement in United States District Court today enjoining eight major oil companies from fixing gasoline prices. The agreement terminates an anti trust suit brought by the Gov ernment against the companies on April 8, 1965.

title: 1961 Request by South Vietnam For U.S. Combat Forces
description: Cablegram from United States Embassy in Saigon to the State Department, Oct. 13, 1961, on requests by Nguyen Dinh Thuan, Defense Minister of South Vietnam. Copies of this message were sent to Commander in Chief of Pacific forces and to the United States Embassies in Bangkok, Thailand, and Taipei, Taiwan.

title: Farmers Prices Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Prices received by farmers for their products were un changed in midJune from the previous month and averaged 3 per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Depart ment announced today.

title: GARBAGE WORKERS STRIKE IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Thursday, July 1 Detroit's garbage collectors struck the city at midnight, breaking an agreement signed by the leaders of the city's unions a few hours earlier.

title: Further Bundy Instructions To Lodge on Contingency Plans
description: Cablegram from McGeorge Bundy to Ambassador Lodge, Oct. 30, 1963.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Some years ago, a sports writer trying lamely to explain to the heavyweight champion why his newspaper insisted on referring to him as Cassius Clay instead of Muhammad Ali, suddenly asked: Listen, why don't you just clear up the matter by paving your name legally changed? Ali became annoyed. Drag the Honorable Elijah Muhammad and Allah and the Koran through unsym pathetic, misunderstanding courts? Ask the white, Chris tian, oppressive judges for permission to use a name he had been given as a badge of honor?

title: Soviet Cars Vandalized
description: PARIS, June 30 (AP)Eight parked vehicles belonging to the Soviet Trade Mission here were damaged early today. Notes to newspapers signed the Jewish Defense Commit tee said one of its commando groups was responsible.

title: Bundy Cable to Lodge Voicing White House Concern
description: Cablegram from McGeorge Bundy to Ambassador Lodge, Oct. 30, 1963.

title: Acquisition Talks Ended
description: Wolverine World Wide, Inc., announced yesterday that ne gotiations with Lane Bryant, Inc., regarding Wolverine's ac quisition of their Coward Shoe Stores Division have been ter minated by mutual agreement.

title: State Job Center Is Occupied Here In Welfare Protest
description: Members and supporters of the Welfare Rights. Organization yesterday began their campaign to close down state employ ment centers to protest refer ral of employable welfare re cipients to what they called slave jobs.

title: Ford Opposes Federal Agency On Air Bags as Safety Devices
description: DETROIT, June 30The Ford Motor Company charged today that Government reports indi cated the airbag safety device promoted by the Government could be dangerous to car riders.

title: Jersey G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Specialist 4 Ricky D. Gilchrist, of Somer set, N. J., of the Army, had been killed in action in South east Asia.

title: Consensus on Bombing Reached Before the Election
description: Leaders of the Johnson Ad ministration reached a con sensus at a White House strategy meeting on Sept. 7, 1964, the Pentagon study of the war says, that sustained air attacks against North Vietnam would probably have to be launched, and indicated a start for early 1965.

title: Vietnam Program of Action By Kennedy's Task Force
description: Excerpts from A Program of Action for South Vietnam, May 8, 1961, presented to President Kennedy by an interdepartmental task force comprising representatives from the Departments of State and Defense, the Central Intelli gence Agency, the International Cooperation Administration, the United States Information Agency and the Office of the President.

title: Paul G. Pennoyer, 80, Lawyer Active in Various Fields, Dies
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 30Paul Geddes Pennoyer, a noted lawyer, died at his home today. He was 80 years old and lived on Duck Pond Road here and at 215 East 72d Street in New York.

title: PRICES DECLINE ON CROP FUTURES
description: Profit taking and some specu lative selling sent grain and soybean futures prices down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Some of the selling was geared to the weather.

title: EXCHANGE MEMBERS REVERSE BOARD'S BID
description: The membership of the New York Stock Exchange has voted down a constitutional amend ment unanimously endorsed by the exchange's board of gov ernors in the first reversal of the board in 18 years.

title: The Knapp Panel Questions Leary and McGovern Here
description: Former Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary was ques tioned in private here yester day by the Knapp Commission, which is investigating the ex tent of corruption within the Police Department.

title: ALBERT R. WILLIAMS OF COMMUNITY CHEST
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 30  Albert R. Williams, who directed the New Rochelle Com munity Chest and Council from its foundation in 1936 to his re tirement in 1956, died yester day at his home, 97 Liberty Avenue, after a short illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Algeria and a French Company Sign Accord on Oil Indemnity
description: PARIS, June 30The French Algerian oil crisis was resolved to a considerable extent today with the signing of a 10year accord between Sonatrach, the Algerian national oil trust, and the Compangnie Francaise des Petroles, one of two companies whose properties in Algeria were partly nationalized in Feb ruary.

title: ACTION BY GRAVEL VEXES SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Many Senators privately ex pressed dismay, shock and chagrin today at Senator Mike Gravel's release of parts of the Pentagon's secret study of the Vietnam war. But it appeared that no disciplinary action would be taken against the Alaska Democrat.

title: Bove Goes to E. Stroudsburg
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., June 30 (AP)John Bove, 29, an assis tant football coach at the Uni versity of Vermont, resigned to day to accept a similar position with East Stroudsburg (Pa.) College.

title: DANCES AT CUBICULO ARE LEAN AND CLEAN
description: The dances presented at the Cubiculo Tuesday evening had a lean, clean look to them. There were four choreogra phers, Mel Wong, Jan Van Dyke, Beverly Brown and Suzette Martinez, but all shared a movement fastidiousness and a similar disinclination to fling gesture around indiscriminately.

title: CADENCE PLANNING PAYMENT TO CURTIS
description: The Cadence Industries Cor poration (formerly the Perfect Film and Chemical Company), will pay the Curtis Publishing Company an arbitration award of $300,000 to settle Curtis's continuing claims of $20mil lion, Sheldon Feinberg, Ca dence's president and chairman, told the annual meeting here yesterday. He said there was a possibility that Curtis might appeal the arbitration decision.

title: Wessin Held as Plotter In Dominican Republic
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domin ican Republic, June 30 (AP) President Joaquin Balaguer anounced tonight that his Government had smashed an attempted rightwing coup and placed Elias Wessin y Wessin, a retired general, un der arrest.

title: Intelligence Estimate on '63 Unrest
description: Excerpts from Special National Intelligence Estimate 53263, The Situation in South Vietnam, July 10, 1963.

title: FAS FAILS TO MEET INTEREST PAYMENT
description: FAS International, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it could not make interest payments totaling $578,000 due on its per cent, convertible deben tures and its overseas subsidi ary's 5 per cent, guaranteed bonds.

title: Mets Top Pirates;
description: Taking advantage of an hon orary title bestowed on him be fore the game, Dr. Gil Hodges took one look at Nolan Ryan in the seventh inning last night and made an instantaneous di agnosis.

title: Suspect Near Blast Arraigned On a StolenProperty Charge
description: A woman who allegedly left the scene of a bomb explosion Wednesday night carrying a suitcase contining at least $30, 1000 was arraigned yesterday in the Bronx on a charge of re ceiving stolen property.Criminal Court Judge Louis A. Cioffi set bail at $5,000 for Mrs. Jacqueline Leshin, 40 years old, whom the police said they arrested after she was seen leaving 1040 Gerard Ave nue about an hour after the explosion outside a second floor apartment.

title: Smith, Newcombe Gain Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1It will be Stan Smith against John Newcombe for the AllEngland tennis title on Saturday.

title: Froehlke Is Sworn In As Secretary of Army
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)  Robert F. Froehlke was sworn in as Secretary of the Army today by his longtime friend, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.

title: College Head Named Here
description: Leon M. Goldstein, dean for community college affairs of City University, has been named acting president of New York City Community College at 300 Jay Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Gold stein, who said he would ac cept the post only until a per manent president was appoint ed, will succeed Milton G. Bassin, who was named presi dent of City University's York College in Queens.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RUTGERS IVES HURRY
description: Rutgers Ives Hurry, a retired New York real estate man, who was a descendant of Gen. Wil liam Floyd, a signer of the Declaration of Independence for New York, died Wednesday at his home in Saugerties, N. Y. His age was 87.

title: Notes on McNamara Memorandum For Johnson After Vietnam Visit
description: Excerpts from notes accompanying the Pentagon study, from memo randum for President Lyndon B. Johnson from Secretary McNamara, Nov. 1965.

title: Sports of The Times
description: MIAMI BEACHWe go back to the water this week end in lakes and pools across the United States, a million men standing on the tip of the board high above the pool, feeling the eyes of the women and children anticipating the leap and the splashdown. It is a wet moment of glory for the office manager, the waiter, the ad man.

title: Mild Setback for Sato
description: Premier Sato had expected that the signing of the longawaited treaty with the United States for the return of Okinawa to Japan next year would bring gains for his party in the parliamentary election. Instead, the voters administered a mild rebuff to the ruling LiberalDemo crats, who lost slightly while all opposition groups except the Komeito (Clean Government) party made gains elections for half of the upper house.

title: RAIL UNION SETS STRIKE ON 3 LINES
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  The railroads and the United Transportation Union took ac tions today that may result in another nationwide rail shut down on July 16.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Leary Is Arrested By Swiss Police; Extradition Sought
description: GENEVA, July 1Dr. Tim othy Leary, wanted in the United States after escaping from prison, has been arrested in Switzerland, a United States Embassy spokesman said early today.

title: 35,000 JOIN STRIKE OF COPPER INDUSTRY
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 1 (AP)More than 35,000 copper workers in 11 states stayed off their jobs today after a strike was called last midnight against the Big Four copper producers.About 200 representatives of 26 unions called the strike at a nonferrous metals union con ference here.The conference was called after two months of separate contract negotiations with the Big Four producersKennecott in Phoenix, Ariz. Anaconda in Salt Lake, Phelps Dodge in Tucson, Ariz., and American Smelting and Refining in Den ver.The struck plants have oper ations in Texas, Idaho, Wash ington, New Jersey, Maryland, New Mexico, Nevada, Nebraska, Utah, Arizona and Montana.The key issue is work rule changes, especially with Ana conda and Kennecott, union spokesmen said. Most negotia tors left for home today and no new talks had been sched uled.

title: Sir Lawrence Bragg, 81, Dies; Nobel Physics Laureate in '15
description: LONDON, July 1  Sir Lawrence Bragg, the Nobel Prizewinning physicist who with his father discovered the method of determining the structure of crystals by Xrays, died today in Ipswich Hospital. He was 81 years old.

title: Dixon Signs Delinquency Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) President Nixon signed to day a bill to extend for one year the Juvenile Delinquency Prevention and Control Act of 1968. The measure increases from 65 to 75 per cent the Fed eral Share of grants for the pro gram.

title: Bus Strike in Bronx Halts Express Runs to Midtown
description: Thousands of residents of the Parkchester housing proj ect and CoOp City in the Bronx were without express bus service to Manhattan's midtown area yesterday when 180 bus operators and mechan ics went on strike.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bill Allowing Return of Wampum to Indians
description: ALBANY, July 1Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill that provides: for the return of five Indian wampum belts held by the state since 1898 to the Onondaga Nation of the Iroquois Confederation.

title: PHONE RATE RISE OF 12.5% GRANTED
description: ALBANY, July 1  The State Public Service Commission ap proved a $190million tempo rary increase today in New York Telephone Company rates. The new rates will increase average consumer costs by about 12.5 per cent.

title: Memo on Pentagon Meeting Following Up Honolulu Session
description: Excerpts from memorandum by Richard C. Steadman, special assistant Secretary of Defense McNamara, Feb. 9, 1966, summarizing a Pentagon meet ing after the Honolulu talks. According to Mr. Steadman the participants eluded the Secretary, his deputies, the secretaries of each of the armed services and other Defense Department officials.

title: Impetuous Senator Maurice Robert Gravel
description: Man in the News

title: U. S. Aide Says Pullout Will Benefit Vietnamese
description: QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, June 30Marco Mendez, the senior American adviser in Quangtri Province, the South Vietnamese province closest to the demilitarized zone, says he thinks it will be a good thing for the Americans to leave here even if the 10,000 North Viet namese troops later seize con trol of the province.

title: Advertising:
description: The American Advertising Federation has ended its an nual convention in Hawaii but not without electing some new top dogs.

title: SCHOOL AID SUITS SET FOR 6 STATES
description: The American Jewish Con gress and the American Civil Liberties Union announced yes terday that they would sponsor court suits in six states to halt state aid to parochial schools.

title: Bank Combination Begins
description: The combination of the Kings Highway Savings Bank and the Franklin Savings Bank in the City of New York under the name, Franklin Savings Bank of New York, became effective yesterday. The $1billion insti tution has seven offices in Manhattan, two in Brooklyn and one in Nassau County.

title: Teamsters Union Sued
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) Don Vestal, an insurgent can didate for president of the In ternational Teamsters union filed a $150million damage suit today against the incumbent president, Frank E. Fitzsim mons, and other officers, charg ing mismanagement of the un ion's financial affairs. Mr. Ves tal, president of Teamster Local 327 in Nashville, filed the suit in Federal District Court.

title: Garrison Links Arrest to a Move To Hide Kennedy Death Truth
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 1Dis trict Attorney Jim Garrison says that his arrest yesterday on Federal charges of accept ing bribes to protect gamblers is part of the Government's ef fort to suppress the truth about the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: The Screen:
description: Nicholas Roeg's Walk about, which opened yester day at the Plaza Theater, is a very sincere movie that evokesespecially, I suspect, in the minds of sophisticates nostalgia for an innocence that probably never existed. Its sympathies are with the simple folk, but the tech niques by which those sym pathies are demonstrated are so fancy they remind me of things like heated swimming pools and safaris in aircon ditioned Cadillacs.

title: New Yorker Is Released After Belfast Arson Trial
description: BELFAST; Northern Ireland, July 1A threemonth trial for a New York press photographer ended in a Belfast court to day when he was found not guilty of charges of arson and throwing fire bombs at Queens University.

title: POSTAL SERVICE WELCOMED HERE
description: Under darkening skies that threatened to erupt any moment, a celebration was held at noon yesterday outside the General Post Office at Eighth Avenue and 33d Street to mark the inauguration of the United States Postal Service.

title: Steinkraus Wins Abroad
description: AACHEN, West Germany, July 1 (UPI)  William Steinkraus, of Westport, Conn., won the Theo dore Roechling trophy today in a faultless twohorse jumping performance at the Aachen rin ternational horse show. He rode Snowbound and Fleet Apple around the 800meter course in an overall time of 107 seconds.

title: A Connecticut Income Tax Voted, With Veto Unlikely
description: HARTFORD, July 1  The, General Assembly early today, adopted a state income tax. It is expected to become law next Thursday.

title: Survey Faults Children's TV in U.S.
description: A survey of children's pro grams in 16 countries shows that the United States is the only major country that does not have network programs for bhildren on weekday after noons.

title: U. S. Wightman Team Named
description: LONDON, July 1 (UPI)Bob Colwel, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Associa Lion, designated today the six women who will be on the Wightman Cup squad.

title: 2 Magazine Concerns Told To Cease Deception Here
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs obtained an order in State Supreme Court yesterday barring two maga zine subscription sales con cerns in Des Moines, Iowa, from employing deceptive prac tices in selling periodicals to New York residents.

title: Most Powerful Atom Smasher Warms Up on FourMile Track
description: Construction of the world's most powerful atom smasher, a machine that may disclose the innermost nature of mat ter, has been completed, and the breakingin process has begun.

title: HOSPITAL CLOSINGS UPHELD ON APPEAL
description: The Appellate Division re versed yesterday, a lower court ruling that had tempor arily prohibited the closing of two state institutions for the mentally retarded and the transfer of their patients to the Willowbrook School on Staten Island.

title: 3 ESCAPE AS A SUB SINKS IN BRITISH PORT
description: GOSPORT, England, Friday, July 2 (AP)The British sub marine Artemis sank at its mooring here yesterday and its threeman watch was trapped in a forward compartment with a 24hour air supply, the navy said.

title: Social Workers Get Chief
description: Mitchell I. Ginsberg, former City Human Resources Admini strator and now the dean of the Columbia University School of Social Work, took office yester day as president of the Na tional Association of Social Workers, a 52,000member pro fessional organization. Mr. Ginsberg succeeds Dr. Alan D. Wade, dean of the Sacramento State College School of Social Work.

title: NATO Papers Recovered Alter Sale in Norway
description: OSLO, Norway, July 1 (AP) A filing cabinet crammed with topsecret documents of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was sold recent ly by the Norwegian Army, but the papers have been recovered, a Defense Min istry official said today. He spoke on television, confirm ing the report first made by the Oslo newspaper Verdens Gang.

title: Metropolitan Spotlights Contemporary Collections
description: In an age of frequent art heists, most New York col lectors are happy to lend their collections to the Met ropolitan Museum of Art during the summer, when they're away. The Metro politan serves them as a kind of security vault as well as a prestigious showcase with the best of custodianship. At the same time, the public has a chance to see private collections it otherwise wouldn't see.

title: Starstruck Fashions Out of the Forties
description: Shop Talk

title: Three More Steel Makers Planning Layoffs
description: Three more major steel com panies announced yesterday that they would lay off blue collar workers, in most cases because orders for summer de livery were lower than ex pected.

title: A REPORT ON ISRAEL CLARIFIED BY BAYH
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 1 (AP)  Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, has issued a statement of clarification re suiting from what he said was misinterpretation of his re marks at a news conference here Monday.

title: Summary of Knapp Panel Report
description: The Commission to Investigate Alleged Police Cor ruption yesterday issued the following summary of its findings:

title: Senator Hart's Son Jailed
description: ST. IGNACE, Mich., July 1 (AP)James Hart, the 20year old son of Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, pleaded guilty to a charge of illegal use of marijuana today and was sentenced to pay a $200 fine and serve 20 days in jail. The youth was arrested Tuesday night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: OutofFashion Psychic Bids Prove to Be 2Edged Sword
description: Psychic bids, aimed at de ceiving opponents while run ning the risk of misleading one's partner, have been out of fashion for many years.

title: On the Morality of the War
description: DETROITThe military involvement of the United States in Southeast Asia is more than a hotly debated political issue. Vietnam is an urgent moral question demanding an examination by all thinking Americans. That war is always a moral matter should be clear enough. Political and military policies which provide soldiers and weapons for the purposes of death and destruc tion require a moral judgment of the individual citizens with whose tax money and, in some cases, very lives those policies are implemented.

title: F.T.C. Demands Cigarette Ads Include Clear Danger Warning
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  The Federal Trade Commission moved today to force the coun try's six major cigarette manu facturers to include clear and conspicuous health warnings in their advertisements.

title: COLUMBIA'S CREW FIRST AT HENLEY
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, Eng land, July 1There are sev eral new faces at Henley this year, and the British, with their propensity for the traditional way of doing things, are having a time adjusting to the un familiar. The victory yesterday of Columbia University's light weight crew went unnoticed in the British press, but today after Columbia beat the London Rowing Club, a semifinalist last year, in a heat of the Thames Cup, it was impossible not to rank Columbia as one of the favorites for Saturday's final.

title: Priests of Vietnam
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.In Paris re cently I concelebrated mass with two Catholic priests from North Vietnam. It was a memorable experience for me and several other American priests to join in the official liturgy of the church with those whom our Govern ment considers the enemy.

title: ROBERT J. WHALEN
description: OSSINING, N. Y., July 1 Robert J. Whalen, a stockbro ker with Fahnestock & Co., member of the New York Stock Exchange, died at his home yes terday. He was 49 years old and lived on Robin Drive here.

title: Newark Gets U.S. Funds To Set Up an Ombudsman
description: Mayor Kenneth Gibson an nounced yesterday that Newark had received the nation's first Federal grant to establish the office of an ombudsman with power to investigate all city agencies.

title: Final Part of Route 84 Is Opened to Traffic
description: ALBANY, July 1 (AP)The final section of Interstate Route 84 in New York State was opened to traffic at noon today.
