description: Excerpts from memorandum by Assistant Secretary of Defense McNaugh ton, Some Paragraphs on Vietnam, third draft, Jan. 19, 1966, as provided the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the analysts' para phrase or explanation.

title: Knapp Says Mayor Shares Blame for Corrupt Police
description: The head of the Commission to investigate Alleged Police Corruption said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay as chief execu tive officer cannot escape responsibility for widespread corruption the panel found in the Police Department.

title: The Proceedings. In the U.N. Today
description: July 2, 1971

title: Four With 67's Set Pace By Shot in Canadian Golf
description: MONTREAL, July 1  Rolf Deming, a former University of Minnesota mathematics teacher, put together a fiveunderpar 67 today and shared the first round lead of the Canadian open golf championship with three others.

title: Week's G.I. Death Toll One of Lowest of War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 (AP)The continuing disengagement of American forces from the war zone was reflected again today in the United States command's weekly casualty summary, which reported 21 Americans killed in action last week.

title: White House Is Exploring Offer Made in Paris Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The White House began explor ing today the possibility that the latest Vietcong proposal at the Paris peace talks might form the basis for serious negotiations to end the war in Vietnam.

title: TYING AID TO CURB ON DRUGS OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI)  The State Department re jected today proposals pend ing in Congress to cut off foreign aid to nations refusing to curtail production and dis tribution of illegal drugs.

title: U.S. Detonates Atom Bomb
description: MERCURY, Nev., July 1 (AP) A lowyield atom bomb was detonated 900 feet beneath the Nevada desert today, the third shot in two weeks since under ground testing was resumed after a sixmonth suspension. Testing was suspended after a test shot leaked radiation de tectable over 13 states.

title: HOUSE, 343 TO 14, CLEARS JOB BILL BACKED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 1With a belated push from President Nixon, the House cleared to day, 343 to 14, and sent to the White House a $2.25billion measure to create up to 200, 000 emergency jobs in public service.

title: Amy Radwell Is a Bride
description: MALVERNE, L.I., July 1 Miss Amy Lynn Radwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Radwell, was married at the Malverne Jewish Center tonight to Charles Franklin Entelis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lester Entelis. Rabbi Harold Saperstein performed the ceremony. The bride is a 1971 graduate of Vassar College. Her father is a former presi dent of the Radwell Metal Company of Mineola. The bridegroom, a medical stu dent at the University of Vir ginia, was graduated magna cum laude from Wesleyan University. His father is a dentist.

title: STOCKS SLOW UP TO TAKE BREATHER
description: The stock market settled for a small gain yesterday after Tuesday and Wednesday pro duced the best backtoback ad vance of 1971.

title: Turkey's Poppy Curb Is Assessed
description: News Analysis

title: O'Tooles Head Cast in 'Murphy's War'
description: How long has it been since you've seen a new movie, not some television rerun, that takes you inside a U-boat when the fatal depth charge strikes? The bursting tanks, the frantic crew, the guttural cries of throats straining against the roar of the water rising higher and higherthere is perhaps no form of man's inhumanity to man quite so emotionally satisfying to the death lust of the normal moviegoer than the instant preparation of a watery grave for the predators to whom, until that second, submersion had meant safety.Some of the emotional satisfaction (though not exactly the situation) carries over into parts of Peter Yates's "Murphy's War," which opened yesterday at the Music Hall, and which has Peter O'Toole as Murphy, the sole survivor of a World War II torpedo attack, using whatever means at his disposal to wreak single-handed vengeance on the German U-boat that sank his ship and then methodically gunned down the helpless crew.The means include a battered seaplane that Murphy does not know how to fly, an oil company's motor barge and crane and one-lung boat, and the very meager resources, of a medical mission located on the South American river that the submarine has made its secret port of refuge. Against Murphy are the pacifism of the mission's Quaker doctor (Sian Phillips), the lassitude of the oil company's man on the spot (Philippe Noiret), and time itselffor the war is ending, and with it will end the official rationale for revenge.The rationale for revenge takes a beating even before the war has ended, for "Murphy's War" pales over its decent adventure story with the sickly cast of second thoughts and some heavy irony about the senselessness of killing. Now, it so happens that most of the killing in the movie, though dreadfully brutal, makes perfect sense  for the U-boat, to maintain its secrecy; for Murphy, to pay them back. And when the movie, undercuts the impluses behind its action, as it does a little, the humanitarianism on the surface begins to look cheap and the savagery beneath to seem rather noble.The sense of a film in which nothing quite works with anything else pervades "Murphy's War," and it extends from such crucial technical details as the sloppy and finally tedious cross-cutting between things (the seaplane, the motor barge, etc.) and the people who are supposed to be operating them, to the playing together of the principal actors."Murphy's War" is blessed with a very fine cast  that is quite simply never allowed the time or the involvement with one another to make an ensemble performance. This works especially against the excellent Peter O'Toole and Sian Phillips (who is in life the excellent Mrs. O'Toole), who treat each other with interesting complex respect when they get the chance but who rarely get the chance. Most of the time they are kept as far apart physically as ideologically, while she yells across a courtyard, a dock, a river, "Mr. Murphy!," and he, never catching what she has to say, screams back in his best Irish brogue, "Missus?"

title: Frazier Slates Exhibition
description: HOUSTON, July 1 (UPI)  The world heavyweight cham pion, Joe Frazier, signed, with Texas Boxing Enterprises today to stage a fourround exhibition bout July 14 in the Astrohall.

title: Sales of New Issues Spur TaxExempt Bond Prices
description: Taxexempt bond prices advanced yesterday in response to the quick sales this week of several major new issues. As a result, The Bond Buyer yield index declined to 6.19 per cent from 6.23 per cent week ago. If this indicator was calculated before the suc cessful offering of Delaware, Kentucky, Philadelphia and Jackson County, Mo., bonds, it would have been 6.30 per cent or a bit higher, some traders guessed.

title: Chadds Ford Museum Extends Visiting Hours
description: The New Brandywine River Museum in Chadds Ford, Pa., where an exhibition of work by the Wyeths is installed, will be open seven days a week to accommodate a grow ing number of visitors.

title: State Department Memorandum In November on Bombing Pause
description: Following are texts of key documents accompanying the Pen tagon's study of the Vietnam war, covering the period late 1965 to the summer of 1966. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents are printed verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.

title: Back and Forth on the Economy
description: The Nixon Administration continues to march uphill, downhill and sideways on wageprice policy. On Tues day Secretary of the Treasury Connally emerged as the President's economic spokesman to announce that he isn't going to institute a wageprice review board and he isn't going to impose mandatory wage and price controls. Wednesday Press Secretary Ziegler announced that the President was summoning steel company execu tives and labor leaders to the White House to discuss the steel industry's position in the world and, inci dentally, its wage negotiations. Current wage contracts expire Aug. I.

title: Today Show Plans Look. At New Spiritual Fervor
description: The National Broadcasting Company's Today show will present next Thursday a two hour special Turning On to Jesus, featuring scenes from Godspell, the Off Broadway rock musical based on the Gospel according to St. Mat thew.

title: VISIT BY C.I.A. CHIEF TO ISRAEL IS ENDED
description: TEL AVIV, July 1 (AP) Richard Helms, the United States Director of Central In telligence, left Tel Aviv today after a threeday visit to Israel.

title: Notes From McNamara Memo On Course of War in 1966
description: Excerpts from notes accompanying the Pentagon study, from a memo randum for President Johnson from Secretary McNamara, Military and Political Actions Recommended for South Vietnam, Dec. 7, 1965, and notes on revision of the memo, Jan. 24, 1966.

title: The RockefellerLindsay Letters
description: The Dear John letters from Governor Rockefeller Mayor Lindsay and the Mayor's rapier responses, each quickly released to the press in a scramble for the next day's headlines, hardly compare in political significance to the AdamsJefferson letters. Nor do they have exactly the literary quality of the ShawCampbell exchange. To be frank about it, they are peevish, bitter and strictly ephemeral.

title: ELIZABETH JOHNS, OFFICIAL AT U.N.
description: R. Elizabeth (Betty) Johns, a leader in church and social action fields here and abroad, died Wednesday in St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. She was 59 years old and lived at 549 West 123d Street.

title: Yonkers Futurity Trot Seems WideOpen Race
description: YONKERS, July 1As June turned to July today, the thoughts of many local harness racing fans turned to tomorrow night's $110,795.62 Yonkers Fu turity Trot at Yonkers Race way. Most were in agreement that this 17th edition of the onemile classic, which this season kicks off the series for the triple crown of trotting, looms as the most wide open futurity since Delvin Miller's Duke of Decatur won the 1960 test and returned $82.

title: Johnson's Remarks to Officials Of U.S. and Saigon at Honolulu
description: Excerpts from remarks by President Johnson to senior United States and South Vietnamese after the issuance of a joint communiqu at their Honolulu conference, Feb. 9, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. The paragraph in italics is the study's explanation.

title: Turco Defense Rests Case In Black Panther Murder
description: BALTIMORE, July 1Clos ing arguments began late today in Baltimore Criminal Court in the trial of Arthur F. Turco Jr., a white New York lawyer charged with being an acces sory in the torture and murder two years ago of a suspected police informer.

title: Market Place: Usinga Bank's Trust Service
description: Let's say that it is time to face the inevitable. You are looking ahead to the time when you will be dead. Naturally, you want to ar range for your estate to be handled in a wise and effi cient manner.

title: Meo and Thai Drive Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 1 (Agence FrancePresse)  In formed sources reported today that Laotian troops and Thai volunteers were taking advan tage of the rainy season to re occupy areas lost to the enemy earlier this year in the northern part of the country.

title: Pennsy Increases Its Cash Balance
description: The Penn Central Transporta tion Company ended June with a cash balance of $51.4million, or $24million more than had been forecast, when the trus tees on May 28 filed a condi tion statement with the Inter state Commerce Commission.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SAPPORO, Japan, July 1 (AP)  Saijo pounded out a unanimous 10round decision tonight over Ray Vega, a Mexi can lightweight, in a nontitle bout. There were no knock downs. Saijo weighed 131 pounds, Vega 129.

title: Experts See $20Billion Deficit in New Fiscal Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  The Federal Government start ed a new fiscal year today, faced with the prospect of two consecutive budget deficits in excess of $20billion.

title: More Troop Requests
description: Another important factor in Secretary McNamara's disenchantment during the summer of 1966, the Pentagon, ac count declares, was. General Westmore land's continual requests for more troops.

title: PUBLIC CABLE TV HAS BLOCK PARTY
description: Cable television's public chan nelsthe ones the public will have free or virtually free ac cess tobecame available yes terday in Manhattan in char acteristic New York fashion.

title: NEW POSTAL SETUP GOES INTO EFFECT
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The semiindependent United States Postal Service assumed control of the nation's mail system today amid labor difficulties, court challenges and the pos sibility of another rate increase for thirdclass mail.

title: Cable TV: 2Way Teaching Aid
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan., July 1Jeff Hubert, 17 years old, who has been confined to his home after a series of brain tumor operations, took a history lesson here today, beginning an experiment that promises in time to turn an ordinary television set into a much more versatile commu nications device.

title: Concert Opens Arts Site Near Capital
description: VIENNA, Va., July 1  With Mrs. Richard Nixon in attendance, the inaugural concert of the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Perform ing Arts went on as sched uled. To many who were en gaged in the frantic rush to get the installation ready for opening night, the opening was something of a miracle.

title: Heavy B52 Raids Reported
description: SAIGON, Friday, July 2 (AP) Seven waves of United States B52's attacked North Viet namese positions just below the demilitarized zone yester day in the heaviest concen trated raids since last August, the United States command said.

title: Baritone Horn Player, 18, Shows Skill
description: The baritone horn, a kind of preshrunk tuba, is not the first instrument that comes to mind at mention of The Carnival of Venice, that piece being the trumpet's traditional showstopper. But Dunstan Patrick Morris plays it on the baritone so well that he recently won first prize in a highschool musi cians' competition sponsored by the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts and the Music Chairmen's Association of the Public Schools of New York City

title: Harold M. Kennedy Dead at 75; U.S. Judge and Attorney Here
description: Harold M. Kennedy, a former Federal judge and United States Attorney of the Eastern District of New York, died yes terday in the New York In firmary after an illness of six weeks. He was 75 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

title: Books of The Times
description: Lately, people had been asking the re viewer to recommend some nice relaxing books to take on vacation with me. But the reviewer found himself reluctant to answer them. He had never much believed in vacation reading lists, suspecting as he did that the urge to compile or read them was connected more with fantasies of the vacation than the real thingwith visions of hammock and beach that left out of the picture sand, family responsibilities and other interferences. Besides, the re viewer was a secret puritan and thought that if people actually were going to read on vacation, they should read the impor tant stuff they hadn't gotten around to beforeTolstoy, Proust, Gibbon, the com plete works of James Fenimore Cooper, the best books of last winternot special lazy books. In fact, now that he stopped to think about it, the reviewer loathed vacation reading lists, not to mention the prose that usually went into them (Here's a diverting little ax murder to tickle you on a rainy afternoon...).

title: Finding Jobs for Welfare Clients Off to a Slow Start on First Day
description: The state's efforts to get em ployable welfare recipients to work got off to a slow start yesterday, with most of those reporting to state employment offices here simply being inter viewed and registered for jobs.

description: To the Editor:

title: Screen: The Red Angel
description: If you can stand it, by all means see The Red Angel, the new entry in the Japa nese festival at the Bijou Cinema. Not in years, and even in black and white, has the screen projected such pitilessly stark canvas of anatomical and bloodspat tered human agony. Be pre pared.

title: Reserve Plans Tough Rules on Control of Banks
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday proposed tough new regulations to define what con stitutes control of a bank under the terms of the bank holding company legislation passed by Congress last year.

title: U.S. Aid for Hunts Point Center To Go On Despite Audit Report
description: The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said yesterday that it would con tinue to finance the Hunts Point Multiservice Center despite an audit showing that the South Bronx antipoverty project could not account for more than $1.6million in Federal funds.

title: Zoo Pact Averts Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (UPI) Some 140 animal keepers and grounds and building mainten ance personnel at the Phila delphia Zoo voted today to ac cept a new oneyear contract, thereby averting a strike that had threatened to shut down the zoo on its 97th anniversary.

title: 5 AMEX OPERATIONS GET STAFF CHANGES
description: The American Stock Ex change announced yesterday a series of staff changes designed to strengthen the reporting and control of five major operating units under a centralized opera tions function, to create a new policy planning and Govern ment relations division and to increase regulatory effective ness.

title: Cable From Westmoreland In August on Manpower Needs
description: Excerpts from cablegram from General Westmoreland to Gen. Earle G. Wheeler Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp, commander in chief of Pacific forces, Aug. 10, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

title: Seltzer on the Tables, Tradition in the Kitchen
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their service, atmosphere and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Muskie, in Texas, Scores Nixon on Economy
description: DALLAS, July 1  Senator Edmund S. Muskie made the first appearance of his unan nounced Presidential campaign in Texas today and took aim on the issue many Southerners would like to see him stress the economy.

title: QUARTER NET UP AT GENERAL TIRE
description: The General Tire and Rub ber Company increased earn ings in the second fiscal quar ter ended May 31, bringing earnings for the half slightly ahead of the yearearlier pe riod.

title: Dutch Club Is a Mecca for U.S. Youths
description: AMSTERDAM June 24 The young Americans surge into the Paradiso each eve ning, silently watching the psychedelic lights shimmer across the dance floor and listening to a musical, group shriek, Turn, turn, turn.

title: We Must Get Out, Not Sometime, but Now!
description: AMHERST, Mass.  The American people are being asked to believe that Vietnamization is working, and that within the foreseeable future we will be able to bring all our farces home. It must be realized, however, that this dubious possibility is contingent upon our being able to leave in Saigon strong government sympathetic to our purposes, a result we have been un able to achieve through seventeen years of unremitting effort.

title: Botulism Death in Westchester Brings Hunt for Soup
description: The death of a Westches ter County man Wednesday night, apparently from bo tulism, and the serious ill ness of his wife has precipi tated a nationwide search for 6,444 cans of vichyssoise marketed under the Bon Viv ant label.

title: Leading U.S. Military Planners
description: William Childs Westmoreland

title: ROBERT J. FREEDMAN, A TENNIS CHAMPION
description: Robert J. Freedman, an ama toter tennis player, industrialist and art collector, died at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. He was 51 years old and lived at 120 East 71st Street and in Springfield, Mass.

title: CUP NATIONS DROP CHALLENGE ROUND
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 (AP) Representatives of the Davis Cup nations decided unanimously today to abolish the Challenge Round in the in ternational tennis tournament.

title: Lawyer Marries Olivia d'Ormesson
description: Miss Olivia d'Ormesson and Manley O. Hudson Jr. were married in a civil ceremony yesterday at Ormessonsur Marne, France, before the Mayor, Count Olivier d'Ormes son, the bride's father. The two witnesses, required by French law, were Count Wladimir d'Ormesson, grand father of the bride, a former French Ambassador to the Vatican and a member of the Academie Franaise, and Pierre Hottinguer.

title: Peking Criticizes Soviet
description: HONG KONG, July 1The 50th anniversary of the found ing of the Chinese Communist party passed quietly in Peking today with only a joint editorial in the major publications to mark the event.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL TO TRAIN DOCTORS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  A bill authorizing $2.8billion to help train more doctors and other health professionals in the next three years was passed today by the House, almost without opposition. The vote was 343 to 3.

title: Bombing and a Pause
description: In April, 1965, when President John son secretly changed the mission of the Marines at Danang from defense to of fense and thus commited the United States to the ground war in Vietnam, the sustained bombing of North Vietnam was relegated to a secondary role, the Pentagon study declares. Discussing this bombing campaign, known as Operation Rolling Thunder, the study adds:

title: British Act to Retain Titian Sold to Getty; $3Million Needed
description: LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) The National Gallery moved tonight to prevent J. Paul Getty from becoming the owner of the world's most ex pensive Titian painting, The Death of Actaeon.

title: Symbol Takes Center Court
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 1  Evonne Goolagong once told an Australian sports columnist that she had stopped reading newspaper stories about, herself because they all began with, the same word, aboriginal.

title: Roundup: Indians Hand Orioles 6th Loss in 8 Garnes, 32, on Homer in
description: The Baltimore Orioles' pitching staff, which seemed among the best in the major leagues just a week ago, has wilted badly under recent pressure and has permitted the Boston Red Sox an extra chance to contend for the American League's Eastern Division pennant.

title: Waterfront Chief Installed
description: Richard J. Vander Plaat, 55 yearold former Mayor of Fair lawn, N.J., took office yester day as New Jersey's Commis sioner of the Waterfront Com mission of New York Harbor. Mr. Vander Platt and Joseph Kaitz, reappointed as New York's Commissioner, will serve threeyear terms. It will be the fourth term for Mr. Kaitz. Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey appointed Mr. Vander Plaat to succeed Stephen J. Bercik of Elizabeth, N.J., whose term ex pired June 30. They will receive $28,000 a year.

title: SUMMATIONS OPEN AT NEWARK TRIAL
description: NEWARK, July 1Lawyers for the eight defendants in the Hudson CountyJersey City exfi tortion conspiracy trial in Fed eral Court here began their summations this afternoon, at tacking the evidence presented by the Government against their clients in seven weeks of testimony.

title: Miss Herlth Wed. To John G. Ingram
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., July 1Miss Katharine Elizabeth Herlth was married here this afternoon to John Girard In gram at. St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Bradford Johnson.

title: Egypt Holds First Elections To Reconstruct Political Group
description: CAIRO, July 1Egyptians danced and chanted slogans in the streets today, giving a fes tive character to elections to rebuild the country's only polit ical organization, the Arab So cialist Union.

title: A Secret Seminar
description: During the summer of 1966, while Secretary McNamara was pondering the failure of the oilstorage strikes and considering General Westmoreland's latest troop request, a secret seminar of leading scientists under Government sponsorship was studying the overall results of Operation Rolling Thunder.

title: Water Curb Lifted in Florida
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., July 1 (UPI)Restrictions on water use in the southeastern Florida coastal areas were lift ed today because of adequate rainfall in June, The area's 2.5 million residents were asked last May to refrain from water ing their lawns and washing their cars because of the drought.

title: DR. MILTON PROCTOR
description: PORTLAND, Me., July 1 Dr. Milton D. Proctor, retired president of Westbrook Junior College here, now known as Westbrook College died today in the Veterans Administration Hospital at Togus. He was 83 years old.

title: BRITAIN TERMS PACT WITH MALTESE VALID
description: LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) Britain today rejected an as sertion by the Maltese Govern ment that the 1964 defense agreement with Britain no longer existed.

title: Education Voucher Plan. Making Slow Progress
description: The Federal Government's plan to experiment with edu cation voucher systems in a few willing communities  al most given up for dead a few months agois now making slow headway in a handful of localities on both sides of the continent.

title: Nonunion Guards Hired for Beaches As Holiday Nears
description: Negotiations between strik ing lifeguards and the Long Island Park Commission re mained at a standstill yester day, and the commission moved to provide protection for bath ers at the four affected beaches over the July 4 weekend.

title: Indonesia Is Finding New Basis for Hope
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 26I wouldn't have believed it, said an Indonesian student who returned to his country this month after six years of study in Europe. I got back here, and for the first time (I thought to myself that maybe we can make it.

title: Rare Cranes Hatched
description: ITHACA, N.Y., July 1 (UPI) Three whitenaped cranes have been hatched in Cornell Uni thology, the first successful hatchings reported of these birds in the western world in more than 20 years. A uni versity, the first successful that five more eggs were in incubation. There are reported ly fewer than 2,000 such birds in the world.

title: Hanoi Hails Chinese Party
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 1 (Agence FrancePresse)The Hanoi press today gave promi nent treatment to the 50th an niversary of the Chinese Com munist party and published on its front pages the text of a message of congratulations.

title: ALICE T. MASON, 67, ABSTRACT PAINTER
description: Alice Trumbull Mason, an artist whose smallscale ab stract paintings have been exhibited at several major museums, died Monday, appar ently of a heart attack, at her home, 334 West 85th Street. She was 67 years old, and was the wife of Capt. Warwood E. Mason.

description: Merger News

title: JAPANESE IMPOSE CURB ON TEXTILES
description: TOKYO, July 1 (Reuters) Japanese textile leaders today warned against disorderly competition for quotas as the textile industry began applying selfimposed restraints on its exports to the United States.

title: Books of The Times
description: COLLECTED STORIES. By Mary Lavin. With an introduction by V. S. Pritchett. 425 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $8.95.

title: Minnesota Asks to See Pentagon Study in Court
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 1  The Minnesota Attorney Gen eral asked the Federal Gov ernment today to bring all 47 volumes of the Pentagon study into court.

title: Walter Wolfner, ExDirector Of Football Cardinals, Dies
description: ST. LOUIS, July 1 (UPI)  Walter Wolfner, former manag ing director of the St. Louis football Cardinals, died here last night at the age of 73.

title: Interest Rates Increased For Large Bank Deposits
description: Interest rates on large bank deposits were raised yesterday amid gathering signs that a general increase in the prime lending rate on business loans from its present 5 per cent is in the immediate offing.

title: Stale Ruling on Abortion Agency Upheld
description: The Appellate Division yes terday upheld two lowercourt rulings relating to abortions.

title: U.S. Air Strike on Rocket Sites Reported in Foe's Part of DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, July 2 (UPI)  Nineteen United States planes reportedly have attacked part of the North Vietnamese side of the demili tarized zone in an attempt to destroy enemy rocket sites that have been firing at allied bases for two weeks.

title: Gibson Names Youth, 17, To Newark School Board
description: NEWARK, July 1Lawrence Hamm, who led the drive for greater student involvement in the running of the city school system during the Newark teachers' strike, was seated to day as probably the youngest Board of Education member in the country at the age of 17.

title: McNaughton Memo for McNamara On AntiInfiltration Barrier Plan
description: Excerpts from a memorandum to Secretary of Defense McNamara, A Bar rier Strategy, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. According the narrative, the memorandum is unsigned but is by Assistant Secretary Defense McNaughton, in whose handwriting the copy is marked 1/30/66 and copy given to RSM 3/22/66. The study further says that the document is based on a draft memo of Jan. 3, 1966, A Barrier Strategy, by Prof. Roger D. Fisher of Harvard Law School.

title: Salyut Crash Foreseen
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 1 (Reuters)  The Salyut space ship, now circling the earth, will crash back to earth on July 23 unless its orbit is raised, the United States Air Force re ported today.

title: Ohio Paper 100 Years Old
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 1 (UPI)The Columbus Dispatch celebrated its 100th anniversary today with a 100page com memorative edition. Among the 100 pages was a reproduction of the original first page of The Daily Dispatch of July 1, 1871.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Emily Whiting Is Bride Of Neil L. Whittelsey
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 1Miss Emily Jane Learned Whiting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Royal G. Whiting, and Neil Leonard Whittelsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Souther Whittelsey, were married here this morning.

title: U.S. Announces Biggest Single Vietnam Pullout Yet
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 The United States today announced the largest single withdrawal of American troops since the phased pullouts began two years ago.

title: Copper and Silver Show Price Rises On Strike Report
description: Copper and silver futures prices soared yesterday on the Commodity Exchange (Comex) here as a result of a strike by domestic copper workers. Silver is a byproduct of copper mining.

title: Louise Gengler Subdues Jennifer Louis for Net Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 1  Louise Gengler of Locust Valley, L. I., defeated Jennifer Louis of Rye, N. Y., 64, 75, at Fairview Country Club to clay in the final of the 18year old division of the girls' East ern clay courts tournament.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AAnglers search ing for bluefish have been thriving at night as well as during the day. Choppers up to 15 pounds are, being re ported by the Began Basin fleet at Manasquan Inlet. The blues are showing interest in smelts, bunker backs and but terfish. One angler was re ported with 100 blues Tues day night on Bogan's Ja maica. Fluke are still being captured off the Bay Head area while sea bass have been in evidence at the Klondike off Spring Lake.

title: South Korean Eases Stand on China
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 1  President Chung Hee Park, who was sworn in today for his third term as South Korea's chief of state, gave his coun trymen as well as a visiting American delegation headed by Vice President Agnew a quali fied endorsement of President Nixon's efforts to improve re lations with China.

title: Judith Bruce, Radcliffe Alumna, Married to Glenn H. Greenberg
description: Miss Judith Bruce and Glenn H. Greenberg, a grand son of Mrs. Bernard F. Gim bel of Greenwich, Conn., and New York, and the late Mr. Gimbel, who was chairman ofthe board of. Gimbel Broth ers, Inc., were married here yeterday afternoon.

title: HENRY R. LEVY
description: CHICAGO, July 1Henry R. Levy, a retired Chicago indus trialist, died of pneumonia to day in Michael Reese Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: DRAFT BOARDS TOLD TO CONTINUE WORK
description: WASHINGON, July 1 (ap) The Selective Service Di rector, Dr. Curtis W. Tarr, or dered states today to continue all draft procedures except call ups until Congress renews the draft law that expired last mid night.

title: ELLEN ASSERTS OTHERS AIDED HIM
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 1  Dr. Daniel Ellsberg said to day that other individuals, whom he would not identify, had assisted him in distributing to the press the secret Penta gon papers on Vietnam. He said that he was the primary source for all the newspapers that have published articles based on the documents.

title: AUTHOR'S KILLING OF G.I. DESCRIBED
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., July 1 A 16yearold Negro girl testi fied today that Jesse Hill. Ford, the white novelist, shot and killed a Negro soldier after Mr. Ford found the girl and the sol dier in a darkened car parked on his driveway last Nov. 16.

title: Thunderstorms Ease Heat, but Black Out Many Homes
description: Severe thunderstorms pass ing through the city and sub urbs yesterday knocked out electrical power in some areas and brought a sharp drop in the temperature.

title: City Fails in Bid to Block Law Providing for Decontrol of Rents
description: New York City lost in State Supreme Court yesterday its fight to have the State's Va cancy Decontrol Law, which became effective yesterday, set aside as unconstitutional and injurious to the city's interest.

title: Store Sales Advance
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales for the latest week ended June 26 totaled an esti mated $795,000,000, an in crease of 21 per cent above the $657,000,000 in sales for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the same period were an estimated $7,710,000,000, an in crease of 7 per cent above the $7,203,000,000 in sales for the same period last year.

title: Senators Win, 31, From Yanks
description: WASHINGTON, July 1For a lastplace team in financial straits, the Washington Sena tors have been building a lot of selfesteem lately at the ex pense of the New York Yank ees. They did it again tonight Mien Jim Shellenback  who hasn't beaten anybody else all seasonpitched them to a 31 victory over the Yankees.

title: 4 Pirate Hurlers Top Mets, 30;
description: John McCarthy earns less money than most baseball players, but he and his 25man ground crew at Shea Stadium worked harder yesterday than either the Mets or the Pirates in Pittsburgh's 30 triumph.

title: Parachute Jump Gets No Bidders
description: The city put the abandoned parachute jump at Coney Is land up for sale yesterday, but found no takers at any price,

title: Rostow's Memo on Bombing Of Hanoi's Petroleum Facilities
description: Excerpt from memorandum from Walt W. Rostow, Presidential assistant for, national security, to Secretary of State Rusk and Secretary of Defense. McNamara, May 6, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Para graphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: Dr. Arthur W. Grace, 77, Dies; An Expert in Tropical Medicine
description: Dr. Arthur W. Grace, a scien tist and educator who made major contributions to research in the field of tropical medicine, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 25 East End Ave nue.

title: Russians Mourn Soyuz 11 Astronauts
description: MOSCOW, July 1  Thou sands of people waited today in a line that stretched for miles through Moscow streets to pay their last respects to the three Soviet astronauts who died yesterday.

title: PAUL JEAN TIMBAL, A BELGIAN BANKER
description: Paul Jean Timbal, a Belgian banker who played a leading role in the cloakanddagger rescue of millions of dollars worth of diamonds from the Nazi invaders in World War II, died in Brussels on Monday. He was about 70 years old.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell 02 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials fell to 108.7 from 108.9 last week.

title: Priests and Nuns Discover Yoga Enhances Grasp of Faith
description: SOUTH WOODSTOCK, Conn., July 1At dawn one day earlier this week on the campus of Annhurst College a 37yearold woman sat motionless on a red and white striped mat deep in meditation.

title: George Dvorjitsky Is Dead; Public Works Engineer, 81
description: George C. Dvorjitsky, a for mer lieutenant commander in the Imperial Russian Navy, who retired in 1961 as a construction engineer in the City Department of Public Works, died Wednes day in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 97 Fort Washington Avenue.

title: Turkey, Charging Agitation by the Kunds, Quiets an Ancient Town on the Tigris With Martial Law
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey, June 23  Until two months ago, tempestuous feuds among farm ers here were settled with pis tols, women kept away from the main streets of this ancient walled fortress on the Tigris River and sensible city men also avoided the center of town.

title: VIETCONG OFFER TO TRADE P.O.W'S FOR MAT IN '71
description: PARIS, July 1  The Viet namese Communists announced at the peace talks here today that they were ready to re lease all war prisoners they hold in North and South Viet nam by the end of this year if all American troops are with drawn by then.

title: Annual Exodus to Summer Camps Starts at Port Authority Terminal
description: Hot on the heels of Wednes day's last day of public school here, children by the busload headed for summer camps in the cooler hinter land yesterday morning.

title: CAPITAL IMPORTS LOOMING FOR U.S.
description: PARIS, July 1A secret working paper of the Organiza tion for Economic Cooperation and Development sees the United States as a capital importing country by 1975, playing a role usually reserved for the poorer nations of the world.

title: Vietnam Bombing Evaluation By Institute for Defense Analyses
description: Excerpts from report by Institute for Defense Analyses, The Effects U.S. Bombing on North Vietnam's Ability to Support Military Operations South Vietnam: Retrospect and Prospect, Aug. 29, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: Appellate Court Reinstates Policeman's Indictment
description: The Appellate Division de cided unanimously yesterday to reinstate a fourcount indict ment against. Police Lieut. Francis X. Ward that was dis missed last February by Su preme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin.

title: Dow Sets Price Increase
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it had raised prices on three forms of potas sium bromate, effective imme diately. For example, list prices for potassium bromate in gran ular and powdered forms were increased by 5 cents a pound in carloads and truckloads, from 59 cents to 64 cents a pound.

title: Dominican Republic Exiles Wessin for a Second Time
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini cart Republic, July 1 (UPI) Elias Wessin y Wessin, a re tired brigadier general who led Dominican conservative forces in the 1965 civil war, was ex iled today for the second time.

title: U.S. SURPLUS BUTTER IS FREED FOR EXPORT
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today the release of Governmentowned surplus but ter for unrestricted export to meet a shortage in most con suming nations.

title: Saijo Wins Nontitle Bout As W.B.A. Lifts His Crown
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 1 (AP) The World Boxing Associa tion said today it was with drawing its recognition of Shozo Saijo of Japan as feath erweight champion because he failed to defend his title within the group's championship rules.

title: The FuelDepot Issue
description: During the spring of 1966, the Pen tagon study says, the question of bomb ing North Vietnam's oilstorage tanks became a major policy dispute.

title: I.O.S. DISSIDENTS GET 2 OF 27 SEATS
description: TORONTO, July 1In an acrimonious annual meeting that began at 11 A.M, yester day and dragged on until late afternoon today, the manage ment of I.O.S., Ltd., retained control of the Genevabased financial conglomerate. How ever, insurgents who waged a proxy fight captured two of the 27 board seats.

title: Amity With China Possible, Soviet Says
description: MOSCOW, July 1The So viet Union, in a fresh assertion of its desire for improved re lations with China, said today that the longterm interests of the two countries did not clash.

title: Cairo Editor Says Egypt May Renounce Peace Aim
description: CAIRO, Friday, July 2  Mohammed Hassanein Heykal Cairo's most authoritative edi tor, warned today that Egypt might renounce her declared commitment to a peaceful set tlement with Israel and submit a new war strategy at an Arab summit conference.

title: GEORGE W. OXLEY
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 1 George W. Oxley, an authority on corrosives and an engineer for 36 years with the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died last night of a heart at tack at his home. He was 80 years old and lived at 1115 Galloping Hill Road.

title: Text of the Vietcong Peace Proposal
description: PARIS, July 1 (Reuters) Following is the text of the Vietcong's sevenpoint peace proposal presented at today's session of the Vietnam peace talks:

title: Miss Judith Klaperman Wed on L.I.
description: LAWRENCE, L.I. July 1 Miss Judith Reems Klaper man; daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Gilbert Klaperman, and Harold Goldman of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Goldman of Passaic, N. J., were married this even ing, in Congregation Beth Sholom here by the bride's father, its spiritual leader.

title: Doubts Start to Emerge
description: The ineffectiveness of Rolling Thunder and General Westmoreland's mounting demand for troops soon began to create doubts among the Vietnam principals, the Pentagon study says. During the pause in the bombing, both Mr. Mc Naughton and Secretary McNamara wrote lengthy memorandums outlining the change in their feelings.

title: Executive Indicted in Payoff inquiry
description: The defendant is Miison Lip kins of 35 Sutton Place South, whose brother, Sidney, serves as president of Broadway Main tenance, which has held mil lions of dollars in, city con tracts to maintain street lights and other electrical services for many years.

title: BOLD REASONING UPSET IN JERSEY
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 1 (AP)I Found Gold won the $12,000 WRLB Purse at Mon mouth Park today, scoring by threequarters of a length over the previously undefeated 3 yearold, Bold Reasoning, who was the 15 favorite.

title: Voting Age Affects Boards
description: ALBANY, July 1The reduc tion in the voting age to 18 also applies to school board elections, a state official said today. Robert D. Stone, coun sel for the State Education De partment, declared that the broad language of the amend ment is clearly applicable to all annual and special school dis trict meetings and elections in New York State, including elec tion of school board members, budget votes and votes on bond issues and other propositions, including votes for any of these purposes.

title: Pentagon Papers: Vietnam Study Links '65 '66 G. I. BuildUp to Faulty Planning
description: The Pentagon's secret study of the Vietnam war indicates that the rapid expansion of American forces in 1965 and 1966 occurred because no one really foresaw what the troop needs in Vietnam would be and be cause the ability of the enemy forces to build up their effort was con sistently underrated.

title: Opening in Paris?
description: The Communist offer to release all prisoners of war if the United States agrees to withdraw its forces from Vietnam by the end of this year may open the way to a breakthrough at the Paris peace talks.

title: MARKET NEARING MONETARY ACCORD
description: BRUSSELS, July 1Finance Ministers of the Common Mar ket moved nearer to agreement tonight on a plan to increase flexibility of the monetary sys tem.

title: OpenEnded Strategy
description: When President Johnson decided in July, 1965, to accept General Westmore land's request for 44 combat battalions and to endorse his searchanddestroy strategy, he left the U.S. commitment to Vietnam openended, the study, declares.

title: BULLETS FOUND AT JOHNSON HOME
description: A box containing cartridges identical to ones used in the shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was shown to newsmen yes terday by detectives who found it among the effects of Jerome A. Johnson, the man the police say shot the reputed Mafia chief.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: REFUNDING SET FOR EURODOLLARS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reu ters)The Treasury announced today it will refund $1.5billion of Eurodollar certificates dated April 9, 1971, and maturing July 9.

title: Two Slacks Makers File Petitions Under Chapter XI
description: Two New York manufactur ers of slacks and jeans filed pe titions yesterday in the United States District Court for the Southern District for rearrange ments under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bank ruptcy Act. The Chapter XI proceedings are a voluntary form of seeking a financial ar rangement.

title: DECISION ON PAPERS IS HAILED IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, July 1  All major newspapers here gave the Su preme Court decision on The New York Times and Washing ton Post banner headlines and devoted several pages to ex tensive analysis of the issues involved.

title: Rescue Unit Seeks Million For Pakistani Intellectuals
description: The International Rescue Committee began a $1million fundraising campaign here yes terday to help doctors, teachers and other intellectuals who have fled from East Pakistan to India.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Triumphs With an 81 for 54Hole 232
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 1Mrs. Walter Cooperstein, of Glen Oaks, scored an 81 for a 54hole 232 today and won the championship trophy of the women's Long Island Golf As sociation annual tournament, over the 5,480yard, par72 Creek Club course. Mrs. James Keresey of the Creek Club won low net honors at 210 and Mrs. William Eakins, Creek Club, won the putting competition, with 91 strokes on the green.

title: I'm For Mama Takes Aqueduct Dash by 1 Lengths andPays $16.20
description: I'm For Mama won: the fea ture event of six furlongs at Aqueduct yesterday under sound ride by Jamie Arellano. Taking the lead at the start, then yielding it briefly, I'm For Mama showed speed all the way to score by 1 1/2 lengths over Mrs. Lawrence Knapp's Royal Signal, with Michael Phipps's Gay Missile next in he field of nine fillies and mares.

title: Strip Mine Attack
description: As the strip miners attack the land of Appalachia, slashing and gouging trees, rocks and topsoil in their search for coal, conservationists are desperately mount ing a counterattack. In West Virginia a publicinterest law firm is seeking administrative action and, if nec essary, intends to file a suit aimed at forbidding strip mining throughout the entire drainage basin of Coal River.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: July 1, 1971

title: New Volunteer Agency Made Official by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)President Nixon signed into being today his new vol unteer agency called Action and said it was particularly fitting that it should begin operations the day after the 12yearold vote became a reality.

title: Notes on People
description: With a peace symbol hanging around his neck on a golden chain and an American flag pinned on his lapel, Sammy Davis Jr., the entertainer, was named to the National Advisory Coun cil on Economic Opportunity by President Nixon in a White House ceremony.

title: Lord Constantine, Cricket Star And the First Black Peer, Dies
description: LONDON, July 1Lord Con stantine, Britain's first black peer and a former international cricket star, died today of a heart attack at his home here. He was 69 years old.

title: Appeals Court Overturns Dismissal of 2 Patrolmen
description: The Appellate Division voted unanimously yesterday to over turn the dismissal of two pa trolmen accused of protecting gamblers.

title: Theater: Shakespeare Returns to Park
description: Free Shakespeare is back in Central Park, so summer must have started. The sea son by Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater officially opened on Wednesday at the Delacorte Theater. The play was Timon of Athens, and its choice may be, in the eyes and ears of many peo ple, the season's first error.

title: Indians Ousted After Clash At a Nike Site in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) Twelve Indians were arrested and about 80 others fled their makeshift camp on an aban doned Nike missile site today after park workers called on the police to help them remove a fence surrounding the lake front property.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: The weather and a general Hick of interest resulted in sharply curtailed trading on the American Stock Exchange yes terday. Prices opened higher but eased during the day to close mixed.

title: Leo Fuchs to Star in Musical
description: Leo Fuchs has been signed to star in a YiddishAmerican musical comedy that Jacob Jacobs plans to open at the Eden Theater, Second Avenue and 13th Street, in the fall. Mr. Fuchs last appeared on Broad way in Cabaret.

title: MISS DAVIS TO MEET WITH SOLEDAD TRIO
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 1 (UPI)Angela Davis and Ru chell Magee will be allowed to confer three times with the so called Soledad Brothers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hundreds of Black Hold Protest Rally in Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 1 (Reuters)Hundreds of plac ardwaving black students staged a demonstration against racial discrimination outside Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's offices today as British and Rhodesian negotiators con tinued talks on an independ ence settlement.

title: Ballet: Pillar of Fire
description: Antony Tudor's dramatic ballet, Pillar of Fire, is now almost 30 years old. It has always remained a favorite with American Ballet Thea ter audiences, but it would only be fair to say that lapses in performance have occa sionally given it a dated look.

title: Contempt for the Constitution
description: First Amendment guarantees of press freedom, re affirmed this week by the Supreme Court, have again come under governmental attackthis time by a com mittee of Congress.

title: House Unit, 2513, Votes to Cite C.B.S., Stanton for Contempt
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The House Commerce Committee voted today to press a con tempt of Congress citation against the Columbia Broad casting System and its presi dent, Dr. Frank Stanton, for re fusing to cooperate with a Congressional investigation of the controversial documentary The Selling of the Pentagon. The vote was 25 to 13.

title: Rights of Atheists To Adopt a Child Upheld in Jersey
description: TRENTON, July 1The New. Jersey Supreme Court ruled to day that a couple could not be denied adoption rights sim ply because they were atheists.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Burmah Oil Company, Ltd., yesterday ap pointed J. A. M. Lamsden as chairman. He succeeds the late R. P. Smith. N. J. D. Williams, who had been managing director was named chief executive offi cer. Burmah recently terminated merger talks with the Continental Oil Company. The merger if it had come to fruition would have been the largest merger in the history of the oil industry, with com bined assets of the companies totaling $5billion. The majority of its income is derived from dividends from its share holdings in British Petroleum Company, Ltd.

title: Wellington's Funds Showed $3Million Net June Sales
description: The Wellington Management Company reported yesterday that its mutualfund group registered net sales of $3.14 million last month, in contrast to net redemptions of $3.57 million during May, when the industry as a whole slipped into a negative sales position for the first time.

title: Japanese Invest in U.S. Securities
description: Individual Japanese inves tors, permitted yesterday to purchase foreign stocks for the first time since World War II, had no discernible effect on stock markets here, according to specialists in Wall Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: C.C.C. to Sell Subsidiary
description: The Combined Communica tions Corporation of Phoenix, Ariz., announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell the Phoenix Publishing Company, Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of C.C.C., to Kenneth A. and Anita J. Welch. Phoenix Publishing owns Phoe nix Magazine, founded by Mr. and Mrs. Welch, and Outdoor Arizona. Mr. Welch is president of Phoenix Publishing.

title: SAIGON NETWORKS SHUN DISCLOSURES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1The radio and televi sion networks here, which are controlled by the Government, have virtually been directed to ignore all mention of the con tents of the Pentagon papers.

title: Highlights of the Period
description: The United States military effort in Vietnam, according to the Pentagon study, continued to intensifyboth on the ground and in the airthroughout 1965 and well into 1966, despite con tinuing evidence that this escalation was bringing an acceptable outcome no closer to realization.

title: Kentucky Fried Chicken Corp. Is Charged in Suit With Fraud
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 1 (AP)  A Dallas realestate de veloper has filed suit in Del aware Superior Court against the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation for allegedly using fraud and misrepresentation In its dealing with the concern, Unit, Inc., in order to illegally manipulate the price of its stock.

title: Liquor Law Takes Effect, But No One Is Sure How
description: A new state liquor price law goes into effect today and, as one customer moaned, It's enough to drive you to drink.

title: August McNamara Memo to Chiefs Challenging Troop Request
description: Memorandum, CINCPAC CY 1966 Adjusted Requirements & CY 1967 from Secretary McNamara to the Joint Chiefs of Staff Aug. 5, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

title: Curbs in Proxmire Bill Threaten Lockheed's Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Sen ator William Proxmire, Demo crat of Wisconsin, introduced today his own highly restrictive version of legislation that would provide Government guarantees of bank loans to companies whose failure would hurt the national economy.

title: $50,000 for 936567
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., July (UPI)The winning number in this week's New Jersey State Lottery was 936567. Persons holding a ticket bearing this number win $50,000. The num ber was drawn this afternoon at Freehold Raceway.

title: A London View of U.S. Presidents and Their Trials
description: The following is excerpted from commentary by The Economist of London:

title: The Clergyman: Still a Source of Counsel to His Congregation
description: In the last decade, the direction of the church has changed in varying de grew, but one factor has remained im mutable. Clergymen of every faith have retained their role as the court of first resort for the problems of their parish ioners.

title: Advertising:
description: Just when you begin to think that the entrepreneurs of print must have run out of ideas, a new concept hits the scene.

title: Mitchell Will Prosecute Law Violations in Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, July 1At torney General John N. Mitchell said today that the Justice De partment was continuing to investigate the leaking of the Pentagon papers and he prom ised to prosecute anyone who had broken the law.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe interesting thing about this stage of Chile's revolution is that President Allende, who has yet to make a false step on his remarkable zigzag road to Socialism, is manag ing to retain the appearances of proper relations with the United States, the reality of steadily improving relations with Russia, and the full support of the Chilean Communist party although that party is not allowed to play leading role.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rose 12% in Week From 1970
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended June 26 totaled an estimated 15.7 billion tonmiles, 1.2 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

title: Joint Chiefs' Order to Begin Bombing of Hanoi's Oil Facilities
description: Joint Chiefs of Staff's cablegram to Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp, commander in chief of Pacific forces, June 22, 1966, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

title: Poverty Programs In Brooklyn to Get $10Million Grant
description: A $10million grant from the Federal Office of Economic Op portunity for the BedfordStuy vesant economic development programs was announced yes terday by Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: ARTS ENDOWMENT MAKES 49 GRANTS
description: Grants to 49 individuals and groups in the jazz field have been announced by the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington. The grants totaled nearly $50,000 and were award ed in five categories, as follows:

title: Connally Favors a SelfReliant U.S. Economy
description: DALLAS, July 2 (AP)Amer ica has to sort out her own troubles and cannot expect a helping hand from the nations she helped out of their war devastation 25 years ago, Treas ury Secretary John B. Con nally Jr. said today.

title: U.S. MINES BUREAU SCORED AT HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The United States Bureau of Mines came under a barrage of criticism today, including a charge that many of its of ficials regard coal as more val uable than the lives of miners.

title: Brazilian Police Release Becks After Drug Raid
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 Julian Beck, founder of The Living Theater, was reported tonight among those released by the police after a drug raid in Ouro Preto, a town about 300 miles northwest of here.

title: Abu Dhabi Gets 1st Cabinet
description: ABU DHABI, July 2 (Reuters) The first Cabinet in the his tory of this Persian Gulf sheik dom was sworn in here today in the ruler's palace. The 16man Cabinet was appointed yester day, and informed sources said a new set of laws reorganizing the Government would also be announced soon.

title: I.L.O. Finds Sex Bias in Jobs in Europe
description: GENEVA, July 2It's still a man's world as far as the Eu ropean working woman is con cerned, the International Labor Organization said today.

title: Syrians Break Off Talks Over Oil Pipeline Royalties
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 2 Syria has broken off negotia tions with the Westernowned Iraq Petroleum Company in disagreement over royalties for allowing pipelines to cross her territory.

title: 2 Convicted on Securities
description: A socially prominent Atlanta lawyer and a Brooklyn busi nessman were found guilty in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of transporting securities worth more than $350,000, which we're stolen! from Francis 1. Du Pont & Co. in 1970. The convicted defend ants are 49yearold Robert A. Blackwood of Atlanta and 63 yearold Tobias Cohen of Brooklyn. They will be sen tenced Aug. 11, when they appear before Judge Constance Baker Motley.

title: Sports of The Times
description: If you met Jim Bouton on the street, asked him what's been happening since Ball Four, then found a quiet place to listen for several hours, you would probably come away with something very much like I'm Glad You Didn't Take It Personally (Morrow, $5.95). Bouton and his editor, Leonard Shecter, are as frank, jolly, indelicate and shrewd about the American Broadcasting Company Eyewitness News team, publishing a hestseller and meeting with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn as they were about the Yankees, the Astros, Mickey Mantle and Baseball Armies. While they have become richer and more famous since Ball Four, they have not, thank goodness, found humil ity or propriety

title: CHARGE BY ENEMY REPORTED HALTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 (AP)  Three hundred North Vietnamese reportedly charged up a mountain near the demilitarized zone last night but were turned back short of their objective, the artillery outpost at the top called Fire Base Fuller.

title: Authority on the Brain Named M.I.T. Provost
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 2  Dr. Walter A. Rosenblith, an authority on sensory com munications and brain func tion, has been named provost of the Massachusetts Insti tute of Technology. He suc ceeds Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, who became M.I.T.'s presi dent yesterday.

title: Influx of Foreign Investments In Taiwan, Drops for Quarter
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 2The influx of foreign investment in Taiwan declined in the first quarter of 1971 for the first time in more than a decade.

title: John Denver Shows Sensitivity and Style In Bitter End Songs
description: John Denver, the folk singer, is appearing at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street, where he is showing a significant matu ration since his appearance here a year ago.

title: Gen. Ridgway's Son Killed On Canoeing Trip in Canada
description: PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP) The son of retired Army Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway was killed today in an accident while on his way to a canoeing trip in Canada, a friend of the family said.

title: Dying Woman Wins Court Plea to Stop Terminal Surgery
description: MIAMI, July 2 (UPI)  A daughter, appointed guardian of her mother by a judge, ac ceded today to her pleas against the torture of more surgery, although it is all that can save her.

title: JURY PONDERS FATE OF TURCO IN KILLING
description: BALTIMORE, July 2The case of a white New York law yer charged with being an ac cessory to the torture and mur der of a suspected Black Pan ther police informer went to the jury in a Baltimore Criminal Court late today.

title: Miss Goolagong Wins at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2Evonne Goolagong won at Wimbledon today. The 19year old daughter of an Australian aboriginal sheepshearer won the AllEngland women's ten nis championship on the sto ried center court by defeating the great Mrs. Margaret Court. The margin by which she de stroyed her 28yearold Aus tralian opponent defies belief.

title: Wall's 4UnderPar 67 for a 137 Total Leads Canadian Open by One Stroke
description: MONTREAL, July 2  Art Wall Jr. demonstrated today that members of golf's old guard can still play the game. With a 67, the low score of the second round, the 47year old Wall led the Canadian open championship field with a 36hole aggregate of 137.

title: Germany Shapes Controls On Eurodollar Borrowings
description: BRUSSELS, July 2West Ger many intends to impose con trols on the borrowings of its companies in the international dollar market, Economics and Finance Minister Karl Schiller said today.

title: N.Y.U. Dance Unit Winds Up 2d Week With Typical Zest
description: The N.Y.U. Dance Ensemble concluded its second week of programs Thursday evening at the School of The Arts theater with the bouncy enthusiasm that has characterized the se ries.

title: The G.I. Pays
description: The decision of a HouseSenate conference to cut nearly a billion dollars from a $2.8billion military pay raise may represent a victory for the budgetmakers but a defeat for lowranking servicemen who were to have been the principal beneficiaries of the increase. The con ference committee's action is an affront to substantial majorities in both houses who voted the full amount.

title: Bus Terminal Awash With Travelers
description: The weekend that people at the Port Authority Bus Ter minal talk about all year ar rived yesterday.

title: Joint Chiefs' Memo Disputing McNamara View on Bombing
description: Excerpts from Joint Chiefs of Staff memorandum, signed by Gen. Earle Wheeler, Chairman, to Secretary of Defense McNamara., Oct. 14, 1966, as pro vided in the body of the Pentagon study.

title: Braves Top Mets, 32, on Homer; Yanks Halt Red Sox Streak, 60
description: Gil Hodges, who became an honorary medical doctor earlier this week, should now become a professor and teach a course in remedial baserunning.

title: William Bundy's May 30 Memo On Reasons for U.S. Involvement
description: Excerpts front memorandum from Assistant Secretary of State Bundy, Circu lated at State and Defense Departments, May 30, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase explanation.

title: Notes on People
description: Bernadette Devlin, North ern Ireland's militant civil rights leader and, at 23, the youngest member of the Brit ish Parliament, said yester day that she was pregnant.

title: Historians Find Fresh Answers With Tools of Social Science.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 2 A new scholarly publi cation, The Journal of Inter disciplinary History, was or ganized last year to provide an outlet for new approaches in research, and its first three quarterly issues carry some unusual fare for historians.

title: May Building Outlays Stayed at April Level
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Total construction expendi tures in May were essentially unchanged from the high April level, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Talk
description: It's getting so that the summer hostess need hardly step in the kitchen any more. Now she can arrange everything from a Greek wedding feast, complete with bou zouki music and dancing waiters to an Italian cestino, or picnic, to an ice cream making party with hardly more than a phone call to one of several new catering services. In addition, theatergoers can order lunch boxes with such sophisticated contents as cold steak au poivre, chicken roulade and Grand Marnier souffle to be picked up at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater. And weekend guests can bring a house gift of a specially aged, prime cut of beef not available in most butcher shops.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fist Fights Disrupt Peace Rally Here
description: Fist fights and brawling erupted continuously among participants at a peace rally last night, interrupting speech es, including one by a United States Senator who actively op poses the war.

title: Screen: Soul Gumshoe
description: Shaft is a New York pri vate eye with a shabby office in midtown, a duplex in the Village, a wad of bills (and no small change) to tip with, a working lovehate relation with the cops and friends all over the city. He is also black. When Bumpy Jonas, chief hood in Harlem, tells him that his teenaged daughter has been kidnapped and he sus pects that militants have done it, Shaft takes the case more for $50 an hour than for any love of Bumpy. The case turns out to be a bit complex, a major gang war with racial overtones, though, really, no racial undertones. But Shaft delivers Bumpy his girl. And to his pal, Police Lieut. Vic Androzzi, he de livers the still warm bodies of what seems to be virtually all the white half of East coast organized crime.

title: Vietcong Offer Poses a Dilemma
description: News Analysis

title: Indiana Standard Studies Congo Copper Occurrences
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)The Standard Oil Company of In diana announced today results of a geological study of cop per occurrences in the Fun gurume area in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

title: Republican Governor Urges Hatfield's Defeat in 1972
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 2 Gov. Tom McCall said in a tele vision interview made public today, that, it might be provi dent for the state of Oregon if his fellow Republican, Mark O. Hatfield, was defeated for reelection to the Senate next year.

title: World Bank Sets Loans
description: PARIS, July 2 (Reuters) The World Bank announced to day it had approved an $11.8 million 7 per cent United States dollar loan to Fiji.

title: Stocks on Amex Rise Slightly As Preholiday Pace Slackens
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed fractionally higher after drifting lower in extremely light preholiday trading through most of the session.

title: Joint Chiefs' April 20 Report To McNamara on Troop Needs
description: Excerpts from Joint Chiefs of Staff Memorandum 21867 to Secretary of Defense McNamara, April 20, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: Pentagon Papers: McNamara, in '66, Urged Bombing Cutback and Softer Peace Terms
description: Robert S. McNamara, while Secretary of Defense, sought to persuade President Lyndon B. Johnson in October, 1966, to cut back the bombing of North Vietnam to seek a political settlement of the war 17 months before Mr. Johnson made that move on March 31, 1968.

title: A LOSS FOR YEAR SHOWN BY VARO
description: Varo, Inc., makers of military hardware and electronic com ponents, suffered sharp losses in the fiscal year ended last April 30.

title: Dead Man Was Banker
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., July 2  Samuel Cochran Jr., who died on Wednesday as a result of eating soup containing a deadly toxin, was vice president in charge of the Fifth Avenue branch of the Bank of New York at 43d Street. He joined the bank in 1932.

title: McGeorge Bundy's Memorandum To Johnson in May on Bombing
description: Excerpts from memorandum for President Johnson from McGeorge Bundy, headed Memorandum on Vietnam Policy, as provided in the bddy of the Pentagon study. According to the study, the document bore no date but a copy was marked in pencil ree'd 5467 12n. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: Talks in Rhodesia Continue
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 2 (Reuters)British and Rho desian negotiators met secretly for the fourth day today to try to find a settlement of a dead locked dispute over Rhodesian independence, declared six years ago.

title: Ford to Switch Ad Assignment for 3 Car Lines
description: The Ford division of the Ford Motor Company will switch the advertising assign ment for its Pinto, Maverick and Mustang lines from the J. Walter Thompson Company. The new agency, Ford said, will be announced shortly.

title: City Hall Notes
description: LindsayforPresident talk is beginning to stir the Mayor's staff againand the Mayor, as well.

title: Dominican Air Force Chief Reported Seized as Plotter
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, July 2 (Reuters) The chief of the Dominican Air Force has been arrested, apparently in connection with a reported rightwing plot against the Government, Air Force sources said today.

title: HYDRO QUALIFYING PACED BY MUNCEY
description: MADISON, Ind., July 2Bill Muncey, a fourtime winner, led the qualifiers today for Sun day's 63d Gold Cup race with an average speed of 110.159 miles an hour and defied a jinx that has plagued unlimited hydroplane drivers since the season began.

title: DECEIT IN '64 RACE IS DENIED BY RUSK
description: ATLANTA, July 2  Dean Rusk, the former Secretary of State, said today that there was no deliberate attempt to deceive anybody about Ameri can involvement in Vietnam during the 1964 Presidential campaign of Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: MortgageLoan Total Rose. 5th Straight Month in May
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (Reu ters)  Mortgageloan commit ments in May totaled $3,488, 000,000, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Author Denies Intentto Kill Black
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., July 2 Jesse Hill Ford, whose thinly fictionalized bestselling novel about racial Injustice, The Liberation of Lord Byron Jones, angered both whites and blacks in this small west Ten nessee city, swore today that he was not even aiming his rifle when he shot and killed a Negro soldier on his property last Nov. 16.

title: Wood Balance Beam Helps Pupils Learn
description: Patents of the Week

title: Poconos' Oval Stages 500Miler Today
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 2 Mark Donohue, sitting on the pole, leads a pack of at least seven hotshot drivers, with the best chance of winning tomorrow's running of the Schaefer 500, the second round of the United States Auto Club's triple crown of 500mile races.

title: Virus Is Grown in Laboratory From Cells of a Cancer Patient
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Scientists in Texas have re ported growing large amounts of virus from cells taken from a cancer patient suffering from a variety of the disease long suspected of being virus caused.

title: PATRICK ROLAND
description: DULUTH, Minn., July 2 (AP) Patrick H. Boland, a former university and professional football coach, died today in a hospital here at the age of 64. He lived in Superior, Wis.

title: SCHOOL AIDES WIN ON VACATION CUTS
description: An arbitrator held yesterday that the Board of Education had acted improperly in re cently ordering a cut in the summer vacations of 300 to 400 school supervisors assigned to central headquarters and district offices.

title: A Fourth of July Sermon
description: WEST MEDFORD, Mass.Now that the anniversary of the Declaration of our Independence is again upon us with its customary oratorical flourishes it is a good time to take stock of our selves.

title: Avoiding Another Money Crisis
description: An uneasy quiet hangs over the international money markets. The German mark, cut loose from its peg of 27.3 United States cents in early May, is still floating. Within Germany, expectations have grown that the mark will float until there is some fundamental change in the world's monetary situation. The Germans are not anxious to repeg the mark while there is still a chance that hot money flows could recur. The Dutch guilder, the Belgian financial franc and the Canadian dollar are, like the mark, also floating. But other nations are still committed to pegged rates.

title: Governor of Oregon Vetoes Bill Regulating Farm Labor Unions
description: SALEM, Ore., July 2  Gov. Tom McCall vetoed today a bill regulating farm worker unions, two days after he was threat ened with a nationwide boycott of Oregon agricultural products if he signed it.

title: Laird Increases Security On Papers at Rand Corp.
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has ordered tighter secu rity measures at the Rand Cor poration following discovery by the Pentagon of deficiencies in the way the Private research institute has safeguarded secret information.

title: Japan's Surplus at Peak
description: TOKYO, July 2 (UPI)Japan registered a record balanceof payments surplus of $1,183,000 in May, the Finance Ministry and Bank of Japan jointly an nounced today.

title: 60,000 Doctors Quit Health Plans in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 2Japan's med ical system was in confusion today after some 60,000 doc tors withdrew from national health insurance plans covering 160 per cent of Japan's 105 mil lion people.

title: SOYBEAN HIGH SET, BUT CLOSE IS OFF
description: After setting new highs for the season, prices of soybean futures fell off sharply and closed lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Guthrie Leaves Mansion As Retreat for Artists
description: DUBLIN, July 2Sir Ty rone Guthrie, the director playwright who died here in May at the age of 70, has bequeathed his family man sion near Clones in County Monaghan and the major part of his estate as a re treat for working artists and writers of all countries.

title: 15DAYSUSPENSION ORDERED ON I.O.S.
description: TORONTO, July 2The On tario Securities Commission suspended all trading here to day in the common stock of I.O.S., Ltd., and began an in vestigation into events on stage and off stage at the Geneva based financial conglomerate's tumultuous twoday annual meeting here.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bill On ExtraDuty Firemen
description: Following are bill signings announced by the Governor yesterday:

title: Gulf United Nuclear Set
description: The formation of Gulf United Nuclear Fuels Corporation was announced yesterday by the United Nuclear Corporation and Gulf Energy and Environmental Systems, a division of the Gulf Oil Corporation. The company designs and manufactures nu clear fuel for commercial nu clear power reactors.

title: The 200,000 Request
description: The main catalyst for the sharp de bate in the Johnson Administration in the spring of 1967, however, was not the air war but General Westmoreland's request for 200,000 more troops.

title: American Museum at Bath Felicitated
description: BATH, England, July 2 The 9:40 from Paddington left six minutes late this morning With 250 diplomats and social figures for an all day American birthday party, British style.

title: Friend of Ellslierg Sentenced In Refusal to Answer Questions
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2An thony J. Russo Jr., a friend of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, was sen tenced to jail today for refusing to answer questions before a Federal Grand Jury that is in vestigating the release of a se cret Pentagon study on Viet nam. The sentence was stayed, however, pending appeal.

title: COLOMBO ATTACK LINKED BY POLICE TO A GANG PLOT
description: The nearfatal shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. on Mon day was an underworld plot, part of a struggle for preemi nence among certain segments of the ItalianAmerican com munity, a police spokesman said yesterday.

title: Replay of 1964?
description: The Administration's lukewarm reaction to the new Communist peace proposals in the face of what appears to be a deteriorating military situation in South Vietnam lends some weight to the fear expressed by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, selfacknowledged purveyor of the Pentagon papers, that the nation may be faced with a replay of the year 1964.

title: British Excursion Train Derails
description: CHESTER, England, July (Reuters)Two children were killed and at least 30 chil dren and teachers were hos pitalized tonight after two railroad cars left the track near this northwest city.

title: Dubcek Backer Sentenced
description: VIENNA, July 2 (AP)Vladi mir Skutina, a television pro ducer and writer who sup ported the reform regime of Alexander Dubcek, was sen tenced yesterday to four years and two months in prison, the Czechoslovak press agency C.T.K. reported.

title: Merger News
description: The Government suit chal lenging the April, 1969, merger of the Canteen Corporation into the International Tele phone & Telegraph Corporation was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Richard B. Aus tin in the United States Dis trict Court of Northern District of Illinois, Eastern Division.

title: New Trend of Policy
description: The climax for what the study calls the disillusioned doves came in Secre tary McNamara's May 19 memorandum to President Johnson, which marshaled the arguments against the strategy of widening the war and sharpened the case for curtailing the air war.

title: RoundTrip Youth Ticket to Luxembourg Announced
description: Icelandic Airlines announced yesterday a new roundtrip fare of $165 between New York and Luxembourg, effective Aug. 1, for passengers between 12 and 29 years of age.

title: Mrs. John B. Mulligan, 49, Active in Charity Drives
description: Mrs. Marie Louise Mulligan, the wife of John B. Mulligan, senior vice president of Maga zines for Industry, Inc., and publisher of Candy Industry magazine, died apparently of a heart attack at her home yes terday. She was 49 years old and lived at 1111 Park Avenue.

title: HERBERT H. HOLZMAN
