description: MILLBURN, N. J., July 21 Herbert H. Holzman, secretary treasurer of Holzman Hand bags, Inc., 162 Madison Ave nue, New York, died today of a hemorrhage in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 45 years old and lived at 51 Walnut Avenue.

title: MARCOS SUES TIME; $8MILLION SOUGHT
description: MANILA, July 2  Time magazine's properties and as sets in the Philippines were at tached today on orders of a Manila court pending determi nation of a libel suit for 50 million pesos, or $8.3million filed against Tune, Inc. by Pres ident Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: U.S. COURT REALIGNS DISTRICTS IN VIRGINIA
description: RICHMOND, Va., July 2 (AP) A special United States Dis trict Court panel entered an order today reapportioning the Virginia House and directing the City of Norfolk to choose its three Senators at large.

title: NAMES OF DIRECTORS NOT GIVEN BY BANK
description: Directors of the First Penn sylvania Company, parent con cern of the First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, ap proved yesterday the addition of three new members to their group. But, in an unusual ac tion, a spokesman for the company refused yesterday to make their names public.

title: South Africa Curbs Priest, Indicts Second Anew
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 2The South African authorities took stern action under the security laws this week against two Christian churchmen who have denounced apartheid.

title: Veeck Ends White Sex Ties
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)Bill Veeck's ties with the Chicago White Sox ended yesterday with the club's payment of $300,000 on a note that Veeck held since his syndicate sold the team in 1961.

title: Pappas, U.S. Businessman, Acquitted by Athens Court
description: ATHENS, July 3Thomas A. Pappas of Boston, a Greek American businessman, was acquitted in an Athens court tonight on charges of breach of trust, a misdemeanor. The de cision came at the end of a two day hearing.

title: F.C.C. Upholds 4 Networks In Detergent Ads Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Three New York television sta tions and one in Miami did not violate the Federal Communica tions Commission's Fairness Doctrine in broadcasting certain detergent advertisements, the F.C.C. staff has held.

title: 30 State Aides to Begin Audit Of City Departments Tuesday
description: ALBANY, July 2  Thirty state auditors will begin check ing the operations of seven New York City departments on Tuesday as part of a full fledged state audit of the city.

title: HighAltitude Decompression
description: Several American fliers have died because of highaltitude decompression such as that which, according to press re ports from Moscow, may have killed the three Soviet astro nauts.

title: Art: Quilts Find a Place at the Whitney
description: The history of American art in the 19th century is still, as a general rule, writ ten almost exclusively in terms of high artthat is, in terms of painting and sculpture created on the model of European prece dents. Yet the question re mains whether or not the native genius for visual ex pression found its most pow erful expression in such forms. In many quarters the suspicion persists that the most authentic visual articu lation of the American imagi nation in the last century is to be found in the socalled, minor arts  especially in the visual crafts that had their origins in the workaday functions of regional life.

title: Secretary McNamara's Position Of May 19 on Bombing and Troops
description: Excerpts from draft memorandum for the President from the office of Secretary of Defense McNamara dated May 19, 1967, and headed Future Actions in Vietnam. Text, provided in the body of the Pentagon study, is labeled first rough draftdata and estimates have not been checked. Para graphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: Tracing the Roots of Rock Music Proves Difficult at Folklife Fete
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Smithsonian Institution's five day Festival of American Folklife opened last night with a program tracing the sources of development toward rock music.

title: Nine in Church Rebellion Win Florence Legal Battle
description: FLORENCE, Italy, July 2 (Reuters)Five Roman Catholic priests and four laymen accused of having backed a rebellion against the Cardinal of Flor ence won a twoyear legal battle tonight when the public prosecutor said they were not guilty and asked the court to acquit them. The nine had been charged with instigation to commit crime and with disturb ing a religious ceremony.

title: A Pessimistic Report
description: For Mr. McNamara and his influential aide John T. McNaughton, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, the first frontal chal lenge to the basic trend of policy came in October, 1966, and grew out of doubts that had been mounting for nearly a year.

title: Komer Report to Johnson After February Trip to Vietnam
description: Excerpts from memorandum to President Johnson from Robert W. Korner his special assistant, Feb. 28, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: United Plans Excursion Fare Between 4 Cities and Hawaii
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) United Air Lines proposed to day to introduce standby ex cursion fares on Aug. 2 be tween four Middle Western and East Coast cities and Hawaii. The fares would be as much as 38 per cent below the reg ular round trip coach fares.

title: A Very Rare Document
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  We are ap proaching our country's 195th birth day. Now, at long last, while it is still a living document, all of us should quickly and reverently read the Amer ican Declaration of Independence from beginning to end. In that happy event, 98 per cent of us will be reading it for the first time. In the course of this first close acquaintance with the declara tion, the 98 per cent will find that they have been misunderstanding, misquot ing and misinterpreting the great docu ment for years. These mistakes have been tooled, died, mass produced, wholesaled and retailed throughout our population for so long that some sort of statute of limitations seems to have run against the general popular accept ance of the plain language and obvious meaning of the declaration itself.

title: U.S. Aides Going to Egypt, Seek to Spur Suez Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Two senior United States offi cials will fly to Cairo on Sun day in an attempt to give new impetus to the deadlocked con sultations on an effort to reach an EgyptianIsraeli agreement to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: Veeck Ends White Sex Ties
description: CHICAGO, July 2 (AP)Bill Veeck's ties with the Chicago White Sox ended yesterday with the club's payment of $300,000 on a note that Veeck held since his syndicate sold the team in 1961.

title: Four Movie Theaters Together To Open Wednesday in Queens
description: The first grouping of four separate film theaters under one roof ever erected in the metropolitan area, at Northern Boulevard and 160th Street in Queens, will open July 14. The houses, named the UA Quartet and owned and operated by the United Artists theater circuit, are a reconstruction of the cir cuit's former Roosevelt Theater.

title: Established Names in New Ventures
description: Two women who were fairly entrenched in the fashion business are heading in new directions for fall.

title: Books of The Times
description: SPECTATOR OF AMERICA. By Edward Dicey. Edited by Herbert Mitgartz. 318 pages Quadrangle. $7.75.

title: A MailOrder Crisis Is Cited by Business Bureau
description: Every year, thousands of average consumers eagerly send in checks and money orders for merchandise ad vertised by mail but, after a reasonable time, the goods are not received.

title: U.S. Aides Cautious On. Vietcong Offer For Ending the War
description: WASHINGTON, July. 2The Nixon Administration assumed an attitude of cautious skep ticism today toward the latest Vietcong proposal for a settle ment of the Vietnam war.

title: Antiques: 1876 Centennial Silver
description: American silver made for the Centennial Exhibition held in Philadelphia in 1876 includes a variety of inter esting forms that can be a challenge to find.

title: Bakery at the Vatican Is Closed Permanently
description: ROME, July 2The only bakery in the Vatican was closed permanently today in what appears to be a drive to end all commercial activi ties there.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Finds No Nerve Gas
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Navy says it has detected no contamination from obsolete nerve gas sunk off the Florida coast nearly a year ago. A spokesman said yesterday that the preliminary finding was based on water samples taken by scientists aboard the Navy oceanographic ship Mizar, which returned here last week end after three days in the area 283 miles east of Florida.

title: An Old Congress Hand Smooths Presidential Path to Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, June 27As the struggle over President Nixon's Social Securitywelfare reform bill neared a decisive vote, a relative newcomer to the White House staff sensed that a parliamentary issue could scuttle the Administra tion effort.

title: Highlights of the Period
description: OCTOBER, 1966

title: MANY OF MAFIOSI RESENT COLOMBO
description: The reports by police officials yesterday that the shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was the product of growing hostility among underworld organiza tions in New York come as no surprise to those familiar with Colombo's impact on the Mafia in recent years.

title: Bridge: Negative Doubles Are Helpful By Leading Foe to Anticipate
description: The modern fashion favor ing negative doubles certain ly solves many problems, but it also, permits the opponents to make unsound overcalls and escape disaster. On the diagramed deal East made a highly dangerous overcall of two clubs at unfavorable vulnerability.

title: Consumer Unit Gets Grant
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The Government has provid ed $150,000 to support a new Institute for Consumer Justice. The institute, formed to study procedures for resolving con sumer transaction disputes, will be a Washingtonbased, non profit organization working with the Office of Economic Legal Services Consumer Law Center at Boston College.

title: LOCKHEED, PAN AM GET U.S. CONTRACTS
description: Two financially troubled companies were awarded large military contracts yesterday.

title: MARKET IS MIXER IN SLOW SESSION
description: Stock prices finished on a mixed note yesterday as trad ing fell below 10 million shares on the eve of the long Inde pendence Day holiday. Stock exchanges will be closed Mon day.

title: U.S. Five Triumphs
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 2 (Reuters)  The American Big Ten Conference allstar bas ketball team sustained their superiority over a New South Wales team tonight with a 111 63 triumph. Mark Sibley led the scoring with 22 points.

title: Newsprint Barge Ordered
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, July 2 (UPI)MacMillan Bloedel, Ltd., announced today that it had given Allied Ship builders, Ltd., of North Van couver a $1.8million contract for an oceangoing newsprint barge. It is to be 363 feet long with a 7,200ton newsprint capacity.

title: Ottawa Warns on Cans
description: OTTAWA, July 2 (Canadian Press)The Health Department warned Canadians today against eating foods and sauces pro duced by Bon Vivant.

title: Poland Signs Pact to Buy Oil From British Concern
description: WARSAW, July 2Poland, whose growing oil needs have led her to seek supplies out side the Soviet bloc, has signed a 10year agreement with Brit ish Petroleum, Ltd.

title: Chinese Student Describes Her Life as a Peasant
description: YENAN, China, June 18 Miss Chou Yufung, an at tractive 21yearold student from Peking, has been work ing as a peasant in the ter raced fields of Yenan for the last two and a half years.

title: An End to The. Cries Of Despair
description: Every problem here triggers loud moral condemnations and exaggerated rhetoric. In the 1950's the conserva tives mounted a doomsday crusade against Communism, whipping up the people to paranoid extremes. Russia is about to attack the United States, people were warned. A nuclear war is about to be unleashed, the world is about to blow itself up...

title: Bahnsen Wins Eighth on a SevenHitter
description: BOSTON, July 2For the first time in almost 14 months, the Boston Red Sox were shut out in Fenway Park tonight when Stan Bahnsen pitched the New York Yankees to a 60 victory.

title: G.I. Guilty of Killing Officer
description: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July 2 (AP)Pfc. James D. Moy ler, 20 years old, of Chesapeake, Va., was convicted today of unpremeditated murder in the shooting of his commanding officer in January. He was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

title: Leary Is Expected to Ask Swiss for Political Asylum
description: GENEVA, July 2Dr. Timo thy F. Leary, the advocate of drug use, is expected to apply for political asylum in Switzer land to avoid extradition to the United States, usually wellin formed sources in Berne said today.

title: Indians Protest U.S. Arms
description: CALCUTTA, India, July 2 Nearly 1.5 million school and college students in the state of West Bengal stayed away from their classes today in protest against United States arms ship ments to Pakistan.

title: Severed Cable Cuts Off Power on City Island
description: A construction crane sev ered an underground cable near City Island Bridge in the Bronx last night and cut off power for 1,000 tele phones in Orchard Beach and City Island, firealarm boxes on City Island and the trans mitters of radio stations WNBCAM and WCBSAM.

title: DEFENSE ENDS CASE IN EXTORTION TRIAL
description: NEWARK, July. 2Lawyers for seven of the eight defend ants in the Hudson County Jersey City extortion con spiracy trial in Federal court here late today completed their arguments in summation of the case.

title: Russian Sprinters, Milers Defeat U.S.
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 2 For the second successive year, track and field athletes of the Soviet Union struck at the source of American pride by winning the 100meter dash and 1,500meter run in dual, competition.

title: Deanne Lemle Becomes Bride
description: Miss Deanne Joan Lemle, daughter of Henry Lemle and Mrs,., Edna Fuerth Lemle of New York and Honolulu, was married in Buitenpost, the Netherlands, yesterday to Robert Eric Bosnak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bosnak of Rotterdam, the Nether lands. The morning civil cere mony at the Mayor's office was followed by a religious ceremony performed by Rab bi Abraham Soetendorp at De Vrede, the couple's farm in Buitenpost, Where they plan to raise organic food.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: May 4 Memo on Force Levels By SystemsAnalysis Chief
description: Memorandum for Secretary McNamara, Force Levels and Enemy Attri tion, from Alain C. Enthoven, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Systems Analysis, May 4, 1967, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

title: Hijackers Identified
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) A Federal Aviation Adminis tration spokesman here identi fied the two hijackers as Robert Lee Jackson, 36 years old, and Lidia SanchezArchila. No in formation on their hometowns was available.

title: Offerings Few and Prices Firm In the NewStockIssue Market
description: The newissue market set tled into a quiet, steady pat tern this week following wide price swings in most of June.

title: Jobless Rate Off Sharply, But Doubt Is Cast on Data
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 The nation's unemployment rate dropped substantially in June but part of the reason was a statistical aberration, the Labor Department reported today. After adjustment of the data to eliminate the effects of purely seasonal changes, a particularly difficult adjust ment in June, the unemploy ment rate dropped to 5.6 per cent of the labor force. It was 6.2, per cent in May.

title: Indonesians Vote TodayOn 992 of 13,667 isles
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 2Indonesia holds her first national election in 16 years tomorrow something easier said than done.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose sharply in the Government's Weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities. The auction was advanced from Monday because of the Independence Day holiday.

title: 6th Sub Fires Poseidon
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 2 (UPI) The Casimir Pulaski became the sixth submarine to test fire the new Poseidon mis sile today when she shot one more than 1,500 miles to an, Atlantic Ocean target area. The 34foot rocket was launched while the submarine was sub merged about 30 miles east of Cape Kennedy.

title: Joint Chiefs Demur
description: The public position of the Johnson Administration opposed negotiating with the Vietcong or recognizing them. A proposal for political compromise from Senator Robert F. Kennedy on Feb. 19, 1966  that the Vietcong should be admitted to a share of power and re sponsibility in Saigon  had been quickly denounced by Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey. That, Mr. Humphrey said, would be like putting a fox in a chicken coop; soon there wouldn't be any chickens left.

title: Latrobe Chief Resigns; Successor Not of Family
description: The Latrobe Steel Company, a producer of tool and die steels, announced yesterday the resignation of Marcus W. Sax man 3d as president and chief executive officer. He is suc ceeded by Marshall Schober, the executive vice president.

title: Citywide Pop Concerts Bow on Monday
description: Two extended series of free outdoor concerts of popular music in many locations throughout the five boroughs of New York will begin next week.

title: Governor Wades Through Sea of mills
description: ALBANY, July 2While many politicians were getting an early start on the July, Fourth weekend, Governor Rockefeller spent a good part of his working day today closeted with his aides in New York City wading through 200 bills, some of the last remnants of the nearly 1,100 bills the Legigla ture left as its legacy when it adjourned June 8.

title: The Talk of Abu Dhabi
description: ABU DHABI, June 26In Bedouin tents and in the splendid villas of this remote Islamic capital, there are still Arab women who give their sons the ancient Semitic name of Qahtan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL WOULD STIFFEN STEELIMPORT CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  Senators Hugh Scott and Vance Hartke, from the steel producing states of Pennsyl vania and Indiana, called today for mandatory quotas on Euro pean and Japanese exports of steel to the United States.

title: I. C.C. ASKS POWER ON NONRAIL UNITS
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission again warned Con gress yesterday that it must be vested with additional author ity if it Is going to check the growing trend of the nation's railroads to use their nontrans portation assets for conglom erate merger activities outside the carrier field.

title: Roundup: Tigers Win From Slumping Orioles
description: A third forcethe Detroit Tigersentered the pennant race in the American Leagues Eastern Division last night when the Bengals downed the Baltimore Ori oles and drew to within 4 games of the division leaders.

title: DIAMOND EARRINGS WINS OPEN JUMPING
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 2 Barrett Farm's Diamond Ear rings, who won the class two years ago, captured the first division of the Big G stake for open jumpers today at the Gaudeamus Farm's horse show.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Oklahoma Gets Drought Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Agriculture Departmentap proved today the payment of drought relief subsidies to farmers in seven Oklahoma counties. The allocation of $1.6 million to the Oklahoma Sta bilization and Conservation Corihmittee will be available for financing emergency tillage practices in Beckham, Greer, Harmon, Jackson, Kiowa, Roger Mills and Tillman counties.

title: Rand Aides Say Security Relied Largely on Trust
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 2Officials at the Rand Cor poration believe that their se curity has been better than at most Government facilities, but, as one source said, If you want to reduce the possibility of a leak to zero, you would have to hermetically seal the whole Defense Department.

title: N.L.R.B. Counsel Named
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) President Nixon today named Peter G. Nash, currently solici tor of the Labor Department, to serve for a term of four years as general counsel of the Na tional Labor Relations Board. Mr. Nash, 34 years old, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Colgate University, is a native of New ark, N. Y. He is a former president of the Rochester Junior Chamber of Commerce.

title: Treasury Loan Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) President Nixon signed today a bill extending for two years authority of the Treasury to borrow up to $5billion tem porarily from the Federal Re serve Bank. The authority per mits the Treasury to operate with lower cash balances than otherwise would be needed.

title: Growth of Picturephones Disappoints Bell System
description: PITTSBURGH, July 1  A full year after becoming the first people in the na tion to get commercial Pic turephone service, a small group of businessmen and professionals here are still talking  and looking  mostly among themselves.

title: Profile Bread Will Use New Ads To Rebut Its Earlier Allegations
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)  The makers of Profile Bread have agreed to dispute their own advertising claims in a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission.

title: PriceFixing Charge Refuted
description: The Susquehanna Corpora tion said yesterday that charges by the Department of Justice against its subsidiary, R. & G. Sloane Manufacturing Com pany, were totally unfounded and without merit. Earlier this week a Federal grand jury in dicted R. & G. Sloane, three other manufacturers and two officials on charges of con spiring to fix prices of drain, waste and vent plastic pipe fittings.

title: PIETRO H. DONINI
description: Pietro H. Donini, who with his brother Natalino operated the restaurant known as Piet ro's at 201 East 45th Street for 40 years, died yesterday of cancer at St. Vincent's Hospi tal. He was 68 years old.

title: LUTHER T. CONRADI
description: OGUNQUIT, Me., July 2 Luther Theodore Conradi, a re tired concert pianist, died of heart attack at his home here today. He was 97 years old and lived at Frazier Pasture Road.

title: Snow's 4 Goals for Myopia Pace 96 Triumph in Polo
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 2 Terry Snow scored four goals and led the Myopia polo team to a 96 triumph over Meadow brook today in the Northeast ern circuit 12goal tournament at Bethpage State Park. Russell Corey matched Snow's output to pace Meadowbrook.

title: 6 Tell Panel of Plight of Unemployed
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Louis Lantner is 24 years old. He is a graduate of Brown Univer sity and a former naval officer who served in Vietnam. He made a perfect score on his Fed eral service entrance examina tion. He has applied for jobs at 15 Government agencies, but with no luck.

title: Many Industries Miss Antipollution Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Thousands of industries were in technical violation of a Federal antipollution law today after missing a mid night deadline to apply for permits to discharge wastes.

title: PORTS AND MINES SHUT BY STRIKES
description: Demanding more money, longshoremen halted most cargo handling yesterday in West Coast ports and copper miners forced all major United States producers to shut down.

title: WELLES TO GUIDE TV FILM SERIES
description: Orson Welles will be the host of Channel 13's weekly summer series of silent film classics that wil start Tuesday at P.M. with Charlie Chaplin's 1925 film, The Gold Rush.

title: Veterans Get Parade Right
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 2 (AP)  Federal District Judge Edward W. Day ordered the Bristol Fourth of July Parade Committee today to move the Vietnam Veterans Against the War from last place to the middle of the parade. After lie ruled yesterday that the veterans had a right to partici pate in the parade, the commit tee made the group the last unit in the parade. The vet erans went back to court and won today's order.

title: CHICKENUNIT SUIT SURPRISE TO LOEB
description: The investmentbanking firm of Loeb, Rhoades & Co., which the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation had consulted about financing, expressed sur prise yesterday over allegations by Unit, Inc., in that company's suit against Kentucky Fried.

title: Braniff Airliner is Hijacked From Mexico to Peru
description: MONTERREY, Mexico, July 2 (AP)An armed couple, be lieved to be from the United States, collected $100,000 in ransom today during the hi jacking of a Texasbound jet liner. Africa was believed to be its final destination.

title: Schisgal Play Is Slated
description: Richard Seader and Allan Jack Lewis, in association with Ted Tulchin, will present The Box Step, a new play by Murray Schisgal, on Broadway Feb. 17 after a threeweek run in Washington. Martin Fried will direct. Totally rewritten and given a new title, The Box Step was originally called A Way of Life. It was to have been produced in 1969 by Edgar Lansbury and Marc Merson, who were prevailed upon by the author to close it while still in previews.

title: The Dance: Emergence of a Ballerina
description: Few words are used so in discriminately as the word ballerina. Some people imag ine that every little girl who gets up on tippytoes is a ballerinawhich is about as reasonable as postulating an army where everyone is a general and there are no sol diers. A ballerina is first a woman who dances leading roles with a classic ballet company. And I personally would further define the term to insist that these roles should be danced with some measure of distinction before the dancer is called a bal lerina.

title: Who Needs the National Anthem?
description: When the average man looks at the world around him, he sees many things that serve no useful purpose. These things exist but their existence con tributes nothing to the wellbeing of mankind. Foreign aid. The Philadelphia Phillies. Taxicab horns. The Duke of Windsor. Street  corner telephones. Mount Etna. Tenchildren families. Marshall Ky. Crosswalks. Slumlords. The list is endless.

title: McNamara Draft Memorandum For Johnson in November, '66
description: Excerpts from draft memorandum for President Johnson from Secre tary McNamara, dated Nov. 17, 1966, and headed Recommended FY67 South east Asia Supplemental Appropriation, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

title: G.E. PLANS MOVE TO CONNECTICUT
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it planned to move its corporate headquar tors out of Manhattan.

title: Police Corruption
description: In its brief interim report following almost a year of intensive work, the Commission to Investigate Alleged Police Corruption made several vitally important points. The report itself is a cause both for concern and grati fication.

title: 5 YEARS' PROBATION GIVEN IN DRUG CASE
description: A 39yearold man arrested last October on charges selling heroin to a man who was the a New York detective was given five years' probation yes terday in State Supreme Court in Queens.

title: MacMillan Bloedel Drops PulpMill Plans in Alberta
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July (Canadian Press)A proposed $50million pulp mill at White court, Alberta, 100 miles north west of here, will not be built vowing to market conditions, according to MacMillan Bloedel, Ltd.

title: SIDNEY KALISH DIES; AD FIRM PRESIDENT
description: Sidney Kalish, president of Kalish, Quigley & Rosen, Inc., publishers' advertising repre sentatives, 667 Madison Av enue, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital, after a long ill ness. He was 68 years old and lived at 205 East 78th Street.

title: Armstrong Rubber And General Tire Follow Price Rise
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company and the Armstrong Rubber Company have made the move toward higher tire prices unanimous among major manufacturers.

title: INMATE, 24, FOUND HANGED IN BRONX
description: A 24yearold inmate of the Bronx House of Detention, who had gone through the city's narcotics detoxification pro gram, hanged himself in his cell last night.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, July 2Law has always pervaded American life. Lawyers domi nate our politics and interpret our Constitution. Even the American Revo lution was cast in the form of a return to legalitya revolt against a lawless king.

title: Merton. Akers, Newsman, Dies; A Former United Press Editor
description: COLD SPRING, N. Y., July 2 Merton T. Akers, former day, news manager of United Press International, who wrote the awardwinning This Was the Civil War series for U.P.I. from 1960 to 1965, died today of a heart ailment at his home here, His age was 72.

title: Draft Lottery Planned Despite Lack of Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that the draft lottery for 1972 would be held during July even if Congress did not complete action on legisla tion to extend the draft law.

title: Students Who Are Learning to Add and Subtract Their Rooms
description: In a ballroomsized dormi tory at the rear of a Lower East Side converted super market, there is a rabbit war ren of 35 roomsonwheels where teenagers have classes and jam sessions, study and sleep.

title: REAGAN WON'T BAR RURAL LEGAL AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Gov. Ronald Reagan agreed today to remove his veto of the Cali fornia Rural Legal Assistance program. Under a final accord with the Federal Government, however, the Governor is in a position to eventually take con trol of all legal services pro grams in the state.

title: QUICK PRIDE TAKES YONKERS FUTURITY
description: YONKERS, July 2Quick Pride, in a contending position at every stage of the onemile race, withstood a strong clos ing challenge by Savoir and beat that 21.1 shot by a nose tonight to win the $110,795 Yonkers Futurity trot at Yon kers Raceway.

title: U.S. Quietly Concedes A Recession Last Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 2  The Government officially, but very quietly, accepted to day the verdict that the econ omy went through a reces sion last year.

title: Solitron Meeting Adjourns
description: The annual meeting of Soli tron Devices, Inc., was ad journed indefinitely yesterday for lack of a quorum. Some industry sources considered this a victory for a dissenting share holder, Harold S. Brady. He had tried to block the meeting in Federal court to gain time to form an opposition slate of directors.

title: Dilemma for President
description: Secretary McNamara showed his paper to President Johnson on May 19, the day it was completed, the study says. Al though the analyst provides no docu mentary record of Mr. Johnson's reac tion, he comments that it was not sur prising that the President did not promptly endorse the McNamara rec ommendations as he had on occasions in the past.

title: A.B.A. Unit Urges Trial Judges To Be Calm During Disruptions
description: Apparently shocked by the way some judges have handled highly publicized trials in re cent years, a committee of the American Bar Association has admonished judges to exercise restraint, to suppress personal predilections and to control their temper and emotions.

title: Carter Wins Split Verdict
description: TOKYO, July 2 (AP)George Carter, a 35yearold Tokyo based American boxer from Chicago, retained his Japanese middleweight title tonight with a split decision over Masakazu Taninobu of Japan in a 10 round bout.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Warren and Nickel on Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  The American Association for the Advancement of Science announced today the appoint ment of former Chief Justice Earl Warren and former Inte rior Secretary Walter J. Hickel to a committee that will study means of protecting scientific freedom and assuring scientific responsibility.

title: Rostow Memorandum of May On the Bombing Program
description: Excerpts from a memorandum by Walt W. Rostow, Presidential assistant national security, to Secretary of State Dean Rusk, Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus Vance, Under Secretary of State Nicholas de B. Katzenbach, Assistant Secretary of Defense John T. McNaughton, Assistant Secretary of State William P. Bundy and Richard Helms, Director of Central Intelligence, dated May 1967, and headed U.S. Strategy in Vietnam, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: MRS. LOUIS P. SLADE
description: TIVERTON, R. I., July 2 Mrs. Charlotte Boone Slade, widow of Louis P. Slade, who was principal of high schools in Chicopee, Mass., and New Britain, Conn., for 33 years, died today at her home here. She was 96 years old.

title: DROP IN PRESSURE HINTED IN DEATHS OF 3 ASTRONAUTS
description: MOSCOW, July 2  Dr. Mstislav V. Keldysh, the presi dent of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, said today that an unexpected occurrence aboard the Soyuz 11 capsule led to the death of the three Soviet astro nauts on their way back to earth Wednesday morning.

title: Jill G. Weldon, Editor, Married To Filmmaker
description: LONDON, July 2Miss Jill Gloria Weldon, literary editor of British Vogue, and Philip Leffingwell Spalding, a docu mentary film producer, were married here today at St. Michael's Church in Chester Square. The Rev. Giles Hunt performed the Anglican cere mony.

title: LUNG TESTS SHOW BRONX POLLUTION
description: A preliminary analysis of the breath of 500 community resi dents at a free clinic in the Bronx over the last seven days is reported to have showed that more than 17 per cent of them had symptoms of ser ious respiratory diseases that the subjects themselves were unaware of.

title: Taiwan's Exports Increase
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 2 (UPI)Nationalist China's ex ports totaled $880.5million in the first five months of this year, up 40.1 per cent from the yearearlier level, the Board of Foreign Trade said yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., July 2 (AP)D. Louis Tonti denied today that he was involved in any wrongdoing during the 16 years he served as executive director of the Garden State Parkway.

title: McNamara Memo of Oct. 14, 1966, Opposing Increase in War Effort
description: Following are texts of key documents accompanying the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war, covering the period late 1966 to mid1967, in which Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara began to express disillusionment with the effec tiveness of the war effort. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents are printed verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: HILLIARD SENTENCED IN POLICE SHOOTOUT
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 2 David Hilliard, national Chief of Staff of the Black Panther party, was sentenced today to an indeterminate prison term of one to 10 years.

title: Auto Output Falls 41,867 Units In Week From Previous Period
description: DETROIT, July 2 (AP)  The long Fourth of July week end cut into the nation's auto mobile production this week, with output estimated at 136, 193 cars, down from 178,060 autos the previous week and from 161,453 in the yearearlier week.

title: Vichyssoise Alert Is Issued by State
description: Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, the Stale Health Commissioner, warned the public last night against eating any vichyssoise canned at a Newark plant until it could be determined which brands contained the deadly toxin that killed a Westchester County man and paralyzed his wife.

title: A New Parish Mood
description: News Analysis

title: Executive Changes
description: The Rohr Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of Jerome J. Filiciatto as vice president of the firm's aerospace systems group. He was direc tor of Industrial engineering and facilities.

title: Compensating Jerusalemites
description: Israel's plan to compensate Arab residents of East Jerusalem for property they held within the pre1967 borders of Israel is a positive gesture that unfortunately is likely to have negative results in terms of overall IsraeliArab relations.

title: $7BILLION BUDGET IS SENT TO REAGAN
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July (UPI)The Legislature passed a $7.3billion state budget to day and sent it to Gov. Ronald Reagan, who promised to slash it drastically to avoid a huge tax increase.

title: Puerto Rican Body Loses A City Poverty Contract
description: The city's Council Against Poverty has withdrawn its con tract from the Puerto Rican Community Development Proj ect, Inc., saying that a factional fight among members of the project's board for control of its $2.8million program has led to threats of violence and the closing of the administrative offices at 210 West 50th Street for more than a month.

title: March 28 Westmoreland Cable To Joint Chiefs on Troop Needs
description: Excerpts from cablegram from General Westmoreland to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, MACV FY68 Force Requirements, March 28, 1967, as provided the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's para phrase, or explanation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: More Banks' Prime Rates Raised to 6% From 5%
description: Important regional banks in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Cleveland increased their prime interest rates on business loans yesterday to 6 per cent from 5 per cent. The actions, coupled with a contin ued upward sweep in short term money costs in the open market, bankers said, made a general increase in this key minimum charge on corporate credit practically certain early next week. Most bankers as serted that action was likely on Tuesday, right after the threeday holiday weekend.

title: Amtrak to Increase Train Runs July 12 In New Timetable
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The National Railroad Passen ger Corporation, known as Amtrak, issued a revised time table today, effective July 12, offering more convenient train connections and additional stops.

title: LINDSAY DEFENDS RECORD ON POLICE
description: Mayor Lindsay contended yesterday that during his five and a half years in office he had urged his top police com manders many times to take vigorous and firm action. against police corruption.

title: Pressure for Wider War
description: As 1967 began, the study asserts, the stage was set for a running battle inside the Johnson Administration be tween the advocates of a greatly ex panded air campaign against North Vietnam, one that might genuinely be called strategic, and the disillusioned doves who urged relaxation, if not com plete suspension, of the bombing in the interests of greater effectiveness and the possibilities for peace.

title: Market Place: Be a Warbucks To Grandchild
description: If you were a grandfather and you and your wife had $24,000 in the bank, you might like to do something for your grandchild.

title: Tough Postal Reformer Winton Malcolm Blount
description: Man in the News

title: Duty Suspension Extended
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Extension of the suspension since 1942 of import duties on scrap metal for another two years, to June 3, 1973, was signed into law today by Presi dent Nixon. The extension prin cipally covers scrap iron, steel, aluminum, magnesium, nickel and nickel alloys.

title: San Diego Seeks Convention
description: SAN DIEGO, July 2 (AP) San Diego sent off its bid to day to be host city for the Republican National Conven tion next year.

title: Notes on Johnson Discussion With Wheeler and Westmoreland
description: Excerpts from the Pentagon study describing a conversation on April 27, 1967, between President Johnson and Generals Wheeler and Westmoreland. The narrative says the conversation was reported in notes by John T. Mc Naughton, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs. Italicized emphasis and words in parentheses are those of the Pentagon study.

title: Top Awards Presented to 2 By Press Photographers
description: PITTSBURGH, July 2 (UPI) The National Press Photog raphers Association bestowed its highest awards tonight on Alfred Eisenstaedt, photog rapher for Life magazine, and John G. Morris, picture editor of The New York Times.

title: Westmoreland's March 18 Memo On Increase in Forces
description: Excerpts from cablegram from Gen. William C. Westmoreland, commander of united States forces in Vietnam, to Pacific command, March 18, 1967, provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: British Reserves of Gold Rose to a Record in June
description: LONDON, July 2 (APBrit ain's reserves of gold and for eign currency rose for the eighth straight month in June to reach a peak of $3,619,200, 000, the Treasury announced today.

title: Dietz, in an Upset, Gains Final in Diamond Sculls
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, Eng land, July 2  The United States will be represented to morrow in all the events in which Americans are competing in the semifinals and finals of the Henley Royal Regatta.

title: ROME DOME WINS OPEN JUMP CLASS
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 3 Kip Rosenthal's Rome Dome, a former national junior jumper high point champion, captured his, first open jumper class of the season today at the Gau desmus Farms Horse Show.

title: The Good Word: Walker Percy Redivivus
description: Walker Percy's fine novel Love in the Ruins opens with the hero seated in a pine grove with a gun on his lap awaiting the end of the world. The gun looks Confederate, the waiting is Catholic: these are the positions from which Mr. Percy does his own sniping, at what Mortimer Adler might call the Three Great Tenses.

title: Italian Unit's Camp For Children Opens Upstate This Week
description: ROSENDALE, N. Y., July 3 The ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League's summer camp for children, Camp Unity, in an isolated part of Ulster County near here, was dedicated to day. The camp is scheduled to open next week.

title: MARA C.Y.O. CAMP WILL BE DEDICATED
description: Cardinal Cooke, Archbishon of New York, will dedicate the John V. Mara Catholic Youth Organization sport camp in Putnam Valley, N. Y., on Wednesday.

title: Pentagon Papers: After Tet, Study Reports, Joint Chiefs Sought Virtual Mobilization
description: Amid the shock and turmoil of the Tet offensive in February, 1968, the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war dis closes, the Joint Chiefs of Staff and Gen. William C. Westmoreland sought to force President Lyndon B. Johnson a long way toward national mobiliza tion in an effort to win victory in Vietnam.

title: Listen here! said the left calf to the right foot
description: William C. Schutz is the well known ambassador from Esalen, cap ital of the Encounter Circuit. The epigraph of his previous book Joy was from the song The Impossible Dream. If such vapidity hardly in spired confidence in Schutz's claim that he was liberating human souls from Manichean anguish, it was in keeping with his actual mtier  a species of recreation for a histrionic clientele seeking instant relief from a current variety of weltschmerz. But Schutz, by his own confession, is touchy on the subject of his intellec tual power, which Joy called into question among many of his peers. Accordingly, the epigraph of his pres ent book is from Finnegan Wake. But Schutz is still doing an intellec tual twostep, only this time to Joyce's symphonic novel. Thus he has advanced from the ludicrous to the pretentious.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: HONG KONG, July 3, Reuters Chinese officials and scien tists called at the Soviet Em bassy in Peking to express con dolences over the death of the three Russians.

title: CY KASELMAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (UPI) David (Cy) Kaselman, who led the Philadelphia Sphas to 11 professional basketball cham pionships in 13 years from 1928 to 1940, died of a heart attack today at his home. He was 62 years old.

title: Acupuncture Helps the Deaf in China
description: PEKING, June 21 Yeh Nu hsu, 16 years old, looks like a typical Peking teenager. She is bright  eyed and alert but speaks haltingly. Until one year and a halt ago, she said, I was deaf and mute.

title: U.S. Ambassador In Greece Stresses Democratic Bond
description: ATHENS, July 3Ambassa dor Henry J. Tasca, in a Fourth of July message to Americans in Greece, says that the bond between Greeks and Americans in the last analysis is rooted in our common faith in the democratic ideal.

title: Religion
description: At a recent Billy Graham evangelistic rally in Chicago, a group of about 100 Satan worshipers banded together to march down the aisle and dis rupt the critical moment when members of the crowd were in vited forward to make their commitments to Christ. Their plan was abruptly foiled when a sizable group of longhaired youths shouting Jesus cheers surrounded them and physical ly blocked their way.

title: Miss Kate B. Webb Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Miss Kate Brewster Webb to George Ion Eric Harris has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. George Seemann Jr. of South Nor walk, Conn., and Great Har bour Bay, the Bahamas, and Harry Webb of Shelburne, Vt., and New York. Mr. Harris is the son of Mr, and Mrs. A. Percy Harris of Cashel, Coun ty Tipperary, Ireland. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Morton Instructs Bureaus
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton has in structed bureaus and offices of his department to conform to a new regional pattern for field offices in the country. He asked that the alignment conform as closely as practicable to the 10region Federal organization goal President Nixon outlined in 1969.

title: Woman Dies After Judge Forbade Terminal Surgery
description: MIAMI, July 3 (AP)Mrs. Carmen Martinez, 72 years old, died quietly and without pain at 1:20 P.M. today, 24 hours after a court ruled that she had the right to die in dignity.

title: Aged on L. I. Find Little to Occupy Their Time
description: COMMACK, L.L, July 3 For the suburban aged, there are all the problems of the elderly everywhere  the need for better medical care, for specialized housing and transportation, for something to fill the long empty hours between breakfast and bed time.

title: Triology Declared Winner Of Bermuda Multihull Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 3 (Reuters)  Trilogy, owned and skippered by Al Sunderland of Swansea, Mass., was declared the winner today of the bien nial multihull race between New Jersey and Bermuda on rected time.

title: No Arrests Are Imminent In Colombo Shooting Case
description: No arrests appear imminent in the alleged underworld plot to assassinate Joseph A. Col ombo Sr. last Monday, despite a police assertion on Friday that its investigators know the identity of the plotters.

title: How We Lost the WarA 4th of July Tour Of George III's Boston
description: IN the War of American Independence there were winners and there were losers. Now every Fourth of July you Americans hear from the win ners, so this Fourthjust to be big about itwhy not listen to a loser?hangs in the Old South Meeting House along with a poem lamenting his ob scurity by Helen F. More, no Long fellow:

title: Patriots Sign Sellers
description: BOSTON, July 3 (AP)The New England Pariots an nounced today the signing of the wide receiver, Ron Sellers.

title: the traveler's world
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.It isn't often that you get an opportunity to see at its very beginning the development of a scientific center, a state waterfront park and campsite and an island real estate development of at least 5,000 family units plus motels, hotels and three tournament  quality golf courses. Only a few people have had the opportunity so far to watch this birth on Skidaway Island, a small piece of solid land just 15 minutes southeast of here.

title: ADDICTS' PROGRAM REDUCED IN STATE
description: In response to budget cut backs, Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday a new pro gram for heroin addicts in which they will spend less time in residential treatment centers and rely more on outpatient care. Some addicts will re ceive no residential treatment at all.

title: Sea Cliff Sall Put Off
description: SEA CLIFF, LI., July 3 The Hempstead Harbor three day weekend regatta, scheduled by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club, failed to start today because of lack of wind.

title: Ann Robinson And a Lawyer Plan to Marry
description: PITTSBURGH, July 3 Miss Ann Keeble Robinson and Justin Jason Stevenson 3d, a lawyer with the Shear man & Sterling law firm in New York, will be married here in October.

title: Chance Hinted in Cluster Of Hodgkins Disease Cases
description: The National Cancer Insti tute, reacting to fears generated by the discovery of a cluster of Hodgkin's disease cases in Al bany, is suggesting that the cluster is a result of chance, not contagion, The Associated Press said yesterday.

title: Phils Top Expos With Four Runs In 9th Inning, 63
description: MONTREAL, July 3 (UPI) Tim McCarver drove in two runs with a single to spark fourrun ninth inning tonight and lead the Philadelphia Phil lies to a 63 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Fans Disrupt Soccer Game, Referee Halts Play
description: Most of the crowd of 17,684 left Downing Stadium on Ran dells Island last night not know ing the scare of the soccer game they had just witnessed.

title: Buesing a Skipper
description: HANOVER, N. H. (AP) George Buesing of Westwood, N. J., who has rowed in the varsity boat for two seasons, has been elected captain of the 1972 Dartmouth College heavy weight crew.

title: HORTON STANDS OUT AS COSMOS WIN, 31
description: ATLANTA, July 3  Randy Horton scored two goals in the first five minutes tonight to spark the New York Cosmos to a 31 soccer victory over the Atlanta Chiefs in the North American League.

title: Education
description: The Supreme Court handed down three landmark deci sions last week on public aid to churchrelated schools. For Roman Catholics, two of the decisionsbecause they af fected the crisis area of paro, chiai education, namely the primary and secondary schools  were potentially devastating. They could spell the difference between sur vival and extinction of the Catholic school system as presently constituted.

title: Munford's Path to Money
description: ATLANTAOn May 12, JacksonAtlantic, Inc., of At lanta officially changed its name to Munford, Inc. It was another outward sign of the changing, reshaping and ad justing that has bean going on within the company ever since Dillard Munford, presi dent and chief executive officer, joined the Atlantic Company by way of a mer ger in 1962.

title: New Drive on Coast: Save the Snakes
description: BORREGO SPRINGS, Calif., July 3  California conserva tionists who have been waging a determined battle to protect the state's beaches, forests and other natural beauties have turned their attention to a new save the snakes crusade.

title: Helen Reisner, Senior at Hood, Wed in Maine
description: CAPE ELIZABETH, Me., July 3St. Alban's Epis copal Church was the setting here this morning for the marriage of Miss Helen Mae Reisner to William Alfred Walker 2d. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John S. Rogers.

title: The World
Space
description: This is Amber. Everything is in order on board. We feel fine. We're ready for landing. I see the [space] station. It's shining beautifully in the sun.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Joker's Wild
description: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. Cranking with gusto, Frank Fontaine of Winchester, Mass., the television and nightclub entertainer, soon had a Pipound bluefish next to the boat.

title: L.I, GETS GLIMPSE OF THE CREATION
description: CENTERPORT, L. I., July 3 Anyone who has spent hours on the Long Island Expressway an pursuit of weekend leisure, or anyone who has been tram pled in the Sunday throngs in a Manhattan museum, will ap preciate the Vanderbilt Plane tarium, which opened here this week.

title: Future Social EventsBaseball Isn't the Only Game in Cooperstown
description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Lil Smoothy Wins by 2 Lengths In Schuylkill at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 3The largest crowd of the season 16,449turned out for the Good Old Days program, which featured sports person alities, nickel soft drinks and coffee, 10cent hot dogs, pre inflation priced admittance, live entertainment and the $29,500 Schuylkill Stakes for 2year old, fillies today at Liberty Bell race track.

title: City System of Jailing Addicts Decried After Suicide in Bronx
description: The executive director of the city's Board of Correction said yesterday that the suicide Fri day night of a 24yearold in mate of the Bronx House of Detention illustrates again the fact that prison is no place to put drug addicts.

title: Union Worth $56Million
description: PITTSBURGH, July 3 (UPI) An audit report issued by the United Steel Workers has dis closed that the net worth of the 1.2 million member union was $56,197,020 as of Dec. 31.

title: Mental Aid Cuts Feared
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (AP)  Budget cutbacks pro posed by the Nixon Adminis tration would virtually elimi nate all Federal support for training of mental health pro fessionals, according to the president of the American Psy choanalytic Association. Dr. Robert Wallerstein said the cuts, now moving through Con gress, would return us to the era in which we provide cus todial care and little more for psychiatric patients.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: As one of the (rare) young er members of theater audi ences, I was exposed to some very hopeful and very dis couraging signs for the theater's future at Lenny. The hopeful signs were the play itself, and the audience. Young people can be attract ed to the theater if the sub ject matter appeals to them, as in Lenny, and they ap peared there in greater num bers than at any other play I have seen this season. It was exciting theater, and especially notable for the fact that it worked so well and effectively as Theater, that it fully emphasized the potential of Theater.

title: Art
description: THE Brooklyn Museum is open today from 11 in the morning to 5 in the afternoon because to day is Sunday, and tomorrow from 1 to 5 in the afternoon because although tomorrow is a Monday, it is also a holiday. But the museum will be closed all day on unholi day Mondays and Tuesdays from now on in order to save enough money to keep all the galleries open Wednesdays Saturdays inclusive from 10 in the morning until 5.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: On a Harlem Playground: It's Basketball With Soul
description: Ooohh, Tony Jackson still has that deadly jump shot.... Wow, look at Charlie Brown drive on Mike Riordan, just like he's never heard of the New York Knickerbockers.... Hey, that Julius Ervin is a young Connie Hawkins.

title: Canario Doesn't Flip for Anonymity
description: Arthur Canario is probably the only national champion who is working on a truck, delivering whisky to bars this sum mer. It is doubtful whether bartenders ever heard of him. It is doubtful, in fact, whether sports fans have ever heard of him.

title: Miss Braddicks Is Bride in Suburb
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., July 3In the First Presby terian Church here this morn ing Miss Carolyn Anne, Brad dicks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Braddicks Jr., was married to Paul Arnold Butler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Butler of Pittsburgh. The Rev. William H. Edwards 3d performed the ceremony.

title: Yankee Go Home! You're Ruining Our Shakespeare
description: STRATFORDUPONAVON, England.

title: Mothers' milk or other milk?
description: Dr. William E. Homan's article on breastfeeding (Mothers' Milk or Other Milk?) in the June 6 issue of The Magazine provoked a wide and frequently angry response. Here is a repre sentative sample of letters, with a reply from Dr. Homan.

title: It's Minnie Mouse and Donald Duck and love and peace and stars and stripes forever!
description: On and off the beaches, the Tshirt is the summer uniform of the young. But it doesn't rate unless it says something. Something about love or peace. Something funny or significant. Cartoon char acters are the oddson favorites (a return to the nursery?). In the spirit of youthful independence that we have come to expect, the Tshirt is worn with pants in unrelated patterns and colors. If any thingGod forbid!should match, the wearer is trying too hard.

title: Congress Change Urged
description: BOSTON, July 3 (Reuters) Representative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachu ets, called today for a constitu tional amendment lowering by three years the age requirement for membership in Congress. Father Drinan, Jesuit priest, said in an interview that the age of eligibility should drop from 25 to 22 for the House and from 30 to 27 for the Senate.

title: Safety Guarantees Are Sought On New Nuclear Plant in Maine
description: WISCASSET, Me., July 3 Conservation groups and Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis Have asked to intervene in the granting of the operating license of the Maine Yankee atomic power plant here by the Atomic En ergy Commission.

title: Arbitragers a Mysterious Clique
description: When the New York Stock Exchange published its latest shortinterest figures a couple of weeks ago, the company with the largest total was not a highflying producer of computer equipment, a de pressed steel maker or a be leaguered airline.

title: Airliner Carrying 68 Is Missing in Japan
description: HAKODATE, Japan, July 3 (AP)A Japanese airliner ap proaching this city with 68 persons aboard disappeared in fog and drizzle tonight. A widespread land and sea search began.

title: Miss MacGregor Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 The marriage of Miss Susan Clark MacGregor to Joseph Storer Wheelwright took place here tonight in the gar den at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Clark MacGregor, par ents of the bride.

title: Restore A Star Pays $74.40
description: LAFAYETTE, La., July 3 (AP) Restore A Star, a 311 shot, sloshed through the mud in 1:03 to win the $66,150 Southwest Louisiana thoroughbred futurity at Evangeline Downs today. Re store A Star in recording a one half length victory in the five furlong event, returned $74.40, $24.20 and $11.40.

title: CONVICT RELEASED, TO AID PAROLE UNIT
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., July 3 (UPI)  A convicted murderer with a history of arrests dating back to 1938, has been ordered released from the state prison to enter the field of crime pre vention in Maryland.

title: The Old Powerhouse That Retired to Become a Quiet Rectory
description: DOVER PLAINS, N.Y.  How many couples have his and her 25footlong interior balconies? Or a 30by35foot living room that used to have a turbine vibrating in one corner? Or a river purling along 20 feet below the house  a river that pro vided power for the turbine?

title: Eileen McTernan to Wed
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 3Mr. and Mrs. Gerald John McTernan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Ann McTernan, to Robert Joseph Kane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kane of Brooklyn. An October wedding is planned. The future bridegroom, a graduate of Manhattan Col lege, has a master's degree in physics from St. John's University.

title: LEROY COBB
description: LOS ANGELES, July 3 (UPI) Leroy Cobb, a forward on the University of Southern Cali fornia basketball team for the last two seasons, died Wednes day after openheart surgery at a Houston hospital. He was 21 years old.

title: Restoration Program Approved For Historic Section in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 3The Boston Redevelopment Authority has approved a $16million restora tion plan for the historic Fan euil HallQuincy Market area.The sixacre restoration area includes the domed, granite Quincy Market Building, the brick structures along North and South Market Streets and the streets in between.

title: GERALD FITZGERALD
description: SUMMIT, N. J., July 3Ger ald Fitzgerald of 308 Summit Avenue, vice president of En gelhard Industries in Newark, died today in Overlook Hospi tal. He was 52 years old.

title: VETERINARY CHIEF LEAVES CITY POST
description: Dr. Jeroham Asedo, who has been guarding New Yorkers and their one million animals from transmitting diseases to each other, is retiring as chief of the veterinary division of the city's Health Department.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: World
description: AMSTERDAM  With 20 pound packs on their backs, return charterflight tickets, $5aday itineraries and boundless enthusiasm, thou sands of young Americans are now engulfing Europe.

title: Project for Elderly Widened
description: A yearold experimental tel ephone reassurance system for elderly, blind and disabled wel fare recipients is being ex tended citywide, according to Jule M. Sugarman, Commis sioner of Social Services. The experimental program had en listed volunteers at senior civi zens' center to make up to five regularly scheduled telephone calls a week to the relief clients who live alone and who are referred or the service. By the end of May, 281 were re ceiving the calls.

title: SUMMATIONS END AT JERSEY TRIAL
description: NEWARK, July 3The Gov ernment's prosecutor told a Federal Court jury here today that the Government had in the last seven weeks proved con clusively and beyond reason able doubt that the eight Hud son County and Jersey City of ficials on trial had participated willfully and for personal gain in a massive, systematic kick back shakedown operation.

title: NEW HOUSING BILL TO HELP SUBURBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 Members of the House Banking and Currency Committee wil propose legislation soon that is designed to achieve dispersal of lowincome and moderatein come housing in the suburbs but without forced integra tion by the Federal Govern ment.

title: Not Very Productive
description: WASHINGTONOn June 18, 1970, President Nixon told the nation that he was standing by his basic eco nomic strategy to restore health to the sluggish econ omy.

title: Fireworks Bootleggers Thriving
description: Although the staccato re ports of exploding fireworks are as much a part of Fourth of July history as parades, pa triotism and the first bad case of summer sunburn, behind the holiday drumfire nowadays there is often the hand of or ganized crime.

title: Gardens
description: SOME people have expressed surprise that I manage to spend so many hours on the golf course and still find time for my considerable garden chores.

title: Reagan Cuts $503Million From the Budget Passed by California Legislature
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 Gov. Ronald Reagan cut Cali fornia's budget today by more than a half billion dollars. Items for education, welfare and medical care bore the brunt of the slash.

title: AUSSIE WINS TITLE
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 3At the stroke of 5 today John Newcombe slashed a low volley into the clear to end one of the great finals in Wimble don history.

description: News of Dogs

title: Sir Paul Maltby is Dead at 78; Air Vice Marshal in Far East
description: LONDON, July 3 (AP)Air Vice Marshal Sir Paul Copeland Maltby, the highest ranking Royal Air Force officer cap tured by the Japanese in World War II, died yesterday. He would have been 79 years old next month.

title: Adm. Sharp's Progress Report On War at End of 1967
description: Excerpts from cablegram from Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp, commander in chief of Pacific forces, to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, dated Jan. 1, 1968, and headed YearEnd WrapUp Cable, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. Paragraphs in italics are the study's paraphrase or explanation.

title: Kentucky Plans Stadium
description: FRANKFORT, Ky. (UPI)The state of Kentucky has taken the first step in planning for a new football stadium at the Univer sity of Kentucky in Lexington to replace the 37,500seat Stoll Field. Gov. Louie B. Nunn asked he State Property and Buildings Commission, which oversees state construction and sale of bonds, to consider a $10million to$12million stadium.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Art Notes
description: SUMME'R'S upon us; the art scene's wound downThe galleries are hibernating

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Residual U.S. forces and bases in Vietnam will be hostages to Commu nist attack. They will probably be attacked, and require U.S. reinforce mentsor embarrassing forced with drawal. Thus the historical pattern of escalation and counterescalation will be repeated.

title: Movies
description: THERE is a long tradition in Chris tianity of depicting Christ as a clown. Infinitely vulnerable but never finally defeated, the clown by helping us to laugh at the apparent hopelessness that surrounds usmay lead us to hope once again. Any symbol worth its salt ought to lead us more deeply into the mystery that is man. That the symbol of the clown can still do this is shown by Federico Fellini's delightfully humorous yet deeply touch ing film, The Clowns. Almost a docu mentary on the meaning of man, the film iso ?? to humanity.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe American politician is among the most adaptable creatures on earth. His instincts tell him that he can survive domestic insurrec tion, foreign intrigue, changes in the voting lawsalmost every thingby modest changes in em phasis. He doesn't believe the electorate ever changes.

title: J.S. WIEDHOPF, 81; LED PARFUMS CIRO
description: J. S. Wiedhopf, former chair man of the RoureDupont Com pany, essential oils, and before that president of Parfums Ciro, Inc., died Friday at his home, 200 East 66th Street. He was 81 years old.

title: Bold Reason Rallies to Capture $ 112,100 Hollywood Derby by 1 Lengths
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July It was something like Bel montonthePacific today as the New York horse, Bold Reason, won the $112,100 Hollywood Derby with another Empire Stater, Jim French, a close second.

title: Matzdorf of US, at 76 Breaks Brurnel's Record
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 3 On his final attempt, as the crossbar quivered excitedly, Pat Matzdorf set a world record in the high jump today.

title: The Court's Decision
description: The decision of the Supreme Court allowing The Times and other newspapers to continue to publish hitherto secret Pentagon documents on the Vietnam war is in our view less important as a victory for the press than as a striking confirmation of the vitality of the American democratic form of government.

title: Chip Oliver: Flower Child Back
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 3An attorney attempting to reach Dave Meggyesy the other day seemed surprised when Chip Oliver answered the phone at Meggyesy's home.

title: ASTROS WIN, 4 TO 3, FROM REDS IN 13TH
description: HOUSTON, July 3 (AP)Jim Wynn, who threw out the po tential winning run at the plate during a ninthinning rally, sin gled with two out in the 13th, stole second and scored on Jack Hiatt's single to give the Hous ton Astros a 43 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: ECOLOGY JOURNAL SURPASSES GOALS
description: LOS ANGELES, July 3  An environmental affairs publica tion started here last summer by two fundless college stu dents has evolved from a local newsletter into a slick 80page quarterly that has printed 100, 000 copies for its current issue.

title: Camel, Out of Fashion, Disappearing in Jordan
description: ZIZIA, Jordan, June 21Lieut. Hamden Hamd of the desert po lice peered into his camel's lus trous eyes. A fine head, a beautiful head, he murmured. But I think I would rather have a car.

title: GRAND CIRCUIT SET AT HISTORIC TRACK
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 3 (UPI) Once a year, the major leaguers of harness racing come back to the little leagues for a week of competition in this unique town of 7,000 known as cradle of the trotter.

title: Thoreau on July 4
description: One hundred twentysix years ago today Thoreau borrowed a horse and wagon to carry him and his belong ings to the but he had built at Wal den Pond. All across the country in the present year people who claim him as a forerunner are following him to try to make a life on the land, and many who haven't left metropolis are spiritual dwellers at Walden. The Thoreau cult and the Thoreau Society are flourishing; for them July 4th is Thoreau's independence day, and they may be said to see his independence as expressing the inmost meaning of the independence of the nation.

title: Movies
description: CAN you think of an actor who is not also a director? Not so easy, is it? If you answer Cliff Rob ertson. you're wrong. The same bug that bit Paul Newman, Dennis Hop per, Jack Nicholson, Ossie Davis, Clint Eastwood, Elaine May, Sidney Poitier, Peter Fonda, Alan Arkin, Barbara Loden, John Cassavetes, Albert Finney, Maxi milian Schell, Mai Zetterling, Al Free man Jr. and Jackie Cooper has bitten Robertson. He is the directoralso the writer, producer and starof a drama about rodeo life which was filmed in California this past spring for Columbia and which will be known as J.W., or possibly J.W.Rode Hard and Hung Up Wet. He rode cheap, tooat a budget of $730,000.

title: Richard Weiner to Wed Miss Muldoon
description: ORCHARD PARK, N. Y., July 3Miss Carolyn Ann Muldoon and Richard Steven Weiner will be married Aug. 21 at the Harvard Memorial Chapel in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Independence
description: This is the Long Midsummer Weekend, of course, but today also happens to be Independence Day. The holiday commemorates the signing of the Declaration of Inde pendence, which was written by young Thomas Jefferson, a countryman from Virginia, in a stuffy roominghouse room in Philadelphia the last couple of weeks in June.

title: Cleveland, in Fund Crisis, To Lay Off 193 Policemen
description: CLEVELAND, July 3 (UPI) Mayor Carl B. Stokes has an nounced that 193 of the city's 2.410 policemen would be laid off to help ease a financial crisis.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Although it was almost lost because of the natural interest in Pres ident Nixon's major economic decisions last week all of them against any new poli ciesSecretary of the Treas ury John B. Connally, in announcing the decision, let slip an important strand of thought within the Govern ment.

title: Dance: Revival of Fall River Legend
description: Into each life some rain must fall, and every ballet company needs a few bad ballets. American Ballet Theater, now in its summer season at the New York State Theater, has quite a rich and varied selection of bad ballets, carefully gar nered during the 31 years of the company's existence.

title: The people are decent enough
description: By Alexander Campbell. 215 pp. New York: Praeger. $6.95.

title: Vermont Widens the Rights of Youths
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., July 3 (AP)Vermont, the first state to abolish involuntary servi tude, has become the first state to give its 18yearolds the right to vote, to purchase liquor, make binding legal con tracts and marry without pa rental consent.

title: Elephant's Memory Mixes Radicalism And a Rough Sound
description: The righteous, revolutionary rock band is not a widespread species.

title: Gleaming, $4.40, Wins Lamplighter Handicap by 1 Lengths at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 3 Calumet Farm's Gleaming, rated as the outstanding 3yearold turf racer of the year, scored his fourth consecutive victory and fifth in his last six starts today when he won the $39,475 Lamplighter Handicap at Mon mouth Park.

title: NASHVILLE TOED TO STEP UP BUSING
description: NASHVILLE, July 3This city faces a host of problems educational, legal, economic and politicalas a result of a de cision this week by a Federal court.

title: Agnew Ends LowKey Visit to South Korea
description: SEOUL, July 3Vice Pres ident Agnew brought to a close today his fiveday visit to the South Korean capital. His stay has lent weight to the suspicion of some observers, including, it would seem, Mr. Agnew him self, that his projected month long world tour is essentially a goodwill mission of little real diplomatic substance.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Last Thurs day morning, as they have for more than three years, the chief negotiators at the deadlocked Vietnam peace talks filed into the conference room in the once luxurious Hotel Majestic in Paris. As always, Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, the Vietcong's chief representative, was smiling as she entered, and as always, she was carrying a briefcase.

title: Woods Recalled by Expos To Replace Ailing Britton
description: MONTREAL, July 3 (UPI) The Montreal Expos today placed Jim Britton, a pitcher, on the disabled list and brought up Ron Woods, an outfielder, to replace him.

title: POOR YOUTHS TRY LIFE ON A VESSEL
description: SEATTLE, July 3 (AP)Sea veterans of the Pacific North west no longer hopelessly shake their heads when they see the 90foot towboat Langston Hughes cutting through Puget Sound waters.

title: Coins
description: THIS year marks the 50th anniversary of the Peace Dollar (1921), a beautiful, much ne glected and somewhat contro versial coin. Produced fol lowing World War I, it was the first money issued to commemorate Peace,

title: $4.5MILLION GIVEN 20 PRIVATE COLLEGES
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foun dation announced faculty sup port grants yesterday totaling $4.5million to 20 private col leges and universities with pre dominantly black enrollments.

title: DELAWARE SEEKS RETURN OF DUNES
description: LEWES, Del., July 1Every day is Earth Day, says the bumper sticker on a park truck at Cape Henlopen State Park.

title: Deprived of the right to be dangerous
description: The Book of Daniel is an am bitious, felt reconstruction of the lit tle agonies, paranoias, obscenities, totems, murders, frauds and taboos of postWorld War II America. The novel begins and ends in a library stall. Daniel Isaacson Lewin, a spe cialist on the 20th century, is com pleting his Ph.D. dissertation at Columbia. The son of Paul and Ro chelle Isaacson, who were convicted and executed for attempting to pass on atomic secrets to the Soviet Union (read Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, if you wish), Daniel learns to appreciate his own tentative, dangling status: I live in constant and degrading re lationship to the society that has de stroyed my mother and father. I will never be drafted....I am totally deprived of the right to be dan gerous. If I were to assassinate the President, the criminality of my fam ily, its genetic criminality, would be established.

title: For Her, There's Always One More Place to Visit, One More Charity to Help
description: Mrs. Roger W. Straus will be heading for Europe this week, and just in time, too. The 75yearold philanthropist has been trying to cut down on her charity Work load, and it isn't easy in New York, where her wideranging interests, Tier enthusiasm and her generosity make her an easy mark.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONThe price of reform in America has always been high, frequently so high that It costs more than it is worth. Powerful interests, impregnable institutions, entrenched members of Congressby the time all have exacted their concessions and protected their positions, the most powerful reform movements in the worthiest causes are likely to find themselves with less than half a loaf of stale bread.

description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., July 3Edward Ballan tine, composer, pianist and former professor of music at Harvard University, died yes terday of a coronary throm bosis. He was 84 years old and lived in Vineyard Haven.

description: To the Financial Editor: The proposed U.S. rules to regulate international finan cial transactions of over $5,000 can only be termed too late, too drastic and dis tinctly prejudicial to Ameri can interests.

title: BUSINESS LETTER

title: Music
description: I HAVE been thinking about the new production of Wagner's Tristan and Isolde that Covent Garden staged a few weeks ago. A new production of Tristan is always some thing to be considered very seriously. It was, after all, the most important single opera of the 19th century. In its length, its demands upon singers, its orchestral complexity and its sheer weight, it still poses all kinds of problems. In its new kind of chromatic, tonicavoiding har mony, it was an important (and per haps decisive) step in the dissolution of tonality. Its Schopenhauerian symbol ism is capable of all kinds or interpre tations; and while the libretto itself is wordy and static, the opera as a whole sweeps all before it. Tristan and Isolde is a mighty emotional experience. Books are still being written about it; singers are still worried by its demands; con ductors find it the greatest of all chal lenges; scene designers and directors approach it on tiptoe.

title: BERKELEY COUNCIL DEBATES A BUDGET

title: Art
description: IT Is characteristic of a cer tain form of art that, although clearly issuing from a deep and even complex esthetic impulse, its appeal is not primarily of a sort that requires us to he immediately conscious of its artistic objectives. With art of this persuasion, we tend to pay less attention to its meth ods than to its vision. It of fers the eye a world, and it is only later, almost as an after thought, when the eye has satisfied its appetite for this imaginary world, that we be gin wondering how it has been constructed and what it signify.

He scribbled a name on a piece of paper and stuffed it into an envelope which he sealed. Four days later the en velope was opened. The name inside was Daniel Ellsberg.

title: A shift to the head
description: This is a brisk and useful book. Mr. Dutton, a lawyer and a former aide to President Kennedy, provides a brightly lighted view of Ameri can Politics in the 1970's, as promised in the subtitle. He is al ways satisfying but never comfort ing. The message is that we are in for a jolting but exhilarating ride through new political territory. The method is scholarly scrubbing of in formation from hundreds of sources, with never a resort to hyperbole or frightwig. Though the word revolu tion appears infrequently and fascism only once, both are known to be in the wings. The center, Dut ton seems to say, will not hold, but it won't explode either if common sense is not altogether abandoned. There is tumult aplenty ahead, per haps even including a substantial withdrawal of consent. But on bal ance the prospect is for invigoration of the political body and a shedding of old skins for something more live ly and of more human coloration.Thus there are no revelations, no new actors here: Indochina, the ram paging young, crumbling cities and burgeoning suburbs, campaign costs, fumbling statesmen and inept par ties: Dutton almost never moves out side the standard currency of politi cal chatter.
