title: The blacks aren't where the votes are
description: Bo Callowayformer United States Congressman from Georgia, unsuc cessful Republican gubernatorial candidate against Lester Maddox in 1966, and state manager of the 1968 Nixon campaigncame to Washing ton with other Southern Republican leaders in the spring of 1969: They presented their complaints about school desegregation to representa tives of the Nixon Administration, which was then sounding suspicious ly as though it intended to be firm in enforcing civil rights law. The law...the law, listen here, cried Bo Calloway from Georgia, Nixon promised the South he would change the law, change the Supreme Court, and change this whole integration business. The time has come for Nix on to bite the bullet, with real changes and none of this commu nicating bull. So much for any more of this long and tiresome de bate about what the Southern strat egy means. Bo Calloway has given the most admirably concise definition we are likely to get.

title: Jazz

These recordings of Duke Ellington's two major works of the past three years bring Ellington up to date on disks both in reporting on the band in a period of vital transition and in demonstrat ing the continuing and, if anything, rising level of crea tivity from Ellington during this transition. The transition involves basic changes in per sonnelthe death of Johnny Hodges, the departures of Lawrence Brown and Cat Anderson, the emergence of such new musical personali ties in the band as Norris and Wild Bill Davis.

title: A luxurious storyteller, a concerned human being
description: Late in the 1930's at St. Mary's Parochial Grade School in Belleville, Ill., we used to go to church to do the novena, nine halfhours of devo tion during consecutive weeks to the Blessed Virgin Mary. To join the no vena you needed an intention. That is, a purpose or want. Maybe work for your jobless father, relief for a soul in purgatory, or protection for the nuns of Spain. Mary's interces sion was supposed to lead to realiz ing your intention, although I don't think it worked very well for me.

title: Southern heirlooms
description: Southern hospitality is more than a legend; it still survives in Southern homesand in Southern recipes. When the Symphony League of Jackson, Miss., asked its friends to con tribute to a cookbook this year, they responded with a flood of heirlooms. Mrs. John Bell Wil liams, wife of Mississippi's Gov ernor, weighed in with her spicy combination of black eyed peas and rice. Mrs. Gar diner Green supplied her crabmeat mousse. And Eudora Welty, the revered Jackson novelist, wrote a nostalgic foreword about a Jackson that believed in and knew how to achieve the home flavor. At the right are two typical re cipes from The Jackson Cook book (available for $5.30 from The Jackson Cookbook, P.O. Box 9402, Jackson, Miss. 39206).

description: I speak in defense of the Eurodollar market. This fan tastic facility is under at tack by people wishing to impose controls. I'm afraid that in imposing such con trols they may commit a ma jor blunder and cripple this market.

title: CHURCH TO CLOSE IN CONNECTICUT
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. John Vianney in South port, Conn., established only eight years ago, will close its doors in the near future be cause of spiraling inflation and insufficient operating funds. Southport village is part of the town of Fairfield.

title: Italy Acts to Put More State Funds Into the Economy
description: ROME, July 3The Italian Government announced today a series of measures aimed at stimulating national produc tion and increasing investment, particularly in the underdevel oped South.

title: New Etta Rockleigh Victor
description: ROCKLEIGH, N. J. July 3 Jesse Ronson's aged brown mare, New Etta, took one blue ribbon and finished second in two other classes to win the regular working hunter cham pionship with II points today at the Pegasus Farm's horse show.

title: KY SEES NO OBSTACLE TO AN EARLY PULLOUT
description: SAIGON, July 3 (AP)Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said today that he saw no obstacles on the South Vietnamese side to the new Communist peace proposal that all United States troops be withdrawn from the country by the end of this year.

title: Hospitals Chief Chided on Management
description: Health Services Administra tor Gordon Chase has told the chief of the city's 18 public hospitals that he is dissatisfied with the system's manage ment, control and budgeting.

title: GiantsJets Exhibition Has Tickets Available
description: Some 6,090 tickets remain for the GiantsJets preseason game at the Yale Bowl on Aug. 22. Tickets at $7 each may be ordered by mail from the Yale Athletic Association, New Haven, Conn., 06520, with checks payable to Booth Memorial, the sponsoring charity.

title: StraightA Student Disputed by School Over Ban on Talk
description: LOS ANGELES, July 3 When Judy Schrut, an 18year old straightA student was told she would not be among the student speakers at her high school commencement last month, she had her talk printed and distributed to each mem ber of the audience.

title: Stamps
description: MATHEMATICS and scientific equations are hardly children's play, nor mine, but 10 stamps emanating from Nic aragua should intrigue mathe ematicsminded stamp collec tors. The stamp's motifs are 10 mathematical equations that changed the face of the earth. (Las 10 Formulas Matematicas que Cambiaron la faz de la Terra.) Dr. Pe ter Stubbs of the New Scien tist, in England, holds that these equations in long range importance... un doubtedly place themselves each as a major turning point in science or pure mathe matics.

title: Sale of Dry Cereals Brisk Despite Warning of Empty Calories
description: Nearly a year after a Senate subcommittee was told that most dry breakfast cereals are nothing but empty calories, American cereal bowls are snapping, crackling and pop ping much as they were be fore.

title: 20 Hurt as Bus Overturns
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., July 3 (AP)A bus chartered by the Cleveland Society for the Blind overturned today, injuring about half the 40 passengers aboard, the police said. The police said the bus hit a soft shoulder, went down a slight embank ment and rolled over.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: ONCE upon a time, in the thirties, there was a radio comic named Jack Pearl. He created a character named Baron Munchausen who, if chal lenged while telling a story, would turn to his oppressor and say, Vas you dere, Sharlie?

title: PRO FOOTBALL SET FOR EARLY START
description: Less than five months after Jim O'Brien's field goal decided the Super Bowl, the first five of 26 pro football training camps will open this week, followed by 16 mere next week.

title: Bayonne Times, Sold to Newhouse, Is Shut Down
description: BAYONNE, July 3The 100 yearold Bayonne Times ceased publication with today's edition, which announced that the newspaper's name, circulation lists and certain undisclosed assets had been sold to The Jersey Journal.

title: Glorious Fourth of 1871 Is a Quiet Day in 1971
description: With hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers gone from the city for the Independence Day weekend, there will be no pa rades here and only a bare rem nant of the exuberant display of flags that made the city call the holiday the Glorious Fourth, a hundred years ago.

title: A Lack of Concentration Finished Him, Smith Says
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 (UPI)Stan Smith, defeated by John Newcombe in the Wimbledon tennis final today, said that a lack of concentra tion finished me.

title: AN ECOLOGY PLAN IN STATE OFFERED
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 3  A program to recruit a volunteer state ecology corps to aid in protecting the environment was proposed this week by Senator Norman J. Levy.

title: 3 Big Bands Open Newport Jazz Fete
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 3 The Newport Jazz Festival opened its 18th season last night with a flourish of big bands. There were three of these relatively rare specimens on handStan Kenton's band, Buddy Rich's and Duke Elling ton's  along with Roberta Flack, the singer, and a new quartet led by Dave Pike, the vibraharpist.

title: News of the Rialto
description: AUTHOR George Furth and choreog rapher Michael Bennett, a portion of the team that helped fashion Company into the 1970 winner of the New York Drama Critics Circle's best musical laurels, will be together again on Broadway come the new sea son. But this time their venture will be a straight play, Furth's Twigs. It will be directed by Bennett, marking the first time he has directed a straight play as well as the first time he has been on his own as a director. He was recently co director of Follies with Harold Prince.

title: Photography
description: ANEW marine kit for taking 35 mm color or blackandwhite un derwater photos has recently been introduced by Braun North America, 235 Wyman Street, Waltham, Mass. 02154. Designed to re sist pressures down to 100 feet below sea level, the kit includes a ruggedly con structed clear plastic capsule which encases the camera, and a special underwater flash attachment.

title: Ellen Highsmith Is Betrothed
description: TROY, N. C., July 3Miss Ellen Highsmith and Mitchell Lawrence Silver, who are with the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency in New York, will be married here Sept. 5.

title: Bon Vivant Voluntarily Recalls All Vichyssoise From Dealers
description: Bon Vivant, Inc., disclosed yesterday that it was volun tarily recalling from dealers all the vichyssoise it produces un der 22 brand names. But it emphasized that so far Federal authorities had singled out only one 6,444can lot of its Bon Vivant brand as, a suspected carrier of deadly botulinum toxin.

title: DONALD J. MULLEN
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., July 3 Donald J. Mullen, a New York insurance executive, died today in Doctors Hospital, Freeport, after a long illness. He was 58 years old and lived at 77 Bay Drive.

title: Cesare's Secret Surface Unearths Fast Miles
description: YONKERS, July 3  Last year 11 magic mileseight furlongs in two minutes or less  were registered over the loamandsand halfmile track at Yonkers Raceway. That number set a singlesea son record for the West chester County course, where prior to tonight's card, nine such performances had been turned in far in 1971.

title: Perpetuating stock images about the South
description: The five novels of Madison Jones do not create another Yoknapatawpha County, but they do constitute, with the exception of the Civil War period, an extensive chronicle of the South. The talents Jones displays in his legend of the South are many and often fine indeed. They are strongly in evidence in his first novel, The Innocent (1957), and in his fourth, An Exile (1967). The Innocent contains strikingly realized char acters, a wide and persuasive landscape, and a potential for sig nificantly conflicting forces.

title: As American as a McDonald's Hamburger On the Fourth of July
description: JOPLIN, MO.

title: R. E. Brown Weds Miss Jayne Smith
description: YONKERS, July 3Miss Jayne Marie Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Smith, was married here to day to Richard E. Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Brawn of St. Albans, Queens. The Rev. Alger Adams per formed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: The Industrial Engineer
description: It was a weighty decision when the International Busi ness Machines Corporation chose a decade ago to employ integrated circuits in its pro posed System 360 computer line. To produce the tiny, in tricate devices on a mass production scale required the pioneering of an unfamiliar and complex manufacturing process.

title: Dr. Ian Ramsay of London Plans To Marry Patricia D. Glover
description: HOBE SOUND, Fla., July 3Mr. and Mrs. D. Coleman Glover have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Deere Glover, to Dr. Ian Douglas Ramsay of London, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Alexander Ramsay of Barnham, West Sussex, Eng land.

title: Dobson Hurls 5Hitter and Blair Bats In 4 Runs as Orioles Rout Tigers, 81
description: DETROIT, July 3 (AP)  A former Tiger, Pat Dobson pitched a fivehitter and Paul Blair drove in four runs with two doubles for the Baltimore Orioles today in an 81 victory, over Detroit.

title: 3 Arrested at La Guardia
description: Three men were arrested here yesterday by agents of the Federal bureau of Investigation on charges of transporting stolen property from Toledo, Ohio, to LaGuardia Airport. The three were identified as Michael F. Zagarino, 25 years old, of 1701 West 8th Street, Brooklyn; Anthony Sabella, 37, of 2160 Seward Avenue, the Bronx, and Joseph Lupo, 24, of 17 Avenue W. Brooklyn. They were seized at the airport.

title: Student to Wed Ellen Resnikoff
description: ASHEVILLE, N.C. July 3 Mr. and Mrs. Louis Resni koff have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Hedy Resnikoff, to Robert Anthony Garfield, son of Mrs. Theodore Abbott Garfield of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Mr. Garfield.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEW building material that is becoming in creasingly popular with professional remodel ers and doityourselfers looks and feels just like real marble, but unlike marble it is quite simple to work with. Called Corian, it can be cut, drilled, sanded and shaped with ordinary woodworking tools and its nonporous sur face is much more resistant to staining and marring be cause it is virtually imper vious to water, most house hold cleaning liquids and other chemicals or foodstuffs. It is also highly resistant to scratching, burning and scorching.

title: Judy Ann Hoss, T. R. Schwerin Plan Wedding
description: DENVER, July 3Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Hass of Denver and Sedalia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judy Ann Hass, to Thomas R. Schwerin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Schwerin of Locust Valley, L. I. The wedding is planned for July 17.

title: Wright Survived the Wrong Results
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia Bob Wright, who manages one of the largest marinas in western Canada, nearly went bankrupt when his hobby be came his business.Today, Wright breathes easier. His slips, which rent for 60 cents per foot a month, are filled. Fishing boats, which go for $2 an hour, are in great demand. Sailboat char ters have become so popular that Wright has instituted sail ing lessons. He has opened a big outboard service center and a sailingstores shop, and has installed two sets of marine railways for hull repairs.

title: China Aids Chilean Victims
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July (AP)The Government an nounced today that $2million donated by China to victims of a snowstorm here last month will be used to build a housing project in Santiago for 800 families. The storm killed 15 persons, drove thousands from their homes and caused wide spread damage.

title: New Troop Needs
description: A far different assessment came, on Feb. 12, with the Tet offensive at its hejght. General Westmoreland reported then to the Joint Chiefs and Secretary McNamara., that, as of Feb. 11, the enemy had attacked 34 provincial towns, 64 district towns and all of the autonomous cities. This, the general said, the enemy had been able to do while committing only 20 to 35 per cent of his North Vietnamese forces... employed as gap fillers where VC [Viet cong] strength was apparently not ade quate to carry out his initial thrust on the cities and towns.

title: New Air Treaty Reported Between Cuba and Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, July 3 (AP) Cuba and Mexico have agreed to a new air treaty that will allow Cubana Airlines to con tinue its twiceweekly flights between Havana and Mexico City, the Cuban Ambassador, Joaquin Hernandez Armas, said today.

title: ARTHUR E. LASKIN
description: Arthur E. Laskin, a real es tate investor and former vice president and treasurer in charge of the New York head quarters of J. Laskin & Sons, fur dressers and dyers, died Friday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 33 East 70th Street and in Greenwich.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Life
description: I was born in Kislovodsk on Dec. 11, 1918. My father, a student at the philological department of Moscow University, did not complete his studies as he enlisted as a volunteer in the 1914 War. He became an artillery offi cer on the German front, fought throughout the war and died in the summer of 1918.

title: INNOVATION URGED ON FOUNDATIONS
description: John D. Rockefeller 3d, draw ing on his 40 years of philan thropic experience, has urged foundations to shed their con servatism and show their will ingness to innovate, to take risks and to make mistakes.

title: Kiwanis PresidentElect
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (UPI)Kiwanis International's new presidentelect is Lorin J. Badskey of North Webster, Ind. He was named at the group's 56th annual convention this week to succeed Wes H. Bartlett of Angona, Iowa, who will become president in October.

title: Architecture
description: THE British tend to plant bombs, intellectually, in scholarly publications. The fallout can be deadly. Right now, the fallout is all over the architectural profession. Have you heard about the breakdown of the architectural belief system?

title: The Series So Far
description: Events before Tonkin Incidents: Study says Americanrun covert war against North Vietnam preceded Tonkin Gulf clashes by months.

title: Fresh Air Fund's Children Dazzled by Rural Marvels
description: First thing that happened when they got off the bus in Jonestown, Pa., 5yearold Her bert King and 6yearold Eddie Heribreto Conception, both from Brooklyn, had an argu ment.

title: NIXON SETS GOAL OF OPEN WORLD
description: WASHINGTON, July 3Pres ident Nixon, starting America's 200th birthday party five years ahead of time, declared tonight his goal was the building of an open world.

title: Canadian Economic Mission Ends Its Visit to Peking
description: HONG KONG, July 3 (Reu ters)A Canadian economic mission left Peking by air today for Canton on its way home after a weeklong visit to China, the Hsinhua press agen cy reported.

title: Judith McGregor to Be Married
description: The engagement of Miss Judith McGregor to Donald Richard Caldwell has been announced by Mrs. Constance Marcy McGregor of Washing ton and Robert Gardner McGregor of Sarasota, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Donald Mitchell Caldwell of Plymouth, Mass., and the late Mr. Caldwell.

title: Strolling, Novel in Hand, To Recapture the Paris of Proust
description: PARISWhen Swann's Way, the first sec tion of Marcel Proust's prodigious seven volume novel, called Remembrance of Things Past, was first published in 1913, a literary critica favorite of the French middle class at the timedescribed the work as not positively boring, though a bit banal. By the time of Proust's death in 1922, however, the novel was beginning to be recognized as a masterpiece, one that revealed French life and society as never before, not by generalizing or philosophizing about it, nor by concocting mem orable big scenes, but rather by piecing to gether an extraordinary mosaic of minute and precise observations. And today, Proust's repu tation is assured. He is widely acknowledged to be France's greatest modern writer.

title: WILLIAM P. NEWMAN
description: BANGOR, Me., July 3  Wil liam P. Newman, former presi dent and board chairman of the Eastern Trust and Banking Company here, died today at the Eastern Maine Medical Cen ter after an illness of several months. He was 82 years old.

title: Textile Woe
description: The $21  billion a year American textile industry, which understandably doesn't like bad news, is pointing to some recent negative an nouncements as confirmation of its oftexpressed fears over the flood of imports.

title: Police Given Stick of TNT
description: Two policemen on their way to the Chief Medical Examiner's office in a radio patrol car were handed a halfpound stick of TNT yesterday by a man who said he found the explosive on a doorstep at 135th Street and Park Avenue, the police said.

title: Van Zandt Hawn Fiance Of Elizabeth C. Thacher
description: Miss Elizabeth Coverdale Thacher and Van Zandt Hawn, who were graduated last month from the Univer sity of Virginia School of Law, plan to be married in September.

title: Southern Novelist Is Acquitted In Rifle Killing of Negro Soldier
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., July 3 Jesse Hill Ford, the white South ern author whose bestselling novel, The Liberation of Lord Byron Jones, described justice in the South as bigoted and brutal, was acquitted tonight of the murder of a 21yearold Negro soldier.

title: Music
description: The following letters, never before published, were obtained through a Tin Pan Alley source. Their authenticity has not been fully verified.

title: A Quarrel About the Past
description: WASHINGTON  Quarreling about the past is one of the ways in which men seek to understand the present. We study history and debate its les sons because we have an inherent human need to find standards for judgment, sources of inspiration, and guides to wiser actions.

title: Tunney's Bill Backs Youth Sports Program
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP)Senator John V. Tun ney has proposed longrange authorization and financing for the national summer youth sports program: With out legislation, the California Democrat said, the program was in danger of dying at the end of the summer.

title: Pittsburgh Divided on Skybus Project
description: PITTSBURGH, July 3Plans to build an automated skybus that would speed commuters from suburban South Hills to downtown Pittsburgh have evoked vigorous opposition here from Mayor Peter F. Flaherty.

title: HAWAII'S NATIVES SCORE ESTATE JOB
description: HONOLULU, July 3Native Hawaiians are expressing ve hement resentment over the ap pointment of a JapaneseAmer ican, Matsuo Takabuki, to the board of trustees of the Bernice Pauahi Bishop Estate.

title: Talc it from one who's been to the cleaners: For a gambler, it helps to be rich
description: THE compulsive gambler sub consciously wants to lose his shirt, of course, along with everything else he owns, and so he again and again puts down the rent money on the Montreal Expos or 80to1 2yearold maiden fillies wear ing blinkers and bandaged forelegs. And if he's nothing else, Walter Matthau, the 50yearold stage and movie actor, is a compulsive gambler. A few years ago, for instance, while in Florida to film episodes of a TV series called Tallahassee 7000, Matthau breathtakingly managed in a mere two weeks to drop no less than $183,000. He lost the money, moreover, not by backing crippled nags at Hialeah but mainly instead by betting on the outcome of spring training baseball games, a way of tossing bundles of money out the window that should surely that year have won him the Nobel Prize for masochism.

title: JAPANESE EXPORT TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 3Japanese busi nessmen with attache cases are a common sight in the lobbies of South Africa's luxury hotels these days, but they are not always and everywhere treated as honorary whites in this raceconscious country.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Pollution, No Quick Buck
description: Having the technology to alleviate industrial pollution is one thing, selling it is quite another.

title: Hempstead Residents Bar LowIncome Housing Units
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 3 Hempstead Town Presiding Su pervisor Francis T. Purcell said this week that no lowincome housing would be built in the town because of opposition from its residents.

title: Cable to Envoys in Asia on Day Of Johnson's Deescalation Speech
description: Excerpts from cablegram from State Department to United States Ambassa dors in Australia, New Zealand, Thailand, Laos, the Philippines and South, Korea, March 31, 1968, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study. The message announced provisions of the major speech President Lyndon Johnson was to make hours later. Paragraph in italics is the study's para phrase or explanation.

title: Orantes, Franulovic in Final
description: BELGRADE, July 3 (AP) Manuel Orantes of Spain and Zeljko Franulovic of Yugo slavia gained the final of the international tennis champion ship of Yugoslavia today. Oran tes defeated Bora Jovanovic of Yugoslavia, 64, 108, 63, and Franulovic downed his coun tryman, Nikola Spear, 64, 62, 62.

title: Mae Cavanagh Engaged To Henry W. Siegel 3d
description: The engagement of Miss Mae Angela Cavanagh to Henry William Siegel 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Siegel Jr. of Millbrook, N.Y., has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ed ward F. Cavanagh Jr. of New York and Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Photography
description: AMONG the books which have appeared recent ly are two notable volumes which are val uable additions to the litera ture of documentary photog raphy.

title: Kathrin Schwarzschild to Wed
description: RICHMOND, July 3Miss Kathrin Schwarzschild and Dr. George Clifford Brown, both of New York, plan to be married here on Sept. 18 at the home of the prospec tive bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Harry Schwarzschild.

title: National Notes
description: It rises like a giant steel sun flower, 250 feet into the sky above Coney Island. For decades, it offered New York adventurers of all ages a topside, bird'seye view of their cityand then breathtaking, feathery descent to earth. But the famed parachute jump at Coney is idle, now; the park has been turned into a park ing lot. And last week, the mighty steel tower suffered a final indignity: offered for sale by the city, it attracted not a single bidder.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Veep on Tour

title: Television
description: PEGGY PINN is a black woman with a mission. She will go just about anywhere and do just about anything to train my brothers and sisters in film making, and to try to get them meaningful jobs in television and the movie in dustry.

title: Thurmond's Daughter Is an Honorary WAC
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) Senator Strom Thurmond's threemonthold daughter has been appointed an honorary member of the Women's Army Corps.

title: Orientation Memo for Clifford Telling How Targets Are Chosen
description: Excerpts from memorandum from Assistant Secretary of Defense Paul C. Warnke to Clark M. Clifford, newly appointed Secretary of Defense, March 5, 1968, as provided in the body of the Pentagon study.

title: A Fork in the Road
description: In late February, the President sent General Wheeler to Saigon to consult with General Westmoreland on precisely how many more men he wanted. Gen eral Wheeler returned on Feb. 28 and immediately delivered a written report to the President, The report began by saying that General Westmoreland had frustrated the enemy's objective of proyoking a general uprising. But it went on to say that the offensive had been a very near thing for the allies and then ranged in bleak fashion over the situation in Vietnam:

title: WAR COUNT EARNS 2 HUNTER AWARDS
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., July 3 StaStill Farm'sWar Count, a descendant of Man o' War, won the amateurowner hunter championship and retired two trophies today at the Smith town Hunt horse show.

title: Elder Tops Golf Balloting For Spot in American Clasics
description: AKRON, OHIO, July 3. (UPI) Lee Elder, a professional golfer from Washington who finished third in the New Orleans open this year, was named on 114 of 139 ballots to become the top choice of the Golf Writers' Association of America for participation in the American Golf Classic.

title: Soutar Gets Bowling Lead; Davis Rolls a 299 on Coast
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., July 3 (UPI)Dave Soutar closed with a 279 game for a 1,413 sixgame series and the first round lead today in the $50,000 WinstonSalem open bowling tournament.

title: Nassau Area Takes Tennis Seriously
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I. July 3Tennis is a serious pastime in this Nassau Coun ty community, with men, wo men and youngsters of all ages, sizes and shapes slam ming balls on hundreds of public and private courts all day and under lights in the cool of the evening.

title: Springbok Team Divides Australians
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 3 Riotous demonstrations against the South African rugby team now touring Australia have be come such an intense political issue that Prime Minister Wil liam McMahon, a supporter of the tour, is considering calling national elections a year or more ahead of schedule in the expectation of profiting at the polls from the controversy.

title: Early Health Bill Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) A national healthinsurance bill will probably not be ready for House consideration earlier than 1972, Mr. Mills says in an interview in American Medical News.

title: MONDALE ASKS HALT IN SPACE PROGRAMM
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) The United States Skylab program should be halted until the Soviet Union fully analyzes the deaths of its three astro nauts. Senator Walter F. Mon dale said today.

title: Diane Lewis Plans Fall Nuptials
description: ROCHESTER, July 3Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Lewis Jr. have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Diane McNaughton Lewis, to Foster Comings Greene Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Greene of West Hartford, Conn.

title: Ann Freed Married to Allan L. Edmonds
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 3 Miss Ann Caroline Freed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Freed, was married this noon to Allan Lee Ed monds, son of Mr, and Mrs. Lee O. Edmonds of Bartles ville, Okla. The Rev. John A. Cairns performed the cere mony in the White Plains Presbyterian Church.

title: Music
description: IN 1925, Loew's added to its chain of movie palaces the St. Louis The ater. In 1927, it added the Penn Theater in Pittsburgh. Both were designed by Rapp & Rapp, architects of Chicago. In the past decade the St. Louis Symphony purchased the theater in its city for $400,000, remodeled and opened it as its new home, Powell Hall, on Jan. 24, 1968. Recently, the Pittsburgh. Symphony was able to buy the Penn Theater for $850,000 (it is in the downtown area where land is costly). With extensive renovation it is being turned into a home for the or chestra, the Pittsburgh Opera, the Pitts burgh Ballet, the Pittsburgh Youth Sym phony and the Civic Light Opera. As announced a week ago, it will open with an orchestral concert on Sept. 10, in which William Steinberg will conduct Mahler's Second Symphony and a new work commissioned from Samuel Barber for the occasion.

title: Burger Asserts Reform Is Not Role of Courts
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger believes that some dis, appointments may be in store for young people who are be ing attracted to legal careers on the theory that they can change the world by litigation in the courts.

title: Picketing L.I. Lifeguards Ordered Off State Sites
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 3 State Supreme Court Justice Arthur M. Cromarty today en joined striking Long Island lifeguards temporarily from picketing or interfering in any way with the activities of working substitute lifeguards and delivery employes on state property.

title: Mrs. Chaffee golf Victor
description: PAWTUCKET, R. I., July (AP)  Mrs. David Chaffee of Barrington captured the Rhode Island women's Golf Association championship yesterday by de feating Judy Whalon of Cran ston, 2 and 1, in the 18hole final at Pawtucket Country Club. The title was the second for Mrs. Chaffee, the former Nancy Johnson.

title: SEARCH DELAYED IN SEALED MINE
description: FAIRMONT, W. Va., July 3 Efforts by search teams in the Farmington No. 9 Mine, where seven bodies were recovered this week, are being delayed until the Seven North area has been secured.

title: Martin Eecharting Big Board Course
description: William McChesney Martin Jr., who helped chart the course of the New York Stock Exchange 30 years ago, is back in Wall Street after long absence, once again pondering the fate of the securities industry.

title: Air Price War Worries Administration
description: The Nixon Administration is showing deep concern about the spreading price war in the international airtravel market.

title: Stewart Wins Pole Position for Duel With Ickx in French Grand Prix Today
description: LE CAMP DU CASTELLET, France, July 3The French have modernized grand prix racing. The result is the track of the future and about as much glamour as a computerized can opener.

title: Chess
description: WHEN the chess journalists assem bled at the Palma de Mallorca Interzonal tournament last year voted Bobby Fischer the top player of 1970, there were few dis senterseven on the Other Side. In deed, if anyone had been so audacious as to dissent, the journalists could have produced wholly convincing statistics to back up their choice: In 1970 grand master Robert James Fischer scored 47 victories against top class opposition, drew 23 games, and lost only 3a score of 80 per cent!

title: Ward Sees Horse Of Another Color In Sans Marque
description: Horse Show News

title: Blockbusting Curb Faces a Court Test Here
description: New strategies for curbing the blockbusting that has plagued neighborhoods in four Brooklyn and Queens commu nities will be tested shortly by state and city agencies and by civic and religious groups.

title: Elizabeth Little Fiancee of Doctor
description: SUMMIT, N.J., July 3Mr. and Mrs. W. Putnam Living ston of Summit and Centre Lovell, Me., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Liv ingston's daughter, Miss Elis abeth Wolcott Little, to Dr. Daniel Marie Gerard Leyre of Montpellier, France. The cou ple plan to marry in Novem ber.

title: The Best Way to See The Old Bailey Is To Commit Murder. But There Are Alternatives
description: LONDON  The 6,000 members of the American Bar Association visitina London from July 14 to 20 for their annual meeting will find their counterparts here in quite a tizzy. When Britain's Attorney Gen eral proposed a few modest law re forms a few years back he was greeted, as someone put it, with a frenzied baying noise as sometimes ends the wilder sort of hunt ball.

title: Canda Gives Grants to Athletes To Plug a Brawn Drain to U.S.
description: OTTAWA  Under the po litical sponsorship of John C. MOM an overweight Cab inet minister (5 feet 10 1/2 inches, 215 pounds) who has no time to exercise; the Fed eral Government has under taken a multipronged pro gram to strengthen amateur sports in Canada.

title: The Nation
description: He was a newstyle Mafia lead errespectable. But last week he was gunned down, according to police, in an oldstyle Mafia war.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Recordings
description: THERE is public music, and there is private music, and we need both. Certain compos ers, such as Berlioz, rarely write anything other than public music, even when they try to adopt an in timate tone; others never seem to be addressing a crowd, even when they cast their ideas in larger forms, as Schubert did in his sym phonies. But who among composers today is writing successfully for large audi ences, or even in the tone of voice needed to hold the crowd's attention? Some of the pop musicians, of course, but no very important clas sically rooted composer. Yet the classical humanist tradi tion values nothing higher than a work, such as Bee thoven's Ninth, that speaks to all men, that appeals to their communality as much as to their privateness.

title: Egyptian Engineer Held In Cairo as Spy for Israel
description: CAIRO, July 3An Egyptian engineer captured by Israeli troops in the Sinai Peninsula during the 1967 war was re ported today to have been ar rested here on charges of espi onage or behalf of Israel.

title: Nader Opens Inquiry Into A.A.A. Policies On Consumer Issues

title: The Amchitka Affair...
description: Amchitka is a remote, uninhabited island more than a thousand miles west of Anchorage, Alaska. It is the site chosen by the Atomic Energy Commission for this coun try's biggest underground nuclear test. Intended to be the warhead for the Spartan antiballistic missile, the nuclear device when detonated will set off an explosion with the force of five million tons of TNT. That is approximately 250 times more powerful than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima.

Corona, accused of mass killings, recessed today for the Independence Day weekend without acting. Mr. Corona has been hospitalized for more than two weeks for treatment of an apparent heart attack.

title: I as Sorry To See It End
description: AS much as I can remember of that pertion of my life spent in the false twilights of movie theaters, I've experienced only three or our movies that I was genuinely sorry to see end. W. S. Van Dyke's Tarzan The Ape Man was one, but, as it turned out, it didn't really end since it became a continuing series for Johnny Weiss muller and Maureen O'Sullivan. They weren't allowed to quit until age made it obvious that the only decent thing to do was to dress them in the kind of clothes God intended them to wear.

title: A touch of nostalgia
description: Nostalgia and romanticism may be news to the theater world, but to decorating, they are strictly old hat. Rooms rich with whimsey and houses that seem to have changed almost imperceptibly with each passing generation are the hall mark of one school of skilled decorators. Anything that appears too planned or matched or shines too brightly with newness is taboo in their romantic rooms. Instead, furnishings are softened and tempered with the patina of age (or its decorating equivalent). This small sitting room with walls of chrysanthemum yellow edged in white exemplifies the romantic spirit. Designer John Robert Moore 2d centered the Regency bull's eye mirror over the fireplace whose tiles are painted with trompe l'oeil animals. To its left, he placed an English lacquered writing table with a whimsical pagoda top. Botanical prints hang over it. On the right is a lacquered tea table with Chinese fretwork. Unmatched patterns vouch for the freedom of the romantic spirit seen here in the chintzcovered chair and its openarmed neigh bor, a gilt Adam chair covered in a silk sari print. The floors are covered in woven straw mats in stead of the tobeexpected heavy walltowall carpeting.

description: To the Editor:

description: GARDINERS ISLAND, L.I., July 3On a deserted beach on this private island last week a young ornithologist crept up to a nest that con tained a baby osprey and deposited in it another fledg ling.

title: Naughty Gal, a Scottish Terrier, Is judged Best of Show in Massachusetts
description: NORTON, Mass., July 3 Mrs. Charles Stalter's Scottish terrier, Ch. Balachan Naughty Gal, was as good as gold today when she was named best in show at the fifth annual dog show of the Hockamock Ken nel Club, held on the grounds of the Norton Elementary School. The victory over 853 other dogs adds to the 3yearold's record of best of breed at Madison Square Garden and best in show at Greenwicsh, Conn.

title: Kerr on The Last Analysis and Black Girl
description: PRODUCER  DIRECTOR Theodore Mann has done playwright Saul Bellow no favor in re viving The Last Analysis at Circle in the Square. The Last Analysis has been one of those faintly legendary failures that a determined cult, no doubt out of admira tion for bellow the novelist, has loyally clung to, holding it a superior piece of satirical work destroyed in its original Broadway production by (a) an inferior mounting, (b) im perceptive reviewers, or (c) an indifferent, if not mind less, middleclass audience. The mistake in reviving it is that everyone who's ever heard the legend can now go to check on it for himself. Which means that this is like ly to be the last of The Last Analysis.

title: Packers Appoint Scout
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 3 (UPI)The Green Bay Packers announced today that Bill Tobin had been hired as a personnel scout. He was a running back with the Houston Oilers in the American Football League in 1963 and 1964.

title: COMPUTERS ERRED ON WAR PROTESTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 At the start of the first Vietnam moratorium on Oct. 15, 1969, Army computers put together a detailed catalogue of antici pated disturbances in nearly 200 city squares and college campuses around the country. Events proved it to be an essen tially misleading estimate of a peaceful day of antiwar pro test.

title: The Last Word: Stendhal on Love
description: Around World War II students at Columbia College were being treated to the Socratic method by a master. A boy, big with answer, would thrust up his band, get the nod and rise: Because, sir, the boy would say; Troilus loved Cressida. Raymond Weaver, sensing that his time had come around again, would draw a handkerchief from his breast pocket, touch it to his lips, pause like an actor consuming 300 frames for a facial effect, and ask: What . . . do . . . you . . . mean . . . by . . . love? The boy would scoop handfuls of air, do a softshoe routine; and love would remain a mystery.

title: White Cane Safety Day Set

title: Where Have Intermissions Gone?
description: NOBODY pays any attention to intermissions anymore. In fact, practically nobody has inter missions anymore. More and more often, on Broadway as well as off, the curtain goes up, the play goes on, the customer notices after a while that his feet are going to sleep and he could do with a stretch, the customer glances at his watch to see if it isn't about time for a nice little break, the cus tomer notices that it is well past the time for a nice little break, and the customernow in panicrips open his program. Yep. There it is. Tonight's play is to be performed without an intermission.

title: Books of The Times
description: To her short fiction, Cynthia Ozick brings qualities that are largescaled, majestic, generous. She works out of a tradition, mostly European, that is not afraid, even within modest limits, to employ a broad canvas, an abundance of characters, a variety of incidents. She does not depend on the small epiphany or the arch nostory or the extended anecdote. Her sto ries are in the scale if not the dimensions of a novel. Her imagi nation runs by in stinct to the fan tastic and the supernatural, and these elements ap pear in her stories as naturally as the events of every day. In fact so heightened, so taut, are the feel ings and spirit of her characters that we are surprised, for example, that Envy, a beautifully written and magnifi cently realized novella, really takes place on the level of the commonplace. And in Virility, one expects the hand of God or Satan to intervene though neither does or needs to. The explanation, to the puzzle is simple enough.

title: The CollectionOver 7,000 Items and Still Growing
description: When President Johnson ac cepted the Joseph H. Hirsh horn collection for the nation a little more than five years ago, it contained about 7,000 sculptures and paintings. Since the formal acceptance of this gift of more than Medici proportions, Mr. Hirshhorn has acquired 2,000 more sculptures and paint ings with the intention of adding them to the collection to be installed in the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Wash tington.

title: The Talk of Howard Johnson's
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., July 4Laniel Hopkins Lawson 3d had flipped his fourth frenchfried potato at his sis ter, using his fork as a cata pult, and was preparing an other launch when his moth er's patience expired.

title: Make Mine Semiautomatic
description: The gentlemen of the Building In spectors Union are to be congratulated on their demand to be allowed to carry guns in the pursuance of their duties. The rapid escalation of the number of groups allowed this privilege has made obvious to the average citi zen of New York that his only alter native to a planned withdrawal from the city is the widespread deployment of defensive arms. If building inspectors need guns to enter buildings, their residents certainly do. A firearm has become the sine qua non of the con tinued existence of the individual in our large urban centers. Once this fact is recognized, careful consideration must be given to its ramifications.

title: Leaders of the Insurgency
description: Vietcong organizer, nineteenfifties; Secretary, Lao Dong (Communist) party Central Committee for the Southern Re gion 1956; Secretary General Lao Dong party, 1959; since 1960, First Secretary of party . . . born into peasant family, Quangtri province in central Vietnam, 1908 . . . worked as secretary with rail ways, Hanoi . . . given 20year prison term for subversive activities, 1930: released 1936, resumed political work for Indochinese Communist Party . . given 10year sentence, 1940. . . re leased on Vietminh takeover 1945 . . . led guerrillas against French in South starting 1946 . . . commissioner at Viet minh's military headquarters in South, 1952 . . rose in party, named First Sec retary, September, 1960 . . . led Hanoi delegation to 1967 50thanniversary celebations in Moscow . . . since Ho Chi Minh's death, has emerged as first among equals in collective leadership . . . has sponsored popular economic re forms . . . advocates protracted war strategy . . . said to be selfeffacing, pragmatic . . .

description: Robert Barnes Rudd, Tomp kins Professor of English Lit erature Emeritus of Hamilton College, died Saturday in a nursing home in White Plains. He was 83 years old and lived in Clinton, N.Y.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: MUSKIE REPORTED SOUTH'S FAVORITE
description: WASHINGTON, July 4If the Democratic National Con vention were held tomorrow, Senator Edmund S. Muskie could expect the votes of a large majority of the Southern states.

title: Proposal to Hunt the White Ibis Stirs Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 4 The Louisiana Legislature last year designated the white ibis as a game bird and instructed the State Wildlife and Fisheries Commission to open a hunting season for it.

title: Tea Exports Down In Ceylon's 1st Half
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 4 Exports of tea declined during the first half of 1971, but the commodity remained Ceylon's main earner of foreign ex change, it was reported here today.

title: Lansdale in the Breach
description: While Colonel Lansdale's team car ried out its covert operations, the major policy decisions made by the National Security Council in August, 1954, were being put into practice.

title: State's Rainbow Division Offers Economic Rainbow to Watertown
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., July 4 It's not the holiday, or the lovely weather, or the beatitiful lakes that has brought the crowds this weekend to this centuryandahalfold city in the dairy country of Jefferson County.

title: WILLIAM F. DIETZ
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 4William F. Dietz, who retired recently as advertising manager of Topics Publishing Company, publisher of Drug Trade News, died here Friday. He was 70 years old and lived at 341 Raymond Street.

title: 2 Retain Water Ski Title
description: CYPRESS GARDENS, Fla., July 4 (AP) Larry Sheppard and Len Novakofski, 1970 champions, obtained almost per fect scores today in the All American water ski champion ships to retain their titles.

title: Office Help Scarce Here, But Jobless Rolls Grow
description: In offices throughout the city, busy executives are an swering their own telephones, filing their own memos and fall ing behind in their correspon dence and accounts because of an acute shortage of office help.

title: Miss Dianne Foley Married in Jersey
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 4The marriage of Miss Dianne Virginia Foley to Ture Olof Dorrnsjo Jr. took place in the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Chapel at Seton Hall University here this afternoon. Msgr. Edward Fleming performed the cere mony.

title: 1952 Policy Statement by U.S. On Goals in Southeast Asia
description: Statement of Policy by the National Security Council, early 1952, on United States Objectives and Courses of Action With Respect to Southeast Asia. According to a footnote, the document defined Southeast Asia as the area. embracing Burma, Thailand, Indochina, Malaya and Indonesia.

title: 4 Ship Collisions Off Japan Leave 1 Dead, 10 Missing
description: TOKYO, July 4 (AP)Eigllt freighters were involved in four collisions that left one per son dead and 10 missing and three ships sunk in dense fog off western Japan late yester day and today, Japan's Mari time Safety Agency reported.

title: Brink of Intervention
description: In the spring of 1954, as the French military position in Indochina deterio rated rapidly and the date for the Ge neva conference approached, the Eisen hower Administration twice hinted to France that it was ready to intervene with American forces.

title: TURCO FREE IN BAIL AFTER HIS MISTRIAL
description: BALTIMORE, July 4 (UPI) Arthur Turco, a New York law yer, was free in $10,000 bail today for the first time since his arrest in Baltimore eight months ago.

title: Agnew Celebrates the Holiday on Flight to Singapore
description: SINGAPORE, July 4Vice President Agnew raised a glass, to both friends and critics as he celebrated July 4 some 35,000 feet above the South China Sea en route from Seoul to Singapore.

title: Airing of Pentagon Data Backed in Poll
description: A Gallup Poll made public to day indicates that, even before the Supreme Court ruled In fa vor of newspapers' right to publish the Pentagon papers, a majority of Americans familiar with the issue thought publica tion of the articles was the right thing.

title: ALBERT B. TIBBETS OF NATIONAL LEAD
description: CARMEL, N. Y., July 4  Albert B. Tibbets, retired sales promotion manager of the Na tional Lead Company and a former newspaperman, who had been a leader in civic activities, died Friday in Putnam Com munity Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Croton Falls.

title: Palestine Liberation Army Said to Oust Communists
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 4 The Palestine Liberation Army has been purged of elements described as Communists or Communist sympathizers, ac Cording to reports published in the press, here today.

title: Red Sox Homers Sink Yanks
description: BOSTON, July 4Carl Yas trzemski, who has been booed lately in Fenway Park, reported ill today and his place in the Boston Red Sox lineup was taken by Joe Lahoudwho hit two home runs the first two times he batted to lead Boston to a 74 victory over the New York Yankees.

title: Dr. D. J. Mayerson Weds Miss Mann
description: EAST CHATHAM, N. Y., July 4Miss Bonnie Mann, daughter of Louis Mann of Great Neck, L. I.; and the late. Mrs. Mann, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Donald, J. Mayerson of New York and, East Chatham, son of Mr. and Mrs: Sam Meyerson of Brook lyn. Rabbi Harry Lawrence performed the ceremony at the, home of the bridegroom.

title: Greyhound and Bret Hanover Named Best of Century
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 4 (AP) Greyhound has been select ed as the outstanding trotter of the century and Bret Han over as the top pacer in a membership poll of the Hall of Fame of the Trotter. The results were announced yes terday.

title: FULTON TRIUMPHS IN Y.R.A. REGATTA
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 4 A Yacht Racing Association fleet of 140 got in some excel lent racing today in a south southwest breeze that built up from 9 to 14 knots off the Laraohmont Yacht Club.

title: Ramsin Takes $270,000 Race In France as Tarbes Runs 3d
description: SAINTCLOUD, France, July 4Ramsin won the $270,000 Grand Prix de SaintCloud to day, the first major French weightforage contest of the thoroughbred season. The 121/4furlong race wao run at the Val D'or racetrack in the hills overlooking the Seine.

title: China Backs Vietnam Peace Proposals
description: HONG KONG, July 4China gave full backing to the latest Communist peace proposals for a settlement of the war in Vietnam in an editorial in Peking's Jenminh Jih Pao to day.

title: Soviet Space Scientist States Salyut Program Will Continue
description: MOSCOW, July 4A Soviet space scientist said today that, despite the death of the three Soyuz 11 astronauts last week, their work aboard the Salyut orbiting space station was suc cessful and that similar stations would be developed in the future.

title: The Geneva Disaster
description: When the Geneva agreements were concluded on July 21, 1954, the account says, except for the United States, the major powers were satisfied with their handiwork.

title: Isaac Captures Firecracker 400
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 (AP)Bobby Isaac finished with his Dodge's hood flapping in the wind to whip Richard Petty by four seconds in the Firecracker 400 stock car race today.

title: EVERETT D. M'COOEY
description: Everett D. McCooey, last sure viving son of John H. McCooey, the late Brooklyn Democratic leader, died Saturday in Flush ing (Queens) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 14210 Roosevelt Avenue in Flushing.

title: Memo of EisenhowerDulles Talk On the French CeaseFire Plan
description: Memorandum by Robert Cutler, special assistant to President Dwight Eisenhower, May 7, 1954.

title: Report of Ho's Appeals to U.S. In '46 to Support Independence
description: Following are the texts of key documents accompanying the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war, covering events in the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents appear verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.

title: SOVIET AND EGYPT BACK SUEZ POLICY
description: MOSCOW, June 4The So viet Union and Egypt affirmed tonight that the Suez Canall should be opened only it Israel agreed to withdraw her forces from all occupied Arab territory.

title: South Asia: The Approach of Tragedy
description: ESSEX, Conn.Unless two rather unlikely developments occur, South Asia is in imminent danger of erupting into a tragic, needless war.

title: Vernon Downs Barn Burns
description: VERNON, N, Y., July 4 (AP) Fire destroyed a 26horse barn at the Vernon Downs har ness track early today, but only one of the 23 horses in the building was injured. Track spokesmen said four grooms discovered the fires shortly be fore 5 A.M.

title: '54 Report by Special Committee On the Threat of Communism
description: Excerpts from Part II of the Special Committee's Report on Southeast Asia, April 5, 1954. Part I was not made available with it.

title: Deadly Loot Still Missing
description: ARVADA, Colo., July 4 (UPI) There was no response today to an appeal by the police for help in recovering a stolen con tainer of highly contagious spi nal meningitis bacillus. The germ was part of the loot taken by a burglar from the home of a researcher at the Colorado General Hospital Friday night or early yesterday.

title: NAUGHTY GAL BEST FOR 2D DAY IN ROW
description: NORTH FALMOUTH, Mass., July 4Mrs. Charles Stalter's Scottish terrier, Ch. Balachan Naughty Gal didn't live up to her name this weekend as she went best in show two days in a row.

title: PowerSupply Increases In New England Debated
description: BOSTONNothing ever real ly changes in the electric util ity industry. They're still fight ing the same publicvs.private power battles of the Thirties. The only difference is the pres ence of environmentalists who appear to be fighting both sides.

title: Author, Acquitted in Slaying, Expected the Worst
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., July (AP)Jesse Hill Ford, the white novelist who Was acquit ted late last night in the slay ing of a black man, said today he was ready, to, go back to work. The allmale jury, which included one black man, de liberated nine hours.

title: Oath by Lee Displayed
description: RICHMOND, July, 4 (AP) Robert E. Lee's oath of allegi ance to the United States, lost for more than a century and recently discovered in a bundle of papers in the National Ar chives, has been put on display at the Museum of the Confed eracy. Lee signed the oath in Lexington, Va., on Oct. 2 1865, the day he became president of what is now Washington and Lee University.

title: WILKINS ASSERTS YOUTHS ARE HARD
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 4  To Roy Wilkins, two months away from his 70th birthday, the young black activists of today differ most dramatically from their predecessors in the hard ness of the younger men and their lack of trust of white people.

title: Israel's Offer to Aid Blacks Irks South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 4A $2,850 gift of fered recently by Israel to the Organization of African Unity, has irked the South African Government and has caused strains within, this country's Jewish community.

title: Rabbi Is Criticized for Views on Jesus
description: Two leaders of American Orthodox Judaism have criti cized a Reform rabbi for hisl assertion that the American Jewish religious community should reexamine tie role of Jesus as a prophet and teacher within the Jewish tradition.

title: Javits Foresees Vietnam Pullout by Mid1972
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he believed President Nixon would an nounce on Nov. 1 that Viet namization has been completed and that we are getting out just as rapidly as our troops and materiel can be redeployed.

title: Commanded Asiatic Fleet
description: Admiral Hart, who entered the United States Naval Acad emy in 1893 and retired in 1945 to serve for two years as an appointed Senator from Con tiecticut, filling a vacancy, was one of the senior commanders in World War II.

title: Dulles Cable Barring Intervention
description: Cablegram from Secretary Dulles to Ambassador Dillon in Paris, April 5, 1954.

title: Peking Gives Hanoi Aid
description: TOICYO, July 4 (AP)China. agreed today to supply North Vietnam with additional mili: tary aid, the Chinese press. agency Hsinhua reported in a broadcast monitored here in, Tokyo. No details were given of what was covered in the agreement.

title: Births
description: CATTIERMr. and Mrs. Joan Cattier of Locust Valley, N.Y., wish to announce the birth of a son, Jacques Edouard on June 18, 1971.

title: Leaders of the Insurgency
description: Vietcong organizer, nineteenfifties; Secretary, Lao Dong (Communist) party Central Committee for the Southern Re gion 1956; Secretary General Lao Dong party, 1959; since 1960, First Secretary of party . . . born into peasant family, Quangtri province in central Vietnam, 1908 . . . worked as secretary with rail ways, Hanoi . . . given 20year prison term for subversive activities, 1930: released 1936, resumed political work for Indochinese Communist Party . . . given 10year sentence, 1940. . . re leased on Vietminh takeover 1945 . . . led guerrillas against French in South starting 1946 . . . commissioner at Viet minh's military headquarters in South, 1952 . . . rose in party, named First Sec retary, September, 1960 . . . led Hanoi delegation to 1967 50thanniversary celebations in Moscow . . . since Ho Chi Minh's death, has emerged as first among equals in collective leadership . . . has sponsored popular economic re forms . . . advocates protracted war strategy . . . said to be selfeffacing, pragmatic . . .

title: The American Breakdown
description: There is evidence enough to support any survey's finding that Americans have a new and urgent concern over national unity, political stability and law and order. The survey results released by Potomac Asso ciates, Inc., the other day only tend to confirm what many observers have felt intuitively for some time. This is that the United States has slid backwards over the past five years and that continued social unrest is likely to lead to a real breakdown in this country.

title: 2d Big WilkesBarre Fire
description: WILKESBARRIE, Pa., July 4 The second general alarm fire in as many days occurred here today when the business offices and warehouse of the Paul J. Eyerman Inc., Roofing Com pany were destroyed. Damage was estimated at more than $750,000. Nine firemen were in jured, none seriously, yesterday when fire destroyed three build ings across from City Hall.

title: Nixon Names Trustees Of Hirshhorn Museum
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) President Nixon announced over the weekend the ap pointment of eight members of the board of trustees of the planned Joseph H. Hirsh horn Museum and Sculpture Garden here.

title: Hirshhorn Museum Taking Shape in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  As the steel skeleton of the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum takes shape along the grassy mall in front of the Capitol and as work proceeds on the float ing granite doughnut that will house the prodigious Hirshhorn collection, no one talks seriously of stopping the project, yet controversy clings to it like bittersweet vines.

title: Holiday Race Held
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 4A special 22hour Inde pendence Day distance race was held today in addition to the 79yacht race of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club in the reg ular Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association competition.

title: Rights Report Is Critical Of Wide Mayday Arrests
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The District of Columbia Human Re lations Commission has report ed that more than half of the 10,000 young people arrested during the Mayday demonstra tions here two months ago did not violate any law.

title: Guachero Star Victor
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., July 4 Alan Burtis's Guachero returned to the Star Class winner's circle today as 46 boats sailed with the Sea Cliff Y.C. in the Hemp stead Harbor competition.

title: Greece's Political Prisoners
description: In his letter on this page, Greece's Ambassador to the United States indulges in semantics in an effort to per suade Americans that there are no longer any political prisoners under the military dictatorship he serves. But his definition of political prisoner is too narrow and his facts are misleading.

title: Eisenhower Committee's Memo On French Requests for Aid
description: Excerpts from memorandum for the record, Jan. 30, 1954, by Brig. Gen. Charles H. Bonesteel 3d on meeting of President's. Special Committee on Indochina.

title: 2 U.S. Plays in Paris Are Hailed at Close
description: PARIS, July 4An excep tional theatrical venture came to an end here last night with the last performances of two American plays that have been showered with critical praise by French critics.

title: Brown Gains Net Semifinal
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 4 Bailey Brown of Bronxville Field Club, the defending cham pion, John Mangan of Manurs ing Island Club, Rye; Bill Tully of Pelham Country Club, and Dick Goldstein of the County Tennis Club of Hartsdale reached the semifinal round of the Westchester County Ten nis League's 40th annual Paul Martin Memorial tournament today. The matches are being held at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club.

title: Braves Pin 20 Loss on Mets;
description: A skywriting airplane printed God Bless America across the sky above Shea Sta dium, and Jane Jarvis at her organ played such patriotic tunes as America the Beauti ful, Semper Fidelis and the Halls of Montezuma in the Stadium.

title: ALBERT MATARASSO
description: LONG BEACH, L.L, July 4 Albert Matarasso, a retired in surance broker and a leader in the Sephardic Jewish commu nity, who translated books from Ladino, the language spoken by the Sephardim, died today. He was 81 years old and lived at 450 Shore Road.

title: Miss Kelly Gains Award
description: BAYSHORE, LI., July 4  The South Bay Cruising Club's Broadside Award, given to the outstanding female skipper with an allgirl crew, was won today for the second straight year by Patricia Kelly, a Bayshore schoolteacher.

title: Texts of Final Declaration at Geneva Conference And U.S. Statement Renouncing Use of Force
description: Following are the texts of the final declaration endorsed orally by France, the Vietminh, Britain, China, the So viet Union, Laos and Cambodia at the end of the Geneva conference in July, 1954, and of the statement of United States policy delivered at the conclud ing session by Under Secretary of State Walter Bedell Smith. The final declaration, along with the armistice agreement signed by France and the Vietminh, constitutes the Geneva ac cords on Vietnam.

title: BOSTON PRELATE ASSAILS ABORTION
description: The Most Rev. Humberto S. Medeiros, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, said yes terday that 165,000 human lives were snuffed out by legalized abortion in the city of New York last year.

title: Personal Finance
description: After a few trips to Florida or other coldweather resorts and basking in the warm winter sun, middleaged Northern couples are apt to ask, why not retire there?

title: 3 G.I.'s Are Reported Killed By Enemy Shells at Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 5 (UPI)A mor tar barrage by enemy gunners struck a barracks filled with sleeping American soldiers at an air base in Danang at mid night and sent flames tracing through nearby buildings, mili tary sources said today.

title: Political Struggle
description: The Pentagon study divides the de velopment of the insurgency in South Vietnam into roughly three periods:

title: Health Measures Urged At Talks on Environment
description: STOCKHOLM, July 4 (Reu ters)A Council of Europe conference on environmental health today called on govern ments to take measures to pro tect people from impure food, bad housing, unmanageable waste and pollution.

title: Jehovah's Witnesses Told Nations Face Collision With God
description: More than 60,000 Jehovah's Witnesses who filled Yankee Stadium at the close of a five day assembly were warned yes terday by their president of an imminent collision of all na tions, head on, with Jehovah our God during the lifetime of our generation on earth.

title: 15 Entered in $117,400 Suburban at Aqueduct
description: The big money and the big crowd will be at Aqueduct to day, but the big race will more likely be at Monmouth Park.

title: DIP IN BIRTH RATE ON RELIEF ROLLS REPORTED BY CITY
description: A dramatic reduction in births among welfare recipients here was disclosed yesterday, by Hu man Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman, who attrib uted the decline to the impact of family planning services.

title: Details on Chinese Informant
description: Cablegram from Under Secretary Bedell Smith at Geneva to Secretary Dulles, July 19, 1954.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Shortage of Jobs Causing Women a Special Problem
description: DETROIT, July 2The only jobs we have is where nobody on God's green earth would go, complained a normally gentle, whitehaired counselor for women seeking work.

title: Public Broadcasting Scored on Commercial Trend
description: Noncommercial public broad Casting has been charged with casting itself in the mold of commercial television and as piring to become a fourth net work under the decentralized domination of the Ford Foun dation, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Soviet Supports Proposals
description: MOSCOW, Monday, July 5, (Reuters)Pravda, the Soviet: Communist party newspaper, pledging continued support for North Vietnam, said today that the recent Vietcong peace pro posals offered a good basis for, a political settlement in Viet nam and eventually the whole of Indochina.

title: Letters of Independence
description: Following last week's landmark freedomofinformation Supreme Court decision, it is now possible to publish a series of supersecret letters. Some anonymous sources hint that this series of letters actually doesn't exist. Others don't bother to hint.

title: Trevino Wins in Playoff; Palmer Quits British Golf
description: MONTREAL, July 4Lee Trevino, who recently beat Jack Nicklaus in an 18hole playoff for the United States Open golf title, won the Can adian open today by running in a birdie putt against Art Wall Jr. on the first hole of a sudden death playoff.

title: Canadian Says Pentagon Study Omits '66 Peace Offer by Hanoi
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Ches ter A. Ronning, a retired Cana dian diplomat, said today that accounts he had read of the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war did not describe a visit he had made to Hanoi in March, 1966, in which the North Vietnamese gave him what he considered to be major new peace offer.

title: Mrs. Pick Is Wed To Dr. Eissner In Illinois Home
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., July 4Mrs. H. Judith Pick of Chicago was married here this afternoon to Dr. Bruce Allyn Eissner of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. M. Thorn as Eissner of Bainwine, N. Y., who were marking their. 42d wedding anniversary today. Rabbi Allan Tarsish perform ed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Neis ser, cousins of the bride.

title: Kissinger and Thieu Confer on Pullout
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4  Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national se curity adviser, conferred with President Nguyen Van Thieu for two Moots today on a broad range of topics including future American troop withdrawals, economic and military aid and the latest Communist peace proposals.

title: Sir Maurice Bowra, Hellenist Who Taught at Oxford, Dead
description: OXFORD, England, July 4 (AP)  Sir Maurice Bowra, one of the world's outstand ing authorities on classical. Greek, died today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: For years now, heroin addicts have been sent to State and Federal hospitals in the United States, detoxified and held for varying lengths of time, usually a few weeks, then released in the hope that they would not return to heroin. The results have not been encouraging. An overwhelming majority of ad diets have returned to the places where they first became addicted and re sumed their habit. In fact, the success rate even among highly tbuted rehabilitation programs that work with addicts for years has not been encouraging.

title: Creek Churches Hold Joint Independence Rite
description: The Greek Orthodox churches in this country con ducted special doxologies yesterday in joint observance of American independence and Greek independence.

title: India Denies Charge
description: NEW DELHI, July 4 (Reu ters)The Indian Defense Min istry said today it had no knowledge of any attacks by Indian Air Force planes on East Pakistani territory. Paki stan's charges of attacks were totally unfounded, a spokes man said.

title: Highlights of the Period
description: South Vietnam, the secret Pentagon account contends, is essentially the cre ation of the United States, and the formative years were those of the Tru man andin particularthe Eisenhower Administrations.

title: ALBERT S. SKLAR
description: Albert S. Sklar, prsident of J. Sklar Manufacturing Com pany, makers of surgical instru ments, died Saturday evening in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 650 Park Avenue.

title: East Haven Adds a Curfew After Disorders at Beach
description: EAST HAVEN, Conn., July 4 Mayor Frank Messina today announced a curfew from 11 P.M. to 5 A.M. following dis turbances last night in which scores of youths in beach areas scuffled with the police.

title: Urban Woes Follow Refugees From City
description: FISHKILL, N. Y.George B. Young bought his home in this still semirural commu nity to escape the abrasions of life in the city, 60 miles to the south.

title: JACOB STEIN
description: Jacob Stein, a retired cutter who was a founder of Local 10, International Ladies Garment Workers Union, died, yesterday at his home, 418 East Market Street, Long Beach, L.I. His age was 81.

title: Markets Are Closed
description: All domestic commodity, fi nancial and stock markets will be closed today in a Monday observance of the Independ ence Day holiday. Banks will also be closed. Canadian and London markets will be open for trading.

title: Miss Jean A. Joseph Is Bride Of Mohan Kumar, an Engineer
description: HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J. July 4Miss Jean A. Jo seph and Mohan Udiaver Kumar were married here twice this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John L. Joseph of Hasbrouck Heights.

title: PRINCETON CLASS SHUNS AEROSPACE
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 4  Formerly considered one of the most promising fields for col lege graduates, the aircraft in dustry now seems about as attractive as a plane crash to most students in the Depart ment of Aerospace and Me chanical Sciences at Princeton University.

title: 39 MARINE RECRUITS FELLED BY PUSHUPS
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S. C. July 4 (UPI)Marine Corps officials said today that 39 recruits had been hospitalized with kidney trouble, complaining that they had been forced to do pushups for as long as half an hour with out rest.

title: Excerpts From Lansdale Team's Report on Covert Vietnam Mission in '54 and '55
description: ...This is the condensed account of one year in the operations of a cold war combat team, written by the team itself in the field, little by little in mo ments taken as the members could. The team is known as the Saigon Mili tary Mission. The field is Vietnam. There are other teams in the field, American, French, British, Chinese, Vietnamese, Vietminh, and others. Each has its own story to tell. This is ours.

title: Qualified Progress ...
description: Assessing the first year's operations of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, Com missioner Henry L. Diamond was no doubt entitled put the best possible light on its achievementsand he did. There were grounds for selfcongratulation, partic ularly on the introduction of the toughest pesticides regulations in the country and the prompt and effective reduction of mercury discharges into the state's water ways within months of that hazard's discovery.

title: Sue Lyon Wed in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 4 (UPI)  Sue Lyon, who played the title role in the film Lo lita, was married today to Roland Harrison of Los Angeles. The actress, who is 24 year old, and Mr. Harrison, who is in his late 20's, were married at the Chapel of the Stars. It was the second marriage for Miss Lyon, who was divorced from Hamp ton Fancher 3d in 1964. Mr. Harrison is with a concern that makes TV commercials.

title: Independence Day
description: Banks, stock exchanges, post offices and many de partment and retail stores and library branches are closed. There is no regular refuse collection and Sun day parking rules are in effect.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The oldest sporting event in Britain, according to British historian, H. A. Harris, is a sculling race for ap prentice watermen, the taxidrivers of the 18th century. The race, called Doggett's Coat and Badge, was first held in 1715. Harris writes: When rowing as an amusement became popular in the schools and universities of Britain early in the nineteenth century, it was felt that these youngsters could not fairly be expected to compete against men for whom rowing was a fulltime occupation, and so watermen were excluded from their regattas. There was similar class of professional runners, employed to carry messages quickly about London. The diarist Pepys records a race on July 30th 1663 between the Duke of Richmond's running footman and a challenger. These watermen and footmen may be called work professionals.

title: City Policeman Held As a Lone Gunman In String of Holdups
description: MINEOLA, L.L, July 4The Nassau County police an nounced today that they had arrested a New York City pa trolman they believe may be the lone robber who, since last August, has held up as many as 25 drugstores for their cash receipts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DavidoffEisenberg Duo Defeats Oberts in Handball
description: Carl and Ruby Obert, top seeded, were defeated in the semifinals of the national Amateur Athletic Union one wall handball championships yesterday by Ken Davidoff and Howie Eisenberg.

title: Delaware Shows the Way
description: A precedent has been set in the State of Delaware that measures the distance Americans have come in reexamining their values. It is almost inconceivable that ten, even five, years ago the legislature and Gover nor of any state would have barred heavy induttry from its coastal lands on the ground that while jobs are very important to our people . . . so is the overall quality of our environment.

title: Jazz: Wide Range of Styles Is Shown
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 4 Yesterday afternoon's pro gram at the Newport Jazz Festival cut through a wide range of styles from the early ragtime piano of Eubie Blake, still lively, ebullient and nimblefingered at 88, and the stride piano of Wil lie (The Lion) Smith, a mere septuagenarian, through the hardcharging, straightahead attack of the Freddie Hub bard Quintet to the saxo phone and fiddle playing of one of the founders of the current jazz avantgarde, Ornette Coleman.

title: Vietnam Papers: Doubt Cast on View That the North Imposed War on the South
description: Under the heading Origins of the Insurgency in South Vietnam, the Pentagon's study analyzes the Viet cong movement and its role in the development of the war. The follow ing article, by Fox Butterfield, de scribes the analysts' findings.

title: SECRETARY LAIRD ARRIVES IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, July 4Defense Sec retary Melvin R. Laird arrived here today on what was de scribed as a visit combining business and sightseeing.

title: Dam Stirs Turkey's ElectricPower Hopes
description: KEBAN, Turkey  Two years behind schedule and twice as costly as initially projected, a mammoth dam is rising on the Euphrates River here in an effort to convert this bleak and back ward area of Eastern Ana tolia from a drain on Tur key's economy to a major as set.

title: Cable by Dulles on Negotiations At Geneva on Vietnam Elections
description: Cablegram by Secretary Dulles to United States Embassy in Paris with copies to the United States Embassies in London and Saigon and to United States Consul General in Geneva for Under Secretary Bedell Smith, July 7, 1954.

title: The American Flag A Center of Dispute On Birthday of U.S.
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 4 Today, 195 years after the founding of the republic, the American flag has become a center of controversy in most of the 50 states.

title: U.S. Future in Track Good as Gold?
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 4 The world keeps waiting for the sunset in United States track and field, but American athletes continue to produce new rays of hope for the 1972 Olympics.

title: Edmund P. Cullinan, Clerk With U.S. Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, July 4Ed mund P. Cullinan, longterm clerk of the United States Su preme Court, who retired June 14 after 41 years' service, died yesterday at Georgetown Uni versity Hospital.

title: A LANDLORD CURB SUGGESTED BY CITY
description: The city's Rent Administra tor proposed a shortcut tactic yesteray to combat harassment of tenants by landlords, which city officials fear will increase under the new state law re moving apartments from rent control when they become vacant.

title: Ailing Stewart Takes French Grand Prix
description: LE CAMP DU CASTELLET, France, July 4Jackie Stewart won the French Grand Prix as he pleased today, but it wasn't as easy as it looked. The former world champion from Scotland is a sick man.

title: Bell Wins in Germany
description: HOCKENHEIM, Germany, July 4 (AP)  Derek Bell of Britain drove his 8.1liter Mc Laren M80 to victory today in the third run of the interseries race championship for unlimited sports cars and prototypes.

title: Chutist Lands in Central Park and Gets a Summons
