description: A 23yearold man para chuted yesterday into Central Park, where he landed in a tree, scraped his arm and was given a summons for parachuting within the city limits.

title: Ann Wolff Wed to M. L. Osborn
description: WESTON, Mass., July 4  In St. Julia's Roman Catholic Church here today Miss Ann Wolff was married to Michael Lorington Osborn of Caracas, Venezuela, by the Rev. Sid ney J. Smith.

title: Intuition? It's Not a Woman's Monopoly
description: It may come as no sur prise to women to learn that they are inherently better negotiators than men, not only at home but in the busi ness world.

title: COMPROMISE PLAN TO BUILD BOMBER HINTED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 4  A compromise proposal that would add millions to the new defense budget might well placate a number of Senators who insist that a program for a new stra tegic bomber would be a waste of money, Congressional sources say.

title: RAY DUMONT, 66, BASEBALL FIGURE
description: WICHITA, Kan., July 4 (AP) Ray Dumont, Who organized the semipro National Baseball Congress 40 years ago, was found dead in the organiza tion's headquarters yesterday. Death was believed to have been from natural causes. As sociates said Mr. Dumont had been in failing health for some time. His age was 66.

title: Chinese Communists' Position On a Neutralized Indochina
description: Cablegram from Under Secretary of State Bedell Smith at Geneva to Secre tary Dulles, July 18, 1954.

title: 1954 Study by the Joint Chiefs On Possible U.S. Intervention
description: Excerpts from memorandum from Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson, May 26 1954, on Studies With Respect to Possible U.S. Action Regarding Indochina. The italicized emphasis appears in the original document.

title: Rep. Broyhill Scores Panel On Censure of C.B.S. Head
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)  Representative James T. Broyhill, Republican of North Carolina, said today that the pending House action against the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem sets a dangerous precedent by seeking to establish Con gress as the final judge of edi torial content.

title: 5,000 A.B.A. Lawyers Arrive Here
description: Nearly 5,000 lawyers, many accompanied by their families, registered yesterday at the con vention headquarters in the New York Hilton Hotel for the American Bar Association's 94th annual meeting.

title: GIVEN ROAD TAKES HORSE SHOW TITLE
description: DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 4 After winning the title three years in a row, AllAround Farms' Jay Rene finally was dethroned as regular working hunter champion of the Gaude amus Farms horse show today.

title: Chemical Workers' Dispute Settled ire West Germany
description: BONN, July 4After nearly a month of scattered strikes in West Germany's chemical in dustry, the national executive of the chemical workers union reached a settlement with the employers and ordered its mem bers to return to work to morrow.

title: Imports and Labor Upset Steel Industry's Planning
description: PITTSBURGH, July 4There was unsettling news for steel producers and steel users last week.

title: Shop Talk
description: Apartment dwellers and trailer owners are now being wooed by an everincreasing number of American produc ers of minisized home laun dry equipment. Scaleddown washers and dryers that were almost impossible to find here a decade ago (and, more often than not until five years ago, were imports from Europe) are now being made by Frigidaire, General Electric, Hoover and Maytag, General Electric, the newest entrant, introduced its portable clothes dryer at Macy's last month. As with the Hoover and the Maytag, General Electric's dryer, measuring 28 inches high, 21 inches wide and 18 inches deep, is small enough to be stored in and even op erated in a closet (none re quire venting). Since all three dryers operate on 115 volts A.C., or house current, no extra wiring is necessary.

title: Stars Down Darts, 21
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)  The St. Louis Stars beat the Washington Darts, 21, today in a North American Soccer League game. Casey Frankie wicz, playercoach, scored twice in the second half to give the Stars their first triumph over Washington in two years.

title: In the Mekong Delta, the New Politicking
description: PHUVINH, South Vietnam, July 2The combination of showmanship, curiosity and controversy that Americans have long accepted as part of political campaigns rippled through this little Mekong Delta town today as Ngo Cong Duc, the local Congressman, came home to register for his reelec tion campaign.

title: Shapiro and French Rider Tie for First at Aachen
description: AACHEN, Germany, July 4 (UPI)Marcel Rozier of France on Sans Souci and Neal Shapiro of the United States on Sloopy tied for first place today in the Grand Prix of Aachen jumping on the final day of the Aachen international horse show.

title: Bridge: Ineptness May Show Way To a Successful Defense
description: Inexperienced players some times suffer from the delu sion that their own incom petence would be sufficient to confuse an expert oppo nent. On the contrary, a novice is easy to play against because he gives his oppo nents information that a bet ter player would have kept concealed.

title: Chase, Despite Critical Memo, Finds Gains at City's Hospitals
description: Despite his memorandum of last month calling for better management, control and bud geting in the city's public hospitals, Health Service Ad ministrator Gordon Chase said yesterday that the system had made real and very important accomplishments during its first year.

title: Ina Balansky Is Bride Of Paul David Samuel
description: Miss Ina Balansky, and Paul David Samuel were married here at noon yester day. Rabbi Edward E. Klein performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Wallach.

title: Roundup: Blue Gains 17th Triumph
description: Vida Blue took another giant step toward the 30vic tory plateau last night as the Oakland Athletics halted the Angels at Anaheim, 21, for the pitcher's 17th victory.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Federal Coal Mine Health and Safety Act of 1969 is adding about $1 billion annually to the cost of pro ducing coal. Workers' productivity has been adversely affected. In 1970 the daily output per worker in under ground mines, which have borne the major brunt of the new law, declined by 9 per cent and by another 6.7 per cent in the first quarter of 1971.

title: Eisenhower's Instructions To U.S. Envoy at Geneva Talks
description: Cablegram from Secretary of State Dulles to Under Secretary Walter Bedell Smith, May 12, 1954.

title: Soviet Buildup in the Middle East Puts New Pressure on NATO
description: LISBONThe military situa tion in the Middle East, which since 1967 has centered on the ArabIsraeli confrontation, has been expanded by events to include the whole eastern basin of the Mediterranean.

title: Colombo's Refusal To Buy Off Gallo For $100,000 Cited
description: Joseph Gallo, who was ques tioned by the police in the shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., reportedly demanded, un successfully, $100,000 to keep him from renewing a feud within the Mafia family Co lombo allegedly heads.

title: Cooking's Fun But Politics Is Way of Life
description: WASHINGTONAlthough the Hale Boggs's annual garden party was an extravaganza with a cast of a thou sand, the hostess did her own cooking. A lot of Louisiana specialties, she said.

title: Pakistan, in a Protest to India, Charges Air Attack on Village
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 4 Pakistan protested to India last night that the Indian Air Force attacked a village in East Paki stan earlier in the day. India's acting High Comthissioner in Islamabad was called to the Foreign Office to receive a stern note, a Pakistani Govern ment spokesman said.

title: Pentagon Papers: Eisenhower Decisions Undercut the Geneva Accords, Study Says
description: The secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war discloses that a few days after the Geneva accords of 1954, the Eisenhower Administration's National Security Council decided that the ac cords were a disaster and the Presi dent approved actions to prevent further Communist expansion in Vietnam.

title: ARABS ATTRACTED BY NORTH SEA OIL
description: LONDON, July 4Saudi Ara bia, guardian of the world's largest oil reserves, is joining the crowd of companies and countries maneuvering to win additional concessions for oil exploration in the British North Sea.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, July 4Richard Nixon is approaching a decisive moment in his Presidency. Developments abroad and at home press for a fundamental reap praisal of his policy on Vietnam. His response on that issue in the coming weeks' could affect the character that history will give himas a divisive President or one who, as he wished, helped to bring a shattered country together.

title: Giles Wins Virginia Golf, Beating Wadkins, 3 and 2
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., July 4 (AP)Vinny Giles of Richmond won the Virginia amateur golf championship today with a 3 and 2 victory over Lanny Wad kins, the National Amateur champion, in the 36hole final.

title: DR.E.W.ANDREWS, ARCHEOLOGIST, 54
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 4 (AP) Dr. E. Wyllys Andrews 4th, the archeologist identified since 1941 with Dzibilchaltun, a major center of the. Mayan civ ilization of Yucatan, Mexico, died here yesterday following a lengthy illness. He was 54 years old.

title: Ali's Unanimous Decision
description: Muhammad Ali scored his most impressive victory out of the ring when the Supreme Court last week handed down its 80 decision overturning the, pugilist's 1967 conviction for draft evasion.

title: Dillon Reply on French Reaction
description: Cablegram from Ambassador Dillon to Secretary Dulles, April 5, 1954.

title: Brooklyn Nlan's Body Found in Car Trunk
description: The body of John A. Lom bardo, a former city employe, who has been missing for two weeks, was found stuffed in the trunk of his car yesterday in front of a Bath Beach apart ment building in Brooklyn.

title: Postal Talks Called Tough
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP)  Postmaster General Winton M. Blount said today that postal unions were negotiating in a very tough way in contract talks with the new United States Postal Service, but he added that, he did not think there would be a strike. There is no need for a strike, no ra tionale, and I don't think it will occur, Mr. Blount said in an in terview on the National Broad Casting Company's television program Meet the Press.

title: Farrar Straus Gets Solzhenitsyn Book
description: In the fiercest interna tional contest for a work of fiction in years, Farrar, Straus & Giroux, a small but prestigious New York pub lisher, has obtained the American rights to Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn's latest novel, August 1914.

title: 2 U.S. Aides Arrive in Cairo in Continuing Efforts to Reopen Canal
description: CAIRO, July 5  Two United States diplomats, Donald C. Bergus and Michael Sterner, ar rived in Cairo today on a some what mysterious mission rela ted to continuing efforts by Washington to achieve an agree ment for a reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: OUTLOOK CLOUDY ON AID FOR ROLLS
description: LONDON, July 5 (Reuters) British Areospace Minister Frederick Corfield declined to promise today that Government aid for RollsRoyce's RB211 aircraft engine program would be continued beyond the tar get date of Aug. 8.

title: Brooklyn Boy Drowned
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., July 5 (AP)  A 5yearold Brooklyn boy was drowned to day when he fell out of a row boat into Hessian Lake. The boy, Sheldon Parker, was with his stepfather, Marcel Orret Walcott, when the accident oc curred.

title: U.S. Indians Tour Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, July 5 (AP) Mayor Teddy Kollek took five Southwest American Indians in tribal dress on a tour of Jerusalem today. The group is here in program sponsored by the Ford Foundation.

title: Business and Labor Practice TV RolePlaying
description: The television camera pointed straight at the busi ness executive while the in terviewer threw one tough question after another at him.

title: NAACP. SOFTENS ANTINIXON STAND
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 5The National Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People tonight shifted away from its position of a year ago when it idenounced the Nixon Adminis tration as antiNegro.

title: Burger Tells Nation's Bar To Tighten SelfDiscipline
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger warned the American Bar Association yesterday that the legal profession must im pose more stringent disci pline on unruly or dishonest lawyers or outside forces will take over the job of policing lawyers' ethics.

title: DR. WALTER BILOTTA, AN OBSTETRICIAN, 58
description: Dr. Walter As A. Bilotta, a Brooklyn obstetrician and gyne cologist, died Saturday in Brook lyn Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 91 Rugby Road, Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The New York City Health and Hos pitals Corporation has now been in existence for one year, a period char acterized by cutbacks in Federal, state and local funding and by recession and inflation in the economy.

title: City Air Sets Record: It's Good a 3d Day
description: New York City enjoyed its third consecutive day of air rated as good yesterday the first time three such days have occurred in a row since network measurements be gan, according to Jerome Kretchmer, the Environmental Protection Administrator.

title: Advertising:
description: Two executives of Parents' Magazine Enterprises have written a book on the sell ing of magazine advertising, which they, and others in the field believe is a first.

title: New PATH Station Is Opening Today At Trade Center
description: New Jersey commuters who arrive in the city's financial dis trict on PATH trains today will start the day about 25 feet low er than usual, but in aircondi tioned comfort in a spacious, new terminal.

title: EDWARD T. TIGHE, 69, LED LEGAL AID UNIT
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 5 Edward T. Tighe, head of the Legal Aid Society bureau here, for the last three years and before World War II head of the criminal division of the New York Legal Aid Society, died today in Suffolk General Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 79 Evergreen Road.

title: SOME CONSUMERS WARNED ON SUING
description: An official of the Federal Trade Commission said here yesterday that many or most of the private classaction law suits recently brought against corporations under the Federal Government's new Truthin Lending law appeared to be, in effect, abuses of this law.

title: Irving Pergam, 61, Executive Of Supermarket Publishing
description: Irving Pergam, an executive of trade publications in the supermarket and distribution field, died yesterday in Parsons Hospital, Flushing, Queens. He was 61 years old and lived at 4819 192d Street, Flushing.

title: Heflin Still Unconscious
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) Van Heflin remained uncon scious and in critical condition today at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. The 60yearold actor's condition has not changed since he was hospitalized June 6 after suffering a heart attack in a swimming pool in West Holly wood.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: Business Administrator for Jersey City since 1969 . . . had been Director of Public Works . . . 48 years old . . . was accused by Government of using his position to ex tend the conspiracy through out the city and county to the Port Authority and the Turnpike Authority.

title: TREVINO IS EAGER FOR BRITISH TITLE
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 5 (AP)Lee Trevino, the United States Open Golf champion, pale, tired but resolute, flew in today from Montreal and found himself a cofavorite with Jack Nicklaus in the British Open.

title: DYNAMITE VICTOR IN OVERNIGHT SAIL
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 5Jack Hirsch's Dynamite, a Whitby45 sloop out of She drake. Yacht Club, Mamaro neckk, N. Y., won the Riverside Yacht Club's 40th annual Stratford Shoal overnight race today on corrected time for the 45mile passage on Long Island Sound.

title: Roundup: Senators Wallop Indians, 156, for 6th Victory in Row
description: Last Wednesday, the 12 owners of the American League teams met in Detroit to discuss the financial plight of the Washington Senators. Bob Short, the owner of the Senators, characterized his team as an artistic and finan cial failure. Rumors filtered out of the meeting that the Senators might be moved to Texas.

title: Dominican Arrives in Spain
description: MADRID, July 5 (Reuters) Elias Wessin y Wessin, the retired general accused of masterminding an attempt to overthrow the Dominican Re public government last week, arrived here today after de portation from Santo Domingo.

title: 6 Found in Plane Wreckage
description: OLD FORT, N. C., July 5 (UPI)The bodies of a Florida concrete concern owner, his wife and four children were found by a 150member search party today in the scattered wreckage of a singleengine plane. The victims were identi fied as Harmon B. Jones, 41 years old, his wife, and their four children, Cathy, Randy Ronnie and Karen, who ranged in age from 8 to 18.

title: Lawyers Divided Over Proposal For Uniform State Divorce Laws
description: Lawyers were talking about a longproposed nationwide Uniform Marriage and Divorce Act during a seminar at the American Bar Association con vention here yesterday and before long they were squabbling like  well, like squabbling married couple. Still they were hopeful of reaching an agreement.

title: YOUTH IS SLAIN HERE; 3 HELD AS SUSPECTS
description: A 22yearold Brooklyn man was shot to death last night on the Lower East Side after he was accosted by three men, ap parently in a dispute over money, the police reported.

title: Burger Calls Court In Fact Unanimous In The Times Case
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger says that the. Supreme Court was actually unani mous in principle in its 6to 3 decision last Wednesday against the Justice Depart ment's effort to bar publication of material from the topsecret Pentagon papers in The New York Times and The Washing ton. Post.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:It was recently reported that the United States will increase its aid to the police forces of many foreign coun tries to help, them deal with guerrillas and subversion. If one substitutes Communism for the last word in the preceding sentence, the purpose will be clear.

title: They Still Fly Off Carriers in Tonkin
description: ABOARD U.S.S. ORISK ANY, in the Tonkin Gulf, July 4I was here in the beginning, here again at the worst part when we were bombing North Vietnam, and now I'm here again at the endat least I hope it's the end, a Navy pilot on this aircraft carrier said as he prepared for a bombing mis sion over Laos.

title: Train With Bombs Righted
description: MEADVILLE, Pa., July 5 (UPI) Salvage crews completed to day the touchy job of righting 15 derailed cars of a train car rying high explosive, but de fused, bombs for the Navy. The derailment occurred yesterday in an isolated area near Cam bridge Springs.

title: 3,000 Hasidic Jews Here Mark Rabbi's Release in Soviet in '27
description: More than 3,000 Hasidic Jews filled the synagogue and headquarters of the Lubavitch er Movement in Brooklyn yes terday to observe the 44th an niversary of the release of a famed Lubavitch rabbi from a prison in the Soviet Union.

title: Patient Killed, Wife Hurt When Ambulance Explodes
description: PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) A man was killed today when the ambulance in which he was being taken to a hospital ex ploded and burned, the police said. His wife and four other occupants of the ambulance were injured, one critically.

title: Tenants in Luxury Apartments Pay $40,000 and End Strike
description: Tenants in the luxury apart ment building at 239 Central Park West, who had withheld about $40,000 in rent in a battle with the management over maintenance, turned the money over to the manage ment last week.

title: Merger News
description: The General Capital Corpo ration has agreed to sell its T. I. Swartz men's wear manu facturing and retailing division to LTM, Inc., a privately held Bostonbased softgoods con cern, in a cash transaction, it was announced over the week end. General Capital, formerly the General Corporation of Ohio, has expand ed its operations in the last eight months from a re tailing concern to an industrialcon struction and real estatedevel opment organization.

title: Lear Siegler in Financing
description: Lear Siegler, Inc., announced over the weekend that it had negotiated a $60million loan from the Prudential Insurance Company of America. Proceeds will be used to reduce short term borrowings and to refund existing longterm debt.

title: Japanese Recover Bodies Of 68 Killed in Plane Crash
description: HAKODATE, Japan, July 5 (AP)Troops and policemen re covered all 68 bodies today from a mountainside near here where a Japanese airliner crashed in drizzling rain Satur day.

title: Madeline Horn Dies at 61; SpeedSkating Medalist
description: BEAVER DAM, Wis., July 5 (AP)Madeline Horn, who won more than 300 medals and scores of trophies in speed skat ing competition in the United States, Canada and Europe, died Friday. Miss Horn, who was 61 years old, won the North American championship in 1933.

title: LONDON EXCHANGE BARS I.O.S. TRADING
description: LONDON, July 5 (Reuters) The London Stock Exchange today banned trading in the shares of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., one of the key companies in the I.O.S. mutual funds complex started by Bernard Cornfeld, the financier.

title: Son Ange Placed First in Liberty Bill Dash on foul Claim
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5  Calumet Farm's Son, Ange took home the lion's share of the $58,850 purse for the Fire cracker Handicap, the richest sprint in the country for older horses, after finishing second today at Liberty Bell race track.

title: First Tropical Storm Begins
description: MIAMI, July 5 (UPI)Tropi cal storm Arlene, the first of the season, produced 50mile anhour winds off the North Carolina coast today and be gan moving to the north. It will probably pass near or just east of Nantucket Island before noon tomorrow, the National Hurricane Center said.

title: Crew Says Sailor Left Ship for Raft 200 Miles at Sea
description: SAN DIEGO, July 5 (AP) Reports that a young sailor cut loose a life raft and jumped from an Australian warship about 200 miles from land have prompted an official, inquiry, the authorities said today.

title: Reston Hopes to Visit Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, July 5 (UPI) James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times, said today that he would leave for China Thursday for a threeweek visit. Mr. Reston, who arrived here yesterday with his wife, said he hoped to go to Hanoi from China to find out if the war is going to end. He said he had applied for visas for North Vietnam but has received no reply.

title: 2 Turkish Newsmen Jailed For Insulting Armed Forces
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 5 (Reuters)  A military court sentenced two Turkish journal ists today to a year's imprison ment for having insulted the armed forces and the security authorities.

title: Sisco May Visit Israel
description: WASHINGTON, July 5As sistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco may visit Israel later this month in an effort to narrow the gap between Israeli and Egyptian positions on the terms of an agreement to re open the Suez Canal.

title: Supplying Major Fuels Poses Increasing Problems
description: Although the fuels that run the American economy are in no imminent danger of depletion, the nation's energy managers foresee an increasing number of problems supplying society's prodigious demands.

title: French Offer Reward In $2Million Robbery
description: PARIS, July 5The police offered an $18,000 reward to day in the search for bandits who five days ago robbed the central post office in Stras bourg of $2,120,000 in French banknotes.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: President of Jersey City Council ... 42 years old ... a Florida bank official testi fied that Flaherty and Mayor Whelan deposited in his bank $1.25million in cash and municipal bearer bonds in nameless numbered ac counts between 1968 and 1970.

title: New Brooklyn Bridge Car Routes
description: The map shows changes in the pattern of westbound Brooklyn Bridge traffic that are scheduled to go into effect about 10 A.M. today. Traffic is being rerouted to facilitate the construction of a pedestrian plaza, expected to be complete in the sum mer of 1972, linking the Municipal Building with the new police headquarters building now under construc tion.

title: Books of The Times
description: CASANOVA IN LONDON. By Peter Quennell. 198 98 pages. Stein Day. $6.95.

title: Agnew, in Singapore, Says U.S. Media Unintentionally Aid North Vietnamese
description: SINGAPORE, July 5Vice President Agnew renewed his criticism of the United States news media today, charging them with unintentionally as sisting the North Vietnamese by some aspects of their cov erage of the war in Indochina.

title: Dance: American Ballet Theater's Swan Lake
description: Anyone for Swan Lake? When the American Ballet Theater first mounted the David Blair productions of Swan Lake and, later, Giselle, they both were brilliant in concept but there were moments of awkward ness about the way the com pany had taken to them. The company inhabited these productions without really, possessing them.

title: SATO REORGANIZES CABINET AND ASKS BETTER U.S. TIES
description: TOKYO, July 5  Premier Eisaku Sato today appointed a new Cabinet that is ex pected to give major attention to Japan's fraying economic re lations with the United States.

title: Siegal Loses at Baastad
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 5 (AP)Bob Carmichael of Aus tralia defeated Steve Siegel of Teaneck, N. J., 63, 63, 6.3, in the opening round of the men's singles at the Baastad tennis tournament today.

title: Holiday Ends With Long Traffic Jams
description: Cool mountain glades, quiet country lanes and shimmering beaches melted into memory for hundreds of thousands of homebound New Yorkers yesterday as the threeday In dependence Day weekend drew to a close with a massive Gordian knot of traffic on major arteries into the city.

title: Little Progress in Talks
description: BONN, July 5 (Reuters) German Government sources said today Economics Minister Karl Schiller has made little or no progress in persuading French. Finance Minister Val ery Giscard d'Estaing to accept wider parity bands between Common Market and third country currencies.

title: $57,700 OAKS WON BY FOR WARD GAL; ALMA NORTH IS 2D
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 Forward Gal displayed the strength and speed that made her last year's champion 2 yearold filly as she easily won the 48th running of the Mon mouth Oaks today against a strong field at Monmouth Park.

title: Scot Takes Ring Title
description: LONDON, July 5 (AP)Evan Armstrong of Scotland knocked out Jimmy Revie of Britain in the 12th round tonight and won the British featherweight boxing title. Revie had been champion since March, 1969.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Tackle Talk (A. S. Barnes and Co., Inc., 275 pages, il lustrated, $8.95), by Hal Ly man and Frank Woolner, is a worthwhile and authoritative manual of saltwater fishing, suitable for both expert and beginner.

title: U.S. Trade Tactics Vexing Europeans
description: PARIS, July 5  American pressure on Europe and Japan to accept voluntary restraints on exports to the United States or face stiff restrictive meas ures is being viewed in Europe with mounting alarm.

title: From the Russian Underground
description: S. P. Pisarev, 69, member of the Soviet Communist party since 1918 and minor party official, last year di rected a letter to the Soviet Academy of Medical Sciences protesting the So viet police practice of sending political prisoners to psychiatric institutions such as the Serbsky Institute of Psy chiatric Diagnosis. Pisarev's letter reached the West through the Russian underground.

title: Woman Found Strangled In Her Bronx Apartment
description: The nude body of a 27year old woman, her hands and feet tied to her bed, was found by the police yesterday morning in her apartment at 1160 Crom well Avenue, the Bronx. She had apparently been strangled.

title: Utes Pin Business Hopes to a Resort
description: BOTTLE HOLLOW, Utah, July 5Ute Indians are hunt ing dollars and letting white men hunt their deerat a price.

title: New President of the A.B.A.
description: Man in the News

title: Fatal Shooting of a Driver Stirs Up Flatbush District
description: At 4:35 P.M. on Monday, June 7, a car driven by Leslie Kempler, a 21yearold white man, struck the rear of a bus at a busy intersection in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and then careened into another automobile.

title: Children Have an Organized Romp in Park
description: A carefully structured day of unstructured free play drew hundreds of children and their parents yesterday to Central Park's Sheep Meadow to toss Frisbees, swirl Hula Hoops, watch a puppet show and generally celebrate their own independence.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have just invented a way to save money for the city. For every four buses the city buys, only one will have an engineat great saving of initial cost. Then we could hook the other three to it and the first one could pull them all.

title: Championship Frisbee: America's Antisport
description: COPPER HARBOR, Mich., July 5There's a parade and a queen, and the crowds cheer on their heroes, but the international Frisbee cham pionship, held here on the shores of Lake Superior over the Independence Day week end, is not any Tournament of Roses or World Series. It may be more fun, half seri ous sport and half spoof on the overorganized, commer cialized world of sports  an antisport.

title: Bridge:
description: For more than 20 years imaginative bridge organizers have attempted to apply the lightning thought processes of the computer to the prob lems of scoring bridge tour naments. Nearly all the at tempts have been unsuccess ful, or excessively expensive, or both.

title: Article 1  No Title
States Righter in Race
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., July 5 (UPI)J. B. Stoner, twotime States' Rights party candidate for President, announced today that he would seek the United States Senate seat in Georgia formerly held by the late Rich hard B. Russell and now held on an interim basis by David H. Cambrell.

title: Low Mortgage Rates Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, chair man of the Senate Housing Subcommittee, urged Treasury Secretary John B. Connally Jr. today to hold down interest rates on mortgages.

title: The Way of Mao
description: The Chinese, in the days of empire, used to say: Heaven is high and the emperor is far away. It was an aphorism that sustained a rationale for local initiative and regional autocracy. The recent opening of Commu nist China to American observers has produced a series of reports which reveal that maxims and proverbs are still a part of the rationale of Chinese society; but the source of guidance has very much come down to earth.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 5 John Mangan of Rye won the Paul Martin Memorial tennis tournament for the eighth time in 11 years today by beating Bailey Brown of Bronxville, 6.3, 06, 62, at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club.

title: Nation's Energy Crisis: It Won't Go Away Soon
description: This is the first of three articles on the national energy crisis and the conflict between the need for more power and the desire to preserve the environment.

title: Market Place:
description: You won't see Francis Wil liams of Eberstadt & Co.'s Chemical Fund Shedding any tears over the fact that there were more redemptions than sales of mutual fund shares on an industrywide basis in May.

title: Myopia Wins in Polo, 103, As Pete Bostwick Excels
description: BETHPAGE, L.I., July 5 Pete Bostwick scored six goals to lead the Myopia polo team to a 103 rout of Connecticut Pitchfork today in a North eastern 12goal tournament semifinal match at Bethpage State Park.

title: Dr. Virginius Mattia, 48, Dies; HoffmannLa Roche President
description: NUTLEY, N.J., July 5Dr. Virginius D. Mattis, president and chief executive officer of HoffmannLa Roche, Inc., here, the pharmaceuticals company, died yesterday of a heart ail ment at his summer home in Long Beach Township. He was 48 years old and lived at 28 Greenview Way, Upper Mont clair.

title: Ruth Berghaus Will Direct East Berlin Brecht Troupe
description: BERLIN, July 5Ruth Berg haus has been appointed direc tor of the Berliner Ensemble, the East Berlin Brecht troupe, to succeed the late Helene Weigel, it was announced in East Berlin today.

title: Cory Captures Both Heats In Goshen Cup for Pacers
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 5 (UPI)Cory won the $11,922 Goshen Cup for 2yearold pac ers today as the 61st year of Grand Circuit harness racing began at the historic track here.

title: Garrison Asks Curb On Papers Printing Affidavit on Bribes
description: NEW ORLEANS. July 5 District, Afthrrtey Jim Garri son will go into Federal Court tomorrow to try to stop two New. Orleans newspapers from publishing contents of an affi davit in whuch Mr. Garrison and nine other persons are charged with taking bribes, to protect pinball machine operators.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam Is Lowest Since 1966
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 (UPI)Some 2,200 more G.I.'s went home last week to cut the United States military force in Vietnam to 239,500 men, the lowest since March 31, 1966, the military command reported today.

title: Now the Girls Are on the Fire Line
description: MISSOULA, Mont. (AP) Women have invaded another traditionally allmale strong holdthe domain of the pro fessional forestfire fighter.

title: Wind of Reform in Ulster?
description: Prime Minister Brian Faulkner has made the most imaginative proposal yet advanced for giving the Catholic minority a creative role in the Government of Northern Ireland. He would revamp the function of the Stormont Parliament by establishing four powerful committees with paid chairmen, of whom two would come from the Catholic opposition, to help shape Government policy rather than merely debate and vote on programs issued by the Cabinet.

title: Sect Protests in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM, July 5 (AP) Stonethrowing members of an ultraorthodox Jewish sect snarled traffic through the re ligious quarter of Jerusalem today for the third successive day, the state radio reported. There were no reports of in juries because of the sect's pro tests over public buses operat ing on the sabbath.

title: 20 in Motorcycle Gang Held In a Disturbance in Margate
description: MARGATE, N.J., July 5 Twenty members of the War locks, a Philadelphia motor cycle gang, were arrested in this South Jersey seashore resort early today following a throttleroaring disturbance in which two policemen and a gang member were hurt.

title: VICTORY GAINED BY DOUBLEDARE
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 5Joseph F. O'Hora and Dr. George K. Brazill Jr. won with their Shields Class sloop, Dou bleDare, for the second day in a row and Robert F. Shat tuck's Serafina took her first Etchells22 race in the season's 16th Yacht Racing Association championship regatta today.

title: Markets Were Closed
description: All securities and commodi ties markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of the Independ ence Day holiday. Canadian, European and other foreign markets were open for trading.

title: Guinean Military Reshuffled
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, July 5 (Reuters)  President Skou Tour of Guinea today reshuf fled his military high command and then summoned it and political leaders to study a plan to invade Guinea that he said had been drawn up Friday, the Conakry radio reported.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times
description: For their annual dinner in Chicago recently, the pro football players had Bill Cosby, who used to run track, as their speaker. Cosby told them: My best time for the 440 was 63 seconds. You see, I went to an allwhite high school. Everybody broke up. Cosby set the tone for a warm, friendly evening.

title: FIRE DRILLS DUE IN SKYSCRAPERS
description: The city announced new fire safety regulations for highrise office buildings yesterdayin cluding a requirement that the owners or managers hold periodic fire drills.

title: Screen Actors Approve Strike July 14 if Contract Talks Fail
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 Members of the Screen Actors Guild, whose unemployment rate has been more than 90 per cent in recent months, have voted overwhelmingly to strike motion picture and tele vision productions on July 14 if a new contract cannot be negotiated before then.

title: Auditing the City's Books
description: New York City taxpayers, hit by a variety of new and additional levies, should receive both protection and as surance from the work of state auditors who will be beginning today to sift the books of the city as an entity.

title: Store Buyers Point to a Surge
description: If many of the nation's store buyers have guessed right, the American public wants for this fall somewhat lower prices for apparel, knits, knits, knits, more dresses and fewer pantsuits and the fourinch tie for men.

title: NAUMBURG CONCERT GIVEN ON THE MALL
description: Symphonic music rarely works well in an openair set ting, but the pitfalls can be minimized by careful program ing. The Naumburg concert in the Central Park Mall Sunday night scored well in this re spectthree of the four works made a creditable musical effect.

title: City Budget Cuts Kill Police Magazine
description: A magazine that may soon become a collectors' item has been circulated in recent days in the city's police stations and among friends of policemen.

title: SCHONMEN URGED TO FOSTER CHANGE
description: Fortyeight school superin tendents from large and small districts throughout the coun try were told yesterday that a phenomenon all of them must be prepared to acceptand must encouragewas change.

title: Shop Talk
description: What happens to collec tors' collections when they haven't an inch of space left tin their own apartments? You open a shop, said Or lando Rigono, whose Non Sequitur, Inc., at 353 Colum bus Avenue (77th Street), has become a favorite browsing spot for residents of the area. Mr. Rigono and his partner, Jim De Biasio, who are both high school teachers (Mr. Ri gono teaches Spanish and French; Mr. Di Biasio biology and the per forming arts), opened their original shop, several doors from the present location, two years ago. Since then, they've made an informal ar rangement with Joseph Spin elli, another collector, who spends most of his working hours managing a printing plant in the Village.

title: Kiesinger Quitting. As the Chairman Of German. Party
description: BONN, July 5Kurt Georg Kiesinger the former Chancel lor, declared today that he was stepping down, as chairman of the Christian Democratic Union, West Germany's princi pal Opposition party.

title: 2 Collect $31,313 Each In West Va. Big Exacta
description: CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., July 5 (AP)Two unidentified bettors collected $31,313.40 each today for $2 bets in a record twoway Shenadoah Downs Big Exacta payoff.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ADDS 4 REGIONAL POSTS
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day that the Westinghouse In ternational Company had been integrated into the corporate structure of Westinghouse and that four regional vice presi dents had been named to serve as corporate representatives in areas outside the United States.

title: Israeli Editors to Oppose Censorship by Government
description: TEL AVIV, July 5 (AP)  Is raeli newspaper editors resolved yesterday to fight Government censorship in order to insure the public's right to receive re liable information.

title: Lansky Sues Israeli Paper That Called Him a Gangster
description: TEL AVIV, July 5  Meyer Lansky today sued an Israeli newspaper that had called him a gangster.

title: Black Political Potential in South Shown
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The Bureau of the Census released today data that reaffirm the immense potential political power of Negroes in the South.

title: COLOMBO INQUIRY IS MOVING SLOWLY
description: Detectives investigating the shooting of Joseph A, Colombo Sr., the reputed Brooklyn Mafia leader, were described yester day as proceeding quietly and slowly, with no major devel opments to report.

title: Kicker Loses His Legs In a Fireworks Blast
description: CONCORD, Calif., July 5 (UPI)Dale Allen Eidson, re cently signed as a special kicker by the San Diego Chargers, lost both legs yes terday in a fireworks explo sion in which his 4yearold nephew was also injured.

title: Laird Holds Talks in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, July 5 (AP)Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird conferred for two hours today on United States and Japanese defense programs With Yasuhiro Nakasone, out going director general of Japan's Defense Agency. Mr. Nakasone resigned Friday along with all other members of Premier Eisaku Sato's cab inet. He was not named to the new Cabinet Mr. Sato an nounced today, but received a high post in the ruling Liberal Democratic party.

title: Leftist Parties Planning a Strong, Joint Presidential Ticket in '72
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 5A strong joint national ticket in 1972 and a powerful organization in all 50 states emerged as major objectives this weekend at a convention of leftist parties.

title: The HomeRule Enigma
description: News Analysis

title: CLEMENCY URGED FOR OBJECTORS
description: Conscientious objectors to the conflict in Indochina who have gone to jail or to other countries to escape military service in a war that violated their moral convictions deserve clemency at the war's end, ac cording to an eminent Orthodox Jewish scholar.

title: Canadian Bill Would Curb TakeOvers by Americans
description: TORONTO, July 5The Ca nadian Government has initiat ed its first broadgauge action to curb takeovers of Canadian businesses by Americans.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: Hudson County Treasurer since 1965... 75 years old.... the prosecution charged he kept track of the kickbacks received by officials and others in Jersey City and in the county ... also charged with receiving a fraudulent pension ... a veteran of more than 40 years in poli tics.

title: The Greybeard Holds Lead In TransPacific Yacht Race
description: SAN PEDRO, Calif., July 5 (UPI)  The Greybeard of the Royal Vancouver Yacht Club held the lead today on the sec ond day of the TransPacific Yacht Race, but favored Wind ward Passage was knifing rap idly through the pack toward the front.

title: Hijacking Case in Argentina Passed to Higher Tribunal
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 5 (AP) A police van delivered a United States Navy deserter and a Guatemalan woman to court today to face charges of kidnapping and theft of an air craft in the hijacking of a Braniff International jetliner. But the judge passed the case to a higher tribunal and they did not appear before the bench.

title: Kretchmer Says Most Industry Here Is Resisting Efforts to Curb Pollution
description: The city's Environmental Pro tection Administrator charged yesterday that industry, with a few honorable exceptions, was fighting tooth and nail every step of the way against municipal efforts to end health and environmental dangers.

title: Borowiak, Emerson and Cooper Gain at Gstaad
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 5 (AP)Jeff Borowiak of Ber keley, Calif., rallied to win his firstround match in the Swiss tennis tournament today. He defeated Armand Armrltray of India, 46, 97, 75.

title: More Federal Funds Urged for the Fight Against Lead Poisoning in Children
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 The Administrattion has asked for $2million to attack the pro blem of lead poisoning of chil dren, but critics contend that the sum is far too little to make an impact on a health hazard that may endanger as many as 400,000 children.

title: Curtis Person, Zimmerman Share Lead in Seniors Golf
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, July 5 (AP)Curtis Person of Mem phis and William H. Zimmer man of Columbus, Ga., shot 73's today to lead the first qualify ing round of the international seniors amateur golf champion ship.

title: MRS. EDNA JOHNSON
description: Mrs. Edna Leader Johnson, a popular singer around the turn of the century at such night spots as Reisenweber's, Shanley's and Rector's, died Sunday at the Woodhaven Home at Port Jefferson Station, L. I. Her age was 83. She was the widow of Howard E. John son, lyricist of When the Moon Comes Over the Mountain, Ireland Must Be Heaven and lather songs, who died in 1941.

title: Catfood and Cosmetics
description: The recent annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission in Washington was a dismal fiasco. At time when whales are being depleted at an alarming rate and some species are teetering on the edge of extinction, the commission calmly set quotas for 1972 for all but one of the world's oceans at the same high level as prevailed in 197071.

title: ACK ACK CAPTURES COAST HANDICAP
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 5 (UPI)Ack Ack won the $79, 850 American Handicap on the turf at Hollywood Park today. Leading from start to finish despite an impost of 130 pounds, Ack. Ack raced the 1 miles in 1:47 15 to set a track record. He clipped one fifth of a second off the pre vious mark set by Hill Clown in 1967.

title: Cigarette Smoking Rises
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) The Agriculture Department reported today that cigarette consumption was 5 per cent higher in April than in Janu ary. The department said the main reason was that as ciga rette commercials on radio and television stopped Jan. 2, anti cigarette announcements de creased considerably.

title: Tanner Gains at Clay Net
description: CHATTANOOGA, July 5 (AP) Roscoe Tanner of Chattanooga, the defending champion, led the seeded players who ad vanced into the second round today of the National Amateur claycourt tennis champion ships.

title: Car Kills 2 Queens Boys Removing Dog in Street
description: Two boys were killed last night in a street in the Long Island section of Queens by a driver who was arrested and charged with vehicular homi cide and drunken driving.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: New Jersey Commissioner of the Port of New York Au thority ... 70 years old ... former Hudson County au ditor ... appointed chief in vestigator of city records and accounts by Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City in 1949 ... former vice chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Ad thority.

title: HORSERACE LINK SOUGHT IN KILLING
description: Brooklyn detectives investi gating the, murder of a man whose body was Sunday in the trunk of his ar in the Bath Beach district were check ing yesterday on whether the slaying had any connection with a suspicious race that touched off a riot at, Yonkers Raceway on June 7.

title: MRS. HAROLD G. BROWN
description: STOCKTON, N.J., July 5 Mrs. Martha Frances Brown, wife of Harold Gilmore Brown, a New York stockbroker with Baker, Weeks & Co., died yes terday in a convalescent home in Doylestown, Pa. She was 72 years old.

title: OffDuty Policeman Shoots Assailant on East Side
description: An offduty policeman shot and seriously wounded a man who allegedly slashed him with a knife while attempting to rob him in the East Village last night.

title: Dr. Frederick Josephson, Queens Surgeon, 66, Dies
description: Dr. Frederick Josephson, chief surgeon and a general partner in Whitestone (Queens) General Hospital, died there on Sunday after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 5819 Main Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Nixon Hails Youth Vote as 26th Amendment Is Certified at the White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 The 26th Amendment to the Constitution, which lowers to 18 the minimum voting age in all elections, was officially cer tified today in a ceremony con ducted by. President Nixon.

title: Drought Forces Bats From Carlsbad Caves
description: CARLSBAD, N. M., July 5 (UPI)Most of the 200,000 bats in the Carlsbad Caverns have moved because of the drought, Hiram Tarent, a park guide, said today.

title: PRESSURE MOUNTS FOR RISING YIELDS
description: With the Federal Reserve con tinuing to tighten money mar ket conditions and with the prime rate expected to move up almost at any moment, pres sure throughout the credit mar kets this week will be toward higher yields.

title: I.S. Is Testing TV on Drones As Way to Patrol Suez Canal
description: Tests of live television as means of maintaining continu ous airborne surveillance of the Suez Canal are being conduct ed by the United States Air Force along a strip of the Cali fornia coast.

title: POWER IN DACCA REPORTED CUT OFF
description: NEW DELHI, July 5Bengali insurgents have knocked out the electrical power station in Dacca, the East Pakistani capital, authoritative foreign sources reported here today. These sources, who received the information from contacts in Dacca, said the city had been blacked out since Saturday night.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, Scien tific and Technical Subcom mittee10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ONE INMATE SLAIN; 2D KNIFED IN FLORIDA
description: RAIFORD, Fla., July 5 (AP) An inmate at Raiford State Prison, angered over the theft of some of his personal belong ings, stabbed to death a second inmate and critically wounded a third today, the prison super intendent said.

title: 3Way Tie Marks Babylon Regatta; 9 Pilots Unbeaten
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 5 Nine skippers completed the threeday Babylon Yacht Club's invitation regatta with three straight triumphs as the series ended today in a light south easterly. The Lido 14 Class se ries finished in an unbreakable threeway tie among Bill Mc Grath, Bob Schwarzler and Ed Von Rhee, each of whom had a first, a second and a third.

title: French Reserves Up
description: PARIS, July 5 (Reuters)The Finance Ministry said today that France's gold and foreign currency reserves increased by 148 million francs in June  compared with a rise of 368 million francs in Mayto total 29.5billion francs.

title: U.S. BIGGEST USER OF PAPER GOLD
description: WASHINGTON, July 5By the end of May the United States had become the world's largest user of Special Drawing Rights, or paper gold, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: French Criticize U.S. Veto Of Atlantic Telephone Cable
description: PARIS, July 5  Communica tions Minister Robert Galley charged today that the United States had vetoed a new trans Atlantic telephone cable against the advice of its own experts in order to favor excessively, a system it dominates Intelsat.

title: $290,000 in Marijuana Found in Car on Turnpike
description: SALEM, N. J., July 5 (AP) A Californian was held without bail in Salem County Jail today after the New Jersey Turnpike police reported finding $290,000 worth of marijuana in the trunk of his car.

title: Twice Worthy $13.20 Victor
description: The 56,900 fans at Aqueduct yesterday had considerable trouble deciding on a favorite for the $115,400 Suburban Handicap, but they finally mans aged to come up with the cor rect one. A field of 13 including an entry participated in the 1mile fixture, and the win ner was Twice Worthy of the Saddle Rock Farm.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: Mayor of Jersey City . . . 48 years old . . . Elected in 1963 by 5to4 vote of City Council after Mayor Thomas Gangemi resigned because State Department questioned his citizenship status . . . Re elected in 1965 and 1969. . . elected to city council in 1961, he cast deciding vote in 1963 mayoral election by City Council. . . Former chief of security for New Jersey Bell Telephone Com pany Fighter pilot in South Pacific in World War II . . . Flew 63 missions and won Air Medal with five clusters. . . . . Civilian com munications adviser with Eighth Army in Korea, . . . Born in Jersey City Jan. 28, 1922 . . . one of 13 children . . . Married to former Eileen Gutwald . . . Has six children. . . . known as a man who speaks bluntly on public is sues and as a foe of liberal ity or permissiveness . . . once said that the guns that killed policemen were loaded over the last 10 years by society's spineless leaders whose pro gram has been one of pan dering and pimping for every base impulse of every base man.

title: Cuban Convict Executed
description: HAVANA, July 5 (Reuters) One of three prisoners who killed three prison guards in an escape Saturday was recap tured, sentenced to death and executed by a firing squad the same day, officials announced here today. The three prisoners in a Havana jail had been imprisoned for nonpolitical offenses.

title: New Turkish Regime Fin d s Reform Is Slow
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 28 Martial law has made the traffic run on time in Istanbul and Ankara, Turkey's two big gest and formerly most chaotic cities. The militarybacked Government, which invoked emergency powers in 11 of the 67 provinces two months ago, is finding, however, that it is easier to discipline drivers and vehicles than to institute the more basic reforms that are the Government's reason for being.

title: Early Results Show Regime Well Ahead In Indonesian Vote
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 5  Preliminary results from Indonesia's national election Saturday show a tally of more than 50 per cent for the Govern mentbacked party, more than enough to insure majority sup port in the House of Represent atives for President Suharto.

title: Legislator Calls on the City To Add Food Inspectors
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein urged the city yesterday to hire 220 additional food in spectors and samplers and to take other steps to halt what he termed a health crisis in food inspection practices in the city.

title: P.S.C. Official Asks Underground Lines At Housing Projects
description: New statewide rules to re quire the underground installa tion of all electric and tele phone wires and equipment for new housing developments for four or more families were recommended yesterday by a State Public Service Commis sion examiner.

title: Satan Cult Death, Drugs Jolt Peaceful Vineland, N. J.
description: VINELAND, N. J.  On a summer's evening, spacious welltended Landis Park is filled with the comforting traditional sounds of small town America. The crack of a bat sets oft a burst of cheers at one of three teen age baseball games, and there are excited cries from chil dren riding a neonlighted Ferris wheel at a carnival.

title: Julian Bond Aids Vote Drive in South
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 5 The other day a tiny old black lady at Hattiesburg heard State Representative Juhan Bond of Georgia tell a perspiring crowd of Negroes in Mount Zion Bap tist Church that voting con trols everything important in your lives.

title: WHELAN IS GUILTY WITH 7 OFFICIALS IN TRIAL IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, July 5All eight defendants in the Jersey City Hudson County extortion con spiracy trial were found guilty in Federal Court here late this afternoon.

title: Even Today, Some Nuns Choose the Cloistered Life of Prayer
description: Throughout the United States there are between 3,000 and 4,000 Roman Catholic women who have elected to give up the prospect of home, husband and family to lead the special life of the cloistered nun. To the outsider, the convent environment may seem an escape from the temporal problems of the world, but the sisters view it differently. For them it is a life of dedication, a triumph of love and by through prayer despite occasional moments of loneliness, depression and homesickness. Living in the shadow of the militant women religious, about whom so much is heard, the number of cloistered nuns is shrinking. Yet the pull of the different cloistered orders still attracts a trickle of new postulants eager to join the more secluded life and step to a slower pace.

title: Russian in Stockholm Asks Asylum in Kidnapping Case
description: STOCKHOLM, July 5 (Reu ters)A young Russian asked for political asylum here today after narrowly escaping an ap parent kidnapping attempt by Soviet Embassy officials, police sources said tonight.

title: German Reserves Fall
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, July 5 (Reuters)West Ge'many's reserves fell by 1.7 billion marks to 60.1 billion marks in the week ended June 30, the Bundesbank said today.

title: Canadian Reserves Off
description: OTTAWA, July 5 (Canadian Press)  Canada's foreign ex change reserves totaled $4.85 billion at the end of June, down $26.8million from the record $4.88billion at the beginning of the month, the Finance De partment reported today.

title: PLAYERS COMPLAIN ON HIDDEN TV PACT
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association has filed an unfair labor practice charge against the 24 major league clubs, citing their refusal to divulge terms of a new tele vision contract.

title: ARCHIE BAUCUM, 60, TEXACO EXECUTIVE
description: HOUSTON, July 5Archie W. Baucum, executive vice presi dent of Texaco, Inc., and chief executive officer of the com pany's Southern operations, died today of a heart attack at his home. His age was 60.

title: Irish Sweeper Takes Dash At Delaware, Pays $23.20
description: STANTON, Del., July 5 (AP) Harold A. Blanckes Irish Sweeper, purchased last Janu ary at a Hialeah sale of 2year olds for $4,500, scored a major upset today by defeating the 12 favorite, Cohasset Tribe, in the $28,350 Dover Stakes at Delaware Park.

title: CAPT. MEDINA SEEKS EVIDENCE IN VIETNAM
description: ATLANTA, July 5 (AP) Capt. Ernest L. Medina, facing trial on charges of murder and assault in the 1968 raid on My lai, has left for Vietnam with an Army prosecutor and his military defense attorney.

title: Nixon's Health Plan Falls Short
description: Now that President Nixon's health insurance bill has been released in full, it becomes evident that the program sets forth would fail to meet its an nounced goals.

title: Philip H. Power Marries Miss Sarah H. Goddard
description: BIG BAY, Mich, July 5  Miss Sarah Hutchins God dard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wendell C. Goddard of Grosse Pointe Farms, was married in the woods near the Goddard family cabin at the Huron Mountain Club here today to Philip Harwick Power, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Barnum Power of Ann Arbor. The lev. Frank Fitt, minister emeritus of the Grosse Pointe Memorial Pres byterian Church, performed the ceremony.

title: Paris: Monet's Gems Glow in Their New Setting
description: Arts Abroad

title: Popitorie Is Hospitalized
description: CHICAGO, July 5 (AP)Joe Pepitone of the Chicago Cubs was carried off the field on stretcher today after fouling pitch off his right ankle in the fifth inning of a game against Pittsburgh. First reports said he suffered a severe bruise and was sent to a hospital for Xrays.

title: Minh Asks U.S. Pressure To Assure Fair Elections
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5Gen. Duong Van Minh, a potential challenger for South Vietnam's presidency this fall, has charged in an interview that President Nguyen Van Thieu is using intimidation and pressure to insure his reelec tion and has urged that the United States apply all its influ ence for a fair and honest contest.

title: Posey Takes OverAll Honors in Continental Series Race
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, July 5 (UPI)Sam Posey of Sharon, Conn., finished in second place in the first heat today but won the second and the over all honors in the L & M Grand Prix Continental Series race at MidOhio sports car course.

title: PLAN FOR A CHARTER UPHELD BY VATICAN
description: ROME, July 5  The Vatican today defended its controversial project for a fundamental law of the church as being just as essential as political consti tuitions in the contemporary world.

title: Fifth Avenue Cards Expands
description: Fifth Avenue Cards, Inc., has announced the opening of three additional shops in June and several other openings set for summer and fall.

title: Attack on Way of Life Stirs a Storm in Polish Press
description: WARSAW, July 5Three weeks ago a Warsaw writer, Wieslaw Gornicki, stunned and dismayed his readers with a savage indictment of his fellow Poles.

title: Tests Said to Show Few Vietnam G.I.'s Are Heroin Addicts
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 (UPI)Initial results of new tests devised to seek out and rehabilitate heroin addicts among homewardbound Amer ican soldiers disclose an addic tion rate of only 2 per cent, Military sources said today.

title: 600 Cans of Recalled Soup Are Still Unaccounted For
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) The Food and Drug Administra tion said today at least 600 cans of vichyssoise believed to be contaminated still were unac counted for in the area from New York to Washington.

title: Comment by Macomber
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) William B. Macomber Jr., a Deputy Under Secretary of State, said today that only a very small percentage of the Pentagon papers could be dam aging if disclosed and that newspapers had largely retrained, from publishing those sections.

title: Fillmore West Rolls Into Rock Age Past
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 (AP)  Singing and gyrating to squealing guitars, some 2,500 rock music fans packed the Fillmore West last night to say goodby to a music institution.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: Hudson County Police Chief since 1955 ... carne up through the ranks ... 57 ... prosecution sought to prove that the Chief's expenses, in cluding a $4,800 mink coat for his wife and extensive bank deposits and purchases of property in Florida were considerably in excess of his $13,000ayear salary.

title: AUSTRALIANS REPORT PEKING TRADE TERMS
description: PEKING, July 5Representa tives of Australia's opposition Labor party emerged from trade talks yesterday with China's assurance that it will give equal consideration to Australia and Canada as potential suppliers of wheat once Canberra estab lishes diplomatic relations with Peking.

title: How We Went to War
description: WASHINGTON, July 5It is not enough to say that Mr. Johnson in 1964 was behaving in more or less the customary way. The question that mat ters is why men who lead democracies even, and indeed especially, men who count themselves as standing on the left of centerbehave like this. ... The problem which has burst out of its cage is the relationship between democracy and war.

title: AUGUST DERLETH PROLIFIC AUTHOR
description: SAUK CITY, Wis., July 5 August Derleth, author of about a hundred books who was per haps best known for his series of novels about the fictional town of Sac Prairie in Wis consin, died yesterday, appar ently of a heart attack. His age was 62.

title: Advertising:
description: An agreement was reached in London last week under which Ogilvy & Mather Inter national would acquire all of the advertising activities of S. H. Benson (Holdings) Ltd., with billings of $68million, and extend its sphere of in fluence from 17 to 24 coun tries.

title: Police Here Adopt New Policy On Briefings in Investigations
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has decided to change the police tradition of maintaining silence during ma jor investigations in favor of careful disclosures designed to encourage public confidence and cooperation.

title: U.A.W., in Debt, Halts Funds For Alliance With Teamsters
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 5 The Alliance for Labor Ac tion, a joint venture by the Teamsters and the United Auto mobile Workers to organize the poor and involve labor in com munity action programs, will not have any new funds for about a year.

title: Gamely, El Patron, Flying Bret Score In Yonkers Series
description: YONKERS, N. Y., July 5If Women's Lib becomes aware of the conditions written by Ed Parker for the Ed Sullivan Pacing Series, which got under way tonight at Yonkers Race way with Gamely ($19.20), El Patron ($22.60) and Flying Bret ($21.80) winning onemile divi sions, the racing secretary may find himself in hot water.

title: EYE OF A BLIND MAN MAKES 2D EYE WORK
description: MOSCOW, July 5 (UPI)A Soviet eye surgeon restored the sight of a man whose eyes had been burned by chemicals by fabricating part of a new right eye for him from the rear half of his left eye, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today.

title: Russian's Memoirs Reissued, Minus Criticism of Stalin
description: MOSCOW, July 5Ivan M. Maisky, the Soviet Union's wartime ambassador to Brit ain, who sharply criticized Stalin in his memoirs six years ago, has just had a new edition published with all unfavorable, references to Stalin eliminated.

title: Pompidou and Brandt Sail the Rhine and Hold Talks
description: BONN July 5President Pompidou of France and Chaticellar Willy Brandt opened a new round of regu lar consultations today with almost six hours of talks and sightseing'aboard an excur sion boat cruising down the Rhine from Mainz to Kob lenz.

title: Detroit Strike Ends
description: DETROIT, July 5 (AP)De troit's 1,400 sanitation workers ratified a threeyear contract with the city tonight, ending a strike that had halted garbage collections for 1.6 million De troiters since Thursday.

title: Britons and Rhodesians Talk
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, July 5 (Reuters)British and Rho desian negotiators met here to day for a fresh round of secret talks in an attempt to find a way out of the longdeadlocked independence dispute.

title: Israeli Women Soldiers Get a Raisein Hemline
description: TEL AVIV, July 5 (UPI) The Israeli military command belatedly surrendered to wo men's fashion today and or dered women soldiers to raise their hemlines to five inches above the knee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lessons of Vietnam
description: News Analysis

title: Ryun and Keino Set for Mile Race Today
description: STOCKHOLM, July 5, (UPI) Jim Ryun, who holds the world record for the onemile run; is scheduled to meet Kip choge Keino of Kenya in the highlight event of the July track and field games that start here tomorrows.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: Hudson County Democrat ic chairman . . . 49 . . . de scribed by the Government as a bag man . . . considered a figurehead with little real power . . . his own lawyer called him a dupe and said his concept of interstate commerce, involved in the criminal charges, was no more than a Hudson Tube ride to see a Knicks game in Manhattan.

title: Reduced Programs for Summer Open in the City Schools Today
description: The City Board of Educa tion's summer school and rec reational programs will get under way throughout the city today, although some of the programs have been cut back from last year for budget rea sons.

title: Reforming the Regulators
description: The independent regulatory commissions have for many years been the subject of continuing debate. Since there is wide agreement that they are not so effective as they should be in protecting the public interest, the controversy is over how to improve their performance.

title: Sycor Sets Leasing Deal
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 5 (UPI)Sycor, Inc., has an nounced that the North Ameri can Corporation, a leasing con cern, has agreed to buy a mini mum of $12million worth of Sycor dataprocessing terminals over the next three years, pro viding that Sycor finds custom ers to rent them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 Firemen Are Injured
description: Sixteen men in two Lower East Side fire companies were taken to Bellevue Hospital last night for treatment of smoke inhalation and heat exhaustion after they battled two fires on East 44th Street. The fires, damaged one apartment at 333 East Fourth Street, and three at 346 East Fourth Street. Eight adults and 15 children were relocated from the second address.

title: U.S. Nan Is Appointed To Senior Vatican Post
description: ROME, July 5An Ameri can nun, Sister Taddea Kelly, a member of the Sisters of the Presentation of Mary, to day became the first woman to hold a senior Vatican of fice.

title: HIS PACE IS SLOWING, WILLIE SUTTON SAYS
description: Few people are enjoying Independence Day more than I am, Willie Sutton, the 70year old former bank robber, said here yesterday.

title: Iraq Expels Two Britons, Charging a Link to Spies
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July (Reuters)Two British diplo mats were ordered today to leave Iraq within 24 hours be cause of their links with a spy and intrigue network, the offi cial Iraqi press agency reported here.

title: Pakistan Charges Britain With Interfering in Affairs
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 5 The Government of Pakistan disclosed today that it had lodged a protest with Britain charging that a concerted anti Pakistan campaign was under way in London.

title: Gas Leak Scars Arkansas Forest
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 5 A pipeline carrying anhydrous ammonia ruptured after dark on June 5 near the remote com munity of Floral in northeast Arkansas, sending about 80 tons of gas billowing over the countryside.

title: Stottlemyre Loses 50 Lead In 7Homer, 32Hit Game
description: BOSTON, July 5The New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox played a friendly little game of cutthroat in Fenway Park today before 23,364 cus tomers.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Unless Dr. Henry Kissinger can bring back from Saigon better news about Vietnamization than the pub lished reports suggest, the latest Viet cong proposals appear to have put President Nixon in an excruciating dilemma.

title: Officials Found Guilty in Jersey
description: Purchasing agent for Jer sey City since 1961 . . . 52 years old . . . accused of de manding a $3million kick back on a $42million electric construction contract in 1969 . . . described as a bag man in the conspiracy to extort more than $3million.

title: Policeman Shot by Partner As They Chase 4 Youths
description: One policeman accidentally shot another last night as they chased four teenagers after a dispute at a Chinese Restaurant. In the Bronx.

title: Brazilian Police Rearrest Beck of the Living Theater
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, July 5 (AP)Julian Beck, the theatrical director, and his wife, Judith Malina, have been detained by the Brazilian po litical police until further notice, police sources reported today. It was the second time that the Becks were arrested since Friday.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: FIRST ISRAEL BANK OPENS

title: 29 LARGE BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE TO 6% FROM 5%
description: The nation's major banks many of them carefully playing the role of reluctant dragon began yesterday to raise their prime lending rates to 6 per cent from 5 per cent.

title: Engineer Funds Released
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) The White House released today nearly $67million in Congres sional appropriations for Corps of Engineers and reclamation projects that had been frozen as an antiinflationary move.

title: Neighborhoods: Peaceful Bath Beach
description: To its residents, Bath Beach is quiet, orderly, neat. Its style is beach resort, only now the large beachfront ho tels are gone and so indeed is the beachboth replaced by the Belt Parkway.

title: Nun in Jersey Loses Court Appeal Based On Priest's Privilege
description: TRENTON, July 6A New Jersey Appeals Court ruled to day that a nun did not have the same right as a priest to withhold information concern ing crimes.

title: Jones and Moses Beaches Bar Swimming as Storm Roils Surf
description: A rough, pounding surf and the death of a 22yearold man by drowning caused the Long Island State Park Commission yesterday to close Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Park to swimmers.

title: U.S. Arms Aide Optimistic
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 6 (AP)Gerard C. Smith, head of the talks on limitations of strategic arms, arrived here to day and said he hoped for a concrete agreement with the Soviet Union. The Soviet dele gation is due here by train to morrow from Moscow. The talks are to resume Thursday.

title: Gift to City To Expand The Courts
description: A Federal grant of $1, 084,782 has been awarded to the Mayor's Criminal Justice Coordinating Coun cil to establish night and weekend courts in the Bronx and Queens.

title: U.S. MAY PUT OFF REPLY TO VIETCONG
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The United States is giving such serious study to the Vietcong peace plan submitted in Paris last Thursday that a formal response is likely to be de layed, senior Administration of ficials said today.

title: Badillo Forms New Council To Plan East Harlem Aid
description: An East Harlem planning group modeled after the local community planning board con cept was instituted yesterday by Representative Herman Badillo, Democrat of New York, to coordinate neighborhood needs with Federal programs.

title: Head of AntiRed Unit Finds Too Little Work
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) The head of the Subversive Activities Control Board con ceded today that there was not enough work to keep the board and its staff busy.

title: MARKET SCORES SLIGHT ADVANCE
description: The stock market scored a slight advance yesterday, despite the growing number of banks that raised their prime rate to 6 per cent from the former 5 per cent level.

title: Weather Stirs Retail Business
description: Aggressive price promotions and consistent, seasonal weath er favored retail business in New York last month, yielding a moderate increase in sales over June, 1970.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISWashington has never be fore engaged in such intricate and widespread negotiations, affecting our relationships with so many lands in cluding Russia and China, as those now under way in Europe and Asia.

title: SONGCAN IS VICTOR AT COSHEN TRACK
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 6 (UPI) Songcan, owned by the Donhy Stable of Forest Hills, Queens, and Saucy Wave, owned by Bert V. James of Pittsburgh, won the Grand Cir cuit Stakes features today at Historic Track.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon In California
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 6 (AP)President Nixon ar rived at 6:12 P.M. at nearby El Toro Marine Air Station to start a twoweek stay here.

title: TRADING DRIES UP IN BOND MARKETS
description: The bond markets, hit with a prime rate increase they had been expecting and waiting for New York City's recordsmash ing $357.5million financing to day, decided that the best thing to do yesterday was to hold their ground and let trading ac tivity dry up.

title: ROBERT WATERS, 78, RADIATOR FIRM HEAD
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., July 6 Robert S. Waters, retired chair man of the board of the former National United States Radiator Corporation, died Sunday night at Memorial Hospital here. He was 78 years old.

title: CREW OF APOLLO 15 UNDER CONFINEMENT
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 6 (AP)The Apollo 15 astro nauts were limited to contact with 102 persons today as they began a threeweek preflight medical isolation. The isolation is intended to limit exposure to disease or illness that could delay their launching to the moon July 26.

title: Britain Denies Ousted Aides Conspired Against Baghdad
description: LONDON, July 6 (Reuters) Britain denied today that two of her diplomats who were ex pelled from Iraq had been con spiring to overthrow the Bagh dad Government.

title: 4 Cuban Fishermen Are Freed by U.S.; Exchange Is Hinted
description: KEY WEST, Fla., July 7 (UPI) The Coast Guard released four Cuban fishing boat cap tains and their vessels to Cuban authorities in international wa ters last night as part of an ex change being negotiated for fdur Americans held in Cuba.

title: Nixon Sees Strong Rivalry From 4 Other Economic Superpowers
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 6 President Nixon said today the United States would face severe economic competition from the Soviet Union, China, Western Europe and Japan in the next few years and needed to institute internal reforms to meet the challenge.

title: Canadian Pacific Sets Split
description: The Canadian Pacific Rail way, which over the weekend dropped railway from its name to become simply Cana dian Pacific, Ltd., is planning a fiveforone stock split. Share holders will be asked to ap prove the split at a special meeting to be held early this fall.

title: Incentives in Poland
description: Polish newlyweds may have to wait five years for an apartment; automobiles, scarce and expensive, are avail able to only a tiny fraction of the population; meat and other high quality foods are often in short supply as well as relatively high priced. It Is factors such as these that explain the phenomenon one Warsaw writer recently called Poland's petrified proletarians, workers content to do as little as possible because they are resigned to a bare subsistence income and living standard without much hope of improvement no matter how hard they may work.

title: Brooks Robinson Tops American League Voting
description: Brooks Robinson, the third baseman for the world cham pion Baltimore Orioles, was the top votegetter for the Ameri can League AllStar team, ac cording to the figures issued yesterday by the baseball com missioner's office.

title: After the War Is Over
description: Economic Analysis

title: Massachusetts Gas Tax Up
description: BOSTON, July 6 (AP)An in crease of 1 cent a gallon in the state tax on gasoline was signed into law today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent. The rise, from 6 cent a gallon to 7 cents, goes into effect tomorrow.

title: State Aide Says Whelan Lost Office on Conviction
description: Thomas J. Whelan, the two term mayor of Jersey City, and Thomas M. Flaherty, the City Council President, forfeited their offices on their convic tion Monday of extortion con spiracy, a New Jersey state official said yesterday.

title: Seoul Police Give Haircuts
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 6 The Seoul police started to day a mass crackdown on longhaired youth's in a what was described as a social puri fication campaign. More than a tthousand young men were rounded up in the streets and had their hair out short at police stations.

title: 2 SLUM REBUILDERS ACCUSED BY RUSKIN
description: City Investigation Commis sioner Robert K. Ruskin charged yesterday that two men had pocketed a $300,000 windfall from an inflated mort gage from the city's Municipal Loan Program and suspended further payments for slum re habilitation to the pair.

title: Rail Benefit Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) President Nixon signed legis lation today temporarily in creasing annuities under the Railroad Retirement Act by 10 per cent. The measure confers on the railroad retirement sys tem the same increase in benefits provided for Social Security.

title: Will Jack Make His 25th Reunion?
description: NEW HAVENThe class of 1951 has just held its twentieth reunion at Yale but Jack Downey wasn't there. Jack and an assistant, Richard Fec teau, have been in prison in China since Nov. 29, 1952.

title: 500 Blocks Reported Cleared of Rats This Year
description: Health Services Administra tor Gordon Chase reported yes terday that rats were eradi cated in 500 of the city's most infested blocks during the first six months of this year.

title: SickleCell Anemia Tests Will Be Given Free Here
