description: Free blood tests for sickle cell anemia, an incurable he reditary disease that afflicts one in 500 American blacks, will begin today at noon.

title: INSTRUCTION TIME CUT TO 7 PERIODS
description: The Board of Education has set a new limit on the maxi mum number of instructional periods that may be offered by city high schools starting in the fall.

title: CONSUMER CREDIT ROSE DURING MAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 Outstanding consumer install ment credit rose significantly in May, although by less than April's record increase, the Fed eral Reserve Board reported to day.

title: 6 Women Identify Youth as Attacker In West Side Cases
description: A 20yearold youth was identified by six women last night as the person who had robbed and, in some cases, raped them in the last three months.

title: Indictment Against Banks Over Loans Dropped in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 6 (UPI)  A Federal judge dis missed indictments today against two Ohio banks charged with making illegal loans to political candidates during the state's 1970 primary election campaign.

title: G.O.P. Sets Parley Date; Site Still to Be Determined
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)The 1972 Republican Na tional Convention will be held Aug. 21 to 24, probably in Miami Beach or San Diego, Senator Robert J. Dole of Kan sas, the party chairman, said today.

description: To the Editor:

description: LONDON, July 6The open ing production of The Devil's Disciple at London's new Shaw Theater is a rather mel ancholy event for the British youth theater movement. It marks the end of a dream for Michael Croft, the founder of the National Youth Theater, who seven years ago almost succeeded in establishing a drama center where work by professionals and youths could have flourished under the same roof.

title: Racing Body Rules Slain Man's Widow Can't Own Horses

description: SAIGON, Wednesday, July 7 (AP)Capt. Ernest L. Medina, charged with murder and as sault in the Mylai case, arrived in Vietnam today to take dep ositions from witnesses. He is scheduled to stand teal July 26.

title: The Master of Soviet Film Comedy Is at It Again
description: MOSCOWLeonid Gaidai, the master of Soviet comedy films, is at it again, poking fun at the foibles of the sys tem.

title: SIMON S. HAMBURGER

title: Pops Was King
description: If, as many believe, American jazzthat indefinable offspring of the historical and cultural and racial vortex of New Orleansis this country's singular contribution to the art of the world, it was surely Louis Armstrong more than any other who made it so. No one else played so creative or enduring a role in the evolution and devel opment of jazz or in insuring its survival.

title: Comment by Ziegler
description: KANSAS CITY, July 6  Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, was asked today to comment on the interview in which Mrs. Binh said that there was nothing rigid about the peace proposal and that she would gladly meet privately with an American to discuss it.

title: AUSTRIA EXPECTED TO VOTE THIS FALL
description: VIENNA, July 6A caucus of Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's Social Democrats decided to night to. Gall for the dissolution of Parliament tomorrow and new elections to break the present equilibrium, which Dr. Kreisky says, is paralyzing political activity.

title: Tigers' 7 in 2d Beat Yanks, 127
description: DETROIT, July 6Stan Bahnsen, the pride of the Yankees' pitching staff for more than five weeks, failed to last two innings tonight as the New York club was beaten by the Tigers in a 2hour58 minute marathon, 127.

title: Advertising:
description: Many of the folks In De troit's marketingadvertising media community didn't dis cover until yesterday that Ford announced late Friday it was moving three car lines out of J. Walter Thompson, the agency for the entire Ford Division for over 20 years.

description: LONDON, July 6 (AP)  RollsRoyce (1971), Ltd., is fly ing a team of engineers to Peking this week in an effort to sell British jetliners to Com munist China.

title: Laments at British Open Today
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 6To hear them talking this is not the golf course it's cracked up to be.

title: PROXMIRE CHARGES F14 JET IS A LEMON
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that he had information that cost overruns on the Navy's F14 jet fighter plane could approach $4billion.

title: After the Soyuz Tragedy
description: Soviet authorities have still not made public the con clusions of the special commission which investigated last week's tragic death of the Soyuz 11 cosmonauts. But they have already announced that they regard the experi ment in which the deceased cosmonauts participated as having been a major success, and that they intend to move rapidly toward establishing a permanent manned orbiting space station. Moscow has not felt it necessary to explain why it feels the disastrous end of the Soyuz 11 mission requires no more serious rethinking of the space station program.

title: De Sica and Pasolini Capture Top Prizes at Berlin Film Fete
description: BERLIN, July 6Moviemak ers from Italy won the lion's share of prizes at Berlin's 21st nternational film festival, which ended tonight, free of political turmoil, after 12 days.

title: 5Party Coalition Cabinet Is Installed in Netherlands
description: THE HAGUE, July 6 (Reu ters)  A new fiveparty Cabi net, headed by Premier Barend W. Biesheuvel, was sworn in today by Queen Juliana at her Huis Ten Bosch Palace.

title: To Catch a Park Thief, Borrow 10Speed Bike
description: A policeman commandeer ed a 10speed racing bicycle last night to capture a sneak thief in Central Park. He got his man after an eightblock chase.

title: The Purloined Papers
description: WASHINGTONMore than a cen tury ago Alexis de Tocqueville told us: Scarcely any political question arises in the United States that is not re solved, sooner or later, into a judicial question.

title: Soweto: Rigors of Apartheid, as Felt in Biggest Ghetto
description: SOWETO, South Africa. July 2  Every weekend an average of 15 people meet violent death in this Bantu urban area, South Africa's largest ghetto and one of the biggest allblack settlements in Africa.

title: Whitney Seymour Sr. Gets Bar Group's Highest Award
description: Whitney North Seymour Sr., a former president of the Amer ican Bar Association and of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, was awarded the A.B.A. medal, the associa tion's highest award, last night.

title: Bridge:
description: Most players, even the greatest, double the oppo nents into game now and then. Those who never do so are overcautious, and fre quently allow their oppo nents to go down two or More tricks undoubled.

title: Sailor Fights Navy on Return to Spain
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., July 6 Attorneys for a 20yearold American sailor who arrived in Charleston as a stowaway after escaping from the Spanish au thorities are battling what they say are Navy plans to return him to Spain without benefit of extradition.

title: 70's Are the Talk of the 70's
description: YONKERS, July 6When the subject of septuagenarian train errivers in harness racing bobs up, the names of Earle Avery, 77 years old; Sanders Russell, 71, and Sacher Werner, 72, dominate the conversation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: GARRISON ACCUSES 2 FEDERAL AIDES
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 6 District Attorney Jim Garrison, filed seven criminal charges to day against two Federal offi cials who were involved in the, bringing of bribery charges against him last Wednesday.

title: SONGCAN IS VICTOR AT COSHEN TRACK
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 6 (UPI) Songcan, owned by the Donhy Stable of Forest Hills, Queens, and Saucy Wave, owned by Bert V. James of Pittsburgh, won the Grand Cir cuit Stakes features today at Historic Track.

title: Hobby Anounces in Texas
description: HOUSTON, July 6 (AP)  William P. Hobby, president and executive editor of the Houston Post, announced today as Dem ocratic candidate for Lieuten ant Governor of Texas. The present Lieutenant Governor, Ben Barnes, has announced as Democratic candidate for Gov ernor.

title: Kreiss Bows to Stolle
description: DUBLIN, July 6 (Reuters) Fred Stolle lost the first set, but the Australian recovered to beat the Wimbledon junior champion, Bob Kreiss of Bel Air, Calif., 46, 62, 63, and reached the quarter finals of the Irish open tennis tournament to day.

title: Screen: 'Adrift,' a Dream Anecdote:Work by Kadar Opens at the Rendezvous Life's Blessings Theme of Fisherman's Tale
description: The three movies of Jan Kadar that I have seen"The Shop on Main Street" (1966), "The Angel Levine" (1970), and "Adrift," which opened yesterday at the Cinema Rendezvousthough differing in story and details of situation, all share a distinctive technical vocabulary and a pervasive, perhaps obsessive, preoccupation with a theme.Actually, "Adrift," which was begun in Czechoslovakia in 1968 and interrupted by the Russian occupation, mostly predates "The Angel Levine," though it is a more assured and, in general, a more interesting movie.The Kadar theme concerns the failure to accept life's difficult blessings, and in each of the three films it is embodied in an anecdote having to do with a humble man who is strongly tempted to virtue but who, out of fear or skepticism or desire, resists the temptation and so loses the familiar giftin each case a womanthat he learns too late has given his life its value.In "Adrift" the hero (Rade Markovic) is a fisherman who rescues from the river a beautiful and utterly mysterious girl (Paula Pritchett). His interest in her, annoyance at first, grows until he can no longer make love to his wife (Milena Dravic) and when she takes sick and then miraculously almost recovers he prepares her medicine in a poisonous concentration  which he is about to give her when . . ."Adrift" never quite ends; it circles. Its late sequences repeat its early sequences, and its central anecdote is told as a flashback in the course of an unreal inquisition that turns out to be a drunken dream. Dislocations between levels of reality are important to the movie, as its title suggests, and the deceptively simple, rather banal story is clearly intended to support a meaning structure that is at once demanding for its audience and, hopefully, magical in its associations.I must say that I think the magic at no time works, that the demands are purely gratuitous, that the simplicities of the story are every bit as real as they are apparent, and that its banality is only enforced by the devices  the shock cutting, the symbolic clues, the musical mottos, including the choir of heavenly voices that seems to travel from one Kadar movie to anotherby which the director intends to impress significance upon material from which he has been unable or unwilling to extract meaning on its own terms.Nevertheless, "Adrift" is serious work by a director who knows what he wants to do and commands the resources and the skill to do it. I continue to find Kadar a dull artist, but in the context of his particular kind of semimystical cinema he provides at least the example of a genuine intellectual ambition at work.In the previous Kadar movies I have seen, the prize neglected was played by Ida Kaminska, an actress with qualities calculated to bring out the worst in her director. The very lovely and talented Miss Dravic is in every way an improvement, except that stuck in bed and made feverish, she begins to seem, in Jan Kadar's hands, a little like Ida Kaminska. An American, Paula Pritchett, plays the girl in the river. Between the classic angularity of her face and the magnificent nonangularity of her body she combines the best of two erotic-fantasy worlds. But she does not, if you happen to notice, offer much of a performance.

title: Syria Wins Higher Pipeline Royalties
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 6 Syria announced today that the Westernowned Iraq Petroleum Company had agreed to in crease by more than 50 per cent its payments for the right to pipe oil across Syrian soil to the Mediterranean Sea.

title: TRIAL IS SET AUG. 4 FOR MYLAI COLONEL
description: FORT MEADE, Md., July 6 (AP)A military judge refused today to dismiss one of four charges against Col. Oran X. Henderson of the Army arising out of the alleged covering up of the killing of South Viet namese civilians at Mylai in 1968. He set Aug. 4 as a tenta tive date to start Colonel Hen derson's courtmartial.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sales of Savings Bonds Climb to 16Year High
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Americans bought more Series E and H United States Savings Bonds during the first half of 1971 than in any other sixmonth period since 1955.

title: Donohue's Standing Rises Like Rocket On Holiday Driving
description: About Motor Sports

title: Executive Changes
description: Bache & Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, has elected Elliot J. Smith as senior vice president. Mr. Smith is national sales manager and heads the firm's marketing and sales division.

title: Canadian, Back From China, Sees More Trade
description: OTTAWA, July 6Canada's Trade Minister, JeanLuc Pepin, returned from China today filled withoenthusiasm over the prospects for trade now that the two countries have opened diplomatic relations.

title: Sally Lucas Jean Is Dead at 93; Long Active as Health Educator
description: Sally Lucas Jean, a pioneer health educator whose career in the field began in the Span ishAmerican War, died on Monday at her home here. She was 93 years old and lived with her longtime friend and secretary, Dorothy Goodwin, at 530 East 23d Street.

title: N.M. RESPONDS TO F.C.C. RULING
description: The National Broadcasting Company over the weekend dropped television commer cials by the Standard Oil Com pany of New Jersey promoting its oil drilling operations in Alaska.

title: Democrats Offer Program On Economy and Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)  Democrats proposed today a sevenpoint program they said would get the economy moving again and combat in flation.

title: NEW PATH STATION OPENS DOWNTOWN
description: Thousands of New Jersey commuters homebound from the financial district of Man hattan confronted new turn stiles built for exact change as PATH's handsome, marble faced rail terminal under the World Trade Center opened yesterday.

title: MRS. ROSWELL RAUSCH
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 6 Mrs. Louise Cornell Rausch, ac tive in civic affairs here for half a century, died yesterday at her summer home in East Blue Hill, Me. She was 80 years old and was the wife of Roswell H. Rausch, a retired vice presi dent of the Scott Paper Com pany.

title: Mills Deplores Crime's High Cost for Individual
description: Representative Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, a Congres sional leader known for his interest in the dollars and cents of Government, spoke to the American Bar Association last night about crimein terms of dollars and cents.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 7, 1971

title: 2 Held Without Bail In Prostitution Case By an Angry Judge
description: Two women charged with prostitution were held without bail yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court by an irate judge who complained that the midtown area is inundated with prostitution.

title: GERHARD KORALLUS, MERCEDESBENZ AIDE
description: FORT LEE, N. J., July 6  Dr. Gerhard Korallus, senior vice president for finance and administration of Mercedes Benz of North America, Inc., died today after a long illness. He was 49 years old and lived in Upper Saddle River.

title: Stock on Amex Rise Slightly In a Session of Light Trading
description: In relatively light trading, stock prices on the American Stock Exchange rose slightly? yesterday.

title: McGovern Accuses Party Aide Of Showing Support for Muskie
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 Senator George McGovern of Sotith Dakota today accused Robert S. Strauss, the Demo cratic national treasurer, of vi elating neutrality while demon strating support for the unan nounced Presidential campaign of Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: Advertising:
description: Bon Vivant, the Newark soup maker, doesnt adver tise much, but when it does it's usually in an upscale me dium. Yesterday its ad agen cy, the Lee Mandell Com pany, was in the process of killing an ad scheduled for the September Town & Coun try.

title: ANTIGENS ARE FOUND IN VARIOUS CANCERS
description: ALBANY, July 6Basing its work on earlier research that confirmed the presence of a blood antigen in patients with cancer of the digestive tract, a research team in the State Health Department reported to day finding a similar antigen in patients suffering from cancer of the breast, lungs, bladder, prostate, kidneys and nervous system.

title: 21 IN HOUSE ASSAIL CITATION OF C.B.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Twentyone House Democrats charged today that the Com merce Committee's attempt to cite the Columbia Broadcasting System and its president, Frank Stanton, for contempt of Con gress was a threat to the First Amendment. They urged their colleagues to oppose the move.

title: Reserve Aide Tells N.A.A.C.P. Blacks' Job Outlook Is Gloomy
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 6  A leading Negro economist pre dicted hepe today that it would be quite some time before there would be any improve ment in the employment situa tion for black Americans.

title: Harris Hints He'll Join 1.972 Race
description: Wash ington Notes

title: Giants Obtain Gaechter, Dallas Safety, in Trade
description: The New York Giants an nounced yesterday they had acquired Mike Gaechter, a safetyman with nine years of experience, from the Dallas Cowboys in a trade for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: Mrs. Binh Calls for Talks
description: PARIS, July 6 (UPI)Mrs. Binh indicated today that the latest Vietcong peace proposals were not an inflexible takeit orleaveit package.

title: LOULA COMBS, 90; BRED SHOW HORSES
description: LEE'S SUMMIT. Mo., July 6 (AP)Mrs. Loula Long Combs, a nationally known grande dame of showhorse owners, died last night. She was 90 years old and lived at Long view Farm.

title: Oil Leases Sold in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 6Oil companies paid $3,898,288 for oil and gas leases on 97,460 acres of Texas school land to day, with Gulf of Mexico leases producing most of the interest. Several major companies, in cluding Humble, Texaco and Gulf, did not enter bids. With the royalty set at onesixth, bidding was on the cash bonus. A total of 869 tracts was of fered and bids were made on 158. Only 176 bids were re ceived.

title: $9,000aYear Teacher Left College $2Million
description: CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) A former Chicago high school teacher, who never made more than $9,000 a year for the 46 years she taught; has willed $2million to medical research at the University of Chicago, the university an nounced today.

title: DuPont Sets Reduction In Polyester Film Prices
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had reduced prices on most of its Mylar polyester film by as much as 10 per cent to 20 per cent.

title: METALS FUTURES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Prices of metals futures con tinued to rise yesterday as a result of the copper strike.

title: VIETNAM INQUIRY URGED BY TAYLOR
description: Telford Taylor, former Unit ed States prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials, called on President Nixon and Congress yesterday to appoint a nation al commission to investigate the origins and conduct of the war in Vietnam.

title: U.S. Aide Says Pollution Fight Balks Power Growth
description: Environmentalist objections to energy development were held to have become excessive yesterday by an Assistant Sec retary of The Interior and spokesmen for the coal and oil industries during the Amer ican Bar Association meeting here.

title: Radioactivity of Coal Cited by Con Ed Chief
description: Coalfired power plants, because of radioactive ma terial contained in most coal, give off gases with low levels of radioactivity and often emit more radioactive material than nuclear plants, Charles F. Luce, chairman of the Consolidated Edison Com pany, said yesterday.

title: Thrift Unit, Alleging Disruption, Would Make Bank Sell Interest
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6The First Surety Corporation, Burbank, Calif., savings and loan holding company, has pe titioned the Federal Home Loan Bank Board to force di vestiture by a bank of a con trolling interest in the holding company.

title: Nation's Energy Crisis: Nuclear Future Looms
description: Slowly, reluctantly and fearfully, the United States is moving toward a nuclear powered future. It is not that people have learned to love the atom; it is because few can think of any other ac ceptable answer to the na tion's energy crisis.

title: The Torture of the Greeks
description: The following article is taken from letters written on tissue and smug gled out of an Athens prison. They came from members of the student resistance organization, Rigas Ferraios, and describe their treatment by Greek security police.

title: For People Who Always Wanted a Big Blue Hand on the Wall
description: Shop Talk

title: Upstate Crash Kills 4
description: HANNIBAL, N. Y., July 6 (AP)Three women and the 16yearold daughter of one of them were killed today when the car in which they were riding slammed headon into a tractortrailer on Route 104 in this community about 13 miles west of Oswego.

title: Bar Group Bids Judges Set Example of Decorum
description: By unanimous voice vote of its 297member policy making unit, the American Bar Association adopted yester day a set of courtroom guidelines that urged judges to set the tone for orderly proceed ings by behaving well them selves.

title: Governor Signs Bill Allowing Purchase Of Stadium by City
description: ALBANY, July 6Governor Rockefeller announced today the signing of a bill authorizing New York City to buy and modernize Yankee Stadium as a means of keeping the New York Yankees and the Football Giants in the city.

title: Brutality Charge Results In Buffalo Police Lineup
description: BUFFALO, July 6For the first time in the history of the Buffalo Police Department, a group of policemen stood in a lineup tonight at headquarters in a case of alleged police bru tality, but the complainants were unable to single out any one.

title: New Measurements Used On Balance of Payments
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  The Commerce Department published today, after lengthy study, a new set of measures of the United States balance of international payments. The new measures are de signed to be more meaningful than the old, which had be come increasingly difficult to interpret. However, today's report cautioned that no one of the new statistics should be taken as the single best measure of the balance of payments, and that none of them measured precisely whether the payments balance was in equilibrium.

title: ACTIONS ON VIETNAM DEFENDED BY GRAVEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Senator Mike. Gravel defended to the Senate today his public reading of parts of the Pentagon papers on the United States involvement in Vietnam.

title: Former Champions Lead In Slice Cup Sailing Series
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 6 Three former Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association wo men's champions led after three races today in the Syce Cup sailing championships on the Sound.

title: A Park for the People
description: If Congress does what is clearly expected of it, the Gateway National Recreation Area will soon become a reality. With Administration backing, enthusiastic sup port in the Congressional delegations of both New York and New Jersey and the approval of all who want bring parks to the people, the likelihood is that a Gate way law will be passed in this session of Congress.

title: EARNINGS DECLINE AT HARRIS TRUST
description: The Harris Trust & Savings Bank, a principal Chicago in stitution, reported yesterday a 25.1 per cent decline in second quarter earnings reflecting a substantial decrease in loans and sharply lower rates.

title: Planners Approve $15Million For New City Transit Projects
description: The City Planning Commis sion approved yesterday the adding of $15million to the 197071 capital budget for new mass transit projects to qualify the Transit Authority for $24 million in surplus Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority funds.

title: Minsky 4th in Debut Here
description: Minsky, full brother of the outstanding European cam paigner, Nijinsky, made an unsuccessful American debut at Aqueduct yesterday when she finished fourth in a field of six in the $20,000 Sea O Erin purse, a 1 116mile race on turf for 3yearolds.

title: Big Minh Denies That U.S. Had Role in AntiDiem Plot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (AP)Gen. Duong Van Minh, leader of the group that over threw President Ngo Dinh Diem in 1963, was quoted today as denying that the United States had supported and encouraged the coup.

title: DRUGS USED ON JOB, STATE STUDY SHOWS
description: A study estimates that per haps 100,000 people in the state are using illegal narcotics reg ularly while they are at work.

title: 5 PLAYWRIGHTS WIN IN SHUBERT CONTEST
description: Winners of the fourth annual Shubert Foundation Playwrit ing Contest were announced yesterday by Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, chairman of the board of directors of the Sam S. Shubert Foundation.

title: YITZHAK TABENKIN, ZIONIST PIONEER, 84
description: TEL AVIV, July 6Yitzhak Tabenkin, a Zionist pioneer, died here today at the age of 84. He will be buried tomorrow in Ein Harod, a kibutz in the Jezreel Valley he founded in 1921 and which remained his home.

title: Notes on People
description: Indian security police helped Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, dodge antiAmerican demonstrators yesterday at New Delhi airport. Mr. Kissin ger arrived for a twoday visit that is expected to include talks with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Francis Vivian Drake, 76, Dies; A Writer on Military Subjects
description: STONINGTON, Conn., July 6 Francis Vivian Drake, a writ er on military sgbjects and an early educator on aviation fighting techniques, died at his home on Sunday evening. Be was 76 years old.

title: Crealy Forced Out
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, (UPI)  Dick Crealy of Australia, the defending champion, withdrew from the $33,000 Swedish open tennis championship today aft er suffering a leg injury in his firstround match with Patrick Proisy of France. Crealy re tired at 11 in the second set after Proisy had won the first, 75.

title: Reform Plan Envisages Deputy Secretary of State
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  Secretary of State William P. Rogers announced a reorgani zation of the State Department's structure and practices today that he said would provide for better management, a more re liable periodic review of policy objectives and a fairer person nel policy.

title: Roundup: Now Hitters Scream at Ellis
description: Dock Ellis of the Pirates, whose real name is Dock Ellis Jr., owes it all to chew ing gum.

title: U.S. Sells Crime Insurance in 11 States
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) The Government announced today that it would begin sell ing crime insurance Aug. 1 in 11 states and the District of Columbia where private insur ance is not available at rea sonable rates.

title: Dilworth Quits Board
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (UPI)  Richardson Dilworth an nounced today his resignation as president of the Philladel phia School Board, effective Aug 31. The former reform Democratic Mayor said he was stepping down because he wants to speak out on local political issues in the coming mayoral campaign.

title: Steel Pay, Profit And Employment
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  President Nixon's Cabinet Com mittee on Economic Policy is sued tables today on wages levels, employment and corpo rate profits in the steel indus try.

title: National Symphony Attains $3.1Million Goal for Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The National Symphony, one of 60 symphony orchestras in the nation to receive challenge grants totaling $83million from the Ford Foundation, has achieved a major fundraising goal.

title: Sex Clinic Suit Dismissed, But Action Could Be Refiled
description: ST. LOUIS, July 6 (AP)  A $2.5million damage suit against the sex researchers William H. Masters and Vir ginia Johnson was dismissed today by a Federal district judge.

title: U.S. Aide Calls Soyuz Deaths Like Those of Our Own
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 6A United States rep resentative joined in tribute of fered here today to the three Soviet astronauts killed last week aboard the Soyuz space craft and said that their loss was felt as if they were our own.

title: NEWCOMBE, OKKER ADVANCE IN TENNIS
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 6 (Reuters)  John Newcombe of Australia and Tom Okker of the Netherlands coasted to victories over American opponents in the Swiss international tennis championship today.

title: Come to Agreement In Other Areas
description: BONN, July 6France and West Germany ended two days of summit talks here today without reaching an agreement on monetary problems result ing from Bonn's decision last May to float the Deutsche mark.

title: Dockers Resume Picketing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 (AP) Picketing resumed today as longshoremen continued a strike in 24 West Coast ports, now six days old. Members of the In ternational Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union paused yesterday to honor the men who died July 5, 1934, in the strike that won recognition for their union.

title: HEARINGS OPENED FOR KAHANE TRIAL
description: A patrolman who infiltrated the Jewish Defense League is to testify for the Government at the conspiracy trial of Rabbi Meir Kahane and about a dozen T.D.L. members.

title: Brazil Charges Julian Beck Had Marijuana in His Home
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, July 6The police announced today that more than two pounds of marijuana had been found in the home of Julian Beck, the founder of New York's Living Theater.

title: G.E. to Build New Unit
description: The General Electric Com pany announced yesterday that its medical systems department plans to build a $30million plant in Waukesha County, west of Milwaukee. The new facility will serve as headquar ters for the department and also provide manufacturing and warehousing space. Construc tion is scheduled to begin later this year with initial produc tion in early 1973. The new plant is expected to provide employment for about 1,500 persons.

title: A 6Currency Float Backed in France
description: PARIS, July 6  Jean  Mar cel Jeanneney, economic ad viser to the late Charles de Gaulle, urged today that France accept a German pro posal for a generalized Com mon Market currency float against the dollar.

title: Test of Vichyssoise Uncovers Botulin In 4 Out of 321 Cans
description: Laboratory tests have re vealed botulin, the toxin that causes botulism, in four additional cans of Bon Vivant brand vichyssoise from the same batch as the can that has been linked to the death of a Westchester banker last Wednesday and the partial paralyzing of his wife.

title: Ecuador Ousts Soviet Aides
description: QUITO, Ecuador, July 6 (AP)  The Foreign Ministry an nounced today the expulsion of three Soviet diplomats for reasons of state and of internal order. Unofficial sources said the expulsions were related to labor conflicts.

title: Amtrak Makes Improvements in LongHaul Service
description: The National Railroad Pas senger Corporation, known as Amtrak, released new nation wide schedules of intercity pas senger trains yesterday includ ing improved longhaul service.

title: Montessori Youth University Opens on L.I.
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., July 6 The first Montessori method school in the United States to include students at the high school level opened its doors yesterday on a 14acre farm here.

title: Armstrong Was Root Source of Jazz
description: An Appraisal

title: A Broad Central Marketplace
description: William McChesney Martin, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is still a few weeks away from completing his eagerly awaited study of the New York Stock Exchange, but he has already made it clear that he hopes to create a broad national securities market with a reorganized New York exchange as its center.

title: Excerpts From Le Duc Tho Interview
description: PARIS, July 6Following are excerpts from the trans script of an interview today with Le Duc Tho, a member of the Politburo of the ruling Communist party of North Vietnam, conducted by An thony Lewis of The New York Times. Mr. Tho spoke in Vietnamese, which was translated into English by an aide, Phuong Nguyen Dinh. Two other aides, Tran Thien Can and Nguyen Thanh Le, were with him.

title: ROSTOW SAYS TIMES DISTORTED ARCHIVES
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 6 (AP) Walt W. Rostow, former aide to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson, has ac cused The New York Times of misleading the public with its account of the Pentagon pa pers, The Daily Texan said to day.

title: 3 Choreographers Offer Wide Variety In Cubicalo Dances
description: Interesting dance beginnings did not often develop to in teresting conclusions at the Cubiculo Monday evening. Car olyn Bilderback, Shawn Avrea and Charlotte Honda presented a program of choreographic ideas and images that for the most part went subtly and sometimes blatantly awry.

title: JOHN F. HUNT
description: PORTLAND, Me., July 6 John F. Hunt, a longtime New England newspaperman, died in Mercy Hospital here yester day. He was 65 years old and lived in suburban Yarmouth.

title: Market Place:
description: Now that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., has gone public, you can march right out to your friendly neighborhood stock broker and buy a piece of the world's biggest brokerage house.

title: 15 Defections Thwarted, Poland Says in Warning
description: WARSAW, July 6  Polish authorities sought today to dis courage wouldbe defectors by publicizing an unsuccessful at tempt by 15 Polish vacationers to escape to the West from Yugoslavia.

title: Vasquez's Challenger Is His, Conqueror
description: It may be trite to say that dynamite comes in small packages, but the saying fits Davey Vasquez perfectly. Vasquez, at 5 feet 1 inch, is the smallest professional boxer in New York, but he is one of the best.

title: George J. Saliba, Engineer, Pioneer in Sound Recording
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 6 George J. Saliba, a consulting engineer and a pioneer in sound recording, died at his home yes terday, of complications after major surgery. He was 66 years old and lived at 170 Hill side Avenue.

title: Larsen Is Defeated By Bobby Fischer In Opening Game
description: DENVER, July 6  Bobby Fischer, moving forward in his quest for the World's Chess Championship, defeated Bent Larsen of Denmark in 41 moves in the first game of their match tonight in Temple Buell Col lege here.

title: HANOI AIDE SAYS P.O.W. AGREEMENT CAN BE SEPARATE
description: PARIS, July 6A high ranking North Vietnamese lead er said today that the new Communist offer to return war prisoners if American forces are withdrawn by the end of 1971 was not dependent on a political settlement in South Vietnam.

title: Newton Jury Picking Starts
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July (AP) Jury selection began today in the retrial of Huey P. Newton, Black Panther leader, convicted of voluntary manslaughter in the 1967 shooting death of an Oakland policeman.

title: Mets Lose, Trail by 5 Games;
description: Ominous signs, including two power failures and the dis abling of Jerry Koosman, de scended upon Shea Stadium like a rainstorm last night as the Mets completed the first half of their season by losing to the Montreal Expos, 51.

title: Auto Rally Driver Killed
description: SALVADOR, Brazil, July 6 (AP)Danilo Antonio Zaffari, Brazilian driver, was killed and three of his teammates injured yesterday during the first leg of the 3,000  mile Fortaleza  Chui automobile rally when their Brazilian  made Dodge Dart overturned.

title: An Army of Price Agents Keeps Tabs on Economy
description: Mrs. Dorothy Weinberg picked up the container of eggs from the Finest super market dairy case, made sure she, had chosen large white and said, Hmm, last month they were 53 cents a dozen. Now they've gone up to 59 cents.

title: A Draw in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, July 6 (Reuters) The second game in the semi finals of the challengers' tour nament for the World Chess Championship between Tigran Petrosian, former champion, end grand master Viktor Korchnol ended in a draw on the 37th move here today, ac cording to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Soviet's Stankovich Wins World Fencing Foils Title
description: VIENNA, July 6 (Reuters) Vasily Stankovich of the So viet Union won the men's in dividual foils final tonight in the world fencing champion ships.

title: Toyota's U.S. Sales Soar
description: DETROIT, July 6Nothing in the dealer's showroom, from Detroit or Europe, appears able to slow the assault of the Japanese automobiles on the American market.

title: Rights Aide's Home Blasted
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 6 (AP)An explosion has caused about $1,000 damage to the home of James R. Mapp, presi dent of the Chattanooga chapter of the Natictnal Association for the Advancement of Colored People, the authorities said to day. Mr. Mapp is on vacation and no one was in the home.

title: Urban Guerrillas in Uruguay Seem to Have Modified Tactics
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 6The urban guerrillas of Uru guay have apparently decided to avoid upsetting the nation wide elections scheduled for November.

title: Z MAGISTRATE CASE STILL UNDER STUDY
description: ATHENS, July 6The Greek authorities have declared that no formal charges have been lodged against Christos Sartze takis, the former investigating magistrate whose activities were depicted in the film Z.

title: U.S. URGED TO PUSH ENVIRONMENT AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The policymaking body of the Na tional Science Foundation has told the White House that the United States needs a compre hensive national research pro gram to help man understand and cope with his increasing effects on world environment.

title: Survey Shows Public Colleges Feel Education's Money Pinch
description: Higher education's financial crisis, most often associated with the private institutions, is having an increasingly pro found effect on publicly sup ported colleges and universities, according to a survey released yesterday by the National Asso ciation of State Universities and LandGrant Colleges.

title: Frick Collection Seeks to Stave Off Tax
description: No one ever thought it would happen, but the Frick Collection, that elegant man sion of masterpieces on up per Fifth Avenue, has in stalled a contribution box in its entrance lobby. Its dis creet legend, lettered in gold, reads To help maintain the standards and support the educational activities of the Frick Collection, contribu tions in any amount are wel come.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times
description: FAKING IT, or the Wrong Hungarian. By Gerald Green. 411 pages. Trident Press. $7.95.

title: Police Bill of Rights Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)  A measure to establish a police officers' bill of rights was introduced today by Rep resentative Louis Frey Jr., Re publican of Florida.

title: Irving Greenfield Weds Mrs. Molly K. Spirn
description: Mrs. Molly Katzoff Spirn, an interior designer with Cav allon Associates, was mar ried here last evening to Ir ving Greenfield, a member of the New York law firm of Greenfield, Lipsky & Bress. Rabbi William Berkowitz per formed the ceremony in the chapel of Congregation B'nai Jeshurun.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times
description: A little old man poked his baldish head, covered with a black yarmulke, into Room 402 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens, and said, Please, is Mr. Holz man here? I would like to get some autographs for my grandchildren. They are Knick fans.

title: Louis Armstrong, Jazz Trumpeter and Singer, Dies
description: Louis Armstrong, the cele brated jazz trumpeter and singer, died in his sleep yester day morning at his home in the Corona section of Queens. He had observed his 71st birthday Sunday.

title: Audience in Park Responsive To Music by Black Composers
description: Four different ensembles were presented by the Society of Black Composers in a con cert at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park on Monday night, but the program turned out to be surprisingly homo geneous.

title: HARRY HOFFMAN
description: Harry Hoffman, a retired president of Gilcrest Clothes, Inc. a men's clothing manufac turer, which he founded, died Monday in Monlefiore Hospital, the Bronx. He was 82 years old and lived at 92 Van Cortland Park South in the Bronx.

title: Spain Raises Drug Penalty
description: MADRID, July 6 (AP)The Spanish Government has raised the maximum fine for posses sion of hard narcotics to nearly $400,000, a Government spokes man said today.

title: Babylon Sanitation Head Found Guilty of Larceny
description: RIVERFIEAD, L. I., July 6 Anthony Serigano, director of sanitation for the Town of Babylon, was found guilty to day of thirddegree grand lar ceny in conjunction with the theft of funds from the town's Republican Club treasury in 1968.

title: DEPOSITS RULING FAVORS TENANTS
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice ruled yesterday that, in ef fect, millions of residential ten ants in New York State were entitled to interest on security deposits they entrusted to land lords before last Sept. 1.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS THAT STEEL PACT BE CONSTRUCTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 Appealing to patriotism and en lightened selfinterest, President Nixon admonished leaders of the steel union and the steel Industry today to reach a con structive contract settlement.

title: SEOUL WEIGHS SHIFT IN PANMUNJOM ROLE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 6  A major change in the for mat of the Korean armistice commission meetings at Pan munjom, where American and North Korean generals have engaged in sterile argumenta tion for 18 years, is in pros pect if a recent suggestion of the senior United States nego tiator is heeded.

title: Reserve Unit Voted Minor Tightening
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted in early April to seek a temporary and minor tightening of money market conditions with the aim of slowing the growth of the money supply and other mone tary aggregates, it was dis closed today.

title: State Auditors Begin City Study To See If Taxpayer Gets Value
description: The vanguard of state audi tors who will make he first comprehensive outside investi gation of New York City's gov ernment arrived yesterday at the Municipal Building.

title: U.S. AND EGYPT OPEN NEW TALKS ON SUEZ
description: CAIRO, July 6Two United States diplomats met today with the acting Foreign Min ister of Egypt, Hafez Ismail, starting a new round of talks aimed at breaking a deadlock on terms for a reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: M.T.A. TO BUY LAND FOR STEWART FIELD
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority announced yes terday the first step to acquire approximately 9,000 acres of land for part of a fourth jet port for the metropolitan area at Stewart Airport.

title: WILLIAM J. HICKEY
description: NEWARK, July 6 (AP)Wil liam J. Hickey, a former deputy, commissioner of the New York Stare Liquor Authority, died yesterday at his home, 856 Thurston Road. He was 66 years old. Mr. Hickey, who joined the agency in 1935, was named a deputy commissioner in 1956.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES GETS MORE CREDIT
description: Eastern Air Lines announced yesterday a series of refunding operations under which it will have a call on an additional 450million in bank credit, with an interest rate onehalf of one percentage point above the prime rate.

title: MRS. A. H. ROSENBERG
description: Mrs. Gertrude A. Rosenberg of 63 East 9th Street and East Hampton, L. I., who retired last year as publicity director for the Brooklyn Young Women's Christian Association, died yes terday in Southampton (L. I.) Hospital following a long ill ness. She was 65 years old.

title: Teamsters Union Is Praised by Nixon and Hodgson
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 6  Teamsters' convention dele gates, who have heard few kind words from top Admin istration officials in the last decade, were praised today by President Nixon and Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson.

title: Storm Moves Out to Sea
description: BOSTON, July 6 (AP)Ar lene, the first tropical storm of the season, veered out to sea today, causing little or no harm to the mainland. The National Weather Service here reported that the storm began heading in an easterly direction about 200 miles southeast of Nan tucket Island.

title: Canada Sells Peru Wheat
description: OTTAWA, July 6 (Canadian Press)The Canadian wheat board has sold 8.3 million bush els of wheat to Peru, Otto Lang, minister responsible for the board, announced today. The sale, which includes a pro vision for the purchase of an additional three million bush els, is worth about $22million if the full amount is taken.

title: 2 LOCKHEED AIDES ARE RETIRING EARLY
description: Two vice presidents of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation took early retirement yester day. They are Frank L. Frain, 58, who had been senior vice presidentfinance and a direc tor, and Rodgers Donaldson, 62, who had been vice pres ident and general counsel.

title: ROADWAY EXPRESS STEPS UP PROFITS
description: Roadway Express, Inc., re ported yesterday substantially larger revenues and earnings, in the 12 and 24 weeks ended June 19.

title: Colombo Undergoes Surgery; Still in a Coma After 10 Days
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was operated on for two hours at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday to ease a blockage of fluid that had built up in his skull. The hospital called the operation routine.

title: Agnew Reaches Kuwait On His 10Nation Tour
description: KUWAIT, July 6  Vice President Agnew brought his touring caravan to the Middle East today with a warning that there was not yet cause for undue optimism for peace in the Middle East despite rehewed United States efforts to achieve a settlement.

title: Top Armstrong Disks Over the Years Listed
description: Following is a selected Louis Armstrong discography.

title: SOLUTION SOUGHT ON CYPRUS TURKS
description: ATHENS, July 6Greek ef forts to speed a compromise solution of the longsmoldering Cyprus problem have drawn near blank, diplomatic sources here and in Ankara, Turkey, fear.

title: Worsen Charge Discrimination By Colleges on the Basis of Sex
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Women faculty members at major colleges and universities throughout the nation are bringing charges of sex dis crimination.

title: ITALY DENIES A CURB ON TEXTILE EXPORTS
description: ROME, July 6Italy's Minis try of Foreign Trade declared today that, contrary to local reports, Italy has not decided to limit the exporting of tex tiles to the United States but only footwear.

title: OREGON SLOOP OUT OF RACE TO HAWAII
description: SAN PEDRO, Calif., July 6 (UPI)Nimble, a 42foot sloop from Portland, Ore., was the first casualty of the 1971 trans Pacific yacht race today when she reported a crushed mast. The report was made in the daily roll call of the 69 sailing craft embarked on the 2,225 mile race from here to Hono lulu.

title: CITY IN MISSISSIPPI BARRED ON TESTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  A Federal district court has ruled that a desegregating school sys tem cannot impose testscore requirements on its teachers that reduce markedly the ratio of Negroes on its faculty.

title: Teleprompter Shifts Aide
description: Henry D. Pearson Jr., assist ant general manager of Tele prompter Manhattan Cable TV, has been named the coordina tor or the system's new public access channels. In his new post, Mr. Pearson will work with individuals and commu nity groups seeking access to the public channels in setting up time allocations for their broadcasts.

title: STORM BRINGS LULL TO WAR IN VIETNAM.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (Reuters)  Typhoon rans and wind struck Indochina to day, cutting back American air strikes. Military spokesmen re ported a comparative lull in ground fighting.

title: Captain's Gamble Aids Navy Addicts
description: SAN DIEGO, July 6Eight young sailors and marines who became heroin addicts in Viet nam will arrive here tomorrow to begin three months of in tensive treatment at the Navy's new West Coast drug rehabili tation center.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP)  The following servicemen from the New York area were identified by the Defense De partment today as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: JAMES F. GOULD
description: James F. Gould, coordinator of special projects for the Of fice of Public Information of the New York Urban Coalition, died Sunday while vacationing in the Barbados, W. I. He was 33 years old and lived at 470 West 24th Street.

title: Brokers Warned to Check On Unregistered Stock
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The Securities and Exchange Com mission warned brokers today that they have an obligation to investigate and make sure the securities laws are not being violated when they sell signifi cant amounts of unregistered securities.

title: NEWPORT COUNCIL WEIGHS FESTIVAL
description: A ground swell of financial support for the Newport Jazz Festival began to develop yesterday following the can cellation of the festival on Saturday. Damage caused when hundreds of young peo ple broke into Festival Field during the Saturday night concert was estimated by George Wein, producer of the festival, from $20,000 to $30,000. In addition, Mr. Wein has promised to refund money for all tickets sold for the Sunday and Monday con certs, a sum which he said would amount to approx imately $80,000.

title: WORTV TO PRESENT A SERIES IN SPANISH
description: In what is believed to be a New York first for a very high frequency television station, WORTV will present, begin ning July 19, a daily dramatic series in Spanish.

title: Ryun Last as Keino Runs Year's Top Mile in 3:54.4
description: STOCKHOLM, July 6 (UPI) Kipchoge Keino of Kenya won a mile race tonight in 3 minutes 54.4 seconds, the fastest time in the world this year. The American world recordholder, Jim Ryun, finished a distant last in the field of 10 runners. Keino led the three last laps, beating the runnerup, Ulf Hoeberg of Sweden, by 3.2 seconds.

Whelan, and the City Coun cil President, Thomas M. Fla herty, two of the eight men convicted in Federal court on Monday on extortionconspir acy charges. They are Specialist 4 Steve R. Joiner of Tucson, Ariz.; Pfc. James A. Forehand of New York City, and Pfc. Richard M. Scotto of New burg, N.Y.

title: RECORD SET FOR MAY BY TEXTILE IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) Textile imports in May to taled 519 million square yards, a record for the month but 2 per cent below April's level, the Commerce Department report ed today.

title: A REPORTER WINS RIGHT TO APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  A Federal district judge granted Washington newsman today the right to appeal a ruling that would require him to name news source in a $10million libel suit or face a possible summary judgment and punish ment for contempt of court.

description: Although aspirin is probably the most widely used of all drugs, its mode of action with in the body has defied satis factory explanation for genera tions. Now, however, British researchers believe they have found the answer.

title: Sports of The Times
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 7With treecovered Slate Hill looming over the backstretch and church steeples rising high behind the minigrandstand, Historic Track transports itself back in time this week to celebrate 100 years of Grand Circuit harness racing. Sixty miles beyond the hill, where the Lenape Indians once lived, is New York City, where, for this insulated track, OTB is a fourletter word and where the rumblings of another harness scandal are being heard.

title: chess: Fischer a Good Bet to Beat Larsen, but by What Score?

description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) The Head Start program for needy preschool children will start charging middleincome parents next Sept. 1 whose children have been enrolled for socioeconomic diversity.

title: Cross-Country Ride and a Chase in Spain
description: In the hearts of many Americans, I suspect, faith in God is a lot less important, less immediate and even less mystical than faith in the internal combustion engine. It's no wonder. The internal combustion engine, especially when it is placed in an automobile, is something that can be touched, tinkered with, modified, souped up and, when necessary, dismantled, as well as worshiped as the means by which a man makes his way through life.When your destination is without meaning, your style must be expressed through transportation, according to the wisdom of the contemporaries. Thus, nothing becomes modern man as much as the wheels in which he makes his arrivals and departures.In Monte Hellman's new film, "Two-Lane Blacktop," which opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater, the godhead is the crankcase of a 454-cubic-inch, high-performance '55 Chevy with aluminum heads, the car through which two young men, identified only as The Driver (James Taylor) and The Mechanic (Dennis Wilson), realize their destinies in a series of drag races in Esso country, across blacktop space and through stop-watch time.If my description so far sounds heavily metaphoric, it's because "Two-Lane Blacktop" looks very much like the sort of movie that was conceived as a metaphor and, only after some difficult labor pains, given form as a literal narrative. Ordinarily, it's the sort of movie I find easy to resist; since I prefer metaphors that, like friends, reveal themselves in the natural order of events, without proclamations."Two-Lane Blacktop," however, is a remarkably engaging movie, mostly in spite of, rather than because of, its metaphorical aspirations. All of which was most surprising to me after having plowed through the screenplay, by Rudolph Wurlitzer and Will Corry, which Esquire published last April and, with a certain reckless optimism, described as its "nomination for the movie of the year," even though there were still eight months to go.Monte Hellman, its 40-year-old director, has for some years enjoyed an underground reputation as the man who made not only "Beast from Haunted Cave," for Roger Corman's atelier, but also two low-budget Westerns, "The Shooting'' and "Ride the Whirlwind," which received few, if any, theatrical dates in this country and yet were acclaimed in France as two of the most exciting, most objective, most nihilistic American films in years.On the basis of "The Shooting," which I once saw on television," and "Two-Lane Blacktop," it seems to me that Hellman's reputation may well be deserved, but for reasons that have not so much to do with his apparent fondness for elliptical, draw-your-own-conclusion narratives as for his humor, his appreciation of action as the caw material of film narrative and for a fine discipline of technique. All of these have helped to transform a sometimes pretentious screenplay into a real movie.Most of "Two-Lane Blacktop" has to do with a cross-country race, from New Mexico to Washington, D.C., undertaken by The Driver and The Mechanic, accompanied by a teen-age hitchhiker, The Girl (Laurie Bird), in the back seat, with a fancy, 1970 Pontiac G.T.O., driven by a dapper, 30ish psycho known only as G.T.O. (Warren Oates). Each one of the characters is obviously damned, in one way or another, in his passage through the American landscape. The Driver and The Mechanic can relate, ultimately, only to their car; G.T.O. to the fantasies of what he once was (a TV producer, a dutiful son, a test pilot, or all or none of these things), and The Girl only to momentary fulfillment with whomever she happens to be.The movie, however, deals in specific encounters, in individual races, in meetings in roadside hamburger stands and tanktown bars, most of which vividly catch the tempo and rhythm of American life in much the same way that good rock does, even when the actual lyrics are fruity, or unintelligible.Perhaps because his role is the only one that suggests a past, Oates is the most interesting person in the film, a driving, driven middle-aged man, his handsome face beginning to collapse, who keeps talking about the need to settle down if he isn't to go into orbit, though he clearly already is in orbit and out of control. James Taylor, the recording star, and Dennis Wilson (of the Beach Boys) may or may not be actors, but they have the proper cool for contemporary mythic characters, and they look so much alike that I can't believe it's an accident. They are the two faces of the same man. Miss Bird's Girl, looking like a young, vulnerable Mimsy Farmer, is a lost seed that somehow grew."Two-Lane Blacktop" is a far from perfect film (those metaphors keep blocking the road), but it has been directed, acted, photographed and scored (underscored, happily) with the restraint and control of an aware, mature filmmaker.
