title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Richard Fleischer's "The Last Run," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is a rather straight, often solemn chase movie that somehow needs the Marx Brothers. Lacking them, and having instead George C. Scott, Tony Musante, Trish Van Devere, and Colleen Dewhurst, it stumbles along with determination, I guess, but some deathless lines and very possible situations are wastefully thrown away."You were veryardent," says a soulful, heavily Latinate Miss Dewhurst, the local prostitute of a little Mediterranean fishing village, to Mr. Scott, an American expatriate and her current customer. Though I suspect the begining of some kind of family joke, Mr. Scott comes back with nothing worth repeating. But you can imagine a Rufus T. Firefly given that line for openers.And later, when he is explaining the sadness of his life to Miss Van Devere  the moll of the gunman he is helping to escape the police and everyone else  and she asks where his wife is, Scott answers, "I don't know. Right after our son died she went to Switzerland to have her breasts lifted. I thought she meant by surgery. She never came back."With only the slightest change in delivery it might have been Otis B. Driftwood playing for sympathy in the mighty heart of Mrs. Clay-pool, but George C. Scott plays for nothing except for Richard Fleischer, whose comic gift has never run wild and who here is striving for a kind of Hemingwayesque elemental truth amid the sun-drenched walls and deep interior shadows of an endlessly picturesque Spain.Facing that truth is one Harry Garmes, ex-get-away-man who comes out of retirement to drive a hood to safety  that turns out to be a trap from which the real escape must be made. Harry has been nine years away from the business, and he mostly wants to test himself (much talk about alternate ways of dying), but the hood calls him "uncle" and the hood's girl sometimes acts like his niece, and the test proves a little inconclusivethough I'd say he passes.Despite the profundities of the dialogue, "The Last Run" is a decent enough project that has been rendered ludicrous in its intimacies and dull in its excitements more by directorial misjudgment than by any necessity in the screenplay. Fleischer, a veteran of more than 20 years in the business ("Dr. Dolittle," "Tora! Tora! Tora!," etc.) seems not yet to have mastered the reaction shot; and his automobile chase sequences, for all the billowing dust and squealing tires, seem to move at 30 miles an hour.I happen to admire all the cast, but from other movies. Groucho, Harpo and Chico might have triumphed over Fleischer, but Scott, Musante and Miss Van Devere do not.

title: Public (Be Damned) Television
description: These are the three insistent facts:  Never before as now, in these days of world complexities, of swift events and swifter reactions, of doubts about democracy itself, has it been more urgent that public opinion in the nation be informed.

title: New Hampshire Votes Earlier Primary Date
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 7 The New Hampshire legisla ture completed today its ap proval of a bill advancing the state's Presidential prefer ence primary from the sec ond Tuesday in March to the first Tuesday in March. Thus, the 1972 primary would be held March 7.

title: Advertising:
description: In a sudden surge of ap preciation, the Leo Burnett Company, No. 1 in Chicago, has raised six associate cre ative directors to the honored rank of creative director. They are Jim Black, Bruce Kellett, Al Lerman, Al Sam uelson, Mitch Seltzer and Jim Shyinkus. One is an art di rector; all the rest are copy writers.

title: Choosing Vice Presidents
description: Among the less publicized recommendations of the commission for reforming the Democratic party's con vention rules is one bearing on the nomination of the Vice Presidentan item of convention business that is too often treated by the delegates as a seriocomic after thought.

title: EDWARD CALHOUN, L. I. SURGEON, 62
description: Dr. Edward J. Calhoun, a Naisau County surgeon, died of cancer yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 2 Shore View Road, Port Washington,

title: Trevino Shares Lead in Golf
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 7  Lee Trevino was among the four leaders today, but the story of opening day in this 100th British Open was that Jack Nicklaus blew it at the finish.

title: Rockefeller Sees a Halt to All State Highway Work Without New Bond Issue
description: ALBANY, July 7Governor Rockefeller said today that the state would not be able to meet its current and future trans portation needs if the voters did not approve a $25billion transportation bond issue in a referendum in November.

title: AUSSIE DEFEATS KEINO IN 5,000 RUN
description: STOCKHOLM, July 7 (UPI) Tony Benson, the new Aus tralian running star, beat Kip choge Keino of Kenya in the 5,000meter run tonight during the second day of the July Track and Field Games.

title: Which China at the U.N.?
description: Such a regime [as that in Peking] is dearly unChinese in character and unChinese in purpose. How can such a regime represent the great Chinese people in the United Nations? How can such a regime speak in the name of the Chinese people and give expres sion to their true interests and aspira tions.

title: Castro Reports New Case
description: HAVANA, July 7 (Reuters) Premier Fidel Castro said today that Cuba was investigating the case of two Americans whose plane landed in Cuba in sus picious circumstances.

title: Nation's Energy Crisis: Is Unbridled Growth indispensable to the Good Life?
description: This is the last of three or tides on the national energy crisis produced by the conflict between the need for more power and the desire to save the environment.

title: Lorin Hollander Plays Outdoor Recital in Harlem
description: In certain small ways, it was exactly like a concert at Lincoln Center. A fountain.  or rather a playground sprinkler  plashed sooth ingly. The program was filled with familiar names: Grana dos, Chopin, Albniz, Scar latti, Ravel, Prokofiev. The acoustics were controversial, to say the most.

title: Article 7  No Title
Antimony Prices Reduced
description: N.L. Industries, Inc., former ly known as the National Lead Company, said yesterday that it had reduced prices by 11 cents a pound of RMM brand antimony metal, to 57 cents a pound in carload lots f.o.b. Laredo, Tex. Antimony is used in lead alloys.

title: Pants Issued on Oil Cleanup
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Coast Guard announced today that it had awarded three contracts to develop systems to clean up oil spills on the seas. They totaled $637,632 and went to Ocean Systems, Inc., of Res ton, Va.; the Lockheed Missile and Space Company, of Sunny vale, Calif., and the Martin Marietta Corporation, of Denver.

title: Published Phone Number For Police Was in Error
description: An article in The New York Times on Tuesday dealing with the demise of the Police Department's house organ, Spring 3100, erroneously listed the telephone number of Police Headquarters as Spring 73100.

title: BODY OF ARMSTRONG TO BE ON VIEW TODAY
description: The body of Louis Armstrong will be on public, view in the Seventh Infantry Armory today at 66th Street and Park Avenue.

title: Reston Enters China
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, July 8 (AP)James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times, left here today for a visit to mainland China that is likely to last about three weeks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: The CNA Financial Corporation announced yes terday in Chicago the appointment of Elmer L. Nicholson, 52 years old, as chairman, president and chief executive officer of the insurance holding com pany. Mr. Nicholson, who succeeds Howard Reeder, resigned early yesterday from his post as president of the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia. Mr. Reeder, 65 years old, is expected to assume the new title of chairman of the executive committee on Sept. 10. In another change, David G, Scott, executive vice president and director of CNA, resigned from the company for personal reasons.

title: Al Capp Wins a Delay
description: BOSTON, July 7 (UPI)Ex tradition proceedings against Al Capp, 61 years old, creater of the Li'l Abner comic strip, to face morals Charges in Wis consin were put off today un til Sept. 28. Municipal Judge Elijah Adlow continued the case to allow time for a hearing that must be held by Attorney General Robert H. Quinn be fore Gov. Francis W. Sargent can act.

title: SENATE APPROVES A SPECIAL AGENCY TO COMBAT CANCER
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The Senate approved today, 79 to 1, a bill to establish a special agency for a massive research attack on cancer.

title: Rich and Royal Children Mix With Poor at Unusual British School
description: STREET, England, July 1 in the classrooms of the Mill field School, the sons of Welsh miners and gardeners sit beside the children of Arab rulers. At midday, stu dents swarm toward the elm shaded 48acre campus's playing fields  children of film stars and truck drivers, shop clerks and millionaires, children who are emotionally disturbed and some who are neargeniuses.

title: Soviet Shifts Salyut Orbit
description: BOCHUM, West Germany, July 7 (UPI)The Soviet Union's orbiting space station, Salyut 1, has undergone course change, apparently to prevent it being burned up in the earth's atmosphere, the In stitute for Space Studies said today. It said the change tended to bear out predictions that manned Soviet space sta tion experiments will continue.

title: H. & M. Is Ordered to Pay Some Liquidating Dividend
description: Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan ordered yesterday the prompt payment of a partial cash liquidating dividend of $40,998,923.71 to the stockhold ers of the Hudson & Manhattan Corporation.

title: Lindsay Urges Lawyer Activism in A.B.A. Talk
description: Mayor Lindsay urged yester day an activism by lawyers that appeared to contrast with the expressed views of Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, who sat frowning at the Mayor's left as he spoke.

title: 3 Alcoa Smelters To Cut Production
description: The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would cut production, effective July 15, at three of its smelters.

title: A.U.S. Missionary Couple Slain in Dominican Republic
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, July 7 (UPI) Two American Baptist mission aries, Paul Potter, 39 years old, and his wife, Nancy, 36, of Marshfield, Mo., were found slain today in their home in Santiago, 110 miles north of here, the national police re ported.

title: SENATE BILL AIDS RURAL INDUSTRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  Congress was presented today with a plan designed to reverse the trend of immigration of the rural poor to bigcity slums and to attract industry to rural areas.

title: A DIVERSE GROUP FIGHTS TAX BREAK
description: WASHINGTON, July 7A diverse group of plaintiffs, in cluding Ralph Nader, a member of Congress, the auto workers' union and a real estate devel oper, brought suit today in an effort to force the Treasury Department to withdraw its new regulations that would save business more than $3bil lion annually in taxes.

title: UPSTATE CONCERT ERUPTS IN MELEE
description: JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Thurs day, July 8Disturbances fol lowing a rock music concert continued here early this morn ing as the police reported the arrest of seven persons, and firemen fought a blaze at a wholesale store in town.

title: Domestic Help to Get $1.85 Pay Guarantee
description: ALBANY, July 7 (UPI)  An estimated total of 100,000 domestic workers will come under the state's $1.85an hour minimum wage law next Jan. 15.

title: Pete Seeger Packs First Folk Concert At the Metropolitan
description: The buoyant collage of mu sic, history, satire, philosophy and politics known as a Pete Seeger concert made a smash hit of the first folk event ever held at the Metropolitan Mu seum.

title: Yevtushenko Urges End Of Political Taboos in Art
description: MOSCOW, July 7  Yevgeny Yevtushenko, proclaiming that the Stalin days must never re turn to Soviet society, has called for more open discussion and an end to forbidden themes in literature.

title: James Ira Keller Jr. Dies at 70; Former Haskins & Sells Partner
description: WAYNESVILLE, N. C., July 7  James Ira Keller Jr., a retired partner in the interna tional public accounting firm of Haskins & Sells and an early force in educational television, died today at his summer home, here. He was 70 years old and lived also in Coral Gables, Fia.

title: Bonn Official in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, July 7 (AP)For eign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany arrived in Is rael today for talks with lead ers, who have expressed con cern over Bonn's Middle East diplomacy. Mr. Scheel is the first West German foreign min ister to visit here since diplo matic relations were estab lished in 1965.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. EDWARD SEIDMON
description: PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 7 Dr. Edward E. Seidmon, pres ident since 1966 of the Board of Health here, died yesterday in Muhlenberg Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 905 Charlotte Street.

title: Vietnamizing the Peace
description: The statement of a highranking North Vietnamese in Paris that the latest Communist proposal on war prison ers and withdrawal is not dependent on a political settle ment in South Vietnam removes a major obstacle to serious negotiations. The peace plan was not clear on this point when it was introduced by the Vietcong dele gate last week. By suggesting that political questions could be discussed with the Saigon Government after the American withdrawal, the Communists in effect have proposed to Vietnamize the peace.

title: Tennis Federation Bans Contract Pros
description: STRESA, Italy, July 7 (Reu ters)  The International Lawn Tennis Federation imposed its expected ban on the Dallas based World Championship Tennis professional group today.

title: A Crowd Protests Slaying by Police In Brooklyn Area
description: An angry crowd of more than 200 people gathered outside the Bergen Street precinct in Brook lyn last night and early today to demonstrate against what they said was police brutality following the fatal shooting of a 22yearold man by a plain clothes man earlier in the day.

title: Macon Mayor Led Assault Armed With Machine Gun
description: MACON, Ga., July 7 (UPI) In an effort to provide leader ship, Mayor Ronnie Thompson, armed with a submachine gun, led an assault against a sus pected sniper's nest during ra cial unrest last week, it was revealed today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Forger's Signed Works Shown
description: Undaunted by several pris on sentences, David Stein, whose skill as a forger of paintings helped him to un load hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of master pieces, is still plying his brush. A show of his latest works opened last evening at the WrightHepburnWebster Gallery here, and, as before, they bear a striking resem blance to canvases by Picas so, Chagall, Miro and Ma tisse.

title: EARNINGS DECLINE FOR J. P. MORGAN
description: J. P. Morgan & Co,, Inc., which owns the Morgan. Guar anty Trust Company, reported yesterday a 4.6 per cent decline in earnings before security transactions in the second quarter.

title: 13 of 17 Detained Americans Leave Cuba Aboard 2 Boats
description: MIAMI, July 7 (AP)  Four Cuban fishermen released from a United States prison headed home today while 13 Americans held by the Havana Govern ment left Cuba abroad a pri vate yacht and tugboat.

title: Use of Private Patrolmen On City Streets Increasing
description: A hapless subway purse snatcher picked the wrong street on which to seek ref uge the other night.

title: A MexicanCuban Accord On Air Service Reported
description: MEXICO CITY, July 7Mex ico and Cuba have reached pre liminary agreement to continue flights between their capitals for at least another year after their current air treaty expires at the end of this month, sourc es close to the Cuban Embassy said today.

title: H. George Richardson, 70, ExGeneral Cable Officer
description: RYE, N. Y., July 7  H. George Richardson, a retired vice president of the General Cable Corporation, died yes terday at United Hospital, Port Chester, after a brief illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 53 Beverly Drive.

title: Macmillan Wins Award From Bar Association
description: The Macmillan Company, book publishers, was among 19 win ners of the 1971 Gavel Awards conferred yesterday by the American Bar Association for outstanding published, broad cast and filmed contributions to public understanding of the American system of law and justice.

title: From Good Guy to Bad In One Easy Mistake
description: TRENTON, July 7As a favor to a state trooper friend, an assistant counsel to Gov. William T. Cahill agreed to take part in a po lice lineup today.

title: Vietcong Battle in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Thurs day, July 8 (Reuters)A group of Vietcong troops from Cam bodia entered Thailand's north eastern Surin Province yester day and, wounded five border patrol policemen in a clash, informed sources said today. The sources said the Vietcong were about 500 yards inside Thaiterritory when they opened fire on a 10man police patrol.

title: Board to Give Hoffa  A Parole Rehearing
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  The United States Board of Parole agreed today on the basis of new and substantial information to rehear the parole request of James R. Hoffa, the imprisoned former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Jury Gets Extortion Case
description: BUTTE, Mont., July 7 (AP) Jury deliberation began today In the Federal case against Edward G. Partin, a Louisiana teamsters union official ac cused of extortion to gain con trol of the concrete business in Baton Rouge. The defendant, who testified for the Govern ment in the jurytampering conviction of James R. Hoffa, former president of the union, was brought to trial here after his attorneys gained a change of venue.

title: GENERAL PHONE SEES RECORD NET
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation expects its net income for this year to be the highest in its history with share earnings running in the range of 15 to 20 per cent over 1970, Leslie H. Warner, chairman and president, told a luncheon meeting yesterday of the New York Society of Se curity Analysts.

title: Courage in Connecticut
description: The legislature in Connecticut has shown commend able economic and political courage in adopting a pro gressive income tax, as the solution to the state's fiscal problem. Normally, a state looks to its Governor for leadership on a difficult issue of this kind But Gov. Thomas J. Meskill, a newly elected Republican, has been running away from the problem since January.

title: Old Law Is Used to Rid Harbor of Debris
description: The Army Corps of Engi neers and United States At torneys here are using an old law in a new joint ap proach to keep the owners of derelict vessels and rot ting piers from adding to the accumulation of debris that chokes New York Harbor.

title: RCA Profit Rises by 64%
description: The RCA Corporation real ized a 64 per cent increase in secondquarter earnings, bring ing net for the half 15.8 per cent ahead of last year.

title: Liguori Sets 2,000 Mark
description: LOUVAIN, Belgium, July 7 (UPI)Marty Liguori of Cedar Grove, N. J., set an American record for the 2,000 meters during an international track and field meet today.

title: Article 6  No Title
$125,000 for Fitzsimmons
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 7 (UPI)  Delegates at the Teamsters Union convention today gave their president, Frank E. Fitz simmons, a $25,000 raise, in creasing his salary to $125,000 a year.

title: LEONARD M. FOWLE, A YACHTING WRITER
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 7 Leonard M. Fowle, a writer on yachting, died of a heart attack at his home on Saturday. He was 67 years old and lived at 36 Norman Street.

title: Airline Plans Warrants
description: Eastern Air Lines confirmed yesterday that as part of an agreement under which the Equitable Life Assurance So ciety has agreed to a renego tiation of a $71,750,000 note offering, it is issuing to the insurance company 467,200 of detachable stockpurchase war rants to Equitable. The war rants entitle Equitable to pur Chase additional common stock at $15.625 a share until Dec. 31, 1982.

title: Yanks Win, 53, With 2 in 11th
description: DETROIT, July 8The New York Yankees, unable to win in three previous outings al though averaging 13 hits, de feated the Detroit Tigers, 53, tonight with a 15hit barrage in 11 innings.

title: STEEL TALKS OPEN; PACT ENDS AUG. 1
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  Steel union and management negotiators sat down to the task of hammering out a con tract settlement today without comment on yesterday's exhor tation by President Nixon.

title: NEW NAME AND WORK SOUGHT FOR AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP)  Attorney General John N. Mitchell sent to Congress today legislation to rename the Sub versive Activities Control Board and give it some work.

title: House Panel Backs A Plan to Tighten Election Spending
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  A campaign spending bill twice as restrictive as the measure now awaiting Senate floor ac tion was approved today by the House Communication Sub committee, over Republican op position.

title: House Votes Tight Curbs On Mailing of Sex Material
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Tight curbs on the mailing of sexoriented material to homes and an effort to modify the Supreme Court's obscenity definition by act of Congresswere approved by the House today, 356 to 25.

title: Article 13  No Title
Boston Leather Concern Obtains Corfam Rights
description: George Newman & Co., a Boston leather supply concern, said yesterday that it had pur chased the remaining inventory of Corfam and has been granted a license to use the name from E.I. duPont de Nemours de Co., Inc. for about $6million.

title: Roundup: Astros Looking for Room at Top in West
description: Setting a club record for runs scored in a single game, the Houston Astros bluntly intruded themselves into the National League's Western Division pennant race yester day with a rousing 184 tri umph over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Construction Din Greeted With a Shrug
description: To the passerby, the whine of power saws the clatter of bolttighteners and the roar of compressors and earthmovers at the construction site on the Avenue of the Americas be tween 45th and 46th Streets adds up to quite a racket.

title: Newport Festival Canceled
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 7 (AP) The Newport City Council tonight canceled the license for a folk music festival scheduled for July 1618. The vote was 52.

title: C.I.A. Aides Reported Leading Commando Raids in North Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 7 A secret operation involving commando raiders, some led by employes of the Central Intel ligence Agency, is reported un der way against the Com munistheld Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos.

title: Bolivia Yields to LeftWing Pressure
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 4  After seven months of frenzied nationalism, Bolivia's weak left wing Government has achieved neither political popularity nor economic stability.

title: U.S. Will Seek Clarification Of Communist Peace Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (Reu ters)United States officials today stressed a need for fur ther clarification of the new Communist peace plan for Viet nam, and said that a formal American response would there fore be withheld in Paris to morrow.

title: JOSEPH JOSEPHSON
description: BORDENTOWN, N.J., July 7 Joseph Josephson, president of the Jersey Maid Dairy, which sells milk and milk products wholesale in the central New Jersey area, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 87 years old and lived at 11 East Union Street.

title: CITY PLANS DRIVE ON PROSTITUTION
description: Mayor Lindsay announced plans yesterday for a crack down on prostitution and pornography in midManhattan to eliminate the abuses that have tarnished its character.

title: RECORD INTEREST OF 7.578% CHARGED CITY ON BOND SALE
description: The city was forced yester day to pay the highest interest rate in its history to sell record $357.1million of its bonds.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: NEWPORT, Wales, July 7 (UPI)Ken Rosewall of Aus tralia won hip thirdround match in the Welsh open tennis championships today, beating Terry Ryan of South Africa, 64, 63.

title: Article 10  No Title
Kissinger Is Not Planning To See Hanoi Aide in Paris
description: NEW DELHI, July 7 (AP) Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, said today he had no plans to meet Le Duc Tho, a member of the North Vietnam ese Politburo in Paris this weekend.

title: Drive Mounted to Get Funding for Health Council
description: Some of the leading figures in the city's medical establish ment joined yesterday in an 11thhour drive to restore pub lic financing of the Health Re search Council.

title: CITY'S BONDS SOLD AT A RECORD COST
description: New York City's big $357.1 million bond issuesold at a record borrowing cost and of fered to investors at taxfree yields as high as 7.80 per cent moved out fast yesterday and acted as a psychological prop for the entire municipal bond market.

title: SMITH ADVANCES TO QUARTERFINAL
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 7 (UPI)  Stah Smith of Pasa dena, Calif., the runnerup at Wimbledon, gained the quarter finals of the $33,000 Swedish open tennis championship today by beating Tenny Svensson of Sweden, 64, 36, 75, 60.

title: A Saigon General Named As a Trafficker in Heroin
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  A highranking South Vietnamese general was named by a mem ber of Congress before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today as one of the chief traf fickers in heroin in Southeast Asia.

title: Loan Set to Iran Airline
description: The ExportImport Bank and the Chase Manhatttan Bank of New York said yesterday they would lend about $14.1million to Iran's national airline for its purchase of three Boeing 737 200 mediumrange jets.

title: Dissidents at I.O.S. Ask a Court to Find Fund in Contempt
description: TORONTO, July 7  A group of former I.O.S., Ltd., employes who tried to win control of the Genevabased financial company last week at its an nual meeting accused the man agement today, of voting cer tain shares in violation of a court order, according to sources close to the insurgents.

title: Patman Warns U.S. May Check Gambling Disease in the States
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  New. York's lottery and off track betting enterprises were attacked today by the chair man of the House. Banking and Currency Committee, who sug gested the Congress might con sider Controlling or stopping some of these more outland ish schemes to raise public monies through gambling.

title: UNDERWORLD LINKED TO TRUCK HIJACKINGS
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Organized crime is playing an increasing role in truck hijack ings, Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today.

title: Baseball's Front Door Opens to Satchel Paige
description: Satchel Paige was given full membership yesterday in the Baseball Hall of Fame instead of being honored in a separate niche reserved for players of the old Negro leagues.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading shareholders, directors and officers of its listed companies.

title: $15MILLION ASKED IN LUNCH PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, July 7Forty Senators urged the Nixon Ad ministration today to release immediately at least $15million in additional funds they, said was promised to cities for sum mer free lunch programs.

title: Article 14  No Title
Big Allis Shut Down Again; Power Here Cut 5 Per Cent
description: Big Allis, Consolidated Edi son's troublehaunted million kilowatt generator, shut itself down yesterday afternoon, prompting a 5 per cent voltage reduction throughout the city and Westchester County and raising fears of a new cycle of powers cutbacks.

title: AMEX PRICES GAIN AS VOLUME RISES
description: In accelerated trading, prices on the American Stock Ex change rose yesterday.

title: Katrina Dyke Wed to a Physician
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 7  Miss Katrina Ryerson Dyke and Dr. Wesley Brocklenbank Mason were married here this morning at the Belmont Plateau in West Fairmount Park.

title: STATE ENFORCING RELIEF RESIDENCY
description: The first welfare applicants ineligible for relief under the new state law requiring one year's residency are being re turned from New York State to their home areas.

title: Cooper Acts to Force C.I.A. to Report to Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  John Sherman Cooper of Ken tucky, one of the most in fluential Senators on foreign policy matters, introduced legislation today that would require the Central Intelligence Agency to give detailed intelli gence information to Congress regularly.

title: N.A. Rockwell Gets Contract
description: The North American Rock well Corporation yesterday re ceived a $67million Air Force contract for production of guidance and control system for Minuteman 111 missiles.

title: Mrs. Foulk Retains Lead In Syce Cup Title Sailing
G.E. Earnings Set Mark;
description: The General Electric Com pany recorded sales and earn ings in the three and six months ended June 30, the giant elec tricalelectronic producer re ported yesterday.

title: Rumania Combats Western Influences
description: VIENNA, July 7 (Reuters)  President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today, called for a war on bourgeois influences in Rumanian life.

title: Article 5  No Title
Macrobiotic Cooking  Learning the Secrets of Yang and Yin
description: My name is Cornelia Aihara, from San Francisco. I have lost my voice. It will come back. Please be quiet.

title: Sales of Autos Steady for June
description: DETROIT, July 7The United States is, halfway home to its first 10millioncar year, the auto sales figures for the first six months show. The automo bile manufacturers of Detroit had predicted a 10millioncar year last fall, but the general reaction was skeptical.

title: Cleaning Up Midtown
description: Not since the Jimmy Walker era forty years agoand perhaps not even thenhas New York City appeared as wideopen to resident and casual visitor alike as does today. In certain sections of the central city every form and variety of human degradation seems to flourish openly on the sidewalk and not too secretly behind cur tains off the street. Pimps, pushers, prostitutes and por nography are everywhere; no sensual appetite need remain unsatisfied nor any depraved taste untested this midtown perversion of Fun City.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Excellent catches of blue fish are being made all along the East Coast from Cape Hatteras to Cape Cod, for those who seek this hard fighting species.

title: HARVARD TO DROP I.B.M.AIDED STUDY
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 7 The Harvard University Pro gram on Technology and So ciety, a widely publicized, $5 million inquiry into the impact that technology has upon socie ty, is being terminated. Sup ported by the International Business Machines Corporation, the program began in 1964 and was to lave lasted 10 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RevenueSharing Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The House Ways and Means Com mittee began deliberations to day on various proposals to give additional Federal financial assistance to states and local governments. Much of the half day committee session on re venue sharing was devoted to a discussion of the budget officials.

title: Market Place: A New Debate For Big Board
description: Controversy is no stran ger to the New York Stock Exchange, so it comes as no surprise that another major debate is simmering behind the placid granite faade surrounding the structure at 11 Wall Street.

title: Sadat Sees Decisive Year
description: CAIRO, July 7  President Sadat warned in a speech to day that 1971 would be de cisive in the Arab conflict with Israel, as two United States diplomats pursued a secrecy shrouded mission here to seek a formula for reopening the Suez Canal.

title: Court of Appeals Upholds Lawyer on Cutting Support
description: ALBANY, July 7 (AP)The Court of Appeals ruled unani mously today in favor of a New York lawyer who cut off support for his collegestudent daughter when she adopted a style of life he disapproved of.

title: Recalculation to Let City Schools Retain About 480 Positions
description: A recalculation by the Board of Education will give an ad ditional $3,335,000 allocation to the city's financially pressed decentralized school districts, school officials disclosed yester day.

title: Rocket Attack in Israel Kills Two
description: TEL AVIV, July 7  A woman and a fiveyearold girl were killed tonight when Petah Tiqvah was struck by Katyusha rockets, presuma bly launched by Arabs. Eighteen other persons were hospitalized, some of them suffering from shock, it was announced here.

title: Hats to Go With the Fashions for Fall
description: Many of the socalled ex perts in any field may well puzzle the average woman. Fashion editors are often un fashionable, beauty writers frequently ignore their own advice and, currently, two out of three millinery buyers are unhatted.

title: Maffei of Italy Captures World Fencing Gold Medal
description: VIENNA, Austria, July 7 (AP) Michele Maffei of Italy cap tured the gold medal in saber by winning four of five bouts in the roundrobin final at the World Fencing championship at the Stadthalle Arena today.

title: Bar Parley Rejects EndWar Resolution
description: Delegates to the American Bar Association closed their threeday convention here yesterday by voting not to urge the Government to withdraw from Vietnam as soon as phys ically and logistically possible.

title: Wallace and Humphrey To Discuss Rural U.S.
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 7 (AP)Gov. George C. Wal lace and Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Min nesota, opponents in the 1968 Presidential campaign, will meet here tomorrow to talk about problems of rural America.

title: DaytonHudson Aide Leaves
description: The Dayton Hudson Corpora tion announced yesterday the resignation of Douglas J. Day ton as senior vice president. Mr. Dayton, who is resigning to pursue other interests, will remain a director of the store chain.

title: Another Moscow Draw
description: MOSCOW, July 8 (UPI) The semifinal match between Soviet chess masters Tigran Petrosian and Viktor Korchnoi ended in a draw today, leaving the challenger series here dead locked, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstate Man Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Capt, Larry R. Dewey of Weedsport, N.Y., of the Army, had been killed in action in Indochina.

title: Ford May Import Trucks From Japan
description: DETROIT, July 8The Ford Motor Company confirmed today that it is considering importing small Japanesemade trucks for sale in the United States and also announced a dividend increase. If Ford does import the trucks, it would mean that the com pany would cancel plans to build a similar small truck in this country, and would be another example of Detroit's manufacturers deciding that they aren't able to compete with the Japanese. The divi dend action raises the quar terly payout to 65 cents share from the 60 cents paid since December, 1965. The in creased dividend is payable Sept. 1 to stockholders of rec ord July 29.

title: C.I.A. Says Plan Seeks to Embarrass U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 The Central Intelligence Agency has told President Nixon that the new Vietcong peace proposal is aimed at embarrassing the United States both at home and overseas and encouraging the opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu in South Vietnam.

title: Banks Raise the Prime...
description: The nation's major banks have increased their prime lending rate from 5 per cent to 6 per cent. The move gives rise to concern that higher borrowing charges will hurt the business recovery, prolong unemployment and push up prices, since interest payments are a cost ele ment both to consumers and to businesses.

title: PHONE RATE RISES EFFECTIVE TODAY
description: The New York Telephone Company raised its rates at 12:01 A.M. today to reflect a $190million temporary increase approved July 1 by the State Public Service Commission.

title: PANASONIC FILES SUIT ON DUMPING
description: The Japanese manufacturer of Panasonic products said yes terday that it had filed a suit in the United States Customs Court to challenge recent ac tions by the Treasury Depart ment and the Tariff Commis sion under the Antidumping Act of 1971, involving televi sion receivers Imported from Japan.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LONDON, July 8 (AP)Brit ish officials today identified Anatoly N. Fedoseyev, a Rus sian who defected here six weeks ago, as a scientist who has done important research in electronics.

title: Yaged's Sextet Adds Its Touch A la Goodman
description: To a passerby, the sounds coming from Bryant Park yes terday shortly after noon sug gested that one of Benny Goodman's small groups was at work on the patio in front of the statue of William Cul len Bryant. As it turned out, it was not Mr. Goodman but, as is usually the case these days when the Goodman sound is heard live, Sol Yaged and his sextet.

title: U.S. ACTS TO CLARIFY VIEW ON ATOM ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The State Department today sought to dispel any suggestion that Japan might feel impelled to ac quire nuclear weapons.

title: IT'S LONDON NEXT FOR A.B.A. PARLEY
description: A flourishing American insti tution, the farflung business convention, is being carried to new heights this weekend as 5,300 lawyers and their families a total of 12,000 peoplede part for a round of educational, convivial and taxdeductible events in Europe.

title: Killings Baffle Wilmington, N.C.
description: WILMINGTON, N.C., July 8 Thte murder of two night se curity guards at a junior high school troubled by integration problems has left Wilming ton's police and other citizens bewildered.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Movies by Bayer and Rivette Begin Runs:Stage Troupe Tours in 'Mississippi Summer'
description: Meaning in movie titles goes as much by fashion as does anything else, and though most are merely inexpressive, those that aren't tend to carry connotations as much suggestive of their times as of themselves. Thus, in better and more innocent days, somebody about to see "Christmas in Connecticut" or "Home in Indiana" might at least have known what kind of film to expect. But I'd lay odds that almost anyone chancing on William Bayer's "Mississippi Summer" will assume a documentary on race relations. That would be wrong. It is a fiction film about race relations. And race relations all year long; there is a Christmas Party right in the middle of "Mississippi Summer."It concerns a troupe of actors, half black, half white, who in 1964 travel through Mississippi performing a voter-registration propaganda play in churches and barns before black rural audiences. At first, their leader, Michael, speaks noble words to them and they respond nobly. But gradually their audiences fall off and nobody wants to register anyway and the company begins to split, black and whiteuntil they part, the whites driving their car down one fork in the road, the blacks driving their bus down the other fork in the road, with Michael deposited in front of a stop sign at the intersection, without visible means of transportation.Symbolism at just this level typifies "Mississippi Summer," which also fails in dialogue, direction, editing and acting. I have heard lines delivered more feelingly in Army training films, where, indeed, I have also heard better lines. I believe it is the custom in treating films of this nature not to question anyone's sincerity and generously to allow for everyone's ineptitude. But Mr. Bayer's performances seem to have come out of first year drama school, and his ideas, out of a Waring blender, and if his exploration of a tragedy of our times is to be taken for real, then he succeeds only in giving sincerity a bad name."Mississippi Summer" was made with the help of a grant from the American Film Institute.

title: TWO IN LONDONDERRY KILLED BY SOLDIERS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 8  A man was fatally wounded in a Roman Catholic district of Londonderry today, the second shot and killed there by British soldiers in clashes with rioters since last night.

title: Day of Repentance Urged
description: DENVER, July 8 (AP)The Full Gospel Businessmen's Fel lowship International, an evan gelican organization of 150,000 businessmen, called on Presi dent Nixon and Congress to day to set a date for a uni versal day for fasting repen tance and prayer. The plea, made in a resolution, was adopted by some 5,000 dele gates attending the 18th an nual world convention of the groups.

title: Wallace Tells Humphrey at Hearing They May See Each Other in '72
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 8  While Hubert H. Hum phrey sat, staring grimly at the floor, George C. Wallace smilingly transformed a Sen ate hearing here today into campaign platform for 1972. Although the Alabama Gov ernor had been asked to testify on the problems of rural development, he chose instead to restate his 1968 Presidential campaign themes and offer a broad hint, as he has before, that he will be candidate again next year. Senator Humphrey, the Minnesota Democrat who is chairman of the subcommit tee holding the hearings, watched and listened from across a gleaming walnut table in the Alabama House of Representatives as Gover nor Wallace criticized the Su preme Court, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, busing, bureaucrats and superrich foundations. As the Governor ended his testimony he told Senator Humphrey that they might see each other again in 1972. Mr. Humphrey, who was the Democratic Presi dential candidate in 1968, smiled fleetingly. Of course, Governor, you meant that would be a strictly social oc casion, he said. The hearing today was part of a field trip by Senator Humphrey's Sub committee, the Agricultural Subcommittee on Rural De velopment. Another hearing is scheduled tomorrow in Georgia. Previously, the subcommittee had traveled to Iowa and South Dakota for similar meetings with state officials. But neither of those hearings attracted the attention focused on the en counter today between the two losers in the Presidential elec tion of 1968. The historic chambers of the Alabama House of Representatives, where in 1861 the state seceded from the Union, were jammed with partisan supporters of Governor Wallace and throngs of the curious.

title: Jones Plays Black President for TV Film
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 Early morning Washing tonbefore the office work ers take to the sidewalks. A light mist rises from the Po tomac. (NOTE TO JOE SAR GENT: CUE GOD).

title: Rotz Guides Patelin to OneLength Triumph in Sprint at Aqueduct
description: Patelin demonstrated a great improvement in getting away from the gate in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday, and this education enabled her to win the sixfurlong sprint by a length over I'm For Mama.

title: Phils to Raise Their Fence
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 8 ((UPI) The Philadelphia Phillies said today the National League had granted them permission to raise the eightfoot Veterans Stadium outfield fence to 12 feet on July 19.

title: SUFFOLK FREEZING JOBS ON WELFARE
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 8. An unexpected increase of 50 per cent in the Aid to Families With Dependent Children wel fare case load in Suffolk Coun ty for the last year has caused an $18.9million deficit in the county's welfare budget.

title: Hanoi Paper Says Morale Of Saigon Troops Is Failing
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 8 (Agence FrancePresse)The North Vietnamese Army news paper, Quan Doi Nhan Dan, said this week that the United States was desperately, but vainly, trying to halt the collapse in morale of the South Vietnamese Army.

title: Books of The Times
description: MY GALLERIES AND PAINTERS. By Daniel. Henry Kahnweller with Francis Crmieux. Translated from the French by Helen Weav er. With an introduction by John Russell. 160 pages. Viking Press. $8,50 hardcover. $4.25 paperback.

title: Fuel Barge Explodes After Crash in Canal
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., July 8 (AP)A burning fuel barge exploded in the Intracoastal Waterway today after collid ing with another barge about 40 miles southeast of Lake Charles. There were no re ports of injuries.

description: DETROIT, July 8.Bill Gil breth, a 23yearold Texan from Abilene, faced the New York Iankees for the first time to night and the southpaw had little difficulty.

title: U.S. Reply to Proposal of the Vietcong
description: PARIS, June 8Following is the text of the opening re marks made by David K. E. Bruce, head of the United States delegation, at the 120th session of the Vietnam peace talks here today:

title: $1Billion City Projects Approved in 3 Minutes
description: It took three minutes and 34 seconds yesterday for the city's. Board of Estimate to approve $1.6billion worth of city construction, virtually the entire capital budget for 197172.

title: College Nantes President
description: NORTH EASTON, Mass., July 8 (AP)The board of trustees of Stonehill College has ap pointed the Rev. Ernest J. Bar tell as its new president, effective Sept. 1, it was an nounced today. Father Bartell is director of the. Center for the Study of Man in Contemporary Society at the University of Notre Dame.

title: YALE GROUP SINGS SHEPHERD KING
description: NORFOLK, Conn., July 8 Shop around enough and sooner or later you might be able to hear all of Mozart's operas, not just the five mas terpieces. Last year the Cara moor Festival at Katonah, N. Y., staged Idomeneo. This past winter the Juilliard Amer ican Opera Center presented La Clemenza di Tito. Last night the Yale Summer School of Music here put on what was said to be the first full produc tion in America of Il Re Pas tore.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 8Therese Sullivan of Brooklyn defeated Diane Lie benson of Stamford, 63, 61, in the 16yearsold final of the Nassau girls' tennis champion ships today at the Port Wash ington Tennis Academy. Miss Sullivan advanced to the final by beating Ellen Ackerman of Purchase, N. Y., 63, 60, while Miss Liebenson defeated Nancy Thornton of Bronxville, 61, 61.

title: Plantings of Cotton Are Raised by 4%
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) Spurred by a Government drive to increase cotton pro duction, farmers have planted 12,398,600 acres this year, up 4 per cent from last year, the Agriculture Department re ported today.

title: Goldenson Out of Hospital
description: Leonard H. Goldenson, presi dent of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., the parent company of A.B.C. Television, was released from Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday where he had been recovering from a coronary oc clusion he suffered on May 29. A spokesman said Mr. Golden son was expected to be back at his A.B.C. office by Aug. 1.

title: Amex Prices Continue to Climb, While Turnover Shows a Drop
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to rise yes terday in slackened trading.

title: POWER FIOLDS UP ON HOTTEST DAY
description: While New Yorkers suffered through the hottest day of the year yesterday, the kind of day that ordinarily imposes the heaviest drain on electrical power, Consolidated Edison was able to meet the demand without voltage reductions, al though its biggest generator re mained disabled.

title: Police Agency to Monitor Courts and Prosecutors
description: The New York Police Department will start monitoring the performance of the district attorneys and the courts here in what it describes as an effort to improve control crime. The monitoring of the two other major branches of the system of criminal justice is one of a number of assign ments given the Criminal Justice Bureau, an agency established within the Police Department yesterday by Com missioner Patrick V. Murphy.

title: New Atomic Device Fired In U.S. Project to Tap Gas
description: MERCURY, Nev., July 8 The Atomic Energy Commis sion moved a step closer today to providing a commercial nu clear explosive service for the nation's natural gas producers.

title: Atoms Track Club Sets Mark in Women's 440 Relay
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 8  In relay races 10 minutes apart, the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn broke one national record and just missed another last night in the Amateur Ath letic Union national girls' championships.

title: Cash and Kaline of Tigers Are Added to American League AllStar Squad
description: BOSTON, July 8 (UP)The American League added a flock of .300 hitters today to the fan chosen starters for the 42d All Star game in Detroit next Tues day night.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe Japanese had been brought up on the theory that they were invincible. They had never been defeated in war. Now all their history books and schoolbooks must be re written in order to adjust history to facts. Are we Americans suffering from the same psychological superior ity complex that affected Japan in 1941?

title: Bettors at Pocono Downs Riot Over Skimpy Exacta
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., July 8 (UPI)The Pennsylvania Harness Racing Commission tried to find out today why an Otacta at Pocono Downs paid far less than usual and 200 bettors went on a ramp age that temporarily closed the track.

title: TWO TAIWANESE JUMP BAIL HERE
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice issued two arrest warrants for bailjumping yesterday for two Taiwanese convicted last May of attempting to murder theson of the President of Na tionalist China here.

description: Louis Armstrong, whose bril liant jazz trumpet and sand paper voice evoked standing, screaming ovations from mil lions of people throughout the world, received a moving, silent farewell yesterday from thou sands of mourning fans who filed by his open coffin at the, Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 66th Street.

title: Forsyte Saga Starts Run on Soviet TV
description: MOSCOW, July 8  Millions of Soviet television viewers to night got their first look at The Forsyte Saga, whose cast of selfassured British bour geois will be entertaining them all summer.

title: N.A.A.C.P. AIDES DIFFER WITH CHIEF
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 8An other and more critical view of the Nixon Administration's pos ture toward black Americans has emerged here at the annual convention of the National As sociation for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: An East Side Man Is Slain When He Interrupts Holdup
description: A 51yearold customer who walked into a holdup in an automobile renting office at First Avenue and 38th Street was shot dead yesterday by one of two gunmen.

title: Corn Blight Reaches State
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The Agriculture Department reports that the overall infec tion level of corn blight re mains light, although the po tentially costly disease has now spread to 581 countries in 28 states, including two new states, New York and New Jersey.

title: Six Foil Teams Advance In World Fencing Event
description: VIENNA, July 8 (AP)Teams froth the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary, France, West Ger many and Japan advanced to the quarterfinals of the works fencing championships' team foil competition today.

title: Fischer Defeats Larsen Again, Taking a Big Lead in Denver
description: DENVER, July 8  Bobby Fischer took a commanding lead today when he defeated Bent Larsen far the second straight time in their 10game match in Temple Buell College here.

title: Rosewell Gains in Wales
description: NEWPORT, Wales, July 8 (UPI) Topseeded Ken Rose wall of Australia dropped only six games today in moving in to the men's singles semifinals at the Welsh lawn tennis championships.

title: Air Force Captain Against the War
description: Man in the News

title: Indonesia Votes
description: To nobody's surprise, early returns from the Indo nesian national election show the Governmentbacked Sekber Golkar party taking a comfortable lead over the fragmented opposition. As one Westerner cynically com mented: This election is in the great democratic tradi tion of Taiwan and South Vietnam.

title: 7 POLICE INJURED IN BROOKLYN FIGHT
description: Seven persons were arrested and seven policemen were re ported injured in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn last night when Molotov cocktails, bot tles and stones were thrown by a member of a crowd of about 200 people protesting the killing of a young Puerto Rican by a policeman on Wednesday.

title: Illinois Suit Seeks to Claim Official's
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 8 (AP)The state of Illinois filed suit today seeking to claim the $3million to $4million estate of Secretary of State Paul Powell.

title: A.B.A. Unit of Young Lawyers Sees Threats to U.S. Liberties
description: A committee of the young lawyers section of the Ameri can Bar Association reported yesterday that there is cur rently an antilibertarian cli mate in the United States which properly can be labeled repressive.

title: Theodoros C. Coritoyannopoulos Marries Georgeanne Madouros
description: Miss Georgeanne Madou ros, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Panagiotis D. Madouros of Forest Hills, Queens, was married in Athens yesterday to Theodoros Christos Conto yannapoulos, son of Mrs. Christos T. Contoyannopou los of Athens and the late Mr. Contoyannopoulos. The ceremony was performed in the Greek Orthodox Cathe dral of Athens.

title: The Chicago Tribune
description: CHICAGOThirty years from now historians may be recounting the story of how The New York Times obtained and printed secret Pentagon docu ments describing the background of the war in Vietnam.

title: Most Times Square Prostitutes Staying Off Street to Avoid Arrest
description: There were fewer prostitutes in evidence in the Times Square area yesterday  following Mayor Lindsay's announcement that, once again, the city was moving to clear the area of prostitution and pornography.

title: Lummus to Build Plant
description: The Consumers Power Com pany announced yesterday the selection of the Lummus divi sion of Combustion Engineer ing, Inc., to design and build a $40million synthetic natural gas plant 40 miles northeast of Detroit.

title: GAINS EXTENDED IN STOCK TRADING
description: The stock market forged ahead yesterday In its third straight gain or a holiday shortened week.

title: MISTRIAL IS RULED IN TEAMSTER CASE
description: BUTTE, Mont., July 8. (AP) Federal Judge W. D. Murray de clared a mistrial today in the conspiracy trial of Edward G. Partin, a Louisiana teamster of fical, after the jury failed to reach a verdict.

title: FAMILY COURT JUDGE CHOSEN BY LIBERALS
description: The Liberal party announced yesterday its nomination of Family Court Judge Millard Midonick who is seeking a Manhattan surrogate post.

title: Eliot Feld Disbands His American Ballet
description: The American Ballet Com pany, which was formed two and a half years ago as the Brooklyn Academy of Music's resident ballet company, has been dissolved.

title: AFTRA DEMANDS 7 DISCLOSE EARNINGS
description: Howard Cosell and John Schubeck are among seven tele vision and radio personalities who may be asked to divulge their earnings during the 1967 strike at the American Broad casting Company if a union pe tition presented yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court is granted.

title: All 125 Grand Central Switches Ordered Inspected by the State
description: The State Department of Transportation ordered tests yesterday of all 125 switches in Grand Central Terminal as a result of the commutertrain derailment Wednesday that killed one person and injured 18 others.

title: BUDGET STIMULUS FOR U.S. ECONOMY EXCEEDING GOALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  Paul W. McCracken, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, told Con gress today that the Federal budget for the new fiscal year just begun was already $7billion more stimulative for the economy, in more spending and less revenues, than was planned in January.

title: G. M. to Sign July 16
description: TOKYO, July 8 (UPI)Isuzu Motors, one of Japan's smaller automobile companies, and the General Motors Corporation, the United States' largest, will sign a formal agreement July 16 on a capital tieup, it was an nounced today.

title: GILMOUR WINS 5 ON YONKERS CARD

With 16,441 fans on hand, the 38yearold reinsman tied the track record for most victories on a single card.

title: Stein Criticizes Meat Industry And Calls for More Inspectors
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, Democrat of Manhattan, proposed yesterday that more inspectors be hired by the city's Health Department and die State Agniculture Depart ment to insure adequate super vision of wholesale meat dis tributing and packing facilities.

title: UNION AMERICA ENDS HOLDINGUNIT ROLE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8 (Reu ters)Unionamerica, Inc., said today it will file a declaration to cease to be a bank holding company by Jan. 1, 1981.

title: A 64 GIVES LEAD TO EICHELBERGER
description: MILWAUKEE, July 8 (AP) Dave Eichelberger used deadly approaches and an unerring putter for a sevenunderpar 64 today as lie took a twostroke lead in the first round of the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: COLOMBO REMAINS ON THE CRITICAL LIST
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader, remained in critical condition and in a coma at Roosevelt Hospital, yesterday, 10 days after he was shot in the head shortly before an ItalianAmerican unity rally.

title: STUDENT, 25, FOUND SLAIN IN FLUSHING
description: A 25yearold podiatry stu dent was found dead in the. bathtub of Ms tworoom apart ment in Flushing, Queens, yes terday afternoon with his feet and hands tied behind his body.

title: COMMAND SETUP REVISED BY ARMY
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Defense Department announced today a worldwide reorganize tion of its command structure that will shift responsibility for the Middle East from the Strike Command at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida to the. European Command at Stuttgart, West Germany.

title: Jim Morrison, 25, Lead Singer With Doors Rock Group, Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, July, 8 (UPI) Jim Morrison, the 25yearold lead singer of The Doors rock group, died last Saturday, in Paris, his public relations firm said today. His death was attributed to natural causes, but details were withheld pend ing the return of Mr. Morrison's agent from France.

title: Nastase, Ruffels Advance
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 8 (AP)Nastase of Rumania won his secondround match to day in the International Grand Prix tennis tournament, but his countryman, Ion Tiriac, lost to Ray Ruffels of Australia.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES PLUNGE IN PRICE
description: Profit taking and liquidation, influenced by the weather, sent soybean futures prices down sharply yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Calling a man a clubhouse lawyer used to be putdown within the cozy confines of what was once called. the world of sport. But today, a truly qualified clubhouse lawyer would undoubtedly be named the most valuable player in his vicinity. Neither the average athlete nor the average fan is equipped to cut his way through the legal thickets that have sprung up on all sides.

title: Drug Aide Here Terms Nixon Program Too Little
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  A Senate panel considering legis lation on the prevention of drug abuse heard expert testi mony today that President Nixon's $155million program was too little and too late.

title: Teamsters Elect Fitzsimmons To Succeed Haifa as President
description: MIAMI BEACH; Fla., July 8 Frank E. Fitzsimmons was Unanimously elected today to a fiveyear term as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: CourtMartial Opens in Britain Of Officer Who Protested War
description: LAKENHEATH, England, July 8  The United States Air Force opened courtmartial proceedings today against Capt. Thomas S. Culver, the first American officer charged with taking part in an antiwar pro test in Britain.

title: ANGELA DAVIS MEETS A SOLEDAD BROTHER
description: SAN, RAFAEL, Calif., July 8 (UPI)Angela Davis embraced George Jackson, one of the three socalled Soledad Broth ers, as she met him here today.

title: Another Century for Boycott
description: LEEDS, England, July 8 (Reuters)  Geoff Boycott hit his third straight testcricket century today, 112 runs, as England tallied 309 for nine wickets on the opening day of the decisive third match against Pakistan. With the first two tests drawn, Pakistan has a real chance of winning a series against England for the first time.

title: PRICES INCREASE ON TAXEXEMPTS
description: Taxexempt bond prices, buoyed by the sale of New York City's big $357.1million issue Wednesday, continued to advance yesterday.

title: GOVERNOR VETOES A BILL ON CORONA
description: ALBANY, July 8Governor Rockefeller announced today his veto of a bill that would have overturned the Lindsay ad ministration's compromise plan to return to a group of home owners in Corona, Queens, the property the city has con demned to make way, for a school.

title: The Dance: A New La Sylphide by Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater's new production of Bournon ville's La Sylphide was long overdue. The ballet was first given by Ballet Theater in 1965 in a mildly terrible ver sion by Harald Lander that messed around the music and the choreography and staged the ballet with all the sen sitivity of a broken sledge hammer.

title: Fresh Berry Mold for a Summer's Day
description: In the menu below dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: 802382 Wins in Jersey
description: OCEAN CITY, N. J., July (UPI)The winning number in this week's New Jersey state lottery is 802382. The number was chosen today in a cere mony on the Boardwalk here.

title: Bridge:
description: The visiting English junior champions had their first taste of success in America Wednesday night. Ceri Evans of London, whose Welsh first name is pronounced Kerry, was a winner at the ProAm tournament at the Middle Bay Country Club, Ocean side, L.I.

title: 3 Major Bank Companies Show Drops in Earnings
description: The full dimension of the squeeze on earnings of the na tion's largest banks began to appear yesterday as three ma jor New York bank companies reported sharp declines for the second quarter.

title: HOUSE APPROVES WIDER U.S. CREDIT TO FINANCE TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The House of Representatives voted today to expand export credit financing by the ExportImport Bank but blocked a move de signed to liberalize EastWest trade.

title: U.S. STEEL CLOSING YOUNGSTOWN PLANT
description: The United States Steel Cor poration announced yesterday it would close its plant at Youngstown, Ohio, and would lay off about 2,700 workers. The action brings to about 11, 000 the number of employes laid off by steel producers be cause of unexpectedly weak de mand this summer.

title: Giants' Mara in No Rush to Rent Ball Park That Doesn't Exist
description: New York's pro football teams were involved yesterday In separate conferences without commitmentsthe Giants on proposed contract for a New Jersey stadium, the Jets on Jim Hudson's uncertain future as difensive back.

title: SALTWith a Dash Of
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Spring arrived late this year in New England but it was accompanied by a whole series of thaws on the international front. We and the Russians have finally concurred on a course in the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) that could lead to an agreement this year, first to limit ABM defenses and then offensive nuclear weapons. We've also agreed to start talking seriously about mutual troop reductions in Europe. France has unlocked the door through which England could enter Europe. Seymour Topping has been in China and Scotty Reston is there now. Even in the Middle East, the level of verbal belligerency is down several decibels.

title: Core Ed Backs the City's Effort To Get Cheap Power From State
description: The city agreed yesterday to let Consolidated Edison build a new transmission line, and Con Edison agreed in return to help the city try to buy cheap stategenerated electric power.

title: 2 DDT Substitutes Are Recommended By U.N Health Unit
description: GENEVA, July 8  More than 1,400 compounds have been tested by the World Health Organization since 1956 as potential insectkillers. But only five, the organization said today, have successfully passed the severe tests in the laboratory and in the field to qualify for operational use.

title: Zimmerman 5 Shots Ahead In International Senior Golf
description: GLENEAGLES, Scotland, July 8 (AP)William Zimmerman of Columbus, Ga., carded a one overpar 71 today to take a fivestroke lead in the inter national seniors amateur golf championship with a three round total of 218.

title: Inna Armand, Friend of Lenin, Is Dead
description: MOSCOW, July 8  Inna A. Armand, a child of the Rus sian Revolution, whose moth er was one of Lenin's closest comrades, died Tuesday after a serious illness. She was 73 years old.

title: Argentine Economic Plan Sets Stage for Elections
description: BUENOS, AIRES, July 8  Gen. Alejandro A. Lanusse, Ar gentina's military president, has set forth a moderately na tionalist economic program as the framework for a political effort to restore an elected government here.

title: Market Place:
description: The performance derby in the mutualfund industry is under way again. It's, not surprising that some extra ordinary results were turned in during this year's surging first half in the stock market.

title: Aid for Lockheed Opposed by Galbraith
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) John Kenneth Galbraith, Harvard economist, said today that legislation to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy would serve no purpose except to increase the political stock of Secretary of the Treasury John B. Con nally Jr.

title: Case of Pentagon Report May Be Before Grand Jury
description: BOSTON, July 8 (AP) Cloaked in unusual secrecy, a Federal grand jury is conduct ing an investigation on which, United States Attorney Herbert F. Travers Jr. says, there will be no public statement what soever.

title: 49 POLICEMEN GIVEN MEDALS BY MAYOR
description: Fortynine policemen received medals yesterday from Mayor Lindsay for bravery in the line of duty.

title: WIMBLEDON FOES WILL MEET AGAIN
description: DUBLIN, July 8 (UPI)  Evonne Goolagong and Mrs. Margaret Court set up a repeat of their Wimbledon final by advancing today to the final of the Carrots Irish open tennis championships.

title: AntiU.S. Pressure By Arabs Is Urged In Fighting Israel

title: Funny Cars Race Tonight
description: CENTER MORICHES, L. I., July 8The United States Funny Car Championships, de voted to one of the most popu lar classes in drag racing, will be run this weekend at New York National Speedway here. The schedule provides races at 8 P.M. tomorrow and Saturday, with the finals beginning at 2 P.M. Sunday.

title: Bonds Urged Here On Parade Cleanup
description: The Mayor's Council on the Environment proposed yes terday that sponsors of parades here be forced to pay for cleanup and traffic con trol for their events.

title: Trevino Ties Jacklin at 139 For British Open Golf Lead
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 8  With four birdies down the stretch and a 40foot putt across the heart of the home. green for an eagle 3, Lee Tre vino came out of the nick to day to tie Tony Jacklin for the lead at 139 halfway through the 100th British Open golf championship

title: Zender Team Leads Golf at 65
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 8 Amateur golf was on the up swing today as a record 142 teams in the John G. Anderson memorial tournament com pleted the first half of a 36 hole qualifying test. Both the East and West courses of the Winged Foot Golf Club were in use.

title: U.S. War Deaths, at 45, Are Highest in 6 Weeks
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 (UPI)  Fortyfive Americans died in the Viet, nam war last week, the high est count in six weeks, the United States command re ported today. Twentythree were killed in combat and 22 died of disease or accidents.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert B. Clark yester day was elected president and chief executive officer of HoffmanLaRoche, Inc., Nutley, N. J., the United States pharmaceutical affil iate of the Switzerland based Hoffmann  LaRoche. Mr. Clark, who has been executive vice president and a board member of the company since 1968, suc ceeds Dr. V. D. Mattia, who died suddenly on July 4. Before joining Hoffmann LaRoche Inc. Mr. Clark, 57, who holds a master's degree in chemistry from Harvard University and a law degree from Brooklyn Law School, served in various capacities with WarnerLambert Phar maceutical Company. He served as a patent attor ney with WarnerHudnut in 1947 and by 1967 was a senior vice president of the WarnerLambert Pharma ceutical Company.

title: Wells Fargo Bank Joins Prime Rate Rise to 6%
description: The Wells Fargo Bank, San Francisco, announced yesterday an increase in its prime lending rate to 6 per cent from 5 per cent. The bank had been the lone holdout among the nation's largest banks at the lower rate.

title: Delay on Copper Exports
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The Commerce Department said today that because of a copper industry strike, applica tions filed after July 2 for cop per exports will not be proc essed pending a review of the copper supply and demand sit uation. It said the new order includes copper scrap, refined copper and blister copper. How ever, it said licensing will con tinue for the export of copper ores, concentrate and other un refined copper except blister copper.

title: Study Finds States Cut Welfare Funds, Reversing a Trend
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 A confidential Federal survey has found that 10 states, and possi bly more, are reducing welfare benefits this year, sharply re versing a longtime trend of higher assistance levels for, the poor.

title: It Is Really a Question of Loving Mississippi Not for What It Is but for What It Can Be
description: GREENVILLE, Miss.Granted that accepting the challenge of unity is what the graduating class of 1971 has endeavored to do for these past nine months. But it seems that only through steadfast commitment to that challenge can any semblance of concreteness be given to that effort. And commitment to unity or brotherhood can mean something only when the vagueness of such terms is clarified by applying them to something specific. Probably, in the case of this class, the most mean ingful commitment to be made would be the commitment to the brotherhood of this state.

title: A Step Away From the Nile
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmos phere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: PENTAGON DEFENDS PLANS FOR BOMBER
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The Defense Department acknowl edged today that its plans to build the B1 longrange bomb er as a successor to the B52 had been criticized by the Gen eral Accounting Office, but it defended the Air Force pro gram.

title: J.P. Morgan Appoints Chairman
description: Ellmore C. Patterson will be come chairman of the board and chief executive officer of J. P. Morgan & Co. and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Com pany of New York on Aug. 1, the company announced yester day.

title: Some Cigar Prices Raised By a Gulf & Western Unit
description: The Consolidated Cigar Cor poration, a subsidiary of Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday price rises on some Muriel cigars and three regional brands, effective with shipments Aug. 2.

title: Horsemen Honor Longden
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 8 (AP)  Johnny Longden, who won 6,032 races as a jockey, was inducted into the Horse men's Hall of Fame yesterday. The 61yearold Longden is from Taber, Alberta.

title: NIXON REBUFFED ON RESERVE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) The House Appropriations Committee turned down today a Nixon Administration propo sal to shift the Coast Guard Reserve program to the Navy.

title: Kitty Hawk Quits Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 (AP)  The United States Navy announced today that the 80,000ton aircraft car rier Kitty Hawk has been with drawn from the Vietnam war and is now under operational control of the United States First Fleet in the eastern Pacific.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The survival of a nonCommunist South Vietnam, the goal or President Nixon according to Tom Wicker, is. not a bad goal. In fact, over 50,000 American soldiers have died for this goal. Now it is in sight. The South Vietnamese Government is stable, the army increasingly competent and the countryside generally peaceful. Mean while, American combat casualties and commitments ire greatly reduced from two years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NABISCO SEEKING J. B. WILLIAMS CO.
description: Merger News

title: Katzenbach and Miller Set On Washington Post Board
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) Nicholas de B. Katzenbach and Arjay Miller were elected today as board members of The Washington Post Company.

title: ARMS TALK RESUMED BY U.S. AND RUSSIANS
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 8 (AP)The fifth round of talks between the United States and the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms started today and conference sources said both sides were optimistic and determined to reach an agree ment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GETS STATE INCOME TAX
description: HARTFORD, July 8  Gov. Thomas J. Meskill allowed personal income tax to become law in Connecticut today with out his signature in what he called a silent protest.

title: Notes on People
description: Sargent Shriver, who held high posts in the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon Adminis trations, was talking about one of his favorite subjects, Democratic politics.

title: General Bids Thieu Protest Drug Charge
description: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July 8  Maj. Gen. Ngo Dzu, who was identified yesterday by a member of the United States Congress as one of the chief heroin traffickers in South Vietnam, today asked President Nguyen Van Thieu to protest the allegation, according to the general's senior American ad viser, John Paul Vann.

title: Uganda Warns Tanzania; Threatens to Attack Planes
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 8 President Idi Amin of Uganda threatened today to shoot down any aircraft that, crossed Ugan da's border with neighboring Tanzania and to attack any Tanzanian ships approaching Uganda's shores on Lake Vic toria.

title: Not Guilty Plea in Hijacking
description: LOS ANGELES, July 8 (UPI) Donald B. Irwin, 28 years old, charged with kidnapping in the hijacking of a Trans. World Airlines 707 jetliner last Sep tember, pleaded not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity today.

title: Judge Not Lest Ye Be Judged
description: WASHINGTONThe Pentagon Pa pers are in themselves quite deceptive. There is not one piece of paper from the President, nor one piece of proof of any of the socalled decisions the Pentagon analysts assert were made. There is only the flight of memos between various levels of State and Defense. Every working newsman in Washington knows about contingency planning and is aware that while a hundred consensuses may be reached at lower levels, until the President de cides, there is no decision. This is elementary in the structure of the Presidency. What the President thinks, says and does is the decisive piece of action.

title: F.D.A. Hot Line Presses Search for Bon Vivant Cans
description: A hot line between Brooklyn and Washington sizzled yesterday with mes sages and instructions in an international search for cans of food that might contain the lethal botulism toxin.

title: ... as Mr. Nixon Counsels Steel
description: The Administration's approach to an incomes policy to restrain wages and prices, however, appears to have moved only slightly from its original laissezfaire line.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: While I praise The Times for the great public service it has performed with the Pentagon documents, I can not agree with your editorial opinion that this is a ringing victory for free dom under law.

title: Retaliating, C.A.B Bars Australia's JumboJet Flights
description: The Civil Aeronautics, Board, retaliating against Australian rebuffs to United States air lines, voted yesterday to bar Australia from starting jumbo jet service to this country in September.

title: Nader Lays Staining To Some Toothpastes
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, charged today that toothpastes containing start, nous fluoride, a decayretard ing additive, really stained teeth. He asked the Govern ment to require warning la bels on the toothpaste tubes.

title: 64% in Poll Say U.S. Is on Wrong Track
description: WASHINGTON, July 8Near ly twothirds of the American people believe that their coun try has lost its proper sense of direction, according to a na tional survey by the Roper Or ganization. Many of them blame drug abuse and the Vietnam war.

title: What Price Teamster Support?
description: The budding love affair between the Nixon Adminis tration and the International Brotherhood Of Teamsters has some ugly overtones. The ardor with which the Presi dent and Secretary of Labor Hodgson have been wooing the twomillionmember union, exiled from the rest of the labor movement in 1957 for hoodlum domination, would be questionable enough if it were regarded solely as a bid for political and financial support in next year's Presidential election.

title: List of Road Bottlenecks
description: Motorists driving in and out of the metropolitan area this weekend may encounter delays because of con struction work at the following points listed by the Automobile Club of New York:

title: Enemy Supplies Found
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 8 (AP) Special forces making a new drive in the Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos were reported today to have uncovered large caches of enemy munitions, food, medicines and other sup plies.

title: R.O.T.C. Men Taste Army's Life, From Guns to K.P.
description: INDIANTOWN GAP, Pa., July 8Joe Biernat. a 20 yearold accounting major at Saint Bonaventure Univer sity, was walking down a wooded path with three other students here today when a grenade suddenly exploded to the right. Machine guns fired from the bushes and the youths were ambushed by four experienced paratroop ers.

title: Lacking Health Permit, Bluegrass Fete Put Off
description: The New England Blue grass Festival of country music, scheduled to be held on July 16, 17 and 18 at Step ping Stone Stables, Esco heag, R. I., has been post poned because the festival has not been able to get a health permit.

title: 18YearOlds Can Bet, Too
