description: MONTPELIER, Vt., July 8 (UPI)  The Vermont At torney General's office said to day that persons 18 to 21 years of age could bet at the state's track at Pownal under the new law redefining a minor as one who had not yet reached 18.

title: SLAYINGS IN CITY UP 30% OVER 1970
description: Statistics released yesterday by Dr. Milton Helpern, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, show that 714 persons were killed here in homicides in the first six months of 1971, point ing to a record high rate for the year and showing an in crease of 30.1 per cent over the same period last year.

title: Law Firm to Train Black Lawyers to Aid Poor While Earning Living
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 8  An integrated team of lawyers with deep roots in the civil rights movement will open a new law firm here next Thurs day that will try to show young black lawyers how to represent the poor and the blacks and still make a living.

title: Whelan Yields as Mayor of Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, July 8 Thomas J. Whelan, who was convicted with seven associates of Federal charges of extortion and conspiracy last Monday, announced today that he would cease functioning as Mayor of Jersey City, a post he had held for seven and a half years.

title: Postal Pay Talks Discussed
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The weekold Postal Service and representatives of seven unions representing its 650,000 employes met with Labor De partment officials today to plan a resumption of contract talks. The negotiations recessed last week without agreement to replace one that the unions had with the old Post Office Depart ment.

title: Rikers Island May Be Posh, but They Miss House of Detension
description: New York's newest and perhaps best hotel, is what, Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath called the new Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island when it opened three weeks ago. The guests don't en tirely agree  but they weren't expected to.

title: U.S. TRADE POSITION IS FOUND SLIPPING
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The United States competi tive position in world trade this year will slip to the lowest point in 34 years, the Commerce Department predicted today.

title: '72 BID BY HARRIS GAINS MOMENTUM
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The sudden Presidential bid of Senator Fred R. Harris is mov ing into high gear. The Okla homa Democrat is expected to announce within a few days that he will not seek reelection to the Senate next year, in order to concentrate on na tional office.

title: Advertising:
description: Needham, Harper & Steers has arranged to purchase an additional third of USPBen son Australia, that country's fourth largest agency.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 9, 1971

title: Judge Prevents Garrison From Arresting U.S. Aides
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 8 (AP) Judge Herbert W. Christen berry barred District Attorney Jim Garrison in United States District Court today from ar resting two Government offi cials who brought Federal charges against him.

title: U.S, IN PARIS, ASKS A CLOSED SESSION ON VIETCONG PLAN
description: Text of Bruce's statement is printed on Page 2.

title: Banks Warned on Abusing Use of Loans at Reserve
description: The official spokesman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned banks yes terday against abusing the privilege of borrowing from the Federal Reserve System.

title: State Will Open College Without a Campus in Fall
description: The State University's new experimental college, whose students will earn degrees with out being attached to a specific campus or having to enroll in traditional courses, will start operation in the fall in the Albany and Rochester areas and spread throughout the state by 1973, the university an nounced yesterday.

title: 20 Killed, 100 Hurt As Severe Quake Hits Central Chile
description: SANTIAGO,. Chile, Friday, July 9 (AP)A severe earth quake rocked, central Chile late last night, with seismographs registering 7 to 10 on the Richter scale. Several hours later President Salvador Al lende Gossens reported that about 20 persons had been killed and nearly 100 injured, but it was believed that some of the areas hardest hit had not been heard from.

title: Uruguay's Youths Seek Violent Change
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 8There will have to be blood, said the highschool boy, standing in classroom Tues day right and almost trembl ing with intensity. We've learned that we cannot get the changes we want without vio lence. The system will not give up without an armed revolu tient

title: Japan's New Foreign Chief Stresses U. S.Tie
description: TOKYO, July 8  Takeo Fukuda, Japan's new Foreign Minister, said today that the ad justment of economic relations with the United States was the most urgent problem the Japa nese Government faced in the next six months.

title: Pro Football Lowers Retirement Age to 55
description: The retirement age for for mer pro football players was lowered yesterday following agreement between the own ers and the Players Associa tion. A player who was ac tive for five seasons may now receive benefits at age 55 rather than 65.

title: Last of Mothball Fleet Are Bound for the Wreckers
description: STONY POINT, N.Y., July 8 The last two vessels in the Maritime Administration's moth ball fleet here were towed from an anchorage in the Hudson Riv er to begin their last voyage a 3,500mile trip to Spain, where they will be broken up and sold for scrap.

title: Italian Divorce Law Upheld
description: ROME, July 8  The Italian Constitutional Court ruled to day that Italys new divorce law was constitutional. The law went into effect last December and has been bitterly fought by conservative Roman Catholics.

title: Roundup: Frank Robinson Makes 2,500Hit Plateau
description: Frank Robinson had a nice flair for a significant occa sion. Last night, needing one hit to reach the 2,500 plateau, he achieved that level with a threerun homer as the Bal timore Orioles romped to a 73 triumph over the Wash ington Senators.

title: Advertising:
description: The Bureau of Advertising has named Mark B. Bollman to the new job of executive vice president for national sales.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA A  Fishing along Barnegat Light is poor, and one local operator com plained, I ask the fish why, but they don't tell me any thing. If anglers are lucky in the area, they might catch some flounder. Around Bri dle, excellent bluefishing is reported in the Mud Hole and the Klondike. At night, the blues take butterfish and bunkerbacks, but during the day they're biting on smelts. Trailers are catching tuna on some days, when the water turns a bit colder, southeast of Brielle. Codfish are be coming abundant.

title: MOTT, JOHNSON GAIN BOYS' TENNIS FINAL
description: Thomas Mott of Westboro, Mass., and Mark Johnson of North Miami Beach, Fla., upset the first two seeded playersto gain the final round of the 14 yearsold division in the East ern boys' tennis championships yesterday at the West Side Ten nis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: MRS. JOSEPH ROBERTS
description: Mrs. Anna Lurie Roberts, one of the pioneer merchants in the Port Richmond section of Staten Island, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital, Concord, S.I. She was 80 years old.

title: Equipment Men Reach Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) A tentative contract agree ment has been reached in nineweekk strike by 6,000 heavy equipment operators in southeastern Pennsylvania and Delaware. Industry officials said today that members of Local 542, Operating Engineers Union, would vote on the con tract over the weekend. If it is approved, they will report to work Monday.

title: Colonel's List of Alleged Reds Given to Eastland by Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) A private dossier on alleged Communists and subversives kept for 23 years by a retired Army colonel and his wife has been turned over to Senator James O. Eastland by the Pentagon.

title: ALFRED H. DUNRILL OF TOBACCO GROUP
description: LONDON, July 8  Alfred Henry Dunhill, president of the Dunhill Tobacco group, and a leading figure In the British tobacco industry, died today at Hove, Sussex. He was 75 years old.

title: BRAZIL REPORTED TO HOLD THE BECKS
description: Julian Beck, his wife, Judith Melina, and 17 members of their Living Theater have been under arrest in Belo Horizonte, Brazil, since July 1 on charges of possessing drugs and subver sive literature, a member of the group said here yesterday.

title: Franc in High Demand; Revaluation Is Rumored
description: PARIS, July 8The French franc was in demand today as rumors of an upward revalu ation spread in the currency markets.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: July 8, 1971

title: ArtInspired Reproductions That You Can Wear to Dinner
description: Emilio Pucci is my mas ter, admitted Yannis Tsek lenis, a personable 33year old Greek fashion designer who visited New York last week. Like the Italian who convinced women to wear printed dresses the year round, Tseklenis aspires to a niche in the wardrobes of women who are internation al about fashion.

title: Legislator Forms Panel to Draw New Standard Apartment Lease
description: Assemblyman Anthony Oli vieri of Manhattan announced yesterday the formation of a committee to prepare a new standard lease for city apart ment dwellers to replace the one now in effect.

title: JUNE SALES SURGE AT RETAIL CHAINS
description: Many of the nation's largest retail chains reported yester day substantial gains in sales for the five weeks ended July d, with Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest merchan diser, achieving its biggest monthly increase since May 1969.

title: Attempt to Override Veto Of Job Bill Due Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI)  A Senate, committee decided today to try to override Pres ident Nixon's veto of a bill to create 200,000 public construc tion jobs for the unemployed.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD SHOWS RISE IN NET
description: Kaufman & Broad, Inc., re ported yesterday sharply high er earnings for the fiscal half year ended May 31 with sales up 50 per cent. In addition di rectors voted yesterday to split the stock on a twoforone basis and declared a regular quarterly cash dividend.

title: Dog Racing Bill Signed
description: CONCORD, N.H., July 8 (UPI) Gov. Walter Peterson signed a bill today legalizing dog rac ing in New Hampshire.

title: Ecological Group Sues to Halt Atom Test in Aleutian Islands
description: WASHINGTON, July 8  A new environmental group filed suit against the Atomic Energy Commission in United States District Court here today seek ing to halt the underground nu clear test planned this fall on Amchitka Island in the Meut fans.

title: JAPAN AND MARKET IN TRADE IMPASSE
description: BRUSSELS, July 8The Eu ropean Common Market and Japan today ended a threeday round of trade talks without any progress toward agreement.

title: Foundation Gives $124,300 For a Study of Cable TV
description: The Center for Policy Re search has received a grant of $124,300 from the National Sci ence Foundation to study the uses of cable television as a means of communication and decisionmaking on the corn munity level, Dr. Amitai Etzi oni, director of the center, an nounced yesterday.

title: Seven Plans of Reorganization Given for Some Mecom Holdings
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 8 (AP) John Mecom Sr., an independ ent oil operator, and six oil companies in which he has in terests have submitted separate plans for reorganization of some Mecom holdings under the bankruptcy laws.

title: British Financing Seen
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (Reu ters)  Senator Robert Taft, Republican of Ohio, said today the British Government may pick up the additional financing for Lockheed if Congress fails to approve a loan guarantee for the Tristar airliner project.

title: FLORIDA POWER NET DECLINES IN QUARTER
description: The Florida Power Corpora tion reported yesterday a de cline in firsthalf net income despite higher operating reve nues.

title: Puerto Rican Theater Sets 5th Season
description: The Puerto Rican Travel ing Theater Company, a non profit multiracial mobile unit, has received a total of $74, 606 in grants from city, state, Federal and private sources to begin its fifth summer season.

title: Weekly Reports Are Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, July 8The weekly rail freight report of the Association of American Railroads will be delayed until tomorrow because of the ob servance this week of the In dependence Day holiday. The report on truckloadings is still not available because of the Western Union strike. Mean while, the Commerce Depart ment said today its weekly report on retailstore sales will be delayed until tomorrow be cause of processing delays.

title: Advertising:
description: What an ethical drug ad agency, a consumergoods agency, a rentacar com pany and a book publisher might well have in common is Francis Joseph Scully. He has tried them all, and at 46 years of age he appears to have taken a rewarding route.

title: MRS. FOULK TAKES WOMEN'S SAIL CUP
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 8 Mrs. Betty Foulk of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Old Greenwich, Conn., nailed the lid on the Syce Cup, emblematic of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association women's sailing championship, today.

title: U.S. Judge Dismisses Suit Against Jersey Welfare Law
description: TRENTON, July 8A Federal District Court judge today dis missed a suit brought by the National Welfare Rights organ zation against New Jersey's new welfare regulations.

title: Generator Gap
description: Big Allis, Consolidated Edison's giant generator, has clearly become too much of a bad thing. In 1969 it broke down twice. In July of 1970 it went out of com mission entirely, to resume the generating of electricity only last month. And now it has collapsed again. While prospects this time are for a quick recovery, New Yorkers are nevertheless left once more with the threat of those power cuts, dimouts and brownouts to which they have become painfully accustomed.

title: U.S COPIERS JOIN DRIVE IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 9United States helicopters airlifted 1,500 South Vietnamese troops into the Parrot's Beak section of eastern Cambodia yesterday for the start of a pincer move ment against enemy troop concentrations and supply lines.

title: Koosman Trouble Laid to Soreness In Rib Cage Area
description: The Mets received a prog nosis on Jerry Koosman's physical problems yesterday, but they're still waiting for someone to find the cure for the ailment that has struck their entire team.

title: Textile Negotiator for U.S. Flies Back to South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 8 (Reuters)  Anthony Jurich, a White House aide and chief workinglevel negotiator in the deadlocked United StatesKo rean textile talks here last month, flew here today, ap parently at short notice to the Korean Government.

title: Charlie Shavers, TrumpeterSong Writer, Dead
description: Charlie Shavers, composer and trumpeter, whose warm mellow trumpet won him popu larity as a jazz instrumentalist, died yesterday in Calvary Hos pital, the Bronx, after a short illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 3128 101st Street, East Elmhurst, Queens.

title: DECISION POSTPONED ON A PHONE TOWER
description: A proposal to permit the con struction of a telephone com pany tower as high as the Woolworth Building near the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge produced a series of shouting matches but no deci sion in the Board of Estimate yesterday.

title: NINO FOR VERONICA IN CHANNEL 9 SERIES
description: Adios, Veronica! Bienvenido, Nino!

title: Dooley Retains Ring Post
description: ALBANY, July 8 (UPI)Ed win B. Dooley was renamed chairman of the State Athletic Commission today by Governor Rockefeller. His salary is $31, 325 a year.

title: Accord Set on Pipeline
description: The Dow Chemical Com pany, the Houston Natural Gas Corporation and Tenneco, Inc., announced yesterday agree ment in principle on a plan for an immediate 333mile west ward extension of the 36inch intrastate Texas Natural Gas pipeline now being operated by the Intratex Gas Company, a subsidiary of Houston Natural Gas.

title: ' Nun' Adapted From 'La Religieuse'
description: "The Nun," Jacques Rivette's film adaptation of Diderot's "La Religieuse" (published in English as "The Memoirs of a Nun"), is a beautiful, calm, austere movie that somehow manages to be remarkably faithful to the original, yet quite different in tone. Here is a most curious example of the adaptation of a classic being more somber than the text from which it was adapted. Because we always like to think of ourselves as more sophisticated now than we were six weeks ago (to say nothing of 200 years ago), it usually works the other way around.Diderot's "La Religieuse," written in 1760 but not published until 1796, had its origins as an elaborate and rather cruel practical joke, as a series of letters written by Diderot to his friend, the Marquis de Croismare, who had earlier assisted a certain Sister Suzanne Simonin in her unsuccessful suit to have her vows revoked. Attempting to lure his friend back to Paris from his country estate, Diderot, in the letters, represented himself as Sister Suzanne, newly escaped from her convent and in need of the marquis's aid.In addition to the letters, Diderot also composed a journal, supposedly kept by Sister Suzanne, in which she recounted how she had been forced into the nunnery by her family, had been coerced into taking her vows, had been tortured when she resisted the hair shirts and the whips, and had memorized the order's constitution to become, in effect, a nunnery lawyer.Things went no better for Sister Suzanne when she was finally transferred to another convent, which was run by a mad mother superior, a pretty, pudgy-faced lesbian, and where the sisters drank liqueurs, munched sweets and shrieked up and down the cloistered corridors, blowing kisses to one another. With the help of an erring monk, Sister Suzanne leaped over the wall one night to meet a death more precipitous than fate might reasonably have been expected to impose, principally because Diderot realized that the Marquis de Croismare had taken the joke seriously and was preparing to come to the sister's rescue."La Religieuse" was not as much an expos of convent lifethough it came to be known as thatas it was a romantic polemic on tyranny, written in the extravagant terms that its author knew would most fascinate and upset the good marquis. Even today it is quite out-rageous, as when, for example, Sister Suzanne and the crazy mother superior stage what amounts to a slapstick battle over Sister Suzanne's virtue, so amazingly well preserved that Samuel Richardson's Pamela would have been proud to call it her own.There is, however, behind all of the extravagances of "La Religieuse" the straightforward progression of tragedy, and it's this progression, this movement towards an inexorable fate, that Rivette's film details with almost classic simplicity. "The Nun" is theatrical, without in any way being uncinematic, beginning as if it were a ritual, or a play, the stage of which is the chapel where Sister Suzanne (Anna Karina) makes her first dramatic refusal to take the vows, and then is led away, crying, by the older, completely implacable brides of Christ. There are hardly any exterior shots in the film, but even the few exteriors have the sealed, exitless feeling of the convent interiors.Miss Karina's beauty, for which Godard once made movies that were also homages, is the perfect centerpiece for a film that looks cool and graceful but is passionately determined with the heart of a revolutionary. It's a lovely performance, one that never condescends to play on pathos but grows in strength with each new outrage so that the final, very wild moments of the film have the kind of conviction that transforms melodrama into something a good deal more important.The cast also includes Liselotte Pulver, Micheline Presle and Francine Berge, as mother superiors of varying degrees of correctness; Christine Lernier, as Sister Suzanne's real mother, who dismisses her daughter with the cheery reminder that "my fate in the hereafter depends on you," and Francisco Rabal, as the monk who, with love, successfully dooms Sister Suzanne.Rivette and Jean Gruault (who also wrote Godard's "Les Carabiniers" and Truffaut's "The Wild Child"), did the excellent adaptation, which, not so incidentally, has taken a long time to get here. The film, which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, was made in 1965, banned for a while by the French Government for reasons that were patently absurd, and then shown twice at the 1968 New York Film Festival. It's with pleasure I report its arrival.

title: Poland Belittles Conflict Over Pentagon Papers
description: WARSAW, July 8A Polish newspaper reader was quickly disabused today of his sug gestion that the controversy in the United States over the pub lication of the Pentagon pa pers represented evidence in favor of freedom and the dem ocratic system.

title: Chiefs, Apollon Play Tie
description: ATLANTA, July 8 (AP)The Atlanta Chiefs and Apollon of Greece played a 11 tie tonight in a North American Soccer League game.

title: Data Denied McNaniara, Ellsberg Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  Daniel Ellsberg asserted today that Pentagon officials working for the Joint Chiefs of Staff kept from Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara the ex istence of a study of the 1964 Tonkin Gulf incident.

title: Article 3  No Title
JOHN W. BRADY
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 9 John W. Brady, a retired vice president of the Colonnade Company, Cleveland, a restau rant chain in the Middle West, died Wednesday at White Plains Hospital after a brief illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 45 Popham Road here.

title: Barbara Marron Becomes a Bride
description: SADDLE RIVER, N. J., July 9Miss Barbara Rose Marron was married here this afternoon to Frank Peter Manginello.

title: China Rejoins Korean Talks After 5 Years
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, July 9 A Chinese Communist dele gate returned to the Korean truce village of Panmunjom today, after his country's ab sence of five years, to attend a meeting of the Korean Mili tary Armistice Commission.

title: Marine Midland Profits Off Sharply for Quarter
description: Marine Midland Banks, Inc., the $8  billion Buffalo  based bank holding company that blankets New York State, re ported yesterday a sharp de cline in secondquarter profits.

title: Merger News
description: The Coleman Company, Inc., is planning to add guns, rifles, istols, skeet traps and ammuni tion to its outdoor recreation equipment, through the pro posed $26.7million acquisition of the Crosman Arms Com pany, Inc. The agreement ap proved yesterday by directors of Crosman and the executive committee of Cole man calls for an exchange of two Coleman shares For each Crosman share. A total of 766,908 Coleman shares would be involved. The stock closed at 34 off  on the Ameri can Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: AUSSIE GIRL, 14, SWIMS RECORD 400
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., July 9 (AP)Shane Gould, a 14 yearold Australian, took the world record in the women's 400meter freestyle from a countrywoman, Karen Mores, winning in 4 minutes 21.2 sec onds today at the Santa Clara international swimming meet.

title: U.S. JUDGE REJECTS SHIFT OF DAVIS CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July (UPI)  Federal District Judge Samuel Conti refused to take over the Angela DavisRuchell Magee case today. He turned down Miss Davis's petition that Gov. Ronald Reagan be ar rested and tried for con spiracy against here.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 2.4% From the YearAgo Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended July 3 totaled an estimated 14.2 billion tonmiles, 2.4 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Loadings in the same week totaled 495,950 cars, an increase of 2,203, or 0.4 per cent above the comparable week a year ago.

title: Books of The Times; In Praise(!) of Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES. The Architecture of Four Ecolo gies. By Reyner Benham. Illustrated. 256 pages. Harper & Row. $6.95.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: PARIS  The only practical Ameri can interest remaining in these nego tiations is to get out with a degree of honor. This is probably the last chance to do it.

title: Stargell No. 1 for June
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (UPI)Pittsburgh's Willie Star gell was named National League player of the month for June today by a panel of 60 baseball writers and broadcatters. Star gell hit 11 homers in June, batted .333 and, drove in 36 runs in 29 games.

title: Grand Funk Railroad Presents Heavy Rock in Concert at Shea
description: The mammoth Grand Funk Railroad concert last night be fore 55,000 people at Shea Sta dium was really a spectacle, not a concert.

title: Judge Calls U.S. Voiding Of Mayday Permit Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) A Federal judge ruled today that the Government acted il legally on May 2 in revoking a permit issued to Mayday anti war demonstrators to assemble in West Potomac Park near the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Reds Down Mets
description: CINCINNATI, July 9Like two desperate gladiators thrown together by some mad emperor, the Mets and Reds were paired tonight in steamy Riverfront Stadium.

title: CLEMENTE NAMED TO ALLSTAR TEAM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP)Roberto Clemente of the Pittsburgh Pirates drew his 11th AllStar game assignment today as Sparky Anderson, the Cincinnati Reds' Manager, com pleted the National League squad.

title: PERONIST DEMANDS DATE FOR ELECTIONS
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 9The personal delegate of the exiled former dictator, Juan D. Pern, demanded today that election dates be set promptly as a con dition for Peronist support of President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse's political pacification plan.

title: Johnson Takes Boys' Tennis
description: Mark Johnson of North Miami Beach, Fla., defeated Thomas Mott of Westboro, Mass., 63, 63, to win the 14years division title in the Eastern Boys' ten nis championships yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens. John McEnroe of Douglaston, Queens, upset firstseeded Larry Linett of Albany, 62, 62, in the 12 years division final.

title: Columbia Aids Minorities To Posts in Broadcasting
description: Gloria Rojas is. Geraldo Ri vera is. Sherman Jackson is. So are J. J. Gonzales, Edgar Henry, Laura Blackwell and a host of other promising young journalists around the country.

title: Hiram Walker Shows Sharp Dip In 3dQuarter Sales and Profit
description: Hiram WalkerGooderham & Worts Ltd., showed a sharp decline in sales and earnings in the third fiscal quarter end ed May 31, reflecting in pant strike which ran from Feb. 20 to June 11, according to the company's report issued yes terday for the nine months pe riod only.

title: PENTAGON PAPERS IN SECOND PRINTING
description: The Pentagon Papers, the paperback published by Ban tam Books in association with The New York Times, has gone into a second printing, a day after the first copies were shipped out on Thursday.

title: GEORGE E. GREENE
description: George E. Greene, a commer cial advertising artist, died Wednesday at St. Vicent's Hos pital of complications following surgery. He was 73 fears old and lived at 118 Waverly Place.

title: NEW MARGIN RULES ON BROKERS' ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Federal Reserve Board revised its rules today to make clear that banks may not extend credit exempt from margin re quirements for the purchase of publicly traded stock in broker dealer companies.

title: Article 8  No Title
No U.S. Officials Injured
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) A State Department spokesman said the United States Embassy in Santiago had reported that no American officials were injured and that United States property had. been only super ficially damaged.

title: Jersey Sees Crime Cut By Lottery
description: TRENTON, July 9New Jersey lottery officials said today that the state's weekly drawings had cut into organ ized crime's profits from the illegal numbers racket and added that a plan to run a daily lottery was being studied.

title: Georgia Broker, 55, Wins Golf for Seniors
description: PERTH, Scotland, July 9 (Reuters)William Zimmer man, a 55yearold stock broker from Columbus, Ga., shot a 3overpar 75 today to win the international seniors amateur golf championship at the Gleneagles course with a fourround total of 293.

title: ARTHUR L. NEWMAN
description: Arthur L. Newman, a lawyer and coin collector, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hos pital after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 125 East 72d Street.

title: JIM GARRISON DROPS CHARGES AGAINST 2
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 9 (UPI) District Attorney Jim Garri son dropped his charges against two Federal attorneys today when United States District Judge Herbert W. Christenberry ruled that the case would have to be tried in Federal court.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Tells Superintendents Decentralization Is a Must
description: Representative Shirley A. Chisholm told a conference of school superintendents here yesterday that there must be community control of local schools to make educators an swerable to those they serve rather than to the far re moved desires of those who sit above them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE LAYOFFS SET IN STEEL INDUSTRY
description: Two more mores to lay off workers in the steel industry were announced yesterday, but a third producer announced it would recall nearly 2,400 men who previously had been laid off.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Reversing a Welfare Trend...
description: Belatedly but still too timidly, public officials are be ginning to bring their critical faculties to bear on New York City's frightfully wasteful and degrading welfare problem that mires more than one million in poverty and burdens the budget. For far too long there has been an unwillingness to face the problem squarely, to ask the obvious questions, to move forcefully in response.

title: Store Sales Increase 28%
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Department of Commerce re ported today that department store sales for the week ended July 3 were an estimated $808 million, and increase of 28 per cent above the $631million sales for the comparable week of last year. Total, retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $7.916billion, an increase of 15 per cent above the 86.883billion sales for the like period last year.

title: Surgery for Miss Englehorn
description: CALDWELL, Idaho, July 9 (AP)Shirley Englehorn of Caldwell, the pro golfer, will undergo surgery on her left ankle Monday.

title: Market in Term Papers Is Booming
description: BOSTONOn a wall of the tworoom Htintington Ave nue offive of Termpapers Unlimited, Inc., one of the newest academic enterprises in this city that is surfeited with colleges and universi ties, hangs a small sign: We Do Not Condone Plagiarism.

title: South Africa's Mulattoes Growing Bitter in Apartheid's Limbo
description: CAPETOWN, July. 7There isn't one place in central Cape town where I can have a drink with a white man who may be a client, said a welltodo tradesman who is colored, the South African designation for mulattoes.

title: World Bank Rules Against Distributing Report on Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, has de cided not to distribute to na tions that have granted aid to Pakistan a written report by his staff that describes condi tions in East Pakistan as close to chaotic.

title: U.S. WON'T COMMENT ON NUCLEAR REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, July 9A State Department spokesman said tonight that the depart ment hasn't anything to say about a published report that President Nixon is considering a recommendation to move nuclear weapons from Okinawa to Taiwan.

title: Suit Filed to Block Conversion Of Stewart Into Fourth Jetport
description: A suit was filed yesterday seeking to block the develop ment of the former Stewart Air Force Base in Orange Coun ty as a fourth major jetport for the New York metropoli tan area.

title: Kazoo Maker Expects Humming Business
description: DETROIT, July 9  The buzzing of 3.5million kazoos may present parents and noise pollution foes with their most formidable youth problem this year, but it may make Albert Broder a rich man.

title: U.S., SOUTH KOREA PLAN TEXTILE TALKS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 9 (Reuters)  South Korea and the. United States today agreed to resume soon deadlocked ne gotiations for a curb on ac celerating Korean noncotton textile exports to America.

title: SANTANA ROUTS SMITH IN 4 SETS
description: BASTAAD, Sweden, July (UPI)  Manuel Santana oust ed the ailing Wimbledon run nerup, Stan Smith of Pasa dena, Calif., from the $33,000 Swedish open tennis champion ships today, beating the top seeded American, 62, 46, 63, 61, in a quarterfinal match.

title: YABLONSKI SUSPECT PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., July 9 Aubran W. Martin, one of five persons charged with the murders of Joseph A. Yablon ski, a United Mine Workers union insurgent, and two members of his family, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment this afternoon in Washington County Court.

title: The Talk of Montevideo
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 8This is the 19th win ter of economic depression and political confusion in Montevideo, and it may be spring before even the shape of change begins to show.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRICES SHOWED ADVANCE OF 0.3% IN JUNE
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The rise in industrial wholesale prices moderated slightly in June, the Labor Department re ported today.

title: Ulster Rioters Burn U.S.Owned Factory
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, July 9 (AP)  Rioters set fire to an Americanowned factory tonight and fought British troops trying to retch the flames.

title: Wexler Heads Jewish Group
description: GENEVA, July 9 (AP)Dr. William A. Wexler of Savan nah, Ga., was elected chairman of the World Conference of Jewish Organizations today, succeeding Nahum Goldmann, who is retiring after holding the office for 13 years.

title: Article 5  No Title
Executive Changes
description: The Rockwell Manu facturing Company an nounced yesterday the election of Louis Putze as president, chief exec utive officer and a di rector. The 54yearold Mr. Putze joins the company from Singer Company where he was a deputy vice president for the industrial prod ucts group. He succeeds A. C. Daugherty, who has resigned as president and a director. The company, also elected W. F. Rock well Jr. as chairman to succeed his father, Col. W. F. Rockwell, founder of the company, who will become honorary chairman, W. F. Rockwell Jr. had formerly been chief executive officer and held the title of vice chairman. S. Kent Rockwell, president and director of Keystone Aeronautics Corporation, was elected to the board to fill the seat vacated by his grand father, Colonel Rockwell.

title: WAR CRITICS CURB POLICE QUESTIONS
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 8  The Philadelphia Police Depart ment, taken to Federal Court on charges of inhibiting the rights of demonstrators to free speech and ass??bly, has agreed to stop asking questions about political views and asso ciations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corn and Soybean Futures Show Decline in Price
description: In anticipation of a Govern ment report, which was ex pected to show more acreage devoted to corn and soybeans, futures prices fell yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Article 4  No Title
PHIL WOODS GROUP AT TOP OF THE GATE
description: Phil Woods, the jazz alto saxophonist who moved with his family from Bucks County, Pa., to Paris four years ago, came home to play at the New port Jazz Festival. He was not heard there because the festival was canceled before he and his European Rhythm Machine had an opportunity to play. But his transAtlantic trio was not in vain: Mr. Woods and his group have moved into the Top of the Gate, Thompson and Bleecker Streets, where they will appear through July 18.

title: 150 Missing in Floods
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 9 (Reuters)About 150 persons are missing in floods in the jungles of southern Colombia, a Government official said to day. Rescue teams in helicop ters and trucks are on their way to the disaster areas.

title: The Illegal Peddling of Handcrafts  Better Than Having a Job
description: A few months ago 20yearold Suz anne Charles was a secretary in a Man hattan publishing company. Last Sun day she was selling sude belts for $6 in Central Park.

title: Article 7  No Title
Market Place: No Private Club, Lasker Asserts
description: The most powerful body in Wall Street is the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange and for years the governors have bristled at the repeated suggestion that they ran the Big Board as a private club.

title: Accused General in Saigon Terms Drug Charge a Plot
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 10  Maj. Gen. Ngo Dzu, who has been ac cused by a United States Con gressman of being one of South Vietnam's chief traffickers in narcotics, said this morning that the charges were the poor invention of a jealous army rival, and that Communists might have had a subtle hand in the controversy.

title: 53 HURT IN CRASH AT PENN STATION
description: A Long Island Railroad train struck another during the com muter rush hour last evening in a tunnel leading out of Pennsyl vania Station. At least 53 per sons were injuted, some seri ously, the police said.

title: DAVID H. ROUS
description: David H. Rous, treasurer of the GrandCity Container Cor poration, North Bergen, N. J., died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 350 Central Park West.

title: Volvo Posts Record Sales
description: Volvo, Inc., of Rockleigh, N. J., reported yesterday that June sales of 4,779 units repre sented the highest sales total for any month in the importer's history. The previous high of 4,563 sales was recorded in April. Stig Jonsson, president, said that cumulative sales for the year are running almost 16 per cent higher than a year ago, compared with a 5 per cent improvement for domestic car ??.

title: I.O.S. INSURGENTS SUE ON ELECTION
description: TORONTO, July 9The stockholders who would like to wrest control of I.O.S., Ltd., from its present management took their case to the New Brunswick Supreme Court to day.

title: TAINTED SOUP LAID TO POOR HEATING
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had learned the probable explanation for the contamination of Bon Vi vant vichyssoise with deadly botulism toxin.

title: CURRENCIES FACE NEW PRESSURES
description: PARIS, July 9Speculative money flows into Japan and France have added a fresh note of uncertainty to the world currency situation.

title: Advocate of Legal Marijuana Resigns Judgeship in Kentucky
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 9  A Juvenile Court judge who has been under fire from the county administration for pub licly advocating the legalization of marijuana has resigned.

title: Italian Agreement Ends 6Month Hotel Dispute
description: ROME, July 9 (Reuters) Management and workers in Italy's hotel industry tonight reached agreement on a new labor contract, ending a bit ter sixmonth dispute that has endangered the nation's tourist industry.

title: Large Wheat Crop Seen; Corn Plantings Rise 12%
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)  Farmers are harvesting bumper wheat crop of 1,547, 622,000 bushels, 12 per cent more than last year, and have planted 12 per cent more corn for harvest next fall, the Agri culture Department announced today.

title: Lindsay Names a Coordinator To Aid DrugAddicted Veterans
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday an nounced the appointment of fulltime coordinator of addic tion services for veterans to deal with the problem of drug addiction among returning soldiers.

title: Shut sleazy Hotels To Bar Prostitution, Businessmen Urge
description: Times Square businessmen met yesterday with the police and urged the closing of some midtown hotels as a means of controlling prostitution in the area.

title: Jim French Cncedes 1217 Pounds as Dwyer Pick Today
description: Jim French, the hardy travel er owned by Frank Caldwell, heads the field for the Dwyer Handicap, at Aqueduct today. The colt's reputation and pre Sentions ate such as to make him the favorite to take the 54th running of the 1mile race for 3yearolds.

title: 3 Shot in Robbery in Municipal Building
description: Two gunmen wounded an elevator starter and two Brinks guards yesterday morn ing and escaped with $143,000 after an exchange of shots in the Municipal Building as em ployes were beginning to come to work.

title: Latin Trade Gain Lags
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)  The Commerce Department reported today that United States trade with Latin Ameri ca and the Caribbean, though continuing to grow, increased at a slower rate in 1971 be cause of increased competition from the European Common Market and Japan.

title: 2 Drivers Suspended
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., July 9 (UPI)  Two more sulky driv ers at Pocono Downs were sus pended today in the aftermath of a riot by 200 bettors angered over a lowpaying exacta.

title: 275 LBS. OF HEROIN SEIZED IN 2 RAIDS
description: In two unrelated cases, the United States Customs Service and the New York City Police Department disclosed yesterday the seizure Thursday night of 275 pounds of nearly pure heroin with a value estimated at $32.5million in illicit street sales.

title: Table on U.S. Foreign Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Following is the table released today by Senator William Proxmire listing (in thousands of dollars) United States military and economic assistance 43 countries:

title: With Adolfo's Fashions, It Helps to Be Neither PennyWise Nor PoundFoolish
description: Someone once said that it is impossible to be too rich or too thin. Whoever it was must have just seen an Adolfo collection.

title: Stokes Criticizes Press and Politicians
description: CLEVELAND, July 9 The newspapers, local politicians and the national political par ties were denounced today by Mayor Carl B. Stokes in one of his goodby speeches to the city.

title: MRS. LEWIS J. O'SHEA
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July  Mrs. Ruth O'Neill O'Shea, wife of Lewis J. O'Shea, presi dent of Ives Laboratories, Inc., a subsidiary of American Home Products Corporation, died to day in Greenwich Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at Dingeltown Road.

title: Dishes That Have Been in Museums
description: Shop Talk

title: Biberman Memorial Set
description: A memorial service will be held Thursday for Herbert Bib erman, the director and writer, at the Theater De Lys, 121 Christopher Street, between 5 and 6 P.M. Mr. Biberman died last week. Among those who will pay tribute are Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee, Ring Lardner Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Philip Lang mer, Corliss Lamont and Lucille Lortell.

title: Agnew Assures Saudi Leaders Nixon ls Neutral on the Mideast
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, July 9 Vice President Agnew ended today what was clearly the bus iest and perhaps even the most productive series of meetings, of his 10nation goodwill tour, now approaching the halfway mark.

title: Four U. S. Concerns Join Panarctic's Gas Search
description: TORONTO, July 9Four ma jor United States natural gas distributors bet $75million to day that eventually they will deliver to their customers large volumes of gas from under ground pools far north of the Arctic Circle.

title: Steele Reaffirms Charges
description: NEW HAVEN, July 9 Representative Steele today re affirmed his charges that Gen eral Dzu is one of the chief traffickers in heroin in South east Asia.

title: Export Bank Says New U.S. Measure Will Expand Trade
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The president of the ExportImport Bank said today that legislation affecting the bank now passed by both houses of Congress and nearing final enactment could make it possible to add be tween $2billion and $5billion to United States export totals within a year.

title: Article 1  No Title
U.S. PLANS TO GIVE 6 MIDEAST NATIONS $500MILLION ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Nixon Administration is plan ning military aid loans and grants of about $500million to six Middle Eastern countries, including Israel, Jordan and Lebanon, in the current fiscal year.

title: Britain to Divest Private Investments
description: LONDON, July 9 Britain's Conservative Government is trying to divest itself of a $275 million investment portfolio in private industry built up by the former Labor Government in the name of industrial as sistance.

title: Kahane Enters Guilty Plea On One Charge, in a Deal
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the head of the Jewish Defense League, and two other members of the militant organization pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to a con spiracy charge involving the manufacture of explosives.

title: Bank Robber Holds Woman Hostage for 5 Hours and Then Surrenders
description: ST. PAUL, July 9 (UPI) A young, bank robber who said he wanted to shoot a policeman and be flown to Algeria held a St. Paul grand mother hostage for five hours today before surren dering to the police.

title: The Whatif Gang
description: Three men returned from earth orbit on June 30 with a new endurance record. The machine Soyuz 11 obedi ently and carefully deposited its cargo in sight of the recovery helicopter. The joyous backslapping reunion with their compatriots was denied this crew. Lieut. Col. Georgi T. Dobrovol sky, Viktor I. Patsayev and Vladislav N. Volkov perished during the reentry maneuver.

title: Bridge:
description: A stunning upset occurred in the first round of the Fun City Regional Knockout Team Championship, which goes into its third round this after noon at the New York Hilton with 16 teams surviving.

title: Hanoi's Defense Chief Says U.S. Traps Itself in Vietnam
description: LONDON, July 9 (UPI)The North Vietnamese Defense Min later, Gen. Vo Nguyen Glap, said in an interview released today that the United States had trapped itself in a tunnel without end in Vietnam. Gen eral Giap said America has only two choices: Stop the war or change strategy.

title: Mrs. Martinot Wed in Jersey
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 9 Mrs. Laurie Ruprecht Mar tinot, widow of Paul J. Marti not, was married here this afternoon to Edwin Lester Groves Jr. The Rev. David St. George performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: REFORM DIVORCE BILL PASSED IN MICHIGAN
description: LANSING, Mich., July 9  Michigan's Senate passed today a Houseapproved divorce re form bill.

title: HansArnold Fraenkel, 68, Led Coffee Import Firm
description: HansArnold Fraenkel, a cof fee importer specializing in African coffee, died Wednesday at his home in Hartsdale, N. Y. He was 68 years old and also lived in Sherman, Conn.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials slipped to 108.6 from 108.7 last week.

title: Trevino's 208 Leads by Shot
description: SOUTHPORT, England, July 9  Lee Trevino leads the 100th British Open by a stroke over Tony Jacklin and Liang, Huanlu, with the rest of the distinguished field scattered widely behind them.

title: N.A.S.D. KEEPING EYE ON MARKET MAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The National Association of Securi ties Dealers has put additional staff members to work to police situations in which market makers in over  the  counter stocks refuse to buy or sell stock at the price they have given to the automated quota tions system, NASDAQ.

title: WILKINS DISCERNS CHANCE FOR NIXON
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 9Roy Wilkins said today that it was still possible for President Nixon to win a sizable share, of the black vote in the 1972 Presidential election.

title: Corona Leaves Hospital
description: YUBA CITY, Cailf. July 9 (UPI)Juan V. Corona, the mass murder suspect, was re leased from Sutter County Gen eral Hospital today after three weeks' treatment for a heart ailment. He was returned to jail.

title: Ambrose Takes Maine Golf
description: ROCKLAND, Me., July 9 (AP)Rich Ambrose of Orono won the Maine amateur golf championship today with an 8and7 victory over Ted Johns of Hampden.

title: UB IWERKS, ARTIST WITH DISNEY, DEAD
description: BURBANK, Calif., July 9 (AP) Ub Iwerks, Walt Disney's chief cartoonist and the man who helped create Mickey Mouse, died Wednesday. His age was 70.

title: Auto Output Steady
description: DETROIT, July 9 (AP)Do mestic auto output remained unchanged this week despite Monday's shutdown for Inde pendence Day.

title: Gerken Gains in Clay Courts
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 9, (AP)  Secondseeded Paul Gerken of East Norwalk, Conn., advanced to the semifinals of the National clay courts cham pionships today with a 64, 60, 61 victory over Fred McNair of the University of North Carolina.

title: Chilean Earthquake Toll Rises to 74
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July (AP)The death toll from violent earthquake that struck central Chile last night rose to 74 tonight, the Government said. It reported that 135 per sons had been very seriously injured and that 48 others were in serious condition.

title: Appellate Division Upholds Award for Damage by Pill
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday unanimously upheld an award of $251,000 to a Brooklyn woman for medical damage that a lowercourt jury decided re sulted from taking birthcontrol pills.

title: France Takes Foil Crown At World Fencing Tourney
description: VIENNA, July 9 (AP)France won the foil team title in the world fencing championships today by defeating Poland, 97. The French had upset the So viet Union, 93, in the semi finals.

title: Captain Invites Air Force Jury To Hyde Park Site of Meeting
description: LAKENHEATH, England, July 9A United States Air Force officer, accused of having taken part in an antiwar protest that began at Hyde Park Speakers Corner, today invited a military jury to appear there on Sunday.

title: I. HERBERT SCHAUMBER
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 9  I. Herbert Schaumber, stockbroker, died today of can cer at St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. He was 67 years old and lived at Baldwin Farms here.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Thomas A. Edison knew a lot about many subjects. But he was weak on vacations. He did not observe them. After a long siege of slaving in his laboratory, Thomas was confronted by Mrs. Edison, who told him he had to take a rest and no fooling. She suggested he go to the one place in the world he desired more than any other.

title: Article 9  No Title
Yanks' Stottlemyre Beats Red Sox, 52
description: On a weekend dedicated to the past in Yankee Stadium, Mel Stottlemyre rubbed out a recent memory last night when he pitched and batted the New York Yankees to a 52 victory over the Boston fled Sox.

title: STOCKS MOVE UP AS TRADING FALLS
description: Strength in American Tele phone and Telegraph was as market feature yesterday as stock prices edged ahead to round out a week of modest but steady gains.

title: West German Breaks Hammer Throw Mark
description: STUTTGART, Germany (AP)Uwe Beyer of West Germany broke the listed world record for the hammer throw today with a toss of 245 feet and 8 inches dur ing qualifications for the German track and field cham pionship.

title: Hofstra Display Links Art and the Automobile
description: Ever since the first auto mobiles chuffed and chugged their way onto the roads and into the landscape of indus trial civilization, they have been icons of artistic con sideration.

title: Martin Backs Loan Help to Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Un der Secretary of the Treasury Charls E. Walker and William McChesney Martin Jr., former chairman of the Federal Re serve Board, both said today that they believed there was a danger that the present eco nomic recovery could be abort ed if the financially troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation or other large companies went bankrupt.

title: WEEK'S NEW ISSUES SHOW MIXED TREND
description: The newissue marketwhere the shares of companies that had no previous public market are tradedremained quiet this week, which was shortened by the Independence Day holiday.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCES
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed higher yester day in moderate but increased trading.

title: Federal Funds for Asian Studies in Universities Face Deep Cuts
description: Asian studies in American universities, now gaining in creased attention as contacts with Communist China are broadened, face the deepest cuts in Federal funds for foreignarea and language pro grams since the start of such aid in 1958.

title: Antiques: Depression Glass Popular
description: Depression glass, the mass market molded ware at its peak between 1930 and 1940, is coming up fast as the poor man's Art Deco.

title: Newcombe in Semifinals
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 9 (AP)John Newcombe of Australia, the Wimbledon cham pion, beat Jeff Borowiak of Berkeley, Calif., 64, 61, today and advanced to the semi finals of the international Swiss tennis championships.

title: Guinea Reports 8 Officers Will Be Shot for Treason
description: DAKAR, Senegal, July (Agence FrancePresse)Eight Guinean Army officers, includ ing the former chief, of the de fense staff, Gen. Keita Nouman dian, were condemned to death today, the Conakry radio mon itored here, reported.

title: Democrats to Miami Beach
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The Democratic National Committee announced today that Miami Beach, Fla., had been formally approved as the site of the 1972 Democratic National Convention. A com mittee announcement said a poll of the full national com mittee overwhelmingly ap proved the choice recommend ed June 29 by the Site Selec tion Committee. The conven tion will open July 10.

title: Man in the News
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 9 A black judge is presiding at the trial here of 12 Black Panthers charged with at tempted murder in a police Panther gun fight in New Orleans last September. He is Israel M. Augustine Jr., the first black Criminal Court judge in Louisiana since Reconstruction and believed to be the first black judge to preside at any of the recent Panther trials held in several major cities.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: REPAYMENT ON SST TO AIRLINES URGED
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 9The Nixon Administration asked Congress today to ap propriate $58.5million to pay the airlines capital they have expended to develop the super sonic transport plane.

title: ... The Workfare Record
description: There can be no doubt about the need for job oppor tunities for all Americans, especially minority group Americans, as Dr. Andrew F. Brimmer of the board governors of the Federal Reserve System emphasized in his address to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People the other day. Unem ployment remains unacceptably high among minority youths in urban areas.

title: Two Tied for Women's Lead
description: HORSHAM, Pa., July 9 (AP) Kathy Whitworth and Jane Blalock tied for a twostroke lead with 5underpar 68's to day in the $25,000 George Washington Ladies Golf Clas sic.

title: 2 More Railroads Threatened By Strikes, Raising Total to 5
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The United Transportation Union announced today plans to strike two more railroads, bringing to five the number of lines it has said it will shut down this month in a dispute over work rules.

title: Nixon Eulogizes Mrs. Kabis
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif, July 9 (UPI)President Nixon said today the untimely death of Dorothy Andrews Elston Kabis, United States Treasurer, is a blow not only to her friends and associates, but to the coun try in whose service she lived and died. Mrs. Kabis died of a heart attack last Friday at Sheffield, Mass. A message from the President was read at her memorial service at the National Presbyterian Church in Washington today by Sena tor William V. Roth, Republi can of Delaware.

title: Roundup: Renko of Expos Stops Phils on One Hit, 30
description: Steve Renko, a 6foot6 inch pitcner for the Montreal Expos, has confounded many National League observers because he does not use his height and 227pound weight to overpower hitters. Instead, he uses control and two basic pitchesa fastball and a sliderto retire enemy batters.

title: Oliva, McDowell Replaced
description: BOSTON, July 9 (AP)Tony Oliva of, the Minnesota Twins and Sam McDowell, a southpaw pitching ace of the Cleveland Indians, were forced to with draw today from the American League AllStar squad for the 42d classic with the National League Tuesday in Detroit.

title: Tennessee State Women Set World Mark in Relay
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 10 (UFI)Tennessee State's 440 yard relay team, anchored by Iris Davis, set a world record of 44.7 seconds in the national Amateur Athletic Union wom en's track and field champion ships tonight. The record came. in qualifying for tomonrow night's finals.

title: James Kelly, Brooklyn Historian And an ExCounty Clerk, Dies
description: James A. Kelly, Borough His torian of Brooklyn since 1944, died Thursday in his home at 178 81st Street, Brooklyn. He was 86 years old.

title: The Shadows Will Tell the Time
description: Some say baseball is out of joint with the times. Well, at least we have that to be grateful for, these times being made up of a number of appall ing ingredients.

title: Hail, Ivy League!
description: On May 9 an article appeared in The New York Times stating that a preliminary survey of a 16college study of high school students, teachers and guidance counselors indicates al most universal dissatisfaction with the present college admission procedures. The director of admissions at Princeton University, John T. Osander, went even further in saying that the overall college admission system existing throughout the nation amounted to absolute insanity.

title: Profile of Botulism, Rare but Deadly
description: Botulism is rare, but often fatal. During the last 10 years, according to the Center for Disease Control in Atlanta, a Federal agency, there have been about 50 deaths due to this deadly variety of food poisoning in the country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We read with interest your editorial of June 9, Rails for the Future, which says that Secretary Volpe and Senator Barry Goldwater, when tak ing part in a recent testflight of the FrancoBritish Concorde supersonic jetliner, could have brought home a more useful message from the exper mental run in West Germany of a prototype train designed to move be tween cities at speeds of up to 350 miles per hour.

title: U.S. Aides Confirm Drive by Laotians
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 9 United States officials, ac knowledging for the first time that a new sweep was under way on the Plaine des Jarres, reported today that American backed Laotian commandos were in control of twothirds of the plain area.

title: SKYE TERRIER TAKES KENILWORTH'S BEST
description: DURHAM, Conn., July 9 Champion Glamoor Gang Bus ter, a 3yearold dark silver skye terrier, won his first best inshow award today at Durham Fair Grounds. Bred and owned by Walter F. Goodman and Mrs. Adele F. Goodman of Oyster Bay, L. I., he won the title in a field of 984 dogs at the sec ond annual Kenilworth Kennel Club of Connecticut allbreed 1, dog show and obedience trials.

title: Paul Chavchavadze Dies at 72; Translated Book by Alliluyeva
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., July 9  Paul Chavchavadze, who translated Only One Year by Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, died today of a heart attack in Cape Cod Hospital, Hyannis. He was 72 years old and lived here.

title: Virginia Wade Wins Title
description: NEWPORT, Wales, July 9 (AP)Virginia Wade of Britain defeated Mrs. Judy Dalton of Australia, 63, 63, 64, today to win the women's title in the Green Shield open tennis championships.

title: BALLET THEATER PRESENTS NOCES
description: Jerome Robbins's Les Noces goes brilliantly through the mo tions of rustic piety and bawdi ness but stops somewhere short of total convincingness in its portrayal of peasant custom.

title: TEXAN CONVICTED OF DRAFT REFUSAL
description: HOUSTON, July 9  A 21 yearold Houston man who vol untarily surrendered his stu dent deferment from the draft in 1969 because he considered it unfair was convicted last night of refusing induction into the armed forces.

title: Net Deposit Inflow Lags
description: The net deposit inflow last month into New York State savings banks slowed to $146, 407,000 from $395,636,000 in May, the Savings Bank Asso ciation of New York State re ported yesterday. The associa tion said that the June figure was nevertheless a record for that month.

title: Friends Bid Louis Armstrong a Nostalgic Farewell at Simple Service
description: Louis Armstrong was given a fond and nostalgic fare well yesterday at a funeral service in Corona, Queens, that shunned the high notes and display of the jazz fu nerals of New Orleans, where his celebrated horn first was heard. The dominant emotion of the ceremony in the small, brick Corona Congregational Church was one of gratitude. In eulogies and prayers, ex pressions of grief were regu larly checked by reminis cences of the mirth that his presence had Inspired. We know what must be taking place in Your Kingdom, said a Franciscan priest, the Rev. William J. McManus, deliver ing the invocation, for wherever he went in this world, there was jubilation. Move over, Gabriel, here comes Satchmo, said Fred Robbins, a disk jockey and close friend of the musician who delivered the principal eulogy for Mr. Armstrong, who died Tuesday at the age of 71. Mr. Armstrong's closest associates asserted that the absence of any bands or stir ring trumpet solos from his funeral was a faithful re flection of a wish he had often expressed. Louis was a simple man, said his man ager, Ira Mangel. He wanted a simple church, simple every thingno music, no sadness. He said if he had one band, he would have to have all of them.

title: Article 6  No Title
STATE TO REHIRE 2,300 REGULARS
description: ALBANY, July 9The state announced today that thou sands of temporary and provi sional employes would be dis charged soon to make way for the return to the payroll of 2,300 workers who had been laid off despite their perma nent Civil Service status.

title: New Welding Method
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 A method of welding strips of steel, which was patented this week, is expected to save time and money for the automotive industry.

title: WESTBURY WEIGHS SUPERFECTA BETS
description: Superfecta betting, a form of wagering designed to stimulate harness racing businese, is ex pected to be available for the first time downstate when a 72night season gets under way at Roosevelt Raceway on July 23.

title: City University Post Filled
description: Dr. David Newton, acting president of York College of the City University since last September, has been named vice chancellor of the univer sity for faculty and staff rela tions. Dr. Newton will head a new office that will handle col lectivebargaining negotiations with the university's 15,000 faculty and staff members. He will assume his new post Sept. 1.

title: Most City Aides Keep PayCut Pledge
description: The last two or three of 26 highlevel city officials who joined: last year in highly pub licized voluntary. $1,000ayear pay cuts; said yesterday that they would actually turn the money over to the city, it was disclosed: when reporters raised the question.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Weather Forecasting: The, er, Cloudy Science
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I.  There was a time when finelooking women used to give the weather on television. One of them, named Tedi Thurman, even gave her own statistics. Then the medium became aware of its re sponsibilities and outgrew this sort of ribaldry. Nowadays, authoritative sounding men give the weather. This is what we call progress except for one thingyou can't depend on their forecasts either.

title: Investigation Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP)  A State Department official indicated today that both the United States and the South Vietnamese Governments were investigating Mr. Steele's charges.

title: Sergeant and Suspect Die in Shootout
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 9 A Norwalk police sergeant and a bankrobbery suspect were fatally wounded today in a gun duel during an auto chase that began, after a branch of the Connecticut National Bank here was robbed of $12,000.

title: Chrysler Lifts Truck Prices
description: DETROIT, July 9 (UPI) Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday its 1972 model trucks prices would be raised 4.1 per cent over comparable 1971 models. The company said the increase was subject to change between now and the time the 1972 models go on sale in Sep tember.

title: Officer Is Accused of Murder Attempt in Arrest
description: A police lieutenant was ar rested yesterday and charged with the attempted homicide of a woman he was arresting, and, in a separate case, two patrolmen were arrested and charged with threatening a youth they were arresting. All three men were suspended from the force.

title: HAROLD MOSSBERGER
description: HOUSTON, July 9 (AP) Harold W. Mossberger, vice president and director of ad vertising for. The Houston Chronicle, died late Thursday after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: 70 Concerns Here Cited as Polluters
description: The Department of Air Re sources reported yesterday a record crackdown on industrial air polluters here with the be ginning of showcause proceed ings against 70 plants.

title: Puerto Rican Art Museum Finally Gets Its Own Home
description: El Museo del Barrio, after two and a half years of a vagabond existence in schools and homes, now has quarters of its own in Hispanic Har lem.

title: Beman's 63 for 134 Total Ties 4 Others for Lead in Greater Milwaukee Open
description: MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP) Deane Beman, last year's win ner, carded an 8underpar 63 today but still had to share in a fiveway tie for the 36hole lead in the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tourna ment.

title: McCloskey Will Challenge President in 2 Primaries
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey Jr., a 43yearold Cali fornia Republican, announced today his candidacy for Presi dent.

title: The C. D. U. Leadership
description: Former Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger has finally bowed to the inevitable at 67 and announced that he will not seek reelection in October as chairman of West Ger many's Christian Democratic Union. This decision effec tively removes Dr. Kiesinger as the party's candidate for Chancellor against Willy Brandt in the next election. It also launches a significant phase in Federal Republic politics.

title: Bomb Blows Out Windows In City Hall in Providence
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 9 (AP)The police said a bomb blew out windows on the first two floors of City Hall tonight.

title: WILSON ACCUSES HEATH ON MARKET
description: LONDON, July 9  Harold Wilson tonight accused the Gov ernment of failing to tell the British people the true cost of entering the Common Market.

title: Lunch Money
description: A hungry child is an unanswerable argument. Whether in Pakistan or the Bronx, a malnourished child is reproach to adults and to their mistaken values.

title: Newspaper and Guild Begin Longer Sessions in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 9  Negotia tors for the Newspaper Guild and The Evening News here began a series of eighthoura day bargaining sessions today in an effort to end the strike that has kept the state's larg est evening newspaper out of circulation for the last 45 days

title: MRS. JERRY WOLMAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) Mrs. Anne Wolman, wife of the former owner of the Phila delphia Eagles, Jerry Wolman, died of a heart attack today at Doctors' Hospital. She was 41 years old.

title: N.A.A.C.P. at 62: Some Battles Won, Unity Stressed
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 9  At 62, the N.A.A.C.P. is alive and well in Minneapolis.

title: Erasing the Stigma for Household Help
description: I'm fed up with hiring people to clean my apart rnent, a New York dress buyer complained. Either they don't show up or they come and do such a slap dash job that I end up having to do it again myself. Like other wom en throughout the United States, the dress buyer has discovered that part  time help is going the way of the finger bowl and the calling card. Long hours, low pay, lack of prestige and oppor tunities in other fields are steadily reducing the num ber of candidates available for domestic work.

title: 2d Con Ed Generator Out, But Heavy Demand Is Met
description: Another generator joined Big Allis on the Consolidated Edi son Company's list of disabled power sources yesterday, but the company bought power from other utilities and man aged to survive the hot, sticky day without cutting voltage.

title: U.S. Denies Adviser Role
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (Reu ters)  The State Department denied today that any United States advisers were accom panying Laotian forces.

title: CITY STARTS MOVE AGAINST FIREMEN
description: The city moved yesterday to punish firemen who violated the Taylor Law last January by refusing to perform any normal duties except to answer fire alarms and respond to other emergencies.

title: Israeli Copter Down With 10
description: TEL AVIV, July 9An Israeli Air Force helicopter with 10 men aboard crashed into the Mediterranean off the coast of the occupied Sinai Peninsula yesterday, it was announced today. Search for the helicopter and survivors began yesterday and continued today.

title: Graebner, Drysdale Gain Finals
description: DUBLIN, July 9 (Reuters)  Clark Graebner of New York and Cliff Drysdale of South Africa qualified today for the men's singles final in the Irish open tennis championships.

title: Zoo's White Tiger Dies
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) One of the only three white tigers in the United States, Mona, died yesterday at the National. Zoo of unknown caus es. The other two, also at the National Zoo, are among only 30 known white tigers in the world.

title: POLICE REVIEWING COLOMBO ATTACK
description: Detectives investigating the shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader, are reinvestigating the entire occurrence from the start, the chief of detectives said yester day.

title: F.T.C. Blocks Bid For Post Refunds
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)  The Federal Trade Commis sion today dismissed complaint by thousands of former Satur day Evening Post subscribers who claimed they should have received cash refunds instead of substitute subscriptions when the magazine died in 1969.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. ISAAC GELLER
description: BAY SHORE, L. I. July 9 Dr. Isaac Geller, a general prac titioner, with offices in West Islip, died today apparently of a heart attack at his home here. His age wat 47.

title: Notes on People
description: Back from a vacation in Bermuda after suffering dizzy spell in New York three weeks ago, Secretary General Thant returned to work declaring that he was fully recovered. Mr. Thant, who is in his 10th year as Secretary General, the long est the post has been held by one person, said his deci sion to retire at the end of the year was irrevocable. Would he accept a draft if a tangle developed choosing his successor? I don't think so.

title: Boise Cascade Backs Out of Talks on McCall Books
description: The Boise Cascade Corpora tioni a national timber and land devalopment congoanerate, has withdrawn from negotia tions for the purchase of the Saturday Review and part of the McCall book division from Norton Simon, Inc.

title: Saigon Presses New Cambodia Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 (AP)  South Vietnamese troops pressed their new drive into Cambodia today but for a second day reported no contact with enemy units.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Art: Frei Otto's Minimal Structures Subject of Display Here
description: They call him Frei the tentmaker and roofer to the world. He's designed structures from soap bubbles, giant envelopes for cities and pneumatic tents that shelter groves of trees. His buildings, which can span acres, are made of such ma terials as plastic sheet, thin metal membranes and wire netting. And he's not un happy when his work is thrown away.

title: Dance: Japanese Mixture
description: LEE, Mass., July 9After a somewhat atypical opening last month when it presented a stringy of nonprofessional companies in conjunction with the Northeast Regional Ballet Festival, the 39th sea son of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here is now in full swing.

title: $1.7Billion of War Funds Unaccounted For in Audit
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The General Accounting Office, the Congressional, watchdog agency, has.reported that it is unable to determine how $1.7billion of $2.1billion authorized for the pacification program in South Vietnam was spent or com mitted during the threeyear period ended July 30, 1970.

title: Upstate Thieves Steal cannon in Two Moves
description: HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., July 9  It took two tries but thieves last night succeeded in stealing the Revolutionary War cannon here that was said to mark the spot where Benedict Arnold met with a spy to plot the betrayal of West Point to the British.

title: Article 2  No Title
Spear's Duo Wins Anderson Golf Medal
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 9Aided by a spectacular back nine of 29, young Rick Spears and Wayne McDonald scored a bestball round of 64 today to win the medal in the John G. Anderson memorial golf tour nament. Their sevenunderpar burst over the East course of the Winged Foot Golf Club gave them a 36hole qualifying ag gregate of 131 and a onestroke margin.

title: JAZZ ON THE HUDSON TO START O?? JULY 19
description: Jazz, which has traditionally gone up the Mississippi River, will go up the Hudson on Mon day, July 19. It will also come back down, all as part of Jazz on the River Cruise, presented by Jazz Adventures, an organization that puts on weekly noontime jazz sessions on Friday at the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street.

title: W. R. Grace Group Sets Rise on Film and Sheeting
description: W. R. Grace & Co. announced yesterday that its Hatco group will raise prices by 5 per cent on polyvinyl chloride film and sheeting, beginning July 15.

title: AN EXCHANGE OFFER EXTENDED BY ELCOR
description: The Elcor Chemical Corpora tion, Midland, Tex., has ex tended for one weekuntil July 16nits offer to exchange 1.2 million shares of common stock for $12.5million of con vertible subordinated deben tures, Roy E. Campbell, presi dent of the company, said yesterday.

title: The Days of Ruth Are Over
description: Yankee Stadium is going on wel fare. Governor Rockefeller has author ized a $24million bond issue to rescue the most famous baseball diamond in the world from the obsolescence of its 48yearold frame. It is hoped that a renovated stadium will keep the Yan kees from moving to New Jersey, im prove attendance, and serve as a kind of architectural amulet to ward off the urban decay which has ravaged the rest of the south Bronx. A renovated Yankee Stadium is all well and good, but so far no one has answered the## big question: Who's going to renovate the Yankees?

title: Israel Seeking to Bolster Ties In Western Europe and Africa
description: JERUSALEM, July 9  Is raeli diplomacy is reaching out, during the current lull in the ArabIsraeli peacemaking efforts, to solidify relations with countries not directly engaged in the diplomatic maneuvering of the Middle East.

title: Yevtushenko's Complaint
description: A decade ago, when he was writing such masterpieces as Babi Yar and Stalin's Heirs, the Soviet poet Yevtushenko seemed to many in his contry and abroad to speak as the conscience of his generation. It was the generation born during the bitter collectivization struggle of the early 1930's, the generation raised to believe that Stalin was an omniscient living god, the generation that in early maturity had to absorb the staggering psycho logical blow represented by Nikita Khrushchev's expo sure in 1956 of Stalin as the murderous psychotic that in fact he was. Yevtushenko's enormous popularity in the decade that followed Khrushchev's speech indicated how well he had spoken for millions of his contemporaries in calling for restoration of truth and justice and for practical measures to prevent new Stalin from arising in the future.

title: Colombo Is Still in Coma, With Condition Still Critical
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr. re mained in a coma and in criti cal condition in Roosevelt Hos pital yesterday, 12 days after being shot in the head.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: If Israeli and Arab in the near future are to emerga without new violence from their present impasse, a new door must be opened through which both can pass with dignity and with national selfesteem.

title: NADER STILL FINDS CORVAIR UNSTABLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, produced today what he said were more General Motors tests showing that a half million Corvairs still on the road were unstable. He renewed his charges that the company had misled the courts and Con gress by covering up the tests.

title: A condemnation, a report, a defense
description: The calamity at Mylai will be with us for some time to come, and with the U.S. Army even longer, serving as a kind of metaphor for the Ameri can way of war in South Vietnam. Seymour Hersh in My Lai 4 and Richard Hammer in One Morning in the War dealt with the facts of the massacre itself, and these three books carry the story a bit further. Two of them center on Lt. William L. Calley and the court martial, the third on the company of men who committed the killings.

title: TREVINO ENTERS RICH GOLF CLASSIC
description: Lee Trevino, the United States, Canadian and British Open champion has joined Jack Nicklaus and Charles Coody in the Westchester Classic to be played July 22 to 25 at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N. Y.

title: Casper in $165,000 Golf
description: SUTTON, Mass., July 10 (AP) Billy Casper, one of pro golf's career greats, filed his entry today for the $165,000 Massa chusetts Classic Aug. 12 to 15 at Pleasant Valley Country Club.

title: Breaking out
description: Confine a young architect in a typical oneroom studioand stand back. He's bound to burst out. Architect Clyde Rich exploded his standard Lshaped apartment into a wideopen razzledazzle of light and color with no more lethal a force than mirrors. He mirrored most of the ceiling and immediately gained a nonexistent second floor and a magical shim mer of colors and lights. We fight the rat race all day, he said. I wanted a totally different environment to come home toone where one feels uptight. And no one could in this optically stimulating space where tables of opaque and fluorescent Plexiglas seem edged in neon and the vibrant rugs and pillows float against dark walls and upholstery.

title: Up, Up and Away
description: The folks over at the Equi table Life Assurance Society are cheering on Eastern Air lines these days. And well they should in light of a loan extension agreement that was completed last week.

title: Recordings
