Yet the flat simplicity of the play's structure and its lack of any true develop ment does make it a little tedious. Also, in that worthy but foolish Athe nian, Timon, we have the dullest and least convinc ing of all Shakespearean heroes. For all this it is understandable why  once in every decade or so Timon has to be staged but it also has to be staged better than this. Gerald Freedman's direc tion seemed oddly flaccid. He is not much helped by the company. The verse speaking was the worst I have heard in Central Park for some seasons. For Walter Kerr see Page 1.

title: Canada and the Multinational Corporation
description: TORONTO  In the cur rent issue of Foreign Affairs, Raymond Vernon writes that, as a rule, tensions generated by the presence of multi national corporations are a manifestation of powerful psychic and social needs on the part of elite groups in host countries, including the desire for control and status and the desire to avoid a sense of dependence on out siders.

title: DISRUPTIVE PUPIL LEARNS TO LEARN
description: Ray, a shy 15yearold Puerto Rican youngster who lives in Brooklyn, was dismissed from several; schools because his teachers found him unstable and despaired of his ever learning anything.

title: Coins
description: THE Morgan Dollar was issued as a result of the BlandAllison Act of Feb. 28, 1878, which restored the domestic silver dollar (90 per cent silver and 10 per cent copper) to general circulation. The coin, despite a production lapse from 1905 through 1920, has had a long and interesting life.

title: Et Al.
description: Tinker is an octogenarian na tive New Yorker with a Yankee sea captain background, a law degree, some strategically lo cated Manhattan real estate, a way with Latin American busi ness (mostly railroad) ventures, a knack for collecting colorful friends, honorary degrees, gold medals, orders of merit (there is also a foundation that dis penses charities while perpetu ating his name). He did tours of duty in Mexico in the days of Obregon and Pancho Villa, in New Orleans when the Cre ole tradition was still alive, on the staff of this magazine as a columnist on rare book collect ing. An oldstyle raconteur and bibliophile, Tinker has covered some of this autobiographical material in his dozen previous books; but here he embraces his entire career for the first time, zestfully, unselfconscious ly, a bit garrulously.

title: Hospital Provides a Confidential Drug Analysis
description: A woman in Flushing the other day discovered something in her son's room that looked like a small piece of tar. The woman could not identify the substance, but she was afraid that it was an illegal drug.

title: Letter to the Editor 4  No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: Staten Island Cricket Victor
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club defeated the Chase Man hattan Bank eleven by six wickets yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island. Chase Man hattan had 69 runs, Staten Island 70 for four wickets.

title: POLL FINDS NIXON AT HIS LOW POINT
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The Gallup Poll reported today that President Nixon's popularity fell in June to the lowest level since he took office, with 48 per cent of the people approv ing of his performance and 39 per cent disapproving.

title: Music
description: TWO of the happier August musical tradi tiond  traditions by courtesy, since neither is very oldwill be resumed in a few weeks. The Mostly Mozart Festival has sched uled 25 concerts in Philhar monic Hall between Aug. 2 and 28. During much the same time the shorter Newport Music Festival in Rhode Is land, subtitled A Romantic Revival in Newport's Fabled Mansions, will be going on, this one from July 29 to Aug. 7. But there will be 28 events at the Newport Music Festi val, and those panting to hear all the unusual 19thcentury works dredged from the lower depths of that century can attend three concerts a day if they so desire.

title: Art Notes
description: HAS the Big Interna tional Art Show had it? You'd think so, judging from the poor public turnout for last summer's Venice Biennale (to say nothing of the lackluster exhibits themselves), plus the negative reactions that Braz zil's upcoming Sao Paulo Bi enal, tainted by that coun try's military dictatorship, has drawn well in advance of its September opening.

title: PAT HAWKINS SETS U.S. HURDLE MARK
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 10 (AP)Pat Hawkins of Brooklyn improved her Ameri can record in the 200meter hurdles tonight as she won in 26.1 seconds in the finals of the National Amateur Athletic Union women's track and field championships.

title: Verona Is Set for Park
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival's second outdoor pro duction is Two Gentlemen of Verona, opening July 22 at the Delacorte Theater in Cen tral Park. The classic will have music by Galt MacDermot, composer of Hair, and lyrics by John Guare, authr of The House of Blue Leaves. The cast includes Jerry Stiller, Jonelle Allen, Clifton Davis and Raul Julia. Mel Shapiro is directing. Jean Erdman is providing the choreography. The scenery is by Ming Cho Lee and the cos tumes by Theoni V. Aldredge.

title: Friends World College Has 3 Bosses
description: WESTBURY, L. L, July 10 If the three administra tors who have been running the Friends World College here should disagree, they hope to be able to work out their differences in a Quak erly manner.

title: Miss Dorothy Humphrey Married
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 10 Miss Dorothy Eyre Hum phrey, daughter of Mrs. Watts Sherman Humphrey of Princeton and the late Mr. Humphrey, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Campbell Culp Jr. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Culp of Yardley, Pa.

title: Cancer Conquest or Setback?
description: The weakness of Congress in handling a technical issue has rarely been more glaringly demonstrated than in the 79 to 1 vote by which the Senate approved the socalled Conquest of Cancer Agency. Only Senator Gaylord Nelson had the political and moral courage to oppose a move which has drawn critical fire from a large percentage of the nation's biomedical researchers.

title: N. A. A. C. P. Parley Ties Black Survival to Ability to Move to Suburbs
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 10 A major theme of this week's 62d N.A.A.C.P. convention was that the survival and prosper ity of many American Negroes will depend on their ability to, move from the inner cities to the suburbs and the areas where the jobs are.

title: Gov. Reagan to Receive Football Foundation Medal
description: Gov. Ronald Reagan of California has been named the National Football Foun dation's Gold Medal recipi ent for 1971.

title: Phils Top Expos, 20, 32
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) Rick Wise won his first game since pitching a nohitter on June 23 as the Philadelphia Phils beat the Montreal Expos, 32, tonight and completed a sweep of their doubleheader.

title: MICHAEL F. M'CARTHY
description: WILLINGBORO, N. J., July 10Michael F. McCarthy, vice presidentsales of Lewis & Co., sugar brokers of 120 Wall Street, New York, was killed yesterday in an automobile ac cident. He was 32 years old and lived at 10 Barnwell Lane.

title: Priest to Run Marathon
description: DUBLIN, July 10 (UPI)  The Irish Athletics Board today nominated Paddy Coyle, a Ro man Catholic priest stationed in Belfast, as one of its three representatives for the Euro pean championship marathon run at Helsinki in August. Fa ther Coyle won the Irish na tional title last month.

title: HUNTINGTON GETS REPERTORY HOME
description: HUNTINGTON, L,I., July 10  After eight years of strug gle, Long Island's first year round professional repertory theater staged its first perform ance here last week.

title: Scheinblum, Hendrick Head Association AllStar Team
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., July 10 (AP)Rich Scheinblum of Denver and George Hendrick of Iowa head the 18man all star team announced today by the American Association.

title: Senators Enroll Boyce
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., July 10 (UPI)Gary Boyce, a Michi gan State outfielder, signed today with the Washington Senators for a financial pack age totaling $12,000. Boyce was to report to the club's Geneva, N. Y., farm club.

title: N.Y.A.C. Crew Wins in Orchard Beach Regatta
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 10In a rowing sequence that had the makings of an episode in a Mack Sennett comedy, a rudderless New York Athletic Club crew was first across the finish line in an Elite8 Orchard Beach Lagoon race today.

title: Plumage, male and female
description: Thea Porter, the London designer who has been a pet of the inter national set for several years, has just opened a shop in New York. It's filled with the drippy chiffon fantasies that people have come to associate with her name. And there are caftans, velvet suits and printed chiffon shirts for men all rather sensuous and more than vaguely Oriental in feeling. Lions and peacocks strut in an orange and lavender pride across this chif fon dress with purple velvet binding. $350. The puffysleeved brown and peach silk organza is $200. His pea cockeried black and white chiffon shirt is $75. All at Thea PorterNew York, 203 East both Street.

title: OMBUDSMAN AIDS JERSEY PRISONERS
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., July 10 Every day, Peter R. Del Vecchio, the ombudsman for the Bergen County jail, tours the jail and its annex talking to prisoners, listening to their complaints and trying to give them personal attention that is unusual for prisoners.

title: TOP FREIGHT WINS TROT AT YONKERS
description: YONKERS, July 10Impar tiality, a word uppermost in the lexicon of most racing secre taries, was shown tonight by Ed Parker, who listed two junior freefforall events as co features on the harness program at Yonkers Raeeway.

title: Miss Hingson Bride in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH, July 10  Miss Roberta Ann Hingson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Andrew Hingson, was married here tonight to Alan Michael Gates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Gates. The ceremony in the Heinz Me morial Chapel on the Uni versity of Pittsburgh campus was performed by the Rev. Dr. Carl O. Stromee of the First Baptist Church, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Francis Wheaton.

title: Miss Mary Stout Married at Home To Colby Student
description: WEST ALLENHURST, N. J., July 10The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Stout, daughter of State Senator Stout, to Stephen Mason Foehl took place this after noon at Laneside Farm, the Stout home. The bridegroom is a son of Charles Allen Foehl of Williamstown, Mass.

title: Nebraska Kid Wins In Hunter Ciass At Jersey Event
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 10 The equestrian magic of the late Ben O'Meara, possibly the greatest jumper rider in the his tory of the show ring, still is in evidence.

title: Brookhaven Antiques Fair
description: The women's auxiliaries of Brookhaven Memorial Hospital will sponsor an antiques fair and sale from Aug. 18 to Aug. 20 at St. James Parish Hall in Brookhaven, L. I.

title: Trash Will Be Converted Into a Wall Map of Suffolk
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., July 10 Empty cans, milk containers, broken glass and wastepaper will be converted into a three dimensional, diorama map of Suffolk County by Temima Ga zari in a project sponsored by the Suffolk Museum.

title: Ecology: Pesticide Makers' Bte Noire
description: Him to kill insects and weeds, satisfy environmental ist and make a dollarall at the same timehas be come a triple headache for an increasing number of pest icide producers.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: About Motor Sports
description: Their heads are bloody but unbowed. The skeptics in sisted that they could not bring it off; yet Joe Mattioli, the board chairman, and Bill Marvel, the general manager, managed to open Pocono In ternational Raceway last weekend with the Schaefer 500. There was that enormous field of earth that, with a few days of rain, might have turned into an ocean of mud. There was the constant concern with the touchandgo condition of the track, particularly in the turns. There were all those things that could not be fin ished as Mattioli and Marvel came down to the wire.

title: Playwrights Meeting Set To Open in Connecticut
description: The seventh annual National Playwrights Conference will open tomorrow at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.

title: First Bank Since Depression
description: BOYNE FALLS, Mich., July 10 (UPI)Boyne Falls, popula tions 280, will have in operation Monday its first fulltime bank since the Depression. Robert Donner, 25 years old, a teller at a Boyne City parent bank, will be manager. He said he planned to work the threeteller facility alone until business justifies more employes.

title: Trevino Gives $4,800 to Orphanage
description: SOUTHPORT, Engiand, July 10 (UPI)  Lee Trevino re members his humble begin nings.

title: Cowboy Niland Likes Kid Rules
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (UPI)The public has heard a lot from rebellious pro foot ball players who claim the game is dehumanizing. John Niland, on the other hand, thinks bed checks, training rules and other restrictions are necessary for a winning team.

title: Newell Resigns Rockets Post
description: HOUSTON, July 10 (AP) Pete Newell resigned today as general manager of the Hous ton Rockets of the National Basketball Association. Club officials said personal consid erations persuaded Newell to remain in California.

title: For Young Readers: two American debacles
description: When the white man wins it is a battle. When the Indian wins it is a massacre. The double standard derided in this incisive Indian saying applies equally to these two volumes of surpassing scholarship and narra tive punch. Chronologically, it's a long haul from the defeat of Gen. George Custer by the Sioux and their allies in late June, 1876 and the dis aster at Pearl Harbor in December, 1941.

title: The Scarcity of Maine Lobsters Causes Price to Rise
description: BEALS, Me., July 10  A shortage of softshell lobsters has increased their prices through most of the state.

title: Suburban Babes on Broadway
description: FOR the class project, The Behavior of Mid dle  Class Women in Groups I chose to ex amine a Saturday Mat inee Club to see how the members relate to such phe nomena as the Broadway the ater, and how they behave once they leave the confines of their suburb and enter the theater district of New York. My method of observation was to join a group of women in my home suburb of Madi son, New Jersey, who had or ganized a theater club.

title: Letter to the Editor 3  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 1Legged High Jumper Is 4th in London Meet
description: LONDON, July 10 (UPI) Tony Willis, 16 years old, onelegged high jumper from Plymouth, finished fourth today in the intermediate boys' high jump with a leap of 5 feet 9 inches at the Eng lish schools athletics cham pionships.

title: Group Finds Nation Imperiled By a Widening Security Gap
description: The United States is in dan ger of becoming a secondrate power, subject to political blackmail and intimidation by the Soviet Union, the Commit tee to Unite America has warned.

title: Dodgers Sign Wilhelm, 47; Hurler Assigned to Spokane
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (UPI) The Los Angeles Dodgers to night, signed Hoyt Wilhelm, major leaguer for 20 years, to a contract with their Spokane club in the Pacific Coast League.

title: WILLIAM H. RUNYON
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 10 William H. Runyon of 863 Mar tin Street, postmaster here for 15 years and a past president of the board of police commis sioners of Elizabeth, died last night at the Alexian Brothers Hospital. His age was 73. He retired as postmaster last year.

title: LAOS DENIES THE U.S. IS DIRECTING DRIVE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 10 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Laotian Government denied today press reports that cur rent military operations in the strategic Plaine des Jarres 120 miles north of Vientiane had been planned and were being run by the United States Em bassy.

title: Search Continues for FoodCans With Signs of Botulism Toxin
description: Health Inspectors and Gov ernment officials continued searching supermarkets here and contacting grocery whole salers across the nation yester day in an effort to, track down products emanating from the Bon Vivant, Inc., plant in New ark that might contain the lethal botulism toxin.

title: Protest by Firemen Ends
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 10 (UPI)City firemen were back on the job today after most of the night shift called in sick to protest the suspen ??ions of two fellow firefighters. The two suspended firemen were accused of taking part in a work slowdown that their union has been holding since May 10.

title: Alaska Army Chief Named
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 10 (AP)The chief of staff for the United States Army in Vietnam, Maj. Gen. Charles M. Gettys, will become command ing general of the Army in Alaska in early October, the Army said yesterday. He will replace Maj. Gen. James F. Hollingsworth, who is returning to Vietnam.

title: Briton Runs 10,000 Meters In 27:47 for European Mark
description: PORTEMOUTH, England, July 10 (AP)David Bedford set a European record of 27 minutes 47 seconds for the 10,000 me ter run today and paced Britain to victory over France in an international track and field meet.

title: New Pool in Brooklyn
description: A new swimming pool in Brooklyn is open for public use, the New York City Parks, Rec reation and Cultural Affairs Administration announced. Sit uated at East New York and Stone Avenues, the facility also includes a wading pool and a bathhouse.

title: FRANK I. LIVERIGHT
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., July 10  Frank I. Liveright, a former vice president, treasurer and secretary of L. Bamberger & Co., who donated his coin col lection to the Newark Museum, of which he was a trustee, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 93 years old and lived at 132 Second Avenue.

title: HoleInOne by Spears Helps His Team Advance to Anderson Golf Semifinals
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 10A holeinone always helps in match or stroke play. Today Rick Spears holed an ace as he and his partner, Wayne McDon ald, former Canadian amateur champion, won a firstround match in the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament. Later they reached the semi final round.

title: 10 More Reputed Mafiosi Exiled to Isle Off Sardina
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, July 10 (Reuters)A second group of 10 suspected Mafia leaders is being exiled to the small island of Asinara off Sar dinia the police announced here today.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Music Mailbag
description: THIS letter is written in response to Joan Pey ser's article, Boulez: bringing 'Em Back to Life?

title: Manta, $3.20, Wins Beverly Hills by 3 Lengths and Completes Pincay Triple
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 10 (UPI)Manta raced to an easy victory in the sixth running of the $66,400 Beverly Hills Handi cap on the turf at Hollywood Park today.

title: Brasselle Held in Shooting
description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 (AP)Keefe Brasselle, who starred in The Eddie Cantor Story, was arrested today for investigation of assault with intent to commit murder, the police said. The police said Mr. Brasselle, 47 years old, was booked after a man identified as Richard B. Crawford, 29, of Los Angeles, was shot and seriously wounded in a predawn dispute in a bar in nearby Studio City.

title: An Unlikely Partnership A Success at Monticello
description: A Kurtz and Gurfein part nership might he found just about anywhere except at a race track.

title: NAMATH IS EAGER FOR A GOOD START
description: With several positives and negatives, the Jets will open their training camp at Hofstra University this week.

title: QUALIFYING SET FOR OPEN TENNIS
description: A satellite tournament that will qualify four men to com pete in the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens, this year will be held on the courts of the New York City. Parks Administration in late August. Madison Square Garden is the sponsor.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: A brisk jaunt with Fred erick A. Collins Jr. from his headquarters in the Sperry & Hutchinson Building at 42d Street and Madison Ave nue to the Skytop Club in the Pan Am Building for lunch recently was like cov ering a tour with a candi date for political office.

title: Sex Exploitation Spreading Here
description: The active field of opera tions by prostitutes, pimps and pornography dealers has spread from the Times Square area, and now ex tends from Lexington to 10th Avenue and from 40th Street to the upper 50's.

title: Nobody Said You Had to Eat Off the Floor
description: The author subtitles her man ual The Psychiatrist's Wife's Guide to Housekeeping, and no member of that unpaid so rority is likely to deny that she has touched all the bases. How to Turn a Broom Into a Dustmop, How to Shampoo a 4YearOld (a stiff highball on the bathroom shelf), Cleaning Day and How to Recover (tuna fish and a mystery novel in bed). The style is arch to the point of upchuckery: this should have run as a series of articles, on glossy stock, between the household ads.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: THANKS for Julius No vick's review of the Arena Stage produc tion in Washington of Lorraine Hansberry's The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window. Faulty as, it is, he writes, I think I love this play.

title: Bowie, Bolan, Heron Superstars?
description: FROM time to time in the history of pop music, an artist has created a rec ord that has shaken the medium to Its foundations with the force of originality, leaving its impact on every record to follow. Sgt. Pep per did that. Sweet Baby James did. Meet the Bea tles changed the whole world. But most often a per former who has something original to say is dismissed as being too far out for the gen eral public to appreciate, and he becomes, at best, the lead er of a small cult of devoted fans.

title: Dance
description: SARATOGA is one of those places I usually seem to miss, and I always mod estly regret it. IIorses and ballet, trees and greenery, handsome houses, winding roads and an openair theater that, even for someone like myself to whom openair the aters are an anathema, let alone a contradiction in terms, has surprising merit for what it is.

title: An Imperfect Peace
description: The Communist peace offensive in Paris has con fronted President Nixon with an excruciating decision: to admit that victory is beyond our grasp and to pull out of Indochina, finally and fully, leaving the fate that tormented region to contending indigenous forces.

title: Malta Seeks to Revive Once Thriving Dockyard
description: VALLETTA, Malta, July 1  The new Socialist Prime Minister of Malta, Dom Mint off, has set out to restore the good name of the island's vital drydocks.

title: Coins
description: PLANS for a concen trated drive to deter pseudo coin issues were drawn up at the annual congress of the Inter national Association of Pro fessional Numismatists, held at the Palacio Hotel in Esto ril, Portugal, recently. The IAPN delegates stressed that member dealers throughout the world take no part in transactions involving issues of doubtful legal status.

title: Education
description: In New York City, begin ning next fall, 450 teenagers will skip school for a week at a time, on and off for the entire year. And when they do go to classes, it will be without setting foot inside a school building.

title: A STUDY ON SOUND TO WEIGH SHIP BAN
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., July 10 The New England River Basins Commission, mandated by Congress to conduct a threeyear study of Long Island Sound and the land around it, will consider a series of possi bilities ranging from a total ban on commercial shipping in the Sound to the removal of Structural eyesores on the shores.

title: Una cosa de curiosit, de maraviglia, de scandalo
description: I was muoh further out than you thought, and not waving but drown ing.Stevie Smith.

title: Peter D. Voysey Plans to Wed Abigail Ordorica, WINS Aide
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 10The engagement of Miss Abigail Ordbrica to Peter Derry Voysey has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Rafael Ordorica, parents of the prospective bride. Her fiance is the son of Frank Ernest Voysey of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Mrs. Voysey.A September wedding is planned.

title: Austrian Legislators Ease Laws on Homosexuality
description: VIENNA, July 10Homosex ual relations between consent ing adults have ceased to be a punishable offense in Austria.

title: Dune Buggies: We're Even Sending One to the Moon
description: A MANHATTAN commuter from Huntington, L. I., drives one to and from the station. A pediatri cian living on Long Island takes one to his office in Manhasset.

title: Tarboosh and Second Bar Both Win by Nose in Split Stakes at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP) Calumet Farms' Tarboosh and J. C. Bryant's Second Bar won divisions of the Dragoon Stakes for 2yearolds today before a crowd of 13,631 at Liberty Bell Park race track. Each victory was by a nose.

title: Art
description: IF you happen to be a racist, a hawk, a Nazi, a crooked politican, or just a plain old sotinyourways mem ber of the capitalist bourgeoisie, I do not think you will be running much risk of getting your ideas changed if you pay a visit to the Museum of Mod ern Art's big summer exhibition, The Artist as Adversary, even though the artists represented in it have raised their voices against racism, war, fascism, political corruption, and all the com fortable delusions cherished by a con servative society.

title: Umont Is Plate Umpire For AllStar Contest
description: Frank Umont of the Amer ican League will be the home plate umpire for Tuesday night's AllStar game at Detroit, according to Com missioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: Sara Hahn Is Engaged
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 10 Robert H. Hahn has an nounced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Sara Eliz abeth Hahn, to Eric C. Vidinghoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Vidinghoff of Newtown Square, Pa. The future bride is the daughter also of. Mrs. Marion K. Hahn. Her father is a vice president of the Great American Insur ance Company. Her lianas father is a vice president with the Tasty Baking Com pany. Miss Hahn and her fianc0 are graduates of Wil liam Smith and Hobart Col leges.

title: Hospital Fund in Brooklyn Gets Campaign, Chairman
description: C. Wesley Meytrott has been named chairman or the 1971 fundraising campaign of the Brooklyn Division of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

title: Hanoi Reports Big Rice Crop
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, July 10 (Agence FrancePresse) Hanoi and its four neighboring agricultural districts this year produced the biggest winter and spring rice crops ever re corded in North Vietnam, ac cording to statistics published here today.

title: McAloon Is at Home in School or Ring
description: His name is Danny McAloon and he is a rarity in professional boxinga college graduate and a private secondary school teacher. He and his wife, Diana, have a baby son, Danny Kyle.

title: Clover
description: The clovers come to bloom and the bees are working overtime. Honeybees are humming a July song of honey for the comb. Big, lumbering bumblebees drone from clover head to head, sucking nectar from the deep throated blossoms and at the same time fertilizing them as no other insect can. Butterfliesmore butterflies than usual this year, it seemsflit and float across the mead ows and along the roadsides, pausing at one fat clover head after another for a sweet sip.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Photography
description: THE Artist as Adver sary, a huge ex hibition of more, than 400 works at the Museum of Modern Art, through Sept. 27, includes 56 photographs plus a scattering of prints, posters and collages that incorporate photographs. With the exception of Tina Modetti's Illustration for a Mexican Song, which is shown in a gallery devoted to art inspired by the Mexican Revolution, all the photo graphs are grouped together in one smallish gallery which is either the first or the last that the visitor sees, depend ing on which way he goes round.

title: Nuptials Held for Janie Bernstein
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 10Miss Janie Bernstein, daughter of Mrs. Louis Bern stein and the late Mr. Bern stein, was married here this afternoon to Ross Burkhardt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Burkhardt of New York and Bennington, Vt. Rabbi Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at Tarrytown House here where a reception for 110 guests was also given.

title: Mental Health Work Among Children in Nassau Called Inadequate
description: FREEPORT, L. L, July 10 Nassau County's public, private and voluntary resources are in adequate to meet the needs of children suffering from servere emotional problems, the direc tor of the county Mental Health Board said this week.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: General Motors dawdled along last week in the stock market as a number of re lated issues boomed ahead.

title: Ali Breaks Camp
description: CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)  Mohammad Ah broke camp to day and will leave Sunday for Houston, where he will begin the final twoweek phase of training for his bout with Jimmy Ellis.

title: Ticketron Sets Up Shop For the Weekend Golfer
description: Golfers who play courses operated by Westchester County soon will be able to drop into computerized booths to reserve teeoff times as much as a week in advance.

title: Sundae Record Claimed
description: WOOSTER, Ohio, July 10 (UPI)An 883pound ice cream sundae was eaten in 45 minutes by about 2,000 people here at a holiday fireworks display. Bob Bercaw, owner of an ice cream parlor and restaurant, claimed the world record for his crea tion, which contained 42 flavors. He said the previous record was a 667pound sundae prepared by Baskin'Robbins of, Holly wood, Calif.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: 91, Deplores 18Year Vote
description: AKRON, Ohio, July 10 (UPI) William Frew Long of near by Macedonia, who is 91 years old and the nation's oldest Mayor, believes that lowering the voting age to 18 is a dangerous experiment be cause younger persons do not have enough experience to qualify to vote. I understand their ambition, but there is a question in my mind whether they are qualified to make de cisions without the experience, said Mr. Long, who first ran for political office at age 82.

title: Bishop Mugavero Names Priests As Episcopal Vicars in Brooklyn
description: The Most Rev. Francis J. Muga??, Bishop of the Ro man Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, has named five prie??as episcopal vicars to help the diocese maintain close, regular contact with its flock of about 1.5 million churchgoers in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: OIL WINDFALL AIDS ALASKA REVENUE
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, July 10 Even though the flood of oil royalties has been held up by trouble in building a pipeline, this state's fiscal situation has remained immeasurably stronger because of the wind fall of lease sale income from the North Slope oil lands.

title: INDIANS SCORE, 32; SPLIT WITH ORIOLES
description: BALTIMORE, July 10 (AP) Mike Paul, just recalled from the minors, gained his first vic tory of the season as the Cleve land Indians turned back the Baltimore Orioles, 32, tonight and gained a split of their doubleheader.

title: Iran's Ruling Party Retains Control in the Election of Parliament
description: TEHRAN, Iran, July 10 Iran's geverning party, faced with. Only token opposition in yesterday's general cleption, was assured today of control of Parliament during the next four years.

title: Russian Says He Defected Because of Disillusionment
description: LONDON, July 10Anatoly Fedoseyev, the Soviet electron ics engineer who defected six weeks ago, said today he had decided to flee because he could no longer endure the So viet system.

title: Robert Hittle Weds Mary Langdon
description: ATHERTON, Calif., July 10 Miss Mary Anne Claggett Langdon, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. George Dorland Langdon of Salisbury, Conn., and Little Compton, R.I., was married here this afternoon to Robert Lester Hittle, son of Mrs. Carl Hittle of Pine dale, Wyo., and the late Mr. Hittle.

title: 80 Dead and Many Missing In Flooded Colombia Towns
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 10 (Reuters)At least 80 persons were reported dead today and many more were missing in heavy floods in the jungles of southern Colombia.

title: Kafka and the News
description: NEUCHATELA Czech author once told me that he understood Kafka only since his country turned Communist.

title: U.S. TO SCRUTINIZE A QUEENS PROJECT
description: The City Housing Authority began advertising for construc tion bids last week for a con troversial 840unit lowincome housing project in the middle income section of Forest Hills Queens.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Seedcorn companies, faced with the task of detasseling thousands of acres of seed corn, are willing to try a new way  saw blades wielded by helicopter.

title: U.N. BRAIN TRUST FOR COUNCIL ASKED
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10Ambassador Nsanze Terence of Burundi, who has completed his month as presi dent of the Security Council, has introduced an idea for brain trust to back up the Council with expert guidance on important problems.

title: Jersey Nuptials For Miss Pratt
description: WESTFIELD, N.J., July 10 In the Presbyterian Church here this morning Miss Susan Pratt was married to David Jan VanNess by the Rev. Dr. Frederick Christian.

title: Eurodollars: What to Do
description: Two suggestions for dealing with Eurodollar problems . . . The first is to eliminate as quickly as practicable United States balanceofpayments restrictions and con trols, thereby encouraging the return of an important segment of world dollardenominated financing to the jurisdiction of United States monetary and regulatory authorities. If this were done, a Eurodollar market would continue to exist in London and elsewhere, but prime borrowers would tend to shift dollar financing back to New York.

title: Wash, State Picks Coach
description: PULLMAN, Wash. July 10 (AP)Bab Greenwood, assist ant coach at the University of Iowa, was named head basket ball coach at Washington State University yesterday, succeed ing Mary Harshman. Harshman resigned at the end of last sea son to assume head coach ing chores at the University of Washington.

title: Robert Hamlin Jr. Weds Miss Sandra L. Killion
description: MILTON, Mass., July 10 Miss Sandra Lee Killion, a legal aide to Garrett Byrne, district attorney of Suffolk County, Boston, was married here this afternoon to Robert Tappan Hamlin Jr., who will join the Boston law firm of Nutter, McClennen & Fish.

title: Bail Fund Will Be Started For indigent L.I. Residents
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., July 10 A $2,500 fund to provide bail for indigent residents of Long Island has been established by the Society of St. Vincent de Paul in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: TV STATION FOR SALE N. Y. STATE HURRYI AGENT. X 7758 TIMES ADVT.

title: Raiders' Mix Unretires
description: OAKLAND, July 10 (UPI) Ron Mix, nine times an all American Football League of fensive tackle, told the Oakland Raiders today, he was coming out of retirement and would report to their training camp at Santa Rosa on Wednesday.

title: Arab Reported Killed in Gaza
description: GAZA, July 10 (AP)Mili tary authorities said an Israeli Army patrol shot and killed an. Arab guerrilla today after he threw a hand grenade at the soldiers at the entrance to the Nuseirat refugee camp south of here in the occupied Gaza Strip.

title: RONDON TOPS GRIFFIN ON 10ROUND VERDICT
description: VALENCIA, Venezuela, July 10 (UPI)Vicente Paul Rondon of Argentina, the World Boxing Association light  heavyweight champion, outpointed John Grif fin of the United States tonight in a 10round nontitle bout at the local bullfight forum.

title: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title
Miss Laura C. Emerson
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 10Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wil liam Austin Emerson Jr., formerly of Atlanta, of the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Laura Cole Emer son, to Sydenham Benoni Alexander Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander of Tusca loosa, Ala.

title: City College Soccer Team Lists a 12Game Schedule
description: City College's soccer team will meet 12 opponents, in cluding six Metropolitan Soc cer Conference rivals, next fall.

title: Sailing Regatta Becalmed
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 10 The 19th scheduled regatta of the season for Yacht Racing Association fleets based east of Rye was canceled today be cause of lack of wind for the Belle Haven Club event on Long Island Sound.

title: Future of BritishLed Oman Scouts Is Uncertain
description: MUASCAR AL MURQAAB, Sharja, July 1The officers at this military camp dress with Sandhurst smartness although they wear no socks. The desert outdoors has a carefully raked look, and indoors Arabic voices mingle with those of the British upper class.

title: Kathy Whitworth Cards 70 and Leads by 2 Shots With 138
description: HORSHAM, Pa., July 10 (AP) Kathy Whitworth complained that she Couldn't concentrate on her game, but she managed to shoot a threeunderpar 70 today for a 36hole twostroke lead in the George Washington Ladies Golf Classic.

title: Students Thrive at a Summer School for Skiing
description: ALTA LAKE, British Co lumbiaThe absentee rate is zero at the Whistler Moun tain summer ski school. No body wants to play hooky from teachers such as Mrs. Nancy Greene Raine and Toni Sailer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Despite the view of some observers, that Senator Gravel behaved in an un orthodox and emotional way when he tried to read a part of the Pentagon papers into the public record, I must observe that if more men wept over our past and present involvement in Indochina, perhaps this war would be endednow.

title: Lots of Lavender
description: LAVENDER that oldfash ioned, spicily fragrant perennial herb has been grown in gardens for uncountable years. The blossoms are used for mak ing sachets to be placed in drawers and closets where linen is stored as well as in potpourri jars. The whole plant with its silvery gray leaves and spikes of lavender flowers is aromatic. It isn't even necessary to touch the flower stems to release the distinctive fragrance, for on a hot, dry summer day it fills the air around the plant.

title: Marcel Proust at 100
description: Proust's mother, everyone im mediately said(and the echo is with us yet, for it was the kind of con jecture we talebearers love)  was marked before she bore him by that foolish war the inept French were diddled into waging against Bismarck and his Boche, much as the mother of Thomas Hobbes was marked, and infected the future philosopher with the fear she felt at the approach of the Spanish Armada. And cer tainly the siege of Paris was no pic nic: citizens ate the horses and the dogs, then the animals in the zoos; cats cost six francs, rats one; streets were crowded with defeated soldiers, carts of dead and wounded, insur rectionists, and, in the days before the cannonading scattered them, an audience of gossips. The section of the city where Madame Proust was shortly to seek refuge in order to procure for Marcel his welcome from the world received from Edmond de Goncourt, whose prize her son would one day win, a grim Journal in vocation: Cursed Auteuil! This sub urb will have been deprived of com munication with the rest of Paris, sacked by the Mobiles, starved out, shelled, and now is to have the mis fortune of being occupied by the Prussians.

title: The Iron Horses Build Up Steam For Summer Runs
description: WHETHER it was the lonely whistle of the afternoon local pulling into Shakers Crossing or the blast of the regal State of Maine Express roaring along beside the highway, the steam locomotive was indeed a sight to behold. The experience may seem just a thing of the past to many people these days, but, in fact, it's not too late to feel the thrill of riding behind an iron horse.

title: MRS. JANE HAYFORD; LED A PRINTING FIRM
description: PATERSON, N. J., July 10 Mrs. Jane Taylor Hayford, president of the former Pater son Rutherford Company, a printing concern, and a civic leader, died today in the Chris tian Sanitarium, Wyckoff. She was 81 years old and lived at 594 Broadway.

title: TwinsRoyals Rained Out
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 10 (AP)  The Minnesota Twins  Kansas City Royals game was postponed by rain today after a 45  minute wait beyond starting time.

title: If You Really Haven't Crawled The Pubs of Dublin, You Really Can't Say You've Seen the City
description: DUBLINIt's a great art to saunter, Thoreau said, and you can still practice it in London and in parts of New York and San Francisco (but not, I'm told, in Beverly Hills nor, as I've seen with my own eyes, on the New Jersey Turnpike). Dublin, on the other hand, may still be the golden city for saunterers.

title: Pipeline to Be Deactivated
description: ANCHORAGE, July 10 (AP) More than twothirds of the Ar my's 626mile petroleum prod ucts pipeline between Haines and Fairbanks will be deacti vated in the next weeks, the commander of the United States ArmyAlaska announced yester day.

title: Policemen in Berkeley Can Wear Hair Longer
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 10 (AP)A short haircut and a clean shave will no longer be required for policemen in this university city, where long hair and beards are common.

title: White Sox Sink Brewers
description: CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) Rick Reichardt lined a twoout single to left today in the ninth inning, driving in the winning run and giving the Chicago White Sox a 43 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: 31 DOUBLE DELTA MONMOUTH VICTOR
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 10 Double Delta, a 5yearold mare from the stable of Dryman and Greenslit, scored an 8 length victory today in the $46,375 Molly Pitcher Handicap at Monmouth Park.

title: Mentle, a Fencer Is Named Brooklyn Poly's Top Athlete
description: Henry Mentle of the fencing team at Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn has been named athlete of the year in the college's annual sports awards presentation.

title: RealtySolicitation Ban Ordered in 4 Districts
description: Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo signed an order last week that prohibits the solicitation by realestate brokers or salesmen of List ings of houses for sale or purchase in the Crown Heights and East Flatbush sections of Brooklyn and in the Cambria Heights and Laurelton sections of Queens.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: The 195th anniversary of America's emergence from colonial status has just been celebrated, but many close ties to England still remain and not the least, to some of us, are the delightful rituals and traditions involved in fishing for trout and salmon with artificial flies.

title: Field of 30 Teams to Compete In L.P.G.A. Event at Cape Cod
description: The first Ladies Professional Golf Association team cham pionship at Cape Cod starting on Thursday, will be played at two courses.

title: Home Improvement
description: THERE are many steps the homemaker can take to help keep the sun's heat out during the summer months. For those who do not have air condi tioning, these steps will serve to keep the house much more comfortable during heat spells: for those who do have air conditioning, these same practices will help to lower the cost of running their equipment, while at the same time helping the national ef fort to conserve existing fuel and energy sources (and thus help minimize the possibility of brownouts or blackouts).

title: Strand Ordway Is Bride Of Thomas R. Quesada
description: WHITE BEAR LAKE, Minn., July 10The marriage of Miss Margaret Strand Ord way, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gilman Ordway Jr., to Thomas Ricardo Que sada took place here this afternoon.

title: Councilman From Williamsburg Realizes 1944 Political Dream
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt was his heroas he was hero to just about every other Brook lyn boy in those yearsand 11yearold Leonard Scholnick carefully mapped out the route of the President's Brooklyn campaign tour that day in 1944.

title: State Fish Hatchery And Game, Farm On L.I. Are Spared
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 10The 89year old state fish hatchery here and the Middle Island Game Farm at Ridge have received a new lease on life as a re sult of legislative action in the recent session.

title: City Planning Pilot Center Giving Wide Health Tests
description: The City Department of Health is surveying its 151 dis ease and healthcare clinics with the view of eventually scrapping many in favor of centers that would test clients in one visit for a wide variety of abnormalities.

title: ROUGH SEAS CLOSE TWO BEACHES ON L.I.
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 10 The Long Island State Park Commission closed the Robert Moses State Park surf beaches to swimming at 1:15 P.M. today and the Jones Beach State Park surf beaches at 3 P.M.

title: College AllStars' Jazz Begins 9th L.I. Season
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 10 As inevitably as swallows returning to Capistrano, mu sic students that Clem De Rosahas taught over the last 10 years at Walt Whitman High School and in the Cold Spring Harbor School District No. 2 turn up on Long Island cach summer as Clem De Rosa's College AllStars. The band has been giving free outdoor concerts of bigband Jazz every summer since 1963.

title: State Aids, 9,722 Veterans
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that a record 9,722 military veterans were enrolled in state jobtraining programs in New York as of last May 31. Of that number, he said, just over 5,000 veterans were en tered in onthejob training pro grams while 4,700 others were in apprentice training. The to tal was the highest for any sin gle state in the country, Mr. Rockefeller said.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon, who says he doesn't like to interfere in the operations of the free market place, did it again last week. This time he brought the authority of his office to bear on the beginning of contract ne gotiations in the steel industry, summoning union and company officials to the White House be fore they sat down together at the bargaining table.

title: Bonn Aide Back From Israel
description: BONN, July 10 (Reuters) The West German Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, re turned tonight from Israel and said his fourday official visit there had been necessary and useful.

title: An Ode to Gowanus, The Aromatic Ditch
description: The Gowanus Canal, a richly aromatic avenue of steadily declining commerce, slices more than a mile into Brooklyn from Gowanus Bay, earning some gratitude and a great deal of enmity from those who dwell, by choice or by lot, in areas steeped in its flavors.

title: Ronan, Citing Accidents, Says He Will Seek Penn Station Control for L.I.R.
description: The chairman of the Metro politan Transportation Author ity announced yesterday that he intended to seek Long Island Railroad control over opera tions at Pennsylvania Station and of rights of way now owned by the Penn Central Company.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Governors are not the only ones using the term fiscal crisis these days. The ex pression is also heard in city halls. One Philadelphia bank er declared recently that there was a good chance at least one city would go bankrupt before long.

title: JOB DENIAL TIED TO ROSTOW VIEWS
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 10, (AP) A selection committee once con sidered Walt W. Rostow, Johnson Administration aide, for a.'dean's position at the Uni versity of Texas but decided against him, partly because of his association with the hawk Position on the Vietnam war, according to correspondence disclosed here.

title: Giants and Jersey Agency at Odds Over Doming of Proposed Stadium
description: Discussion over the ad visability of a domed foot ball stadium in the planned $200 million sports complex in New Jersey is among the unresolved issues in the ne gotiations between the New York Giants and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, According to sources close to the negotia tions, the authority would prefer a domed stadium, but the Giants want it open. Wellington Mara, owner and president of the Giants, has argued that fans enjoy re calling games played in freezing weather, even if they didn't particularly enjoy it that day. Mara also con siders weather an intrinsic part of a football game. In the preliminary design of the East Rutherford complex by the architectural firm of Ewing Cole Erdman and Eu bank in Princeton, N. J., the football stadium has no roof. The football stadium would have a seating capacity of 75,000; the baseball stadium 55,000, and the indoor arena 20,000. The race track would have a capacity of 60,000, with about 20,000 seats. Oth er plans for the 600acre site include an exposition hall, a hotel and parking for 30, 000 cars.

title: Green Thumbs Grow in the Botanic Garden
description: Radishes are growing in Brooklyn, as are cabbages and carrots, beets and beans, scallions and squash. Egg plant, celery, parsley and peas are also maturing, and, before the summer is over, there will be a grand harvest of tomatoes and peppers, cu cumbers and corn.

title: Books:
description: PSYCHO  CYBERNETICS AND THE STOCK MARKET. By Claude N. Rosenberg Jr. Playboy Press. 224 pages. $6.95.

title: Iranian Bus Crash Kills 17
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 10 (Reuters)Seventeen persons were killed and 25 others in jured when a passenger bus collided with a truck yesterday between Teheran and Zenjan, northwest of the capital, it was reported today.

title: LINDSAY APPOINTS PANEL TO SURVEY CITYSTATE LINKS
description: A ninemember city commis sion to investigate statecity relationships was appointed yesterday by. Mayor Lindsay, who first publicly proposed such a panel on the same night that the state decided to inves tigate his administration.

title: The Nation
description: Rather than the story of O or J or M, this will be the story of, let us say, I, another initial intended to pro tect the innocent from scandal and preserve anonymity: To be sure, I is almost the strait laced reverse of those other curved letters of the alphabet But last week, following Mayor Lindsay's announced crackdown on prostitution in midtown Man hattan, I decided to, stroll up Eighth Avenue from 42d Street to test the climate for himself.

title: Anne Todd, Artist, Is Wed in Bedford
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., July 10 Miss Anne Hampton de Pey ster Todd and Frederick Horny Osborn 3d, both de scended from Jacobus Van Cortlandt, grandfather of John Jay, the first Chief Justice of the United States, were married here this after noon in the forest chapel of St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: Jim Prench Takes Dwyer And Pays $4 at Aqueduct
description: Jim French, Frank Caldwell's persistent colt who has been running with the best of them all year, finally managed to win a race yesterday. The sturdy 3yearold captured the $81,700 Dwyer Handicap after a stirring stretch duel with the Rokeby Stable's Farewell Party, whom he beat by three quarters of a length.

title: Failing Eysight Forces Tony Conigliaro to Retire
description: BOSTON, July 10 (AP) Tony Conigliaro, one of base ball's most feared sluggers un til this season, abruptly an nounced his retirement at the age of 26 today, claiming fail ing eyesight and other ail ments had curtailed his effec tiveness.

title: The Carrion Eaters
description: These are human scavengers who descend on the dismem bered carcass of the British Raj, circa 1947, to carry away what they can of the remains. Their focus in this wellexe cuted swashbuckler is one of those convenient Himalayan kingdomshere called Chan that offers blue chip rewards to successful predators, in cluding mineral wealth and more rubies and emeralds than you will find on West 47th Street. To complicate a fear fully complex situation, the Hindu prince of Moslem Chan is pretty crazy. Now go on with the story, as they used to say in the magazine serials. Enter exR.A.F. Wing Commander Tom Kinsman, the prince's pilot and a soldier of misfortune too damn nice to execute a suc cessful caper. Enter Martin Christok, a smarmy Sidney Greenstreet. Enter brassy Oona Kane, a princehunting vamp. Enter the Government at New Delhi, and a few regiments of infantry. This is the stuff that good commercial fiction is made of, and Mr. Ballinger handles it nicely.

title: LANCERS TRIUMPH OVER COSMOS, 32
description: ROCHESTER, July 10The North American Soccer League defending champions, the Roch ester Lancers, increased their firstplace lead in the Northern Division tonight with a 32 vic tory over the New York Cos mos before 8,523 fans at Aqui nas Stadium.

title: Connecticut Test Due
description: NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 10 The New Haven Legal Assist ance Association has initiated court action here and in Hart ford to test the constitutional ity of Connecticut's oneyear residency requirement for wel fare recipients.

title: Miss Hannah Biddulph Engaged To Wed Michael Robert Bruce
description: Mr. and Mrs. C. Ashrcead Biddulph of St. Croix, Virgin Islands, and Montclair, N. J., have announced the en gagement of Mr. Biddulph's daughter, Miss Hannah Hard ing Biddulph, to Michael Rob ert Bruce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic John Bruce of New York and Nassau Point, L. I.

title: GRADUATES SHIFT ON MEDICAL OATH
description: MIAMI, July 10For the sec ond consecutive year, graduates of the University of Miami Medical School have recited the Oath of Maimonides instead of the traditional Oath of Hip pocrates upon receiving their medical degrees.

title: Horse Show News
description: When Dr. Columbus Gan genii decided to start a horse show at Gaudeamus Farms in Doylestown, Pa., seven years ago, he envisioned the event growing fast.

title: Loudon Wainwright At Gaslight Evokes Dylan Comparisons
description: Loudon Wainwright 3d, with longer hair and a slight beard but the same baggy old pants and shirtsleeves, finishes an engagement Monday evening at the Gaslight, 152 Bleecker St.

title: BIG ALLIS GETTING READY FOR A TEST
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany completed reassembly of its problemchildBig Allis, the millionknowatt generator  yesterday afternoon, and began mechanical turning of the unit's shaft and rotor before attemp ting steam and electrical tests.

title: Little Signs Broncos Pact
description: DENVER, July 10 (AP)Floyd Little recovered from a hairline fracture in his back, has signed a contract for another two years with the Denver Broncos of the National Football League. Terms of the running back's pact were not disclosed.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe recent spate of special missions overseas by highranking U.S. officials emphasizes again that in major areas of diplomatic decision making the American President tends often to ignore his Secretary of State.

title: The Nation
description: Everyone's saying the music's for freethat's the line from a recent rock album by singer David. Crosby. But there have been signs that rock music can be expensive, toonot only in terms of tickets, but also in the toll of deaths, destruction of Property, drug abuse and general misery that seems to accompany today's rock festivals. The mass youth gatherings that were once so refreshint like an unexpected sea cruise, are going down like the Andrea Dorea.

title: WEBSTER RATES OFFENSE STRONG
description: As impatient as the wildest eyed fan to get a new football, season started, and bursting with plans and moderate op timism, Coach Alex Websteri will get his first group of New York Giants into action this week at C.W. Post College in Brookville, L.I.

title: Klein Joins Harvard Staff
description: Elliot Klein, a 28yearold as sistant soccer coach at Nassau Community College for three years, has seen named assistant soccer coach at Harvard.

title: Funseth, With 201, Milwaukee Leader
description: MILWAUKEE, July 10Rod Funseth, his short game work ing to perfection, took a one stroke lead today after the third round of the $125,000 Greater Milwaukee Open golf tournament.

title: Cocker Spaniel Is Best in Farmington Show
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., July 10A silverbuff cocker span iel, Ch. Sagamore Toccoa, known to her owner, Mrs. Peggy Westphal of Bedford, N. Y., as Bunny, proved the best of 1,241 dogs at the 23d annual show of the Farming ton Valley Kennel Club today.

title: Ft. Greene's Brownstoneurbia, Where Color Lines Are Fuzzy
description: Two years ago Warren Adams, a Queens homeowner, moved to the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn to cut down commuting time to his Manhattan job.

title: WAKE FOREST MAN HEADS HONOR TEAM
description: Jim Simons of Wake Forest, the standout amateur of the United States Open; the first freshman, Ben Crenshaw of Texas, and three repeaters were among nine golfers: named for the 1971 allAmer lean collegiate golf team to be honored at the Americana Hotel on July 20.

title: 5 V. A. Pilot Clinics Still Experirrzenting on Drug Addiction Cures
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich. After six months of experiment ing with various combinations of cures for drug addiction, the Veterans Administration's five pilot clinics are still experi menting.While each clinic is free to operate as it chooses, most have their patients on some form of methadone therapy. That is, addicts receive mea sured doses of addictive metha done to wipe out their craving for heroin while undergoing continuous therapy, from psy chiatric to vocational, to get at the emotional root of their addiction.

title: Sewage Imperils Some Beaches in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, July 10Though ocean beaches along the New Jersey shore have re mained relatively free of sewage pollution, the effluent trom sewagetreatment plants and the drainage from thou sands of septic tanks are creat ing health problems in some coastal rivers and bays.

title: Queens Residents Score Board Head
description: Angry black residents of the South JamaicaSt. Albans area of Queens have charged the white chairman of their com munity board, with a conflict of interest on a public hous ing project.

title: LeftLeaning Bloc in Uruguay Mounts Vote Drive
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 9There is a new political force in Uruguay that has been called, depending on personal viewpoints, the country's last and only chance to avoid civil war, a new method of revo lutionary mobilization and a Trojan horse that could bring Communists to power here.

title: Made by a volcano, saved
description: This is a fine book of extraordinary breadth, rich as are the islands in all manner of life, and compressed with unity into the small boundaries of a book as the island life is com pressed into a few seabound miles. But with patterns that represent all the world.

title: Messersmith Notches First Shutout of Year as Angels Top A's, 30
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 10 (AP)Andy Messersmith, an AllStar Game pitcher, hurled his first shutout of the season today to give the California Angels a 3.0 victory over the Oakland A's.

title: CATER BATS IN TWO
description: Having saluted the glories of the past, the New. York Yan kees then confronted the reali ties of the present before 43,433 persons at Yankee Sta dium yesterday. And they showed a nice flair for the dra matic, scoring three runs in the eighth inning to turn back the Boston Red Sox, 53.

title: Curry, British Champion, Sees Skating as Art
description: John Curry, the British figure skating champion and his teach er, Peter Dunfield, have said that there is a very thin line between art and athletics in competitive skating. They try to cross that line six days a week at the Sky Rink on West 33d Street near 10th Avenue.

title: CRAM ADVANCES IN STATE TENNIS
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 10Paul Cranis of New York, the division's national clay champion, led the field into the third round of the New York State claycourt tennis championship for men 35 years and over by routing Arthur Fischer of Brooklyn, 60, 60, at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: Headliners
description: Female First

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: POST'S FERGUSON SIGNS WITH UTAH
description: GREENVALE, N.Y., July 8 Jack Ferguson, the lone sen ior starter on the 197071 C.W. Post college basketball team, has signed a professional con tract with the American Bas ketball Association champion Utah Stars. He is scheduled to report to the team's rookie camp in midAugust.

title: Ties to Washington
description: Goldman, Sachs & Co., perhaps more than most Wall Street investment banking firms, has maintained strong ties with Washington.

title: Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: A Caretaker's Homecoming?
description: The scene is a small antique shop somewhere on the outskirts of London. Potts, the owner, is sitting in his seat. He never leaves this seat throughout the play. A woman enters. She is in her forties. She is English. It's very cold out.

title: 60 Report to Oilers
description: KERRVILLE, Tex., July 10 (UPI)All 60 early arrivals at the Houston Oilers' camp passed their physicals today as the team opened training. Coach Ed Hughes put the squad through a mile run. Bill Fisher, a freeagent defensive back from San Fernando Valley, posted the fastest time, 4 min utes 25 seconds.

title: Minority on House Panel Issues a Report on C.B.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) A minority of the members of the House Commerce Com mittee believe it is unneces sary as well as unconstitu tional to require the Co lumbia Broadcasting System to submit to the committee un televised material it, gathered for its documentary The Sell ing of the Pentagon.

title: Stamps
description: To encourage a world wide battle against ra cial discrimination, the General Assembly of the United Nations in De cember, 1969, designated 1971 as International Year to Fight Against Racism and Racial Discrimination. A number of countries have already issued stamps on the theme and others are plan ning to do so.

title: Letters To the Travel Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: M. C. Madden to Wed Miss Marcia J. Brown
description: MEXICO, N. Y., July 10 Miss Marcia Jean Brown, director of the Episcopal School in New York, and Michael C. Madden plan to be married in September. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Brown, parents of the bridetobe.

title: The Buried Life
description: Midge Turk (formerly Sister Agnes Marie) was one of the teaching Hollywood Nuns; she defected after 18 years of the buried life and became college editor of Glamour Maga zine. She was convinced that she wanted to do something noble and worthwhile when she took her vows as a teen ager. She found herself ques tioning the religious life, how ever, when the problems of the MexicanAmerican ghetto where she taught proved out of reach. Her ideas landed her in trouble with the authorities, and the conflict made her ill. This is a sprightly story but only skin deep. Also, mission life doesn't seem so bad as her title sug gests.

title: If Today's Sunday, This Must Be . . .
description: WASHINGTONWith a major foreign affairs review under way at the western White House in San Clemente, Calif., the President's men are fanning out across the world seeking informa tion, policy ideas, political support and diplo matic agreements.

title: STEWART EXCELS
description: CINCINNATI, July 10The Mets continued slipping through the National League tonight as they dropped their ninth deci sion in their last 10 games, this one by a 42 score to Wayne Simpson and Clay Carroll of the Reds.

title: NIXON NAMES GROUP ON EMPLOYE SYSTEMS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 10 (AP)President Nixon has named a 15member advisory council that will recommend ways in which the Federal Government Can work with state and local governments to strengthen their personnel systems.

title: Fresh Air Fund Puts 2,800 in Camp
description: FISHKILL, N. Y.  The sail boats running before the wind here on Beaver Lake this sum mer will be manned by hun dreds of boys and girls from impoverished communities of New York.

title: The Calley Case ReExamined
description: AT Fort McPherson, Ga., bead quarters of the Third Army, two military lawyers have be gun combing the 5,070 pages and 800 exhibits composing the case of the United States v. First Lieut. William Laws Calley Jr. By the middle of this month at the earliest, and possibly as late as Labor Day, they will submit a recommendation for legal action to the Third Army commander, Lieut. Gen. Albert O. Connor.

title: Women Organize for Political Power
description: WASHINGTON, July 10More than 200 womenRepublicans, Democrats and independents met today to inaugurate a new organization aimed at increas ing the number of women hold ing public office.

title: Darts Subdue Tornado, 21
description: DALLAS, July 10 (AP) Warren Archibald scored one goal and set up the other as the Washington Darts posted a 21 victory over the Dallas Tornado tonight.

title: Moon Soil Is Traded
description: HOUSTON, July 10 (UPI)  Moon soil samples returned from the Sea of Fertility by the Soviet Union's Luna 16 will be distributed among 24 United States scientists, officials at the Manned Spacecraft Center said today. American scientists exchanged three grams of moon soil returned by Apollo 11 and Apollo 12 for an equal measure of the Luna 16 soil returned Sept. 24 by the mechanical lender.

title: Claire Joseph Is Bride of Donald R. King
description: Miss Claire Joseph and Donald Raymond King were married yesterday afternoon at the Siloam Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn by the Rev. Dr. Milton Galamison.

title: Manila Asks Taiwan's Troops To Quit South China Sea Island
description: MANILA, July 10The Gov ernment of the Philippines an nounced today it had taken steps to protect its interests in a group of islands and coves in the South China Sea that the Filipino explorer, Tomas Cloma, claimed in the early nineteen fifties and gave the name Freedomland.

title: Reds' Mission Now: Saving Face
description: CINCINNATI, July 10What can you say about a baseball team that died?

title: 9 G.I.'s Are Injured In Korea as Blacks Raid 4 Village Bars
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 10 A United States spokesman announced today that the Amer ican and South Korean author ities were investigating an inci dent in which about 100 Amer ican Negro soldiers armed with knives and clubs raided four bars in a village 35 miles south of Seoul last night.

title: Oyler to Captain Trackmen
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 10 John Oyler, a 21yearold senior from Biglerville, Pa., has been elected to captain Princeton University's 197172 varsity track team. A varsity letter winner in track and cross country, Oyler has stood out in the middle distance events for the Tiger track squad.

title: Music
description: CELEBRATION OF LIFE, the Louisiana pop festival that promised to be the year's major gathering of the tribes, collapsed halfway through a scheduled eight day run near the town of McCrea. The festival, which was forced by law suits and threats of violence to vacate three previous sites in Mis sissippi and Louisiana before settling on a 700acre, tree less cow pasture owned by Baton Rouge lawyer Ralph Kelton, was more a crash course in survival training for its nearly 70,000 partici pants than the idyllic week in the country planned by its promoters.

title: Child for the Nivens
description: A daughter was born June 25 to Mr. and Mrs. James Graham Niven of New York at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Niven, the former Miss Fer nanda Wanamaker Wetherill, is the daughter of Mrs. Wa.na maker Leas and Francis Dring Wetherill of Phila delphia. Mr. Niven, the son of David Niven, the actor, is with Lehman Brothers, in vestment bankers. The child, a descendant of John Wana maker, founder of the Phila delphia department store, has been named Fernanda Wana maker Niven.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Is This All there Is to Show Biz?
description: A FEW things you've always wanted to know about the theater but were too intelligent to ask:

title: Gardens
description: SOME of the best wild flowers for garden use bloom in the summer. Admittedly, they are harder to grow than standbys like petunias and daylities, but with a few simple pre cautions they thrive under cultivation. And they add color, variety and inter est when the garden needs them most.

title: Art
description: IN his famous essay on Constantin Guys, The Painter of Modern Life, Charles Pierre Baudelaire placed Guys among those other delightful artists who, though depicting nothing but the familiar and the charm ing, are in their own way no less serious historians. A few of them have even sac rificed too much to charm, and have . . . rounded their angles, smoothed the rough edges of life and toned down its flashing highlights. Less skillful than they, (Guys) . . . has deliberately fulfilled a function which other artists have scorned and which it needed above all a man of the world to fulfill.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In the helicopter hovering above the New Jersey meadows, Sonny Werblin glanced at the nearby New York skyline.

title: Colleen Pelleriti to Wed
description: MIAMI, July 10Lieut. Col. Richard V. Pelleriti, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Pelleriti have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Colleen Mary Pelleriti, to Capt. Carl P. Parlatore of the Air Force. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Parlatore of Plainview, L. I.

title: Books:
description: THINK, IT IS YOUR MONEY! or HOW TO SUC CESSFULLY SOLVE MONEY AND INVESTMENT PROS LEMS THRU GAME THEORY. By Leon H. Nissimov. May house. 40 pages. $3.

title: 2d Suspect in Norwalk Slaying Gives Himself Up to the Police
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 10 The second suspect in the murder yesterday of a police sergeant surrendered this morn ing at the home of a police lieutenant about a mile from the scene of the shootout fol lowing a bank robbery.

title: G.A.O. FAULTS SYSTEM USED BY POST OFFICE
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) The General Accounting Of fice said yesterday that the Post Office Department rushed into service in 1966 an automa tic system of collecting payroll and mail volume information that cost more than double the original estimate and that has proven largely ineffective.

title: Editorial Cartoon 2  No Title
American Explorer Will Seek Early Man in Amazon Jungle
description: MEXICO CITY, July 10An American explorer, Gene Savoy, who won fame as the discov erer of a city of the Incas in Peru in 1964, is to set off shortly on an ambitious ex pedition to the Amazon to try to prove his theory that Amer ican man originated in the jungles east of the Andes.

title: TAMPERING FEARED IN SIRHAN EVIDENCE
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (UPI) The District Attorney said today he was terribly con cerned about the possibility that the physical evidence used to convict Sirhan B. Sirhan of the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy had been tampered with.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: INVESTORS in large numbers continued to huddle under a cloak of caution last week, waiting for some concrete developments in the economic or political realm to motivate a pronounced new trend in the secu rities markets.

title: Tennis Site Switched
description: SOUTH ORANGE. N. J., July 10 (UPI)  The North Jersey junior tennis championships, scheduled for Mount Freedom on Monday, have been trans ferred to the Orange Lawn Ten nis Club in South Orange on North Ridgewood Road.

title: What's New In Poppies?
description: WINTERhardy, pest free, thrifty and gaily colored, pop pies are hard to beat. Among numerous kinds, three are most popular to day: Oriental poppy (Papaver orientale); Iceland poppy (P. nudicaule) and Shirley pop py, a strain of the common field poppy of Europe, P. rhoeas.

title: Carol Fallon to Marry
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 10Mr. and Mrs. John Nor ton Fallon have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Grace Fallon, to Peter Jeremiah Maloney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Maloney. Miss Fal lon is a senior at Marymount College in Tarrytown. Her father is an assistant vice president of the New York Telephone Company. Mr. Ma loney is a senior at St. Bona venture College.

title: SCHWARZLER WINS LIDO 14 SAIL RACE
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., July 10 Although he was about a min ute late getting across the start ing line Bob Schwarzler closed in on the 11 other boats in his class today and just beat Dr. Adrian Spitz at the finish line to capture the Lido 14 Class Race. A fleet of 150 assorted carft are participating in the invitation regatta of the Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club, which concludes tomorrow.

title: Dostoevsky
description: To the Editor:

title: Newcombe, Okker Win
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 10 (AP)The Wimbledon cham pion, John Newcombe of Aus tralia, advanced to the final of the Swiss international tennis championship today by defeat ing Ismail ElShafei of Egypt, 62, 63, 64.

title: Three Phases of Adulthood: Transitions Termed as Difficult as Adolescence
description: TOPEKA, Kan.Psychiatrists, long concerned with the phases individuals grow through from infancy to adulthood, are now learning that there are three distinct phases of adulthood be tween which the transition pe riods can be as, stormy and dif ficult as adolescence.

title: CARDS' 2RUN 9TH TOPS ASTROS, 65
description: ST. LOUIS, July 10 (UPI) Jose Cruz singled home Joe Torre to cap a tworun rally in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight and give the St. Louis Cardinals a 65 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: The Nation
description: JERSEY CITY  Nobody can quite believe it yet, said an old Jersey City political ob server, commenting on the con viction last week of practically the entire political hierarchy of Jersey City and its appendage, Hudson County. The disbelief, it should be made clear, had nothing to do with the dis covery that public office has been used for private profit, this has long been taken for granted in Jersey. City. It is the guilty verdicts that have stunned lotel pundits.

title: ARTHUR K. WINGET TEXTILE OFFICIAL
description: ALBEMARLE, N. C., July 10 (AP)Arthur Knox Winget, a former president of the Ameri can Cotton Manufacturers In stitute, died Thursday at the age of 88.

title: PIERREPONT SCHREIBER
description: SPRINGFIELD, N. J., July 10  Pierrepont D. Schreiber of 271 Short Hills Avenue, a former member for many years of D. E. Coppet & Co., a New York brokerage house, died Thursday at Overlook Hospital, Summit, after a brief illness. His age was 76. He retired in 1967.

title: WILLIAM M'ROSSIE
description: William MacRossie, a real estate consultant and apprais er, died Friday evening in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 850 Park Avenue.

title: C. I. Wallace Jr. Weds Betsy Sargent
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 10 Miss Betsy Sargent, Baugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. George Andrews Sargent of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married in Calvary United Methodist Church this afternoon to Charles Isaac Wallace Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Wallace of Annapolis.

title: Yakima, Wash., Woman Wins 25th Powder Puff Air Race
description: BATON ROUGE, La., July 10 (UPI)Gini Richardson of Ya kima, Wash., flying solo, was declared the official winner to day in the 2,400mile transcon tinental Power Puff Derby. She outraced 144 other women pilot to win the $10,000 first place prize.

title: After Mao, What?
description: CAMROSE, CanadaSince return ing from my recent visit to China, I am frequently asked,: After Mao, what? and After Mao, who?

title: Big Cargo Ship Christened
description: QUINCY, Mass., July 10 (AP) The S. S. Doctor Lykes, said to be, the world's largest com mercial dry cargo ship, was christened today at the Quency Shipbuilding division of the General Dynamics Corporation. The 875foot ship was built for Lykes Bros. Steamship Com pany, Inc., of New Orleans.

title: FIRST JOHNSON FILES MAY OPEN NEXT YEAR
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 10 (AP) The first papers available to researchers from former Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson's files will concern educational mat ters during his Administration and may be available in 1972.

title: New Faces Abound As Giants Start Camp at C. W. Post
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 11 Although in his third season as coach of the Giants, Alex Webster's first fullscale train ing camp began officially at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: Threat to Medical Research
description: The medical research community of New York City is understandably alarmed by the scheduled demise of the Health Research Council. Begun in 1958 by Mayor Wagner, the Council has been a mechanism by which New York City and New York State provided small but highly essential seed money for the city's outstanding medical researchers. The few million dollars spent an nually have provided the bases which permitted investi gators to do work that attracted many millions of dollars of other research funds to the city. Few municipal invest ments have been so profitable from a purely economic point of view.

title: 17 Indians Die at a Well
description: JAIPUR, India, July 11 (Reu ters)Twelve children and five women were killed and six more persons were injured last Thurs day when a platform over a well collapsed about 80 miles from this northwestern Indian town, it was reported today. The accident occurred during a wellworshipping ceremony fol lowing the birth of a on to a villager.

title: Gisbert Victor in Final
description: MUNICH, July 11 (AP)Juan Gisbert of Spain won the men's singles title in the Bavarian in ternational tennis champion ships today when he defeated Peter Szoeke Hungary, 6.2, 64, 64.

title: Italians Restriction On Export of Shoes To. U.S. Buoys Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) President Nixon is reported to believe that an Italian Gov ernment decision to restrict shoe exports to the United States may have solved a prob lem for the American shoe in dustry and relieved some of the pressure for Congress to impose import limitations.

title: Mets Lose 2, Trail by 10
description: The Mots lost two games to the Reds in Cincinnati yes terday, 72 and 53, and fell 10 games behind the Pitts burgh Pirates, the leaders of the National League Eastern Division. (Details on Page 35.)

title: Theater: Sound of Music Is Back
description: The dunes, the ones at Jones Beach, are alive again with The Sound of Music. And why not?

title: They Drank Wines at Lunch, Dinner and in Between
description: PARISIn Bordeaux and the surrounding vineyards, the problem for several thou sand people recently was one of pacing. If it had merely been a case of one dinner, the problem would have been simple. It was not difficult to take the Chateau Lavine HautBrion 67 with the cold salmon; the Cuvde de la Commanderie (a Medoc blend) 67 with the ragout of squab; the Chateau Maucaillou 66 with the beef; the Chateau Lanes san 64 with the cheese and the Chateau Lafon 69 with the vacherin dessert.

title: Atoms Set World Mark
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., July 11 (UPI)A mile relay team representing the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn set a world record of 3 minutes 33 8/10 seconds last night in the na tional Amateur Athletic Union women's track and field meet.

title: Mrs. Charlotte David Is Wed in Tarrytown
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July. 11The marriage of Mrs. Charlotte E. S. David of Port Chester to Morton Belove of White Plains took place at the Hilton Inn here today.
