title: Van Heflin Still in Hospital; Condition Remains Critical
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 12 (AP) Van Heflin, who suffered heart attack while swimming more than a month ago, was reported still in critical condi tion today at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital here.

title: New Zealand Critical
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 12Prime Minister Keith Holyoake implicitly criticized the United States today after it had refused to make available a copy of the Pentagon report on the war in Vietnam.

title: U.S. Judge Enjoins State On Relief Residency Rule
description: BUFFALO, July 12A Fed eral District Court judge here ordered the state today to stop enforcing its new oneyear resi dency requirement for welfare applicants until a trial could be held to determine if the require ment is constitutional.

title: ANDERSON SHRUGS AT ELLIS REMARK
description: DETROIT, July 12 (AP)  Manager Sparky Anderson of the National League AllStars, will open tomorrow night's game against the American League with Dock Ellis, despite the Pittsburgh pitcher's recent remark that he had no chance to be named the starter.

title: Giant Rookies Advised to Stay Loose
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 32  Did you bring your shoes? Sid Moret asked a Giant rookie today as camp opened.

title: A General Looks at Media Reporting
description: Following is Gen. Bruce K. Holloway's testimony to a subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee of March 23:

title: Santa Maria Drums Set Latin Jazz Pace At Metropole Shows
description: The Metropole, the long, narrow, mirrorlined room on Seventh Avenue just north of Tim'es Square that housed a wide variety of jazz from Dixie land to big bands before it installed the topless GoGo girls who now perform on the platform behind its bar, is getting back into the jazz field. This time it is trying Latin jazz.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: LOOKING FOR A NEW JOB? See our Knight on Page 14. First Investors Corporation ADVT.

title: F.T.C. COMPLAINT ACCUSES GROLIER
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 The Federal Trade Commission accused. Grolier, Inc., today of a wide range of deceptive practices in the sale of en cyclopedias and other publica tions.

title: Atoms Club Ties for First After Protest in A.A.U. Meet
description: A protest was filed and al lowed against the Chicago club's entry in the 880yard medley relay that had finished third. It was ruled an illegal runner had competed for the Chicago team and its was dis qualified, moving the Atoms up from fourth to third in the event.

title: Mission Derided in Cairo
description: CAIRO, July 12The mission of two United States diplomats to seek a formula for an Israeli pullback from the Suez Canal and a reopening for the waterway was scored here to day as a theatrical play.

title: Michael Ling Is Cleared For Supervised Position
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would permit Michael F. Ling, who has been accused of securities fraud, to be em ployed by the Institutional Equity Corporation or a similar organization, provided he is supervised.

title: Noguchi's Rescue of a Samurai House
description: When Isamu Noguchi was told two years ago that an 18thcentury samurai's house was about to be destroyed to make way for a road, the lean, intense sculptor who calls New York City his home but also spends part of each year in Japan and Italy, said he wasn't interested in saving it.

title: Big Board Chiefs Start Drive for New Rates
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 The New York Stock Exchange launched today its appeal for higher sales commissions for its members with the argument that brokers needed larger prof its if they were to attract the additional investment capital they would need for stable fu ture operation.

title: First National City Increases Profit
description: The First National City Cor poration, parent of New York's largest bank, reported yester Iday a 19.4 per cent profit in crease for the second quarter. This was in sharp contrast to the yeartoyear declines at its competitors that have reported so far.

title: Advertising:
description: Usually J. Walter Thompson, with the openhanded ness befitting the world's largest agency, celebrates a new account with free coffee for all hands. Yesterday all hands got the freebie without the new business, and an explanation from Dan Seymour, the boss.

title: PENNSY HEARING SET ON CANADIAN CLAIMS
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Phila delphia set yesterday a hearing for July 22 on a plan by the trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company for handling claims of Canadian creditors.

title: Nixon Appoints 3 to Panel
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 12 (AP)President Nixon ap pointed three new members to day to the Commission on High way Beautification, which keeps tab on policies and practices in outdoor advertising and junkyards. The appointees are Alfred Bloomingdale, chairman of the board, AB Enterprises, Los Angeles; Marion Fuller Brown, member of the Maine Legislature, and Michael Ra puano of Newton, Pa., land scape architect.

title: DRUG SMUGGLING LAID TO CAFE MAN
description: A partner In a Manhattan restaurant was held in $50,000 bail in Federal District Court yesterday on an indictment charging him with plotting to smuggle cocaine into this coun try concealed in hollow wooden table tops.

title: Heath Asserts Parliament Will Back Market Entry
description: LONDON, July 12Prime Minister Heath said today that he was completely confident of winning Parliament's ap proval for British entry into the European Common Market.

title: U.S. Emerges as the Sole Supplier of Arms to the Indonesians
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 12The United States has emerged as Indonesia's exclu sive supplier of aims, and this year's requested militaryaid budgetdeclassified recently in Washingtonwould put In donesia among the top recipi ents of such aid.

title: MARJORY GENGLER JERSEY NET VICTOR
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., July 12Marjory Gengler of Locust Valley, L. I., the East's No. f ranking player, advanced today in the New Jersey State worn en's tennis championship with a 60, 60 rout of Mary Heiny of Oakland at the East Orange Tennis Club.

title: ALLENDE SIGNS BILL TAKING U.S. MINES
description: SANTIAGO, July 12Presi dent Salvador Allende Gossens signed today the constitutional reform passed by Congress yes terday nationalizing large cop per mines in which United States companies have about $700million invested.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAIGRET AND THE WINE MERCHANT. By Georges Sinienon. Translated by Eileen El lenbogen. 187 pages. Harcourt Brace Jaya noyich. $5.50.

title: Namath is Satisfied With Wrist After Ending Drills in Alabama
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., July 12 (AP)Joe Namath, after several weeks of fun and work, departed today, vowing to report to the New York Jets on time and saying his goal was to regain the pro football championship.

title: TVA. Darn Plans Anger Carolina Farmers
description: BREVARD, N. C.Winfred Lee Jones, 90 years old, stood on the porch of his unpainted house, which was the color of aging tortoise shell, and looked through the shade trees in the yard down alto the narrow valley, across the neat rows of cab bages in the reddish brown fields to the creek that has always tied his valley to the next and the next.

title: MRS. HENRY DARLINGTON
description: Mrs. Dorothy StoneSmith Darlington widow of the Rev. Dr. Henry V. B. Darlington, for mer rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street, died Sunday at Lake. Placid, N. Y., where she was spending the summer. She was 81 years old and lived at 2 East 93rd Street.

title: Wagner Firm Enjoined
description: BOSTON, July 12 (UP1)The Boston office of the Securities and Exchange Commission to day said a Federal court has permanently enjoined C. H. Wagner Co. and Clarence 14, Wagner from violations of the S.E.C's net capital rule for brokerage firms.

title: U.S. WINS CONTROL OF STRADIVARIUS
description: A violinist has lost a court battle to keep a Stradivarius violin that he received from a friend who later encountered tax trouble.

title: ERNEST H. VOGELSANG
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., July 12Ernest H. Vogelsang, an accountant with The New York Times from 1936 until his re tirement in 1962, died yester day in Morristown Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 16 Ash Street.

title: Soviet Jews Seeking Visas Reported on Hunger Strike
description: MOSCOW, July 12 (AP)A group of 29 Jews from Soviet Georgia began a hunger strike today in Moscow's central tele graph office to protest lack of action on their requests to emi grate to Israel, Jewish sources reported.

title: John W. Campbell of Analog, Science Magazine, Dead at 61
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J., July 12John. W, Campbell, editor of Analog, a leading science fiction and fact magazine, who was also a writer and antholo gist, died, yesterday of a heart ailment at his home, 1457 Or chard Road. His age was 61.

title: 3 More Metropolitan Wings Are Approved
description: The City Art Commission gave preliminary approval yesterday to three more ele ments of the Metropolitan Museum's controversial mas ter plan: the Rockefeller wing for primitive art; the Western European arts wing; and a glassenclosed sculp ture court. The three units are all to be built on the south side of the present building, over an existing parking lot.

title: WORLD BANK UNIT SAYS PAKISTAN AID IS POINTLESS NOW
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 A special World Bank mission has concluded that East Pakistan has been so ravaged by the West Pakistani military crack down that new international development efforts will have to remain in a state of suspen sion for at least the next year or so.

title: Study of Friday Crash: Train Passed a Signal
description: The Long Island Railroad train that crashed into the rear of another train loaded with commuters at Pennsyl vania Station Iast Friday aft ernoon had passed a restric tive signal, the Federal Rail road Administration reported yesterday.

title: KODAK INTRODUCES TWO NEW CAMERAS
description: The Eastman Kodak Com pany introduced yesterday two new lowcost secqrity cameras and special films aimed specif ically at the market for small businesses that cannot afford the elaborate equipment used by banks and department stores.

title: RICHEY ROLLS UP 63, 62 VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Cliff Richey, last year's win ner but seeded only fifth this time, rolled to an easy victory over Jeff Austin in the first round of the $50,000 Washing ton Star international tennis tournament today.

title: Edgar Eisenhower, Late President's Brother, Dies
description: TACOMA; Wash., July 12 (AP) Edgar N. Eisenhower, a lawyer here and brother of the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower, died today at, the age of 82.

title: Mrs. Alexandra E. Allan Wed To Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.
description: Mrs. Alexandra Emmet Allan was married here on Friday to Arthur M. Schlesin ger Jr., the historian and writer, who served as Special Assistant to Presidents Ken nedy and Johnson.

title: Bronfman Rites Today at 2
description: The funeral service for Sam uel Bronfman, founder and president of Distillers Corpora tionSeagrams Ltd. of Montreal and New York, will be held today at 2 P.M. at Congrega tion Shaar Hashomayim, West mount, Montreal. The time was incorrectly given in yesterday's New York Times. Mr. Bronfman died Saturday at the age of 80 in Westmount.

title: Preliminary Retail Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (Reu ters)Retail sales rose $522 million in June to a seasonally adjusted $33,045,000,000, re versing an $81million decline in May, according to a pre liminary Commerce Department estimate issued today.

title: SUSPECTS SEARCH IS RULED ILLEGAL
description: TRENTON, July 12 (AP) The state's secondhighest court ruled today that the State Po lice did not have the right to stop and search a car simply because its driver and occu pants had long hair.

title: C.B.S. in Contempt?
description: The Supreme Court has made it clear that the protec tion of the First Amendment extends not only to news papers and magazines but also to radio, television and movies. It has also ruled that persons holding public office or who are in the public eye are legitimate topics of press coverage and comment.

title: U.S. Replaces Baldwin, Americal Division Chief
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12  The commanding general of the United States Army's 23d Division, the Americal, is being replaced, the American military head quarters announced today.

title: Black Panther Freed By Mistake in Detroit
description: DETROIT, July 12 (UPI) Jerome Lee, serving time on an arson conviction, was mistakenly released from jail up completion of a 30 day contempt of court sen tence stemming from his re fusal to testify at the mur der trial of 12 fellow Black Panthers, officials disclosed today.

title: End to Tobacco Aid Sought
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Senator Frank E. Moss, Dem ocrat of Utah proposed amend ments today to the agricultural appropriations bill to end to bacco price supports. He said the appropriation bill includes $60to $70million to subsidize, advertise and export tobacco, a product which just 18 months ago the Senate determined was so hazardous that it should not be advertising over the broadcast media, and every package of which should be la beled with a health warning.

title: Clash in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 12 (UPI)  North Vietnamege troops reportedly attacked Cambodian soldiers sweeping strategic marshlands 12 miles east of Pnompenh today.

title: Sharman Is Named Laker Coach After Quitting A.B.A Utah Five
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP)  Bill Sharman was named coach of the Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball As sociation today. He received fiveyear contract, the terms of which were not announced. It was estimated he would get $70,000 a year.

title: Greek Exile Asks U.S. to Stop Military Assistance to Regime
description: WASHINGTON, July 12A Greek exile appealed to the United States today to stop military assistance to Greece because the military junta, he said, had reduced the Greek Army to a police force hardly capable of carrying out its commitments under the Atlan tic alliance.

title: Stalled Train Ties Up Line
description: A stalled engine on the 6:05 P.M. Penn Central train to New Haven halted traffic on the line for more than a half hour yesterday. A spokesman for the railroad said that the engine stalled between the Woodlawn and Mount Vernon stations and that it was re placed about 40 minutes later.

title: LARCIIMONT CRAFT OUT OF DOLDRUMS
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 12 Larchmont Yacht Club's 73d annual Race Week came out of the doldrums today when the Juniors set sail on Long Island Sound. The seniors had been becalmed for the first two days and won't get a chance to try again until Thurs day, after the youngsters finish their threeday stint.

title: West Side Democrats Feuding Again
description: The Democrats who defeat ed and dismantled the once fabled Tammany Hall polit ical machine under the ban ners of reform a decade ago are now marked for re form themselves in a series of bitter West Side primary contests.

title: CURBS ON POUNDS FOR E.E.C. TO END
description: BRUSSELS, July 12Britain and the European Economic Community agreed today on plans for phasing out Britain's exchange controls on the move ment of capital to other Com munity countries in five years after Britain joins. Her entry date is considered likely to be Jan. 1, 1973.

title: Libyan Support Reported
description: CAIRO, July 12The press and radio revolutionary Lib ya were reported today to be continuing expressions of sup port for army units that at tempted to overthrow King Has san II of Morocco last Satur day.

title: The Democratic Outlook
description: The growing number of wouldbe Democratic Presi dential candidates is a testament to the party's confidence that it can defeat President Nixon for reelection. The unusual variety of these candidates in experience, style and convictions is a testament to the party's traditional diversity.

title: U.S. Aide Reports Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)  Foreign governments are complaining about newspaper publication of the Pentagon papers, Marshall Green, an As sistant Secretary of State, said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Quake Strikesin Turkey
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 12 (AP) Several persons were injured and buildings were de stroyed when an earthquake struck southeast Turkey last night, officials reported here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NIXON TOPS KENNEDY AND WALLACE IN POLL
description: A Presidential poll involving President Nixon, Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama had Mr. Nixon winning with 44 per cent of the vote, Louis Harris, the polltaker, reported yesterday, according to the As sociated Press.

title: A Jury Indicts Corona On 25 Murder Counts
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., July 12 (UPI)A 25count murder indictment was returned to night against Juan V. Corona, suspected slayer of transient farm workers along the Feather River.

title: Kahane, Facing Jail Term, Vows More Attacks on Russians
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the head of the militant Jewish Defense League, said yesterday, at a news conference that he and his followers would not be de terred from using explosives or other forms of violence against Soviet installations in this country if they considered it necessary.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Regents

title: Thailand Protests Publication in U.S. Of Pentagon Study
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 12 (UPI)Thailand formally pro tested to the United States to day against the publication of data from the Pentagon papers.

title: Nixon as Conservationist
description: WASHINGTON, July 12No Presi dent since Franklin D. Roosevelt has been a conservationist in his private beliefs and instinctive personal reac tions. Roosevelt, an Easterner who loved the West, would not meet the rigorous standards of the new envi ronmental movement. For example, he was keen on drowning river valleys to build darns to generate cheap hy droelectric power, a practice which would win him no applause from to day's conservationists.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Members of the Committee on the Atlantic Salmon Emer gency (CASE) are bitterly disappointed that a meeting of the 15nation International Commission for Northwest Atlantic Fisheries (I.C.N.A.F.) held last month in Halifax, Nova Scotia, brought no agreement to end the high seas fishery for Atlantic salmon in the Davis Strait off West Greenland.

title: St. Petersburg Booms Set Up to Repel Dead Fish
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 12  Workmen installed 3,000 feet of flexible oil containment booms and wire nets across the mouths of half a dozen St. Petersburg bayous and inlets yesterday and today to keep thousands of dead fish killed by a red tide in Tampa Bay from getting into the water ways.

title: Moroccan Revolt
description: On King Hassan's own account, the attempt to over throw his constitutional monarchy in Morocco might have succeeded if its main leader, an army general who was Minister of the Royal Household, had not been accidentally killed by a fellow rebel. As he reflects on this revolt led by a trusted general who was regarded as the most important officer in his army, the 42yearold monarch can hardly fail to take seriously the warning of hostile Radio Libya that the revolution is not over in Morocco.

title: PROFIT RISES 13% AT WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation had record sales and earnings in the quarter and half ended June 30, with profit up about 13 per cent and sales up 4 per cent in both periods, it was reported yester day.

title: Mitchell Knew of Talks of Pan Am and T.W.A. Three Months Ago
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  The merger discussions be tween Trans World Airlines and Pan American World Air ways, which surfaced publicly today, were brought to the at tention of Attorney General John N. Mitchell three months ago in a memorandum from his predecessor of the Eisen hower years, Herbert Brownell.

title: Brid4ge: Griffin's Team Gains Edge In Regional Tourney Final
description: The knockout team cham pionship at the Fury City re gionals ended here Sunday night lira victory for a group led by, Torn Griffin of New York.

title: Johnson Girlfriend Is Questioned in Colombo Case
description: A young woman who was girlfriend of Jerome A. Johnson last May, a month before he al legedly shot Joseph A. Colombo Sr., has said that Johnson had acquired plane tickets to the is land of Jamaica with a de parture date at the end of June.

title: Kriss, Soviet Union Fencer, Regains World Epee Crown
description: VIENNA, July 12 (Reuters) Grigory Kriss of the Soviet Un ion, World and Olympic cham pion in 1964, regained the men's individual pe title in the world fencing champion ships tonight.

title: DELGADO BEATEN BY VASQUEZ HERE
description: Davey Vasquez avenged the only loss on his professional record in successfully defend ing his North American bantam weight title last night in Madi son Square Garden.

title: Economic Analysis
description: OTTAWA, July 12The unprecedented commitment four American natural gas distributors to advance $75 million for exploration in the Canadian Arctic is an example in miniature of a mammoth transborder energy partnership that could unfold during the next decade. The oil and gas industries in both countries  and much of Canada's industry is Ameri Canownedwant it. So do both national Governments. How ever, the Canadian Government is wary about entering any comprehensive agreement with Washington. Every time Wash ington advocates a continental energy policy, as the Secre tary of the Interior, Rogers Morton, did last month, Ottawa recoils from what it regards as a fatal embrace.

title: Bond Prices Move Up in Light Trading
description: Bond prices moved upward yesterday as investment bank ers prepared to bid today for the $150million of New York Telephone Company bonds scheduled for sale today.

title: New DeskTop Calculator
description: The HewlettPackard Com pany announced yesterday at Palo Alto. Calif., that it has placed on the market a new desktop calculator that has six times the memory capacity of comparably priced units.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE TO HIGHER GROUND
description: The inchahead stock mar ket, fighting the summer dol drums and some disappointing profits for individual compa nies, continued yesterday to creep toward higher ground.

title: The Future Could Not Be Seen
description: The average reader of The New York Times, equipped with hindsight, is smarter than any President.

title: MAYOR ASKS U.S. FOR $2.6MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  Mayor Lindsay asked Congress today for $2.6million to re imburse New York City for police protection during the 25th anniversary celebration at the United Nations last fall, but the State Department ad vocated a smaller payment $1.3million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place: Funds Outcome In june Awaited
description: Nervously and perhaps a bit tensely, Wall Street is awaiting the Investment Company Institute's monthly report on mutualfund sales and redemptions.

title: Wood and Scher Post 76's, Pace L.I. Junior Qualifiers
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., July 12 Cameron Wood of Mill River and Robert Scher of Kennedy High School shot 76's today and led the qualifiers in the Long Island Golf Association junior championship. Match play will start tomorrow over the par72, 6,576yard Middle Bay Country Club course.

title: Morgan Bowl for Sailing Is Captured by Mrs. Baker
description: MORICHES, L. I., July 12 Mrs, Louise Rice Baker cap tured the Morgan Bowl, em blematic of the Great South Bay; Yacht Racing Association's women's title, today.

title: Estes Is f3aroled to Work on Texas Farm
description: EL PASO, Tex., July 12 (UPI) Billie Sol Estes walked out  jail today a free man after erving slightly more than six rears of a 15year sentence for tis part in a multimilliondollar swindle.

title: Dr. Reuben and His Wife: We Agree on Everything
description: SPRING VALLEY, Calif. I make the living, and Bar bara makes life worth liv ing, explained Dr. David Reuben, the sex expert ex traordinaire for millions of readers since the publication of his book, Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Sex, But Were Afraid to Ask.

title: OTB System Is Feasible For Suffolk, Panel Is Told
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 12 A special Suffolk County commission studying the feasi bility of offtrack betting or construction of a quarterhorse track for Suffolk County be gan a series of meetings today that officials said could lead to establishment of an OTB corporation by next January.

title: Laotian Advance Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos July 12 (Agence FrancePresse) Mili tary sources said today that Government forces com manded by Gen. Vang Pao were advancing toward Green Peak Mountain, 19 miles northeast of the Plaine des Jarres and 38 miles west of the LaotianNorth Vietnamese frontier.

title: DEMAND FOR FRANC CONTINUES STRONG
description: PARIS, July 12The French franc continued in demand to day, with the Bank of France again compelled to purchase dollars to keep the franc rate from going through its upper limit.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Two well established operating rules of legisla tive life are at work against C.R.S. News in its struggle against chair man Harley Staggers and the House Commerce Committee:

title: PRIZE SILVER WINS DASH AT AQUEDUCT AND RETURNS $6,60
description: Prize Silver outgamed Peace Corps in the stretch drive to win the feature race at Aque duct yesterday. The event, a sevenfurlong dash for older horses, was witnessed by a crowd of 30,792.

title: Consumers Buying Plans Ebb;
description: Buying plans of the Ameri can consumer, after improving steadily in the first four months of 1971, have dropped signifi cantly in the last two months, the Conference Board report ed yesterday.

title: Ontario May Cut Vote Age
description: TORONTO, July 12 (AP) Eighteenyearolds would be given the vote in provincial and municipal elections and allowed to purchase alcoholic beverages under legislation in troduced today by Ontario's Premier, William Davis. The bill would also give young people the right to hold elective office and sit on juries.

title: Gruening Tells Officers Group Nixon Doesn't Intend to End War
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 Ernest Gruening, the former Democratic Senator from Alas ka, said tonight that President Nixon hasn't any intention of ending the war in Vietnam and never has had.

title: Free Press, Free People
description: Our democracy does not work well in secret. The Pentagon Papers illumi nate the arrogance of those in high places and the serious erosion, if not breakdown, of our constitutional sys tem of checks and balances.

title: Puerto Rican Doctor Appointed To 2d Highest City Health Post
description: Dr. Antero Lacot, the con troversial administrator of Lincoln Hospital, in the Bronx, has been appointed to the sec ond highest position in the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: NO ARRESTS MADE FOR PROSTITUTION
description: There were no arrests for prostitution in Manhattan on Sunday and no arraignments of prostitutes in Criminal Court yesterdaythe first time in 15 years that there have been no such hearings.

title: Predawn Blackout Strikes Uptown Area
description: A power failure blacked out upper Manhattan and Riverdale for three hours yesterday morning at a pre dawn ebb of activity when it might have been expected to have all the impact of a light going off in a refrigerator when the door is closed.

title: Serious Talks Begin
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 13 (AP)United States and Soviet negotiators began what confer ence sources called serious consideration today of their goal to reach accord on the limitation of defensive antibal listic missiles and offensive strategic weapons.

title: JOHN DILLE, EDITOR AT TIMELIFE BOOKS
description: John M. Dille, an editor of TimeLife Books and for 23 years on the staff of Life mag azine, died Sunday at his home. He was 50 years old and lived at 164 East 64th Street.

title: Nixon Adviser on Drug Abuse Ends 3Day Survey in Vietnam
description: SAIGON South Vietnam July, 13President Nixon's special advisor on drug abuse finished today a threeday tour of United. States military drugdetection and treatment center in South Vietnam, but declined to specify what he had found.

title: EXPORTLOAN BILL WORRIES RESERVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 The Federal Reserve Board is concerned that Congress may be on the verge of passing legislation that could result in a large and rapid outflow of dollars in the form of bank loans to foreigners. Such an outflow, of course, would deepen the nation's balanceof payments deficit.

title: KENNEDY REVEALS PAKISTAN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Senator Edward M. Kennedy made public today a survey on East Pakistan prepared by two American officials and de clared that it showed that mil lions would starve unless emer gency measures were taken be fore Aug. 1.

title: Atlas Corp. Reports Sale Of Uranium Concentrate
description: The Atlas Corporation report ed yesterday the sale of 1.1 million pounds of uranium con centrate to two unnamed buy ers. Deliveries will be made from next Sept. 1 to Dec. 31, 1972. The uranium concentrate wiuld be produced at Atlas's Moab, Utah, processing plant and raises to about 3 million pounds the total orders through Dec. 31, 1974.

title: 500 Rail Cars Ordered
description: Burlington Northern, Inc., an nounced yesterday it had or dered 500 socalled jumbo cov ered hopper cars from ACF In dustries, Inc. The new cars, each of which will have a 4,650 cubic foot capacity, will be de signed primarily for grain movement. Deliveries of the new equipment will begin in August.

title: Pentagon Aide Urges Deployment of More Missiles as Bargaining Chips for Talks With the Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  David Packard, Deputy Secre tary of Defense, argued before a Senate Foreign Relations sub committee today that the Unit ed States must proceed with deployment of offensive and defensive missiles as bargain ing chips in the strategicarms talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Advertising:
description: When the Shell Oil Com pany moved its corporate headquarters to Houston, Ogilvy & Mather wasn't far behind. It probably isn't wise to let too much space come between a client and an agency when there is about $25million in billings in volved.

title: LEGER AND PERRY REGATTA VICTORS
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 13 It's become feast or famine so far as wind is concerned for the 73d Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week over the first four days.

title: Wood and Scher Gain
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., July 13 The comedalists, Cameron Wood of Mill River and Robert Scher of Kennedy High, led the way into the semifinal round of the Long Island Golf Associa tion's junior championships at the Middle Bay Country Club today. Par for the 6,576yard course is 36, 3672.

title: House Vote on Contempt
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) Following is the rollcall by Which the House voted today, 226 to 181 to send the Colum bia Broadcasting System con tempt citation back to the Commerce Committee:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A prominent Lebanese diplomat recently told me there is an intense rivalry between Red China and the Soviet Union for influence in the Arab Middle East. In Lebanon, the commandos get arms from both rivals, and most of those in Lebanon and Jordan were trained in Red China. My source also said it is suspected a num ber of commandos were trained in North Vietnam and even practiced fighting with the Vietcong against the South Vietnamese.

title: PHILIP C. PLATT
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 13 Philip C. Platt, president of Edwards & Platt Inc., manufac turers representatives in the plumbing field who moved here from Manhattan last November, died yesterday at his office. He was 70 years old and lived at 75 Beacon Hill Road in Port Washington, L. I.

title: Merger News
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) A Federal judge denied today a request by the WarnerLam bert Company to keep the Federal Trade Commission from issuing a complaint charging it with antitrust violations in the acquisition of Parke, Davis & Co.

title: Judge Upheld in Ordering Blood for Jehovah's Witness
description: TRENTON, July 13 (AP) The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a hospital may give a blood transfusion to save the life of an adult patient even if it violates the patient's re ligious beliefs.

title: Man in the News
description: Stuart N. Scott has a for tunateand for a New York lawyer, unusualqualification for the new job he is in line to take on as head of the state committee that will in vestigate New York City's governance. I'm a complete independent, he said in a telephone call from London, where he is at tending the Amer ican Bar Associa tion convention. I have never registered for any party. A close colleague put the same thought differently; As an apolitical creature, he's unbeatable.

title: PANAMERICAN TEAM TOPS COLLEGIANS, 50
description: The United States Pan American Games baseball team made it two in a row over the Atlantic Collegiate Baseball League AllStars at Shea Sta; dium yesterday with a 50 victory behind the twohit pitching of Jackson Todd, who yielded one hit in six innings, and Jay Smith, who gave up one in three.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS TRADING EASES
description: In moderate trading, prices yesterday suffered their worst loss in three weeks on the American Stock exchange.

title: Russian Taught in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda (Reuters) The Soviet Union is financ ing a Russian language course at Makerere University here and has sent a Russian teacher.

title: ROBERT STACK FILES SUIT AGAINST C.B.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP) The actor Robert Stack filed a $25million damage suit against the Columbia Broad casting System today, charging that its controversial Selling of the Pentagon misrepresent ed his position on the Vietnam war.

title: EUGENE B. GERMANY, TEXAS BUSINESSMAN
description: DALLAS, July 13 (AP) Eugene B. Germany, banker, oilman, politician, and a founder of Lone Star Steel Company, died in a Dallas hospital yester day. He was 79 years old.

title: West Pakistan Pursues Subjugation of Bengalis
description: NEW DELHI, July 13Army trucks roll through the halfdeserted streets of the capital of East Pakistan these days, carrying antistate prisoners to worksites for hard

title: COSMOS, APRON BATTLE TO 11 TIE
description: The New York Cosmos and Apollon of Greece battled to a 11 tie at Yankee Stadium last night before 4,763 fans, the largest home crowd ever to watch the. Cosmos.

title: Detective Who Testified Against Police Is Guarded
description: Frank Serpico, the detective whose information led to crim inal and department charges being brought against 20 police men, has been assigned a police bodyguard.

title: England Beats Pakistan To Take Cricket Series
description: LEEDS, England, July 13 (Reuters)England scared a 25run victory over Pakistan today, and won the three match international cricket series, 10. The first two matches were drawn. The pace bowler, Peter Lever, clinched the victory when he took Pakistan's last three wickets in four balls without conceding a run.

title: Bill to Reduce Noise Of Jets Is Opposed By Head of C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, July 13  Secor D. Browne, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, to day labeled legislation aimed at quieting the roar of jet air craft too expensive, technologi cally impossible and diplomati cally risky.

title: Horse Disease May Be Infecting Texans
description: HOUSTON, July 13A case of Venezuelan equine enceph alomyelitis in a human has been confirmed in a Mexican town near the Texas border, and a number of residents of Brownsville, a small Texas bor der town, apparently have the illness, a United States Public Health Service official said today.

title: BANK IN OHIO PLANS AUTOMATIC TELLER
description: The City National Bank of Columbus, Ohio, announced yesterday two banking inno vations designed to speed Creditcard payments to mer chants and to provide around theclock banking services to consumers.

title: Women's Caucus Target of White House Jokes
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13 (UPI)President Nixon and his top diplomatic advisers talked today about the National Women's Political Caucus and not very kindly.

title: PORTER EXPECTED TO REPLACE BRUCE AT TALKS IN PARIS
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Nixon Administration plans to replace David K. E. Bruce as chief United States delegate at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris on or about Aug. 15, senior of ficials, said today.

title: Griffin Says. Labor. Act Has Not Been Enforced by Government
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Senator Robert P. Griffin charged the Labor Department today With failure to enforce the LandrumGriffin Actthe law he helped write 12 years ago, as a bill of rights for organized labor.

title: Army Is Destroying Biological Weapons
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., July 13 After a year and a half of planning and preparation, the Army has begun destroying the nation's stockpile of germ and toxin warfare agents, along with the munitions that would have been used to carry them to an enemy.

title: Rains Come and the Laotians Again Take Plaine des Jarres
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 13 (AP)  Americanbacked Meo tribesmen were reported today to have extended Laotian Gov ernment control over the entire Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos.

title: No Rest for Dr. Luns
description: For a world that takes stability for granted and Gov ernment reshuffles at The Hague in stride, the Cabinet sworn in by Queen Juliana last week had a striking aspectand it was not the debut of Barend Biesheuvel as Premier. It was the absence from the list for the first time In nineteen years of Joseph Marie Antoine Hubert Luns, the world's senior foreign minister.

title: New Government in Iceland
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 13 (Reuters)A leftwing coali tion Government consisting of the agrarian Progressive party, the Communistled Labor Al liance and the small Leftist and Liberal Union was formed to day with Olafur Johannesson, the Progressive leader, as Premier. It replaced the Govern ment of the conservative Inde pendence party and the Social Democrats, which lost its ma jority in last month's elections.

title: CHARLES BASCH JR.; CREATED AD JINGLES
description: Charles J. Basch Jr., a wool converter and advertising exec utive who helped to widen the impact of the ad jingle on the nation's airwaves, died of a heart attack on Monday at his home. He was 75 years old and lived at 771 West End Avenue.

title: Display at Metropolitan Is Completed by 3 Loans
description: When the collections of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pearl man, Mrs. Alex Hillman and Mr. and Mrs. Philip Levin moved into the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday, the Summer Loan Exhibition 1971 was finally complete Although the three additions are not so large in size as the collec tions of John Powers and Nathan Cummings, which opened as part of the sum mer exhibition, two weeks ago, they are markedly bet ter in quality and selectivity.

title: 4 ON BOARD SCORE HOSPITAL SYSTEM
description: Four of the 15 directors of the city's public hospital sys tem, dissatisfied with the di rection of the system and the speed with which it is moving, called yesterday for a special board meeting to discuss a wholesale reorganization.

title: Carl Stern, an ExFirst Cellist Of the Philharmonic, 69, Dies
description: BANGOR, Me., July 13  Carl Stern, former first cellist of the New York Philhar mnoic, died yesterday of cancer. He was 69 years old and lived in New York and at Brooks ville near here.

title: Notes on People
description: Johnny Sample, who played professional football for 11 years and capped his career by helping the New York Jets win the 1968 Super Bowl, was arrested in Philadelphia yesterday on charges of hav ing cashed 15 forged United States Treasury checks that were stolen from the mails.

title: Jackson to Visit Florida
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today he would take a sixday looksee in Florida, starting Thursday,

title: 2,000 to Fight Drug Abuse
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The Customs Bureau said to day that it would hire 2,000 new employes to help imple ment President Nixon's drive against drug abuse in the United States.

title: HOUSE VOTE KILLS MOVE TO CITE C.B.S. ON PENTAGON FILM
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The House voted today to recom mit to the Commerce Commit teeand in effect to proposed citation for contempt of Congress against the Colum bia Broadcasting System and its president, Dr. Frank Stan ton.

title: Albatross Rated 15, but 6 Will Oppose Colt in Cane Pace
description: YONKERS, July 13In the opinion of the linemaker, $5 should get you $1, if you be lieve, as many do, that Alba tross will win the Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway Friday night.

title: Haack Queried on SmallInvestor Rates
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission questioned today just how small investors who get turned away by brokers finding their business unprofitable are going to be put in touch with a broker who will serve them, as the New York Stock Exchange has promised.

title: Bay State Tax Bill Killed
description: BOSTON, July 13 (AP)The Massachusetts House killed to day Gov. Francis W. Sargent's third major tax bill of the 1971 session. The bill, which would (lave raised $233million was defeated on a 128104 roll call. A motion to reconsider the vote, will be taken up tomorrow.

title: Suffolk Migrant Labor Report Cites 965 Violations in Camps
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 13 A total of 965 sanitary and housing violations, including widespread rat infestation, were discovered in migrant la bor camps in Suffolk County investigated by the County Health Department last year, according to a report presented to the County Legislature today.

title: A POLLUTION CODE VOTED BY COUNCIL
description: The City Council unanimously approved yesterday a stringent airpollution control code that reduces the allowable sulphur content in fuels burned here and limits the amount of particle emissions from ventilators and fuelburning equipment.

title: Ellsberg Says Kissinger Knew About Pentagon Papers in 70
description: Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, the po litical scientist who made the Pentagon papers available to the press, said during a long television interview last night that Henry A. Kissinger, Presi dent Nixon's national security adviser, had been consulted about the Pentagon study be fore the project began.

title: Upset in Junior Tourney
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 13 (AP)Unheralded Henry Bunis of Cincinnati upset topseeded Raul Ramirez of La Jolla, Calif., 57, 64, 63, in the third round of the national junior clay court tennis championship to day. Jeff Miller of Scotch Plains, N. J., was among the victors.

title: Abortion Bill Advances
description: LANSING, Mich., July 13 (UPI) A bill that would allow a woman to obtain an abortion for any reason during the first 90 days of pregnancy was re ported out of the House Social Service Committee today, 5 to 3.

title: Homer Jones Traded to Cards
description: ST. LOUIS, July 13 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals ac quired a wide receiver, Homer Jones, from the Cleveland Browns today for a high fu ture draft choice.

title: Fanny May Results Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 13Mortgage interest rates drifted higher again at this week's auction of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the association announced today.

title: Suffolk to Buy 231Acre South. Shore Site for Park
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. L, July 13 The Suffolk County Legisla ture today authorized the ac quisition of the 231acre Gardi ner Manor estate in West Islip for $2million.

title: About Pro Football
description: Financial disagreements, which have been major be tween owners and players in recent years, continue to harass pro football. Greg Landry, the Detroit Lions regular quarterback, consid ers the only salary offer his club has made to be ludicrous.

title: McGovern Strives to Ease Balloting by 18YearOlds
description: Senator George McGovern announced yesterday that he was seeking legislation to fa cilitate registration and voting by the 18to21yearolds grant ed the vote under the recently approved 26th Amendment to the United States Constitution.

title: Nationals Also Connect 3 Times6 Equal Record
description: DETROIT, July 13Vida Blue gave up two home runs in three innings tonight, but his American League teammates recovered from that shock to defeat the National League, 64, and break an eightgame losing streak in baseball's 42d AllStar Game.

title: Provision for Loss Slated At Arthur G. McKee & Co.
description: Arthur G. McKee & Co., specializing in the engineering, design and construction of metal refining, coal preparation pits and food precessing plants, announced yesterday that it is planning to make a provision of $3million in its financial results for the first six months ended June 30, 1971, to cover probable losses on certain large lumpsum contracts.

title: Screen: Schatzberg's The Panic in Needle Park
description: If you set out to make a movie about wasted lives, you will, such are the para doxes of the art, most likely be undone by problems in form and dramatic structure though it might have seemed that the real chal lenge was only to discover a decent bond of sympathy with the quality of human suffering that is your sub ject.

title: Landmarks Unit Backs Restoration of 9 Old Houses
description: Harmon H. Goldstone, chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, said yesterday that the commis sion would recommend to Mayor Lindsay approval of architects plans for the restoration of nine old houses on the site of the Washington Street Urban Renewal Area.

title: CITY BEGINS PARK AUTHORIZED IN 36
description: The city broke ground yes terday for a twoandahalf acre neighborhood park in Woodside, Queens, that was au thorized in 1936 by Mayor Fi orello H. La Guardia.

title: City Transit System At Reduced Rates Planned for Elderly
description: A program to provide taxi or livery service at reduced rates for the elderly who are not receiving health care be cause they cannot use public transportation was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

title: FINNIE TO TRY OUT ON JETS DEFENSE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I. July 13 Perhaps the most significant project in the early days of the New York Jets training camp will be the inspection of Roger Finnle, whom his teammates call Superman, at both defensive end and defensive tackle.

title: Morell's Fashions Still High Art
description: Never take a designer's word about his collection. The daytime things are just good clothes to wear, Nor man Norell said before his showing yesterday. The eve ning things are very fantas tic, very showy.

title: Development Unit Set Up for Harlem
description: The state's Urban Develop ment Corporation and a group in Harlem agreed yesterday to form a subsidiary to help com munity organizations build and operate housing, cultural, civic and commercial facilities in the area.

title: ITALY IDENTIFIES 43 MAFIA LEADERS
description: ROME, July 13 (AP)A par liamentary commission, after sevenyear investigation, named 13 Mafia leaders today, de scribing them as bloody crim inals, killers, drug dealers, per sons capable of any atrocity. Publication of the report marked the first time a par liamentary investigation had identified leading Mafiosi.

title: PROFITS SOAR 160% AT MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's big gest brokerage house, reported yesterday that earnings for the first half of the year advanced by 160 per cent to $40,243,000 from $15,470,000 a year earlier.

title: Deaths
description: BARRYElizabeth (nee Seaman), July 12 In Las Vegas, Nevada. Survived by husband Robert C. Barn and children Michael Gall, Paul and Christopher and 3 grandchildren and 5 sisters. Funeral July 15 in Las Vegas. In lieu of flowers family requests donations be made to American Cancer Society or Easter Seal Society.

title: Russians to Visit Test Site in Nevada
description: DENVER, July 13  A group of nine Russian scientists this week will be the first from the Soviet Union to visit the Atomic Energy Commission's Nevada test site where the United States conducts its un derground tests of atomic wea pons.

title: British Study Hits ExPergamon Head
description: LONDON, July 13An offi cial report charged today that Robert Maxwell, former chair man of Pergamon Press, Ltd., a major publisher of scientific books, could not be relied on to exercise proper stewardship of a publicly quoted company.

title: SAMUEL LAMBETH
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., July 13 Samuel Lambeth, who retired from the nationaladvertising department of The New York Times on March 1, 1969, died yesterday. He was 67 ears old and lived at 25 Farley Road.

title: The Cheng and Erh Hu Provide Notes of Interest at Bach Night
description: The suonds of the p'i p'a, cheng, elfin and erh hu were heard at the meeting of the International Bach Society in the Lincoln Center Library auditorium on Monday night. One might have expected to hear Bach transcriptions being played on these Chinese instru ments, since the composer's music has been adapted to just about everything that can be played, from balalaikas to steel, drums.

title: BLAME QUESTIONS SCHOOL SPENDING
description: Three Board of Education bills totaling more $9,000 including one for an ex ecutivedevelopment, program weekend seminar, at a resort in the Catskillsrhave been challenged by Controller Abra ham D. Beanie.

title: SCREEN ACTORS SET TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13 (UPI) The Screen Actors Guild an nounced today (it had tenta tively approved a new three year contract with film produ cers. The Guild had set dead line of 12.01 A.M. tomorrow for a strike against major studios, independent companies and the three major television networks.

title: Britain Earned Big June Trade Surplus
description: LONDON, July 13  Britain turned in a strong foreigntrade performance in June, earning merchandise surplus of 39mil lion ($93.6million), the Depart ment of Trade and Industry an nounced today.

title: Young Candidates Abound in a Michigan Primary
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., July 13A 22yearold college drop out who goes about barefoot and wearing overalls is in the City Council race in usually, tranquil East Lansing, a city of 47,500 with winding streets and splendid homes.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities,. The President saw Henry A. Kissinger and Secretary of State William P. Rogers at the Western White House in San Clemente, Calif.

title: Power of the Purse
description: Ralph Nader, Representative Reuss of Wisconsin, John W. Gardner's publicinterest lobby Common Cause and a number of other plaintiffs have brought suit against the United States Treasury to force it to withdraw its new Asset Depreciation Range (A.D.R.) system, which would reduce business taxes by an average of $3.9 billion a year over the next decade.

title: Hotel Trading Is Suspended
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended for 10 days over the counter trading in the stock of Hotel, Inc., Cleveland, because it said there was no adequate inform ation available about the con cern's financial condition. The latest published information disseminated by the company was as of Dec. 31, 1969, and contained misleading and de ceptive information concerning the profitability and assets of Hotel, the commission said.

title: 2 Jazz Techniques Ring Out in Park
description: Two of the most highly developed techniques in the jazz world were on display Monday night at the Wall man Rink in Central Park the piano technique of Oscar Peterson and the vocal tech nique of Ella Fitzgerald.

title: MOBIL OIL BACKS PUBLIC TV SERIES
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting announced yes terday reception of a $1,120,000 grant from the Mobil Oil Cor poration renewing its funding of Masterpiece Theater for two years. The series, which last season presented The First Churchills, The Spoils of Poynton, The Possessed and Pere Goriot, is televised Sundays at 9 P.M. on more than 200 noncommercial stations be longing to the Public Broad casting Service network.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If Carl David Askling's July 3 OpEd article Who Needs the National An them? was meant to be humorous, the printing of it was a waste of valu able newspaper space. If it was meant to be serious, Mr. Askling has missed the whole purpose of the public rendi tion of our national anthem.

title: Home Burned Out, Stomp Seeks Aid
description: Three members of the com pany performing the rock musi cal Stomp, whose theater in Atlanta was burned down on Saturday, arrived here yester day by bus to raise money to resume their theater attivities.

title: Memorial Service Is Held For Rodriguez in Germany
description: NURENBERG, Germany, July 13 (AP)A memorial service for the Mexican racing driver, Pedro Rodriguez, killed Sunday in a crash at the Norisring, was held today at West Cemetery.

title: PRODUCTION OF SMOG DENIED BY STAUFFER
description: HOUSTON, July 13  The Stuffer Chemical Company in a statement today denied that its sulphuric acid plant was the source of the chemical smog that has made groups of people ill four times since April 22.

title: REAL ESTATE FUND SUED IN U.S. COURT
description: A suit in Federal Court here Is seeking $30million in dam ages for shareholders in the Real Estate Fund of America, Ltd., a foreignbased mutual fund that sold shares overseas to persons making real estate investments in the United States.

title: Aid for Lockheed Passes First Legislative Hurdle
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Administration's effort to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion from bankruptcy passed its first legislative test today.

title: MORRIS GILBERT, EXTIMES WRITER
description: Morris Gilbert, a retired New York Times writer, died yes tetday in St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport, Conn., after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 181 East 93d Street.

title: SUIT BY GOLDFIELD SEEKS ACCOUNTING
description: The Goldfield Corporation filed suit here yesterday in State Supreme Court seeking an accounting by former offi cers and directors, including Richard C. Pistell, who had been chairman and president.

title: Gasolines Called Similar
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) A Senate subcommittee in vestigation indicates there is basically little difference in ma jor gasolines or in most widely advertised additives, Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, said today. Mr. Hart made the statement in an nouncing four days of hearings next week, by his Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee, into the question of whether motor ists would pay less for gasoline if service stations could shop around and were not required to buy only from their parent company.

title: Rocketdyne Gets Contract For Space Shuttle Engine
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The space agency said today that it had awarded the Rocket dyne Division of North Ameri can Rockwell Corporation a $500million contract for con struction of a reusable main engine for the space shuttle.

title: Net for Period Rose Only 1.2% Over Results in 1970
description: The International Business Machines Corporation posted record aftertax profits in the quarter and half year ended June 30, but the gains over the previous year continue to nar row, according to results issued yesterday from tits Armonk, N. Y., headquarters.

title: A Malaise in U.S. Classical Recording
description: Three years ago, with much fanfare and covert crossing of fingers, Angel Records signed the Chicago Symphony to what was proclaimed as a trenddefying contract. The European company hoped to show, officials said, that a great symphony orchestra could still be recorded at a profit in this country in spite of steeply rising costs and falling classical sales.

title: Executive Changes
description: Shearson, Hammill & Co., Inc., announced yesterday several orga nizational changes, in cluding the election of Heath B. McLendon, 38 years old, as executive vice president and a member of the executive committee. Mr. McLen don, formerly national institutional sales man ager, simultaneously as sumed responsibility for the investment division, succeeding Walter May nard, who has retired. Mr. Maynard will con tinue to serve actively as chairman of Shearson, Hammill's investment company subsidiary, Shearson, Hammill Management Company. Robert T. Allen, head of research, first vice president and a director of Shearson, was named president and James Heller, first vice president and director, was elected vice chairman of the subsidiary. Suc ceeding Mr. Heller, Melrose B. O'Rourke, was named national manager of the municipal bond department, as well as a first vice president and voting stock holder of the firm.

title: OTB to Take Full Range Of Big A Bets Tomorrow
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation announced yester day that starting tomorrow it would start taking daily double, exacta and acrossthe board wagering on races at Aqueduct.

title: Bid for Subpoena Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) A source in the Justice De partment said today that the department's Internal Security Division is seeking to subpoena a New York Times reporter to appear before the grand Jury in Boston. The reporter was iden tified as Neil Sheehan, one of the writers of The Times's series, which was based on his investigative reporting.

title: Francis Wins Ike Golf by 3 Strokes on 218
description: EAST WILLISTON, L. I., July 13Gene Francis shot steady golf in a strong wind on his home course at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today to win the 19th annual Ike Tournament with a 54hole total of 218 two over par.

title: Market Place: Fund Head Calm On Redemptions
description: Howard M. Stein is not upset by all the chatter about net redemptions in the mu tualfund industry. His view point is worth examining.

title: NEWCOMBE ROUTS ULRICH BY 60, 60
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The four topseeded players advanced with victories today in the first round of the $50, 000 Washington Star interna tional tennis tournament.

title: SWINDLE CHARGED TO TWO POLICEMEN
description: State Supreme Court Justice James J. Leff has accused two 27yearold New York City policemen of trying to per petrate an audacious swindle with a $100,000 personal in jury suit against a taxicab company and one of its drivers.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISCommunist strategy in this final phase of the Indochina war seems postulated on proving Abraham Lin coln was wrong and that it is indeed possible to fool all the American people all the time. Hanoi has reason to believe it may well demonstrate this cynical theorem's accuracy.

title: Mrs. Frisby Duo Leads
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 13Mrs. Raymond Frisby of Huntington Crescent and Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks teamed for a 36, 3470 and the firstround lead today in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's 36hole bet terball partners tournament at the Maidstone Club.

title: Funds for Victims Of Lead Poisoning Asked of Senators
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) A Senate panel was told to day that the Nixon Administra tion had rejected a recommen dation of Government health specialists for a national push this year against childhood lead poisoning.

title: U.A.W. Aides to Forgo Raise
description: DETROIT, July 13 (AP)About 850 international representa tives for the United Automobile Workers have agreed to forgo 7 per cent pay increase to help ease the union's financial plight. Emil Mazey, the union's secre tarytreasurer, said that in giv ing up the increases the repre sentatives would save the union more than $500,000.

title: Three Performers in Sex Show Are Given Jail Sentences Here
description: Three performers in a live sex show were sentenced to jail terms yesterday by a Man hattan Criminal Court judge the first time this has hap pened in an obscenity case in the memory of court officials and members of the District Attorney's staff.

title: UNIONS DECRY USE OF FOREIGN LABOR
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) Labor leaders said today that industry's growing use of cheap labor abroad threatened a return to sweatshops and collapse of the economy.

title: Amtrak's Hot Line
description: The mercury was touching 93 degrees on 34th Street when Amtrak's Merchants Limited, once the pride of the old New Haven Railroad, pulled out of Pennsylvania Station for Boston the other evening.

title: DEMOCRAT URGES A CAMPAIGN CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Senator Fred R. Harris of Okla homa proposed today that Dem ocratic Presidential candidates agree to curtail spending and to debate regularly in the 1972 primary contests.

title: Libby Holman Death in Car Termed Suicide in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, July 13 (AP) The Chief State Medical Exam iner said today that the death last month of Libby Holman, former torch singer, was a re sult of suicide.

title: Commitment to the Schools
description: By signing the $5.5billion schoolaid bill that exceeds his own request, President Nixon has put an end to a threeyear feud with Congress. Aside from erasing the unfavorable image of an educationminded Congress battling an antieducation Administration, the truce offers Mr. Nixon an opportunity to do some economic pumppriming for a socially vital purpose.

title: Saigon Court Upholds Thiea's Election Law
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 14 (AP) The South Vietnamese Su preme Court yesterday up held the constitutionality of a newly enacted and con troversial election law that restricts the number of presi dential candidates.

title: Vote on School Budget Held in L.I. Communities
description: Voters in five communities in Suffolk County and one in Nassau County voted on school budgets, members of the school boards and a number of propo sitions yesterday.

title: AUDITING SCORED IN STATE SURVEY
description: Serious flaws in the auditing of brokorago houses by inde pendent accounting firms have been disclosed by a sixmonth survey conducted under State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: LETELLIER TAKES L.I.P.G.A. WITH 210
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., July 13Ron Letellier of North Hills shot rounds of 72 and 68 today to finish with 210 and win the Long Island Profes sional Golfers Association 54 hole medal play championship at Cold Spring Country Club by two strokes.

title: Credit Markets: Phone Bonds Issued
description: The New York Telephone Company auctioned $150mil lion of bonds yesterday. They were designed to yield inves tors 7.90 per cent, but the response was only fair and the advance in the corporate bond market came to a halt.

title: KEY STOCKS DROP AND SET OFF SLIDE
description: Weakness in two cornerstone issues  International Business Machines and American Tele phonecaused shakiness yes terday in the general stock mar ket. More than 1,000 issues showed declines on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Police Will Keep Up Pressure on Pimps
description: They dress expensively, drive luxurious cars, and are seen most frequently between the hours of 11 o'clock at night and six in the morning around Times Square.

title: Costa, 18, From Argentina, Keeps Dinghy Series Lead
description: BABYLON, L. L, July 13 Martin Costa, 18yearold junior and senior champion of Argen tina, had a sixth and a first today to retain the lead in the International Penguin Class Dinghy Association Champion ship. The final event of the series scheduled for today was postponed until tomorrow be cause of heavy seas whipped up by a 30knot southwester.

title: DR. EMANUEL SCHWARTZ
description: Dr. Emanuel S. Schwartz who had been a general prac titioner in the Yorkville area of Manhattan for more than dO years, died yesterday of a heart attack in the Glens Falls (N. Y.) Hospital while vacation ing in the area. He was 74 years old and lived at 348 East 84th Street.

title: 2D BRITISH SOLDIER IS KILLED IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, July 14 (AP) Sixty or more bullets were fired at a British Army patrol in a Roman Catholic section of Belfast early today, fatally wounding one soldier.

title: Advertising:
description: The Council of Better Business Bureaus confirmed yesterday that it had found a man to head up its staff for the planned industrywide effort at advertising selfregu lation.

title: Dean Rusk on the Pentagon Papers
description: The following was excerpted from an hourlong interview last week on N.B.C. Television with the former Sec retary of State, Dean Rusk.

title: Pakistan Condemned
description: The report of a World Bank mission to East Pakistan last month is a devastating indictment of the West Paki stani military crackdown in Bengal. It strongly chal lenges the Administration's policy of continuing both military and economic support for the Yahya Khan re gime in Islamabad.

title: J. C. PENNEY CALLS CONVERTIBLE ISSUE
description: The J. C. Penney Company, Inc., announced yesterday that it had called for redemption all of its $125million issue of 4 per cent convertible subordi nated debentures. The effect of the call will be to force holders of the debentures to convert them into Penney common stock since any holder who does not convert his bonds stands to suffer a stiff loss.

title: NEWARK PAPER BARS UNION PLAN IN STRIKE
description: NEWARK, July 13Hope for a settlement of the American Newspaper Guild strike against The Everting News of Newark dimmed today following the re jection, by the newspaper's management of a nonstrildng crafts tution's suggestion that the management return to a prestrike offer of settlement it had made to the Guild.

title: 38 Get Off the Mark in Battle for Giants' Jobs
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 13A huge crop of 38 Giant rookies and free agents broke into specialized groups today as training camp opened on a brilliant, comfortable after noon more suited to baseball than football.

title: Cranis Gains Round of 8
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 13  Paul Cranis of New York, the topseeded player, defeated George Gondelman of Great Neck, LI., 61, 60, today to become the eighth and last player to gain tomorrow's quarterfinal bracket in the New York State men's 35 years tennis championship at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Duryea Voices Displeasure Over Vetoes by Governor
description: ALBANY, July 13Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea said today that his fellow Assem blymen believed that Governor Rockefeller vetoed more bills than he should have following the 1971 session.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: America's textile industry differs from any other industry in that it must be considered Prom a historical standpoint. The Japanese textile in dustry was wiped out during the war and in order to permit the sale of raw cotton and of textile machinery to Japan after the war, the industry worked out a quota system to provide for a very generous amount of im portation of finished goods. This quota had a 5 per cent rising scale, was generally satisfactory to both Japan and the United States for many years, and now is more than double its original size.

title: RADNITZ/MATTEL PLANS 8 MOVIES
description: Mattel, the toy manufacturer that recently joined with Robert B. Radnitz, the movie producer, to form Radnitz/Mattel Produc tions, will make eight feature films over the next three years. Two will be directed by Martin Ritt, who was responsible for Hud and The Spy Who Came In From the Cold,

title: LOCAL RULE URGED IN SCHOOL CENTERS
description: An independent evaluation of the city's Community Education Centers has recommended that local residents be given greater operational control over the programs, which cost $14.6 in the last school year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Both The Times and the President of the United States are concerned about the safety and wellbeing of the Ameri can people, but while your editor Is responsible only to your American readers, the President is responsible not only to Americans but also to for eign governments.

title: Books of The Times
description: CAPE ANN: CAPE AMERICA. By Herbert A. Kenny. Drawings by Torn O'Hara. 294 pages. Lippincott. $6.95.

title: NIXON CRITICIZED ON BUM POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 A powerful civil rights coali tion severely criticized today the Nixon Administration's pol icies and practices in provid ing housing for minorities and the poor.

title: ROBERT MURPHY, A NATURE WRITER
description: PRESCOTT, Ariz., July 13 Robert Murphy, a naturalist and an author, died today of can cer of the liver He was 68 years old.

title: SOYBEANS ARE HIT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Soybean futures prices con tinued the rise started the day before during the opening mo ments of yesterday's session on the Chicago Board of Trade. But, after several seesaw moves, prices dropped sharply as a re sult of profit taking just before the close. Trading was mixed and heavy.

title: Prof its Increased By Unionamerica, Union Bank Parent
description: Unionamerica, Inc., parent company of the Union Bank, Los Angeles, and several other important financial service companies, announced yester day that its net income In the second quarter was $4.8mil lion, or 56 cents a share, up 16.5 per cent from the $4.1 million or 49 cents a share earned in the same period last year.

title: STATE REPORT CITES CON EDISON TROUBLE
description: A state report said yesterday that Consolidated Edison had lost all four of its 168,000kilo watt gasturbine emergency electric generators, mounted on barges in Gowanus Creek, on the same day its millionkilo watt Big Allis unit broke down last week.

title: Island Floatingon Ocean Could Carry Atom Plants
description: Funds have been allocated for construction of a float ing island that could serve as a prototype for midocean weather stations, bases for seafloor mining operations or platforms to carry nuclear power plants.

title: Humphrey Asks New Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, intro duced a bill today to create congressional agency similar to the executive branch's Na tional Security Council. The bill would authorize a joint Con gressional committee to study, review and make recommenda tions about national security.

title: COURT CONVICTS OMAR OFFICER
description: LAKENHEATH, England, July 13A United States Air Force courtmartial found Capt. Thomas S. Culver guilty today of having taken part in an anti war demonstration in London on May 31 in violation of mili tary regulations.

title: F.T.C. Bids Auto Makers Verify 60 Claims in Ads
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Federal Trade Commission ordered seven automobile manufacturers today to document 60 advertising claims such as over 700 per cent quieter and 109 advantages to keep it from getting old before its time.

title: L. I. Family in Adoption Case Missing
description: A Massapequa, L. I, couple who are fighting a court order to return the 3yearold ChineseAmerican girl they hoped to adopt have disap peared from their home, tak ing the child with them.

title: The First Reaffirmed
description: The rights guaranteed to the American people by the First Amendment were reaffirmed once more yesterday when the House sent back to the Commerce Committee a proposed contempt  of  Congress citation against the Columbia Broadcasting System and its president, Dr. Frank Stanton. The 226181 vote was a deserved if unusual rebuff to Commerce chairman Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia, for his misbegotten effort to compel C.B.S. to turn over unused material compiled for its documentary, The Selling of the Pentagon. The merits of that controversial production were not at Issue. The House has recognized, as Mr. Staggers did not, the very clear constitutional prohibition against such inter ference with freedom of the press as applied to electronic journalism.

title: WELFARE TEST CASE TO BE HEARD AUG. 9
description: A threejudge Federal Dis trict Court hearing on a con stitutional challenge to New York State's oneyear welfare residency requirement was scheduled yesterday for Aug 9 in Buffalo.

title: About Motor Sports
description: This is the time of year when travelers from outer space visit the New York area, and the leading hot shoes will provide a lively weekend as they show what they do to win well over $300,000 a year. That dazz ling spectacle of noise, fan tasy and blinding speed, a bigleague Cham pionship drag meet, plays for three days at Englishtown, N.J., 15 miles south of New Brunswick. In addition, we have the good ol boys of the Southern stockcar tour making their annual ex tension into the North, with a major stop Sunday at Trenton, N. J.

title: Economic Analysis
description: When President Nixon sub mitted his fiscal 1972 budget last January, it showed an $11.6billion deficit. Expendi tures were budgeted at $229.2 billion, but revenues were esti mated at only $217.6billion because the economy would still be recovering from the 196970 slump. At the time George P. Shultz, director of the Of fice of Manage ment and Budget, said Mr. Nixon had not batted an eye over the large budget defi cit. He had accepted the eco nomic theory thatas long as expenditures did not exceed what the level of revenues would be if the economy were at full employment, defined as 4 per cent unemploymentthe actual deficit did not matter and would not be inflationary.

title: SANGUILLEN FAILS TO CRACK LINEUP
description: DETROIT, July 13Sparky Anderson, the first National League manager to be on the losing side of an AllStar Game in nine years, had one big regret tonight: He didn't get Manny Sanguillen, the Pitts burgh catcher, into the game.

title: KEITH M'CUTCHEON, A MARINE GENERAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) Keith B. McCutcheon, a re tired Marine Corps general, died of cancer today at the Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 55 years old.

title: SORCERY, A SLOOP, IS FIRST AT HALIFAX
description: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 13James French Baldwin's big sloop Sorcery was first to finish in the 360mile race from Marblehead, Mass., to this port, and late tonight she was as sured of winning Class A hon ors.

title: Grand Jury Studies Disclosure of Papers
description: BOSTON, July 13A Federal grand jury here has been pre sented information gathered by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who have attempted to learn how secret Pentagon papers were made available to the press.

title: Pentagon Accounts For Vietnam Funds Reported Missing
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Defense Department explained today what had happened to $1.7billion in United States support for the Government of South Vietnam that an audit by the General Accounting Office had not been able to trace.

title: CONSTANTINE MEETS U.S. ENVOY IN ITALY
description: ATHENS, July 13  Greece's exiled King, Constantine, and the United States Ambassador to Greece, Henry J. Tasca, have met at Porto Ercole, a fashion able Italian resort.

title: Amateurism Is Dead
description: WASHINGTONAs we approach an other Olympic year we have already heard the rumblings of the problem that has plagued the Olympic move ment for years. Avery Brundage, speaking for the International Olympic Committee (I.O.C.), has warned that several European skiers may be barred from the 1972 winter Olympics on the grounds that their amateur status has been tainted by commercialism.

title: 3 Killed, One by a Buffalo, In Wyoming Park Accidents
description: ELK, Wyo., July 13 (UPI) The deaths of three persons, including one run down by a buffalo in a meadow, were re ported today in two Wyoming national parks.

title: COLOMBO'S DOCTORS FEAR AN INFECTION
description: Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader who was shot in the head June 28, is being treated with antibioticsto ward off systemic infection, a Roosevelt Hospital spokesman reported yesterday.

title: Petrosian Plays 5th Draw
description: MOSCOW, July 13 (AP)The fifth game of the semifinal match in the world chess chal lengers eliminations between Grandmasters Tigran Petrosian and Viktor Korchnoi, both of the Soviet Union, ended in draw today at the 16th move. The match remains tied, 21/2 2, after five straight draws.

title: Players Seek Facts on TV Pact In Bargaining With Baseball
description: DETROIT, July 13No dra matic developments emerged today from the meeting of the player representatives of the 24 major league teams with Marvin Miller, director of the Players Association, and Dick Moss, the Association's coun sel. But some of the matters discussed may get to be well publicized issues eventually.

title: For a Dull Party, It Was Exciting
description: Some of the Miss Universe contestants met some of New York's most eligible bache lors Monday night. After sev eral hours of mutual inspec tion, desultory conversation, dining and dancing, it was a tossup as to which group was more unimpressed.

title: TALITHA POL, WIFE OF PAUL GETTY JR.
description: ROME, July. 13 (AP)Talitha Pol, former British actress and wife of Paul Getty Jr., the American millionaire's son, was found dead in her Rome apart ment Tuesday night, the police said. She was 31 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: Why has the National Asso ciation for the Advancement Of Colored People survived and prospered as a haven for Ne groes who believe, and for those who want to believe, in America? To someone who ob: served the 62d annual conven tion of the association, which ended in Minneapolis on Friday, it appears that the mass  membership organization has somehow managed to combine ele ments of family, church, social and political groups with the feeling of par, ticipation in a great moral cru sade.

title: Thant Hopeful of Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 13 Secretary General Thant considers prospects for a peaceful solution of the Viet nam war brighter now than at any time since peace talks be gan in Paris in May, 1968, a spokesman said today.

title: Rancher Is Fined the Minimum In Death of Eagles in Wyoming
description: CASPER, Wyo., July 13Van Irvine, a rancher facing 29 charges following the thallium sulphate poison deaths of 22 eagles, pleaded no defense to day and paid minimum fines totaling $675 plus $4 costs.

title: Barbara Walters Planning To Take Moderator's Job
description: Barbara Walters of the Na tional Broadcasting Company's Today show will take over the moderator's job net season on WNBCTV's weekday morn ing talk program, For Women Only.

title: STUDY IS PLANNED ON CABLE TV USES
description: The Center for Policy Re search has received a grant of $124,300 to study the use of cable television for communica tion and decisionmaking on the community level.
