title: $11.8Millionto Feed Children
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today that more than $11.8million in additional funds would be apportioned to help operate child feeding pro grams this summer at organized playgrounds and daycare cen ters.

title: AGNEW, IN NAIROBI, SEES KENYAN LEADER
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 13 Vice President Agnew met in formally here today with Kenya's President, Jomo Ken yatta.

title: BAR CHIEF TO HEAD INQUIRY INTO CITY
description: Governor Rockefeller will appoint Stuart N. Scott, out going president of the New York State Bar Association, to head the state investigation of New York City operations.

title: City Stores Acquires Land And 2 Buildings on 5th Ave.
description: The City Stores Company, parent concern of W. & J. Sloane, Inc., announced yester day the acquisition of the 14,500squarefoot tract of land and the sixstory and the 12 story buildings located on it that constitute a major portion of the Sloane store on the southwest corner of Fifth Ave nue and 38th Street in Man hattan.

title: FRANCE AGAIN DENIES UPVALUATION IS SET
description: PARIS, July 13  French Finance Minister Valery Gis card d'Estaing reasserted today for the second time In two weeks that France would not upvalue the franc.

title: Fedayeen Report Big Attack by. Jordan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 Arab commando spokesmen said here today that Jordanian tanks and infantry had begun an allout offensive against guerrilla positions in Jordan.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Continuation of the meet ing requested by the Sene galese Government10 A.M.

title: Art for Rockies Sake: Mountain Gap to Get Big Orange Curtain
description: RIFLE, Colo., July 10Big time art is coming to this small mining and cow town in west ern Coloradoreally big art, all the way from New York City in the form of an incredible orange curtain.

title: Unit Pricing Gets Off to a Faltering Start
description: Quick now: if one brand of tissues costs 29 cents for a box of 125, and a second brand costs 39 cents for two boxes of 200 each, which brand is cheaper?

title: JACKSON'S HOMER TALK OF THE STARS
description: DETROIT, July 13Frank Robinson was named the All Star Game's most valuable play tonight, but he and the rest of the American Leaguers preferred to talk about Reggie Jackson's mammoth homer that started them on the way to their first victory since 1962.

title: Inventories Rose About the Same In May as April
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Total business inventories rose $630million in May, about the same as in April and indicating a slightly fas ter inventory growth in the second quarter than in the first, the Commerce Depart ment reported today.

title: I.T.T. Unit Gets Contract
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation an nounced yesterday that its sub sidiary, ITT GIMilian, Inc., has been awarded a $28.6million contract for longrange air search radar systems and equip ment. The systems are to be used aboard destroyers, air craft carriers and guided mis sile frigates and cruisers.

title: International Paper and St. Regis Had Sharp Declines
description: Sharply reduced earnings for two top paper producersthe International Paper Company and the St. Regis Paper Com panywere reported yesterday for the second quarter and the half.

title: Fischer Maintains His Streak, Beating Larsen in Fourth Game
description: DENVER, July 13Bobby Fischer defeated Bent Larsen of Denmark in 33 moves in the fourth game of their chess match today. Fischer leads, 40.

title: Venezuela Oil Bill Gains
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 13 (UPI)The Venezuelan Sen ate approved yesterday the first article in the controver sial oil reversion bill which af fects properties of United States and other foreign oil companies operating here. The bill has already been passed in the Lower House and now only requires Senate approval and signature by the chief of state to become a law of the land.

title: Adm. J. J. Clark, Commander Of Fleets in Pacific, Dies at 77
description: Adm. J. J. Clark, one of the Navy's most colorful carrier commanders in World War II and the commander of the Sev enth Fleet in operations against North Korea, died yesterday in Naval Hospital, St. Albans, Queens, after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 655 Park Avenue. He was chair man of Hegeman Harris Inc., a construction and investment concern here.

title: Sports of The Times.
description: Monroe Kaufman is a successful insurance manager from New Rochelle, N. Y., who enjoys sports in all seasons. He owns season tickets for home games of the New York Giants, treks off to ski in Vermont and drives in from West chester County with his family on foggy winter nights watch the New York Knicks battle Lew Alcindor.

title: Brazil Believed Moving Toward Forced Relocation of Tribes
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 13 President Emilio G. Mddici has ordered the formation of three new Indian reservations.

title: 10 ARE EXECUTED BY ARMY IN RABAT
description: RABAT, Morocco, July, 13 Ten highranking officers of the Moroccan Army died be fore firing squads this morning, with cries of Long live Has san II on their lips. On com mand, units of the army, navy and air force spat on the bodies.

title: Laird, Ending Talks, Shuns Pledges Sought by Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wed nesday, July 14Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird ended two days of consultations here yesterday with the issuance of a joint statement that appar ently fell far short of the specific assurances and com mitments his South Korean hosts had sought.

title: How a Teacher Amassed Her Fortune
description: CHICAGO, July 12Miss Muriel E. Forsland, a Chicago high school teacher who left $2million to the University of Chicago for medical re search, amassed her fortune by almost daily trading in common stocks, using as be ginning capital only her $9,000ayear teaching salary.

title: CoinFutures Plan Studied
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (Reuters)The Treasury is in vestigating a plan by the West Coast Commodity Exchange, Inc., to engage in futures trad ing in rare gold Coins, officials said today.

title: 33 Georgian Jews Vow to Fast Until Soviet Grants Exit Visas
description: MOSCOW, July 13  At the far end of Moscow's busy Cen tral Telegraph Office, 33 Jews from Soviet Georgia sat on stools or sprawled on the floor tonight as the second day ended in their selfannounced hunger strike to obtain permission to emigrate to Israel.

title: Bridge: Feigns, 78, and Greene, 63, Show They Are Still Winners
description: Five months ago Jay Fel gus won the master pair title in a New York sectional tournament at the age of 78, and became the oldest man ever to win a major New York title.

title: Fighting Still Curtailed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 (AP)An almost com plete cessation in war action in South Vietnam extended today through a ninth day, and even United State air strikes were heavily curtailed by tropical storms.

title: TELEPHONE STRIKE SCHEDULED TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 Joseph A. Beirne, president of the Communications Workers of America, announced this afternoon that his 500,000 worker union would strike the nation's telephone system at 6 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Stadium Bonds Attract No New Orleans Bids
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 13 The Louisiana Domed Stadi um Commission failed for the fourth time today to sell $113million in construction bonds to build an 82,000seat downtown arena.

title: Detroit Hospital Aide Slain
description: DETROIT, July 13 (AP)  A man armed with a rifle, shot and killed a hospital official, wounded a woman secretary and barricaded himself in their office today, holding out for more than an hour before be ing shot and captured by police. The captive, identified as Rob ert Putnam, 25 years old, was shot in the head and reported in critical condition.

title: Nixon Selects Head of Rights Unit
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13President Nixon an nounced today that he would nominate David Luke Nor man to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Civil Rights Division.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dean Acheson's conclusion that we need a selfgoverning body for the press  to stimulate  selfrestraint in publishing material ethically uncle sirable (The Purloined Papers Op Ed July 7) is a frightening, though perhaps unconscious, attack on consti tutional liberties.

title: Irin's Ruling Party Wins
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 13 (AP) Iran's ruling party, Iran No vin, won 230 seats in the lower house and 28 in the upper house in Saturday's general elections, Interior Minister Hassan Zahedi announced to day. The opposition Mardum party got 37 seats in the lower house and two in the Senate.

title: Hearing Set for Berrigans
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) The United States Board of (Parole announced today that it would hold a hearing July 28 on applications for parole by Philip and Daniel Berrigan. The Rev, Philip Berrigan began serving a sixyear sentence July 5, 1968, for draft law violations. The Rev. Daniel Berrigan start ed serving a threeyear sentence last Aug. 3 for destruction of government property.

title: City's SchoolJob Tests Barred as Biased
description: A Federal judge ruled yester day that the city must give up its traditional examinations for selecting school principals be cause the tests discriminated against blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: HOOD'S BOAT INS IN HALIFAX RACE
description: HALIFAX, N.S., July 14  Ted Himd's Robin becatne the official winner of the 14th iennial MarbleheadtoHalifax yacht race today when time ran out on all the other prospec tive challengers.

title: Japan Seen Easing Import Curbs
description: An Administration official said yesterday that Japan was moving at long last toward a significant reduction of her import barriers, but asserted that her restrictions on foreign investment were still far from liberal.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: LANDON CRITICIZES PRESIDENTS ON WAR
description: TOPEKA, Kan., July 14 (UPI) Alf M. Landon, the Republi cans 1936 candidate for presi dent, said today that modern Presidents had no right to wage war and mislead Congress and the public in the style of the old discredited divine right of monarchs,

title: PHONE STRIKE ON ACROSS NATION; IMPACT IS SLIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Telephone service remained virtually unimpaired today as about 400,000 members of the Communications Workers of America began a nationwide strike against the Bell System.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The new welfare reform bill, if passed, will pro vide the munificent total of $2,400 a year for a family of four, providing the family meets the work rules and survives the other red tape in which the program will be wrapped.

title: Chiefs Arbanas Retires
description: KANSAS CITY, July 14 (UPI) Fred Arbanas, tight end of the Kansas City Chiefs, who was injured in the sixth game last season, announced his re tirement today,

title: Edward Smith Dead at 76; A Book Promotion Executive
description: WEST REDDING, Conn. July 14Edward Leffingwell Conn., a retired book promotion execu tive, died today in the Danbury Hospital after a brief illness, He was 76 years old and lived on Lime Kiln Road here and at 17 East 96th Street, New York.

title: Bergman's 'Touch' Tells a Love Story
description: Ingmar Bergman describes "The Touch" as his first love story, which just goes to prove that a director, even one of the best, may often be a most unreliable source of information about his own work. If they aren't love stories, whatin the name of God (who, in Bergman's world, is synonymous with enigmatic love)are "Shame" and "The Passion of Anna?" What is "The Hour of the Wolf"? In each of these films, Bergman deals with aspects of lovewith the cruelties of love, with the terrible absences of love, and with the processes by which love, in its own time, can die."The Touch," Bergman's first film to be shot in English, is certainly not his first love story, though it comes close to being the first outright soap opera that I can remember him making.Because "The Touch" is by Bergman, you may be sure that it's quite unlike any other soap opera you've ever seen, but it shares with that sometimes fascinating serial form a passion for detailing the gloomy side effects of passion, while communicating hardly any sense of the exaltation. Like "The Secret Storm," it stands around talking its head off, in language that is neither rich, nor strong, nor funny, nor poetic enough to do real justice to its emotions.Unlike "The Secret Storm," however, "The Touch" does have a beginning, a middle and an irrevocable end. It's the story of a rootless, neurotic, German-born American archeologist (Elliott Gould), on a dig in Sweden, a placid Swedish doctor (Max von Sydow), and the doctor's wife (Bibi Andersson) whom the archeologist, with the touch of love, brings to life, which may, in fact, be her destruction.At one point during their affair, the archeologist takes his mistress to the medieval church where he is working and shows her an ancient wooden madonna that has been walled up for something like 500 years. In the course of excavation, he tells her, larvae, of an insect long since extinct, have been reawakened and now are in process of destroying the madonna from the insidewhich is more or less the capsulated story of the middle-class wife.The trouble with "The Touch" is not in the situation, or in the ideas, but in the language. The English dialogue that Bergman has given his stars sounds like those early, grammatically perfect, and lifeless translations of Ibsen that Eva La Gallienne used to pump around the American stage. "Go, now, Andreas," Gould says to von Sydow in a crucial confrontation between the lover and the husband. ''You've humiliated both of us long enough with this ridiculous visit of yours!"The banality of the language has no visibly ill effect on the performances of Miss Andersson and von Sydow, who, when they are speaking English, must sound a little bit strange and self-conscious. It is, however, fatal to Gould, who doesn't help matters by giving his lines those slightly flat readings that were so funny in "M*A*S*H" and "Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice," but, in "The Touch," suggest that the actor is in a different dimension of drama from those of his costars.It's an extremely complex role that Bergman has written for Gould, that of a man who is haunted by the fact that he is his family's only male survivor (his father died in a concentration camp), and who is apparently his sister's protector and lover. But little of this complexity comes through and I, for one, never believed that his archeologist could find a cuff-link in a messy bureau drawer, much less an ancient shard on a hillside.Von Sydow has one of those roles, which, by definition, is impossible to respond tothat of the cuckolded husband  but Miss Andersson is as charming and affecting as a movie that is not dealing in charm and affection allows her to be.Bergman may occasionally make dull moviesas I believe "The Touch" to bebut he cannot be stupid, and "The Touch" is full of what might be called the innuendos of his genius. The opening sequence, where Miss Andersson visits the hospital room in which her mother has just died, is as lovely an evocation of loss as Bergman has ever done. There are fragments of love scenes, between the wife and her husband, and between the wife and her lover, that are so simple and personal you forget you are in detergent drama.Although it is often oblique, the drama is without mystery, and sometimes ridiculously blunt, as when Miss Andersson visits Gould for their first successful assignation and we hear, offscreen, the sound of a buzz saw. This is what some critics mean, I guess, when they say that the film is accessible."The Touch" opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater.

title: Red Sox Players Apologize and End Quarrel Over Tony Conigliaro
description: BOSTON, July 14 (AP) Carl Yastrzemski and Billy Conigliaro of the Boston Red Sox made their peace today and Tony Conigliaro reported he batted all last season with his left eye almost closed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is very easy, especially for a paper with your record, to defame a country and a Government to such an audacious extent as you did with the July 7 OpEd article, The Torture of the Greeks.

title: Perry of Pequot Y. C. Wins Award as the Best Junior in Larchmont Race Week
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 14 Ken Legler of the host Larch mont Yacht Club and Ned Nunes of Belle Haven Club at Green wich, Conn., won the Lightning Class races, which, because of too much wind, were the only ones the juniors could sail on Long Island Sound today. But David Perry of Pequot Y. C. at Southport, Conn., received the major junior award of Larch moat race week as the young sailors completed their three clay portion of the club's 73d annual event.

title: Credit Markets: Rates Hold Steady
description: The bond market meandered through a session that was ex tremely quiet for a Wednesday yesterday and wound up just about where it started. Interest rates thus showed no signifi cant change.

title: 31 SEIZED BY ITALY IN DRIVE ON MAFIA
description: ROME, July 14The Sicilian police and carabinieri have be gun a new nationwide crack down on Mafia suspects after the recent upsurge of violence in Palermo.

title: Jersey Tells U.S. Court It Didn't Coerce Smith
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 14 The State of New Jersey asked the United States Court of Ap peals for the Third Circuit to day to deny a new trial for Edgar H. Smith Jr., who has spent 14 years on Death Row more than any other con demned man in the country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On July 8, as reported on your July 9 front page, Paul W. McCracken, chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers, advanced this line of reasoning in testimony before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee:

title: American Airlines Continuing Layoffs
description: The president of American Airlines, George A. Spater, has notified the system's 35,000 employes that another work force reduction has begun.

title: Official Is Criticized for Giving Westinghouse Postal Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  House subcommittee investiga tors charged today that an of ficial of the. United States Postal Service had committed himself to awarding a $3.4 million job evaluation contract to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation before sending out requests for competitive bids.

title: Customers of Prostitutes Are Difficult to Prosecute
description: If Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy decides to crack down on the men who patronize the city's prostitutes a move he is considering, he said yesterdayhe will be taking on a job that many law officials say is even more diffi cult than the job of cracking down on the prostitutes.

title: The Stage: Shakespeare and Arrabal Back to Back
description: LONDON, July 14What is a national theater? Britain's National Theater seems to take a deliberately controversial view of the question. The danger, I sup pose, of any national theater is that it becomes too con ventional, too hidebound: In London it seems that this is a danger most skillfully avoided.

title: New Envoy to Sierra Leone
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14 (UPI)President Nixon to day named Howard P. Mace, director of personnel at the State Department, to be am bassador to Sierra Leone.

title: SUIT CHARGES F.B.I. WITH HARASSMENT
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15 Two antiwar groups and 18 in dividuals suede, the Federal Bureau of Investigation today, asking the Federal District Court here to enjoin as uncon stitutional continuous and malicious harassment by agents since the theft of. F.B.I. files at nearby Media in March.

title: Hassan, Who Charged Foreign Role in Mutiny Sees Cairo Aide After a Delay
description: RABAT, Morocco, July 14  King Hassan II received a spe cial Egyptian envoy tonight after having kept him waiting for two days.

title: Lindsley Harris, Bruce Swenson Marryin Dallas
description: DALLAS, July 14Miss Lindsley Harris, a greatgrand daughter of the late Col. Henry Dickinson Lindsley, chairman of the first Ameri can Legion convention and a former Mayor of Dallas, was married here tonight to Bruce Merritt Swenson, a grandson of the late Martin F. Tiernan, cofounder of the Wallace Tiernan Company, Inc., now a subsidiary, of the Pennwalt Corporation.

title: Personal Finance
description: Consumers are not ready to accept the almost check less society that bankers and some businesses would like.

title: Rev, Justus Sweeney, Head Of Mission Band Apostolate
description: The Rev. Justus Sweeney, a Franciscan priest who directed the Mission Band Apostolate of the order's Holy Name Province on the East Coast of the United States, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in the mon astery of the St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church at 135 West 31st Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We read with great interest the July 8 news article by Richard Phalon on efforts under way to rid the harbor of debris.

title: Blood and Fog Over Rabat
description: King Hassan's emergence in triumph over the abortive attempt to overthrow the monarchy in Morocco has been clouded by the summary executions without trial of ten highranking army officers implicated in the coup. The King would have emerged from his ordeal with far greater statureand probably greater popular support if he had responded to the plea of the International Commission of Jurists and ordered a courtmartial in which the officers could at least have had the benefit of open trial.

title: Skating Show Is Seeking to Break the Ice With China
description: On the chance that a new opendoor policy may have been initiated by a United States tabletennis team, an intrepid impresario is making an effort to get into main land China with one of his six ice shows.

title: Martha C. Harmon Wed to C.H. Wilbur
description: COBALT, Conn., July 14 Miss Martha Christie Har mon was married here at noon today to Christopher Hayes Wilbur, son of Richard Purdy Wilbur, Olin Professor of English at Wesleyan Uni versity, and Mrs. Wilbur, of Middletown; Conn:, and Cum mington, Mass.

title: U.S. Said to Be Planning to Seek Indictment of a Times Reporter
description: BOSTON, July 14The Justice Department was report ed today to be planning to ask a Federal grand jury here to hand down a criminal indict ment against Neil Sheehan, reporter for The New York Times, in connection with the revelation of the Pentagon pa pers. The grand jury is investi gating how the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war was made available to the press.

title: UNION COUNTY BANK FACES A REHEARING
description: TRENTON, July 14 (AP)A state appeals court overturned today, a ruling by the State Banking COmmissioner granting the Union County, Trust Com pany the right to open a branch office in Eatontown.

title: City Drive on Bias Ties Up $200Million in Building
description: More than $200million in city construction for such things as schools, libraries and firehouses has been halted to bring pres sure on building trade unions to admit more blacks and Puer to Ricans.

title: News of Dogs
description: When Mrs. C. Westcott Gallop Jr. of Wayne, Ill., showed a dog in competition for the first time, she was not yet old enough to qualify for junior showmanship. She was 9 and the rules say child must be at least 10 to enter either the novice or junior classes. She had received a collie her ninth birth day. I showed him in breed events and train ed him for obedience, she recalled.

title: Newsday Appoints Forst Managing Editor for News
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 14 The appointment of Donald Forst as managing editor for news coverage of Newsday was announced today by David Laventhol, editor of the Long Island newspaper.

title: A Toast to Bastille Day At the French Embassy
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 On July 14, 1789, the day of French independence, the streets of Paris rang with the sound of gunshot. Today French embassies around the world observed Bastille Day, but.the only sounds were of corks popping from thou sands of champagne bottles.

title: General Dynamics Contract
description: The electric boat division of the General Dynamics Corpora tion has been awarded a $26 million, contract, by the United States Navy for the overhaul, refueling and conversion to Poseidon missiles, of the Polaris nuclear submarine Kameha meha.

title: Miss Bonitie Patton Maloney Bride of Peter Ebel in Ireland
description: Miss Bonnie Patton Maloney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Maloney of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married in the Naas Church on the Furness estate in Naas, County Kildare, Ireland, yesterday to Peter Martin Ebel, a writer and teacher. He is the son of Edwin W. Ebel, also of Chap paqua, and the late Mrs. Natalie Ebel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your article by Sanche de Gra moot [OpEd July 1] on former Secre tary of Defense McNamara your writer mentions that Albert Speer, with whom Mr. McNamara is compared in an unfavorable way, was never a member of the Nazi party. Mr. Speer requested party member ship and joined the Nazi party in Jan uary of 1931. His membership number was 474,481.

title: HUMPHREY, MUSKIE ASK MISSILE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Two Democratic Presidential candidates, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Senator Edmund S. Muskie, joined today in a proposal that the United States and Soviet Union freeze the deployment of nuclear weapons while they seek an agreement to control strategic arms.

title: COPPER FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Copper futures prices, which had dropped the last two ses sions, despite the continuing strike in the industry, rose yes terday on the Commodity Ex change (Comex) here. Trading was moderate.

title: Brenda Beauty Wins $33,800 Dash at Aqueduct
description: Availing himself of the splen did interference that his father set up for him, Bobby Wood house rode the Birchfield Farm's Brenda Beauty to vic tory in the $33,800 Astoria Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Nonoperators Learn Complexities of Placing Calls
description: An American Telephone and Telegraph Company supervisor hovered over her pupil, Who sat grinning at a bank of switch board lights and wires.

title: Flight From Children
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  It could almost have been predicted that the delegates to the National Women's Political Caucus in Washington last weekend would boo and heckle Dr. Benjamin Spock as a sexist.

title: Shop Talk
description: It's pretty hard to come up with something new for dogs these days but if Le Dog Store hasn't done it, it must have come close. All Brandes, Susan Kendrick and Jerry Comiskey, partners in the new establishment at 230 East 59th Street are offering satin wedding coats for canines. Both male and female ones are white but the female one is a bit fancier. Each costs the same, though$10.95 and like all good wedding clothes, these are made to order. As if this weren't enough, Le Dog Store makes coats of gold lame for going out on the town after dark. The lam is bordered with fancy gilt braid but if this sounds a bit too elaborate (or ex pensive, the coat is $16.95), there are jewelled necklaces that would make any old hound glitter on the night time scene.

title: Sternkopf Quits Port Authority; Hopes to Prove My Innocence
description: TRENTON, July 14William A. Sternkopf who was con victed in. Federal Court in Newark with seven others last week of charges of corruption in Hudson County resigned to day as New Jersey commis sioner on the Port of New York Authority.

title: DIALED CALLS GET SERVICE AS USUAL
description: Minor inconvenience rather than major disruption was the rule yesterday on the first day of the nationwide telephone strike.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DETROIT, July 14The 1971 AllStar Game turned out to be a good show, with the American League finally winning one, 64. It also demonstrated, indirectly and by contrast, a deep baseball problem that had been getting quiet but persistent attention among officials from Com missioner Bowie Kuhn down.

title: Patrnan Directs Lockheed To Prove Need for Loans
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Representative Wright Patman called on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation today to furnish hard evidence that it had ex hausted all other avenues for loans before his committee vot ed on the Administration bill to provide Government loan guarantees.

title: 29 U.S. Centers to Fight Heart and Lung Disease
description: To mobilize a considerable part of the nation's medical re sources for attacks on diseases of the heart, blood vessels and lungs, $16.4million in Federal funds has been granted for the establishment of 20 specialized centers of research. Two of the largest will be in this city.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Dean Acheson (OpEd July 7) says that the purloined papers should have been returned to their owners, the Government, Like the Chief Jus tice, he views the papers as physical possessions, in the category of lost shirtstuds or stolen fivedollar bills. Even so, it seems odd to return the evidence of deceit and betrayal of public trust to the authors of the deceit.

title: Eurodollar Borrowhigs Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (Reuters)Eurodollar borrow ings by United States banks from their foreign branches rose $570million in the week lended July 7 to $2,072,000,000 outstanding, the Federal Re serve reported today. The (in crease followed a decline of $767  million in the preceding week.

title: Razor Blade Ad Spurs Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (UPI)A damage suit for more than $1million was filed today on behalf of a 2yearold Los Angeles boy, Morgan Deegan, who was allegedly cut by a razor blade included in an ad vertisement. The defendants are The Los Angeles Times, Philip Morris, Inc., the Ameri can Safety Razor Company and 23 others. The suit said the ad, run as an insert in a number of papers, was likely to pro duce severe cuts and injuries.

title: WELTER DOMINATES TWO PENGUIN SERIES
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 14 Alex Welter of Sao Paulo, Brazil, who captured the junior series this morning, held the lead after two races in the International Penguin Class Dinghy Association senior championship later today.

title: Market Place: Analysts Revise I.B.M. Forecast
description: International Business Ma chines absorbed a 13point thrashing Tuesday in heavy trading and then skidded more points yesterday as Wall Street emerged from its shock over the huge com puter company's cheerless secondquarter financial re port.

title: FIFTHROUND DELAY. GRANTED TO LARSEN
description: DENVER, July 14Bent Lar sen of Denmark obtained a postponement today of his chess match tomorrow with Bobby Fischer of the United States because of illness.

title: LIQUORI IS VICTOR; RYUN FINISHES TOUR
description: FORMIA, Italy, July 14 (AP) Marty Liguori of Villanova easily defeated Gianni Del Buono of Italy today in a 2,000 meter race.

title: Senator Buckley Calls Antimilitary Binge a Threat to the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Senator James L. Buckley said today that the nation had been on an antimilitary binge forc ing sharp cutbacks in large areas of defense spending es sential to its security.

title: The Threatened Ibis
description: As it rises in brief flight, its snowy wings delicately fringed in black, the white ibis is an unforgettable sight. This beautiful wading bird and its rarer cousin, the wood ibis, grace the shores and marshes of the Southern coastal states.

title: DR. JOHN T. WILLIAMS OF MARYLAND STATE
description: SALISBURY, Md., July 14 (AP)  Dr. John T. Williams, longtime Maryland State Col lege president, died yesterday at Peninsula, General Hospital of what was termed a con gested failure, secondary to a heart failure, He was 66 years, old.

title: See What They Did To the Garage Sale
description: PASADENA,'Calif., July 14The stands of the Rose Bowl were empty Sunday. The only action on the football field came from automatic sprinklers scattering arcs of water to protect the grass from the sun, already scorching at 9 A.M. But outside, 20,000 persons formed long lines at the ticket booths and paid 50 cents for admission to the plaza that circles the stadium.

title: SENATE SUSTAINS PRESIDENT'S VETO OF JOBS PROGRAIYI
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Senate upheld today President Nixon's veto of a $5.6billion bill embracing an emergency job program for the unem ployed. The vote was 57 to 36, five short of the twothirds needed to override a Presiden tial veto.

title: Bridge: Aces Favored to Win Spingold In Chicago Play Next Week
description: During the Spingold Knock out Team Championship in Chicago next week, many of the topranked experts will be considering their chances of representing the United States in the World Team Olympiad in Miami next year.

title: Food, Happy Memory From a Painful Past
description: I couldn't understand how I could breathe,. It wasn't fresh air but at least ft was air. I lost all track of time felt the sweat running down my face and it was tickling, me. I had a strong desire to scratch my nose, but I couldn't move my hand. I cried again, wondering at the same time why I didn't feel hungry. As soon as I thought of it, I did, more than ever. If I could just have one meal, a good meal be fore I died.

title: MinorityBusiness Study Set
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) A House subcommittee will look into complaints that Gov ernment programs do not reach far enough or provide adequate funding in their efforts to help minority business enterprises, Representative Joe L. Evins, Democrat of Tennessee, chair man of the House Small Busi ness Committee, said today.

title: Vietnamese Refugees From Cambodia. Say They Don't Want to Go Back
description: TAMTHONG, South Vietnam, July 8One year after the allied attack on Cambodia swept them into the Indochina war, the Vietnamese settlers in Cambodia who fled the fighting there have put down new roots in South Vietnam and, despite the hardships, say they want to stay.

title: I.B.M. Expands Capacity Of System/7 Computer
description: The International Business Machines Corporation an nounced yesterday that it had expanded the data storage capacity of its System/7 and provided a new customde signed console. The System/7, introduced last fall, is I.B.M.'s lowestcost computer, renting for as little as $352 a month.

title: Relations With Peking Are Emerging As Key Issue for Australian Elections
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 14  The question of Australian relations with Communist China is shaping up as the ma jor, issue on which the next na tional elections will be fought.

title: Astronomers Detect Chemical Molecule Beyond Milky Way
description: Observations with California radio telescopes have, for the first time, detected a chemical molecule beyond the Milky Way Galaxy, or star system, of which the sun, earth and other planets are a part.

title: Voters in Suffolk Communities Act on SchoolRelated Issues
description: Voters in seven communities In Suffolk County voted yes terday on school budgets and fiscal proposals as well as school boardcandidates. In two districts, budget items submit ted for the second time were rejected again.

title: Paper Makers Profit Off
description: Profits of three major paper companiesthe Crown Zeller bach Corporation, the Kim berlyClark Corporation and the Scott Paper Companycon tinued to be depressed in the second quarter and first half, according to their midyear re ports yesterday.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Into the brave new world of environmental litigation enters a book intended to give lawyers and laymen a knowledge of the legal weap ons with which to combat the various forms of pollution that are, in Ralph Nader's in troduction, more than some thing smelly and ugly, but rather a silent, lethal long range form of violence.

title: BAR ASSOCIATION MEETS IN LONDON
description: LONDON, July 14With some of its members wearing top hats and cutaway coats, the American Bar Association began its London meeting with unaccustomed pageantry today in ancient Westminster Hall, the birthplace of England's earliest courts.

title: Progress Reported in Prostitution Drive
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that substantial progress had been made in ridding the midtown area of street solicita tion by prostitutes since a police crackdown began last week.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchange yes terday issued their latest reports on changes in own ership by major stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: QUEENS COLLEGE BACKS EXPANSION
description: The doubling of classroom space at Queens College is pro posed in the master plan for the Flushing institution, which was released yesterday. The cost was put at $140million.

title: Nuclear Detective Team Describes Method Used to Find an Errant Missile
description: A nuclear detective team, as signed to monitor any radio active buildup around atomic power plants, described yes terday how scientists used the same method to find a missile nose cone lost in Mexico that contained a lowenergy radio isotope.

title: Dusty and Sweets McGee' at Coronet
description: For 89 long minutes, in a new color film titled "Dusty and Sweets McGee," the camera glues to a group of young and not-so-young junkies lolling and wallowing around Los Angeles. Their language, denoting an almost methodical drug addiction and most of it delivered in a paranoid whine or mumble, is filthy. The point, quite literally, is an interminable, almost loving focus on needle injections.The sound-track spice is an intrusion of caterwauled rock 'n' roll. The low-keyed color photography by a Hollywood ace, William Fraker, is excellent. Such is the modest production, written and directed by Floyd Mutrux, which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater, with a cast primarily of actual dope addicts "doing their own thing." One viewer frankly wishes they had done it privately.Young Mr. Mutrux had a sound enough idea in recruiting a cast of nonprofessionals, letting them speak spontaneously and looping the vignettes together with a final, melodramatic flourish to underscore their plight.The horror is here to see, explicitly detailed. But the droning and the people, both, are repetitious, dirty and, worse, dull. It becomes stultifying. To listen is to learn, at least about this bunch.One dolorous youth labels himself a homosexual hustler, a seducer of young boys, who might not be "if the country were all it should be, ya know?" No. An older junkie babbles with a kind of jovial pride, standing before his alma mater, the Los Angeles jail. A runny-nosed girl peddler tells us that she's really "afraid of the junkies, ya know.""Ya know I'll be comin' home," yodels a sound-track singer in a sickening scene, as a baby-faced couple in their mid-teens prepare an injection that kills the boy. The boy has previously groaned, as if by accident, the most significant line in the picture: "Life isn't all (unprintable) and dope. People do things." Yes.

title: Tuesday Night Fight
description: Stateline, Nev.Ernie Shavers, 201 pounds, Warren, Ohio, knocked out Bill McMurrya, 210, Sacramento, Calif., 1 round.

title: LATE RALLY TRIMS LOSSES IN STOCKS
description: A late rally led by the glam our issuesand coming as surprise to some observers trimmed losses in the stock market yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 1.17 points to 891.21.

title: ASHE, GRAEBNER, RICHEY DEFEATED
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) Cliff. Richey, Arthur Ashe and Clark Graebner, three of the topranking American play ers, were knocked out of the $50,000 Washington Star inter national tennis tournament in the second round today.

title: Coach Quits After Students Win Ruling on Hair Length
description: SOMERS, N. Y., July 14 (UPI)  A high school football coach and two of his assistants resigned today in protest of the State Education Commissioner's ruling allowing scholastic ath letes to wear their hair long.

title: EARNINGS AT CHASE SLUMPED IN JUNE
description: The Chase Manhattan Cor poration, parent company of New York's second largest bank, reported yesterday a sharp deterioration in its prof itability during the month of June.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Mississippi Corporation announced yester day the election of Downing B. Jenks as president and chief executive and Robert H. Craft as chair man. They succeed the late William G. Marburg who held both posts. Mr. Jenks is president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, a subsidiary, and Mr. Craft is chairman of Mississippi River's finance committee.

title: Mellon National Mapping OneBank Holding Venture
description: The Mellon National Bank & Trust Company, Pittsburgh, the largest bank in Pennsylvania and the 13th largest in the na tion, announced yesterday plans to form a onebank hold ing company to take over ownership of the bank.

title: Package Reply to Vietcong Not Planned, Ziegler Says
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14The Western White House sought today to discourage speculation that President Nixon was preparing a pack age response to the Viet namese Communists seven point peace proposal of July 1.

title: William Donaldson Jr., 78 Dies; Headed the House Press Gallery
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)  William J. Donaldson Jr, former superintendent of the House Press Gallery and a prominent figure at national political events, died last night at his home here after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Giants Deny Agreement, But Jersey Talks Go On
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 14Wellington Mara, presi dent of the New York Giants, denied today a report that the club had reached agree ment with the New Jersey Sports Authority to move to the new sports complex planned for the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: 12% Decline Front 70 Period Is Far Short of Expectations
description: DETROIT, July 14Newcar sales sagged sharply in early July with 159,776 United States models reported sold, down 12 per cent from 181,491 deliv eries a year before and the lowest selling rate for July 110 in a decade.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I compliment The Times and John Noble Wilford for the recent series, Nation's Energy Crisis. In a debate normally dominated by extremists on one side or the other, all loudly shout ing their projections of doomsday un less this or that policy is immediately adopted, it is comforting to find some calmer heads who can sort out the problems and arguments clearly and dispassionately.

title: Thieu Charges Slander
description: SAIGON, Thursday, July 15 (AP)President Thieu accused Vice President Ky today of slandering him and said that the scathing charges made by Mr. Ky in a letter were part of a political campaign.

title: ALGERIA, TUNISIA SUPPORT HASSAN
description: TUNIS, July 13King Has san II of Morocco, who staved off an attempt at a military coup last Saturday, has been assured of the support of his North African neighbors, Tu nisia and Algeria, at least on the surface.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Continuation of the meet ing requested by the Senega lese Government3 P.M.

title: Women of Yale
description: NEW HAVENFor the first time in its long male history, Yale College last month graduated women182 in a class of 1,132. Called superwomen when first admitted two years ago as transfer students, they have frequently scored higher academically than their male classmates.

title: Volkswagen and Ford Buses Called Inadequate
description: The two largestselling mini buses in the United States are grossly inadequate when it comes to safety, the magazine Consumer Reports charged yes terday.

title: Unit Formed by Sutton and Jones Buys WLIBAM
description: Radio station WLIBAM, which caters mainly to New York's black community, has been sold for $1.9million to a group headed by Percy E. Sut ton, Manhattan Borough Presi dent, and Clarence B. Jones, editor and publisher of The Amsterdam News.

title: Stolen Audubon Prints Found in Queens Motel
description: A collection of stolen rare books was recovered last night by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at a Queens motel near Kennedy Interna tional Airport, the F.B.I. re ported.

title: Jordan Acknovviedges Clash in Effort to Oust Guerrillas From Inhabited Areas
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 14 Jordan announced today that her troops had been battling Palestinian commandos in the northern hills since yesterday in an attempt to push them away from inhabited areas.

title: Soviet and Benelux Sign Their First Trade Treaty
description: BRUSSELS, July 14 (UPI) The Soviet Union signed to day its first trade treaty with Beneluxthe economic union of. Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. The treaty pro vides for mutual mostfavored nations treatment.

title: Civil Rights Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Howard A. Glickstein an nounced today that he was re signing as staff director of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, effective Aug. 13. The Rev. Theodore M. Hes burgh, president of the Univer sity of Notre Dame and com mission chairman, said deputy director John Buggs would be acting staff director pending appointment of a successor.

title: Bond Director Resigns
description: Joseph Klingenstein has re signed for reasons of health from the board of Bond Indus tries, Inc. Mr. Klingenstein is a senior partner of Wertheim & Co., investment bankers. He has been succeeded on the Bond board by Alfred Klein baum, also a Wertheim partner.

title: DETECTIVE'S STORY QUESTIONED HERE
description: The lawyer of a police lieu tenant accused of conspiring with the men of his command over the division of bribes said yesterday that the prosecu tion's key witness had told two completely different stories while under oath.

title: 3 TALL BUILDINGS FOUGHT IN QUEENS
description: Elected officials, civic leaders and residents of eastern Queens argued yesterday before the City Planning Commission against construction of three 32story apartment buildings on a small part of the Glen Oaks golf course.

title: Advertising.
description: Wilson, Haight & Welch, a 44yearold, Hartfordbased agency, and the Bresnick Company, 35, of. Boston, became one yesterday. The ceremony was held in Boston, the home of the bride.

title: MRS. RICHARD WILLIAMS
description: Mrs. Katharine Landis Wil liams, wife of Richard Williams, senior vice president of Amer ican Avitron, Inc., died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital of a short illness. She was 52 years old and had homes in Fairfield, Conn., and Manchester, Vt.

title: EASED APARTHEID SEEN IN JOB NEED
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 13The growing economy is undergoing strains that are hurting nonwhites now but may help erode apart heid in the long, run.

title: Canadian Gets Invitation
description: VANCOUVER, B. C., July 14 (Canadian Press)  The Op Inosition leader, Robert L. Stan field, received an official invita tion today to visit China. He asked for a visa seven weeks ago.

title: News Analysis
description: On Tuesday evening, the Po lice Department scheduled a news conference for 10 A.M. yesterday on the nearfatal shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the reputed Mafia leader. Then, at the last minute yes terday, the conference was called off. I had a sore throat, Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman explained with a grin. No rea son, the depart ment's new press spokesman, Deputy Commissioner Rob ert Daley, added, smiling slightly.

title: KENNEDY DENOUNCES THE A.M.A. AND NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)Senator Edward M. Ken nedy accused President Nixon and the American Medical As sociation today of forming a marriage of convenience op posed to meaningful reform of the nation's health care system.

title: JACKSON TV STATION DEFENDS PRACTICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) David Mieher, news director for television station WLBT, Jackson, Miss testified at a Federal Communications Com mission hearing today that his station had followed standard newsservice guidelines in iden tifying persons in its news broadcasts.

title: Teamster Pension Aide Indicted in Kickbacks
description: An official of the teamster union's pension fund was in dicted yesterday on charges of obtaining a $55,000 kickback to approve a pensionfund loan to a financially troubled tex tile company.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 14 (UPI)Henry Bunis of Cincin nati, who had upset topseeded Raul Ramirez of La Jolla, Calif., was beaten today by Mark Meyers of New Orleans, 64, 46, 60, in the fourth round of the national junior clay court tennis championship.

title: NAVY ADOPTS PLAN ON MS AMNESTY
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  The Navy and the Marine Corps announced today an amnesty program for drug abusers who volunteer for rehabilitation, but they said twotime viola tors could face disciplinary action.

title: HUGHES EXPECTED TO SHUN 72 RACE
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa is expected to announce at a Capital Hill news confer ence tomorrow that he will not be a candidate for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination.

title: KLEIMAN QUITTING SURROGATE RACE
description: Crimlnal Court Judge Alfred H. Kleiman announced yester day his withdrawal as a candi date far the Democzatic noml nation for surrogate.

title: ROBERT B. WILKE, 55, R.K.O. GENERAL AIDE
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 14 Robert B. Wilke, director of sales development for R.K.O. General, Inc., of New York, died of cancer Monday evening at New York Hospital, He Was 55 years old and lived at 3 Brit tany Lane.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  When leaders of the Commu nications Workers of Amer.ica asked members to sanc tion the strike that began today against the Bell Sys tern, the request was made over a network of 65 tele vision stations. It was typical of the Innovative leadership of Joseph An thony Beirne the philosopher of the American union movement and the only president the 500,000mem ber Communications Workers union has had since it was formed in 1947.

title: MARKET CAMPAIGN PRESSED BY HEATH
description: LONDON, July 14  Prime Minister Heath, faced with hardening opposition from the trade unions and the Labor party, sought to marshal the full support of his own, party today for his Government's de cision to join the Common Mar ket.

title: Lawyers Club Lets In Women Members Now
description: Another breach has ap peared in a stronghold of male supremacy, the busi nessman's lunch club. The Lawyers Club at 115 Broad way, a Wall Street area rendezvous where business is transacted over midday food and drink, is going to admit women as members.

title: Mineral Research Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Senate Interior Commit tee approved a bill today call ing for a multimilliondollar mineral research program, The bill would authorize Federal grants to states for establish ment of mineral research and training centers.

title: SALT's Auspicious Opening
description: Word from Helsinki indicates that the latest round of strategic arms limitation talks has got off to a good start, at least in the sense that serious discussions aimed constructive results have taken place. The improved atmosphere was forecast last week by Pravda's com mentary on SALT resumption, which read like an effort to begin preparing Soviet public opinion for an agree ment.

title: Ky Says Thieu Tries to Rig Vote
description: SAIGON, Vietnam, July 14 Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky accused President Nguyen Van Thieu today of, using dictatori al practices to silence the op position, muzzle the press and insure his reelection.

title: 3 PREMIERES SLATED IN JOFFREY SEASON
description: Three premieres and a revival will be presented by the City Center Joffrey Ballet in its sixweek fall season from Oct. 6 through Nov. 14 at the City Center.

title: NIXON WILL PRESS PENDLETON PLANS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 14The White House said to day that President Nixon was prepared to override a recom mendation by the House Armed Services Committee against his proposed transfer of more than 4,000 acres of Camp Pendleton to the State of California for recreational use.

title: Soviet Details Conspiracy Behind Pentagon Papers
description: MOSCOW, July 14Soviet readers, still curious about how it was possible for several American newspapers to pub lish secret Pentagon papers on Vietnam without the Govern ment's approval, were today given a conspiratorial explana tion that reflects some current Soviet thinking about America.

title: City to Control the Group Developing the Navy Yard
description: The city administration is to get majority control of the board of directors of the non profit corporation that for the last five years has been work ing to develop the old Brooklyn Navy Yard as an industrial park.

title: Heavy Surf at 2 L.I. Parks Brings Beach Restrictions
description: WANTAGH, L.L, July 14 Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Parks were closed to ocean swimmers at 10:30 A.M. today because of heavy surf and the continued absence of lifeguards.

title: JOHN F. WESTFIELD, A CHURCH AIDE, 64
description: John F. Westfield, secretary of church development and building of the United Church of Christ, died Tuesday in St. Vincent's Hospital after being struck by a car near his office at 289 Park Avenue South. He was 64 years old and lived at 42 Brookfield Road in Upper Montclair, N.J.

title: SIMPSON'S 69 SETS JERSEY OPEN PACE
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 14 Paul Simpson, a 20yearold college golfer, followed last year's pattern when an ama teur won, by leading the New Jersey open with a 69 today.

title: SAMUEL Z. LEVINE PEDIATRICIAN 76
description: Dr. Samuel Zachary Levine, a noted pediatrician and a member of the New York City Board of. Health, died yester day of a coronary occlusion at his home. He was 75 years old and lived at 345 East 69th Street.

title: FACTORY OUTPUT UP AGAIN IN JUNE
description: WASHINGTON, July 14In dustrial production rose in June for the fourth consecutive month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: CAUTIOUS BIDDER SCORES ON COAST
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 14 (AP)John Rota brought Cau tious Bidder back from a poor start to an impressive victory today in the $103,575 Holly wood Lassie Stakes at Holly wood Park.

title: American Can Net Drops;
description: Weakening prices for bev erage cans and disruptions re lated to the firstquarter strike sharply reduced profits of the American Can Company in the three and six months ended HJune 30, according to yester day's semiannual report.

title: Continned Slack in. U.S Economy Forecast by O.E.C.D.
description: PARIS, July 14The Organi zation for Economic Coopera tion and Development forecast today continued slack in the United States economy over the next year and a deteriorat ing trade balance.

title: Iceland Would Shut U.S. Base
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 14 (AP)Iceland's new leftist government said today it would renegotiate the defense agree ment with the United States with a view to closing the large North Atlantic Treaty Organi zation base at Keflavik.

title: Moss Asks Recycled Paper
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) Senator Frank E. Moss Democrat of Utah, introduced a bill today to require that The Congressional Record be printed on recycled paper. He also in troduced a bill making recycled paper available for use in Con gressional offices. He con tended, that the United. Statei could reclaim 200 million tons of waste paper a year.

title: Prince Franz Josef, 77, Of Thurn and Taxis House
description: REGENSBURG, West Ger many, July 14 (AP)Prince Franz Josef von Thurn and Taxis, head of one of Europe's oldest noble frimilies, died yes teday after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: NIXON URGES LIMIT ON CAMPAIGN MAIL
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  The Nixon Administration pro posed yesterday that any limit on campaign spending cover expenditures for direct mail as well as radio, television and newspaper advertising.

title: Chess: Fischer's Recent Showings Create Unbeatable Image
description: A chess tournament for computers will be held in Chicago over the first week end in August. It is reassur ing to know that some of our best technical minds are at Work in this area, and we May someday have a ma chine that can hold its own with Bobby Fischer. Clearly no human player appears capable of doing it.

title: BAN ON ARMS AID TO GREECE FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  A proposal to ban arms aid to Greece was narrowly defeated today in the House Foreign Af fairs Committee.

title: Reprimand and Fine For Antiwar Officer
description: LAKENHEATH, England, July 14Capt. Thomas S. Culver was reprimanded today and fined $1,000 for taking part in an antiwar demonstration.

title: About Pro Football
description: Phil Olsen, a touted de fensive lineman, signed with the Los Angeles Rams yes terday, thus joining his fa mous brother Merlin, eight years his senior. The younger Olsen, a first draft choice a year ago, had belonged to the New England Patriots, but his lawyer, Ed Masry, found a flaw in the contract and Olsen recently was declared a free agent. Twenty teams made bids for Olsen, an allAmerican at Utah State. The Rams will have to compensate the Pa triots with a player of draft choice of equal value, and negotiations between them began yestbrday.

title: Value of the Dollar Continues to Erode In Trading Abroad
description: PARIS, July 14The West German central bank is de termined not to show a monthly increase in its dollar holdings during the period of the float ing mark.

title: Soviet Jews in Plea to U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Thursday, July 15 (UPI)  Georgian Jews on a hunger strike in the Moscow post office sent cablegrams to day to President Nixon and other world leaders protesting Soviet refusal to permit them to go to Israel.

title: Guyana and Alcan Reach Accord on Compensation
description: MONTREAL, July 14 (Cana dian Press)  The Government of Guyana and Alcan Alumi num, Ltd., of Canada have reached an agreement on compensation as a result of the nationalization of the Demerara Bauxite Company, an Alcan subsidiary.

title: St. Anseim's Coach Quits
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., July 14 (UPI) AI Grenert announced today he was resigning after 22 years as varsity basketball coach at St. Anselm's College, which in April eliminated ath letic scholarships for basket ball.

title: Fuel Measures Adequate
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Justice Department said today existing antitrust laws are presently adequate to deal with any mergers between coal and oil interests or other sources of energy.

title: NADER PROPOSES PENSION CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Ralph Nader advanced today a plan to revise the nation's pri vate pension programs and in crease the individual worker's control over his share of the money.

title: S.E.C. Adopts Revisions Of Form on Mutual Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Securities and Exchange Com mission announced today that it had adopted revisions of its form. N1R on which mutual fund mangement companies re port to the commission.

title: DECISION RESERVED ON SUIT BY A CABBY
description: A judge in Small Claims Court reserved decision early this morning in a case involv ing a taxi driver who contends that owners have been illegally deducting money from their drivers paychecks since March 2, when the cab fares were raised.

title: Phillips Oil Expanding
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla., July 14 (UPI)The Phillips Petro leum Company has announced plans to construct facilities at its Philtexplant near Borger, Tex., to manufactitre new poly phenylene sulfide plastic resins. The unit will have a capacity of about six million pounds a year and is scheduled for com pletion in mid1973.

title: Yankees at Home Today
description: Today is Senior Citizens Day at Yankee Stadium for the game between the Yankees and the Milwaukee Brewers. Senior citizens will be admitted to the park for 50 cents.

title: Laird Stops Off in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, July 14 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird arrived here last night for a stay of several days to work on a report of his trip to Asia.

title: JACKSON PRODS U.S. TO GIVE ISRAEL JETS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14  Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, press ing Israel's repeated requests for more American Phantom fighterbombers, today accused Secretary of State William P. Rogers of helping to make the Soviet Union a major Middle Eastern power.

title: ell Vows to Give Caster A Battle for Sauer's Spot
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 14 Contact lenses were ordered today for Rich Caster, the New York Jets wide receiver with an opportunity to be a starter following George Sauer's retire ment.

title: Windward Passage Sets Sailing Record
description: HONOLULU, July 14 (AP) Pushed by a 20knot north east wind, the 73foot ketch, Windward Passage, sailed past Diamond Head to be come the first yacht to finish the transPacific yacht race, finishing at 8:09 P.M. yester day, Hawaii time.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: JERUSALEM, July 14 (Reu ters)Foreign Minister Abba Eban today urgently appealed for more United States Phantom jets to counter the accelerated Soviet supply to Egypt and Syria.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE ONION EATERS, 13v J. P. Donloavy. 306 pages. Delacorte Press. A Sevrridur Law renca Book. $7.95.

title: John M. S. Hutchinson, 54; An Inventor and Sportsman
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., July 14John M.S. Hutchinson, art inventor and sportsman, was killed in an accident Monday while on a mountainclimbing expedition in Juneau, Alaska. He was 58 years old and form erly lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: REYNOLDS METALS SUED ON TRUST ACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a civil antitrust suit today charging the Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second largest, domestic producer of aluminum, with illegal reciproc ity.

title: Alaska Quake Recorded
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 14 (AP)A moderate earthquake occurred 170 miles south of Sitka and 140 miles west of Ketchikan at 3:24 P.M. today, the Palmer Observatory report ed. He said the tremor was felt in Ketchikano but no injuries or damage were reported.

title: Oklahoma Hires Walker
description: NORMAN, Okla., July 14 (AP) Wade Walker, former athlet ic director at Mississippi State University, today was named athletic director at Oklahoma University. He succeeds Gomer Jones, who died of a heart at tack in New York in March.

title: Freed Tug in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 14 (AP) The tug Battler arrived in Puerto Rico today a week after her release from Cuba. The Miamibased tug, with seven crewmen, was released by the Cubans along with other cap tives July 7 in exchange for the return of four Cuban fish ermen held in the United States.

title: Students Demonstrate Against Peking in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Members of Young Americans for Freedom,. a conservative student organization, demon strated today across the street from the White House against the admission of the Commu nist China to the United Na tions.

title: Apollo 15 Completes Final Practice Countdown in Preparation for July 26 Liftoff on Flight to Moon
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 14  The astronauts and machines of Apollo 15 com pleted their final practice countdown tests today and ap peared to be ready to embark July 26 on the nation's fourth moonlanding mission.

title: Narcotic Addicts Agencies Seek Funds on Street
description: Show a little tenderness! Irving Clayton pleaded yester day as he waved a jar marked, Phoenix House near the face, of an oblivious passerby on Fifth Avenue near 53d Street.

title: Reagan Hints He May Support Nixon Welfare Plan
description: JACKSON LAKE, Wyo., July 14Gov. Ronald Reagan indi cated today that he would prob ably support President Nixon's plan to convert the aid to de pendent children welfare pro gram into a program for guar anteed annual income for poor families.

title: WIDE BACKING FOUND FOR PAYPRICE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Public support for wage and price controls is at the highest level since the Korean war, according to a Gallup poll re leased today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: OSLO, July 14 (UPI)  Jim Ryun of Wichita, Kan., who said he was competing for the last time in Europe this season, placed third in the 800meter race in 1 minute 49.6 seconds tonight at Bislett Stadium.

title: WATERS BLUES BAND ROUSES ITS AUDIENCE
description: Muddy Waters brought his blues band to the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Met ropolitan Museum of Art Tues day night for the second eve ning in the museum's current series of folk concerts.

title: Allied Bulldozers Are Clearing An ExVietcong Base for Crops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (AP)United States and South Vietnamese troops with bulldozers and tanks began clearing a large wooded and scrubbrush area north of here today to permit farmers to re turn to land that had long served as a Vietcong stronghold.

title: WagePrice Controls?
description: For two years George Meany has been warning the Nixon Administration that pleas for voluntary restraint are never going to check the wageprice spiral. Last weekend, in his strongest statement yet, the crusty A.F.L.C.I.O. chief set forth his conviction that mandatory controls on an acrosstheboard basis represent the only way to halt inflation.

title: HARVEY M'CLINTOCK OF INVESTMENT FIRM
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 14Harvey C. McClintock, a general partner in Stillman, Maynard & Co., investment house of 61 Broadway, New York, died early today. He was 58 years old and lived at 91 Wolver Hollow Road.

title: Lincoln's Springfield Home Gains as a Historic Site
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP)  The House Interior Committee approved today a bill to establish Abraham LinColn's Home. In Springfield, Ill., as a national historic site.

title: GROUP HERE SEEKS TO HALT GEE. MOVE
description: The Suburban Action Insti tute said yesterday that it had asked the Federal Government, in effect, to block the General Electric Company's plan to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Fairfield, Conn.

title: Complexities of Piranesi's Prints Unfold at Princeton
description: Scholarly confusion sur rounding the art of the 18th century printmaker Giovanni Battista Piranesi is formid able. One need only consider, say the baffling chronologies of prints pulled during his lifetime and compound that with perplexing dates of prints pulled after his death.

title: AUSTRALIAN SAYS CHINA NOW FAVORS INDOCHINA PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Australian Embassy told the State Department today that China had expressed interest in participating in a new Geneva conference on Indochina.

title: A Reasonable Chance
description: WASHINGTONPublication of the Pentagon Papers has increased a wide spread feeling that the public has not been adequately informed of United States intentions in Vietnam. The credibility of the Government was al ready at low point. To restore con fidence it is essential that the Admin istration now clarify its aims in Vietnam.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS TRADING SLOWS
description: With trading slackening off froth the day before, prices on the American Stock Ex change declined slightly yester day.

title: Monsanto Yarn Prices Up
description: The Monsanto Company, a major producer, of manmade fibers, announced yesterday price increases for much of its Inylon product line in the ap parel area.

title: Quake Shakes Solomons
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 14 (AP)  A strong earthquake shook the Solomon Islands in the South Pacific today and caused a tidal wave that did widespread damage on the island of New Britain in the Australian Trust Territory of New Guinea, One man was re ported drowned and at least three persons were injured when the 7foot wave swept over the island.

title: Merger News
description: The General Host Corpora tion announced yesterday it has received valid tenders for more than 80 per cent of the outstanding voting securities of the Cudahy Company, based on preliminary calcu lations received from the tender agent.

title: I.O.S. Dissidents Report Injunction Against Chairman
description: An opposition group attempt ing to wrest control of Investors Overseas Servicesthe giant mutual fund group4rom Rob ert L. Vesco, its board chair man, reported from St. John, New Brunswick, yesterday that it had obtained a preliminary injunction against Mr. Vesco.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE PROUD OF VICTORY IN ALLSTAR GAME
description: DETROIT, July 14  Last night's AllStar Game started as the Vida Blue story and wound up as the saga of the Reggie JacksonFrank Robinson mutual admiration society.

title: JOSEPH
description: NORTH MIAMI, Fla., July 14 Joseph Klinghoffer, a former news distributor of Wheeling, W. Va., died here today at the age of 69. Since 1959, he had lived in retirement at the Hort zon House at 125th Terrace, and had been active as a part time steel salesman in Miami.

title: 6 Persons in Month Listed in Suffolk With Spotted Fever
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 14 Six cases of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, a dangerous viral disease transmitted by tick bites, were reported in Suffolk County last month, according to Dr. George E. Leone, the county's Health Commissioner.

title: Taiwan to Fight to Keep U.N. Seat, But Doesn't Expect to Win
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 14  The Chinese Nationalist Govern ment here appears almost re signed to losing its seat In the United Nations. It plans to fight to the end but is already con templating the aftermath of defeat.

title: Suicide Called Murderer
description: CHESTER, England, July 14 (Reuters)A man found dead in a fumefilled car left a note confessing to the brutal mur ders of three French campers Monday, the police said today.

title: GIANTS DEFENSE CONCERNS DRYER
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 14  After two apparently frenetic and formless days of training camp, patterns began to emerge today in drills among the Giant rookies and free agents at C. W. Post College.

title: and Public Service Jobs
description: President Nixon has signed the Emergency Employ ment Act of 1971, a bill authorizing the Government to spend up to $2.25 billion over the next two years to create between 150,000 and 200,000 public service jobs for the unemployed. Mr. Nixon vetoed a similar bill last December because he said it would create deadend, W.P.A.type jobs. He expressed willingness to sign the new bill only because it would be temporary and provide training to help workers move to permanent jobs.

title: ExLinebacker Gives Frazier Bloody Nose
description: HOUSTON, July 14 (UPI) Joe Frazier, the heavyweight champion, suffered a bloody nose in the first round of a tworound exhibition bout to night with a 21yearold heavyweight who has had only one professional fight.

title: Fish Fry Helps Drive for a House Panel on Aging
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Hubert Humphrey, a former Chief of Protocol in sneakers and about 2,000 others ate catfish hushpuppies and watermelon at a gasoline sta tion parking lot three blocks from the Capitol last night.

title: All Horses in Texas Placed in Quarantine
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 14 (UPI)Every horse in Texas was quarantined today against an epidemic of a rare sleeping sickness virus that has killed thousands of the animals in South America, Mexico and the United Stales.

title: State Considering Action Against Brokerage Firms
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz suggested strongly here yesterday that his office was compiling evidence that might lead to legal action against several New York brokerage firms on charges of irregularities in the reporting of their financial condition.

title: HUNT T. WAGSTAFF
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., July 14Hunt Tilford Wagstaff, a clog fancier and fire commis sioner here, died yesterday after a sudden illness. He was 62 years old.

title: South Africa's Violent Society
description: In South Africa whites either ac cept the immorality of the racist sys tem whilst enjoying the world's high est standard of living, or oppose the system and suffer harassment and police surveillance. There is no neutral position.

title: Street Academy Program Sends School WalkOuts to. Colleges
description: Fortytwo students who walked, out of the public school system graduated yes terday from the New York Ur ban League Street Academy Program and are bound for col leges across the country.

title: GEORGE GILLETTE, ARMY ENGINEER
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., July 14 (AP) Col. George William Gillette, a widely known engi neer and economic consultant for ports, harbors and water ways, died yesterday at a hos pital here. He was 83 years old.

title: CairoAmman Ties Cooling
description: CAIRO, July 14Relations between Egypt and Jordan, al ternately warm and frigid over the last 15 years, were cooling fast today as a result of Egyp tian anger over the new drive by the Jordanian Army against Palestiniaft guerrilla encamp ments.

title: Notes on People
description: Hell bath no fury like a women's liberationist scorned, and yesterday two of them were furious over reports that President Nixon, Secre tary of State William P. Rogers and Henry A. Kis singer, the Presidential ad viser, had made jokes about the recently formed National Women's Political Caucus.

title: TAINTED SOUP HUNT IS SHORT 1,200 CANS
description: The United States Food and Drug Administration said yes terday that 1,200 cans of a batch of Bon Vivant vichys soise that was found to con tain botulinus toxin were still unaccounted for.

title: Advertising.
description: The Federal Trade Com mission's constantly widening area of interest now actively includes that everpopular form of advertising: the prod uct endorsement.

title: Stans, After Tour, Rejects Contentions Of Cruelty to Seals
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Secretary of Commerce Mau rice H. Stans described as to tally unfounded today chargeS that seals on the Pribilof Islands off Alaska were being inhu manely and indiscriminately slaughtered.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING POSTS GAIN IN HALF
description: The Pacific Lighting Corpo ration reported yesterday gains in firsthalf operating revenues and net income.

title: Dr. Lynn H. Hough Dead at 93; A Leading Methodist Educator
description: The Rev. Dr. Lynn Harold Hough, a prominent Methodist clergyman and educator, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 93 years old and lived at 1165 Fifth Avenue.

title: Youths Seeking Freedom on the Road
description: BIG SUR, Calif.A girl hitchhiked through here the other day, carrying a pack with the words Boy Scouts of America stamped on it. But the Boy Scouts had been crossed out and the word Freaks written in.

title: The Talk of Trailer City
description: NORTH BERGEN, N. J., July 14Visit New York City from New Jersey. That's the latest.

title: Baltimore Slowdown Ends
description: BALTIMORE, July 15 (AP) A fivedayold work slowdown by the city's firemen dead locked in contract talks with the city ended this morning after negotiators agreed yester day to put their wage demands before a city panel. The cur rent pay scale ranges from $7,880 to $10,044, after five years.

title: SAVINGS UNIT SUES ON FRANCHISE TAXES
description: A Queens savings and loan association, with the support of a group representing 174 sav ings and loan associations in the state, yesterday challenged the constitutionality of a 1953 statute requiring savings and loan associations to pay fran chise taxes to both the state and the city at a higher rate than those levied against com mercial banks.

title: Stans Urges Caution in Pollution Fight
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Secretary of Commerce Mau rice H. Stans urged today that programs to halt pollution be weighed carefullyand slowly to determine if they will be too costly or ineffective.

title: Facts About Killing and Crippling Diseases
description: Despite great advances in medical science, heart at tacks, strokes and cancer continue to exact a heavy toll among Americans. De tails on these and other major killers and cripplers were listed yesterday in a study released by the Nation al Health Education Com mittee.

title: Benning's 139 Leads New Jersey Open by
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 15 Bob Benning, often a spotter for the American Broadcasting Company when pro tour events are televised, took the lead in the New Jersey open golf championship today. A. second round of 69, one under par for the 6,502yard Montclair Golf Club course, gave the Plainfield Country Club professional a threestroke margin with a 36 hole aggregate of 139.

title: Syria Seeks to Mediate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 15 Syria began efforts today to end the fighting between the Jordanian Army and the feday een.

title: Exchange to Proceed
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 David Callahan, president of the West Coast Commodity Ex change said today that the ex change would proceed with its plans to trade in gold futures despite a statement by the United States Treasury that it would be illegal.

title: VARIABLE ANNUITIES WIN S.E.C. SUPPORT
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 The Securities and Exchange Commission today endorsed legislation that would exempt certain variable annuities from a requirement that they refund to purchasers, at any time with in 45 days of their purchase, the full value of their invest ment plus any sales charges.

title: Rail TonMileage Down 11.4% From the 70 Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Freight traffic on the nation's railroads in the week ended July 10 totaled an estimated 11.3 billion tonmiles, 11.4 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago.

title: Heart Attack Kills Flipper
description: GRASSY KEY, Fla., July 15 (UPI)  Mitzi, the first dolphin to star as Flipper, is dead. Mr. and Mrs. Milton Santini dis closed today that the sea mam mal died June 25 of a heart at tack at their tourist attraction in the Florida Keys. Her age was undetermined. Mitzi was star in the 1963 film Flipper, a forerunner of the television series, which featured other dolphins.

title: 3 in Wheelchairs Drown
description: ELDORA, Iowa, July 15 (AP) Three disabled war veterans in wheelchairs drowned after boat overturned during a fish ing outing from the Soldiers Home in Marshalltown. Six per sons were rescued. The victims were Charles Seaton, 81 years old, of Springville; Chester Stroud, 40, of Des Moines, and Jorgan R. Hoversten, 77, of Jewell.

title: BOSTON AREA LEADS IN WELFARE SURVEY
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The biggest percentage of its population on welfare and the rate of increase in the District of Columbia is running nearly 60 per cent above last year, Department of Health, Educa tion and Welfare survey shows.

title: Democrats See Agnew Trip As Sign Nixon Will Drop Him
