description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The Democratic National Committee has described Vice President Agnew's 10nation goodwill tour as a meaningless mission that indicates President Nixon will drop him from the Republican ticket in 1972.

title: 3 POLICEMEN DENY DISCUSSING BRIBES
description: Three policemen denied yes terday that they attended a meeting in June, 1967, during which another policeman al legedly told them that only those who picked up graft from gamblers would share in the graft.

title: Copper Futures Prices Retreat As September Leads Activity
description: After rising the day before, copper futures prices dropped yesterday in commodity trad ing despite the fact that the copper strike has not ended.

title: Greece Outlines Aid
description: ATHENS, July 15The Greek Government said tonight that the press had misrepresented the nature of the proposed $118million United States militaryaid program to Greece for the current fiscal year.

title: U.S. CHECKS ON TWO IN RACEWAY INQUIRY
description: The Joint Federal Strike Force Against Organized Crime is investigating a report that a Yonkers Raceway executive and a stateappointed track of ficial won more than $6,000 on a suspicious race that touched off a riot at the Yonkers har ness track on June 7.

title: Helms Displays A Winning Way With Song Here
description: Jimmy Helms flew in from the fourth Olympiad of opening Monday night of his fourweek engagement at Shepheard's in the Drake Ho tel, 56th Street and Park Avenue, bringing with him a medallion for best singer at the festival, where he com peted with entrants from 41 countries. His performance at Shepheard's indicates why he came out on top.

title: Tate Vetoes Bar Tax
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) Mayor James H. J. Tate ve toed today the City Council's proposed 10 per cent tax on acrossthebar liquor sales de signed to raise money for the city's public schools.

title: Famed Garden City Hotel Is Closing
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 15The Garden City Hotel, which for almost a century was the center for such di verse activities as quiet wed dings, gala balls and raucous political conventions, is clos ing its doors.

title: 3 TELL OF DANGER OF AMPHETAMINE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Three young former drug users testified today that ampheta mines were easy to obtain il licitly and that their overuse was often a first step toward incarceration in a mental hos pital.

title: The Health of Americans
description: Epidemics such as those which claimed millions lives periodically in the Middle Ages have long since disappeared in the United States, thanks to advances sanitation, nutrition and medical knowledge. In a typical year, death claims less than 1 per cent of the population and of those who die, more than half have passed three score and ten. Over the last quarter of a century the life expectancy of a newborn American has increased seven years; it now exceeds seventy.

title: 72 DRAFT LOTTERY PLANNED IN AUGUST
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The Selective Service System is planning to go ahead with the 1972 draft lottery early next month regardless of whether Congress acts by then to extend the draft law, offi cials said today.

title: B. & M. Trustees Petition I.C.C. for Role in N. & W.
description: The trustees of the Boston & Maine Corporation as well as the Group of Institutional Bond holders of the B. & M. (largely insurance companies holding more than $46million of B. & M. bonds) have filed petitions with the Interstate Commerce Commission once more asking the agency to include the B & M. in the Norfolk & Western Railway.

title: Store Sales Decline
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partment store sales at $654 million, down 6 per cent from the yearearlier $699million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $6,998,000,000, down 1 per cent from $7,101, 000,000.

title: Frederick C. Schang 3d Dead; Executive of Columbia Artists
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., July 15 Frederick C. Schang 3d, a vice president of Columbia Artists Management, Inc., died today after a long illness. He was 44 years old and lived at 390 West End Avenue in New York.

title: U.S. and Vietcong Plans For Peace Are Compared
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Following is a chart com paring peace proposals by President Nixon in June, 1969, and October, 1970, with Vietcong positions in 1969 and July, 1971. Mr. Nixon has not yet replied to the latest Vietcong proposal.

title: ExCity Aide Joins Hospital
description: Dr. David Harris, who re cently resigned as deputy com missioner of the city Health De partment, has been named as sociate director of Mount Sinai Hospital. Dr. Harris has also been appointed associate pro fessor in the department of administrative medicine and assistant professor in the De partment of pediatrics at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: PLUNKETT SIGNS WITH PATRIOTS
description: AMHERST. Mass., July 15 (AP)Jim Plunkett, the Reis man Trophywinning quarter back from Stanford who was the National Football League's top draft choice this year, signed a multiyear contract with the New England Patriots tonight.

title: CRAMPTON AHEAD IN CHICAGO ON 66
description: CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) Bruce Crampton of Australia fashioned a fiveunderpar 66 today to take the firstround lead in the $150,000 Western open golf tournament but Lee Trevino warned, I'm not out of it yet.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: Area A Anglers are doing extremely well with bluefish along Barnegat Ridge, about 22 miles south of Manasquan Inlet. The choppers, averag ing 8 to 10 pounds, are re sponding to chumming. School tuna also are being encoun tered in the same region. Sea bass and blacks are appear ing in fair number on the rocks and wrecks east of Manasquan. Fluke, from 2 to 5 pounds, have been in evi dence along the Spring Lake area. Jetty jockeys using Hopkins lures and other jigs are capturing small blues be tween the Inlet and Asbury Park.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE KINGS OF VAIN INTENT. By Graham Shelby. 307 pages. Weybright & Talley. $6.95.

title: Roundup: Royals Win on Piniella's Hit
description: Lou Piniella got even with the Cleveland Indians last night.

title: U.S. Suit Against Mine Union Comes to Trial After 6 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Six years and six months after it filed suit, the Government brought the United Mine Work ers union to trial today for alleged violations of a Federal law that is supposed to guar antee democratic procedures in organized labor.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 15 Tom Gorman, America's new est tennis star, and Frank Froehling, making a comeback as an international player, were among six players named to the United States Davis Cup squad today for the last Chal lenge Round here Oct. 8. through 10.

title: CROSWELL BOWEN OF NEW YORKER
description: Croswell Bowen, for many years a staff writer for The New Yorker and an author of books on crime, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 6 East 76th Street. He was 66 years old.

title: U.S. ACTS TO AVERT RAIL STRIKE TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Friday July 16  The Government sought to head off a railroad strike scheduled to begin at 6 o'clock this morning.

title: PENGUIN CLASS SAIL CAPTURED BY REID
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 15 Mel Reid of Setauket, L. I., came through with a first, 12th and a third in that order today and captured the Inter national Penguin Class Dinghy Association senior champion ship.

title: STOCK PRICES SUP AS RALLY FIZZLES
description: A brisk market rally in lead ing issues ran out of fuel yes terday. The DowJones indus trial average, ahead by 4 points at 11 A.M., finished at 888.87 with a loss of 2.34 points.

title: ARMY DECENTRALIZES CONTROL OF TRAINING
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 In a move described as a first priority in the development of an allvolunteer force, the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Wil liam C. Westmoreland, an nounced today a decentral ization of management and control of training in the field.

title: News Analysis
description: Underlying the current drive agdinst obscenity here, with its midManhattan raids, is a tinge of irony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I applaud your June 28 editorial The Paper Jungle. Your criticism of the back office paper mess in Wall Street, the unreliability of the ac counts of many brokerage firms and of their auditors is entirely warranted. Certainly, drastic and immediate changes are essential if we are to have any possibility of avoiding a recur rence of the 1970 crisisprobably with even greater intensity and devastation.

title: PRESIDENT OUSTED AT KINGSBOROUGH
description: Dr. Theodore Powell was dis missed last night as president of the City University's Kings borough Community College, effective immediately.

title: British Welcome Plan
description: LONDON, Friday, July 16 (Reuters)Britain today wel comed the announcement of President Nixon's forthcoming visit to China, which it said it knew about before hand.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEWhen President Nixon gloomily reflected last week on wheth er the United States was destined to emulate ancient Rome and fade away in a welter of decadence, the people of this city were given particular food for thought. For, since the days of its Republican and Caesarian grandeur, Rome has declined with a kind of baroque solemnity and even today is entering on new and perplexing troubles.

title: For Home Chefs
description: In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: NIXON WILL VISIT CHINA BEFORE NEXT MAY TO SEEK A NORMALIZATION OF RELATIONS KISSINGER MET CHOU IN PEKING
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15President Nixon said to night that he would visit China before next May at the invita tion of Premier Chou Enlai to seek the normalization of re lations between the two coun tries and also to exchange views on questions of concern to the two sides.

title: Notes on People
description: Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle, who has headed the Arch diocese of Washington since 1948, has submitted his resig nation to Pope Paul VI, but apparently does not really want to retire.

title: Pentagon Papers Is Selling Quickly Publisher Reports
description: More than a million copies of the paperback edition of The Pentagon Papers are in print, according to Bantam Books, the publisher.

title: HERTZ CUTS RATES FOR SOME RENTALS
description: Hertz Rent A Car, a sub sidiary of the RCA Corporation, announced yesterday that it had lowered rental rates for intermediatesize cars such as the Ford Torinos, Mavericks, Capris and similar sedans.

title: Actor's Wife Slain in Village Apartment
description: A 32yearold woman was found slain in her Greenwich Village apartment last night while her husband was per forming in a play in Central Park.

title: HOUSING PROGRESS CALLED A RECORD
description: Mayor Lindsay visited three pliblic housing projects under construction in two boroughs yesterday, and praised the City Housing Authority for achiev ing a record number of hous ing starts during June.

title: MRS. J. R. BATES HURD
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 15Mrs. Jeanne R. Bates Hurd, secretarytreasurer of Bates As. sociates, preemployment in vestigations, and president of the Westchester Credit Bureau, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. She was 50 years old and lived at 30 Chappaqua Mountain Road, Chappaqua.

title: Dr. Austin H. Schoen, 55, Dies; A Pediatrician and an Author
description: Dr. Austin H. Schoen, senior vice president and director of medical affairs of L. W. Frohlich/Intercon International, Inc., died Wednesday, appar ently of a heart attack, at his home, 100 Victory Boulevard, New Rochelle, N. Y. He was 55 years old.

title: School Administrators Head Urges Change in Licensing Tests to Meet Judge's Objections
description: Walter B. Degnan, president of the council that represents most of the city's 4,000 school administrators, urged yesterday that licensing tests for school supervisors here be revamped to satisfy a Federal judge who banned hundreds of such tests on Wednesday because he said they discriminated against, blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Tyler Blair Weymouth Fiance Of Katherine S. Westmoreland
description: FORT MYER, Va., July 15 Gen. and Mrs. William C. Westmoreland have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kath erine Stevens Westmoreland, to Tyler Blair Weymouth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tyler Wey mouth of New Canaan, Conn.

title: DOLE SAYS TRIALS MIGHT HARM G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Senator Robert Dole, the Re publcan National Chairman, said today that any decision to prosecute criminally the dis tributor of the Pentagon papers or the newspapers that printed them could be politically harm ful to the Republican party.

title: WORD POVERTY FACES U.S. BAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Apparently oblivious to a wave of ridicule that arose over similar effort about a year ago, a Federal interagency commit tee is considering eliminating the word poverty from of ficial reports.

title: Japan's Reserves Expand
description: TOKYO, July 15 (UPI) Japan's gold and foreign cur rency reserves rose to a record of $7.59billion at the end of June, the Finance Ministry re ported today. This was up $683 million from the monthearlier level. Japan had a surplus of $690million in her balance of payments in June.

title: AMPHETAMINE BAN SPREADS IN SUFFOLK
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 15  A voluntary ban by physi cians on the prescribing of am phetamines, begun six weeks ago in the town of Huntington and thought to be the first of its kind in the country, has been extended throughout Suf folk County.

title: LUTHERANS EASE DOCTRINAL STAND
description: MILWAUKEE, July 15Mod erates in the 2.8millionmem ber Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod scored victories on two crucial issues today at a con vention that has pitted them against their president, the Rev. Dr. Jacob A. O. Preus, and his conservative supporters.

title: DOCTOR'S OUSTER IRKS RIGHTS UNIT
description: The city's Human Rights Commission yesterday crit cized all parties concerned in the removal of Dr. Arnold H. Einhorn as chief of pediatrics at Lincoln Hospital, last Novem ber, but concluded that his re moval had not been made be cause of ethnic discrimination.

title: Argentina Denies Dropping, Claim to Falkland lslands
description: LONDON, July 15 (AP) The Foreign Office says Argen tina has not relinquished her claim to sovereignty over the Falkland Islands. This clarified a statement by a Foreign Of fice spokesman July 2 to the effect that Argentina was giv ing up her 139yearold claim to the islands.

title: Benelux Trade Pact With Soviet Marks A Shift by Moscow
description: PARIS, July 15The Bene lux countries  Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have signed a trade treaty with the Soviet Union that could help break down bar riers between the Soviet Union and the Common Market.

title: G.O.P. Congressmen Win in Baseball, 73
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 For the eighth straight year, the Republican Elephants to night trounced the Demo cratic Donkeys in the annual Congressional baseball game, held at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: ROBERT SPITZER
description: Robert Spitzer, senior partner in the New York Stock Ex change firm of Spitzer & Co., died Tuesday night at his home, 35 East 84th Street at the age of 67.

title: Laos: One Day the Airplanes Came
description: WASHINGTONIn December, 1970, sev eral dozen victims of the fullest automated war of our time were asked to record their memories in drawings. They were Laotian refugees from the devastated Plaine des Jarres in northeast ern Laos who were at that time residing in camps around Vientiane.

title: Seaport Museum Shows Old Merchantman's Gear
description: The South Street Seaport Mu seum put on public display yesterday 14 tons of gearin cluding a windlass, a capstan and davitsthat will be used in the restoration of the steel hulled squarerigger Wavertree.

title: 18 NATIONS ASK U.N. TO SEAT RED CHINA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15  Eighteen of Peking's sup porters called today for the General Assembly to recognize Communist China, this fall as one of the Big Five powers in the Security Council and to expel Nationalist China from all United Nations bodies.

title: Monsanto's Profit Up 10%
description: The Monsanto Company re ported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter rose 10 per cent while sales grew 3 per cent.

title: WALLACE IN SPLIT WITH A TOP AIDE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 15Gov. George C. Wallace's political problems at home were intensified this week by a break between the Governor and his Lieutenant Governor, Jere Beasley.

title: CONCERNS OPPOSE STOCKFEE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15A group of officials of some of the nation's largest corpora tions expressed opposition to day to proposed increases in the sales commissions charged by member brokers of the New York Stock Exchange. In ad dition, they sharply criticized the way the exchange is run and what they called its failure to modernize its procedures.

title: Albatross Seeks 2d Leg of Pacing Triple Crown Tonight
description: YONKERS, July 15Alba tross, a 3yearold pacer Stan ley Dancer believes may turn out to be the best ever, will seek his ninth straight victory and 10th in 11 starts this sea son in the 17th annual Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway to morrow night.

title: Unsanitary Restaurants To Be Identified by City
description: The City Health Department, reversing a longstanding pol icy, has decided to make public the names of restaurants that do not promptly correct vio lations of the Health Code.

title: Texas Oil Output Will Fall in August
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 15 Texas oil production will de cline a bit further in August. Today's proration hearing noted lessened demand in evi dence submitted by the pur chasing companies.

title: House Unit Disdoses Civilian Killings in U.S.Backed Program
description: WASHINGTON, July 15  Previously classified informa tion read into the record of a House Government Operations subcommittee today disclosed that 26,843 nonmilitary Viet cong insurgents and sympa thizers were neutralized in 14 months through Operation Phoenix, a counterinsurgency program in South Vietnam fi nanced by the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Three people have drowned at Jones and Robert Moses Beaches as the Long Island State Park Commission contin ues to spend over $160,000 per week in police personnel and equipment, rather than rehire all the qualified life guards.

title: Journey for Peace
description: President Nixon's announcement last night that Henry Kissinger had visited Peking would have been sensation enough, but the President's revelation that he himself has been invited to Peking by Premier Chou Enlai and that he has accepted that invitation is simply astounding. A few months ago, it was considered remarkable that the Chinese invited an American PingPong team to their country with American reporters accompanying it. Now a great leap forward has been made from PingPong diplomacy to preparations for a SinoAmerican summit meeting. It is a dizzying performance, given the extreme hostility of ChineseAmerican relations even since 1950.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Writing as a proArab organization's executive member, James Jones (letter, July 7) boasts of an attack last month against a tanker bound for Israel, pre dicting a Red Sea closed to nonArab shipping  a closed sea (mare clausum). All this would stem, he claims, from the foolishness of our Government's support of Israel.

title: Rules on Capital Structure Revised by the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced major re visions last night in the rules governing the financial struc ture of its member firms.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: TORONTO, July 15 (Canadian Press)The Ontario Securities Commission today extended 15day trading ban on shares of I.O.S., Ltd., to July 27, when it will hold another hearing to de termine whether trading should be resumed.

title: Magoon Captures Hennessy Grand Prix Motorboat Race for 2d Time
description: POINT PLEASANT, N. J., July 15  Bob Magoon of Miami Beach, who won last year's race on a fluke, proved that he had the fastest boat in a starstudded fleet today by winning the Hennessy Grand Prix. He led from the start.

title: Franco Decree on Successor
description: MADRID, Friday, July 16 (Reuters)Generalissimo Fran cisco Franco published a decree today making arrangements for Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, Kingdesignate of Spain, to act as head of state if Generalis simo Franco becomes ill.

title: Snell's Ambition Is to Regain His Jet Propulsion
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 15 In his gray sweat suit, Matt Snell watched as the New York Jets ran through their offensive plays.

title: Patman Qualifies Support for Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Bank ing and Currency Committee, said today he would vote for the Administration's bill to guarantee loans to the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation if the committee decided action was vital before Aug. 6 to save the company from bankruptcy.

title: ROSEWALL RALLY CONQUERS LAYER
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) Ken Rosewall, playing bril liantly at the age of 36, de feated Rod Laver, 57, 63 61, today to advance to the quar terfinals of the $50,000 Wash ington Star tennis tournament.

title: Market Place:
description: When Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith's ini tial public offering was de voured by hungry investors last month, everyone as sumed the floodgates were open for a spate of other brokeragehouse issues.

title: Thant Sees a New Era In International Affairs
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, July 15  Secretary General Thant welcomed President Nixon's announce ment tonight that he would visit China as opening a new chapter in the history of international relations.

title: Advertising:
description: The publisher of TimeLife Books has become the first woman vice president in the 48 years of Time Inc. She is Miss Joan Manley, 39 years old, who last year became the corporation's first pub lisher.

title: BLACKS CLOSE GAPS IN A SOCIAL SURVEY
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) Blacks were catching up with whites in some economic and social areas in the United States between 1960 and 1968, but fell further behind in sev eral key measurements of in come and family life, a Govern mentfinanced study showed today.

title: Jordan Reports Dislodging Guerrillas in Clashes
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 15 As Jordanian troops battled Arab commandos today for the third day, a Government spokesman announced that the army had dislodged the guer rillas from a dozen sites in the AjlunJarash area of northern Jordan.

title: A New R.F.C.?
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, on the verge bankruptcy as a result of huge cost overruns on military programs and delays in building its L1011 Tristar airbus for commercial airlines, says that nothing can save it but a Government loan guarantee of $250 million. Powerful pressures are being brought to bear on Congress to grant this loan guarantee.

title: WAGONER'S JULY 13 IS GIVEN A PREMIERE
description: Dan Wagoner's sense of fun ripples happily from the Dada calculated lunacy of Bram bles to the friendly move ment humor of July 13, his newest group work. The piece was given its premiere funnily enough on July 14 at the New York University School of Ed ucation and is a warm sportive dance for himself, Miriam Berns, Cathy Boyd, Emmy De vine, Sally Hess and Judith Moss.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Bowery Savings Bank announced yester day the election of Miss Dolores 3. Morrissey as vice president in charge of the bank's bond port folio and money position. She will be the bank's first woman vice presi dent. Miss Morrissey, a native New Yorker, joined the nations larg est savings bank in 1948 and continued her edu cation as she moved through the ranks. In 1968 she received her master's degree in in vestments from the Grad uate School of Business Administration of New York University. She was mane an assistant treasurer in 1968, and as sistant vice president in 1969. In announcing her promotion, Morris D. Crawford Jr., chairman, said Miss Morrissey has done an outstanding job in the management of the Bank's bond portfolio and short term investments. Moreover, she is quite knowl edgeable about many other phases of the Bank's operations.

title: Miss Gargan, Thomas G. King To Be Married
description: NORWELL, Mass., July 15 Miss Ann Gargan, a cousin of the late President Ken nedy, who was nurse and companion to her uncle, Jo seph P. Kennedy, from the time of his stroke in 1961 un til his death in 1969, plans to marry an airline execu tive. He is Thomas G. King of Quincy, the British Over seas Airways Corporation station manager at Logan Airport in Boston.

title: GEORGE HIGGINS, 47, OF CHRYSLER, DEAD
description: BETHESDA, Md., July 15 George T. Higgins, director of the Chrysler Corporation's Washington public relations of fice and former secretary of the corporation, died of a cerebral hemorrhage last night. He was 47 years old and lived at 5 Kittery Court.

title: G.M.Isuzu Accord Signed
description: TOKYO& Friday, July 16 (Reuters)The General Corpor ation signed an agreement to day on a capital and business tieup with Isuzu Motors, Ltd., a Japanese motor company, to move into the local car market. Japanese Government approval is expected i August or Sep tember. Under the agreement, G.M. will own a 34.2 per cent interest in equity of the Japa nese concern, Isuzu Motors said.

title: I.0.S. DENIES KNOWING OF VESCO INJUNCTION
description: GENEVA, July 15The em battled management of In vestors Overseas Services dis claimed tonight all direct knowledge of a Canadian court injunction temporarily barring Robert L. Vesco from playing any role in the troubled finan cial empire's affairs.

title: TOM HE IS DEAD; DESIGNER WAS 61
description: Tom Lee, a leading interior and industrial designer, died Wednesday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Lee was injured in an automobile acci dent in Greenwich on July 4. He was 61 years old and lived at 455 East 51st Street and at 625 North Street, Greenwich.

title: List of Road Bottlenecks
description: Motorists driving in and out of the metropolitan area this weekend may encounter delays because of construc tion work at the following points listed by the Automobile Club of New York:

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Co lonialism10:30 A.M.

title: DR. W. HAROLD ROW, CAPITAL CHURCHMAN
description: The Rev. Dr. W. Harold Row, head of the Washington office of the Church of the Brethren and executive of the denomi nations committee on inter church relations, died Wednes day of cancer in Washington. He was 59 years old.

title: Bridge: Summer National Tourney To Open in Chicago Today
description: CHICAGO, July 15  En thusiasts from all parts of North America are converg ing on this city to compete in what promises to be the biggest bridge tournament ever held anywhere. It is the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships, which begin here tomorrow and continue for 10 days.

title: CITY IS UNAFFECTED BY PHONE WALKOUT
description: Local, interstate and over seas telephone service func tioned here normally yester day despite a nationwide strike against the Bell System by 400,000 members of the Com munications Workers of Amer ica.

title: Multiple Bets Off Slowly, But Samuels Is Optimistic
description: Displaying that curious mixture of anger and resig nation that characterizes the horseplayer, New Yorkers got their first chance yester day to make a full range of wagering on the flats at nine of the city's 13 offtrack betting offices.

title: Credit Markets: Prices Hold Steady
description: Newswire accounts of United States proposal for Vietnam ceasefire lifted some bond prices early yesterday but most later settled back to levels reflecting little or no gain.

title: POLICE INVESTIGATE CHARGE OF PAYOFFS
description: The Police Department's Internal Affairs Division is in vestigating allegations by a former policeman dismissed for accepting a $100 bribe that it is a common practice for Harlem policemen to accept illegal pay offs from heroin dealers.

title: U.S. War Dead Listed At 29 in Week's Report
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP)  The allied commands today issued cas ualty summaries for last week listing 29 Americans, 238 South Vietnamese and 1,105 North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops as killed in action.

title: U.S. SORRY ICELAND PLANS TO SHUT BASE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (Reuters)The State Depart ment expressed regret today over yesterday's announcement by the new leftwing Icelandic Government that it planned to close down the American manned Atlanticalliance base at Keflavik.

title: SENATE REJECTS FARM SUBSIDY CUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 The Senate, acceding to Ad ministration wishes, refused today to accept a Houseap proved limitation of $20,000 on subsidy payments to individual farmers.

title: Shop Talk
description: After a few faltering starts Biedermeier may indeed gain a foothold this year in the collecting enthusiams of New Yorkers. Or so Macy's hopes in what is the store's third attempt in a decade to revive the early 19thcentury neoclassic style with a large group of German and Austrian examples of the mode. The quality is, in some cases, ex cellent. The prices are, as antiques of that era go today at auc tion, moderate. And that in cludes console and drum tables at $399, a tambour doored commode at $699, a tall, glassdoored vitrine at $1,200, a dining table made up of the top from one table and base from another at $1,500 and a daybed at $1,500. These designs, now being shown in the ninth floor Corner Shop as part of the store's July furniture show, seem more fashionable in their chunky silhouettes and pale finishes than ever before.

title: Mills Would Tie Revenue Sharing to Need for It
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed today that the form of revenue sharing that he is thinking of supporting would involve financial aid only to those cities and counties that could prove their need for it.

title: MEXICO JOINS FIGHT ON HORSE SICKNESS
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., July 15 (UPI)  Mexico joined Texas today to fight an equine sleep ing sickness epidemic that has killed more than 6,000 horses and made at least 1,000 per sons ill. Unofficial reports said the disease had killed three Mexican children.

title: Yanks Lose on May's Clout in 9th, 10;
description: Dave Maynot to be con fused with Carlos, Lee, Jerry or Rudy Mayhas hit three ninthinning home runs in Mil waukee's five games at Yankee Stadium this season. The first two spoiled shutouts for Steve Kline and Mel Stottlemyre.

title: The Holdup Victim Is Often a Little Boy and the Loss a Bicycle
description: For any little boy just old enough to venture out by himself, any sortie into the streets of Manhattan can be disaster.

title: BRUCE SAYS ENEMY SETS HARSH TERMS
description: PARIS, July. 15  David K. E. Bruce, the United States rep resentative at the Vietnam peace talks, told the Commu nists today that their latest pro posal for a settlement left their objectives unchanged and set farreaching and harsh conditions.

title: Man in the News
description: When a South Vietnamese lawyer who heads a small antiwar movement scheduled a reception in Saigon recent ly, the police kept all but one of the guests from entering.

title: Supply of Money Surges Despite Tightening Goal
description: The nation's money supply spurted during the week ended July 7, the Federal Reserve Sys tem reported yesterday. The increase of $3.2billion to a daily average of $228.4billion came despite the efforts of the central bank to tighten the money market so as to slow the rate of monetary expansion.

title: Treasury Terms Gold Trade lllegal; Exchange Balks
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The Treasury Department said today the West Coast Commodity Exchange's plan for trading in gold futures is il legal and will not be pertnitted to operate.

title: Ellsberg Obtains Delay on Coast Trial
description: BOSTON, July 15Issuance, of an order requiring Dr. Daniel Ellsberg to go to Los Angeles to stand trial in connection with the Pentagon papers was put off for at least eight days today as his lawyers sought to show that the Government's case against him was based on illegal wiretap evidence.

title: LARCHNIONT WEEK OPENS TO SENIORS
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 15 The senior sailors, returning to Larchmont Yacht Club's 73d Race Week after three days devoted to the juniors, finally got some favorable weather on Long Island Sound today.

title: Breach of Contract On U.S. Film Import Charged in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 15 (AP) Foreign Trade Minister I. N. Mishra complained in Parlia ment yesterday that the Motion Pictures Export Association of America had not kept the terms of its contract to popu larize Indian films in the United States.

title: URUGUAY'S CONGRESS DEFIED ON SECURITY
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 15 (AP)  The Cabinet of Pres ident Jorge Pacheo Areco re imposed the country's special security laws today, less than 24 hours after Congress had voted to repeal them.

title: Merger News
description: Trafalgar House Investments, Ltd., announced yesterday in London that its bid terms for acquisition of the Cunard SteamShip Company, Ltd., were equal to 200 pence, or about $4.80 a share. Based on a total of 13 million ordinary shares outstanding and after deducting the more than 2.75 million shares already owned by Trafalgar, the offer would be valued at more than $49million.

title: Saigon Reaction
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, July 16 (Reuters)Presi dent Nixon's announcement was generally well received by South Vietnamese politicians here today although there was no official comment from the Government.

title: HOUSE GROUP BIDS U.S. STOP AIDING GREECE, PAKISTAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 The House Foreign Affairs Com mittee voted today in favor of proposals to withhold military and economic assistance from Pakistan and Greece.

title: Advertising:
description: John Mack Carter, presi dent of Downe Publishing, confirmed yesterday that he had devised a special circu lation plan for American Home magazine, which is designed to build up urban readership while cutting down on the rural.

title: Transcript of Nixon TV Address to Nation
description: Following is the transcript of a state ment yesterday by President Nixon on United StatesChina relations as re corded by The New York Times:

title: Foster Parents Face Order
description: The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday issued an order directing a Massapequa, L. I., couple to show cause why they should not be held in contempt for disregarding a court order to return their 3yearold foster daughter to an adoption agency. The couple, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Polk, were reported to have vanished from their home with the child after being instructed by the State Court of Appeals to return her to the Spence Chapin Adoption Agency.

title: Tension Grows at Newton Trial; Policemen Stationed in Court
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 15 The atmosphere at the retrial of Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, has turned tense and angry.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I'm glad to see that New Jersey is more progressive than Massachusetts in some ways. Referring to your July 7 article on Sharon's Brief Baseball Career , I was the first and only girl on the boys Little League team in Long Branch in 1956. My position was second base, and the highlight of my career was hitting a basesloaded home run off the town bully. There was, of course, much opposition to me, but nothing was done (that year) to evict me from the team. By the next year, however, all Little League rules were changed to begin with the phrase, All boys who.

title: Black Lung Bill Moved
description: WASHINGTON, (AP)Sena tor Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, introduced today a bill to give black lung victims full disability benefits if they are unable to continue working as coal miners.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES BIG FUND INCREASES
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  The Senate Appropriations Committee voted major in creases today over President Nixon's budget recommenda tions for urban housing and veterans medical care.

title: Amex Prices End Day Steady as Trading Gains
description: Although volume was higher, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed unchanged yesterday.

title: LOUISE BERNHARDT
description: Louise Bernhardt, a former contralto with the Chicago Civic Opera and the American Opera Company, died July 9 in Ojai, Calif. In private life she was Mrs. H. Stanley Hillyer, the widow of a New. York real tor.

title: I Like the Food, Nixon Says
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 (Reuters)  President Nixon said tonight after the an nouncement of his plan to visit China that his reasons for going were gastronomic. In his only reference to the rip when he spoke to reporters after his television broadcast, he quipped I like the food.

title: New Beat Is Heard At the Brill Building
description: I remember when you'd bust a gut to have Kate Smith introduce one of your songs on her show. Now it's a record or nothing.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When they begin practicing tomorrow at Trenton Speedway for Sunday's Northern 300, drivers and mechanics of the country's best stockcar teams will be searching for some esoteric little secret to give them some advantage. Often it is something trivial, but many of these Southern crews treat it seriously until it is tried and dropped. This secret in stockcar racing is called the tip.

title: Israel Reports Killing Six In Arab Guerrilla Band
description: TEL AVIV, July 15The Is raeli Army said today that six members of an Arab guerrilla band who were reported to, have fired rockets into Petah Tiqva last week were killed last night in an encounter with Israeli soldiers. A seventh mem ber was reported to have es caped into Jordanian territory.

title: Subversive Control Unit Gets Wider Role
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The Nixon Administration has moved to strengthen the Subversive Activities Control Board which has been under fire for lack of work, it was learned today.

title: Minh Charges U.S. Gives Election Help to Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP)  Gen. Duong Van Minh, a possible contender for the Presidency of South Vietnam, charged today that American support of President Nguyen Van Thieu could pre vent a fair and honest elec tion on Oct. 3.

title: SEXSHOW RAIDS TO CONTINUE HERE
description: The Police Departmen* cold yesterday that it would con tinue to raid sex shows in the Times Square and Greenwich Village areas as part of its crackdown on prostitution and pornography.

title: JEWISH PROTESTERS ARRESTED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, July 15 (AP)The police early today arrested 45 Jews who had been holding hunger strike in Moscow's cen tral telegraph office, Jewish sources reported.

title: News Analysis
description: President Nixon, in his jour ney for peace to Peking, will seek to break down a great wall of hostility that has separated the United States from Communist China for 21 years. His task will not be an easy one.

title: Robert M. Kirk Dead at 56; Consultant on Chemicals
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 15 Robert M. Kirk, a consultant to the chemical industry, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived on East Rocks Road.

title: W. J. Chiego Jr. Marries Miss Lee
description: Miss Elizabeth Kimball Lee, daughter of Dr. Sherman Lee, director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, and Mrs. Lee of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married in Paris on Tues day to William Joseph Chiego Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chi ego of Spring Lake Heights, N. J. Abbe Saint Pierre per formed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Eglise Saint Germain des Pres.

title: Saigon Ends Fruitless Drive in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 16 (AP)  Two thirds of a 1,500man South Vietnamese task force pulled back to South Vietnam yester day from a fruitless, oneWeek drive into eastern Cambodia.

title: 363674 Wins in Jersey
description: EATONTOWN, N. J., July 15 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery is 363674.

title: Jobless Veterans Up Compared With 1970
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Department of Labor statis tics released today show that unemployment among Viet nam veterans aged 20 to 29 increased substantially in the second quarter of 1971 over the same period last year. However, there was a de crease from earlier this year.

title: Italian League's Newark Office Destroyed in Fire
description: NEWARK, July 15The weekold office of the Newark chapter of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League was de stroyed by fire early today.

title: Commodity Price Index Slips 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials slipped to 108.2 from 108.6 last week.

title: AMYUIT L. WILSON
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 15 Amyuit L. Wilson, an engineer and former Superintendent of the Power Division of the Bay way Refinery of the Standard Oil Company in Linden, died today in the Elizabeth General Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 921 Park Avenue here.

title: Hardly Out of Pinafores, She's Into Designing
description: Penny Payne's earliest me mories are of watching her mother, Mrs. Frank J. Payne, at work as a dress designer and trying to imitate her.

title: Kissinger Visit Capped 2Year Effort
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Henry A. Kissinger's secret visit to Peking last week, announced tonight by President Nixon, capped two years of overtures by the United States to China, based on the President's con viction that Peking must be come a fullfledged member of the international community.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Msgr. John M. Oesterreicher objects (letter July 6) that I failed to offer a single argument regarding his May 26 OpEd item on Jerusalem. My re sponse of June 25 was indeed a broad indictment of manifold violations against the Geneva Conventions.

title: LINDSEY SPIGHT, 68, BROADCAST OFFICIAL
description: Lindsey Hill Spight, a found er of the broadcast representa tion firm of Greig, Blair & Spight, predecessor of John Blair & Co., died Monday in Orinda, Calif. His age was 68.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Our Mayor John Lindsay now pro poses a massive program to diminish noise in dear old Fun City. This comes as a disappointment when we recall how Mr. Lindsay at the start of his term as Mayor jettisoned a New York City Code  initiated during Mayor Wagner's incumbency  to prohibit blowing of automobile horns. During the end of his term this ordinance was effective and auto horns were rarely heard.

title: What Price Transit?
description: New Yorkers will be given a Hobson's choice later the year in the form of a transportation referendum with out alternatives. If they want to approve a bond issue, they will have to sanction a split that apportions $1.35 billion for mass transit but $1.15 billion for highways. A voter may feel that the former is a dire necessity and the latter a largely wasteful blight on the land, but he will have to take both or neither.

title: Mets Rally for 94 Victory Over Astros
description: HOUSTON, July 15  Over coming a discouraging start, which found them four runs behind in the first two innings the New York Mets struck back and ended their sixgame losing streak tonight by beat ing the Houston Astros, 94.

title: Hughes Quits as Presidential Aspirant
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Senator Harold E. Hughes of Iowa withdrew from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today after having implied to his staff that he would not be displeased if they went to work for Senator George McGovern of South Da kota.

title: For Those Who Like to Dine Where the Ballplayers Dine
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmos phere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Airline Incorrectly Identified In a Dispatch About Pakistan
description: World Airways, a supple mental airline, was identified incorrectly in an article about Pakistan in The New York Times Wednesday as being Irishowned; it is a United States corporation.

title: Bayonne Oil Washes Up on Coney Island Beach
description: Thick, sticky oil was washed up on the Coney Island beach last night from Bayonne, N. J., and on other city beaches where nearly 40,000 gallons of oil spilled from a Navy ship on Wednesday.

title: KENNEDY RETURNS AS TEXTILE ENVOY
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15David M. Kennedy, Presi dent Nixon's roving am bassador, returned today from an extended trip to the Far East. He will report to the President tomorrow on his ef forts to obtain voluntary re straints from South Korea, Tai wan and Hong Kong on textile exports to the United States.

title: Text of Statement by Bruce at Peace Talks in Paris
description: PARIS, July 15Following is the text of the opening re marks today by David K. E. Bruce, the United States dele gate, at the 121st plenary session of the Paris meet ings on Vietnam:

title: Medical Training Bills Set for Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Senate and House versions of a major financial program to help train doctors and other health professionals will go to a con ference committee, perhaps next week, following passage of two Senate bills yesterday.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE APPROVES A RISE IN DISCOUNT RATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Federal Reserve Board ap proved today an increase in the discount rate to 5 per cent from 43% per cent.

title: 2,500 Walk to the Street in the First Fire Drill in a Skyscraper Here
description: At 10:35 A.M. yesterday, to the imperative sound of alarm bells and klaxons, 2,500 occupants of the 38 story Seagram Building be gan filing out of their offices.

title: Lowery Assails Penn Central and L.I.R. for Failing to Report Fire
description: Fire Commissioner Robert 0. Lowery criticized the Long Is land and the Penn Central rail roads yesterday for having failed to notify the Fire Depart ment of an electrical fire in an East River tunnet on Wednes day.

title: Chicago Bank Enters Geneva Special to The Now
description: GENEVA, July 15The First National Bank of Chicago's, office here, its first In Switzer land, was opened today by Edward F. Blettner, vice chair man.

title: Von Ruden Runs 3:58.9
description: TURKU, Finland, July 15 (AP)Toni Von Ruden, former ly of Oklahoma State, ran mile in 3 minutes 58.9 seconds tonight to beat John Mason of Emporia (Kan.) State by tenth of a second.

title: Congress Chiefs Pleased;
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Members of Congress re acted with surprise and ap proval to President Nixon's announcement tonight that he had accepted an invitation to visit China.

title: Price Rises Seen For Natural Gas After F.PC. Move
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 The Federal Power Commis sion established today substan tially higher rates for natural gas produced in the Rocky Mountain region in a decision that may presage higher gas prices for consumers through out the country.

title: Brady Leaving Women's Wear
description: James W. Brady, publisher of Women's Wear Daily, re signed yesterday to become a vice president of the Hearst Corporation.

title: Protasis, $57.80, Is Victor; Claim of Foul Disallowed
description: Protasis was the star of the show in the Queens County Chamber of Commerce purse at Aqueduct yesterday. Under the guidance of Chuck Baltazar, the Cragwood Stable filly took the sixfurlong test for 3yearolds by half a length over Sigmund Sommer's Sky Play.

title: Health of Nation Lags Behind Scientific Gains.
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 American medical science has made spectacular advances in the last quartercentury, but improvements in the overall American death rate and the infant and maternal mortality rates have leveled off and the United States still lags behind many other nations.

title: Quake Jolts Northern Italy; Two Die of Heart Seizures
description: PARMA, Italy, July 15 (AP) Much of Italy's industrial north, in a triangle from Genoa to Florence to Venice, was jolted by a strong earthquake early today. Two persons died of heart attacks.

title: Plastic Makers Sue City Over Tax on Containers
description: The manufacturers of plas tic products and their trade association sued in State Sup reme Court yesterday to bar New York City from levying a special 2cent tax on most plastic containers sold here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your July 8 editorial states that it should not be necessary for a judge to deny bail to a woman charged with prostitution. I am surprised that you do not point out that such judicial conduct is not merely unnecessary, it is unconstitutional. It is no excuse that the judge was, as you put it, desperate. Desperation is hardly a desirable attribute of judicial tempera ment. It is bad enough that the, oppres sive, elitist and sexist society in which we live generates the conditions against which you so feverishly com plain; it is doubly offensive when a judicial officer flouts the Constitution in the name of that society, thus high lighting the high place our judicial system holds in the list of evils.

title: jersey Central and Unions Scrap Rules
description: NEWARK, July 15 The bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey and all the unions that represent its employes agreed today to scrap the old bible of work rules in an ef fort to save the ailing carrier, which has lost $100million in the last 12 years.

title: Gregory, Nagy Dance in Fallen Idol
description: Some very good ballets danced less well than usual and a minor work that gained enormously from its excellent performance, made up Ameri can Ballet Theater's newest mixed bill of the season Wednesday night at the State Theater.

title: Alcoa Net Declines 23.9%;
description: Higher costs and lower prices reduced profits of the Alum inum Company of America by 23.9 per cent in the second quarter and 33.2 per cent in the half.

title: Giants Gets 49ers Lakes To Bolster Front Four
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 15  Influenced by Jerry Shay's slow recovery from a severely broken right leg last season, the Giants acquired an experienced defensive tackle, Roland Lakes, from the San Francisco 49ers today in exchange for their No. 2 choice in the 1973 college draft.

title: Canadian Gallery Show Strikes Nationalist Note
description: OTTAWACanadian art has struck a nationalist note here with an exhibition in the National Gallery of Can ada called True Patriot Love.

title: Chile Is Buying Out 2 Foreign Banks; Copper Law Signed
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 15 The Chilean Central Bank announced today that two large foreign banksthe Bank of America and the Bank of London and South Americahad agreed to sell their operations here to the nationalized banking system.

title: 3 Killed on Norwegian Tanker
description: OSLO, Norway, July 15 (UPI)  An explosion rocked the 219,000ton Norwegian tanker Aurelian in the Persian Gulf yesterday, killing three persons aboard and wounding a fourth, the ship's owners said today.

title: MARKET SURGES, THEN FALLS BACK
description: The stock market responded early yesterday with a flurry of buying to President Nixon's surprise announcement that he will visit China before next. May.

title: Jones & Laughlin Net Up
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, the first major company in the industry to is sue midyear results, had its best profit performance in the second quarter and first half in five years, according to yester day's report.

title: MRS. THOMAS PAPPAS
description: BOSTON, July 16 (AP)Mrs. Bessie Pappas, wife of Thomas A. Pappas, a GreekAmerican steel figure, who has been prominent in Republican cir cles, died Thursday at a hos pital in Cambridge. Her age was 62.

title: Light at the Edge of the World'
description: "The Light at the Edge of the World," which was switched on in various colors at local theaters yesterday, casts a weak light and considerable heat on a clutch of abnormal principals, who, it eventually turns out, didn't really deserve all that attention. As a period adventure culled from Jules Verne about a harried lighthouse keeper and a bloodthirsty band of ship wreckers out to destroy him, it is short on full explanations and long on aimless sound and fury.Program notes indicate that it takes place in 1865 on a craggy point at Cape Horn. Kirk Douglas, as a bearded, disenchanted, expatriate American with a vaguely spotted past, is the only witness to the murder, by invading wrecker-pirates, of Fernando Rey, the chief lighthouse man, and Massimo Ranieri, his other assistant. So, Yul Brynner, the vicious but sybaritic captain of the marauders, keeps chasing the tortured hero, whose will to survive such ersatz and gory circumstances is admirable."Every ship that passes must pay tribute to me." Brynner declares imperiously at one point. He seems to have done well, what with such spoils as an Arab stallion he uses to pursue Douglas; Samantha Eggar, whom he's plucked off a wrecked packet; a fur-lined kaftan I wears like a Mongol chief tain; paintings, silverwar and fine wines captured by wild, motley crew almost weird as their glowering captain.Kevin Billington, a comparative newcomer from Britain, unfortunately generate little excitement in direction these lurid goings-on in Spain Perhaps, like this viewer, was affected by Douglas who, long before he did patches Brynner in a field climax, says prophetical. "Sometimes my heart is it, in this work."

title: Agnew Confers With Mobutu in Congo
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, July 16Vice President Agnew, end ing the African phase of his world tour, conferred privately for 90 minutes today with Pres ident Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo and then continued the talk at a luncheon in a thatched roof but with a sweeping view of the Congo River.

title: PEKING SEAT IN U.N. EXPECTED IN FALL
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Some diplomats here and in the United Nations predicted today that Peking would obtain admission to the United Nations this fall, replacing the Chinese Nationalists.

title: Helen Hull, Author of 20 Novels And Columbia Professor, Dies
description: Helen Hull, the author of 20 novels, who was emeritus pro fessor of English at Columbia University, died Thursday in St. Barnabas Hospital. She was 83 years old and lived at 872 West End Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Tom Wicker's almost savage reply to Dean Acheson's remarks on The Times publication of the Pentagon papers suggests that Mr. Acheson has struck a nerve when he wonders why the papers weren't returned to their owner as stolen goods.

title: Private Charged in Killing Of Two Officers in Vietnam
description: FORT ORD, Calif., July 16 (UPI)  An Army private has been charged with the murder of two lieutenants and the at tempted murder of three other officers in Vietnam.

title: The Talk of Lakenheath
description: LAKENHEATH, England, July 16On the sprawling United States Air Force Base here, the trial of Capt. Thomas S. Culver was barely overshadowed this week by a widely anticipated and ea gerly discussed event: the opening of the new swim ming pool.

title: Grambling Ace Shows Heels for Giants
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 16Coleman Zeno was a little nervous about reporting to the New York Giants training camp but when he discovered it wasn't as ardu bus as the Grambling College camp, he settled down.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 16Foreign Minister Mahmoud Riad of Egypt said here today that the proposals for a Middle East armistice presented to his Government on May 23 by Don ald C. Bergus, the senior United States diplomat in Cairo, had been formulated by the State Department and did not rep resent an individual initiative by Mr. Bergus.

title: Caterpillar Lifts Profit;
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Com pany, the nation's leading manufacturer of earthmoving machinery and a major pro ducer of diesel engines and electricgenerator sets, had an increase of nine per cent in profit for the second quarter and 7.52 per cent for the first half, it was reported yesterday from Peoria, Ill., headquarters. Sales for these periods set records.

title: 3.67, CAIN IN G.N.P. FOR THE QUARTER 2D BEST SINCE 68
description: WASHINGTON, July 16A steady, but not rapid, recovery of the economy from the 19701 recession was confirmed today by the Government's most com prehensive measurethe Gross National Product.

title: Edgar Snow Sees End of Dulles Ghost Policy
description: GENEVA, July 16Edgar Snow, the American writer who has visited Communist China regularly over the years, said in a statement today on President Nixon's plan to visit China that we are witnessing the liquida tion of two decades of a U.S. East Asian policy dominated by the ghost of John Foster Dulles.

title: Nationalist Chinese React With Dismay to Nixon's Decision
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 16 Chinese in influential Govern ment and business circles here at first reacted with disbelief to President Nixon's announce ment that he would visit Com munist China and then with dismay.

title: Dr. Oswald La Rotonda Dead; Aide at St. Vincent's 50 Years
description: Dr. Oswald La Rotonda, di rector emeritus of medicine at St. Vincent's Hospital and Med ical Center, died at the hospital Thursday night after a long ill ness. He was 79 years old.

title: Hardin Calls Spread of Horse Disease an Emergency
description: About 152,000 of the esti mated 400,000 horses, mules and donkeys in Texas had been inoculated through today with an experimental vaccine de veloped for the Army. The Agriculture Department said that other supplies of vaccine would be sent to Texas to inoculate every equine animal in the state.

title: Bridge:
description: CHICAGO, July 16The Summer National Champion ships of the American Con tract Bridge League began here today with nearly all the country's top  ranked players embarked on 10 days of fiercely competitive play. The opening event was the foursession master mixed team championship, in which the defending champions are Lew and Eugenie Mathe and Gerald and Dorothy Bare, all of Los Angeles.

title: Big Board Alleges Extra Payments To Broker's Staff
description: The New York Stock Ex change alleged yesterday that several employes of the First Devonshire Corporation, a former member firm now in liquidation, had been accept ing payments from customers and registered representatives for favored treatment of their accounts.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: TIDES PUT NEW OIL ON BEACH AT CONEY
description: Although weary city workers cleared Coney Island of an oil spillage yesterday morning, in coming tides and unfavorable winds dumped so much more oil on the beach later in the day that it will probably be closed to swimmers again today.

title: Bar Speakers Critical of Warren Court
description: LONDON, July 16Ameri can and British speakers at the American Bar Association con vention criticized today some of the key safeguards for criminal suspects established during the nineteensixties by the Warren Court.

title: Miss Bellwood Takes Role
description: Pamella Bellwood will take over the role of Jil Tanner, the wouldbe actress in Butterflies Are Free, Monday night at the Booth Theater. She will replace Kathleen Miller in the Leonard Gershe comedy, which costars Rosemary Murphy and Kipp Osborne.

title: U.S.Japan Textile Deals Urged
description: American apparel manu facturers will ultimately be unable to win the battle against Japanese imports and would be better advised to begin setting up Japanese li censing agreements and joint ventures to cash in on a big potential in Japan, according to an industrial engineer who has spent much time in the Orient.

title: SPACE NATIONS SET BROADCASTING RULES
description: GENEVA, July 16 The International Telecommu nication Union has expanded its regulatory role into new fields of space communications by making provisions for the use of satellites for broadcast ing television programs and for keeping watch on the earth's natural resources.

title: Yankee Tootle Dandy Fete
description: MARLBOROUGH, Conn., July 16In the early evening the rattling drums and the shrill fifes had been distinct and moving. But now there were perhaps 100 drummers hammering away and a score or so fifers blowing their hardest, and the sound was deafeningan artillery bar rage with crickets.

title: Tribe Lowers Voting Age
description: TULSA, Okla., July 16 (UPI) The Choctaw Indian nation election committee said today that it had voted to let 18, 19 and 20yearolds take part in tribal elections next month. The Indians will be voting for the first time in 50 years for a chief. Previously, the chief was appointed by the Federal Gov ernment. The Choctaws are the first Indian tribe to allow persons under 21 to take part in tribal elections.

title: Fiats Sales Rose in Half Despite Its Labor Problems
description: Despite labor problems that reduced production of cars, Fiat, S. p.A., Italy's largest automobile manufacturer achieved a sales volume of $1.44billion in the first six months of 1971, an increase of 8 per cent, compared with the first half of 1970.

title: 2 Seized With Bogus Money
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., July 16 (UPI) Treasury agents arrested two Augusta men today with a quarter of a million dollars in counterfeit $5 bills in their pos session. The two were identified as Charlie Reid Sr., 49 years old, and Wallace Span, 39,

title: House Leaders Plan To Adjourn in October
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  House leaders have set a target date of mid October for final adjourn ment of this session of Congress.

title: L.I. Lifeguard Strike Is Expected to Continue
description: WANTAGH, L.I., July 16 The strike of lifeguards at Long Island state park beaches is expected to con tinue through the weekend, officials said today, despite petitions and efforts by nu merous citizens groups on Long Island to end the strike.

title: Nixon Move Pleases Reagan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan suggested today that President Nixon might have left the exact date open for his planned trip to China because the date might be tied in with his hopes to, end the Vietnam war. He said he was happy about the trip.

title: 2 Atom Tests Released Quake Energy
description: Analysis of tremors from 30 underground nuclear explosions has shown that two of them released more than 10 times as much pentup energy as was generated by the blasts themselves.

title: WALSH CRITICIZED FOR. RENT CHANGE
description: State Housing Commissioner Charles J. Urstadt yesterday criticized the City Housing and Development Administrator, Al bert A. Walsh for having pro mulgated a new rent regula tion, and ordered him to rescind it.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: PARIS, July 16In The Making of The President 1968 Theodore White records a comment by Richard Nixon on the function of the American Presi dency.

title: DATA CERTIFICATION REQUIRED OF BANKS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will now require certification of financial state ments filed by banks, the agency announced yesterday in Washington.

title: RCA Announces Increase In ReceivingTube Prices
description: The RCA Corporation said yesterday that it will raise prices by 6.6 per cent on re ceiving tubes sold for replace ment use, effective Aug. 16.

title: STRIKE TO AFFECT AUTOS AND WHEAT
description: The immediate effect of the strike that began yesterday on the Union Pacific Railroad and the Southern Railway was on rolling freight.

title: FOLK SONGS OFFERED BY CAPERS COUPLE
description: Hedge and Donna Capers, a folksinging couple from Los Angeles, are playing through Monday at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 President Nixon's success in ar ranging a trip to China evoked the widespread judgment here today that American policy, in Mao Tsetung's phrase, was taking a great leap forward.

title: Higher Electricity Rates Granted for Upstate Area
description: ALBANY, July 16 (AP)The Niagara Mohawk Power Cor poration today was granted $32.2million temporary in crease in its electric rates in upstate New York.

title: Gas Bills Expected To Increase in Area As Result of Ruling
description: The Federal Power Commis sion's approval of higher prices for natural gas producers in the Southern Louisiana gas fields yesterday will mean higher gas bills for New Yorkers.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Pentagon Picks Navy Aide To Head New Ocean Office
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today the establish ment of an Office of Ocean Affairs and named John W. Warner, Under Secretary of the Navy, to be its first director.

title: Knight Newspapers
description: MIAMI, July 16 (UPI) Knight Newspapers, Inc., an nounced today record earnings for the second quarter and the first six months of this year.

title: Nixon Names 2 Judges
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 16 (AP)President Nixon an nounced today the nomination of Herbert F. Murray and Jo seph H. Young both of Balti more, to be United States dis trict judges for the Maryland district.

title: Proponents of Bach and Rock Join in Musical Confrontation
description: Our day's version of the 18th century's Guerre des Bouf fons (or to English the phrase, War of the Comedians) may be the jousting that goes on between adherents of rock music and the less popular types known vaguely as clas sical. An admirable effort to cut through the fog of con descension and distrust usually laid down on both sides of the matter was made Thursday night at the Lincoln Center Library of the Performing Arts, where Rosalyn Tureck and Michael Kamen joined in lecture  demonstration  debate entitled Bach and Rock.

title: Police Officer Here Denies Taking Part In Gamblers Graft
description: A New York City police lieu tenant denied yesterday that he ever offered to let a policeman in his command use his attic as a hiding place for graft.

title: ALBATROSS VICTOR IN RICH CANE PACE ON 2MINUTE MILE
description: YONKERS, July 16Alba tross paced his slowest mile to night since he won in 2:00 2/5 at Roosevelt Raceway last May 22. But the 2minute perform ance turned in by the colt was good enough for a 1length victory over H. T. Luca in the $106,795 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: President Resigns From Mohawk Air
description: Russell V. Stephenson yes terday submitted his resignation as president and chief execu tive officer of Mohawk Airlines, which has asked the Civil Aero nautics Board to approve its acquisition by Allegheny Air lines.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Possibly the most important U.S. influence on the South Vietnamese elections will derive from the rate of pullout.

title: Senate Confirms Nominees Of President for 4 Posts
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The Senate confirmed today the following nominations by President Nixon:

title: West Europe Pleased
description: LONDON, July 16Western European Governments today welcomed President Nixon's de cision to visit China and said they hoped it would contribute toward world peace and sta bility.

title: The Money in Poverty
description: Revelations made the other day by City Invetigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin and City Councilman Robert I. Postel concerning the city's loan program for the rehabilitation of slum buildings show essentially two things: (1) there are people unscrupulous enough to misuse funds intended to alleviate the consequences of poverty, and (2) the city administration must be alert to the possi bilities of such misuse. That there's money in poverty has long been the perverse cry of those who think they can take advantage of inadequate fiscal controls.

title: Suit Seeks to Bar Catskill Plan
description: BEAVERKILL, N. Y.Two of the country's leading con servation organizationsthe Sierra Club and Friends of the Earthhave brought suit against a housing develop ment here that may have a farreaching effect on the use a property owner may make of land that lies adjacent to legally protected wilderness areas.

title: Mrs. King Reaches Final by Upsetting Mrs. Court, 62, 75
description: HOYLAKE, England, July 16 (UPI)  Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., upset Mrs. Margaret Court, 62, 75, today and moved into the final round of the Rothman's North of England tennis tournament.

title: Screen:
description: Say this for The Brazen Women of Balzac, yester day's new sexteaser at the New Embassy Theater: With its color photography, lovely rustic settings and tasteful manor interiors, it's certainly beautiful to look at. Ditto the girls, a hoteyed covey of belles who swarm around the premises and a group of willing gents.

title: Spread of Horse Disease Beyond Texas Is Feared
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 16with out an immunization program for horses, the Texas outbreak of Venezuelan equine encepha lomyelitis could undoubtedly spread to other states, Dr. David Sencer, director of the Federal Center for Disease Con trol at Atlanta, Ga., said today.

title: Pollution Closes 2 Mississippi Lakes to Fishing
description: JACKSON, Miss., July 16 Mississippi has closed two major lakes to commercial fishing following a report from the Food and Drug Administration office in Atlanta that fish from the lakes contained pesticides as much as three times above the danger limit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is important that the misleading letter by J. Sinclair, president of the Fraser Island Defence Organisation, Queensland, Australia, in The Times of July 8, be answered forthwith so that the situation relating to Fraser Island may be placed in its proper perspective.

title: Bridal for Elizabeth Frigerio And Lawrence Ellis Lewis
description: BEAVER FALLS, N. Y., July 16Miss Elizabeth Leigh Frigerio and Lawrence Ellis Lewis were married here this afternoon.

title: $2.4Billion for Agencies Approved by Senate, 70.0
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Senate passed today bill appropriating $2.4billion for the Interior Department, the Forest Service and related Fed eral agencies. The vote was 70 to 0.

title: Friden Layoffs Planned
description: The Rochester plant of the Friden division of the Singer Company yesterday announced layoffs of about 125 employes.

title: GRUMMAN RECEIVES CONTRACT ADDITION
description: The Grumman Corporation received yesterday $37.1million of additions to existing Navy contracts for production of F14A carrierbased fighters and for E2C carrier based electron ics aircraft.

title: Asfros Drop Me is to 3d, 94;
description: HOUSTON. July 16The sort of versatile futility that made the New York Mets famous long before they acquired the nor mal cares of struggling pennant contenders reappeared in full glory tonight in a 9.4 loss to the Houston Astros.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange opened higher but closed slightly lower yesterday in slackened trading.

title: Richard H. Dietz, 45, Dies; Public Relations Executive
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 16 Richard H. Dietz, an executive of the public relations concern of Selvage, Lee & Howard, was fatally injured in an automobile accident today near here. He was 45 years old and lived in Akron, Ohio.

title: Three More Reserve Banks Increase Discount Rates
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (Reuters)Three more Federal Reserve banks today raised their shortterm lending rate to commercial banks from 4 per cent to 5 per cent.

title: Justice Department Bars Mississippi Area Vote Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP)  The Justice Department re jected today a plan for redis tricting Hinds County, Miss., for upcoming county elections, finding that black voting strength might be diluted by the changes.

title: EARNINGS UP 7.4% AT BANKAMERICA
description: In sharp contrast to most major banking organizations, the BankAmerica Corporation, parent company of the nation's largest bank, reported yester day that its earnings in the second quarter rose 7.4 per cent from last year.

title: Linville Brothers Triumph in Tempest Class Again at Larchmont Race Week
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 16 When there's wind, there's a sailboat race, as there was to day for only the second time for the senior division of Larch mont Yacht Club Race Week, including a race for cruising yachts.

title: 10 Vietcong Reported Killed
description: SAIGON, July 16 (Reuters) A South Vietnamese military spokesman reported today that Government troops ambushed a Vietcong patrol 45 miles south west of Saigon yesterday and killed 10 guerrillas. There were no Government casualties, he added.

title: Shop Talk
description: Do things go better with Coke? Clothes, for instance? The CocaCola Company, which over the years has stamped its name on glasses, trays and lampshades, has figured out a new way to plaster it across the country. This time, the customer is the billboard. Cotton beach pants with the red Coke label and the slogan, It's the real thing, are the company's newest premium idea. And according to a CocaCola spokesman, they're selling, well, like Coke. So far, over 160,000 pairs of the pants have been ordered, via coupon and $2.98.

title: 7 of 9 New Issues Fell During Week
description: Nine companies offered their shares publicly for the first time this week, but investors were reluctant to buy them.

title: C.B.S. UNIT DISPLAYS NEW RECORD SYSTEM
description: A new record system called stereoquadraphonic that per mits four channels of sound to be reproduced from a twotrack source has been developed by Columbia Broadcasting System Laboratories under commission from Columbia Records.

title: NEWCOMBE GAINS NET SEMIFINALS
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) John Newcombe of Australia downed Andrew Gimeno of Spain today and moved into the semifinal round of the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

title: A Restaurant Where the Waitresses Are Missionaries
description: ROMEIn the Eternal City, the best way to man's soul may be through his stomach.

title: Hungary Beats Soviet, 8.2, And Retains Epee Crown
description: VIENNA, July 16 (Reuters) Hungary, the defending cham pion, crushed the Soviet Union, 82, tonight in the final of the men's team pe, the last event in the world fencing champion ships.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Carl Taylor, a Kansas City outfielder, stormed off the field one night in May, burned some of his equipment and fled to Florida. Curt Flood ran away to Europe and Clete Boyer took off at Paul Richards and didn't land until he reached Hawaii.

title: Accounting Office Hits Cost of Labor on U.S. Projects
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Government auditors said to day that the Department of Labor had added millions of dollars to the cost of Federal construction projects over the last decade by setting wage rates too high.

title: 2 Signed for Laugh Maker
description: Miriam Kressyn and Seymour Rexite have been signed for leading roles in The Laugh Maker, the Leo Fuchs musical opening at the Eden Yiddish Theater on Second Avenue and 12th Street in the fall. The musical will have a score by Alexander Olshanetsky and Jacob Jacobs, who also will produce it,

title: Radiation From Trailer on Lot In Bellport Is Called Dangerous
description: BELLPORT, L.I., July 16 A twoacre lot near this South Shore village that is in daily use for storage and movement of heavy construction equip ment is also being used to store a trailertruck load of nuclear waste, its shielding deteriora ting and emitting measurable quantities of radiation.

title: Sargent Signs Bomb Bill
description: BOSTON, July 16 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed yesterday a bill providing a life sentence for persons con victed of placing a bomb that results in death.

title: MISS KIMBALL'S TEAM GAINS STROKE LEAD
description: MASHPEE, Mass., July 16 (UPI)Kathy Whitworth and Judy Kimball took a onestroke lead today in the $20,000 Ladies Professional Golf Asso ciation team championship.

title: JUNE EXPORTS SET RECORD IN CANADA
description: OTTAWA, July 16 (Canadian Press)Canada's record export performance continued through June, reaching $1.64billion and bringing the halfyear total to more than $8.73billion, the Do minion Bureau of Statistics re ported today.

title: Stock Fraud Here Charged to 8, Including Reputed Crime Figure
description: A Federal indictment charged here yesterday that eight men, including a reputed member of organized crime, conducted a conspiracy to distribute mil lions of shares of worthless stock throughout the country.

title: Antiques: Concentrating on the Best
description: The whopping price of $415,800 that a fine 18thcen ury Parisian writing table brought at auction a few weeks ago proves once more that it pays to concentrate on the best in collecting an tiques.

title: WNJR Wins a Reprieve
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) The city of Newark has been granted authority to operate the Negrooriented radio station WNJR for an interim period of 120 days, the Federal Communications Commission announced today. The station had been scheduled to go of the air at midnight tomorrow in a dispute over its license,

title: F.D.A. Asserts 2 Makers Sold Contaminated Candy
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration disclosed yes terday that 204,000 candy bars and 7,100 boxes of candy, most of which have already been sold and presumably eaten, were contaminated with ro dents and insects.

title: Connecticut Residency Rule Stayed
description: HARTFORD, July 16  A Federal District Court judge today temporarily restrained Connecticut from enforcing its new oneyear residency re quirement against applicants for local welfare until a three judge Federal Court could rule on the law's constitutionality.

title: RAILROAD CREWS STRIKE SOUTHERN AND UNION PACIFIC
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Train crews struck the Union Pacific Railroad and the South ern Railway early today, ef fectively bringing traffic to halt on the two lines by the day's end.

title: Bobby Unser Sets Mark Of 193.4 M.P.H. for Lap
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 16 (AP)Bobby Unser recorded the fastest official lap in the history of Indianapolistype car racing today193.444 miles an hour to win the pole position for Sunday's $75,000 Michi gan 200mile race.

title: SAMUEL ZASHIN
description: FARMINGDALE, N. J., July 16  Samuel Zashin, a New York lumber distributor, died today at the Jersey Shore Med ical Center in Neptune. He was 74 years old and lived on Yellow Brook Road.

title: GIISUZU ACCORD PRAISED BY ROCHE
