description: TOKYO, July 16The Gen eral Motors Corporation, the world's largest manufacturing concern with annual sales of more than $24billion, today signed an agreement with ailing Isuzu Motors, Ltd., of Japan to acquire a 34.2 per cent interest in Isuzu.

title: Scare Delays Jet in Boston
description: BOSTON, July 16 (AP)An Irish International Airlines 747 airliner with about 240 persons aboard landed safely at Logan International Airport tonight after the pilot told passengers there had been a bomb scare. The plane, Flight 104 from Kennedy International Airport in New York to Shannon, Ire land, was diverted to Boston and expected to be delayed for three hours while It was searched.

title: BloodClot Study Gets Grant
description: BOSTON, July 16 (AP) Beth Israel Hospital has been awarded a $750,000 fiveyear grant by the National Institutes of Health for specialized study of blood clotting, the hospital announced today. The grant is one of five thrombosis re search grants announced by the institutes.

title: ExGov. Barron Gets 12 Years In West Virginia Bribery Case
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va. July 16  Former Gov. William Wallace Barron, 59 years old, was sentenced to 12 years im prisonment today and fined $50,000 for bribing a Federal jury foreinan in 1968.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: 1,146 Gamecocks Seized
description: LOS ANGELES, July 16 (UPI)More than 1,000 game cocks were confiscated and 22 men arrested in a number of fighting bird raids, Sheriff Peter Pitchess reported yester day. The 1,146 cocks were confiscated do raids at 26 lo cations throughout the county, prompted by citizens com plaints, the sheriff said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: This is relative to two statements made in a recent news story from Athens, Greelcr Albanian Links Resume After 31 Years.

title: Progress at Berlin Talks
description: BERLIN, July 16 (AP)Am bassadors of the Big Four pow ers said today that they had made progress at a fourhour meeting on the Berlin problem. Envoys of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France set their next session for Thursdaythe shortest in terval in the 16month talks.

title: Kremlin Viewed as Stunned by Move
description: MOSCOW, July 16Western diplomats expressed the view today that the news of Presi dent Nixon's plan to visit China had come as a stunning surprise to Soviet leaders.

title: Newark City Subway Will Reopen Tuesday
description: NEWARK, July 16 (UPI) A spokesman for the Public Service Coordinated Trans port Company announced to day that service on the New ark city subway would re sume Tuesday.

title: Misses Wilde and Stuhler Reach Amateur Golf Final
description: SYRACUSE, July 16 (AP) Dianne Wilde of Amsterdam and Sara Jane Stuhler of Fort Johnson advanced today to the 36hole final of the New York State women's amateur golf championship with victories at Nottingham Knolls Country Club. Misses Wilde and Stuhler represent the Antlers Country Club.

title: Inland Adds to Layoffs
description: The Inland Steel Company said yesterday that it had temporarily suspended opera tions in several facilities at its steel mill in East Chicago, Ind., and placed additional employes on layoff clue to declining de mand for steel products. The company said a total of 650 employes were being affected by the latest move. Last week the company said it laid off 100 workers.

title: Market Place: Street Hopeful On Rate Plans
description: Some people in Wall Street are confident the new pack age of brokerage commis sions now being discussed at hearings in Washington will garner approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission with only minor changes.

title: PREFONTAINE WINS 5,000
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 16 One of the more bizarre mo ments in international track and field  in which a runner misjudged the finish line by a full lap in the 5,000meter run  marred another impressive victory by Steve Prefontaine during the PanAfricaUnited States dual meet today.

title: Garden City Hotel Said by Its Owner To Have 'Future
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 16  The Garden City Hotel, whose closing was announced yesterday, is not for sale, its owner said today.

title: Building Aide Pleads Guilty To Receiving Bronx Bribe
description: A City Buildings Department inspector pleaded guilty yester day to receiving a bribe from a Bronx building contractor.

title: MILLS PROPOSES 2 TAX REDUCTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, pro posed tax reductions today for businesses and for lowincome individuals but said he would make the cuts absolutely con ditional on two other changes in national economic policy.Continued on Page 24, Column 1

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Scientists on the staff of the Offshore/Sea Development Corporation, New York, have succeeded in feeding oysters with mammalian blood.

title: Bogus $10 and $20 Bills Are Being Circulated Here
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned yesterday that a significantly increas ing number of counterfeit $10 and $20 Federal Reserve notes had been circulated in the last two weeks in the Second Fed eral Reserve District, which in cludes New York State, north ern New Jersey and Fairfield County in Connecticut.

title: Spain's Netmen Take Lead Over Czechoslovakia by 10
description: PRAGUE, July 16 (Reuters) Spain led Czechoslovakia, 10, after the first day of their Davis Cup European zone Group A tennis series today.

title: HARRY CLARK, 62, FLIGHT MANAGER
description: Capt. Harry L. (Red) Clark, former Eastern area flight man ager for American Airlines and later vice presidentflight of Seaboard World Airlines, died yesterday at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas, after a short illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 27 Shorehaven Lane, Manhasset, L. I.

title: Director of Science Foundation To Head Campus at San Diego
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 Dr. William D. McElroy was named chancellor of the Uni versity of California campus at San Diego today and will leave the directorship of the National Science Foundation about the end of this year to take the job.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION CLIMBS FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, July 16 (AP) domestic auto production rose slightly this week, as increased Ford and General Motors output offset changeover shutdowns by American Motors and a decline in Chrysler production.

title: U.S. Official Leaves Egypt After 11Day Secret Mission
description: CAIRO, July 16  After an 11day mission for talks with Egyptian officials, a United States State Department offi cial, Michael Sterner, left Cairo today for Washington to report on Egyptian attitudes toward efforts to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: Transfer Agent in Jersey
description: The First Jersey National Bank announced that the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange had approved it as a primary transfer agent for securities traded on the ex change. The Big Board changed its rules recently to permit pri mary transfer agents to be lo cated outside lower Manhattan. The First Jersey bank is in Jersey City.

title: JORDANIANS SHELL COMMANDO AREAS
description: AJLUN, Jordan, July 16 Jordanian Army guns shelled the hilly country west of Aj lun today after Palestinian com mandos had fled there from the shellpocked Ajlun woods.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAX'S KANSAS CITY STORIES. By Tony Weinberger. 190 Pages. BobbsMerrill. $5.95.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 Who but Henry A. Kissinger could have slipped into main land China, arranged a chat for President Nixon with Premier Chou Enlai and Chairman Mao Tsetung, and kept it all a secret? Only the President's Assistant for National Security Affairs could match the Orientals at inscrutability, it was said here to day. If that was merely the first of an inevitable string of quips celebrating Mr. Kissinger's role in setting up Mr. Nixon's visit, it was nonetheless ap propriate. Hardly anyone in the White House is more ob sessed with secrecy than Henry Alfred Kissingeror as capable of maintaining it.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Fuller Brush Is Planning A Merged Unit in Kansas
description: The Fuller Brush Company, a division of the Consolidated Foods Corporation, plans to merge its manufacturing and warehousing operations at a new $9million plant to be built in Great Bend, Kans., it was announced yesterday.

title: Kosygin, Meeting 4 Americans, Urges Joint Fight on Pollution
description: MOSCOW, July 16Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin told four Americans today that it was crucial for the Soviet Union and the United States to co operate in a major fight against environmental pollu tion.

title: Lines for Welfare Checks Grow Long
description: I don't mind doing a little light porter work, said Eugene Hudson yesterday as he waited in line at a Brooklyn state em ployment office for his $68.35 welfare check.

title: Stage: 2 at Chichester
description: CHICHESTER, England, July 16Critics notch their declining years not with birthdays but with festivals. The Chichester Festival, set in the luxurious greenness of Sussex, has now reached its 10th season, and I remember the first as if it were the day before yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: First Woman Air Force General Jeanne M. Holm, a 50year old former silversmith, has become the first woman in the Air Force to earn the rank of general.

title: Soviet Satellite Launched
description: MOSCOW, July 16 (UPI) The Soviet Union launched weather satellite today, the first known Soviet space launching since the fatal Soyuz 11 accident.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: We regard the news media's han dling of the Pentagon papers as weak, inconclusive and confusing to the pub lic. Granted, the media have shown courage and solidarity in defending the freedom of the press in America. However, apart from the admirable efforts of The Times, they have dis played, on the whole, little initiative or incisiveness in clarifying for the public the significance of the informa tion contained in the report.

title: Canada Is Set to Issue $550Million in New Bonds
description: OTTAWA, July 16 (Reuters) The Canadian Government said today it will issue $550 million in new bonds in an offering on Monday.

title: Merger News
description: The Kenton Corporation an nounced yesterday plans for its acquisition of Arlan's Depart ment Stores, Inc., subject to ap proval of stockholders of both companies. Directors of the two have already approved the transaction.

title: 6 Americans Are Freed From East German Jails
description: BERLIN, July 16 (AP) East Germany has freed six Americans who had been in its jails from six to 22 months on various charges, among them assaulting border guards, hos tile provocations and trying to help Germans escape.

title: Once Hospital's No Man's Land, Now a Friendly Gathering Place
description: Behind locked doors on the fourth floor of Brooklyn State Hospital a voluntary design program has just been completed that has proven therapeutic for the patients and the single most impor tant project so far for the Parsons School of Design stu dents involved.

title: A Pakistani Terms Bengalis 'ChickenHearted
description: FARIDPUR, Pakistan, June 29Maj. Nazir Baig, the mar tiallaw commander in the Fa ridpur District just west of Dacca, is a chunkily built Ba luchi tribesman from West Pakistan who has spent nearly six of his 20 years of military service in East Pakistan.

title: Welding Dividend Omitted
description: WARREN, Ohio, July 16 (UPI) Directors of the American Welding and Manufacturing Company have voted to omit the quarterly dividend dut at this, time in view of present economic conditions and earn ings prospects for the year. The company last paid a divi dend of 20 cents a share in May.

title: Newport Plans a Study On Future of Festivals
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 16 (UPI)The Newport festivals were given a lift Wednesday when the City Council v. proved a resolution authoriz ing the Mayor to appoint a committee to study the fu ture of music festivals in the city.

title: Blacks and the General Lockout
description: DETROITBoth the collapse of the Chicago Plan for Equal Opportunity and the Department of Labor's an nounced intention to impose an ar rangement in its place are bound to make the debate about hometown plansof which Chicago is the most prominent examplegrow louder. The hometown approach, predicated upon the ability of a minority group coali tion, unions and contractors to nego tiate a voluntary agreement, has the blessing of the Nixon Administration as a vehicle to discharge its responsi bility to achieve equal employment op portunity in the construction industry. But if the Chicago experience means anything, it is that the hometown plans will not work. Indeed, it, makes the Philadelphia Plan, widely criticized for its apparent inability to produce minority union journeymen, look like a relatively successful enterprise.

title: TWO PAPERS SETTLE CHATTANOOGA SUITS
description: CHATTANOOGA, July 16 (UPI)Civil antitrust suits filed by Chattanooga's two daily newspapers against each other were settled today out of court.

title: Move by President Seems to Outflank His Potential Foes
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 President Nixon appeared to day to have significantly de fused criticism of the Indo china war and outflanked his potential Presidential chal lengers with his announce ment that he would visit China.

title: To Ward. Off the Apocalypse
description: In 1960, following the earthquake which destroyed many Chilean cities, Dr. C. G. Jung wrote: Even though today's scientists may reject the idea, the earth seems to be in tune with the destructive fury of mankind. Jung was establishing a close relation ship between the spirit of mankind and the spirit of the earth, suggesting that the earth has a soul of its own. The visionary Swedenborg made similar suggestions. He wrote that the heavens took the form of a man's body. I be lieve that the earth is also divided into parts, like the body of a man. It has a head, a brain, a solar plexis, a heart, and sexual organs. Since these are all different, it follows that the people living in various parts of the world are not the same. If we would accept this reality, everything would be much clearer, for then we would not try to impose our way of life on other people who do not want to be like us.

title: Nichols, Dick Lotz Share Lead By Shot at 138
description: CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) Lee Trevino fell out of conten tion and Bobby Nichols and Dick Lotz moved into a tie for the secondround lead at 138 today in the $150,000 Western open golf tournament.

title: 852's Raid Foe Near DMZ; Scattered Fighting Is Reported
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 (AP)While a series of small skirmishes dominated the ground war today, United States B52 bombers flew four more raids along South Viet nam's northern frontier in a continuing effort to block an enemy buildup.

title: ALBERT CALDWELL, LED PRINTING FIRM
description: BALTIMORE, July 16  J. Albert Caldwell, founder of Universal Lithographers, Inc., in Cockeysville, Md., died yes terday, after a short illness. His age was 68.

title: PARIS COMMITTED TO FRANC PARITY
description: PARIS, July 16France is determined to show that a speculative influx of capital can be fought with an arsenal of exchange controls and remains absolutely committed to main taining the franc's present fixed relationship with the dollar, Finance Minister Valery Gis card d'Estaing said today.

title: The Opened Door
description: President Nixon's bold decision to journey to Peking to seek a normalization of relations between the United States and China opens a door to a new era in interna tional relations affecting almost every part of the globe. This move by both Peking and Washington to exchange views on questions of concern at the highest level marks the end of more than two decades of irrational intran sigence on both sides and the beginning of a more prag matic approach to mutual problems.

title: Rate of Growth in Deposits Moved Lower Last Month
description: The growth in deposits at the nation's mutual savings banks set a record last month, but the rate of gain was lower than earlier in the year, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said yesterday.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES SPUR ON LOCKHEED
description: The House Banking Commit tee voted ylksterday in Wash ington to mice four days of hearings on legislation in an, effort to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.

title: CAROLINA UTILITY SHOWS PROFIT DIP
description: The South Carolina Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday a slight decline in firsthalf net income despite higher operating revenues.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: The second president of the State University of New York, College at Old Westbury, L. I., recently described his experience with the original staff and students: They sometimes speak as if they'd just come from a war.

title: LESTER R. FALLON, 75, OF THOM M'AN SHOES
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 16Lester R. Fallon, former president of the Thom McAn Shoe Company, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 1273 North Avenue.

title: Car Kills Girl, 5, in Jersey
description: WADING RIVER, N. J., July 16 (AP)Fiveyearold Kathe rine O'Neill of West Orange was struck and killed on Coun ty Route 542 in this Burlington County community today by an, auto driven by Eugene Hedge peth, 33, of Camden, state po lice said.

title: Umpiring the Alaska Debate
description: The Federal Communications Commission has tradi tionally taken a narrow view of its own fairness doctrine. Except in overtly partisan political matters, it rarely polices the television networks and stations vigorously to make sure that they present contrasting viewpoints on major issues.

title: U.S. VOTE TO CUT AID ANGERS GREEK CHIEF
description: ATHENS, July 16Premier George Papadopoulos reacted critically today to a vote by the United States House Foreign Affairs Committee in favor of proposals to withhold military and economic assistance from Greece and Pakistan.

title: Thomson, With 130, Leads French Open Golf by Shot
description: BIARRITZ, France, July 16 (UPI)Peter Thomson of Aus tralia shot a threeunderpar 66 today to take the secondround lead in the French international open golf tournament.

title: Urban League Office Burns
description: A fire yesterday morning de stroyed the New York Urban League's employment and vet erans affairs office, at 2381 Seventh Avenue, near 139th Street. A Fire Department spokesman said the fire started in a luncheonette next door. Livingston L. Wingate, execu tive director of the league, said the office would be temporarily relocated at the organization's building at 204 West 136th Street.

title: Salvation on the East River
description: As dusk fell over Manhattan on a recent cloudless sum mer evening, blues singer Dan Smith blew a few warmup notes on his harmonica into a microphone set up front of a small portable stage on a pier at the end Fulton Street. This was a signal that another of the regu lar Tuesday and Thursday evening folk concerts of the South Street Seaport Museum was about to begin.

title: Dollar at Low In Germany
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany July 16 (UPI)  A shaky United States dollar slipped to a new low today in heavy trad ing on the Frankfurt foreign exchange market.

title: Gas Rate Rise Won By Major U.S. Field
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The Federal Power Commission approved today sharply higher rates for natural gas produced in the southern Louisiana area, the nation's biggest source of supply.

title: ' The Devils,' an Adaptation With Fantasy:Work by Ken Russell Opens at Fine Arts Miss Redgrave in Role of Sister Jeanne
description: Ken Russell's "The Devils," an adaptation of Aldous Huxley's "The Devils of Loudun," and of the play that John Whiting based on the Huxley book, is a movie that carries its head (and its mind) tucked underneath its arm. It's a see-through movie composed of a lot of clanking, silly, melodramatic effects that, like rib-tickling, exhaust you without providing particular pleasure, to say nothing of enlightenment."The Devils," in fact, is of so little substance, obscene or otherwise, that I can only believe that the men and women of the Motion Picture Association, who rated the film "X," must be in league with Beelzebub, or with Warner Brothers, the selfdescribed "Kinney leisure company" that financed the film. It just may be that there's still enough mystery in an X rating to make "The Devils" more popular than it has any right to be.In 1634, in Loudun, France, Father Urban Grandier, a handsome, sophisticated lay priest, who had been educated by the Jesuits, was convicted of witchcraft, largely on the hysterical testimony of a small group of Ursuline nuns, and burned at the stake, with the approval of Cardinal Richelieu, whose belief in witches was not noticeably great.Father Grandier was guilty of a number of cardinal outrages (among other things, he had married himself to Loudun's most virtuous heiress in front of his own altar), but his execution, as Huxley carefully detailed, was a badly disguised political act. It was a small, tragic skirmish in Richelieu's much larger campaign to reduce the power of the feudal towns, thereby to assure the absolute authority of the King, Louis XIII, and, through the King, the absolute authority of Richelieu.Although I rather liked Russell's adaptation of "Women in Love," I was appalled by "The Music Lovers," and thus I can't explain why I should have been surprised to find his approach to "The Devils" to be that of a hobbyist determined to reproduce "The Last Supper" in bottle tops. Russell, as writer and director, has simplified and reduced the complexity of the drama to the dimensions of that most boring kind of Pop art, which tries to forestall criticism by making fun of itself.How else to explain a sequence in which Richelieu attempts to lecture the King on the historical necessities of power, while the King busies himself taking pot snots at Huguenots who run across his lawn dressed in bird costumes? "Bye, bye, blackbird," says the king as one uncredited extra explodes in a puff of feathers. It's not the fantasy that is objectionable, but the quality of the imagination behind it.A movie that opens with Louis XIII dressed as Botticelli's Venus, emerging from a half shell in a court tableau (to throw Tiny Tim kisses to his audience), is obviously a movie less interested in coherent thought than in spectacle. This includes crucifixion fantasies, in which Sister Jeanne of the Angels, Grandier's chief accuser, sees herself licking the blood off Christ's (Grandier's) hands, exorcism by enema, tortures, vomiting, and the final immolation."The Devils" is so concerned with the "look" of these experiences that it ultimately diminishes their meaning, and, in turn, the meaning of the lives of the people who lived them.In view of this, I suppose it's no special wonder that most of the performers behave like figures in an animated wax-works. When the screenplay allows, Oliver Reed suggests some recognizable humanity as poor Father Grandier, but everyone else is ridiculous. Vanessa Redgrave, who can be, I think, a fine actress, plays Sister Jeanne with a plastic hump, a Hansel-and-Gretel giggle, and so much sibilance that when she says "Satan is ever ready to seduce us with sensual delights," you might think that Groucho Marx had let the air out of her tires.

title: Housewife Sets Run Mark
description: LONDON, July 16 (Reuters) Mrs. Joyce Smith, a 33year old British housewife, clipped 15 seconds from the world mark for the women's 3,000 meter run at Crystal Palace to night with a time of 9 minutes 23.2 seconds in the British wo men's track and field cham pionships.

title: Harris to Yield Senate Seat To Campaign for President
description: NORMAN, Okla., July 16 Senator Fred R. Harris, the son of an Oklahoma share cropper, announced today that he was giving up his Senate seat to organize a campaign for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: New Chief Named At Franklin Simon
description: Mortimer L. Janis, who had been an assistant fur buyer at the Franklin Simon chain of readyto wear apparel stores in the nineteenforties, is re turning Aug. 15 as president of the New Yorkbased com pany. Mr. Janis succeeds Ed win G. Roberts, who will be come president of the Dayton Hudson jewelry store chain.

title: MURPHY SUSPENDS TWO FOR PERJURY
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has suspended for 30 days two patrolmen con victed in a department trial of giving false testimony in court.

title: Love of Rancher's Wife Is Spark for 'The Hunting Party,' a Western
description: I think it is proper to praise Candice Bergen, who has risen from the ephemeral celebrity stardom in which she began her career to the level of durable professionalism that characterizes her work today. "Durability" may not seem quite the notion for a beautiful young woman, but in Miss Bergen's performances it is as much an intelligent, sympathetic alertness  in a sense, a moral qualityas any gift of nature that accounts for her extraordinary appeal. And that appeal holds good not only for a showcase role in a movie like "Carnal Knowledge" but also for an utterly thankless role in a really stupid movie like "The Hunting Party," which opened yesterday at the Victoria and 86th Street East theaters.Miss Bergen plays the wife of a rich Texas rancher (Gene Hackman), who is also an impotent sadist. One day she is kidnapped by a hard-riding outlaw (Oliver Reed) because he mistakes her for a school teacher and, anxious to improve his lot, means to make her teach him to read and write. They never get beyond the alphabet, but, what with one thing and another, they do fall in loveso that when the rancher gives chase, supported by a hunting party of business associates carrying high-powered rifles equipped with telescopic sights, it becomes something like the flight of passionate innocence from a methodical and psychotic rage.One by one the hunting party cuts down the outlaw's band (much colorful blood and gore) and at the same time loses its own members until there remains only Gene Hackman pursuing across the burning desert a lurching Oliver Reed leading Miss Bergen, who, by now somewhat dotty from the sun, has begun babbling of green fields.To the unwary, "The Hunting Party" might seem an all-out bid for family entertainment, combining as it does sex and violence with primary education. But in fact it neither teaches nor titillatesexcept as movies of this sort tend to get funnier as they become more stark, more elemental, more deadeningly expressive of elemental values in ultimate confrontation. To this end, Don Medford, the director, hokes up the action to a degree not required by the story and, with a stunning tactlessness, catches scene after scene at its dramatic limit and pushes it over into helpless banality.Given a less than perfect environment for actors, Gene Hackman actually improves upon his situation by looking as if he not only wished he could be, but actually were, someplace else. Oliver Reed, who is also not indigenous to the Old West, gives his role his allwhich is considerably more than it can take. Whether making love or dealing death or dying, he acts with a kind of drawn-out intensity that suggests nothing so much as grand opera in close-up. But Miss Bergen, mostly without tricks and without reservations, plainly succeeds with a part that is not so much a character as a test of character. Every so often, and only because it observes her, "The Hunting Party" seems to reveal something of human nature.

title: Officials Arrive in Egypt
description: CAIRO, July 16 (Reuters) Two officials of the Palestinian commandoes arrived today in Mersa Matruh, in the Western Desert of Egypt, to discuss the fighting in Jordan at a meeting with the leaders of Egypt, Lib ya, the Sudan and Syria.

title: NO DEVELOPMENTS IN VILLAGE SLAYING
description: The police said yesterday that they were investigating the slaying Thursday night of a 32year  old woman in her Greenwich Village apartment, but that there were no sub stantive developments in the case.

title: Kapp Quits Patriot Camp; Rejects Standard Contract
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 16 (AP)Joe Kapp, quarterback for the New England Patriots, packed his bags and quit the team today, refusing to sign a National Football League standard players contract.

title: Tiriac, Nastase Win at Net
description: VIENNA, July 16 (UPI) July 16Rumania led West Ger many, 20, at the end of the first day in Bucharest in the final of Group B in the Euro pean zone Davis Cup tennis play today. Ion Tiriac beat Christian Kuhnke, 62, 36, 62, 75, and Ilie Nastase beat Wil helm Bungert, 62, 63, 62.

title: BAY SHORE FIREMEN TOLD TO TAKE BLACK
description: The State Commissioner of Human Rights yesterday or dered the Bay Shore, L. I., Fire Department to accept the mem bership application of a black policeman who has been trying to join the volunteer group for five years.

title: Lichardus, Benning Tied; Jersey Golf Playoff Today
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 16  Eleven years ago Milton (Babe) Lichardus finished in a tie for the New Jersey open golf championship. This after noon the 42yearold profession al from the Shackamaxon Coun ltry Club in Scotch Plains, N.J., again tied for the crown after equaling Bob Benning's 72hole aggregate of 289.

title: TIGHTER CONTROL ASKED ON 2 DRUGS
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Food and Drug Administration and a panel of the National Academy of Sciences have rec ommended tighter controls over two stimulant drugs, one of which has been widely used to treat children.

title: Chess Players in 6th Draw
description: MOSCOW, July 16 (AP) Viktor Korchnoi and Tigran Petrosian, Soviet grandmasters, agreed to a draw today in their sixth semifinal match in the World Chess Challenger's Tour nament. It was the sixth straight draw in the battle be tween the two players.

title: Pleasure Is Voiced By Peking Officials
description: PEKING, July 16Chinese officials expressed pleasure to day over the planned visit of President Nixon, but offered no information about the talks lie tween Henry A. Kissinger and Premier Chou Enlai that ar ranged it.

title: State Will Restrict Buffalo Park Use To Protect Ecology
description: ALBANY, July 16The state's Environmental Con servation Department today or dered Zoar Valley, a 3,500acre state park near Buffalo, closed to overnight camping and motorcycling to prevent ir reversible damage to the park's ecology.

title: Sofia Condemns Move
description: VIENNA, July 16The offi cial radio of Bulgaria said in a commentary, monitored by Radio Free Europe, that Presi dent Nixon does not view rela tions with the Chinese People's Republic as an instrument of peace and understanding be tween nations but rather as a means to keep disunited the antiimperialist forces and the national liberation movement.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended July 13:

title: NEWARK SUSPENDS A TOP HEALTH AIDE
description: NEWARK, July 16Dr. Aaron H. Haskin, Newark's Health Officer and the second ranking official in its public health establishment, has been suspended and accused of neg lect of duty.

title: Democrats Press 72 Guidelines
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Democratic party's Commission on Delegate Selection and Party Reform armed itself to day for the continuing struggle to bring state parties into com pliance with its guidelines be fore the 1972 National Conven tion.

title: Namath Arrives Here and Displays A New Eagerness
description: Joe Namath arrived in New York yesterday and promised to report to the Jets training camp tomorrow along with 26 other experienced players.

title: MICHIGAN TO OPEN INDIAN PROGRAM
description: LANSING, Mich., July 16 Gov. William G. Milliken will order a program to improve the lives of Michigan's 16,854 In dians on Tuesday when he re solves a fishing rights dispute among three tribes and groups of angry sportsmen.

title: 900 Flee Blaze on IRT; Lindsay Attacks M.T.A.
description: A smoky subway fire forced 900 rushhour riders to flee on ladders and catwalks yesterday morning in the Lexington Avenue tunnel south of 14th Street. Eleven passengers received hospital attention, and one of them was admitted for observation after a sweltering trek to daylight.

title: Dance: Interesting Way
description: What is there to say about the American Ballet Theater's Mendelssohn Symphony, Dennis Nahat's ballet, which had its premiere Thursday night at the State Theater? That Mr. Nahat, a 24yearold soloist with the company who has previously choreographed three other ballets, has done it again?

title: TRUDEAU COMMENDS NIXON'S BOLD STEP
description: OTTAWA, July 16Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau hailed President Nixon's plan to visit Peking as a bold and decisive step toward bringing China into world affairs.

title: Gleaming Favored to Raise Victory Streak to 5 in Aqueduct Field of 11 Today
description: Gleaming heads the list for today's running of the Lexing ton Handicap at Aqueduct. Rigged at top weight of 126 pounds, the Calumet Farm's 3 yearold star is the strong favorite to take the 1 316 mile turf race against 10 rivals.

title: Grains and Soybeans Advance On News of Nixon's China Trip
description: A belief by speculators that the announcement of President Nixon's proposed visit to Com munist China could result in increased trading in farm pro ducts sent grain and soybean prices higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: British Ford Is Weathering Contract Loss
description: LONDON. July 16 (UPI) Ford of Britain had just lost the biggest production con tract in British automotive history. The company spokes man turned up his hands and said, That's history now. We've got to move on to other things.

title: U. S. and Mexico to Meet
description: MEXICO CITY, July 16 (Reuters)The United States Embassy announced today that Washington had agreed to a request from President Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico for a highlevel meeting to dis cuss the outbreak.

title: 2 Killed by Fish Oil Fumes
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 16 Two men died and three others were hospitalized in critical condition after being overcome by fish oil fumes at the Vy Lactos Laboratories in northeast Des Moines early to day.

title: Computers for Barclays
description: Barclay's Bank, Ltd., of Lon don announced yesterday that it had authorized delivery of two additional largescale B 6700 computer systems from the Burroughs Corporation The machines will be used to auto mate the bank's branches using Burroughs TC 500 terminals through a data communicatigns network. Value of the equip ment was said to be about $38 million.

title: Opposition Party to Boycott Ulster's Parliament
description: BELFAST, July 16The principal opposition group in the Northern Ireland Parlia ment, the Social Democratic and Labor party, announced to day that it would boycott the legislature and form an alterna tive assembly.

title: U.S. Bugging Cafe at Yonkers Raceway
description: Federal agents have been se cretly recording conversations in the dining room at Yonkers Raceway for well over a month.

title: Long Day's Journey Gets New Cast Tuesday Night
description: John Beal will play the patri arch of the Tyrone family in Long Day's Journey Into Night starting Tuesday night at the Promenade Theater. Carol Teitel will take over the role of his wife, and their sons will be played by Donald Gan try and Dan Hamilton.

title: NIXON IS EXPECTED TO VISIT CHINA AROUND END OF YEAR; TO SEE BOTH MAO AND CHOU
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July, 16Officials at the Western White House said today that President Nixon's trip to China could be made late this year at the earliest and that he would confer with Mao Tse tung as well as Premier Chou Enlai.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Hartford Fire Insurance Company has named William M. Griffin president of Hartford Securities Company, Inc., a new brokerdealer subsidiary. Mr: Griffin is a senior vice president of finance of Hart: ford Fire.

title: Confusion in East Europe
description: WARSAW, July 16Presi dent Nixon's announcement of his planned trip to China ap peared to create confusion among officials in Eastern Europe and delight among ordinary citizens.

title: LUTHERANS FINISH STORMY MEETING
description: MILWAUKEE, July 16 Divided delegates of the 2.8 millionmember Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod ended a stormy eightday convention here today with expressions of reconciliation, a sentiment that had been little more than the gathering's motto all week.

title: Hooray for the TwoParty System
description: From Its inception, America has been well served by a twoparty polit ical system. It has been saved from the turmoil of some multiparty situations such as are now occurring in Italy. The endless wheeling and dealing be tween a myriad of splinter parties creates an unstable atmosphere.

title: EARNINGS DROP 23% AT DISCOUNT CORP.
description: The Discount Corporation of New York, the big Govern ment bond dealer that until re cently was notably shy about disclosing its quarterly profits, reported yesterday that its earnings declined to $294,473, or 59 cents a share in the sec ond quarter, down 23 per cent from the $382,475, or 77 cents a share it earned in the second quarter of 1970. The second quarter this year was far below the spectacular $3.85million, or $7.71 a share Discount posted in the first three months of 1971, when bond prices were rising sharply.

title: ACTIVE WEEKEND DUE IN BELL TALKS
description: The nationwide strike against the Bell System by 400,000 members of the Communica tions Workers of America and by other unions entered its third day yesterday, with lit tle progress toward settlement but no signs of a deterioration in telephone service.

title: Boy Gains After Bite By a Severed Snake
description: SAN GABRIEL, Calif, July 16 (UPI)  An 11yearold boy bitten on the arm by a rattlesnake thought to have been dead was released in good condition from the San Gabriel Valley Hospital to day.

title: Gunmen Kill and Rob Man
description: MEDIA, Pa., July 16 (AP) Three gunmen, posing as F.B.D agents, broke into a home near here early today; shot a man to death, tied up his wife and five children, and escaped with $12,000, the police said. Half an hour earlier apparently the same gunmen had broken into a neighbor's home, tied up a man and his wife, and robbed them of $250.

title: Meeting Is Set for Detroit
description: DETROIT, July 16 (AP) Next year's annual metting of stockholders of the Detroit Edi son Company will be held here for the first time. The meeting is set for April 17. Previous stockholder meetings have all been held in New York City.

title: Minority in Rumania
description: The announced removal of the head of the Union Communist Youth in Rumania, and President Ceausescu's public criticism of his own propaganda chiefwho may also have been oustedstrengthen indications of internal tensions in Bucharest. A few days ago, Mr. Ceausescu had presented an elaborate program for purging Western influences in Rumanian life, denouncing cosmopoli tanism and warning his nation's intellectuals against borrowing ideas from the capitalist world. He particu larly denounced youthful parasites, i.e., dropouts who apparently prefer living on their parents bounty to taking jobs.

title: The Discount Rate Goes Up
description: With Federal Reserve Board approval, seven Federal Reserve Banks this week have raised from 4 per cent to 5 per cent the discount rate they charge member banks in their districts. The probability is that the other five regional Federal Reserve Banks will follow suit next week.

title: Roundup: Blue Wins 18th on OneHitter
description: As if making up for his lackluster performance in the AllStar game, Oakland's Vida Blue returned to com petition in the American League's regular schedule with a fury last night.

title: DISMAY ON TAIWAN
description: The governments of most of Communist China's neighbors appeared yesterday to welcome the news of President Nixon's forthcoming trip to ?eking, but on Taiwan, the Chinese Nation alists reacted initially with dis belief, then with dismay.

title: Man on Crutches Held In Attempted Robbery
description: The police foiled an at tempted bank robbery today involving a man on crutches.

title: I.R.S. FILES LIENS ON KING RESOURCES
description: DENVER, July 16 (UPI)The Internal Revenue Service has filed tax liens totaling more than $8million against the King Resources Company and its subsidiaries. The liens were filed earlier in the week but did not come to light until to day.

title: $2.3BILLION VOTED BY HOUSE FOR A.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) The House sent to the Senate yesterday a 62.32billion, one year program authorization for the Atomic Energy Commission. It did so after refusing to halt an underground test explosion in Alaska.

title: Yanks Win, 74, From Brewers
description: The Yankees made impres sive progress on two reclama tion projects last night. They began reasserting their terri torial rights to the rightfield seats, and Lindy McDaniel showed another sign that he might yet reassert his position as a highly, reliable relief pitcher.

title: PRESIDENT ELECTED BY UNITED NUCLEAR
description: Douglas M. Johnson, who had been financial vice president of the United Nuclear Corpora tion, was elected the company's president yesterday by the board of directors following the annual meeting, which was held at the New York Hilton Hotel. Mr. Johnson succeeds David F. Shaw, who continues as the company's chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Typhoon Again Halts the Fighting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17 (AP)Winds and rain in South Vietnam's northern region halted the fighting today for the third time in two weeks.

title: Election Poses a New Test for Allendel
description: VALPARAISO, Chile, July 17 Chile's leftwing Government and the antiMarxist Opposition will meet here tomorrow in an electoral contest with national implications.

title: Nightingale 5 Points Ahead In Lightning Race Series
description: NOROTON, Conn., July 17Steven Nightingale of the host Noroton Y. C. took the lead for the ConnecticutRhode Island district championship of the Lightning Class today.

title: Two U.S. Judges Retire
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 17 (AP)President Nixon has announced the retirement of two district judges who were nominated to the Federal bench in 1956 by President Eisenhower. The judges are William G. Juergens of Chester, Ill., and R. Dorsey Watkins of Baltimore.

title: Press in Peking Devoting Little Space to Nixon Visit
description: PEKING, July 17  The Chinese Government seems to be making less fuss over President Nixon's forthcoming trip to Peking than most other governments in the world.

title: Wallops Island Is Where the Monkeys and Leeches Are Launched
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va.  WaIlops Island is no Cape Kennedy, but it is the granddaddy of United States space flight facilities and the perfect friendly neighborhood space center where people in the Northeast can brush up on their aerospace technology before planning a visit to the Big Show in Florida.

title: Reds, Held to a Single for 8 innings, Get 3 Runs in Ninth to Beat Giants, 32
Misunderstanding Causes Crew to Abandon a Plane
description: NORFOLK, Va., July 17 (AP) The Navy said today that two F4 J Phantom 88 jet fighters from the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Independence crashed into the Atlantic a week ago after one had engine trouble and the other was abandoned by crewmen who thought they had been told to bail out.

title: Police Here Seek Suspect In Rape of Girl, 15, in Hotel
description: The police were searching yesterday for a man who entered a room of the Statler Hilton Hotel, at Seventh Avenue and 33d Street, Friday afternoon and raped a 15yearold girl from East Weymouth, Mass., who was visiting the city with her aunt.

title: Whitlinger, Du Pre Reach U.S. Junior Tennis Final
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17 (UPI)John Whitlinger of Neenah, Wis., scored his second straight upset in the national junior claycourt tennis championship today when he defeated thirdseeded George Hardie of Long Beach, Calif., 62, 6.1, in the semifinals.

title: Sounds of the Summertime
description: WHEN the birds were singing back in May, it seemed as if nothing could silence those exuberant sounds. But that was in spring, with families to establish and territory to defend. Hence the males asserted themselves at the top of their lungs.

title: NurseMidwives Trained in Brooklyn
description: Midwives, whose specialty dates back so far they might be called the original paraprofessionals, are now being trained at Brooklyn's Downstate Medical. Center in the most uptodate techniques of family planning.

description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich.  A year ago, Donald Holcombe Parsons, a 40yearold Michigan lawyer and entrepreneur, was the headalbeit an embattled oneof a $3billion empire of 19 banks. Now, all that is gone.

description: There was at City Council committee hearing the other day old Joseph Modugno, who used to be the atlarge Republican Councilman from Queens until the LiberalLindsay victory, of 1969, stopped in for a look. He was in the City Hall area in his new role as a Rockefeller appointee to the Court of Claims.

title: About Pro Football
description: This was pro football the week the training camps opened in the summer of 1971: One athlete did not know how to put on his equipment. An owner ordered a general manager to sign a rookie who was asking for $600,000. The son of a famous player quit. A hero kicker became a wide receiver and a quarterback tore up a surgical knee when he assumed the tight end role for one play. A soccer kicker from Israel looked good and two rebels stayed away because they want their longterm contracts renegotiated.

title: Horse Show News
description: One of the major surprises of the Horse Show season has been Barrett Farm's Sable Cape.

title: M'INTIRE CLEARED OF FUNDS CHARGE
description: CAMDEN, N. J., July 17The Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, militant fundamentalist radio preacher, has been cleared of charges that he illegally appropriated funds of the theologically conservative American Council of Christian Churches.

title: Back fire Possible In Housing Protest In Glen Oaks Area
description: Residents of the Glen Oaks section of Queens fighting the proposed construction of three 32story luxury apartment buildings in their community may find that the developer will erect a fourth building if his application for special permits is denied by the City Planning Commission.

description: DALLAS  Three airlines are now locked in a fiercely competitive and costly marketing battle for commuter airline business linking the three biggest cities in Texas  Houston, Dallas and San Antonio.

description: NORTHPORT, L. I., July 17Paul Bordwell of the host Northport Yacht Club took the lead today in the Flying Dutchman Class regional sailing championships on Northport Bay.

description: SANTIAGOFor weeks, Governmentpaid advertisements in the Chilean newspapers have been showing pictures of shackdwellers and naked, undernourished children over a title reading: This would not have happened if the copper had been ours.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 17The West Coast longshoremen's strike, now in its third week, shows every sign of continuing for a long time, with large effects on the economy.

description: ZERQA, Jordan, July 17King Hussein promised today to support Arab commando activities against Israel, but he denounced the guerrilla leaders and said the Jordanian Army crackdown on commandos in northern Jordan this week had been necessary and successful.

title: Mrs. Patricia Nordheimer a Bride
description: Mrs. Patricia Kinsella Nordheimer, a reporter for The Port Chester (N.Y.) Item, was married here yesterday to William Fulton Oursler, public relations director for the International Motor Sports Association, Inc.

title: Bayreuth: Tuxedos in the Afternoon
description: BAYREUTH, GermanyThe parade of long dresses, tuxedos and ruffled shirts starts in midafternoon as operagoers make their way up the hill to the Festspielhaus, passing the bust of Richard Wagner at the far end of the rose garden.

title: The Nation
description: In 1968, while she was still President Johnson's consumer adviser, Betty Furness was asked by Mayor Lindsay to become the city's first Commissioner of Consumer Affairs. She turned down the offer largely because she thought it would be a monumentally difficult job. And she urged Bess Myerson, another photogenic former television performer who was approached by the Mayor, to follow suit. I was terribly afraid, Miss Furness said recently, that people would literally be on the commissioner's doorstep, saying my car doesn't work.

title: Son for the Bareaus
description: A son was born June 21 to Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bareau in Madrid at the British American Hospital. Mrs. Bareau, whose husband is a vice president of the Bank of London and South America, is the former Miss Irene Sylvia Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Nelson of New York, where Mr. Nelson is president of the Nelson Fund. Inc., a mutual fund. The child has been named Oliver.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: Unemployment among scientists in the spring of 1971 grew substantially over that of a year before.

title: Bike Racing in Queens Gaining in Popularity
description: Round and round they go, heads down, legs pumping furiously in rhythm with the slapslapslap of wheels over macadam. At the steeply banked turns, they lean with the gravitational pull, then straighten out and fly down the straightaway, straining to catch the leader.

title: Mrs. Carolyn Marshall Is a Bride
description: Mrs. Carolyn Schmidt Marshall and Harry Lesser Jr., both of St. Louis, were married here yesterday afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Ginsburg, stepfather and mother of the bridegroom. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dana Klotzle of the Unitarian Universalist Association at the United Nations.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: LOS ANGELES  Robert H. Volk has come full circle in the onebank holding company business in a little more than two years. That course, he says, puts me right back Where I wanted to be in the beginning, with flexibility.

title: Pop
description: The communities around Los Angeles and San Francisco have long been the most fertile for American rock music. Unfortunately, political and social problems also clouded the skies of rock, climaxed by the tragic Altamont Free Concert. But as that crisis slips into the past, there has been a lifting of spirits. Once again California is coming alive wth rockandroll sunshine.

title: PHILADELPHIA SAYS CARGO WAS DIVERTED
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (UPI)  Ten major steamship lines have been charged with illegally diverting cargo to New York and Baltimore ports in a suit filed by the Delaware River Port Authority.

title: SUIT CHALLENGING GOLD RESERVE ACT
