title: SPEEDY TRAIN NET PROPOSED FOR 76
description: WASHINGTON, July 17A proposal to commemorate the nation's 200th birthday in 1976 by linking the major cities on the Eastern seaboard with a highspeed rail transportation system is under consideration by the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission.

title: A Vivaldi Lover Gets. To Like Ferraris at Lime Rock
description: ILIKE Vivaldi; he likes Ferrari. The solution: a weekend in the Connecticut Berkshires, within easy reach of both the Lime Rock motor racing course and the Tanglewood music festival.

title: Fiscal Problems Plague Sponsors of L. I. Jazz
description: MIDDLE ISLAND, L. I., July 17When the Thad JonesMel Lewis Jazz Band performs tomorrow afternoon at 5 on the lawn of the Longwood High School, it will be a tribute to the faith and persistence of Ann Sneed, program director of the International Art of Jazz, an organization that has presented free neighborhood jazz concerts in Suffolk County every summer since 1968.

title: Steal This Book
description: If you are a teenage runaway on the lam, or a 50yearold executive finally gone bananas and about to drop out, then what you should probably read is Abbie Hoffman's Steal This Book. It will tell you how to live for free and survive.

title: Medicine
description: On June 2, 1763, a clergyman named Edward Stone read a paper before the Royal Society in London entitled: An Account of the Success of the Bark of the Willow in the Cure of Agues.

title: The World
description: JARASH, JordanAt first, it seemed only a minor bit of inter Arab harassment. The tireless Arab commando spokesmen in Beirut began to complain that King Hussein's army was picking on their men in Jordan again. But Amman let it be known that the army was simply having maneuvers with live ammunition.

title: Shadow Over the Wilderness
description: The Wilderness Act of 1964 gave permanent legal protection to nine million acres of wilderness land that had already been so designated by administrative order; it also provided for a review by Federal agencies of about 45 million additional acres in the wildlife refuges, national parks and national forests to determine whether these lands deserve the same protection.

title: You Can Have a Blast Seeing Apollo 15 Off
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla.Here they, are standing in a giant semicircle some 40 miles in diametera broad, ragged ribbon of birdwatchers, perhaps as many as a million of them, craning their necks as close to Launch Pad 39 as NASA will let the general public get. The time is a week from tomorrow, early on the morning of Monday, July 26. The bird they have come to watch fly is Apollo 15. They can clearly see it poised there on its pad.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: News of Dogs
description: A complaint frequently heard, from both exhibitor and spectator, is the lateness of the group and bestinshow judging. When groups are listed to be begin at 4 P.M., and frequently they start later than the scheduled time, it means the bestinshow will not be named until between 7 and 7:30. In the summer months, with extra heavy travel from the beach and moun tain areas to the cities, one must cope with bumpertobumper traffic, if he stays for the final. So in order to get home and have dinner, many never see the bestinshow judging.

title: Jail Inmates to Get Pool
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17 (AP)A rooftop swimming pool is being planned for inmates at the Jefferson County jail this summer. Sheriff Allen Hamilton said the facility was designed to cool tensions and hopefully keep down trouble at the jail.

title: U. S. Is Facing New Strains In Soviet and Taiwan Ties
description: WASHINGTON, July 17Relationships with Nationalist China and the Soviet Union, whose interests may be the most seriously affected by President Nixon's decision to visit Peking, were described by Administration officials today as the immediate problem facing United States diplomacy.

title: Watts Take Trophy as Outstanding Skippers at Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 17 A boat that can't seem to lose and a husbandandwife team that hasn't lost its class title in three years were the dominant prize winners today as Larchmont Yacht Club's cur tailed 73d Race Week came to a close.

title: A WARM FEELING
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: POLISH OFFICIALS ON TV FARM FORUM
description: WARSAW, July 17Polish Communist party officials adopted an Americanstyle television production this week to explain the radical new agriculture policy.

title: Susan Willcox, John Mackay Are Married
description: WEEKAPAUG, R. I., July 17  The marriage of Miss Susan Ainslie Willcox, daughter of Mrs. Charles Hall Delamater of Weekapaug and West Hartford,. Conn., and the late William Goodenow Willcox 2d, to John Sutherland Mackay took place in the Weekapaug Chapel this afternoon. The bridegroom is the son. of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Sutherland Mackay of Long Lake, Minn., formerly of Far Hills, N. J. The Episcopal ceremony, performed by the Rev. Alexander Ogilby.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: PRAGUE, July 17 (AP)Spain led Czechoslovakia, 21, in the European Zone A final of the Davis Cup today as Manuel Orantes and Juan Gisbert beat Jan Kodes and Jan Kukal, 64, 119, 64, in doubles.

title: Enemy Activity on Rise Near Saigon As Militiamen Replace Allied Troops
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17With most American ground combat troops now gone from the, area around Saigon, and few regular South Vietnamese forces protecting its periphery, enemy activity has been increasing on the outer edge of the capital rgion.

title: Agnew Praises Africans; Chides Some U.S. Blacks
description: MADRID, July 17Vice President Agnew delivered today a broad indictment of unidentified black leaders in America, calling them querulous and saying they had much to learn from the African officials he had met on his worldwide tour.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In recent years we have had mystery fiction with locales in the Soviet bloc countries, in the Soviet Union itself (endlessly), in South American and Caribbean dictatorships. Red China still is an enigma and, while there have been scattered novels about it, most had no more authority than the expertise gleaned from any standard scholarly or newspaper source.

title: Linda Hemstead Wed
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 17Miss Lincia Gertrude Hemstead, daughter of Mrs. Marvin Posner and Dr. George Warren Hemstead 2d, both of Albany, was married here this afternoon to Thomas John Calabrese Jr., son of Mrs. Calabrese of Huntington, L.I., and the late Mr. Calabrese. The ceremony was performed in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Daniel Burns and the Rev. George A. Phillips. The bride's father is an internist and a professor at the Albany Medical College. The bridegroom's father was principal of Memorial High School in Huntington.

title: Reader's Report
description: Bernard Clavel is a dramatic illustration of the pluralist nature of contemporary French fiction. Amid the cinematic hoopla of the New Novel, and some exciting reshufflings of introspective technique, Clavel carries resolutely on with the Old Novel. And he infuses it with a dynamism to which attention must be paid. American readers who have read the author's 1968 Goncourt prizewinner, The Fruits Of Winter, will find in this earlier book a similar perspective: a wrinkle by wrinkle delineation of the rural middle class that includes every wen, goiter and moral flaw. It also includes that terribly abused word: compassion. Clavel displays compassion, without sentimentality, for the most unprepossessing of God's creatures, and in this he differs from the chillier naturalistic writers.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Discourage mosquitoes by a good cleanup campaign. Since they lay eggs in stagnant water, drain and clean bird baths weekly, clean out gutters and clear areas where water collects.... Water, water, water, where there are no restrictions; shrubs, roses, perennials and flower boxes take first priority.... Resow vegetables where the rows are empty.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 382Member U.S. Squad Biggest inpanAmGames
description: CALL Colombia, July 17Bolivia has scored an early victory in the 33nation Sixth Pan American Games to be held here July 30 to Aug. 13. The victory does not rate a medal; an engraved cocktail shaker, yes. The event: The highest proportion of officials to athletes.

title: Eight Students and Professors Study Fresh Air Fund Children
description: FISHKILL, N. Y.Eight students and professors from Dartmouth College and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine have moved into tents and cabins in the middle of the woods here to study hundreds of youngsters on vacation from the slums of New York City.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: The $100billion franchising scene which accounts for 25 per cent of the United States's retail sales and about 10 per cent of the gross national product, according to a recent Conference Board estimate, has encountered assorted bumps and bruises in recent years. In Congress, state legislatures and the courts, franchise companies and their operators are attempting to come to grips with the realities of this way of marketing.

title: Psychic Study Unit Gets Fortune Left For Study of Soul
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 17 (Reuters)  The fortune of a gold prospector who left his money to research establishing the existence of the human soul has been awarded to an organization that studies spiritual phenomena, the Arizona Superior Court said today.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Christian Herald Building at 27 East 39th Street, where the religious monthly is published, has been sold for $1,035,000 to a mining concern that maintains its offices next door.

title: F. G. duPont Jr. Weds Miss Sweney
description: CONCORD, Mass., July 17 Miss Patricia Allen Sweney was married here this afternoon to F. George duPont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. duPont of Fairfield, Conn. The Right Rev. William H. Mead, Episcopal Bishop of Delaware, performed the ceremoy on the terrace overlooking Great Meadows Pond at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Borden, stepfather and mother of the bride.

title: 29 From Coast Join Hunt for Boy
description: SYRACUSE, July 17 (AP)A team of 29 mountain rescue specialist flew across the country from California today to join the massive search for 8yearold Douglas Legg, who has been lost in the Adirondack wilderness for a week.

title: Driver, 25, Shot in Queens After Pursuit by Patrolman
description: A patrolman shot and killed a 25yearold man in Queens last night after the man escaped the scene and then allegedly attempted to run over the pursuing policeman with a car.

title: Malaysian Team Wins
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 17 (Canadian Press)Punch Gunalan and Tan Aik Huang of Malaysia won the doubles badminton competition at the Calgary Stampede yesterday, defeating Ippie Kojima and Shoichi of Japan, 1512, 1115 and 159.

title: Miss Ann Gargan Is Boston Bride
description: BOSTON, July 17 (UPI)The former Miss Ann Gargan, a cousin of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, honeymooned today in an undisclosed country.

title: AustralianChinese Talks
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, July 17 (Reuters)The Melbourne Herald today quoted Prime Minister William McMahon as having said that the Australian and Chinese Ambassadors in Paris met twice in recent weeks.

title: Nixon Appoints 5 to Panel On Environmental Quality
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 17 (UPI)President Nixon has appointed five persons to the Citizens Advisory Committee on Environmental Quality, a group formed two years ago to develop environmental protection guidelines.

title: Sons of Sihanouk Acquitted Of Charges of Terrorism
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 17 (AP)  The two sons of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the ousted head of state, were acquitted today by a special military tribunal in Pnompenh of charges of terrorism.

title: Private Worlds
description: At an unhurried, almost Jamesian pace, Sarah Gainham uncoils the last section of the Austrian trilogy that began with Night Falls On The City. The city is still Vienna, the year is around 1951, and it finds Miss Gainham's characters trying to sort out their badly tangled private lives under the Allied Occupation. Julia Homburg, leading lady of the Burgtheater, has married her lover, George Kerenyi, an antiHitler journalist, after the death of her Jewish husband. Their attempt to regain a civilian equilibrium is jolted by the sudden reappearance of General Tenius, an SS veteran with blackmail on his mind. Why the Kerenyis and their friends have reason to fear Tenius, Miss Gainham tells us in her own sweet time, reweaving along the way the texture of the era. The distinguishing feature of these views of the AustroGerman side of the War is their subtlety. No crude stereotypes are to be found in this, postwar vortex. The spiv, the opportunist, the Nazi and the badly dented man of conscience are presented with meticulous attention to individual details of character.

title: Record Fleet Looming for Friendship Regatta
description: Faced with the largest entry in the 11yearold event's history, volunteer groups conduct. ing the annual Friendship Sloop Regatta off Friendship, Me., from July 29 through 31, also are anticipating a record spectator fleet.

title: THIEU DENOUNCES N.B.C. DRUG CHARGE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17  President Nguyen Van Thieu today described as shocking and slanderous a National Broadcasting Company report alleging that he was using funds from the illegal drug market to finance his campaign for reelection.

title: Leary Asks Swiss Asylum
description: BERNE, Switzerland, July 17 (AP)Dr. Timothy F. Leary, the drug advocate, has applied for political asylum in Switzerland. Held in a Lausanne jail since June 30, pending an official extradition demand from the United States, Dr. Leary is wanted in California, where he escaped from prison while serving one to 10 years for illegal possession of marijuana.

title: Foreign Notes; Why Me?
description: I'm Just a poor old man. I don't understand what you've got against me, 69yearold Giuseppe Doto told a Milan court last Tuesday after it had ordered him off to a fouryear exile in a little mountain town where he will have to stay indoors from 10 P.M. to 7 A.M. and be denied use of the telephone.

title: Art
description: THE Minneapolis Institute of Arts saves its biggest show every year for the summer, and has turned up this year with a lulu that might throw you into a trauma if you are of a certain age and a certain temperament (my age and my temperament). The subject is Art Deco, the decorative style of the 1920's and 1930's called modern at the time, which most of us who were subjected to it would be glad to forget, but which fascinates a generation of youngsters born during the 1940's after the whole dreadful business was over.

title: Music
description: NEVER before In the history of black music had one individual so completely dominated an art form as the Master, Daniel Louis Armstrong. His style was equally copied by saxophonists, trumpet players, pianists and all of the instrumentalists Who make up the jazz picture.

title: Music
description: PUPPETS are normally considered the province of children, but now Lou Harrison has writtea a puppet opera which he is rating 'X in order to keep the children away. The 90minute work is called Young Caesar, and it will be given a preview on Aug. 21 at the Cabrillo Music Festival in Aptos, Calif. Its official premiere will take place this fall at the Pasadena Art Museum, which commissioned it.

title: Ray Named Packer Scout
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 17 (UPI)The Green Bay Packers announced today the appointment of Buford (Baby) Ray as a personnel scout. Ray played with the Packers from 1938 to 1948.

title: Bottle Club Owner and Relatives Accused of Bribery in the Bronx
description: The owner of an unlicensed bottle club in the Bronx, his mother and his cousin were arrested yesterday for allegedly trying to bribe three policemen who arrested him at the club.

title: Kidder Takes Golf Final
description: DOVER, N. H., July 17 (AP) Alan Kidder of Franklin defeated Paul Moriarty Jr. of Nashua. 7 and 6, today and captured the New Hampshire amateur golf championship.

title: HUNTER TITLE GOES TO LIBERTY AWARD
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., July 17Bill Morin's Liberty Award, who spent the first six months of the year competing in the midSouth circuit, captured the regular working hunter championship today at the Springbrook Park horse show. The event was held at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds.

title: CALIFORNIA G.O.P. IN ELECTION DRIVE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 17The Republican party in California is making a major effort to win a special election to fill a State Senate seat next Tuesday, although registration figures and primary election results favor the Democrats.

title: PHILS DOWN CUBS AS JOHNSON STARS
Walkabout: Beautiful But Fake?
description: THE myth of the Noble Savage at perfect peace with Nature is such a hoary one that I suppose it shouldn't be any surprise to find filmmakers, those arch mythmakers, finally turning to Australia for their fantasies. It is, after all, a Last Refuge; in the center of the continent is the last surviving oasis of primitivism where modern man can hide from the civilization he has created for himself.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: PRESIDENT Nixon's electrifying announcement that he would visit China on a journey for peace before next May instilled new confidence in the business and investment worlds late last week, but did nothing, of course, to salve the mounting irritations of the nation's economic problems.

title: L.I.Historical Society Acquires SuperExtra Gazette of 1782
description: A bit of old Brooklyn history, contained in a 12by15inch handbill of 1782, has been safely ensconced in the collections of the Long Island Historical Society, at 128 Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn.

title: the traveler's world
description: THE Federal regulatory agencies including the Civil Aeronautics Board are under examination for failure to perform properly their roles as regulators and protectors of the public, but the C.A.B. must be given a public pat on the back for creating unconsciously one of the funniest bits of bureaucratic humor to come out of Washington in a long time.

title: Nader Group Calls U.S. Lax on Meat Inspection and Pesticides
description: WASHINGTON, July 17A group of Ralph Nader's raiders accused the Department of Agriculture today of failing to guard Americans against bad meat, dangerous pesticides and the forces of corporate agribusiness.

title: Judge Asks Raise, or Else
description: LEBANON, Ind., July 17 (UPI) Superior Court Judge Paul Johnson Jr. and another Judge want a raise. Judge Johnson ordered the Boone County Council Thursday to appropriate $1,500 for pay rises for him and his colleague or face a contempt of court citation.

title: Uneasy Malaysia and Singapore Bolster Defenses
description: SINGAPORE, July 14Half a million pamphlets announcing rewards of up to $6,900 for information leading to the arrest, killing or surrender of Communist terrorists are being distributed in the border areas of Upper Perak in Malaysia.

title: Music Mailbag.
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Wendy Chapman Wed To Daniel Wheeler 3d
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 17Miss Wendy Gilman Chapman and Daniel Fairchild Wheeler 3d, 1971 graduates of the University of Denver, were married in St. Peter's Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The Rev. Nelson M. Burroughs, retired Bishop of Ohio and uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. S. Hughes Garvin, rector of the church.

title: Honolulu Pressmen Settle
description: HONOLULU, July 17 (UPI)The pressmen's union, after turning down the proposal twice, have joined five other unions in ratifying a $3.5milion twoyear contract, it was announced today. The contract with The Honolulu Advertiser The Honolulu StarBulletin and The Hawaii Newspaper Agency, will increase the top minimum from $227 to $295 a week by October, 1973.

title: W. A. Knight Jr.to Wed Philae Carver
description: WOODSIDE, July 17 Mr. and Mrs. G. Calif.,W. Douglas Carver have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Philae Margaret Carver, to Warren Arthur Knight Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. William Scott Wallace Jr. of Boston, and Warren A. Knight of Sarasota, Fla.

title: Religion
description: MILWAUKEE  When the thbusand delegates to the biennial meeting of the Lutheran ChurchMissouri Synod marched into their convention hall here last week, they were greeted by a giant sign bearing a drawing of a dove and the words: Sent to Reconcile. It was an appropriate symbol, for, if there is anything that these particular heirs of Martin Luther need right now, it is a large dose of peace and harmony.

title: Miss Goldman Wed To Milton Fuller Jr.
description: The marriage of Miss Sharon May Goldman to Milton Alvah Fuller Jr., a general partner of Reynolds & Co., stockbrokers, and manager of their Detroit office, took place here yesterday. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: AMERICAN BALLET OFFERS 2 WORKS
description: American Ballet Theater presented two ballets for the first time this season at the State Theater on Friday night, Birgit Cullberg's Miss Julie and Fokine's Petrouchka, in the production that was new last summer.

title: Taiwan Firmly Opposes Any Talks With Peking
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 17At a time when policy shifts in Peking and Washington have produced a climate for consultation, the atmosphere here is unswervingly against change.

title: BOLD REASON, $6.40, TAKES LEXINGTON BY 3 LENGTHS
Letters:
description: Mel Mandell's article, Tenants Strengthen Building Security [June 201, should be of interest to all apartment dwellers and residential owners or managers. Unfortunately, the techniques and implementation of security measures must be custom planned for the particular buildings or areas concerned and as a result, any attempt to approach these complex problems in a general fashion must of necessity fall short of its goal. Recognizing the need for unique approaches, a number of security consultant firms are offering their services to owners on a professional basis.

title: Environment
description: New Yorkers strolling along almost any midtown street in these 90degree July days will often be greeted by a snowfall: white flakes glinting in the sun, tumbling out of the sky. If you scoop up some of the snowflakes, and happen to have an electron microscope handy to examine them, you will find the white fluffs to be composed of millions of fibers of asbestos. Their source? Up among the rising bare girders of the building under construction overhead, asbestos is being sprayed.

title: A DRIVE IS URGED ON SALMONELLA
description: Replying to a complaint by five public health organizations, the New Jersey Department of Agriculture has called for new educational programs to warn consumers about possible food poisoning from Governmentinspected meat and poultry.

title: CITY REVISES RULES ON DATING OF FOODS
description: The city's Department of ConsumerAffairs has issued revised regulations to require retailers to show how fresh packages of dairy products, eggs, baked goods and coffee creamers are.

title: Study of Nixon Order Asked
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) The National Federation of Federal employes called today for the closest Congressional and public examination of President Nixon's recent order upgrading the Subversive Activities Control Board. The federation recalled the national furor over subversion investigations during the nineteenfifties.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 17 (Reuters)Rumania gained an unbeatable 30 lead over West Germany by winning the doubles in the Davis Cup European Zone B tennis final today.

title: Air Bag Controversy Takes On The Aspects of National Debate
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Henry Ford 2d has called the air bag a lot of baloneytoo expensive, perhaps unworkable and possibly dangerous.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.R. to Reduce Ratio Of Its Cars for Smoking
description: The Long Island Railroad has announced that it will reduce the number of smoking cars on all trains starting Sunday, Aug. 1.

title: Policewomen on Streets In Guise of Prostitutes
description: Policewomen have been posing as prostitutes in midManhattan in an attempt to arrest more Johnsas the clients of prostitutes are known  the Police Department announced yesterday.

title: The Nation
description: The new and improved, actionpacked, talentenriched, streamlined Federal Trade Commission (It Scares Advertisers 12 Ways) had a busy time last week, as it has for the last year.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONCongress seems headed toward enactment of some sort of legislation rescuing the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy (at least temporarily) through Governmentguaranteed loans. In the Senate Banking Com.mittee, the bill has been converted from a narrow onebailing out only Lockheed, to a broader measure permitting rescues of companies similarly troubled during the next two and a half years.

title: L.P.G.A. TITLE TAKEN BY WHITWORTH DUO
J. S. AUCHINCLOSS, PUBLISHING OFFICIAL
description: J. Stuart Auchincloss, president of Schnell Publishing Company and publisher of Oil, Paint and Drug Reporter, a chemical marketing newspaper, died yesterday in BeekmanDowntown Hospital from injuries suffered in a fall here Wednesday. He was 42 years old and lived at 45 Woodcrest Avenue, Short Hills, N.J.

title: Extra Man Triumphs
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 17 (AP)Extra Man, the favorite, scored an eighthlength victory today in the $10,000 Junior Derby at Miles Park.

title: Holly Wheeler, '67 Debutante, Betrothed to Paul Harwood 3d
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 14Mr. and Mrs. William F. Sanford of High Fields here have announced the engagement of Mrs. Sanford's daughter, Miss Ann Hollingsworth Wheeler, to Paul Henry Harwood 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harwood Jr. of Fairfield.

title: Fighting 35ers, 140 Strong, Vie for U.S. Tennis Title
description: Athletes, generally, are competitively washed up in baseball, football and basketball at the age of 35. But in tennis, it is a fighting ageand 140 players will be out to prove that in the national claycourt, championship for men 35 and over that starts on Friday at the Shelter Rock Club in Manhasset, L. I.

title: Secretary of Year Named
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (UPI)Mrs. Mildred Kobos, an Air Force secretary for 16 years who advocates loyalty to your boss, is the International Secretary of the Year. Mrs. Kobos won the title Thursday in a contest against four other finalists at the 26th annual convention of the National Secretaries Association.

title: HardRock Music By Two Ensembles Is Performed Here
description: Good, unencumbered hardrock bands are hard to find. At this point in the development of the idiom, nearly everybody feels the need to add something: jazz, country, classical, or some other influence.

title: 6 Take III After Eating
description: Six persons were taken to Harlem Hospital yesterday when they became ill after eating ham and cheese sandwiches at Della's Delicatessen at 23 East 125th Street, the police said. Acicording to hospital officials, the six were in fair condition and would remain overnight for observa Lion.

title: Carter Quits Dallas Camp
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., July 17 (UPI)Joe Carter, the No. 4 draft pick of the Dallas Cowboys, voluntarily left the leam's training camp today. He paid he had personal problems. He is gone permanently, a club spokesman said of Carter. Carter was a tight end at Grambling University.

title: Hospital Elects Banker
description: Neil D. Chrisman, vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, has been elected president of the associate board of regents of the Long Island College Hospital, at 340 Henry Street, Brooklyn. The purpose of the associate board is to acquaint young business leaders in the community with the hospital.

title: The World; Indonesia:; Someone Is Doing Something Right
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia With so much of Southeast Asia now plagued by war and budding insurgencies, one does not have to look at a map of the area very long to decide which country seems to be on the upslope these days. It is Indonesia, which is still tabulating the results of a national election held the week before last.

title: GERALD L. FIEDLER, ADMINISTRATOR, 52
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 17  Gerald L. Fiedler, administrator of Lyndhurst, the 19thcentury Gothic house and estate of Jay Gould, the financier, died here yesterday after a short illness. His age was 52.

title: Jules Feiffer Can't Cut It
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Fire at Forbes Field
description: PITTSBURGH, July 17 (UPI)A twoalarm fire destroyed the locker room and a storage area under the right field stands at Forbes Field today. Fire officials said they suspected arson. The University of Pittsburgh, which took over ownership of the 62yearold ball park after the Pirates moved had scheduled it for demolition.

title: CHUCK DAVIS GROUP DANCES AT HUNTER
description: Any resemblance between the Chuck Davis Dance Company and Les Ballets Africains is not coincidental. Mr. Davis has chosen to model himself on this internationally famous troupe, and though he has yet to assemble dancers who live up to their standard, he has made a beginning with Monifa Olajorin and Martial Roumain.

title: Does Fidel Eat More Than your Father?; By Barry Rechford. 191 pp. Praeger. $5.95.
description: Castro's Cuba as seen by a young Jamaican playwright, with the help of interviews and quotes from Castro. The voices of Cubans on Cuba, pro and con, are illuminating and a welcome change from sociological commentary; but unless one has a firm grasp of Cuban socialism, with its voluntarylabor and antibureaucratic sentiments, as well as knowledge of Third World economics, much here may be confusing. Mr. Reckford puts his playwright skills to good expository use.

title: Ecumenical Benedictines Mark The End of an Era in Minnesota
description: COLLEGEVILLE, Minn., July 17  St. John's Abbey, the world's largest and most ecumenically minded Benedictine community, situated in the wooded,, rolling hills of central Minnesota, is closing an era this summer before exploring even newer approaches to cooperative Christianity.

title: Federal Agents Seize Gun At a J.D.L. Camp Upstate
description: Agents of the United States Treasury Department seized a pistol last week during a two day search of the Jewish Defense League summer camp in Woodburne, officials said yesterday.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (Reuters) Tigran Petrosian and Viktor Korchnoi agreed to a draw after only 13 moves in the seventh game of their world chess title contenders semifinal here today, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency. All six previous games were also drawn by the two Soviet grandmasters.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Have some institutions switched out of Scott Paper and into Procter & Gamble as an aftermath of the disposable diaper battle between these two corporate giants?

title: Modern L. I. Retains Its Traditional Polo
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 17Frederick Guest, the son of Winston Guest and a descendant of one of Long Island's oldest families, plunged his feet into his long leather riding boots, clutched his bamboo handled polo stick and mounted his brown and black pony.

title: Attempts to Modify Income Tax Reported Gaining in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, July 17  A movement to reconvene the Connecticut General Assembly to repeal or modify the recent ly enacted state income tax appears to be gaining momentum.

title: Jules Feiffer Can't Cut It
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Taliaferro Signs for a Year As Patriots Quarterback
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 17 (AP)  The New England Patriots signed Mike Taliaferro, quarterback, to a oneyear contract today.

title: PERCEPTIVE
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: S.I. Tops Britons in Cricket
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club side triumphed by 86 runs over the representatives of the British Navy's H.M.S. Jupiter yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island, scoring 159 runs to the Britons 73.

title: Peter Rabbit and kinfolk
description: Beatrix Potter never forgot what it was like to be a child, which explains perhaps the miracle of Beatrix Potter. It says why, since the turn of the century, her tiny books have held such rapturous appeal with their Jemirna PuddleDucks and Squirrel Nutkins, their small world of Peter Rabbit and all his kinfolk. I have just made stories to please myself because I never grew up, she saidas simple as that. She leaves one a little sorry, even apologetic, to have grown up oneself and lost the knack of it and lost the childhood she never mislaid. If nobody remembered how sensible a world it was, then where would be?

title: PANEL IN GEORGIA ACCUSES POLICE
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., July 17A biracial committee investigating racial problems in this city's police department has charged that police brutality has been displayed by some black and white officers alike.

title: U.S. Plans to Send Vaccine to Control Texas Horse Illness
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced plans today to send 2.6 million doses of vaccine to Texas and surrounding states in a steppedup effort to control a strain of encephalitis that has afflicted thousands of horses along the Texas Gulf coast.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 9TH GAME REJECTED BY UPSTATE VOTERS
description: ALBANY, July 17 (AP)High school athletic officials in the AlbanySchenectady area, especially those from schools with elaborate football programs, have been angered by a recent development.

title: The Humble Beginnings Of an Elegant Mansion
description: SNEDEN'S LANDING, N. Y.A barn forms the heart of Rebekah Harkness's house here, but now it's a drawing MOM.

title: Yoko Ono in Custody Fight
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. ???. July 17 (AP)Yoko Ono, wife of John Lennon of the Beatles has filed suit in Federal Court here seeking custody of her daughter from her first marriage. Mrs. Lennon contended that her former husband, Anthony Cox, had taken Kyoko, 7 years old, on entensive travels in recent years but had no fixed income, employment or home.

title: Stamps
description: TWIN United States 8cent postage stamps commemorating a decade of American space achievements will be issued to tie in with the Apollo 15 mission, now scheduled for blastoff on July 26. Although no specific date of issuance has been announced, the firstday will be commemorated at two points, instead of the usual single city. Issuance will be from the Kennedy Space Center, Florida, and at mission control, Houston, Tex.

title: Miss Humelsine to Wed
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., July 17Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Carlisle H. Humelsine of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Anne Humelsine, to Roger Thomas Harmon, son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Harmon of Jacicsonvile; Fla.

title: Mrs. Krents Has Child
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Krents of Hartsdale, N. Y., in the White Plains Hospital. Mrs. Krents is the former Miss Peggy Bauer of Asheville, N. C., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee M. Bauer of Wilton, Conn. The child, whose father is an account executive with WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, is named Karen Lee. She is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Milton E. Krents of New York. Mr. Krents is the radiotelevision producerwriter.

title: Traveling Abroad Imperi V.I.P. Class'
description: OUSTONHow many couples have you run into lately checking, into the airport with two steamer trunks, two foot lockers and a dozen assorted pieces of luggage?.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: GREENPORT, L. I.,We took our last fish of the evening, a striped bass of about eight pounds, from the dying tide rip between Great Gull and Little Gull Islands, then cut the engine and drifted, enjoying the solitude and mystery of the soft, warm night.

title: Susan E. Cleveland Is Married To Dr. Victor Anthony Altshul
description: MILTON, Mass., July 17Miss Susan Elizabeth Cleveland, a clinical instructor in the department of psychiatry at the Yale University School of Medicine, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Victor. Anthony Altshul, a clinical associate in psychiatry at the Yale School of Medicine.

title: National Notes
description: The strange expression on the face of many a New York male, last week, on close examination turned out to be a smirkinspired by a rash of titillating articles in the public prints detailing the police crackdown on prostitution and corollary obscenities in midManhattan.

title: MOSCOW OUSTS 35 IN PROTEST BY JEWS
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (AP)Thirtyfive Jews who were arrested while conducting a hunger strike in Moscow's central telegraph office have been sent back to the Soviet Republic of Georgia to serve jail terms, Jewish sources reported today.

title: Altesse Royale Scores in $55,200 Irish Oaks
description: THE CURRAGH, Ireland, July 17 (UPI)Altesse Royale, the Englishtrained oddson favorite, held off a strong challenge by the. French filly, Vincennes, to win the $55,200 Irish Guinness Oaks by half a length today.

title: A mirror of our days and needs
description: A veteran now with three books behind him, Jim Harrison is one of our finest young poets. He has a racy Michigan lingo (backwoodswryhuntin and fishin'dirtygone to hell) that he iningles a little too readily with notes from the high lyric tradition. He is relentlessly hard on himself: his past life, his present plights, his character in general. But he redeems the poems from grimness by a buffoonery of anguish and by something else that is more elusive.

title: YearRound Schools Becoming Popular
description: ROMEOVILLE, Ill., July 17 The yearround schoola controversial concept that is being tried in a small but growing number of school systems with burgeoning enrollments and no money for new buildingshas taken firm root here, just 12 months after it was begun.

title: FAIRFIELD IS SITE OF POLO TOURNEY
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 17The national intracircuit eightgoal polo championship starts tomorrow with Fairfield meeting the Greenwich Pitchforks at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

title: CANADIAN GIRL WINS BRITISH DASH TITLES
description: LONDON, July 17 (UPI)Led by Stephanie Berto, an 18yearold sprinter from West Vancouver, Canadians took four titles today in the British Amateur Athletics Association women's championships at Crystal Palace Stadium.

title: A Tuscan dumpling
description: The late Samuele Sebastiani, who left his native Tuscany before the turn of the century, was one of the first vignerons in California's Sonoma Valley. His son, August, who operates the winery today, also inherited his father's fondness for northern Italian cooking. He is quick to praise his wife's ability to prepare the dishes he knew as a boy, including malfatti (literally translated, it means badly made, but it's the traditional Tuscan name for these spinach gnocchi or dumplings). Tender and light, malfatti are an unusual dish.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONAs July ripens into midsummer, a growing number of Americans find themselves taking unwanted, unpaid vacations. Strikes and labor disputes are erupting across the country like a bad case of poison ivy.

title: Hasidic Village Is Flourishing in Rockland
description: NEW SQUARE, N. Y.In the evening twilight, young children play tag here on streets named after the Presidents of the United States. On the sidewalks, 40 miles from New York City, men walk past houses that range from singlefamily Cape Cods to ultramodern garden apartments with Mansard roofs. They have beards, wear long black coats and round black hats, and carry sacred Hebrew books.

title: Medicine
description: One of the most controversial groups in the health care field, the chiropractors, celebrated a major victory last week. Two bills passed by the New York State Legislature and signed into law by Governor Rockefeller granted what the chiropractors call insurance equality. Henceforward, they will be on a par with physicians, dentists and other health professionals with respect to reimbursement by health insurance firms for services provided patients.

title: Ch. AGoGo, a Doberman Pinscher, Is Judged Best in Show at Riverhead
JERSEY RAIL PLAN STIRS SKEPTICISM
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., July 17Railroad workers moving freight trains along the miles of track at the Jersey Central Railroad yards expressed skepticism yesterday on a new labor management agreement designed to save the rail line from a shutdown.

title: Indian Harbor Skippers Take Luders16 Match
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 17 The Indian Harbor Y. C. Luders16 skippers defeated helmsmen from the Centerport Y. C., 13 to 22, under the lowpoint system, off Indian Harbor Y. C. today in their annual interfleet team match for the Firefly Trophy.

title: Miss'Clarissa Whitney Is Wed On Cape to G. Richard Biehl
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., July 17Miss Clarissa Whitney, daughter of Mr.. and Mrs. Henry Dwight Whitney of New York, was married here this afternoon to G. Richard Biehl, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Biehl of Longport, N. J.

title: 4.5% IN G.I. TEST ARE HEROIN USERS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 17Tests of 22,000 American servicemen leaving Vietnam showed that 4.5 per cent of them had been using heroin, President Nixon's special assistant on drugs reported today.

title: Nobody could be more surprised than Stuttgarters that along with beer and MercedesBenz they are now exporting ballet.
description: OF all the images evoked by John Cranko and his Stuttgart Ballet Company, images of belligerence and impudence, of Attila, Genghis Mum, or hordes of Visigoths sweeping down on Rome, the most appealing is piratical. Partly it's because the company crossed the sea, more for glory than for conquest, armed with audacity and derringdo. Also, Cranko himself is a kind of cross between Francis Drake and Henry Morgan, his revolutionary, lawless ballets fly the Jolly Roger, and his dancers disport themselves like swashbuckling buccaneers. Surprise is their weapon. Who ever heard of a German ballet company, much less one from Stuttgart? That's a large provincial town which combines the liveliness of Des Moines with the beauty of downtown Detroit. They make beer and MercedesBenz in Stuttgart. What kind of a name is that for a nice joyous ballet company?

description: TO THE EDITOR:

description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Thompson Dies on Coast; Actor on Fibber McGee Show
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17 (AP) William Thompson, a longtime radio actor who had appeared on the Fibber McGee and Molly Show, died Thursday at the age of 58.

title: VIETCONG INSIST PEACE CAN COME AT TALKS IN PARIS
description: PARIS, July 17A spokesman for the Vietcong delegation declared here today that the Paris peace talks still offered the best means of settling the Vietnamese war.

title: Twenty Years After
description: After more than two decades of tense confrontation and hostility, the governments of the United States and the Chinese Peoples Republic have decided to make a new start toward rebuilding the normal and good relations that had historically existed between the two peoples but that were destroyed by the Communist conquest of China in the late forties and by the Korean war a few years later. That, most simply, is the meaning Chou Enlai's invitation to President Nixon to visit Peking, and of the President's rapid acceptance.

description: DETROIT, July 17  Just a year ago the United Automobile Workers was the richest union in the nation with $120million in its strike fund.

title: Dance; What's New? Classic Ballets
description: THE other day, at a lecture engagement; a not exactly little girl looked at me accusingly and said: I kinda thought, you'd be a little older  for you've been on The Times all my life!". Wow! Well, yes, but, in fact, it has been only six years. It seems more to me sometimes, but it isn't. At least, I think it isn't. Mind you, there are moments when I think I have been on The Times for all of my life as well.

title: Letters:
description: I was originally introduced through the real estate section to the New York City surplus realty sales auctions and have secured several nice properties as a result.

title: Knights of Pythias to Aid Addict Center in Queens
description: The Knights of Pythias has begun a fund raising drive among its membership to furnish a new reentry center for drug addicts about to open in Richmond Hill, Queens.

title: Nassau Blacks Demand Summer Aid
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 17Three hundred black youths appeared at the Nassau County Board of Supervisors meeting this week and angrily demanded county funds for a summer recreation program.

title: Art
description: IT is difficult to generalize about the work of the 47yearold British sculptor, Anthony Caro, on view here in a striking exhibition at the David Mirvish Gallery, 596 Markham Street. Each of Caro's sculpturesseven recent works comprise the present showgives the impression of having set up anew the terms of its own sculptural discourse, its own rules of the games, so to speak, without necessarily resorting to prior stylistic developments. One has the feeling that in each of Caro's pieces, the sculptor has so successfully worked through the particular set of formal challenges and possibilities involved that he feels no need to repeat the effort. It is this ability to remain free of formal conventionseven those which the artist has established for himselfthat makes Caro one of the most impressive of living sculptors.

title: Rome Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH concrete patios, walks, stoops and other outdoor paved areas actually do not require painting, many people still prefer to apply a finish of some kind because they want a change of color, or because they find that a coat of paint makes the surface easier to keep clean. However, a longlasting finish that will also give the hopedfor results can only be achieved if the homeowner selects the right kind of paint for his purposes  and if he makes certain that preparation and application instructions are carefully followed.

title: We See, We Hear, But Don't Believe
description: THERE on the stage are two actresses who can do it, one of them a brilliant performer, the other exceptionally fine  and they don't. We tug at them, we silently beg them, we all but command them to open out to us, we nearly exhaust ourselves in our determination that they shall burst into flame. We can't make them make the fire come, not all of it, not enough of it. Why?

description: WASHINGTON, July 17A leading spokesman for the coal industry said this week that the nation's bituminous coalfields faced the prospect of a major, and perhaps chaotic, strike this fall.

title: About Baseball
description: Before Alex Johnson was suspended by the California Angels, Manager Lefty Phillips benched him several times for not hustling. The Angels, however, can't say Johnson didn't warn them.

title: OPTIMISM VOICED ON ENERGY NEEDS
description: BUCHAREST, July 17Some 1,900 energy specialists from all over the world, meeting recently in Bucharest at the World Energy Conference to discuss the optimum use of energy, showed themselves undismayed, by the threat of an energy gap, which has been much discussed in the West in the last two years.

title: Massachusetts Lawyers Losing Business Under NoFault Law
description: BOSTON, July 17Massachusetts lawyers are feeling the effects of the states nofault automobile insurance law, the first of its kind in the country.

title: BAKERY PIONEERS POLLUTION CURBS
description: MELVILLE, L. I, July 17A watertreatment unit built part of a new baking facility here may prove to be the forerunner of similar antipollution efforts by big bakeries throughout the country.

title: EAST VILLAGER HELD IN 747 BOMB THREAT
description: An East Village man who allegedly telephoned threats to bomb an Irish airliner en route to Ireland unless he received $50,000 was arrested early yesterday as he received the payoff, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Reader's Report
description: What would you do it you found a peculiar young man living in the crawlspace of your basement, dining off uncooked rodents like some carnival geek, and slouching nocturnally about the premises? Call the police? Not Albert and Alice Graves, a pair of old dears who have retired after Albert's second coronary. The Graveses try to adopt the lad, unofficially speaking, in place of the child they've never had, and thereby they bring on an exotic mingling of joys and sorrows and Albert's third cardiac arrest. This is no unvarnished spine chiller  although the action hovers continually on the brink of hysteria. Homogenized with the scary stuff are some, nicely posed questions of guilt and responsibility. First it is Alice who wants to take the youth in, and Albert who is turned off by his animalist lifestyle. Then it is Albert who grows fond of their charge, and Alice who is repelled. As for the wild lodger himselfhe develops a loyalty to his hosts that leads them all to a terminal paradox. A gothic tale this, with a reader's choice of moral conclusions.

title: Language as a tool to move things; Archaeologist of Morning; By Charles Olson. Unpaged. London: Cape Goliard Press. fa association with. Grossman Publishers. $12.95.
description: It it good to have the collected Charles Olson in hand. Cape Goliard of London, publishers of the most magnificent books of poetry in English today, have given us in Archaeologist of Morning all the poems Olson published in his lifetime, apart from the Maximus sequence. The earliest of the poems (1946) are culled from established magazines like Harper's and Atlantic, the later ones from subterranean publications such as Matter and Magazine of Further Studies. Undoubtedly many poems exist in manuscript that have yet to appear, so this collection is incomplete against the larger effort of his lifetime; nonetheless, we are grateful for it. It is a beautiful and impressive tribute to Olson, a year after his death 59.To view the collected poems as this volume forces us to do is to get a confused sense of subjectThere are poems, that weave classical images through contemporary instances; that create Piero di Cosimo effects, luxurious yet deft. Poems that burst upon the tide of an established myth and seem to vivify it, as the beautiful ode to Aphrodite, The Ring Of. Poems written in the heat of Olson's dig among the Maya, unfolding his theories of body (and eye), against his enmity for modem civilization, and its usury of spirit. Poems that try to place everything in a happy parataxis of Sumerian drift, that root out beginnings to beginnings, prelogic, preliminary. Broadsides directed to The Gloucester Times against the dismantling of old houses to make way for the plastic and the new. Poems on what America was, meant, like his West

title: Army Developed Vaccine
description: HOUSTON, July 17The vaccine being used to inoculate horses as a protection against the illness was developed by the United States Army. It is manufactured by a division of the RichardsonMerrell Corporation of Philadelphia.

title: Mrs. King Takes Final
description: HOYLAKE, England, July 17 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach Calif., won the North of England tennis title today by defeating Rosemary Casals of San Francisco, 63, 63, in a match marred by poor play by both women.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: There was a place for style in everything
description: Early in his beautiful and evocative memoir of Gerald and Sara Murphy, Calvin Tomkins points out that, as every college English major knows, the trouble with Tender Is the Night is that Scott Fitzgerald started by modeling Dick and Nicole Diver on the Murphys and ended by modeling them on himself and Zelda. Thus it is that the charming and imperturbable Gerald Murphy, a master of the art of living, turns into a selfdestructive drunk and his beautiful, wise wife into a schizophrenic. It is a happy thing to have the Tomkins book and to know that the real life ending was a better one, that the Murphys, perfectly happy in their marriage, were separated only by death and that their philosophy of civilized epicureanism was strong enough to survive the fearful blows that life had in store for them. They couldn't have ended as the Dick Divers did.

title: SAMUEL HURWITZ, A HISTORIAN, 57
description: Dr. Samuel J. Hurwitz, who retired as professor of history at Brooklyn College last January to become visiting professor of history at San Diego (Calif.) State College, died Thursday of a heart attack in San Diego. He was 57 years old.

title: Wynn's 30 PopUp Draws $100 Fine And Angry Words
description: HOUSTON, July 17  Two glaring mental blunders were the features of last night's game at the Astrodome, in which the Houston Astros defeated the New York Mets, 9.4, but it was the one made by the winning side that caused the fuss.

title: Rabbi Assails Jewish Congress On Fighting PrivateSchool Aid
description: A leading Orthodox rabbi yesterday was sharply critical of the American Jewish Congress for allegedly using Jewish communal funds to combat government aid to secular programs in religious schools.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: But Critics Should Remember Operating ConstraintsAt a dinner of a group who know the financial community well, the question was raised: Can a commercial bank afford to respond to the escalating demands for more socially responsible behavior within our present, profitoriented market system?

title: Fragrant Greetings
description: Cards that can be made to smell like wine, a pine forest, menthol, whisky, flowers or even a rotten egg, are among the latest developments in the rapidly changing greetingcards business.

title: The Last Word: Should Science Be Shot?
description: Things being what they are, which is not what most of would wish them to be, one can't walk down the streets of the mind these days without getting mugged by a Single Cause. The Single Cause usually has an accomplice, the Single Cure. Original Sin, sexism, anality, atavistic aggressive impulses, the school and/or economic system, the death of God, Vietnam, Dostoyevsky, Chairman Mao and Mayor Lindsay are among the Single Causes. Marijuana, Sesame Street, R. D. Laing, water beds, tactical nuclear weapons, Aesthetic Realism, the Living Theatre, the polymorphous perverse, Esalen and Jane Fonda are among the Single Cures.

title: Letters to the Editor

title: HIGHBRIDGE GETS A FEDERAL GRANT
description: A Federal program, little used in the four years it has been available to the city, has granted $818,814 for an effort to stave off further deterioration and abandonment of housing in the Highbridge section of the Bronx.

description: An upstate planning agency has asked the Federal Power Commission to stop a halfcompleted millionkilowatt hydroelectric project on grounds of alleged misrepresentations and Federal license violations by the Power Authority of the State of New York.

description: Ma George, chief engineer of the State Power Authority, has been appointed as general manager of the agency, succeeding William S. Chapin, 67 years old, who is retiring Aug. 1.

description: A bipartisan group of Congressmen, led by John Brademas, Indiana Democrat, and Ogden Reid, New York Republican, has sponsored an important bill which would offer 6preschool care and education to all children at least from the age of two.

title: About Motor Sports
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., July 17Don (Big Daddy) Garlits, who is 39 years old; is one of the pioneers of drag racing; Don (The Snake) Prudhomme, 30, grew up when the sport was already well established. Garlits is gregarious and he likes chatting with fans in the pits, the area where drivers and mechanics work on their cars; Prudhomme is reserved, and he would rather concentrate on his work, preparing his cars. Garlits and Prudhomme respect each other's talent, but they are not chummy. What they have in common is their success: They are the only two men who have ever won national championships three times.

title: Junior Scientists Learn in L. I.Laboratory
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., July 17  Children in shorts and bathing suits, carrying nets, binoculars and jars, are studying nature on the pastoral grounds of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory of Quantitative Biology here.

title: Announcements
PATTERSON DEFEATS POLITE IN 10 ROUNDS
description: ERIE, Pa., July 17 (UPI)Floyd Patterson, the former world heavyweight champion, beat Charley Polite by a decision in 10 rounds tonight before 2,500 fans at the Erie Arena.

title: Music
Music
description: SUMMER festivals have become a way of life in the United States and new ones are being added every year. The latest is named Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts. In one respect it is very similar to the other ambitious American summer festivalsa shed, a pastoral atmosphere, a summerlong mixed program (ballet, jazz and opera in addition to symphonic music), a school, a student resident orchestra, various visiting ensembles. But in another respect it is different. For it is an alliance of Government and private enterprise, and that sets it off a bit.

description: The tough air pollution code passed last week by the City Council faces enforcement problems because of a shortage of inspectors.

title: RomeVienna Pact Puts Border Issues Up to World Court
description: ROME, July 17Italy and Austria signed a treaty here today under which future disagreements over the predominantly Germanspeaking Italian region of Alto Adige (South Tyrol) will be referred to the International Court of Justice at the Hague.

title: Stamps
description: Britain's 1971 Literary Anniversary series will recall the bicentenary of the birth of Sir Walter Scott (17711832), the bicentenary of the death of Thomas Gray (17161771), and the sesquicentennial anniversary of the death of John Keats (17951821). All three were poets and Sir Walter was also a novelist, historian and biographer. The stamps will be issued July 28.UNLISTED in the American Scott and Minkus catalogues, as well as Britain's Gibbons catalogue, are socalled stamps of the State of Oman. There is no such state. Labels of this State of Oman appeared in 1967 and this columnist was gulled into publishing data on the first issue, a toohasty desire to inform readers that this ancient land, whose postal facilities had been under the British raj (via India, originally) for many years, had taken over its own post office operations. This had been true of other Persian Gulf states during the late nineteen sixties.

title: President of Villanova U. Since 1967 Resigns Post
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., July 17 (UPI)The Rev. Robert J. Welsh has stepped down as president of Villanova University.

title: Expos Top Gibson
James H. Kitler Plans to Marry Marilyn Sherman Next Month

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEAnnouncement of President Nixon's eventual Chinese visit dramatically underlines the extent to which the United States is now reexamining Far Eastern policy. The current reappraisal began this summer with signature of an accord returning Okinawa to Japan, the steady decline in tensions between Washington and Peking, and a series of visits to the Orient by leading American officials, including Secretary Laird, Vice President Agnew and Mr. Kissinger.

title: Summer Jobs: the Outs Displace the Ins
description: Nepotism is down and even tlut in the dismal summer job scene. Costcutting and retrenchment have abolished at least for this yearmany of the jobs traditionally allotted by major companies to sons and daughters of employes, customers and of the chairman's fellow clubcar commuters.

title: U.S. Open Tennis Tickets Going on Sale Tomorrow
description: Tickets go on sale tomorrow at Madison Square Garden at 10 A.M. for the United States Open tennis championships Sept. 1 to 12 at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Reader's Report
description: Herman Raucher's second novel, following Summer of 42, is an entertaining if featherweight trifle about a couple of selfmade gypsies larricking through New York. Luther is a rich, derelict kid dedicated to the perpetual puton. Tiger, a gamine from the Midwest, is Luther's accomplice and thrall. Together they panhandle in the subway, crash a U.J.A. banquet, gorge on demonstration samples of food products and embark on one mad caper after another. But while Luther is really crazy, Tiger is only acting in sympathetic vibration and she eventually tries to leave her great imposter for reality and a room at the Y. If you liked Love Story, you might dab away a tear this

title: Music Mailbag.
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: ELLIS POSTS 15TH IN PIRATE VICTORY
ROYALS TRIUMPH OVER INDIANS, 72
Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Penn State vs. NavyAgain
description: Pennsylvania State's football game at the United States Naval Academy on Sept. 18 marks the fifth straight year that the Lions have opened their season against the Middies. Navy will be the first opponent in 1972, but the Lions will open their 1973 schedule at Stanford.

title: Fischer and Larsen Plan To Resume Match Today
description: DENVER, July 17Bobby Fischer of the United States and Bent Larsen of Denmark will resume their chess match at 4 P.M. tomorrow at Temple Buell College here.

title: L.i. Library Head Named
description: ROOSEVELT, L.I., July 17Donald Freshley has been appointed director of the Roosevelt Public Library. Mr. Freshley, a professional librariart for five years, succeeds Mrs. Elizabeth Settanni who is retiring.

title: Sterilization Ban Disputed
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 17 (AP)Four of South Bend's 15 obstetricians have resigned from the St. Joseph's Hospital staff over the last three weeks because of the Roman Catholic institution's policy against voluntary sterilization of women. Dr. Norman Forrest, Dr. George Goderski, Dr, M. C. Sharp and Dr. J. Leonard Lamb urged that the obstetrics department be taken out of the hospital.

title: Launches Needed for Island Tour
description: Wanted!motor yachtsmen willing to help Southampton College of Long Island University conduct its annual series of tours of Gardiners Island for the benefit of the Scholarship Trust Fund.

title: The Black Image In the White Mind
description: A survey of white American racial ideology during the 19th and early 20th century, tracing the circuitous, often contradictory, justifications of racism by Negrophobes and holders of the subtler forms of antiblack sentiment found in the paternalistic, liberal theories of abolutionists and Negrophiles. Detailed and sometimes ponderous, but revealing of the rationalizations and the pseudoscience that shaped America's present biracial society. Frederickson concludes that America's race problem is insoluble and certain to lead to disaster unless today's Utopia can be tomorrow's society. The thesislike presentation doesn't help the argument.

title: Ox Ridge Hosts Farmington
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 17The Ox Ridge Hunt Club's polo team will play Farmington tomorrow in its final tuneup for the national eightgoal intracircut championship.

title: ASTROS DEFEAT METS, 21;
Bullfights Canceled.
description: SEVILLE, Spain, July 17 (UPI)Tomorrow's bullfights in Spain's most famous arena have been canceled because of expected competition of a live telecast from Rio de Janeiro featuring Pelt, Brazil's soccer king.

title: Rubella Shots to Be Given
description: LAKE GROVE, L.I., July 17Children between the ages of 1 and 12 can receive free rubella and measles vaccine Wednesday from 1 to 5 p.m. at Smith Haven Ministries in the Smith Haven Mall. The vaccine will he made available through the Suffolk County Health Department.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: The feeling of unreality that always pervades one when listening to the proceedings in the South African Parliament is stronger than ever this session.

title: YANKS BEAT WHITE SOX, 42;
If Odds Are With You, You Could Get Even
description: HINSDALE, N. H., July 17 (UPI)Hinsdale Raceway will inaugurate Sunday afternoon racing begining tomorrow and offer a parimutuel bet system said to be the first of its kind in the United States.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: William Rieder Weds Miss Susan M. Dughi
description: BAY HEAD, J., July 17. Miss Susan Maybelle Dughi, daughter of Mrs. Louis J. Dughi. of Westfield and Mantoloking and the late, Mr. Dughi, was married here this afternoon to William Thomas Rieder, son of. Mrs. William Dustin Rieder of Miami, and the late Mr. Rieder. Msgr. James S. Foley performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church here.

title: Television
description: IN one of comedian Bill Dana's sketches, his alter ego Jose Jinienez portrays an astronaut just returned to earth. Asked what he did out there during the long hours in space, he replied, I cried a lot.

title: INSULTING
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: L. I. Sewage Plants Held Threat to Water
description: A leading national environmental organization has charged that the Federal Government's policy on new sewagetreatment plants is posing a serious threat of contamination to Long Island's water supply.

title: Minorities Demand Job Training At 2 Building Sites in Brooklyn
description: A coalition of Hasidic Jews, Puerto Ricans and blacks from the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn has asked that construction at the new Woodhull Hospital and at the LindsayBushwick Vest Pocket Housing Project be halted until minority members of the community are enlisted in construction and job training on the sites.

title: 167 BOATS BEGIN MACKINAC RACE
description: CHICAGO, July 17 (AP)With the summer sun shining, 157 yachts set sail today from Chicago's Lakefront on the 333mile ChicagotoMackinac Island Yacht Race.

title: WHEELCHAIR GAMES OPENED IN JAMAICA
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 17 (UPI)  Sir Clifford Campbell, Governor General of Jamaica, officially opened the third PanAmerican wheelchair games to night at the National Arena. A total of 187 competitors from nine countries are entered.

title: Lunokhod Ready for Night
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (UPI)The Soviet Union's Lunokhod moon robot completed today its ninth lunar day and prepared for the cold of a twoweek lunar night, the press agency Tass said. Tass said that Lunokhod traveled a distance of 220 yards during its two weeks of work,

title: Two Yachts Share Lead In Narrasketuck Sailing
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., July 17Steve Baldwin, in Firewater, and Jim Grover, in Sit n Bull, both of the Babylon Yacht Club, exchanged first and second places today to tie for the lead in the Narrasketuck OneDesign Class national championships. A southwesterly prevailed through both races. The series concludes tomorrow with one more event.

title: RED TIDE PLAGUES TAMPA BAY AREA
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 17 Severe outbreaks of the socalled red tide, a neurotoxin in sea water that kills fish and other marine life, plagued St. Petersburg, Tampa and the Gulf of Mexico beaches on Sanibel, Captiva and Estero Islands, west of Fort Myers, this week.

title: Bill Would Cut Legislature
description: BOSTON. July 17 (AP)The Massachusetts Legislature has approved a constitutional amendment proposing a onethird cut, from 240 to 160 members, of the House of Representatives. The amendment must also be approved by the 1971.72 session of the Legislature, by the 197374 session and by the electorate.

title: World Lifting Mark Set
description: MOSCOW, July 17 (AP)Gcnnady Chetin of Penn in the Urals set a world weightlifting record today in the flyweight division when he hoisted 825 pounds, 264 in the press, 242 in the jerk and 319 in the snatch.

title: Education
description: It is testimony to somethingworthiness or the sheer staying power of tradition or influential political and educational alliesthat the Board of Examiners of the New York City school system has survived as the local licensing agency for 55,000 teachers and 4,000 supervisors.

title: Think Rhinoceros,
description: ALBANYWho needs a rhinoceros? Well, who needs a forest, a sand dune, a farmor a farmer, a garbage collector or an Eskimo? Unless you take your Adam and Eve straight, you cannot believe that man came into a lonely world. Nor without those species that preceded them would mankind ever have happened. Earth has always been for sharing.

title: Vatican, St. Patrick's...And the Little Brown Church
description: NASHUA, Iowa  Yes, there really is a Little Brown Church in the Vale. And true to its name, it is little (capacity: 125), brown (it was painted that way when it was built 107 years ago because brown paint was the cheapest), and situated in a vale of pine trees in picturesque, rural setting two miles northeast of here.

title: If we can't abide poverty and won't abolish it, at least we can destroy the poor
description: It is a characteristic paradox of our time that the word welfare has come to mean almost precisely its opposite. No Big Brother, no Ministry of Truth, presided over this linguistic transmutation of gold into lead. Yet this benign term, defined by my dictionary as a condition of health, happiness, and prosperity, immediately summons images of misery. humiliation and waste. The three books considered here go far in explaining why.

title: Patricia S. London Plans a Fall Wedding
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L. I., July 17Miss Patricia Sue London and James Nahum Fingeroth plan to be married Nov. 7. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton London.

title: Gardiner Manor: Bucolic Suffolk Oasis
description: WEST ISLIP, L. I., July 17A rickety wooden gate chained with a rusty padlock guards a narrow, overgrown trail near Montauk Highway here, where cars speed past dc. 50 mileg an hour.

title: Child to the Schusters
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. David I. Schuster at Mount Sinai Hospital here June 20. The child, named Amanda, is a granddaughter of Dr. Nina R. Lief and Dr. Victor F. Lief of New York, who are on the psychiatric staff of New York Medical College. She is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schuster of Cedarhurst, L.I. The child's mother, professionally known as Dr. Carlotta Lief Schuster, is an instructor in psychiatry at New York Medical College and assistant attending physician at Metropolitan Hospital. Her father is professor of chemistry and associate departmental chairman at New York University.

title: POLLS FIND PUBLIC DOUBTS KENNEDY
Pele Gains a Goal: End of World Play
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 17Pele, the magic Brazilian forward generally considered to be the world's best soccer player, has begun the slow change that will make him Edson Arantes do Nascimento, the rich young Brazilian businessman, pleasant hunting and fishing companion, and devoted husband and father of two children.

title: Clytemnestra Is Victor
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., July 17 (AP)  Clytemnestra won the $2,300 feature race at Finger Lakes Race Track today. The 5yearold bay mare covered the 5 furlongs in 1:07 and returned $26.00, $8.60 end $6.00.

title: Days in the Gardens of Hollywood
description: A visitor comes out to see me in Californiaa colleague, a writer. We have never met; there's only been correspondence, an introduction of one sort or another. He is a man smiling, eager, modesta man very much like myself, to look at us both now as we greet each other.

title: Red Sox Take Two
The Annual Hay Fever Hegira Escaping the King of Allergies
description: THERE are so many hay fever victims in the United States  13 million, according to the Allergy Foundation of Americawho would just as soon be somewhere else come midAugust that not long ago a wellknown allergist conceived the idea of organizing a cruise exclusively for the relief of the afflicted.

title: BEAME PROPOSES CITYSTATE PANEL
description: The city commission that is investigating the state and the state commission that is investigating the city should collaborate to help end constant fiscal bickering between the two governments, Controller Abraham D. Beanie said yesterday.

title: Jules Feiffer Can't Cut It; A CON?
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: McCloskey Won't Change Plans Despite Nixon Trip
description: HANOVER, N.H., July 17 (AP)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr., California Republican, said today that President Nixon's proposed trip to China would not affect the Congressman's decision to seek the Republican Presidential nominatiin in 1972. This trip does not change the issues, he said.

title: GERALD L. MORAN
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N. J., July 17Gerald L. Moran, a senior vice president of GTE Sylvania, Inc., in charge of its precision materials group, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 52 Rieman Road. He was 49 years old.

title: Essence of Midsummer
description: The milkweeds come to blossom, and in their fragrance is the very essence of midsummer, a sweetness that scents the roadside but will be gone in the slow turn of time before August has settled on the land. A special sweetness, reminding one of both honeysuckle and tuberose, without the spiced tang of fruit blossoms, without even the faint touch of wildness in the pasture rose. It is a pervasive fragrance, and bees and butterflies gather, knowing that it means a special store of nectar.

title: Robert Siegfried Fiance of Leslie Maddin
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17 Dr. and Mrs. Robert Maddin of Philadelphia and Mashpee, Mass., have anriounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Jeanne Maddin, to Robert Dick Siegfried, son of Mr. and Mrs, Bernard Siegfried of New York and Patchogue, L.I. The wedding is planned for Sept. 26.

title: 35er Netmen to Play Obbligato to U.S. Open
description: A grasscourt tennis tournament for men 35 years and over will be held at the West Side Club in Forest Hills, Queens, during the United States Open championships beginning Sept. 1.

title: SOUTH VIETNAM BARS 400 FROM HOUSE RACE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 17About 400 candidates for South Vietnam's assembly were disqualified today by local committes. The elections are to be held Aug. 29.

title: Earl McNeeley Dies at 73; Hero of 1924 World Series
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 17 (UPI)Earl McNeely, hero of the 1924 World Series for the Washington Senators, died yesterday at a hospital following a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Sihanouk Hails New Policy
description: PEKING, July 17 (Agence FrancePresse)Prince Norodom Sihanouk, who from Peking leads the Cambodian resistance against the regime of Gen. Lon Nol, said today that he was pleased with the new look of ChineseAmerican policy.

title: Songs to sing beyond mankind
description: Paul Celan wrote in German, came of Austrian Jews from Cernowitz, Bucovina (now a part of Rumania), survived Nazi occupation and labor camp, lived from 1947 on in Paris where he died a suicide last summer at 50, and could not even be said properly to belong, as poets do, in the world of their own poetic language. Probably the major poet in German since World. War II, Celan developed, from some of the linguistic improvisations of Rainer Maria Rilke's later poems, partly perhaps under the influence of French poets like Paul Maud, less obviously from the imaginative world of Georg Trakl, a remarkable and difficult expressive mode. His later poetry is not so much an elaboration of terror or negation, but of the possibilities of vision their residues.

title: Bridge
description: FIVE aces are too many for a deck, but may not be quite enough for a team. The World Champion Aces will be attempting to win the Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Chicago this week with one Ace less than their usual complement.

title: Knell for Irish Bars EchoesinBrooklyn
description: The Irishman Mark Twain wrote about in Life on the Mississippi would have liked the bars of Brooklyn. The beer Is cold and unwatered and the variety available on tap is something to marvel at. But whisky! Rye and Irish and Scotch and Canadian are dispensed in smallwater glasses, and several would more than save a man.

title: Lichardus Cards 72 and Beats Benning by 6 Shots in Jersey Open Playoff
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 17Milton (Babe) Lichardus, who, learned his golf as a caddie in the state, became today the first player to win the New Jersey open title four times.

title: Chess
Russians See ATest Site
description: MERCURY, Nev., July 17 (AP)Seven Soviet scientists toured the Nevada nuclear test site today, the first inspection ever by Russian scientists of the site where most American nuclear testing is conducted.

title: The World
Twins Top Senators, 53
LETTERS
