title: Petition Lists Locations Of New Sewage Plants
description: The new sewage treatment plantssome in the plarming stage, and some under construction, and some completed  referred to in the fund's petition are:

title: Coins
description: MOST Americans go about their daily business without giving much, thought to the 20thcentury problems of the dollar, except to express some concern about the shrinkage in its purchasing power, but this monetary unit has had troubles before almost since the time the first settlers arrived on these shores.

title: House, ahoy!
description: Living in this house far out on the northern fork of Long Island is the next best thing to being at sea. The file Wacses chose the site for its privacy and for the rugged cliffs rising from the water's edge. To capitalize on the splendid setting, architect Claude Samton placed the house just 40 feet from the hightide line and rimmed it with decks 50 feet above the water. From inside and out, the sea stretches away to distant horizons. The design is straightforward with a gambrel roof that resembles an inverted ship's hull. The walls and ceilings are cedar planking; the exterior is covered with cedar shakes. The floors are white vinyl. The decks on three sides of the house double the living space and provide an easytosupervise play area for the children.

title: Teaching the Poor How to Eat Better
description: On a garbagestrewn street in the Crotona Park section of the South Bronx, Maria Burgos stopped a young girl who was carrying a child in her arms.

title: SCHENKENS AHEAD IN BRIDGE CONTEST
Discovery of New Star By Japanese Confirmed
description: TOKYO, July 17 (AP)The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory of Cambridge, Mass., has confirmed a Japanese amateur astronomer's assertion that he has discovered a new star and named it Cepheus Nova 1971, Japanese scientists reported Tuesday.

title: Donohue Leading from Start, Takes TransAmerican Race at Elkhart Lake
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 17 (UPI)Mark Donohue started his bid today for his second doublevictory weekend in a month by leading from start to finish in the 200mile Road American Trans American series race for sedans.

title: A NeoNazi Group Stages 3Hour Rally in Yorkville
description: A dozen members of the neoNazi National Renaissance party held a threehour rally in Yorkville last night. They ended a series of speeches at about 9 P.M. and dispersed without incident.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: BRADFORD WARNER, WARNACO DIRECTOR
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 17 Bradford N. Warner, director of corporation, community and employe relations for Warnaco, Inc., manufacturers of lingerie and dress apparel, died last night at Bridgeport Hospital. He was 47 years old.

title: Women Open Political Series
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17 (UPI) The National Organization for Women held the first in a series of workshops on women's role in politics here today. According to Joan Bell, who describes herself as the membership chairperson, the purpose of the series is to train women to become political candidates and to work effectively in support of political candidates.

title: F.T.C. Opens a Queens Office To Hear Consumer Complaints
description: Bringing Government services to residential areas is the train aim of a new consumercomplaint station established by the Federal Trade Commission last week in the Queens County Courthouse.

title: French Council Declares Law Curbing Groups Unconstitutional
description: PARIS, July 17France's Constitutional Council has declared unconstitutional a recent law placing restrictions on the right of free association.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: TILE ADMINISTRATION'S effort to have Lockheed from bankruptcy passed its first legislative hurdle when the Senate Banking Committee passed, 10 to 5, a revised bill authorizing a Government guarantee of a total $2billion in loanswith a limit of $250million for one companyto companies whose failure would adversely and seriously affect the economy of the nation... Rep. Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said later that he would vote for the Administration's kill if the committee decided action was vital before Aug. 6. He said that while he still opposed the loan guarantees he would go along if it was necessary to save the nation from another depression.

title: Miss Sage Dunlop Becomes Bride
description: ROXBURY, Conn., July 17 Miss Sage Dunlap, daughter of Mrs. Cortlandt Heyniger of Woodbury, and the late David R. Dunlap Jr. of Moblile, Ala., was married here this afternoon to Richard Hunt Chase Jr. of Bloomfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chase, formerly of Weston, Mass., and now of Boston.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gardens
description: HOSTAS are grown for attractive glaucous blue to grey foliage or variegated leaves and their sturdy spikes of white, blue or lavender flowers. I appreciate hostas most when they furnish colorful foliage and bloom in shade, where other flowering plants don't thrive. Fleshy roots and water storing underground stems enable hostas to resist drought although they thrive with even moisture.

title: Robert Andrew Raggio to Wed Miss Alice Roberta McAdams
description: The engagement ofMiss Alice Roberta McAdams to Robert Andre,w Raggio has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Waiter J. McAdams Jr. of New York and Pawling, N.Y., parents of the bridetobe. Her, fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Reggio of Pittsburgh.

title: Pele's Farewell Slated For ClosedCircuit TV
description: Peld's last game with the Brazilian national soccer team will be shown live on closedcircuit television today at eight theaters in the New York metropolitan area.

title: SALES OF MARIJUANA BRING 20YEAR TERM
description: WOODSFIELD, Ohio, July 17 James and Connie Eye, a young Woodsfield couple with a twoyearold child, were separated by the law last week for perhaps 20 to 40 years, as they began serving sentences for selling marijuana.

title: Henry King Jr. Weds Carol Mylod
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., July 17St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this morning for the marriage of Miss Carol Nylod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Mylod of Brooklyn, to Henry Brazell King. Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. King of Washington. Both families have summer homes in Spring Lake. The Rev. Francis A. Crine performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: The Nation
Theodore D'Erlanger, 81, Ballet Choreographer, Dies
description: PARIS, July 17Theodore D'Erlanger, the choreographer and ballet teacher, died here yesterday. Born in 1890 in Moscow, he came here as a refugee from the Russian Revolution.

title: Warren Pyles Weds Mrs. Diane Winter
description: ALTOONA, Pa., July 17Mrs. Diane Winter, former longtime personal secretary to Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy and the late. Mr. Kennedy, was married here this afternoon to Warren Pyles.

title: 4 ARAB COUNTRIES ASSAIL MOROCCO
description: CAIRO, July 17Ending a threeday meeting to discuss new rifts in Arab ranks, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, President Muammar elQaddafi of Libya and delegations from Syria and the Sudan tonight condemned what they termed repressions in Morocco since the uprising there a week ago.

title: Queens Coop Sells Organic Food
description: Customers may begin the week shopping for such macrobiotic goods as buckwheat noodles and corn flour and then end it as volunteer grocery clerks, labeling packages, ringing up sales and sweeping the floor.

title: IN THE NATION
description: MIAMIA major trouble with the Democratic Presidential candidates is that the only one who can easily be distinguished from the moderatetoliberal pack is the national defense hardliner, Henry Jackson of Washington. Fred Harris hopes the Populist style will make him another.

title: U.S. Loses in Volleyball
description: WARSAW, July 17 (AP)Poland defeated the United States, 31, in a volleyball match today in a fournation tournament. The scores were 159, 159, 815, 1715.

title: CRUDE
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The Dingle RacesA TwoDay Country Carnival in Ireland
description: DINGLE, Ireland  For the Aga Khan and similar sporting bloods, Ireland in August means the Royal Dublin Society's Horse Show. For me, it means me Dingle Races. Let the international horsey set parade in Phoenix Park in morning dress with beautiful girls in big hats and big names like Guinness. I'll join the crowd in Miss Casey's cow pasture in muddy boots and woolen caps with girls named O'Connor.

title: Princeton Alumni Elect Aide
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 17Mortimer H. Chute Jr., a 36yearold resident of Garden City, L. I., has been elected chairman of the Alumni Council of Princeton University. Mr. Chute will serve a twoyear term as the head of the University's 40,000member alumni association.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Martha Presbrey Honored at Dance
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 17 Miss Martha Rountree Presbrey Jr., debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver M. Presbrey of Washington, Upperville, Va., and Greenwich, Conn., and formerly of NeW Ybrk, was honored here tonight at a reception and dance.

title: Alma North Beats Forward Gal by Length to Take Cotillion at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 17 Forward Gal of the Aisco Stable, a star 3yearold filly, was upset today in the $55,800 Cotillion Handicap at Liberty Bell Race Track by the East Acres Alma North.

title: Stewart Captures British Grand Prix With Petersen 2d
description: SILVERSTONE, England, July 17 (UPI)Jackie Stewart of Scotland virtually ran away from the field today. to win the British Grand Prix in his TyrellFord and increase his lead in the world drivers championship.

title: Et Al.
description: Another eloquent footnote to the long history of man's inhumanity to manthe story of Michael Solomon, who spent 17 years in Russian and Rumanian concentration camps. As a journalist, he fled Rumania after the invasion of Poland; went to Palestine, where he joined the Free Rumania Committee; served four years with the British Army; then, after the war and against all advice, returned to Bucharest a confirmed proWesterner. There he had a good job and a pretty wife but was arrested by the police and turned over to the Russians, who sent him off to Magadan, a detention camp in easternmost Siberia. Through these pages live and die a great variety of people who suffered similar fateswealthy men, German generals, prostitutes, ballerinas. An ark of misery. Mr. Solomon now lives in Montreal.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: SPECIAL 10 Day Labor Day Cruise on the fun ship Homeric sails August 28 to four Caribbean ports. Rates $330.00. Home Lines 42 13'way. 4261515. See Our Ad in the Travel Section Page 31.Advt.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINeITONIf there is Nixon style in diplomacy, it has three dominant characteristics, all borrowed from the world of sports, of which he is an avid student.

title: Miami Beach Club Victor In Tackle Fishing Tourney
description: BERMUDA, July 17The Miami Beach Rod and Reel Club won the 11th annual Bermuda international light tackle fishing tournament today. William Mehrtens, James Lopez and Thomas Makay combined for 9,938 points for the victdrs. Lopez set a record for the competition with an 82pound, Allison tuna caught with 12pound tackle.

title: Pamela Lippe Becomes Bride Of Peter Buck
description: BRONXVILE, N.Y., July 17 Miss Pamela Towen Lippe. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Stuyvesant Lippe, and Peter Allan Buck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Buck of Latham, were married here this afternoon at Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Raymond T. Ferris, assisted by the Rev. Irving Pollard, retired minister of St. Bartholomew's Church in New York, who had married the bride's parents in 1947.

title: Eleanor Culbertson Affianced To Garett J. Albert, a Lawyer
description: KENT, Conn., July 17Mr. and Mrs. William H. Culbertson of Kent and Ocho Rios, Jamaica, W.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Lanier Culbertson, to Garett J. Albert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Don Albert of Union, N. J.

title: Giants Drop 8, Cutting Rookie Hopefuls to 31
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 17 (AP)  The New York Giants cut eight free agents today, reducing to 31 the number of rookies at the team's camp at C. W. Post College.

title: Letters:
description: In view of the article on Breezy Point [June 20] I thought readers would be interested in the following facts.

title: In Danang Area, Unemployment Is the Enemy Also
description: HOAKHANH, South VietnamIn the tiny cafe with its wooden tables and stools where men used to sit drinking Vietnamese beer in icefilled glasses, the owner grumbles that his customers have stopped coming.

title: Et Al.
description: A sympathetic report on the worldwide youth revolutions of the past 15 years by a qualified commentator. PalocziHorvath was a radical in his own youth, a Communist imprisoned for five years under the repressive Hungarian regime because of his beliefs about free speech. Now a teacher in the U. S., he has a jaundiced view of Communist regimes and insists that the youth of the world has become an important force for a new kind of altruistic rationalism. A useful survey.

title: The Nation
description: W. P. A. type fobs are not the answer... such a program represents a reversion to the remedies that were tried 35 years ago. Surely it is an inappropriate and ineffective response to the problems of the Seventies.

title: Adm. Winston Folk Weds Mrs. Guitar
description: OLD LYME, Conn., July 17 Mrs. Janet Atkins Guitar and Rear Adm. Winston Estes Pilcher Folk, U.S.N., retired of Nashville, were married here this afternoon at the First Congregational Church by the Rev. Dixon Hoag.

title: Colson, a State Champion, Is Princeton Tennis Captain
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 17William Colson, a 21yearold senior from Coral Gables, Fla., has been reelected captain of Princeton University's varsity tennis team for 197172.

title: NoNo Words Are Now YesYes
description: AT one point in Carnal Knowledge, the new Mike NicholsJules Feiffer comedy, Jack Nicholson, his face suddenly turning so red you think he's at the point of apoplexy, wheels around to scream at AnnMargret, who plays the mistress who wants to ruin everything by marrying him. At the peak of his tirade, he calls her a fourletter AngloSaxon word that he (poetic soul that he is) then attaches, with a hyphen, to bitch.

title: Music
description: ON approaching old age two ghosts must be abjured: disillusionment and bitterness. For the dreamer I once was, disillusionment is almost unavoidable. For the fighter I still am, the bitter taste of defeat, especially when defeat is considered unjust or treacherous, is apt to poison one's heart and sour one's smile.

title: Will They All Be Albees?

Perhaps the beginning of wisdom in this labyrinthian difficulty is to recognize that there is not one problem but many, and in the nature of things, problems that were so long in the making cannot have swift solutions and some may not have any at all.

Turnbaugh of Bainbridge Island, Wash.

The heaviest Saturday home schedule in the club's historya total of 20 games at the Gardencomprises almost half of the 41game home slate announced today.

title: Frustrated Middle Managers
description: Harry Traynor, 57, is an $18,000ayear department head at a large Eastern corporation. He has more than 20 men reporting to him, commutes to a comfortable downtown suite of offices, and in just three years will be eligible for a pension.

title: TIGERS WIN, 2 TO 1, FROM ATHLETICS; Northrup, Freehan Homers Back Coleman's Hurling
9 Dead as Cars Collide
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 17 (UPI)A station wagon with nine young persons heading for their homes in the Detroit area collided headon with a car traveling the wrong way on a freeway at 1:30 A.M. today, killing eight in the station wagon and the driver of the other auto.

title: Et Al.
description: According to the author, 500,000 American kids under 17 left home in 1969. This book is a sympathetic guide for them, discussing reasons for leaving, reasons for (and against) returning, legal rights, halfway houses, social agencies. The hardcore runaway probably won't read it, but his parents may.

title: 34,000 See Keino Score And liter Redeem Himself
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 17The rabbit ran too fast for Kipchoge Keino today, but Minis Ifter found the perfect pacer to rewrite one of the memorable chapters in inter national track and field. One day after embarrassingly misjudging the finish line in the 5,000meter run, the diminutive 24yearold Ifter saved his big kick for the last 440 yards in the 10,000meter run and outraced America's No. 1 long distance runner, Frank Shorter.

title: Jeweled Tiffany Glow Lingers on L.I.
description: LAUREL HOLLOW, L. I., July 17This small North Shore village with its huge estates and magnificent harbor view is, still much like it was 40 years ago when Louis Comfort Tiffany, the creator of the highly prized Tiffany glass and bronze, lived here in splendor.

title: N. Y. A. C. Four Scores in Youth Rowing
description: CAMDEN, N. J., July 17The New York Athletic Club quadruple sculls crew won the final event of the national youth rowing championship today and qualified for a trip to Yugoslavia. The Winged Foot oarsmen will make the journey provided the organizing committee of that country sanctions the event.

title: EDWIN C. WOLFERZ
description: ORANGE, N. J., July 17Edwin Charles Wolferz, president of the E. C. Wolferz Equipment Company of Belleville and Nutley, died Thursday in Orange Memorial Hospital, after a long illness. He lived at 377 South Harrison Street, East Orange.

description: SAN DIEGO, July 17 (AP)Manager Preston Gomez of the San Diego Padres will undergo a hernia operation Monday, the club said today. Bob Skinner, a coach, will remain in charge on the current road trip

title: Et Al.
description: The story of her 34 years with the Henry Street Settlement by the lady who was its guiding spirit. She writes about her experiences, from the day she came, a young woman, to a slum area in the midst of the depression to her retirement as director of the settlement in 1967. Her theory that to help the poor they must be given opportunities for creative endeavor and a sense of beauty is clearly and forcefully described.

title: Recordings
description: BOOK reviewers write of novels for light summer reading, apparently meaning works that are entertaining but not wholly devoid of intellectual stimulation. If the definition is just, then light summer listening would apply comparably to a twodisk album from Argo called The Wonder of the Age: Mister Edison's New Talking Phonograph. It is a documentary of the phonograph's history. It is told from the English point of view. American contributions to the invention and its development are not slighted, but the recording examples are English, the quotations and anecdotes from English periodicals and newspapers. For Americans this is a pleasant novlyn.

title: Movies
description: CAN you picture Barbra Streisand drudging out her days on Riverside Drive, huddled on a broken bench beside a grimy sandbox, pleading with the neighborhood bully not to throw sand in her toddler's hair? Barbra Streisand pushing a stroller, dodging litter and canine excrement? Barbra Streisand, a sometimes happy housewife who fantasizes about runaway escapades with Fidel Castro and black revolutionaries? Barbra Streisand daydreaming of blowing up the George Washington bridge?

title: Now Is the Time
description: A prologomena for Democratic Party reform. Fred Harris, Senator from Oklahoma and former Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, calls for a restoration of populist principles in the party. He rejects the Southern Strategy and the theories of Kelvin Phillips as unworkable and immoral and says that the Democratics can construct a majority on the Humphrey vote and the populist vote among Wallace supporters. He is also for reform of party instruments, per recommendations following the '68 convention. Unfortunately he deals infrequently with his experiences as party chairman.

title: Oil Companies Find Ecuador's LongSought Eldorado
description: QUITO, EcuadorThe elusive Eldorado that lured both the Incas and the Conquistadors to this poor land for centuries has at last been found. The wealth is vast deposits of highgrade petroleum situated in an oil trap along the eastern foot of the Andes.

description: SANTA ANA, Calif., July 17 A 29yearold doctor who admits having performed more than 2,000 illegal abortions has been released from jail here on his promise to stop practicing medicine while he challenges the constitutionality of California's therapeutic abortion law.

title: The Nation

That day's session of the talks, the 121st in three dreary years, had pretty well dispelled the hope that the July 1 initiative of the Vietcong would get some real negotiation going at last.

title: Photography
description: THE University of California at Santa Cruz is offering a twoweek workshop called Images and Words: The Making of a Photographic Book. To be held in Yosemite National Park from Aug. 8 to 21, the workshop will be led by Ansel Adams, Beaumont and Nancy Newhall, and Adrian Wilson. It is designed for photographers, editors, journalists and others interested in putting together photographic publications or projects, and participants will take photographs, prepare captions and make layouts. There is a $200 tuition fee and applications must be received by July 26. For information write University of California ExtenSanta Calif. 95060.

title: The most brilliant work by the most talented 20thcentury Marxist philosopher
description: Georg Lukacs's History and Class Consciousness is a truly extraordinary work, and its English translation, after almost fifty years of neglect by English and American publishers, is a major event. Indeed, its sheer eventfulness is so fraught with implication that exploring this might overshadow the intellectual content of the book itself. Certainly this long overdue translation tells us something about the ineffectual state of the translation industry and in particular about the American segment of it; for if the book is now available to Americans, it is primarily thanks to the initiative of its original translator, the British publisher.

title: No Sweetness Here
description: There's plenty of sweetness, and a touch of tartness too, in these short stories from Ghana. The title story deals with the bitterness of a divorce made tragic by the concurrent death of an only child from snakebite. Birth, marriage, divorce, work, deaththese universal themes are introduced in a context that gives them a fresh appearance. Some stories make social comment, like one in which a house servant complains that interior plumbing and the electric light are still reserved for the bosses. (My young Master, what does Independence mean?) In another, a brother goes in search of a runaway sister and finds her a prostitute. (Any kind of work is work.) Other stories depict manners and mores: particularly the clash of Western values with traditional folkways. Even at her gravest, Miss Aidoo writes with a sunny charm.

title: Florida Hospital Planned
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17 (UPI) General Health Services, Inc., said it would build a 55.5million, 172bed hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. It will be built near the $500million HaftGans luxury residential community now being developed.

title: Screen: 'Figures in a Landscape' Bows:Losey Work Appears at Festival Theater Robert Shaw, Malcolm McDowell Are Stars
description: Joseph Losey's "Figures in a Landscape" is a movie that intends to say more by going to rather great pains to reveal less.Mac (Robert Shaw), a rough, stupid, instinctive man, a sort of English hardhat, and Ansell (Malcolm McDowell), who is self-aware, sensitive and young enough to be Mac's son, are fugitives from an unidentified war, being pursued through a magnificently photogenic, unidentified landscape by an unidentified enemy, represented for most of the film, by a single helicopter, piloted by a man whose eyes are always goggled.Sometimes the helicopter just hangs over Mac and Ansell, as if waiting for them to kneel or to make some other gesture of supplication. At other times it comes down out of the sun to track them through an orchard, or to pin them to a hillside as it swoops and soars like a hawk preparing for a kill.Mac and Ansell, you realize very early in the film, are the complementary halves of a kind of contemporary Everyman, as much at war with each other as with their implacable pursuer, each absolutely dependent on the other, and, eventually, each as full of love for the other, as full of hate. That sort of realization has a tendency to make my heart sink, since it means that one is not going to be allowed to attend to the simple pleasures of vicarious adventure without also being forced to consider the film's aspirations as a metaphor.What Lossy and Robert Shaw (who, in addition to starring in the film, also adapted Barry England's novel) have attempted to do is to upgrade a genre movie by giving it an intellect. (You might also say they've attempted to downgrade a genre moviebut that depends on your point of view.) The result is decidedly mixed. The adventures are often stunningly realized, though they don't necessarily build in suspense, but run horizontally, as if filling in the time until the final, climactic confrontation, which, incidentally, says no more about Mac and Ansell than have any number of earlier sequences."Figures in a Landscape" is Losey's first film since his two-picture sabbatical as director-in-residence for the Richard Burtons ("Boom," "Secret Ceremony"), during which time it seemed as if his work was evolving into that of a stylish but gloomy interior decorator. With this film, it is apparent that Losey is back in charge of his own career, which is to say he is conceding nothing to the demands of big stars and big properties. He is, instead, pursuing his own metaphysical concerns, which, as in two of his best recent films, "The Servant" and "Accident," are so ambitious that one can admire the concerns even without responding to them.In this case, Losey's directorial talents are evident, though they never transform the Shaw screenplay with its Pinteresque dialogue, into an especially moving or meaningful experience. "No bloody order! No bloody discipline!," Mac rants at the young Ansell, as if they were a father and son in a London suburb and not fighting for their lives in an alien land. They argue about marriage but never mention where they are going."Why marry?," asks Ansell. "With the pill you can have anyone you likemodels, wives, secretaries, physiotherapists." There is a nice, irrelevant lunacy about this sort of exchange, and about the boy's concern that they eat a balanced diet, but, unlike Pinter at his best, these irrelevancies don't give the unspecified menace particular reality. They just distance it further, as the fancy drama it is.Although the figures in the landscape are rather blurred, the landscape itself is beautiful, and Losey builds his drama as much through it as through his two characters. They begin their flight by the sea and race through pastoral landscapes, deserts, canyons, swamps, until finally they meet their separate fates above the timber line, atop a mountain, on a field of summer snow. I liked both Shaw and McDowell, but my greatest admiration goes to Gilbert Chomat, the man who actually flew the helicopter in sequences that are terrifying in a completely comprehensible, nonmetaphysical way.

title: Yevtushenko Poem Garlands the Spirit of Armstrong
description: MOSCOW, July 18Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Soviet poet, today called on Gabriel to lend Louis Armstrong trumpet to cheer up the state of the angels.

title: Afghanistan, With U.S. Pressure, Makes Tourists the Targets of a Narcotics Crackdown
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan long considered haven for smokers of opium and hashish, has begun making life difficult for foreign tourists and campers on the supposition that most of them are narcotics users.

title: Bella Lewitzky, a Leading Coast Dancer, Comes East
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 18  To most in the East Coast dance world, Bella Lewitzky has been mainly name. But it has always been a name mentioned with great admiration, even veneration. Since the 1930's, at the beginning of her association with the late Lester Horton in California, Miss Lewitzky has enjoyed a reputation not only as one of the few prominent figures in modern dance on the West Coast, but also as one of the country's finest dancers.

title: Dill Wins Crown
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 18James Dill Jr. of Mattituck, L. I., was second to Tod Field of Manhasset today in the final race of the series, a performance good enough to earn him the Lightning Class district championship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Acheson Terms Kennedy Out of Depth as President
description: Dean Acheson said in an interview published yesterday that he thought that John F. Kennedy was out of his depth" in the Presidency.

title: Pope, Apparently Praising Nixon Move, SeesBig Event
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, July 18Pope Paul said here today that something big and new is being fulfilled and is preparing itself which may change in no small way the face of the earth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Agnew Is a Guest at Party Marking Franco's Uprising
description: MADRID, July 18  Vice President and Mrs. Agnew were guests of Generalissimo Francisco Franco today at Spain's National Day celebrations in the garden of a palace near Madrid.

title: Bordwell Takes Laurels
description: NORTHPORT, L. I., July 18 Paul Bordwell of the Northport Yacht Club today won the Flying Dutchman Class regional qualifying regatta.

title: BRITAIN AND CHINA MAY IMPROVE TIES
description: PEKING, July 18 (Agence FrancePresse)  Premier Chou Enlai said here tonight that China was holding talks with Britain on the possibility of raising ChineseBritish diplomatic relations to the ambassadorial level.

description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 18 Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week ended yesterday, but the regatta committee, headed by Donald B. King, was back on Long Island Sound today to run crewrace series for the International and Shields classes.

title: POLISH NEWSPAPER LAUDS NIXON MOVE
description: WARSAW, July 18President Nixon's plan to visit China was welcomed here today as a longoverdue reversal of Washington's unrealistic attitude toward Peking.

title: Fumes Kill 2 Cleaning Boat
description: MORGAN CITY, La., July.18 (UPI)Two men died today from ammonia inhalation suffered while cleaning a fish storage hold in a boat near here. The nice, Johnny Mack Johnson, 25 years old, of Morgan City, and Robert L. Evans, 26. of Fellsvillemere, Fla., were reportedly working without has masks.

title: Chess: Psychological Factor a Spur In Fischer's Winning Streak
Chilean Leftist Loses Key Election for a Deputy
description: VALPARAISO, Chile, July 18 The antiMarxist Opposition defeated a candidate of Chile's leftwing Government today in an election here for an important seat in Congress.

title: Tiger, on Return Home, Says He Has Quit Ring
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 18 (AP)Dick Tiger, a former world middleweight and light heavyweight boxing champion, announced his retirement today.

title: Coney Still Closed as Oil Lingers
description: The city's Health Commissioner kept the oilfouled Coney Island beaches closed to bathers yesterday despite an earlier decision by Mayor Lindsay and other officials to reopen them.

title: Religious Order Founded Here By OneYearOld Gay Church
description: The Church of the Beloved Disciple, which has a predominantly homosexual congregation, observed its first anniversary yesterday by installing its own religious order, and blessing the purple and gray vestments of the first three novices two women and a man.

title: 13 Drowned in Ganges
description: NEW DELHI, July 18 (UPI)A boat capsized in the Ganges River yesterday near Bhagalpur, a city 160 miles north of Calcutta, and 13 of the 24 persons aboard were drowned, Indian press reports said today.

title: 50 Reported Surrendered
description: TEL AVIV, July 18  More than 50 armed Palestinian guerrillas fleeing Jordanian troops forded the Jordan River this weekend and surrendered to Israeli forces on the west bank, according to Israeli sources.

title: Brooks Robinson Hits a Grand Slam In Orioles'
description: Brooks Robinson, a doubtful starter because of illness, smashed a grandslam homer yesterday as the Baltimore Orioles scored all their runs in the fifth and beat the Athletics, 73, at Oakland.

title: Nixon Returns to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) President Nixon returned from San Clemente, Calif., today, ending a 12day stay at the Western White House that reached its high point Thursday night with his announcement that he will visit China.

title: Fame From Investigations
description: From 1925 to 1944, Gerald Prentice Nye was a powerful scourge of Presidents, malefactors in public office, Wall Street bankers, munitions manufacturers and advocates of American entry into the war. He was also, in the Populist tradition, friend to the farmer and the small merchant.

title: Raids Close 9 AfterHours Bars Linked to Mafia
description: A joint strike force of nearly 400 Federal and city police officers shut down nine afterhours bars in Manhattan in meticulously coordinated predawn raids yesterday.

title: Lecarreau's Hydro Wins
description: MIAMI, July 18 (AP)  Ed Lecarreaux of New York won the Gold Coast marathon boat race today after two other hydroplanes had an accident in which one split the other.

title: General Electric to Raise Washing Machine Prices
description: The General Electric Company announced over the weekend that it will raise prices on several of its home laundry products, effective Aug. 9.

title: Leahy Off Critical List
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 18 (A)Frank Leahy, the former Notre Dame football coach, was taken off the critical list at St Vincent Hospital last night. His condition was changed to serious. Leahy 62 years old, has been in the intensive care unit since he underwent abdominal surgery Thursday night.

title: U.S. STOPS AIRLIFTING REFUGEES IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, July 18 (Reuters) The United States airlift of East Pakistani refugees away from the border areas of India ended today at the request of the Indian Government, an American Embassy spokesman said.

title: Ohio Legion Elects Negro
description: CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP)Charles R. Green, 50 years old, of Warren was unanimously elected commander of the Ohio American Legion here today, becoming the first Negro to hold the post.

title: CRIME ENGULFING BUFFALO PROJECT
description: BUFFALO, July 18A series of violent crimes this spring and summer at the Talbert Mall public housing project in Buffalo's east side has prompted 145 families, one quarter of the tenants, to request transfers to other projects.

title: Bethpage Poloists Win, 76, On Gayer's Overtime Goal
Ontario Scans Firm Ownership
description: TORONTO, July 18The Ontario Securities Commission plans to hold hearings in September on whether to apply retroactively Ontario's new restrictions on foreign ownership of securities firms.

title: The Shame of France
description: COLMAR, France  During the war in Algeria, there was not a single march on Paris or other mass protest. Even the French Communist party, with 25 per cent of the French voters, was passive, although it could have stopped the butchery of the Algerian people by strikes in the southern parts of France.

title: Namath Passes, Jokes and Philosophizes at Jets'
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 18  Across the locker room, Joe Namath noticed John Schmitt, the New York Jets center, and the quarterback went over and shook hands.

title: 3,000 HEAR ITURBI PLAY IN SUBURB
description: Despite thunder showers in the late afternoon and (erroneous) predictions for more in the evening, an enthusiastic crowd turned up on Saturday for the first summer concert by the Orchestral Society of Westchester. The series this year has been shifted from Manhattanville College to the beautiful grounds of Lyndhurst, a National rust Historic House overlooking the Hudson, in Tarrytown. And the new location is infinitely more congenial. About 1,000 listeners were seated inside the performing tent, perhaps twice that many stretched out on the rolling lawn behind it, enjoying the multiple advantages of cooler air, more enticing atmosphere and, surprisingly, better acoustics.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MEXICO CITY, July 18 (Reuters)Mexico took a 21 lead over Brazil by winning the doubles in their American Zone Davis Cup final today.

Shippers Report Rise in Freight; Gain Is Linked to Strike Threat
description: Freight forwarders said yesterday that the volume of imports into the Port of New York was beginning to rise because businesses had started to build up their inventories against the possibility of longshoremen's strike on Sept. 30.

title: Sports of The Times
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 18Bouncy Moore could have bypassed the Pan AfricaUnited States track and field meet over the weekend. He had won a National Collegiate long jump title, the money and competition were more attractive in Europe, and Southern crowds could never match the psychological fervor of Eugene, Ore., where jumping and jogging are a way of life.

title: STEEL MILLS BRACE FOR AUGUST SLUMP

Riggs and Tony Vincent of New York beat Butch Krikorian of San Jose, Calif., and Joe Woolfson of Union City, Calif., 64, 63, in the doubles final.

description: STOCKHOLMNot long ago, a group of Swedish authors and critics met on the Riviera and discussed the impact of Swedish modernist poetry in Italy over the last decades with some Italian colleagues.

title: JOHNSON'S YACHT OVERAIL VICTOR

Hutchins, the chairman and founder of the center.

title: New Hampshire Saves Home of Franklin Pierce
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 18 The house of one of New Hampshire's famous sons has been saved from the bulldozers of urban renewal.

title: 2 Bombs Explode in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 18 (Reuters)  Bomb explosions tonight damaged a brewery shop near the downtown area and a telephone office three miles south of Belfast. There were no immediate reports of casualties and policemen and troops immediately sealed of the areas.

title: Whitlinger Junior Victor
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18 (AP)John Whitlinger of Neenah, Wis., battled his way back to win the national junior claycourt tennis championship today. He beat Pat DuPre of Birmingham, Ala., 26, 63, 63.

title: Chile's Copper TakeOver
description: President Allende has now signed the amendment Chile's Constitution that nationalizes the copper mines of three American companies. He had promised nationalization in his 1970 campaign and it had become an irresistible political force. Every one of the 158 senators and deputies present  from revolutionary Socialists and Communists on the left to the Nationalists on the right had voted for the amendment.

title: ARAB COMMANDOS REPORTED FLEEING OVER THE JORDAN
description: FARA, Jordan, July 18Palestinian militants reported today that scores of Arab commandos had been fleeing across the Jordan River into Israelioccupied territory to escape from King Hussein's forces.

title: FOLK PROGRAM GIVEN BY JAMAICAN GROUP
description: Perhaps the most commonly known fact about Jamaican folk art is that Calypso is the indigenous dance. But that fact happens to be wrong by several degrees of latitude. As one of the commentators of the Jamaican Folksingers took pains to point out yesterday afternoon at the Hunter Assembly Hall, Jamaicans traditionally dance the Mento, which gives an interesting horizontal and circular movement to the pelvis. Calypso, a Trinidadian variant of the African original, provides a vertical bounce.

title: Six Persian Gulf Emirates Agree to a Federation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18Six Persian Gulf emirates announced today that they had reached agreement to establish a federation before the British leave the area at the end of the year.

title: Youth and Girlfriend Drown In Capsizing Off Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn youth and his girlfriend drowned yesterday morning when their boat capsized in the surf at Manhattan Beach.

description: To the Editor:

title: Elderly Blind Find Joy In Aiding Handicapped
description: A number of elderly blind men and women on Staten Island have volunteered to help the mentally handicapped in Willowbrook State School and elsewhere and have found that they are helping to cure their own loneliness and despondency.

description: WHEELING, W. Va., Until recently, the social leaders of Wheeling would no more have gone to Jamboree U.S.A. than they would have sat on their front porches in their undershirts.

J.; Ronald Andersen of Wichita, Kan.; Marilyn McCrary of Lake City, Iowa, and John Anderson of Springfield, Mo., totaled 38.35 boards to head the 64 teams in the final.

description: The American Jewish Congress charged yesterday that statements by two Orthodox rabbis criticizing the congress's opposition to public aid for religious schools were shocking and untrue.

description: LONDON, July 18British official thinking appears to be moving toward stronger support of seating the Peking Government in the United Nations.

title: Britain's Public and Private Steel Still Vie
description: SHEFFIELD, England There's an old English saying, Where there's muck, there's money, and Sheffield, with perverse pride, used to brag, at least before the War, that more dirt fell on its industrial East End than anywhere else in Europe.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP) Two chartered buses carrying 85 elderly persons on a religious outing collided on the Santa Ana Freeway today, injuring 39 persons slightly and trapping the driver of the rear bus, Ross McCarthy, 45 years old. Firemen had to cut away metal to free the Injured driver.

title: Roundup: Pirates Sweep, Extend Streak to 11
description: James Luke Walker knew things had to get better for him and yesterday they finally did.

title: Phillip W. Habertnan Jr. Dies; Lawyer Served City and State
description: Phillip W. Haberman Jr., a lawyer who had served the city and state in, many public offices, died Saturday of a putmonary embolism in Perth, Scotland, while on a vacation trip. He was 66 years old and lived at 1133 Park Avenue and in Chappaqua, N. Y.

title: A Small Oregon Town Celebrates Big Days
description: COTTAGE GROVE, Ore., July 18The long, familystyle tables were set up in the service shed of the Oregon Pacific and Eastern Railway, and the colorful banners of the local Shriners hid the greasy machinery pushed against the wall. In a makeshift kitchen, a crew of Shriners cooked round, fluffy hot cakes, easyover eggs, and slabs of country ham.

title: Personal Finance
description: Persons who have been in the market for crime insurance and couldn't get it, surely must have discovered by now that come Aug. 1 they can definitely get it from the Government.

title: Mrs. Cary Latimer Robinson Is Wed to Joseph A. Reagan
description: CARTERSVILLE, Ga., July 18Mrs. Cary Latimer Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Ho ratio Luro of Cartersville and Miami Beach, Fla., and Carroll Latimer of Highland, N. C., and Miami, was married this afternoon to Joseph A. Reagan. The Rev. Frank Jenkins, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at Old Mill Farm, which belongs to the bride's grandmother, Mrs. William Weinman.

title: For the Vietnam Farmer, Terror Is Never Far Off
description: TRUNGLAP, South Vietnam, July 13Vo Van Duc, a 40yearold farmer who was abducted with 19 others by the Vietcong last month, tells the story like a man who has memorized a nightmare.

title: Toll of Firemen Reported
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) The International Association of Fire Fighters said today that fire fighting was the most hazardous occupation in our nation today. The association said that 64 firemen died while on active duty in the first six months of 1971. Total onduty deaths in 1969 were 104, it said, and preliminary estimates for 1970 indicate that the number will be at least 10 per cent higher than the previous year.

title: Moroccan Cadets Assert Corps Was Duped Into Attacking King
description: RABAT, Morocco, July 17Four cadets said tonight that their school corps had been duped into believing it was fighting the enemies of King Hassan II last Saturday.

description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY BEST GOES TO SKYE TERRIER
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 18 An alert terrier with great style, elegance and dignity was named the best of 1,304 dogs at the Twin Brooks Kennel Club on The Mall today. He was Ch. Glamoor Gang Buster, Skye owned by Walter F. Goodman and his mother, Mrs. Adele F. Goodman of Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: Books of The Times
description: Wars come and goor at least they used tobut armies remain the same. Anyone who has been subjected by his friends and neighborsor even volunteered for itto Army basic training will find much that rings familiar in Peter Tauber's The Sunshine Soldiers, a sort of journal of his eight weeks of Basic Combat Training. They will also find much to laugh at through gritted teeth, because Mr. Tauber has a nice sense of the absurd, which the Army kept busy nearly every minute of the day. The tone is selfmocking, irreverent and antiheroic, for, aside from some gungho drill sergeants and warwhooping Southern boys, Mr. Tauber's outfit, Charlie Company, was a pretty unheroic lot. But what basic training company isn't? From predawn to exhausted lights out, the trainee is subjected to an incessant din of semiintelligible commands, a torrent of invective that is usually as unimaginative as it is obscene, and a welter of meaningless Sysiphean tasks, all designed to stamp out of him any remaining vestiges of civilianhood.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: GLYNDEBOURNE, EnglandThoughts of the Common Market and politics fade from consciousness. And the reason is not only the tranquility of the setting at this opera festivalthe swallows darting over the lawns at dusk, the click of croquet in the walled garden.

title: The New Options at Paris
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt.  Mrs. Binh's seven paints of July I offer mo... than just an opportunity to settle the prisoner issue. The plan :..le submitted at Paris on behalf of the Provisional Revolutionary Government could lead to an end of the Vietnamese war and a lessening of hostilities in Southeast Asia.

title: Singer Is Putting Fabrics to Fore
description: The 120yearold Singer Company, which went on a. tangent some years ago by adding home entertainment to its sewingmachine store, is now cutting the volume on its audio lines in order to carve out a larger share of the $2.3billion home sewing market.

title: Furniture: That GoodOldDays Feeling
description: Looking backward at some form of the good old days is what the new model rooms at Abraham & Straus are about. But since nostalgia's definition depends on the age of the beholder, the six rooms run the gamut of possibilities from late Victorian and art nouveau to the nineteenforties. Marks for high drama go to two of the roomsthe art nouveau (although it has touches of a lot of other styles and periods) and the Jean Harlow 1930's. The art nouveau room is all silvery green, from the moonlightonwater tone of the velvet that covers the chairs and walls to the pale musty green painted on a curving turnofthecentury desk and low coffee table. It is a captivating kind of decadence.

title: Books of The Times
description: Though she knows all about men, Diana Balooka can't seem to pick a good one. She is such a sophisticated machine for satisfaction, a veritable computer bank of polymorphous pleasuresyet her partners keep walking out on her. In fact, this the only thing her third husband, Jason, enjoysfor he will neither talk to her nor touch her. When Jason fails to return from one of his walkouts, Diana decides upon a divorce. And while her lawyer tackles the legal problems, she addresses herself to the literary ones: how many similes, metaphors and conceits, how many flights of rhetoric, of fantasy, can she find in her predicament? For a woman who had such a notoriously unsuccessful mar riage, who was so vociferously unhappy in it, she certainly takes its dissolution hard.

title: ROSEWALL BEATS RIESSEN IN FINAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Ken. Rosewall trounced Marty Riessen, 62, 75, 61, to win the $50,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament today.

title: N.B.C. News Ending AnchorTeams Era
description: An era in television that saw the team of Chet Huntley and David Brinkley become household words is finally coming to an end with the conclusion by the National Broadcasting Company that the distinctive chemistry of the two men on the air cannot be duplicated by others.

title: Academic Credit Is Urged For Student Volunteers
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) The head of the new Federal volunteer Action program said today that he would ask colleges and universities to grant full academic credit to students for a year spent working in the inner city.

title: France Presses Inquiries Into PropertyFund Fraud
description: PARIS, July 18Want to earn more than 10 per cent on your money?. Thousands of Frenchmen read the ads promising riches through real estate and are now worried about whether they will ever see their money again.

title: Thais Believed Able to Stem Any Rise in Insurgency
description: BANGKOK, ThailandPremier Thanom Kittikachorn told Government workers here recently that United States withdrawal from Vietnam would increase the danger to Thailand because the Communists will intensify their war of insurgency against us.

title: Organizer of OilSpill Cleanup Joseph Patrick Davidson
description: Since Thursday, Joseph Patrick Davidson, first deputy administrator of parks, recreation and cultural affairs, has had to forgo one of his favorite pastimes.

title: Lebanon Curbs Flipper
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 (Reuters)Lebanon has banned) youngsters under 15 years old from playing pinball machines known here as flippers"in public amusement arcades.

title: Anderson Again Captures New York Archery Crown
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., July 18Arthur Anderson of Brooklyn won the men's New York State target archery championship for the third year in a row today at the Nassau County Archery Range.

title: ...And Pele Departs World Stage
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 18 (AP)Pele, known as the Black Pearl and heralded as the greatest of soccer players, ended his career with the Brazilian national team today before an emotional, highly partisan crowd and an international television audience.

title: FLEET OF 23 SAILS TO FISHERS ISLAND
description: RYE, N. Y., July 18The 40th annual American Yacht Club cruise began today with a fleet of 23 setting sail for an overnight race of 81 miles to Fishers Island.

title: Gerald P. Nye Is Dead at 78
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)Gerald P. Nye, a former Republican Senator from North Dakota, who was known as an isolationist before World War II, died yesterday in Georgetown University Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

description: Dr. George B. Kistiakowsky, former science adviser to President Eisenhower, has been awarded the Priestley Medal, highest honor bestowed by the American Chemical Society.

title: Controlling the C.I.A.
description: Senator Cooper's proposal that the Central Intelligence Agency share with Congress its intelligence estimates a logical corollary to the reassertion of Congressional responsibility in the making of foreign policy. The lawmakers obviously cannot fulfill their constitutional function in this vital area with maximum wisdom and effectiveness unless they have access to the best available information.

title: FRANCE SEEKING VIGOR IN BOURSE
description: PARIS, July 18One out of every 33 persons in France is a stockholder, compared with one in 22 in Britain and one in seven in the United States. The average age of French stockholders is 58, compared with 48 in the United States.

title: Impact of Bar Meeting: British Justice May Be Tried Out in U.S.
description: LONDON, July 18A likely result of the meeting of the American Bar Association here is that several key features of the British system of criminal justice will be tried out in the United States during the coming months. For the 6,000 American lawyers who are here, no impression has been

title: Backers of Minh Gather to Attack Thieu and U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18Some of President Nguyen Van Thieu's most tireless critics, who are supporting Gen. Duong van Mirth for president of South Vietnam, held their first public meeting today to denounce President Thieu, and to charge election rigging and American interference.

title: Mrs. Walter Tkach, Wife Of Nixon's Physician, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Mrs. Helen Tkach, wife of Brig. Gen. Walter R. Tkach, President Nixon's personal physician, died yesterday of cancer. She was 52 years old.

title: Hanoi Accuses. U.S. on Nixon Doctrine
description: HONG KONG, Monday, July 19 (Reuters)  North Vietnam accused the United States today of dividing socialist countries under the Nixon Doctrine.

FIRE BASE BUNKERS WITHSTAND BARRAGE

description: TENAFLY, N. J., July 18Miss Suzanne T. Ostrand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold O. Ostrand, was married here this afternoon in the garden of her parents home to Robert C. Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton N. Rosenberg of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Irwin M. Blank of Tenafly.

Mr. Bell, a housing and urban affairs consultant, was chosen last night to lead Louisiana's first allblack ticket since Reconstruction. About 400 delegates attended the convention.

title: CHURCH IS AMAZED BY PRIEST'S NEW JOB
description: CHICAGO, July 18 (UPI)The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago ordered today an investigation into the appointment of a parish priest as the executive director of the Illinois division of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: GREEK'S AID PLAN: A GIFT OF $3MILLION
description: ATHENS, July 18A leading Greek shipowner offered to donate $3million for national defense after a United States Congressional committee voted to withhold military aid to the militarybacked Greek regime until it restores democracy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today July 19, 1971
description: Special Committee on Apartheid10:30 A.M.

title: Nee and Mandell Capture 5,000Meter Races Here
description: Dennis Nee of the New York Athletic Club won an open 5,000meter race yesterday in a field of 56 runners at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. He was timed in 15 minutes 18.8 seconds, finishing 25 yards ahead of John McDonnell, also of the New York A. C.

title: BROKERS DEFEND USE OF DEPOSITS
description: The Association of Stock Exchange Firms charged yesterday that Government attacks on the use of customers free credit balances by brokerage firms were based on a lack of knowledge.

title: BondMarket Rates Face Uncertainty in Busy Week
description: A heavy schedule of financing activity appears likely to make this week a pivotal one for the credit markets, analysts suggest, but the guessing is sharply divided as to which direction interest rates will move.

title: Laird Seeks Realistic Deterrent
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said tonight that the United States must maintain realistic deterrent force while strengthening its Asian allies in a new era of negotiation. He talked to reporters at Andrews Air Force base in Maryland after returning from a 10day tour of Japan and South Korea.

title: Count Goose Wins Six of 7 Classes At Millbrook Show
description: MILLBROOK, N. Y., July 18 Elizabeth Thomas's Count Goose was entered in seven classes in the Millbrook Hunt Horse Show today and won six. In the process, he captured two championships.

title: Grover Takes Final
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., July 18James R. Grover, sailing Sit'n Bull, captured the Narrasketuck Class national championship by winning today's race.

title: Chou Says That Nixon Suggested Peking Visit  The Globe and Mall, Toronto
description: PEKING, Monday, July 18 Premier Chou Enlai was reported to have said to a visiting French group here last night that it was not he but President Nixon who had proposed the Presidential visit to Peking.

title: Lottery Debate to Open
description: BOSTON, July 18 (UPI)Debate will begin in the Massachusetts House tomorrow on a bill to create a stateoperated lottery, Speaker David M. Bartley said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COURTS ARE HELD CREDITORS ALLIES
description: A fouryear study of consumer credit by Columbia Uni, versity released yesterday berated the courts for acting as the collection agents of the creditors rather than administering justice in this type of dispute.

title: InnerCity Decay Causes Business Life to Wither
description: DETROIT, July 18The weatherbeaten plywood board is replacing the gleaming steel and glass skyscraper as a symbol of the American city.

title: Bo Diddley Returns on Guitar At Forest Hills Rock Concert
description: Bo Diddley, who helped start rock n roll and who has been playing it for 17 years, received great applause during his set at the Forest Hills tennis stadium Saturday evening. I want to thank you for my survival during the rock n roll crisis, he told the crowd.

title: Break Up the Family
description: Up to the nineteenth century, European families throughout the ranks of society were an intricate web of relatives; instead of husbands and wives living alone, clusters of married couples lived together. Due to the accidents of war, disease and work, uncles and cousins often took the place of absent fathers, and as many as twenty or thirty children were tended by this network of parents. If we looked in America today for a parallel to these families, we would be more likely to find it among the ranks of the poor than among those of the middle class.

title: Kissinger Says Nixon Meeting With Peking Demands Planning
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Henry A. Kissinger, who slipped secretly into Peking in a silkcurtained limousine July 9, said today that an illprepared summit meeting between the United States and China would be a disaster.

title: PUERTO RICANS HERE MARK '17 FRANCHISE
description: About 1,000 Puerto Ricans gathered on the Central Park Mall yesterday afternoon to commemorate the 54th anniversary of the Congressional act that granted them United States citizenship and to honor the man who was the driving force behind passage of that act.

title: RESTON UNDERGOES OPERATION IN PEKING
description: James Reston, columnist and vice president of The New York Times, underwent surgery for acute appendicitis in a hospital in Peking on Saturday. Mr. Reston and his wife have been in China since July 8.

title: Days of Popcorn
description: Participants in the 439 parades for which New York City issued permits in 1969 enjoyed days of popcorn, bands and good feeling, according to a report of the Mayor's Council on the Environment. For City Hall, however, the report shows that a parade is something less than a picnic.

title: CLARK TERRY FIVE IN JAZZ PROGRAM
description: The legend that within every good jazz musician there lurks a good jazz singer was explored Saturday night at Town Hall and was proved to be reasonably true.

title: LA GUARDIA TO GET A NEW CAB SYSTEM
description: The chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission disclosed yesterday that a new system of central dispatching of taxis would be instituted next month at La Guardia Airport to handle queues and speed service.

title: Korea Storm Toll Rises to 45
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 18 (AP)  The death toll from a torrential rainfall in the Seoul area has risen to 45, South Korea's disaster relief center reported today. It said that 8 persons were missing, 43 others injured and 3,424 people made homeless by landslides and flooding rivers resulting from the seveninch downpour yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hobbs Triumphs Again
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 18 (UPI)  David Hobbs of England turned back a determined bid by Jerry Hansen, a Minneapolis stock broker today and won the fifth race in the L & M Continental championship series at Road America.

title: Radio Tuning In to the Country Styles
description: Country music, once generally dismissed as the doleful maunderings of illiterate hillbillies, is attracting an everwidening audience and has spread from its base in the SouthCentral states to become a programing staple on a majority of the nation's radio stations.

title: Storm Hits Mackinac Fleet
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 18 (UPI)The 155 yachts sailing up Lake Michigan in the 64th ChicagoMackinac Island race ran into stormy weather today. With James McHugh's Inferno of Chicago in the lead, the boats were strung out about 175 miles from their goal.

title: FISCHER DEFEATS LARSEN IN DENVER
description: DENVER, July 18  Bobby Fischer maintained his winning streak today by defeating Bent Larsen of Denmark in 46 moves in the fifth game of their chess match at Temple Buel College.

title: U.S. HEADING OFF NEW TRADE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Government's chief trade negotiator expressed gratification over the weekend that a potentially serious new barrier to United States exports may have been headed off.

title: Beame Says Board of Education Has Failed to Make Vigorous Attacks on Drug Problems
description: City Controller Abraham D. Beame accused the Board of Education yesterday of failing to vigorously act on the drug problem in the schools and of minimizing the problem to the public.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
Explosion Rocks Sydney
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 18 (Reuters)A violent explosion from a leaking gas main rocked the center of Sydney today. The blast shook nearby buildings and sent a hail of glass from shattered windows across a pedestrian crossing, but nobody was hurt.

title: Man Held in Wounding of 3
description: STONINGTON. Maine, July 18 (UPI)A man firing a rifle wounded three persons today. David Eaton, 23 year old, was arrested and charged with assault with intent to kill. The police said that he was a Vietnam veteran on parole from a burglary sentence. The wounded were James D. Haines, 23, of Ann Arbor, Mich, his wife, Sherri, and Karen Ray, 33.

title: Armed Forces Assailed On View of Homosexuals
description: A new study of homosexuality from the Institute for Sex Research, founded by the late Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey, has concluded that the military policy of the United States toward homosexuals is unwise, unjust and in essence unenforceable.

title: End to the Examiners'
description: The ruling by Federal Judge Walter R. Mansfield that the tests administered by the New York City Board of Examiners are defective yardsticks for the licensing of school supervisors is a victory for the cause of educational reform. A preliminary injunction, in a suit brought by the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund on behalf of two acting principalsone black, the other Puerto Ricanrestrains the examiners from giving the tests and from issuing eligibility lists based on their results.

title: Congressional Fellowships For 197172 Are Awarded
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) Eight journalists and eight political scientists were named today as fellows for the 197172 Congressional Operations Program, administered by the Civil Service Commission and the American Political Science Assocation.

title: Scott Heads Draw of 64 In Satellite Tennis Today
description: A new countrywide effort to stimulate tennis tournaments starts today at the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy.

title: BEHLING CAPTURES DRAG RACING TITLE
description: ENGLISHTOWN, N. J., July 18Arnie Bebling of Arlington Heights, Ill., won the top fuel eliminator crown today in the National Hot Rod Association's second annual Summernationals drag raoing championships at. Raceway Park.

title: GOAL ON AIRMAIL NEARLY REACHED
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The United States Postal Service is approaching its selfimposed standard of 95 per cent reliability for the overnight deilivery of qualified airmail letters up to a distance of 600 miles and within two days in the continental United States, according to postal officials.

title: Silvester Wins Two Events In Yugoslav Track Meet
description: CELJE, Yugoslavia, July 18 (AP)  Jay Silvester of the United States won the shotput and discus yesterday at the Skok Memorial track and field meet which attracted over 100 athletes from nine countries,

title: S.E.C. Details Disclosure Required on Environment
description: WASHINGTON, July 18The Securities and Exchange Commission has instructed corporations in detail for the first time on the disclosures they must make in the environmental and civil rights areas.

title: STATE ACTS TO CURB PHONE TARIFF ABUSE
description: ALBANY, July 18The Public Service Commission has begun notifying motels and similar establishments throughout the state that they may face loss of their telephone service if they are imposing higher charges on their patrons for phone usage than the telephone company tariffs permit.

title: Illiteracy Is Persisting in South As It Drops Sharply Elsewhere
description: ATLANTA, July 18Illiteracy still haunts the American South. The latest available information from the United States Office of Education and the Bureau of the Census indicates that nearly one million people in a dozen Southern states are unable to read and write in any language.

title: Advertising:
description: Although advertising circles are probably expecting a momentary announcement from Ford on the future agency for the Pinto, Maverick and Mustang lines that are moving out of 3, Walter Thompson, they're out of luck. The company says the announcement probably won't come till midAugust.

title: Auto Crash Kills Spectator
description: MESSINA, Sicily, July 18(AP)A spectator was killed and 10 others were injured today when a FiatAbarth veered off the track and plunged into a crowd at a Tourism Class auto race. Giuseppe Calarese, the driver, was only slightly hurt.

title: SPAIN ELIMINATED IN DAVIS CUP, 32
description: PRAGUE, July 18 (Reuters)Czechoslovakia won the last two singles today and beat Spain, 32, in the Davis Cup European Zone A tennis final.

title: Dixie Sung at Bull Run But Army Band Is Silent
description: MANASSAS, Va., July 18 (AP)  A chorus of Dixie was sung at the 110th anniversary of the First Battle of Manassas, but without accompaniment from the 75th United States Army Band.

title: Poker Chipsfor the Ears
description: As stores go into their summer doldrumswho can think about a wool suit when the temperature is in the 90's?the small things that perk up a wardrobe seem more important. Jewelry, for instance. Kenneth J. Lane has dreamed up a solution to what to wear with a variety of sum mer dresses in the form of his Poker Chip earrings. The base of the idea is goldcolored clipon rings. Into the rings, one can slip any of six colors in plastic disks: white, red, black, yellow, blue or green. The wearer simply changes the disks to go with what she's wearing. The whole business comes packaged in a black, cylindrical box similar to the ones that hold gaming chips. The set is $20 at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: One Foreign Champion Keeps Rolling Along...
description: PARIS, July 18  He came into the stadium, Superman on wheels, managing to look gigantic while still in his racing crouch, his arched back parallel to the ground.

title: Slum Remodelers Fear Layoffs in Loan Suspension
description: An association of building contractors who rehabilitate slums warned yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's suspension of payments under the city's fraudtinged slum renovation loan program could halt the work of legitimate contractors, generating layoffs and delays for slum families in desperate need of new housing.

title: The Chinese Strategy
description: President Nixon played his China card last week, and international relations will not soon, if ever, be the same.

title: Advertising:
description: An anxious N. W. Ayer & Son learned Friday that it was the new agency for Bell & Howell, which is expected to be spending some $4million to $5million a year on advertising. At the same time, an equally anxious Coordinated Communications, Inc., learned it wasn't getting the account.

title: Dance: Dutch National Ballet Transformed in Year
description: AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, July 18For such a comparatively small country, Holland has an enormous amount of dance. And if April is the time for tulips in Holland, July is the time for ballet.

title: Senator Scott Foresees Vietnam Pullout by May
description: WASHINGTON, July 18Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, said today he believed that President Nixon's decision to visit Peking by May, 1972, indicated that there would be no AmeriCan combat troops left in Southeast Asia by that time.

title: PETTY CAPTURES TRENTON CAR RACE
description: TRENTON, July 18Richard Petty won his 13th stock car race of the season today and moved $6,600 closer to the $1million mark in career winnings. He is now. $6,842 short of that goal, which he expects to reach in the next National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing Grand National race on Aug. 1 at Atlanta. Counting the $157,650 he had already won this season, Petty went into today's race with winnings of $986,558 for 12 years of racing.

title: HORSES IN 5 STATES MUST BE VACCINATED
description: DALLAS, July 18 (UPI)Animal health experts imposed mandatory vaccination programs today and planned to spread insecticide over a 400mile stretch of the Texas Gulf Coast in a Federalstate effort to control a strain of sleeping sickness deadly to horses. The innoculations were ordered for horses in Texas, Oklahoma, New Mexico, Arkansas and Louisiana.

title: A House Committee Rebels
description: A majority of the House Foreign Affairs Committee has finally rebelled against stale and spurious arguments of the Defense and State Departments and voted to cut off aid to the military regimes of Greece and Pakistan. Rather than attempting feverishly to overturn the decision in the full House, the Nixon Administration should try to understand what this usually docile committee majority was telling it with these votes.

title: She Provides a Normal Home for Children of Drug Addicts
description: A little more than a year ago, Lorraine Hale was ?? ment in Harlem. As she rounded corner, she saw a young woman nodding on the stoop of a building. The woman was a drug addict and, with each nod, the balance of the baby in her arms became more precarious.

title: Lu Wins French Open By 2 Shots With 262
description: BIARRITZ France, July 18 (UPI)Lu Liang Huan of Taiwan won the French international open golf tournament Friday with a 3underpar 66 in the final round for a total of 262. Roberto de Vicenzo and Vicente Fernandez, both of Argentina, shared the runnerup spot, two strokes back of Lu.

title: Confusion Marks a Sale At the Garden City Hotel
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 19  Confusion, frustration and anger marked the opening sale today of furnishings and memorabiia from the Garden City Hotel, which closed last week because of financial difficulties.

title: LONG TERM ASKED IN SPANISH SCANDAL
description: MADRID, July 19 (UPI)The state prosecutor has demanded a long prison sentence for the central figure in Spain's Matesa affair and heavy fines for two former cabinet ministers and the former governor of the Bank of Spain, the official press agency Cifra said today.

title: The Money Blanket
description: A thick blanket of money is smothering political life in this country. The need to raise huge sums to pay for expensive campaigns is inhibiting the free, spontaneous interplay of new people and fresh ideas which is essential to a healthy democracy.

title: Aerosol Sniffing: New and Deadly Craze
description: Physicians, government officials, drug experts and chemical manufacturers are growing increasingly worried about a deadly and relatively new drugabuse problem among the nation's children: the inhalation of aerosol sprays.

title: Museum Planned for Wall St. Area
description: Can the Whitney Museum help the hordes of deprived people who work in the culturestarved financial district? It's going to try. This December, it will open a satellite museum in the gigantic new building at 55 Water Street, said to be the largest privately built office structure in the world.

title: Thieu Terms Minh A Liar and Defends Role in Diem Coup
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20President Nguyen Van Thieu struck back at his political rivals tonight, calling Gen. Duong Van Minh a coward and a liar, and insisting that the presidential elections this fall would be fair and honest.

title: Six General Host Directors Elected to Cudahy's Board
description: The General Host Corporation, which has acquired about 84 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Cudahy Company through a cash tender offer, announced yesterday that six of its directors had been elected to the Cudahy board to replace six former directors who resigned from the 11man Cudahy board.

title: Separate Trials Granted to Magee And Angela Davis
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 19 (UPI)  Judge Richard E. Arnason granted separate trials today to Angela Davis and her codefendant, Ruchell Magee, and ordered arguments in Miss Davis's longdelayed case to get under way tomorrow morning.

title: 2,300 Guerrillas Seized, Joidanian Premier Asserts
description: UMM AL HIRAN, Jordan, July 19Premier Wasfi Tal asserted here today that Jordanian troops had rounded up 2,300 Arab commandos in the last week and that only about 200 commandos remained at liberty in Jordan.

title: Eban Addresses Knesset
description: JERUSALEM, July 19  Foreign Minister Abba Eban today forecast a friendly but frank discussion with Assistant Secretary of State Sisco.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As one who is of the new generation of China scholars (at least as far as age is concerned), I must take exception to Prof. Jonathan Mirsky's recent letter. There are many of us younger than Professor Mirsky, who also read all we can about China, talk to travelers and know the Chinese language, and yet have not come to the conclusion that the Chinese experiment is a great and even a noble one.

title: Agree to Settle Charge of Illegally Profiting on '65 Stock Sale
description: Ten shareholders who received $41.8million when they sold their shares of the Dreyfus Corporation to the public in 1965 have agreed to pay $5million to settle a claim that they acted illegally in profiting from the sale.

title: Vietnam Pullout Rate Well Ahead of Schedule
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 19 (UPI)The halfway mark in President Nixon's program to pull 100,000 more servicemen out of Vietnam by December was passed last week when 3,000 soldiers went home.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Power Failure in Rockland
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., July 19 (AP)  Thousands of homes were without power in Rockland County and nearby New Jersey this afternoon after a widespread electrical storm damaged eelctrical transmission lines and transformers. The Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., said 3,000 customers were blacked out in the West Nyack and Nanuet areas of Rockland County and in Oakland, N. J.

title: Copper Exports Resume
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The Commerce Department today lifted a temporary suspension, imposed July 8, on the export of refined copper, blister copper and copperbased scrap.

title: Novel British Cruisers To Replace the Carriers
description: LONDON, July 17Britain's Royal Navy, outnumbered by the United States and Soviet fleets, is turning to novel naval design in an attempt to maintain its significance.

title: Seaboard Offers to Acquire Proposed L.&N. Preferred
description: The Seaboard Coast Line Railroad Company, which has increased its holdings of Louisville & Nashville Railroad common stock to 95 per cent through a tender offer, is making an offer for 772,467 shares of L.&N.'s $2.10 cumulative convertible preferred, Series A, which will be issued by LAN. to shareholders of the Monon Railroad when the L.&N.Monon merger is consummated. Terms have not yet been determined.

title: STOCKS OFF A MT AS TRADING SLIPS
ASHE, LAVER LOSE IN OPENING ROUND
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 19 (UPI)Topseeded Arthur Ashe and secondseeded Rod Laver were upset today in the opening round of the $50,000 First National tennis tournament.

title: Shelton and Sorel Join Cast
description: Reid Shelton and Guy Sorel have joihed the cast of The Rothschilds, the musical at the Lunt Fontanne Theater. They replaced Keene Curtis and Leo Leyden, respectivly.

title: Books of The Times
description: INDIA'S CHINA WAR. By Neville Maxwell. 475 pages. Pantheon. $10.

title: New Head of Counties'
description: MILWAUKEE, July 19Four years ago, shortly after his election as New Castle, Del., County Executive, William John Conner stumbled on the Washington headquarters of the National Association of Counties

title: Britain Cuts Taxes in Bid To Spur Lagging Economy
description: LONDON, July 19The British Government took a gamble today on a new policy intended to recharge the slumping economy and at the same time reduce inflation.

title: NADER CRITICIZES CANNERS'
description: WASHINGTON. July 19Ralph Nader asked the Justice Department today for an antitrust investigation of the National Canners Association on the ground that it handles some consumer complaints in behalf of its members.

title: Sisco Going to Israel for Talks on Canal
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The. State Department announced today that Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco would fly to Israel next week.

title: Convict Escapes in Illinois
description: MARION, III., July 19 (AP)An inmate escaped over high fences at the edge of the Federal penitentiary today in the second successful breakout in four days. Another inmate was wounded and a third was captured in the escape attempt. Officials at the Southern Illinois prison said Warren Briggs of Baltimore, a bank robber, had escaped.

title: Killer Appeals to Justices
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Duane Pope, sentenced to death for slayings during a bank robbery in 1965 at Big Springs, Neb., has asked the United States Supreme Court to overturn his conviction. Pope's application is on appeal from the Nebraska Supreme Court, which denied his motion for a new trial.

title: U.S. Plywood Posts Gains
Meeting the Energy Dilemma
description: The basic energy dilemma of modern society is by now well understood. To provide rising standards of living to increasing populations here and abroad, more energy of all types must be available.
