But virtually all present major modes of energy generation impose costs upon the environment; automobile exhausts spew noxious gases into the atmosphere; nuclear fission reactors produce thermal pollution and longlasting radioactive substances as waste byproducts. In all industrialized countries men are debating how far their nations dare go in fouling air, water and soil to satisfy the present insatiable demand for more power. Everyone now recognizes that there are limits to the volume of effluent the planetary environment can absorb and still continue to permit the survival of plant and animal life.

title: F.T.C. Aide Gets New Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The top lawyer and one of the top policy makers for the Federal Trade Commission, Joseph Martin Jr., its general counsel, is leaving to take a position with the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the F.T.C. said today. Mr. Martin will become an alternate representative to the conference of the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva.

title: SOVIET ASSURANCE REPORTED BY NASA
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that the Soviet Union had assured United States scientists that the recent deaths of three Russian astronauts posed no problems for the Apollo 15 crew.

title: CONTRACTOR CITED IN BLAST ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (Reuters)  Federal investigators studying a tunnel explosion that killed 17 workers in Los Angeles June 25 today said the tunnel contractor, a Lockheed Corporation subsidiary, had willfully violated safety standards.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent incident involving the killing of a polar bear in Central Park's Zoo is another sad illustration of the inadequacy of that facility.

title: SOUTHERN CO.'S NET OFF 13% IN THE HALF
description: The Southern Company reported yesterday a 13 per cent decline in firsthalf net income despite a 9 per cent gain in operating revenues.

title: Peoples Gas Plans Exchange of Stock For Merchants, Inc.
description: The Peoples Gas Company, a utility and pipeline concern, said yesterday in Chicago that it had agreed in principle to exchange Peoples common stock for all the outstanding shares of Merchants, Inc., a diversified trucking and manufacturing organization based in Abilene, Tex. The acquisition which would involve about $37.5million in Peoples stock  is subject to the approval of about 2,100 Mer chants shareholders and to favorable rulings by several Government agencies.

title: Fund Raising by Mail Works for McGovern
description: WASHINGTON, July 19In the first six months of his underdog candidacy, Senator George McGovern has raised nearly half a million dollars from 25,000 contributors through direct mail solicitation.

title: The Overseas Agnew
description: MADRID, July I8Vice President Agnew made the biggest news of his worldwide trip when he criticized Senate doves during a briefing in Singapore, attacked The New York Times and other news media while in Ethiopia and excoriated some American black leaders during the plane trip to Madrid. This sequence says much about the style and substance of his trip and throws into sharp relief his far quieter role as a diplomat. He has made little news or noise as President Nixon's roving envoy, and if he has proved anything it is that he can remain as inconspicuous abroad as he is conspicuous at home.

title: Notes on People
description: A number of the journalists who have visited China in recent months have devoted space in their reports to acupuncture, but yesterday James Reston of The New York Times went his colleagues one better.

title: SUDANESE LEADER REPORTED OUSTED
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, July 20The head of the Government in the Sudan, Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry, was reported to have been deposed in a coup d'dtat last night.

title: IN THE NATION
description: M1AMIIf President Nixon's historic visit to China means that by mid1972 there is to be a negotiated settlement in Vietnam or a total American withdrawal from the war, then the Presidential election may well be settled in Peking. If notif these remarkable new prospects somehow failthen what will happen here in Florida next March 14 ought to be of considerable significance.

title: Topping Out Through Cloud
description: The second of the World Trade Center's 110storyhigh twin towers was topped out formally yesterday in rainy weather in which the toppingout beam was lifted to the 1,350foot level through a cloud. The South Tower and Its twin, the North Tower, which was topped out last December, are the city's tallest structures. The Port of New York Authority's $650million project will be completed near the end of 1973.

title: Nixon Asks for Agency Based on F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Nixon Administration proposed today the conversion of the Food and Drug Administration into a new agency that would regulate foods, drugs and a wide range of consumer products.

title: Chou Meets U.S. Scholars
description: HONG KONG, July 19 (Reuters)Premier Chou Enlai of China today met a 15member delegation of American scholars who specialize in Asian affairs, the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported. Mr. Chou had a cordial and friendly conversation with the Amencans, members of the Committee of Concerned Asian Scholars, which opposes American policy in Vietnam, the agency said.

title: One and One Make War
description: We know best is the predictable reaction of crisis managers to angry popular assertions of principle. If secrecy is the first official refuge from emergency in the name of patriotism, deception is the second. The revelations in the Pentagon Papers involve not one form of deception but two. The first was perpetrated on the public in the name of crisis management. But the companion deception foreclosed all possibility of managerial practicality. It recalled Talleyrand's warning that a blunder is more serious than a crime.

title: Eel Control Funds Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Senate approved $400,000 today for continued research into control and elimination of the lamprey eel, which has severely damaged commercial fishing in the Great Lakes.

title: Nixon to Name.2 Jersey Men To U.S. Appeals Court Seats
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Two New Jersey men, a judge and a lawyer, will be nominated by President Nixon to fill vacancies on the United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia, the White House announced today.

title: Police Seek Bridges to Harlem
description: The new commanding officer of the Sixth Division in Central Harlem feels that his policemen should spend as much time getting out and talking to people as they do flying around answering calls.

title: Hanging From Car Trunk, Hair Triggers False Alarm
description: MODESTO, Calif., (UPI)A group of ranch workers saw a hank of brown hair hanging out of the closed trunk of A parked automobile.

title: House Gets Broadened Bill To Spur Aid to Lockheed
description: A oroaaenea Dill tnat wouin authorize Government guarantees of loans not only to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation but also to other companies in financial distress was introduced in the House yesterday.

title: COALITION URGED FOR U.S. SUBURBS
description: MILWAUKEE, July 19  A national suburban coalition designed to attract more attention to the problems of the suburbs was proposed tonight to the executives of many of the nations urban and suburban counties.

title: No Resistance Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19 (AP)The Iraqi press agency reported today that Sudanese troops supporting Major Atta moved into Khartoum behind a column of tanks and seized Government buildings and the radio station without meeting any resistance.

title: BONDOFFER DETAILS REPORTED BY CANADA
description: OTTAWA, July 19 (Reuters) The Canadian Government gave details today of its proposed $550million offering of new bonds, which was announced Friday.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
HOUSE APPROVES V.A. ADDICT BILE
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The House voted today to expand the Veterans Administration's drug treatment program to include activeduty servicemen and dishonorably discharged veterans.

title: American Killed as Rockets Hit a Depot Near Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 19 (Reuters)  War activity remained at a low level today, with reports of only A few small, isolated skirmishes and a Vietcong rocket attack on a helicopter repair depot near Saigon.

title: Japanese Investors Active
description: TOKYO, July 19 (Reuters)The Federation of Securities Dealers Association said today that about $4mi1lion had been invested in foreign stocks by Japanese individuals since restrictions were lifted on July 1.

title: Bethune Memorial Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)The House sent to President Nixon today a bill extending for two years, until May 31, 1973, the authority to erect a memorial here to Mary McLeod Bethune, a prominent Negro educator. The vote was 288 to 90.

title: Bill on Big Buses Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The House Rules Committee cleared today a bill to allow 102inchwide buses to operate on the interstate highway system where 12foot lanes exist. The bill has been scheduled for a House vote Wednesday.

title: RedInquiry Funds Voted, But Senate Limits Scope
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Senate voted today to continue funding the Subversive Activities Control Board, but it also blocked a recent Presidential order expanding the board's mandate to include investigations of militant groups.

title: Midtown Peddlers: Every Ware Everywhere
description: On the streets of midtown Manhattan these days one can buywithout ever setting foot in a storehandmade belts, tacos, oddball jewelry, egg rolls, custommade photo buttons, plasticwrapped organic snacks, acrylic flowers, 1940 calendar art, real flowers and advice on religion and life from Ferdy.

title: SEA FORCE WINS EMERALD PURSE BY TWO LENGTHS
description: With Jorge Velasquez steering her into the lead just after the start, Sea Force stole the Emerald Purse at Aqueduct yesterday. The result was A little more than a mild surprise to the 27,104 customers, for among those who trailed Sea Force were the wellplayed Stolen. Base, who came second, and the oddson Arachne, who wound up third in the field of six.

title: Pentagon Expected to Act On War Papers This Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Pentagon is expected to make some announcement this week on removing the secrecy label from part of its study of the Vietnam War, Jerry W. Friedheim, Defense Department spokesman, said today.

title: PRICES OF BONDS OFF MODERATELY
Hertz and Marriott Agree
description: The Hertz Corporation and Marriott Hotels, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement under which Hertz rental cars would be available through all Marriott hotels.

title: CHRYSLER TRIPLES NET FOR QUARTER
description: DETROIT, July 19Chrysler and American Motors, in trouble last year, continue to show signs of recovery as both announced today healthy profits for their June quarters.

title: NEW HOUSING PLAN FOR YORKVILLE SITE
description: The city's Housing and Development Administration announced proposed revisions last night in its controversial plans for the fourblock Ruppert Brewery site in Yorkville.

title: Newark May Run Black Oriented Radio Station
description: The Newark City Council is scheduled to meet tomorrow to determine whether the city should operate a blackoriented radio station that went off the air Saturday after its license had been revoked.

title: CHIEF OF ALLEGHENY BACKS MOHAWK DEAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The president of Allegheny Airlines said today that if a proposed merger with Mohawk Airlines were approved, Allegheny would lose $448,000 in the first year or operation.

title: MineralStudy Aid Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to authorize a multimilliondollar mineral research program. The bill, sent to the House would authorize Federal grants to states for establishment of mineralresearch and training centers.

title: Ballet: Personality Intact
description: AMSTERDAM, July 19The more the Netherlands Dance Theater changes, the more it remains the same. The company opened its summer season at the State Theater here in Amsterdam tonight.

title: Scott Extended to Win
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. L, July 19Gene Scott of New York recovered to defeat Tom Abercrombie of Carrollton, Tex., 67, 62, 61, in the first round of the $1,000 Port Washington open tennis tournament tonight. Rain forced the matches indoors at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Lord Astor of Hever Is Dead; Published The Times of London
description: LONDON, July 19Lord Astor of Hever, former publisher of The Times of London, died today in the hospital in Cannes, France. His age was 85.

title: Plan to Move AArms Near China Killed
description: WASHINGTON, July 19United States Government officials said today that nuclear weapons that must be removed from Okinawa would not be shifted to Taiwan, South Korea, and the Philippines in view of President Nixon's efforts to improve relations with Communist China.

title: Javits Says Nixon's China Trip Is Sign of Progress on Disputes
description: SYRACUSE, July 19Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that President Nixon would not be planning a trip to China unless major issues between the two powers were already on the way to agreement.

title: RCA Announces Package
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday a new software package for automating backoffice accounting in smaller brokerage houses. It is designed for firms handling up to 3,000 transactions a day.

title: Alberta Oil Output Rises
description: CALGARY, Alberta, July 19 (Canadian Press)  Crude oil production in Alberta averaged 1,067,927 barrels a day during the week ended July 12, the Alberta Energy Resources Conservation Board reported today, up from the previous week's 953,247 barrels a day.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Scott Paper Company announced yesterday the appointment of G. Willing Pepper, vice chairman, as number two man in the company. Mr. Pepper as sumes direction of Scott's corporate planning function law, finance, commercial development, environmental activities, the fibre division and timberlands. The. company selected Paul C. Baldwin, vice chairman, to replace. Mr. Pepper as head of international operations.. Mr. Baldwin was previously chief staff officer. J. Lawrence Shane was named vice president of finance.

title: HOLDINGS BY SWISS IN I.O.S. FUNDS LIGHT
description: GENEVA, July 19Swiss investors hold only a small percentage of the beleaguered Investors Overseas Services mutual fund shares, the Swiss Bankers Association said today.

title: Weatherly Finishes First
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 19 (UPI)Weatherly, the 1962 America's Cup winner, crossed the finish line of the 64th ChicagotoMackinac race first today. However, she did not appear to be the overall victor because of handicapped times for smaller yachts.

title: TROON CAPTURES FIRST CRUISE LEG
New Convict Leaps to Deaths
description: BALTIMORE, July 19 (AP)Barnard Richardson, 26 years old, who was sentenced to 15 years for armed robbery today after being denied a new trial, jumped nine stories to his death minutes later, still handcuffed.

title: Bridge Two California Experts Lead Life Master Pair Title Play
description: CHICAGO, July 19Two California experts led the field at the halfway stage of the Life Master Pair Championship here tonight. Peter Pender of Sausalito and Grant Baze of San Francisco led the field of 168 pairs into the second semifinalsession with a total of 734 match points.

title: CHINA VISAS SOUGHT FOR FIVE DEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Center for the Study of Democratic Institution has applied for visas for five Democratic Senators to visit Communist China after an interparliamentary meeting in Japan next month.

title: MILWAUKEE CHIEF LAUDED BY DALEY
description: MILWAUKEE, July 19Mayor Richard J. Daley of Chicago said tonight that he would nominate the Mayor of Milwaukee, Henry W. Maier, for Vice President at the 1972 Democratic convention if he wants it.

title: IN THE NATION
description: EDMORE, N. D.Less than a megadeath. That's what the report would read if everyone in North Dakota died in atomic war. So when defense planners talk about 30, 40, 50 megadeaths, this sounds rather comfortinglike it would be getting off easy.

title: In Rome, Fall Collections Get Off to Classic but Blas Start...
description: ROME, July 19Fashion brings hundreds of buyers and press people to Rome each summer, but nobody pays very rapt attention to the styles. It's too hot and there are too many diversions.

title: U.S. Feels Little Is New In Saigon's Trace Offer
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The White House appeared to see little new today in a proposal by South Vietnam for a ceasefire and elections to reunite North and South Vietnam.

title: IngersollRand Is Leaving The City for a Jersey Site
description: The IngersollRand Company, one of the country's largest manufacturers of mining and construction machinery, announced yesterday that it would move its executive offices in January from downtown Manhattan to new headquarters at Woodcliff Lake, N. J.

title: CHANNEL 4 APPOINTS NEW NEWS DIRECTOR
description: The National Broadcasting Company has shaken up its local news division, appointing Bernard Shusman director of Channel 4 News. He replaces Richard Graf, who becomes director of N.B.C. news program services, a news and feature syndication operation for some 120 stations.

title: 11 Policemen Slain in May
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)Eleven policemen were killed and 17 injured in criminal asaults in the nation during May, the International Association of Police Chiefs said today.

title: CONILL EARNINGS DROP IN QUARTER
description: The Conill Corporation, the parent company of Chicago's largest bank, reported yesterday a 16.3 per cent drop in operating earnings in the second quarter. The company said the decline was due to losses security trading and a narrowing of the rate spreadthat is the difference between rates received from loans and the costs of acquiring purchased money.

title: PRICES DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING
U.S. Giving Radar Sites to Vietnamese
description: U.S. Giving Radar Sites to Vietnamese VUNGTAU, South Vietnam, July 13The United States Navy is building 16 radar sites for surveillance of ship movements along the coast of South Vietnam and plans to give them to the South Vietnamese Navy by next spring.

title: I.O.C. Lifts Ban on 10 Skiers Paid to Coach at a U.S. Camp
description: MOSCOW, July 19 (Reuters)  The International Olympic Committee tonight cleared the way for 10 of the world's top skiers to take part in next year's Winter Games in Japan.

title: No Official Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON, July 19State Department sources said today that there had been no official confirmation of reports that General Nemeiry had been overthrown.

title: Roundup: Pat Dobson's 12th
description: According to the 1971 Baseball Register published by The Sporting News, Pat Dobson led the Carolina League in wild pitches with 16 while with Durham in 1961.

title: E. I. DU PONT LAGS IN PROFIT RESULT
A.B.A. in a Fog
description: Since the British have done so well in recent years in meaning up their smokeladen air, it ill becomes the American Bar Association and leaders of American jurisprudence to journey to London to generate an enormous verbal smog.

title: POLICE USE AGENTS TO TEST OWN MEN
description: The Police Department has used undercover agents to find out whether its men are soliciting bribes or stealing drugs lrom heroin dealers.

title: Prices in Ceylon Drop
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 19 Ceylonese rubber is facing a serious decline in price following an announcement by the United States that 6,000 tons will be released from its stockpile this week.

title: Times Report of Gallup Poll Contained Incorrect Figures
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The results of a Gallup survey reported in Sunday's editions of The New York Times were reported wrongly in two respects.

title: DOROTHY KUHN OKO, LABOR LIBRARIAN, 75
description: Mrs. Dorothy Kuhn Oko, a librarian was a pioneer in developing library services for the labor movement, died Saturday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. She was 75 years old, the widow of Dr. Adolph S. Oko, former librarian of Hebrew Union College and Spinoza scholar, and a longtime resident of Morningside Heights.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent letterovritten by a group of China specialists from Harvard University implies an equally important questionthe rights of a nation. It involves the territorial integrity of China.

title: Arms to the Middle East
description: A United States intelligence source told a Times reporter the other day that the Soviet Union had sharply stepped up deliveries of jet warplanes to Egypt. The source reported that Egypt had received nearly one hundred MIG21 warplanes from the Soviet Union since last September, including eight delivered in June.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: You write in your July 8 editorial, Britain: The Debate Begins, that it is almost inconceivable that Britain would turn back at this stage from her entrance into the Common Market when the alternative would be grim for herself, Europe and the world. Let us fervently hope she does turn back.

title: Chinese on Way to Ottawa
description: HONG KONG, July 19 (UPI) Huang Hua, first Chinese Communist Ambassador to Canada, left Peking by air today to take up his post in Ottawa, the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, reported. Mr. Huang, a veteran diplomat, was one of the few senior Chinese officials who met Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security affairs adviser, in Peking on July 911.

title: BLEVINS DAVIS, 68, STAGE PRODUCER
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., July 19 (AP)  Blevins Davis, theatrical producer and playwright, died Friday in London. He was 68 years old.

title: STEEL OUTPUT UP SLIGHTLY IN WEEK
Ampex to Market Recorder
description: The Ampex Corporation said yesterday it plans to begin accepting distributor orders for its Instavideo recorder player systems in late summer with production deliveries scheduled before yearend. The system, compact cartridge TV recorder or playback system for instil tutional closedcircuit TV, was first demonstrated in September, 1970.

title: Samuels'
description: Tennis betting, anyone? Howare J. Samuels will be happy to provide the service.

title: One Suspect Pleads Guilty In Bronx Social Club Holdup
description: Augustus Qualls, one of four men charged in connection !with the holdup of a social club in the Bronx last month, pleaded guilty yesterday to robbery in the second degree before State Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Greenfield.

title: Agnew's Comments on Blacks Are Not Upheld by White House
description: WASHINGTON, Juy 19The White House dissociated President Nixon today from Vice President Agnew's complaint that querulous black leaders in the United States do not compare favorably with black officials in Africa.

title: Mets Triumph, 52, Over Cards
IN THE NATION
description: President Nixon's decision to unfreeze relations with China and to visit that country has major significance for American domestic politics. In its initial impact, this diplomatic move is a political triumph for Mr. Nixon. Americans want peace, and no President ever looks better than when he is seen to be working for peace in a large, statesmanlike way.

title: EDWARD W. M'VITTY, WORLD FEDERALIST
description: A private funeral service was held yesterday in the Community Church for Edward W. McVitty, a former Pan American World Airways executive, who resigned to devote himself to the World Federalist movement in 1948. He died at the age of 65 in Presbyterian Hospital, following a short illness, on Friday, five days after his wife, Marion Hazard McVitty, who had been World Federalist representative at the United, Nations.

title: U.S. Aide Defends Pacification Program In Vietnam Despite Killings of Civilians
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The former head of the American pacification agency in South Vietnam acknowledged today that the agency's antisubversion program had resulted in occasional political assassinations and the killing of overcame these occasional Vietcong agents.

title: Coast Crime Committee Urges Legalized Marijuana for Adults
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19The San Francisco Committee on Crime said today that marijuana should be legalized for adults in California, and that it should be withheld from minors.

title: Coney Island Open To Swimming Again As Oil Hazard Ends
description: City officials ordered the main beaches of Coney Island reopened to swimming yesterday morning after tests showed that the spilled oil that fouled the surf for the last four days no longer presented a health hazard, at least for the time being.

title: Acheson, in '62, Lauded Kennedy Action on Cuba
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 19 Former Secretary of State Dean Acheson, who now maintains that President Kennedy lacked decisiveness during the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, at the time congratulated Mr. Kennedy for your leadership, firmness and judgment.

title: Agnew, Leaving Spain, Calls On Juan Carlos
description: MADRID, July 19  Vice President Agnew concluded his threeday official visit to Spain today with unexpectedly long courtesy calls on Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon, the designated successor to Generalissimo Francisco, and on Vice President Luis Carrero Blanco.

title: Canned Goods: Shoppers Are Taking a Long, Hard Look
description: The recent tood poisoning scare has apparently changed the almost automatic reflex shopping habits of many consumers. A number of food shoppers are no longer satisfied with merely glancing at a label before putting canned products into their supermarket baskets.

title: Gleason Seeks Contract for East Coast and Gulf
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 19Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, told the union's international convention here today that money would be of secondary importance in coming negotiations with the shipping industry.

title: Advertising:
description: Lipton Pet Foods (it makes cat foods), a division of Thomas J. Lipton, Inc. (tea, soup, salad dressing, ice cream and noodles), a subsidiary of Unilever (very big in soaps throughout the world), has just gone into test market with a new product.

title: Pakistan Will Try Bengali Leader Soon
description: LONDON, July 19President Mohammad Yahya Khan of Pakistan said in an interview published here today that Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the East Bengali leader, would be put on trial very soon.

title: Ron Johnson Is Giants'
description: BROOKVILLE, LI., July 19 Ron Johnson, the first Giant running back to crack the 1,000yard barrier, has become the first holdout in the National Football League team's 46year history.

title: Harry W. Morrison Dies at 86; Headed Construction Concern
description: BOISE, Idaho, July 19 (AP)Harry W. Morrison, cofounder of one of the world's largest construction companies, died today at the age of 86.

title: DR. JACOB I. STEINBERG
description: Dr. Jacob I. Steinberg, a retired dentist, who was former president of B'nai Zion, fraternal Zionist organization, died yesterday in Lebanon Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 1420 Grand Concourse, the Bronx.

title: Welfare Group Plans Parley
description: PROVIDENCE, July 19 (AP) Dr. George A. Wiley, executive director of the National Welfare Rights Organization, announced today that his group would hold its fifth annual convention at Brown University, July 28 to Aug 1.

title: Teamster Aide Denies Dual
description: Allen M. Dorfman, a special consultant for the teamster union's pension fund, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he obtained a $55,000 kickback on a loan from the pension fund to a textile company. Mr. Dorfman, who is president of the American Overseas Insurance Company in Chicago, was released in $50,000 bail in Federal court here. His trial is scheduled to begin Nov. 15 before Judge Murray I. Gurfein.

title: Brooklyn C.I. Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Defense Department announced today that Pfc. Richard J. Rossano of Brooklyn, of the Army, had been killed in the War in Southeast Asia.

title: ...While on Rikers Island, a Fashion Show Thrills the Inmates
description: It's too bad that Pierre Cardin himself wasn't there. Like most top designers, his collections are usually received by blase New Yorkers with a sprinkling of polite applauSe, and, if it's unusually good, with a few oohs and aahs.

title: Transit Fund Approved
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI)  Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said today that the Senate Appropriations Committee had approved a $1billion program level for the Federal urban mass transit program. The committee's action must now go to conference with the House, which provided a funding level of $800million in the new fiscal year.

title: Cahill Blocks Port Agency Plan For Building $38Million Hotel
description: TRENTON, July 19  Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that he had temporarily blocked the Port of New York Authority from contracting for the design and construction of a $38million hotel at the World Trade Center.

title: Woods Hole Institution Gets $1.65Million for Building
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 19 (AP)The Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution announced today receipt of three foundation grants totaling $1.65million to be used for construction of an education and research building on a new campus in Falmouth.

title: Miss Terry Borinstein Bride Of Simca Holed, Israeli Cellist
description: Miss Terry Borinstein was married in Ramat Aviv, a suburb of Tel Aviv, yesterday to Sinica Heled, first cellist of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra and a member of the Yuval Trio of Israel. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Zevoulon Shadmy at the Orchestra House and was attended by members of the orchestra. The horn section played the wedding march.

title: H.E.W.BUSINGPLAN BARRED BY COURT
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 19 CAP)The first school desegregation proposal filed by the Nixon Administration that would have required extensive busing was rejected by a Federal judge today.

title: Leaders of Phone Locals in the State Turn Down Nationwide Settlement
description: The heads of the New York State locals of the Communication Workers of America, representing 38,500 New York Telephone Company craftsmen, last night rejected the nationwide contract settlement reached by their international union earlier in the day with the Bell System.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: FOURTH MUSQUACOOK LAKE, Me.  In spring and early summer, one has little difficulty taking fat brook trout from this wilderness lake in northern Maine. In July and August, it is another story.

title: Housing Starts Surged in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Housing starts rose again in June to a level just under the Government's target figure of 2 million units a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Mrs. Joseph H. Ziluca, 76, Dies; A Granddaughter of Garibaldi
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 Mrs. Josephine Garibaldi Ziluca, the widow of Joseph H. Ziluca, an architect, and the granddaughter of Giuseppe Garibaldi, the Italian patriot, died today at Greenwich Hospital after a long illness. She was 76 years old and lived in a mansion on Porchuck Road.

title: 28 ARRAIGNED HERE AFTER RAID ON BARS
description: The 28 alleged owners and employes of nine afterhours bars arrested in a joint Federalcity raid early Sunday morning were arraigned in Federal Court here yesterday.

title: TUNNEL FLOOD STOPS L.I.R. BROOKLYN LINE
description: About 1,100 Long Island Railroad commuters were forced to seek alternate means of transportation out of Brooklyn last night when tracks flooded by a rainstorm forced the suspension of service out of the Flatbush Avenue Terminal for an hour as the homebound rush tapered off.

title: Harold J. Arthur, 67, Dies; Once Governor of Vermont
description: PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., July 19 (AP)  Harold J. Arthur, Governor of Vermont in 1950, died early today at the Plattsburgh Air Force Base Hospital of cancer. He was 67 years old.

title: Red China Buys Aluminum
description: VICTORIA, British Columbia, July 19 (Canadian Press)  Alcan Aluminium, Ltd., announced today the sale of 5,500 tons of primary aluminum ingot for immediate delivery to Communist China. The value of the order is between $2million and $3million.

title: Revere to Raise Some Aluminum Products Prices
description: Price increases were announced yesterday on certain aluminum products, vinyl film and sheeting and certain construction equipment.

title: Ideology in Forefront at 7th Moscow Film Festival
description: MOSCOW, July 19The seventh international Moscow Film Festival opened tonight with the accent heavy on Communist ideology and Soviet patriotism.

title: House Votes R.O.T.C. Raise!
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  The House voted today to double the monthly allowance of Reserve Officer Training Corps members. The bill, which goes to the Senate, would set the allowance at $100 a month.

title: EXPERT PROPOSES DRUG DATA BARK
description: WASHINGTON, July 19A national computerized drug data bank was proposed today by Dr. Lawrence V. Vineburgh, trustee for the Washington Reference Laboratory, which performs addiction urinalyses for the Army.

title: DR. DAVID BECK DIES; INTERNIST WAS 83
description: Dr. David Beck, a retired specialist in internal medicine, died Saturday after a long illness in Mount Sinai Hospital, with which he had been associated since 1912 as interne, resident, admitting physician, chief diagnostician and professor at its school of medicine. He was 83 years old and lived at 175 Riverside Drive.

title: Data on SlumArea Frauds Sought Here in U.S. Drive
description: Law students working this summer in the office of United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr., will start collecting evidence this week of consumer frauds against lowincome city residents.

title: Continental Can Net Slips;
description: Strikes, higher operating costs and the sluggish economy reduced results of the Continental Can Company in the three and six months ended June 30 from the record levels of a year earlier, Ellison L. Hazard, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: First 1,600 Tons Sent
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July 19  The recent departure of a British freighter loaded with Malaysian natural rubber bound for the Communist Chinese port of Dairen represents a concrete realization of Premier Abdul Razak's diplomatic initiatives toward Peking.

title: Peking Reiterates Support Of Vietnamese Communists
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, July 20 (Reuters)The official Chinese newspaper, Jenmin Jih Pao, today reiterated Peking's full support for the Vietnamese Communists and warned American imperialists of miserable failure if it persisted in its present Indochina policy.

title: BROOKLYN BISHOP TO ACT ON SCHOOLS
description: Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of Brooklyn said yesterday that he would name a broadly representative commission early next month to assess the serious financial condition facing the 230 Roman Catholic schools in his diocese and to develop possible courses of action, including closing some of them.

title: Accord in Power Strike
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn., July 19 (UPI)  A tentative agreement has been reached in the 21day statewide strike against the Connecticut Light & Power Company by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. Representatives from both sides, joined by state mediators, reached the accord early yesterday after an allnight bargaining session. A company spokesman said details of a oneyear contract were withheld pending a ratification vote this week by seven locals involved.

title: Nixon's Pollution Fight
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19A standard police technique for eliciting information from reticent persons under interrogation is known as the Mutt and Jeff tactic.

title: Brazil Defeats Mexico In Davis CupTennis,32
description: MEXICO CITY, July 19 (AP)Brazil won the American Zone Davis Cup tennis final from Mexico today.

title: Tourists Strain Israel's Capacity and Many Are Turned Back
description: JERUSALEM, July 19Israeli tourism officials have asked nearly 80,000 prospective foreign visitors not to come during the next two months because of inadequate hotel space. The country is in the midst of a tourist boom far exceeding all expectations and planning.

title: ACCORDS REACHED IN PHONE STRIKE AND POSTAL TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Communications Workers of America and the Bell System agreed today on a new contract. Telephone workers were ordered to return to work at midnight tomorrow, ending a weeklong strike.

title: Fuel Agreement Signed
description: The TesoroAlaskan Petroleum Corporation has signed an agreement to supply the Sat Diego Gas & Electric Company with 3 million to 3.5 million, barrels of lowsulphur fuel annually over a threeyear period beginning about April 1, 1972:

title: WILSON, TOP AIDE SPLIT ON MARKET
description: LONDON, Tuesday, July 20Roy Jenkins, deputy leader of the Labor party, last night endorsed the Conservative Government's terms to bring Britain into the European Economic Community.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) A vice president of Northeast Airlines said today the, line would go out of business if the C.A.B. disapproves an application for the merger of Delta and Northeast.

title: Tristate Women's Unit Seeks Women Candidates
description: A mass movement of women in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut cornmitted to finding women to run for political office and supporting their candidacies was announced yesterday by the Tristate Women's Political Caucus.

title: Nerve Gas Being Moved
description: KOZA, Okinawa, July 19 (UPI)The United States today began moving deadly nerve gas from Okinawa to Johnston Island in the Pacific.

title: Lamonica, Svihus Holdouts
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif. July 19 (UPI)Daryle Lamonica, the No. 1 quarterback, And Bob Svihus, the offensive tackle, officially became holdouts today as they failed to appear with other Oakland experienced players at the Raiders camp.

title: Dance: MakarovaNagy
description: A bevy of Giselles over the weekend brought Natalia Makarova together with Ivan Nagy as Albrecht for the first time during American Ballet Theater's current season at the State Theater.

title: BALL WARNS ON RISK IN FLAMBOYANT  TRIP
description: LONDON, July 19Former Under Secretary of State George W. Ball said today that President Nixon's coming trip to China was flamboyant diplomacy that could just as well have been carried out by sending the Secretary of State, and a step that holds risks for the President.

title: Mrs. Israel Registers a 78 To Win Medal by 3 Shots
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., July 19Mrs. Thomas Israel of the Century Country Club won the medal today in the 32d annual championship of the women's Tri County Golf Association. She triumphed by three strokes with 40, 3878 over the 5,938yard, par36, 3874 Brae Burn C. C. course.

title: Pennsylvania Will Fight Gettysburg Tower Plan
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.. July 19 (AP)  Gov. Milton J. Shapp announced today that the state was suing to prevent construction of a 307foot observation tower overlooking the Gettysburg battlefield.

title: MARTIN E. HEALY
description: Martin E. Healy, an accountant with Asiel & Co., stockbrokers, for 50 years, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 6439 A 186th Lane, Flushing, Queens.

title: Floating Down the River Is a Big Attraction in Nation's Wild Areas
description: MOOSE, Wyo.  At the parking lot near the headquarters of Grand Teton National Park, 11 people jammed into a LandRover and rode 15 miles north on Route 89.

title: HARRY S. DICKEY SR.
description: BALTIMORE, July 19Harry S. Dickey Sr., chairman of W. J. Dickey & Sons, textile manufacturers, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Among the wellpublicized consequences of the methadone maintenance approach to heroin addiction ?? that it allows former addicts to secure regular employment. In the course of the past year, however, it has become clear through numerous reports by methadone patients that a disturbing pattern of job discrimination against former addicts exists in New York.

title: Advertising:
description: What, oh what, could it have been that brought an allstar lineup of National Broadcasting Company moguls to Philadelphia yesterday?

title: U.N. SEEKS A ROLE IN SATELLITE DATA
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 19The United Nations has staked out for itself a future space role in utilizing data from satellites to monitor the earth's environment.

title: COPPER FUTURES DROP DAILY LIMIT
description: Prices of copper futures dropped yesterday, with heavy sales, following the first settle. ment in the national copper strike that began nearly three weeks ago.

title: Iraqis Take Action
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19Iraq's border with neighboring Jordan was closed today, and all flights to or from that country were barred.

title: Rights Group Helps Klan Aide in Fight To Regain His Job
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., July 19  The North Carolina Civil Liberties Union is representing a Ku Klux Klan official who is seeking to regain a city government job he lost because of his association with the Klan.

title: Redemptions of Funds Topped Sales in June for 2d Month in Row
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Mutual funds had more redemptions than sales in June for the second straight month, but the net redemptions were somewhat smaller than in May, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: Congress Puts Off Meeting On Extension of Draft Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)  Reinstatement of the draft law by Congress was put off today into at least a fifth week and possibly into September  when HouseSenate conferees called off a meeting to try to break the deadlock over an amendment setting a deadline for an end to the Vietnam War.

title: More Trainers Facing Ban by Westbury Track
description: YONKERS, July 19 As horsemen prepared to pack their gear to leave for the meeting opening at Roosevelt Raceway on Friday, there was a strong feeling tonight that William (Buddy) Gilmour would not be accompanying them.

title: Suspect in Shooting Of Colombo Linked To Gambino Family
description: Jerome A. Johnson, the man who the police say shot Joseph A. Colombo on June 28, was associated with people known to be connected to the alleged Mafia family of Carlo Gambino, Chief of Detectives Albert Seedman reported yesterday.

title: Health Maintenance Units Get $6.5Million for Work
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Nixon Administration announced today that it awarded 66 planning grants totaling $6.5million to health maintenance organizations during the 1971 fiscal year.

title: Mayor Says Gateway Proposal Will Fail Without Cheap Access
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Mayor Lindsay told a House subcommittee today that the proposed Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance of New York Harbor could not succeed unless the Federal Government paid for transportation facilities to let the public get to the area at reasonable cost.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The news from pro football seems redundant. The celebrated Joe Kapp quits the Patriots because his attorney has told him not to sign the standard player contract required by the league constitution. Larry Brown of the Redskins, a lesser celebrity, wants a $100,000 salary. Archie Manning, the Ole Miss quarterback celebrated from Memphis to Mobile, seeks $400,000 from the Saints. Even Errol Mann, the Detroit kicker hardly celebrated at all, has left camp to hold out. Doesn't anybody want to play this game anymore?

title: Wadkins, a Rookie, Has 6Figure Ideas For Pro Golf Tour
description: Lanny Wadkins, who is being honored tonight as a member of the nineman allAmerica collegiate teaiii, says his goal is to win $200,000 as a rookie golf professional.

title: Nixon's Journey Is Discussed by Rogers and Envoys
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Nixon Administration sought today to halt speculation in Congressional quarters that President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Communist China would hasten settlement of the Vietnam war.

title: Court Voids Pennsylvania Law Cutting Aid to Unruly Students
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP)  A special threejudge Federal panel declared unconstitutional today a 1969 Pennsylvania state law that enabled the state to cut off scholarship funds of students involved in campus unrest.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS LEADER IN SOUTH TO RESIGN
description: The executive director of the Southern Regional Council, John Paul Anthony, will resign within the next two weeks, after six years on the job.

title: Old Brooklyn Bank Has Role in Sophia Loren Film
description: The Bank has changed hands. again and temporarily. Two years ago, a community cultural center put new life in the old, vacated building at: No. 1 Front Street in Brooklyn with a bustling program in theater, crafts and films. Then the structure built by the Long Island Safety Deposit Company in 1868, the oldest surviving bank building in New York, was succinctly rechristened The Bank. Then came Mortadella (Baloney), Sophia Loren's new movie.

title: Miss Goolagong Wins
description: LEICESTER, England, July 19 (Reuters)Evonne Goolagong, the Wimbledon champion, was in good form today as she beat Maria Guzman of Ecuador, 60, 64, at the start of the Midlands tennis tournament.

title: NOFAULT PROPOSED FOR PENNSYLVANIA
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 19 Gov. Milton J. Shapp and the state Insurance Commissioner, Herbert S. Denenberg, proposed a nofault automobile insurance plan today.

title: 'Intolerance,' Griffith's Spectacular, On TV Tonight in Near Its Entirety
description: D. W. Griffith's "Intolerance" had its world premiere at the Liberty Theater on the evening of Sept. 5, 1916. It had cost a mind-bending $2-million to produce, starred just about everyone who was ever connected with Griffith, featured dozens of others not then very well known, like Eric Von Stroheim as a Pharisee (whom I've yet to find in the film), and it intercut four different stories of intolerance through the ages, locked together by the image (out of "Leaves of Grass") of a woman (Lillian Gish) rocking the cradle of humanity.The public, which has never liked to have its mind bent, was apparently confused. The film was a financial failure. The critics, who were in awe of Griffith, were respectful of the film, but bored by everything except its spectacle.It is not difficult to find flaws in such a giant work, but they are small flaws, and it is an idiot's pleasure to dwell upon them, as John Howard Lawson once did when he complained that nothing happened to the woman rocking the cradle. Knowing Lawson's ideas, I suppose he would have liked the woman, towards the end of the film, to abandon the cradle to take up arms at the barricades of Babylon, to kneel at the foot of the cross in Jesus's Judea, to throw a cobblestone at Catherine de Medici after the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre, and to be on hand, in the modern sequence, when The Dear One saves The Boy from the gallows."Intolerance," however, doesn't have much to do with the sort of perfectly composed screenplays Lawson analyzes at such length in his "Theory and Technique of Playwriting and Screenwriting." Like all great art, it transcends the theories and techniques that give some order to lesser art.Tonight, almost 55 years after its New York opening, "Intolerance" will be shown for what I'm told is the first time in something approximating its entirety on New York television, beginning at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, as part of the series titled "The Silent Years." An uncommonly genial Orson Welles, who is a great moviemaker himself when he is not voicing the little homilies of Eastern Airlines ("It's impossible to remain a stranger when someone asks you to pass the yams"), is the host for the series that is allowing us to see, at home, some of the greatest films of the silent era ("Broken Blossoms," "The Gold Rush"), as wel as a lot of representative ones, all from the collection of Paul Killam,Although I have some nagging reservations about the manner of this presentation of "Intolerance," which I saw last week on a television monitor at Channel 13, I can't imagine that anyone who has the slightest interest in movies will miss this screening with a good conscience. I'm talking principally to those people who always mean to get to the Museum of Modern Art, and to Anthology Film Archives, but never quite make it.Of historical interest is the fact that the film, which is usually seen in conventional black and white, is being shown here in what are described as the original color tints designed by Griffith. Like so many silent moviemakers, Griffith sought to reinforce the moods of his drama by switching from one tint of color film stock to another, from scene to scene. The tints I saw the other day are lovely  soft blues, ambers, pinksand have the effect of giving mellow life to what Welles rightly describes as the 19th-century theater tradition out of which Griffith came.It is not difficult to marvel at the physical spectacle of "Intolerance"  the Babylonian sequence and Griffith's extraordinary crane shots have never been equalled; nor does it take a film buff to appreciate what has been called (maybe twice too often) the fugue-like structure of the film, the careful tempo of the cross-cutting that finally culminates in a positive orgy of interrelated, simultaneous climaxes, in Judea, Babylon, Paris and "a western American city" in 1916."Intolerance," however, has a lot more than this. It has, among other things, some beautiful performances, particularly by Mae Marsh as The Dear One, a modern strike sequence that is as stark and straight as a Dreiser exposition, and, over all, the sensibility of a romantic, extremely complicated man who, after the racial madnesses of "The Birth of a Nation," came forth with an essay on intolerance, which so often gets away from its subject that, if the title cards were removed, you might forget about intolerance completely.Don't be bothered by those title cards ("The loom of fate weaves death for The Boy's father"). They are part of the literature of an era, and if you find them camp, the fault is not in the film.I'm bothered, however, by two aspects of this showingthe fact that it is accompanied by a busy piano score that I found insistent and intolerable, and not comparable to what I imagine the live symphony orchestra accompaniment to have been originally. It gets awfully cute. I'm also sorry that, because of technical problems, the film has to be projected at the sound-film speed of 24 frames a second, which is why all the characters seem to walk like penguins. The film was shot at speeds varying from 12 to 20 frames a second, which, when properly projected, give as life-like an illusion of action as do contemporary films.I would hope that people coming upon "Intolerance" will take this into consideration. Silent movies did not. in fact, look "funny." If you want to check this out, Anthology Film Archives, located in Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Theater complex on Lafayette Street, will next be showing "Intolerance" in their repertory on Sept. 29 at 8 P.M.

title: U.S. REDS QUESTION CHINA TRIP MOTIVE
description: The Daily World, the major American Communist daily newspaper, said in a frontpage editorial in its weekend edition that President Nixon's planned trip to China is not an alternative to acceptance of the sevenpoint peace program proposed by the Communists at the Paris talks.

title: NEWSMAN RULING APPEALED BY U.S.
description: The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to require a newspaper reporter to appear before a grand jury even if the GoVernment has not shown that there's a compelling need for the reporter's, presence.

title: Nervousness Over the Dollar Among Europeans Continues
description: PARIS, July 19  All the signs point to continued nervousness over the dollar in Europe.

title: Wallace Aide Says Loyalty to Alabama Led to Opposition
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 19The feud between Gov. George C. Wallace and his Leiutenant Governor, Jere Beasley, continued today as Mr. Beasley called a news conference tto discuss his split with the Governor.

title: Markot Place: The Little Guy And His Trades
description: A timeworn theory in Wall Street is that the little guy is always wrong  that he buys at the top and sells at the bottom while institutions and other stockmarket insiders are capitalizing on his mistakes.

title: Nationwide Drive for Abortion Planned in 3Day Session Here
description: Leaders of a national conference on abortion pledged yesterday to pursue a coordinated campaign for the nationwide repeal of all laws against abortion, despite the walkout at their final session, on Sunday, of a caucus that sought to tie the Lesbian issue to the campaign.

title: Howfield, New Jet Kicker, Booms Them Out
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 19 Gloomy gray clouds moved quickly in a strong wind and every so often there was a spatter of rain as the New York Jets practiced today.

title: 17 Rent Advisers Resign; Say City Ignores Them
description: Seventeen members of the 40member Tenants Advisory Council appointed by Rent Commissioner Benjamin Altman resigned yesterday, declaring that he had refused to accept their advice.

title: A Wayward McDowell Fined for Bus Incident
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 19 (AP)  Sam McDowell, the Cleveland Indians southpaw ace, has been fined about $1,000 for rowdyism on the bus that brought the team here from Los Angeles International Airport last Saturday.

title: U.S. Seeks to Halt Sale Of Independence Cruises
description: The Federal Maritime Commission ordered Wall Street Cruises, Inc., yesterday to show cause why it should not cease and desist from arranging travel space on a laidup American Export Isbrandtsen liner the Independence.

title: 2 SOUTH AFRICANS APPEAL ON RACE
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 19Two South African Cabinet ministers called on whites today to show greater respect toward nonwhites and to be prepared for greater emphasis on the Government's African independent homelands policy.

title: HARTFORD TO HOLD TAX SESSION AUG. 5
description: HARTFORD, July 19  The Democratic majority leaders of the Connenticut General Assembly said today that they would reconvene the legislature Aug. 5 to consider repeal of the recently enacted state income tax.

title: Virginia Asks Stay on Order Reapportioning Legislature
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Virginia's Attorney General and the City of Virginia Beach applied today to Chief Justice Warren E. Burger for a stay of a Federal court order reapportioning Virginia's Legislature.

title: Wall St. Phone Service Is Restored After Fire
description: The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday that it was able to restore service before noon to most of the telephones in the Wall Street area that had been knocked out of service by a fire late Monday afternoon.

title: Max Cohen: Boxer Bridges Suez Gulf
description: It probably has been suggested more than once, that, instead of fighting in the ring, Nessim (Max) Cohen would be the ideal person for making peaceespecially in the Middle East.

title: JOBLESS FIGURES CALLED TOO LOW
description: A Bureau of Labor Statistics survey published yesterday indicated that there were far more people out of work in four poverty areas of New York City than customary unemployment figures showed.

title: High Price of Labor Peace
description: The irony of collective bargaining in this period unchecked wageprice inflation is that it becomes increasingly difficult to determine which hurts the economy morestrikes or settlements. That irony is reflected with special force in yesterday's developments in the weeklong national telephone strike.

title: Vice Adm. Harry W W. Hill Dies; An ExAmphibious Commander
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 20Vice Adm. Harry W. Hill, amphibious commander in World War II and the first head of the National War College established in 1946, as well as superintendent of the Naval Academy in 195052, died yesterday of cancer in Naval Hospital here. He was 81 years old and lived in retirement at 201 Prince George Street.

title: MILITARY TRIALS FACE MORE CURBS
description: A 1969 Supreme Court ruling that military jurisdiction was illegal in the trial of nonserviceconnected crimes was applied retroactively yesterday to a 1944 case by a Federal District Court judge here.

title: REORGANIZATION SOUGHT BY ELCOR
description: The Elcor Chemical Corporation of Midland, Tex., which has suffered severe losses in the last year because of depressed sulphur prices, announced yesterday that it had filed under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act for an arrangement with its creditors.

title: 3 Claimants Seek Possession Of El Greco Put at $1Million
description: Three claimants are seeking possession of a painting by El Greco stolen from a mansion in Madrid during the Spanish Civil War and recovered here by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last month.

title: Mr. Wilson's AboutFace
description: There has always been an honorable, defensible case on both economic and political grounds for Britain remaining outside the European Community; but much of the case against entry now being so tortuously constructed by former Prime Minister Harold Wilson is utterly spurious.

title: SENATE, 870, VOTES $18BILLION OUTLAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  After an hour of sparsely attended debate, the Senate passed unanimously today an $18.7billion appropriation bill to finance housing, veterans and space programs. The vote was 87 to 0.

title: Yemen's Premier Resigns
description: ADEN, Southern Yemen, July 20 Mohammed Noman, Premier of Yemen, has resigned, the Sana radio said in a broadcast monitored here tonight.

title: Fischer Trounces Larsen to Take Series
description: DENVER, July 20  Bobby Fischer defeated Bent Larsen in 40 moves in the sixth game of their chess match in Temple Buell College here today. The final score was 60.

title: Market Place: Board to List Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., a member of the New York Stock Exchange for decades, will have its own shares listed on the Big Board next Tuesday and will begin trading under the ticker symbol MER.

title: Bon Vivant's Soup Plant Not Inspected for 4 Years
description: The Bon Vivant soup plant in Newark had not been inspected by the Food and Drug Administration for more than four years nor by the New Jersey Health Department for nearly five years before botulism was traced to a can of its vichyssoise, state and Federal officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: Secrets in the National Review: Memo Disavowed, Clue Given
description: National Review, the conservative weekly magazine, published yesterday, a selection of what it described as highly classified documents dealing with United States involvement in Vietnam, which it said had been leaked to the magazine.

title: Resurrecting the United Nations
description: In a period of history dominated by dangerous conflicts ranging from the division of Europe to the war in Southeast Asia, the United Nations as a politicalsecurity instrument is moribund.

title: Curb on Rainmakers Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The House Commerce Committee approved today a bill to require that rainmakers report their plans to the Commerce Department before tampering with the dynamics of the atmosphere. The measure is aimed at keeping neighboring states advised of cloudseeding efforts. It stipulates a $10,000 fine for anyone convicted of knowingly and willfully failing to file a report.

title: Miss Goolagong Wins
description: LEICESTER, England, July 20 (Reuters)  Evonne Goolagong of Australia was in to form today as she crushed Kris Kemmer of Los Angeles, 61, 63, in the quarterfinals of the Midlands tennis tournament.

title: Du Pont Improves Pension
description: Employes of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. will shortly qualify for vested rights to a deferred pension after 10 years of service, the company announced yesterday. Rights a deferred pension after 15 years was established in 1959.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Raytheon Company announced yesterday receipt of contracts totalling approximately $49.1million from the Federal Aviation Administration for air traffic control automation equipment.

title: Drysdale, Okker Victors
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 20 (UPI)Cliff Drysdale, Tom Okker, Marty Riessen, and Ken Rosewall won firstround matches today in the $50,000 First National tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis event.

title: POINTS ON RADIO DIAL FOR WEATHER LISTED
description: The International Flight Service of the Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday slight changes in the frequencies that provide uptodate weather information at major airports. While primarily intended for transAtlantic pilots, the service is useful for domestic travelers during periods of hurricanes or winter storms.

title: Japan Bank Adds Computers
description: The computerized banking network operated by the Sumitomo Bank of Japan plans to expand its capacity by installing four National Cash Register Century 300 computers over the next 15 months.

title: Man's Body Found in Car Abandoned After Accident
description: A body was found yesterday in the back seat of a car that had been abandoned after it struck a parked car in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Redskins Obtain Gaechter; CowboysGiants Trade Off
description: THOUSANDS OAKS, Calif., July 20 (UPI)The Dallas Cowboys announced today the trade of Mike Gaechter, a safetyman, to the Washington Redskins for an undisclosed draft choice after a previous trade of Gaechter to the New York Giants was voided.

title: Screen: 'Black Peter':Forman's 1964 Movie at Cinema Village
description: Although it opened only yesterday, at the Cinema Village, "Black Peter" was made in 1964 and was the first full-length movie by the Czechoslovak director Milos Formanwho then went on to make "Loves of a Blonde," "Firemen's Ball," and, in America, "Taking Off." I originally saw "Black Peter" six years ago, at the third New York Film Festival, and I didn't much like it. But I liked it a lot when I saw it again the other day, which may prove that anything, even a movie critic, can improve with time.It may prove something else, however; a law I'd never care to formulate, but which might suggest that certain works of art, and especially certain movies, only get to look as good and as individual as they really are after their time has past. "Black Peter" is very much a film of the early nineteen-sixties, of the life styles and movie styles of the time, and when it first played here, I think that many of us had grown prematurely weary of the early nineteen-sixties  and of the era of cultural cross-fertilization that brought the techniques and subjects of the New Wave and the Twist and the bikini to Eastern Europe.But now Forman's obligations, though no less apparent, seem less important. And the style, which had looked like feeble imitation, reveals itself as a personal understanding of a particularly subtle, genial, unassertive kind. "Unassertive" may be the operative word here, for Forman's specialty in "Black Peter" is a comedy so quiet that it sometimes becomes positively mute.Peter (Ladislav Jakim), at the age of 17, takes a job in a supermarket, where he is made store detective. Like Truffaut's Antoine Doinel, to whom he is a kind of inarticulate first cousin, he thus finds himself in a position of considerable low-level responsibility, with which he is completely unable to cope.He arrests no shopliftersthough he does follow one suspicious character all the way home without stopping him because he can't think of what he should say. With similar mastery he courts his girl (Pavla Martinkova) and suffers the lectures on success and manly labor, that are regularly provided him by his father (Jan Ostroil, in an ultimately hilarious performance)."Black Peter" doesn't really have a story, even in the way that Truffaut's Antoine movies have stories, and, given Forman's comic vision, it is proper that it should not. Instead it has a series of events and interconnected anecdotes and a sense, absolutely unassailable, that even behind its most threatening mask, life bares a face of disarming helplessness. "Black Peter" isn't about anything so pretentious as the brotherhood of man, but it acknowledges a brotherhood of man (and women) that is at once consoling and quite sadly funny.For the most part, "Black Peter" is about a small town's summer months, and I cannot remember a film so wonderfully sensitive to summer pleasures. Teen-age dances, swimming in a river, a band concert, luncheons, songs by local talent at the central restaurant. Forman's studies of amateur musical aspiration would in themselves make a movie, and his willingness to value such aspiration at any level of achievement would go a long way toward indicating in what spirit a movie ought to be made.Nobody, finally, can say what he means, and so everybody stumbles into an embarrassed, or merely feckless, silence. This is very funny, but more importantly it is also very true. For in that pause between the gesture and the word, between the intention and the meaning, lies the unspoken, the all but unspeakable awareness of the painful joy of daily living.

title: SHARES OF BRANIFF AND T.W.A. OFFERED
description: Two large offerings of airline shares were marketed yesterday after the close of the stock market.

title: MRS. KALEMKERIAN, ARMENIAN WRITER
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 20 Mrs. Zarouhi Kalemkerian, a leading literary figure of the ArmenianAmerican community in New York for the last halfcentury, died today in the Ridgewood Valley Hospital. She was 97 years old on Sunday and had lived for many years at 400 Fort Washington Avenue in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sato Seeks Closer Peking Ties But Not at Sacrifice of Taiwan
description: TOKYO, July 20Amid growing political repercussions here over President Nixon's forthcoming visit to China, Premier Eisaku Sato has reaffirmed his Government's basic position that it wants to improve relations with Peking but not at the cost of giving up its ties with Taiwan.

title: Highly Praised Federal Mediator
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A fter nearly 24 straight hours of negotiation, contract talks between the United States Postal Service and seven postal unions seemed to be going nowhere early yesterday morning.

title: OddLot Broker Sees Profits Even if Big Board Pares Fees
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A partner in a small securities firm that handles small transactions for less than the fixed price prescribed by the New York Stock Exchange said today that he thought he could still make money even if the exchange's price, which he has to undercut, were lowered.

title: Canada's Royal Trust and Miami Bank in Deal
description: The Royal Trust Company, the largest concern of its kind in Canada, announced agreement in principle yesterday to exchange Royal stock worth about $10.5million in United States funds to acquire the International Bank of Miami. The two concerns noted that a detailed agreement would have to be prepared for the approval of a wide variety of American and Canadian regulatory agencies.

title: Viveca Lindfors Joins Students in Class She Set Up
description: The briskly cheerful voice teacher. faced the ring of 12 barefoot students clad in leotards and holding sheet music from The Fan tasticks. They stood before chairs, whose armrests held notebooks, in a basement studio of the New School. The atmosphere, with an easy Interchange of comments, was relaxed but purposeful.

title: A.T.&T. COMPLETES ITS STOCK OFFERING
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it has completed its offering of $1,375,000,000 of convertible preferred stock.

title: Hogan's Office Enters Inquiry Into City's Slum Loan Program
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan is studying files and interviewing witnesses concerning 16 buildings for which the Municipal Loan Fund of the City lent money for slum housing rehabilitation.

title: 13 Midwestern Governors Split Over How to Get More Money
description: SOUTH SIOUX CITY, Neb., July 20The Governors of 13 Middle Western states agreed today that they each needed more money badly. But they were widely split over whether it would be better to get these funds through the revenuesharing plans of President Nixon or Representative Wilbur D. Mills or through some form of Federal tax credit that would allow them to increase state taxes.

title: City Hall Hearing Is Converted Into a DayCare Center Scene
description: Cheerful young children ate cheese sandwiches and bananas, scrawled bright crayon pictures on manila paper and frisked and tumbled in the aisle of the Board of Estimate chamber at City Hall yesterday. Occasionally one of them bumped into one of the white wooden benches and cried.

title: Executive Changes
description: The United Brands Company announced yesterday that John M. Fox has resigned as president of the Boston based food company. Mr. Fox will assume a high level executive position with another company to be announced in the near future. He will continue as a director and a consultant of the company.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President hand an early morning meeting with Republican Congressional leaders.

title: Woodall Is Good Insurance in Case...
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 20  Al Woodall took the snap from center, cocked and fired the football. Zap, it hit Vernon Studdard, a rookie receiver who wasn't looking, high on the shoulder pad and bounced off his white helmet. This was at the Jets practice here today.

title: Stanton to Retire as President of C.B.S. in 1973
description: Dr. Frank Stanton plans to retire at the age of 65 as president of Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. In anticipation of the date, in March, 1973, he took steps yesterday to strengthen the company's representation in Washington, where he believes most of the major developments affecting TV's future in the next decade will occur.

title: Job Gap Leaves Youths With Little to Do and All Summer to Do It
description: The 17yearold girl sat dejectedly in a Brooklyn office of the State Employment Service yesterday, her patience running out.

title: Promise of Fresh Air
description: Now that New York City is to have one of the most stringent air pollution codes in the country, a serious effort must be made to provide equally stringent enforcement. Up to now it cannot be said that even inadequate laws have been adequately executed.

title: The Trotting Scandals
description: Since the gangster movies of the nineteen thirties, the Mob and fast horses have always been associated, at least in the minds of a large part of the public.

title: 64 SCHOOL AREAS WARNED ON RACE
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A Nixon Administration official said today that 64 Southern and border state school districts had been told that their desegregation plans must be altered to comply with standards set by the Supreme Court.

title: Fiddler Is Saying Hello to a Record
Bettors of Long Shots Clean Up at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, July 20Longshot players in the crowd of 19,518 at Yonkers Raceway tonight rejoiced after the fifth and sixth races as Tarben Lobell and Southern Foyle scored at huge prices.

title: Marine Instructor Is Fined For Exercising of Recruits
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., July 20 (UPI)A Marine drill instructor has been fined $100 and relieved of all recruit training duties as a result of an investigation into alleged exercise periods that hospitalized 39 recruits with a kidney ailment.

title: STATE PHONE MEN TOLD TO STAY OUT
description: About 50,000 Bell System strikers in New York State were told yesterday by their local union officers not to return to work this morning despite a national contract agreement reached Monday between the Communication Workers of America and the utility company.

title: Ban on X Movies Backed
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 20 (AP)  A bill banning the showing of Xrated movies in drivein theaters to protect the public on highways and streets from accidents caused by distractions was passed today by the Pennsylvania Senate. The measure, which now goes to the House, calls for fines of $100 and up to 10 days in jail for each day of a violation.

title: Benjamin Heath Mead, 88, Former Judge in Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 21Benjamin Heath Mead, a former judge here and a 50year member of the American, Connecticut and Stamford Bar Associations, died today at Stamford hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 33 Old Farms Road, Darien.

title: Gold Trading Begins With a Rush to Bid
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20Sell January gold at $59.50, a trader shouted an instant after the 7 A.M. opening bell on the West Coast Commodity Exchange today. Sold, came the instant reply. Then a raucous bluster of bids was sent up by some 20 traders, their arms flailing the air in the body language that implied money.

title: Work on Gettysburg Tower Is Curbed
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 20 Relying on a new and untested environmental quality amendment to the State Constitution, Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania personally obtained a temporary court order here today against the construction of a $1million commercial observation tower at the Gettysburg National Military Park.

title: F.T.C. ROUND IS LOST BY WARNERLAMBERT
description: The WarnerLambert Company lost a round yesterday in its continuing dispute. with the Federal Trade Commission about WarnerLambert's acquisition last year of Parke, Davis & Co. Both concerns are pharmaceutical manufacturers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Draft Lottery Is Scheduled for Aug. 5 as Deadlock in Congress Is M aintained on Extension of the Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Selective Service System announced today that the next draft lottery would be held Aug. 5.

title: JOHN WALDRON, 59, EXHEAD OF CELTICS
description: BOSTON, July 20 (AP)John J. Waldron, former president of the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association, died yesterday at University Hospital, 10 days after undergoing a cancer operation. He was 59 years old.

title: Teacher Found Slain
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., July 201 (AP)  A secondgrade school teacher was beaten and stran1 Bled today in her apartment on1 the edge of the campus of the University of Vermont. TheI police said that the nude body of Miss Rita Curran, 24 years old, of Milton. was found on the floor of her bedroom.

title: NEW JURY STUDIES PENTAGON PAPERS
description: W ASHINGTON, July 20The Government has dismissed Federal grand jury in Boston looking into the Pentagon papers case and replaced it with another grand jury. Government sources said the action was taken because of a leak to the press.

title: CutPrice Salvation
description: In a speech to the National Petroleum Council a few days ago, Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans urged industry to go easy on saving the environment. The title of his talk was Wait a Minute, an injunction addressed not to those who would plunge recklessly ahead with assaults on the country's air, land and water, but to those who would stay their hand.

title: GOTTFRIED DOWNS MOORE IN TENNIS
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., July 20 (AP)Tom Gorman of Seattle and. Ray Moore of South Africa became the first seeded players eliminated in the Tanglewood international tennis tournament today.

title: Campaign Cost Bill Called Up in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The Senate Democratic leadership caught the Republican opposition by surprise today by calling up for Senate consideration the election reform bill designed to limit campaign spending.

title: Cosmos 429 Orbited
description: MOSCOW, July 20 (AP)The Soviet Union has launched another earth satellite in the Cosmos series to continue the exploration of space, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said today. It did not say when Cosmos 429 had been launched. It is orbiting the earth at a height of 125 to 160 miles.

title: Sargent Tax Bill Voted
description: BOSTON, July 20 (AP) The Massachusetts Senate gave final approval tonight to Gov. Francis W. Sargent's third major tax bill filed this session. The principal provision raises the state income tax to 5 per cent from 4.

title: Books of The Times
description: No one looks at the world with pristine eyes, Ruth Benedict said in Patterns of Culturebut right now there are tens of thousands of young people in this country who are trying to do just that. In some two to three thousand communes and communities, they are trying to put aside their habits and prejudices, their very histories, to start from scratch. Or, as some of them would say it, from consciousness. They have succeeded, to a degree, in stopping the world and getting off. No longer content to criticize or satirize the Establishment, they've elected to shut up and put up. Some of them have put up shacks and some geodesic domes. All of them have patched together their own images of man and if these Frankensteins are not conventionally handsome, they're not quite so bad either when you get used to them. In Getting Back Together, Robert Houriet has captured quite a few of them in a wonderfully freaky family album that may make some of us want to revise our own.

title: Air Crash Kills 4 in Family
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., July 20 (UPI)  Four persons were killed today when a private plane crashed seconds after it had taken off from the TriState Airport. The victims were identified as Robert S. Oxnard, 52years old, of Ashland, Ky., his wife, Dorothy, 47; their daughter, Dorothy, 11, and a grandaughter, Denise Oxnard, 4, of Alexandria, Pa. It was the third fatal plane crash at the airport here in the last nine months.

title: Chicago Edison Up
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the first half.

title: WILLIAM MURRAY, 50, OF INVESTMENT FIRM
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., July 20  William J. Murray, manager of the New York bond department or Elkins, Morris, Stroud & Co., Philadelphia and New York investment securities house, died last night in the Lawrenceville Hospital after a long illness. He was 50 lyears old.

title: Wilson Denounces Laborites Who Favor Joining Market
description: LONDON, July 20Harold Wilson, in an agitated speech, tonight denounced his fellow Labor party members who support British entry into the European Common Market.

title: 5 Indicted in Suffolk for Usury; One Cited Is a Reputed Mafioso
