description: RIVERHEAD, LI., July 20Five men, including the reputed head of the Joseph Bonnano Mafia family, have been indicted on loansharking charges.

title: Grant Rushing to Clinch Giants'
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 20The old and the new Giants, 71 strong, bumped heads, arms and elbows for the first time today at their sprawling training grounds at C. W. Post College.

title: Panther's Wife Held in May 19 Shooting
description: The commonlaw wife of a former Black Panther leader held in a Bronx holdup was held in $100,000 bail and questioned yesterday as a material witness in the machine gun shooting May 19 of two policemen who were guarding the home of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bishop Shot in Miami
description: MIAMI, July 20 (UPI)  The Most Rev. Robert L. Hoddap, 60 years old, Roman aCtholic Bishop of Belize, British Honduras, was reported in serious condition today after being shot a nthe back in an apparent robbery attempt. Bishop Hoddap, Sti native of Mankato, Minn., has been visiting Miami.

title: CITY CONTROL FACED BY ABORTION CLINICS
description: The Health Department would be given the power to register abortion clinics and to shut them down if they failed to meet standards, under regulations published yesterday in the City Record.

title: Israelis Fire at Cairo Jets
description: TEL AVIV, July 20 (Reuters)  Israeli forces opened fire twice today on Egyptian aircraft that crossed the Suez Canal and flew over Israeli positions on the eastern bank, a military spokesman reported.

title: Homes Evacuated as River Rises
description: MOREHEAD, Ky., luly 20 (UPI)Army engineers said tonight that danger of a spillover at a temporary coffer dam was imminent.

title: Mine Roof Blamed in Mishap
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  Robert O. Swenarton, a Bureau of Mines official charged today that inadequate shoring of a mine roof in eastern Kentucky, was responsible for a cavein that killed three men last Friday. The roof fall occurred at the small mine of the Hilmar Coal Company in Ashers Fork, Ky. The three miners were loading coal when the roof collapsed.

title: Donohue's Watkins Glen Goal: Third Weekend Racing Sweep
description: If Mark Donohue is not already marinated in champagne as the result of his second brace of consecutive victories (USAC and TransAm July 34, TransAm and USAC July 1718), he will get another opportunity this weekend at Watkins Glen, N. Y. The occasion is a twoday, $100,000 doubleheader of extraordinary interest that only the upstate track can bring off  the Watkins Glen Six Hours of Endurance on Saturday, last of the 11race schedule for the world manufacturers championship, and a CanAm on Sunday, fourth of the 10race, $1million series for Group 1 sportsracing cars.

title: Part of Coney Island Beach Still Closed to Swimmers
description: A portion of the Coney Island beach was still closed to swimmers yesterday because of traces of the oil that fouled the beach late last week and forced its closing Friday.

title: BLACK H.U.D. AIDE CRITICAL OF AGNEW
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) A young Negro member of the Nixon Administration criticized Vice President Agnew today for his remarks on black leadership and said he was aware that his words could cost him his $21,000ayear job.

title: ELVIN SIMMILL, 65, A JUDGE IN JERSEY
description: WALL TOWNSHIP, N. J., July 20 (AP)Superior Court Judge Elvin R4 Simmill died today at his home after a long illness at the age or 65.

title: Priests Back Black Bishops
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 20 (UPI)  Thirty white Roman Catholic priests have issued a statement urging the church to appoint more black bishops to work with black Catholics. The priests completed a workshop held at the University of Notre Dame on ministering to the black community.

title: A WOMAN INVESTOR ACCUSES WALSTON
description: An Evanston, Ill., woman who owns Florida orange groves has filed a complaint against Walston & Co., the brokerage house, charging sex discrimination.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEThe United States has decided as a matter of policy that its interests will best be served in Italy by revivification of a unified Christian Democratic party. Therefore it is determined to help press for that party's reorganization prior to the 1973 parliamentary elections.

title: $131,000 Is Paid for a Filly At Keeneland Yearling Sale
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 20 (UPI)A filly sired by Damascus out of Oak Cluster brought the top price of $131,000 today in the third session of the Keeneland summer thoroughbred yearling sale.

title: CityCounty Unity Urged at Conference
description: MILWAUKEE, July 20  The mayors of the nation's largest cities and representatives of the nation's counties agreed today that despite differences on some major questions, they had to cooperate to win major legisla tive victories in Washington.

title: 3 and 6 Months Rise
description: Revenues and earnings of the Xerox Corporation in the quarter and six months ended June 30 were the highest of any quarter or halfyear in its history, the midyear report from the company's Stamford, Conn., headquarters disclosed yesterday.

title: CAHILL BROADENS PORT UNIT QUERIES
description: TRENTON, July 20  James C. Kellogg 3d, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, paid an unscheduled visit to Gov. William T. Cahill today to discuss the Governor's veto of an 800room hotel at the World Trade Center.

title: Wheat Is Piled in Street As Result of Rail Strike
description: STAPLETON, Neb. July 20, (Reuters)Wheat was piling up today on the main street of this western Nebraska farm town because the strikebound Union Pacific Railroad was unable to move the grain to market.

title: FRIENDS OF F.B.I. IN A FUND APPEAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The Friends of the F.B.Ian organization formed to combat criticism of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and J. Edgar Hooverreports an excellent response to the several hundred thousand requests it has sent out for taxdeductible contributions.

title: Allende Affirms Policy After Vote Defeat
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 20 President Salvador Allende Gossens and his leftwing supporters said today that the Government's defeat Sunday in a congressional byelection would not alter his basic policy of making Chile a socialist country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: Lanvin Parfums which recently parted with Case & Krone following a strategy rift, has token its Arpege to Rosenfeld, Sirowltz & Lawson.

title: British Economic Test
description: LONDON, July 20As Britain tries to move out of the stopgo economic bind that has restrained her economic growth since World War II, there may be some lessons to be learned by the United States.

title: U.N. Gets Soviet Monument
description: GENEVA, July 20  Yekaterina Furtseva, Soviet Minister of Culture, formally donated to the United Nations today an 85foothigh monument hailing man's ventures in space. The monument, on the grounds of the Geneva office of the United Nations, consists of an arching shaft, sheathed in titanium, beside the figure of an astronaut reaching toward the sky.

title: MARKET SPURRED BY EARNINGS DATA
NIXON STAND CITED BY RUCKELSHAUS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20William D. Ruckelshous administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that, so far as he could determine, his relations with President Nixon remain very good.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Someone came into the room... started shakin the chairman. Said chairman, chairman wake upthe Pigs are vampin'. Still half asleep I looked up and I saw bullets comin from it looked like the front of the apartmentfrom the kitchen areathey were... the Pigs were just shootin'. And about this time I jumped on top of the chairman. He looked up looked like all the Pigs just converged at the entrance way to the bedroom areathe back bedroom area. The mattress was just... goin'. You could feel the bullets goin into it. I just knew we'd be dead, everybody in there.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Under heavy selling pressure, soybean prices dropped as much as 7 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Newsmen Get Wider Access to Prisons
description: The state's Department of Correctional Services has issued new guidelines that liberalize access by newsmen to prisons and prisoners.

title: Arms Talk Held in Helsinki
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 20 (Reuters)The United States and Soviet delegations today held the third working session of their latest talks to limit strategic arms. The session, at the Soviet Embassy here, lasted about 90 minutes. The next will he on Friday at the United States Embassy.

title: Admiral Weds Mrs. MacCracken
description: BETHESDA, Md., July 20Mrs. Sallie Lucile Lewis MacCracken, widow of William Patterson MacCracken, the first Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics, was married here this afternoon to Vice Adm. Vincent Raphael Murphy, U.S.N., retired, a widower.

title: GALBRAITH URGES WAGEPRICE CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, called today for permanent Government controls on the prices of the nation's 2,000 largest corporations and on the wage demands of the biggest labor unions.

title: Advertising:
description: For the last three years Gilbert Advertising has been doing advertising for Club Mediterranee, which now offers group fun for vacationers in five different sun spots. That advertising was instrumental in bringing it another client in the same general area. But different, my dears, terribly different. And posh, unbelievably posh.

title: New Sudanese Regime Acts to End Curbs on Reds
description: CAIRO, July 20The new military Government in the Sudan moved today to lift restrictions on the country's Communist movement and abolished Egyptianstyle political formations recently organized by the deposed leader, Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry.

title: ALVIN STOLINSKY
description: BAYONNE, N. J., July 20Alvin Stolinsky, president of Reading Industries Inc., makers of copper and brass tubing, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 90 West 40th Street. He was 52 years old.

title: Coup in Sudan Planned for Months, Leader Says
description: LONDON, July 20  Lieut. Col. Babakr alNur Osman, the newly named leader of the Sudan, said here today that plans for yesterday's coup d'etat had been under discussion since February.

title: G. RAYMOND WOOD
description: SOMERS POINT, N. J., July 20G. Raymond Wood, director of the Southern New Jersey Development Council, died yesterday at his home, 555 Shore Road. He was 58 years old.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES EXPROPRIATION CURB
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee voted today to cut off sugar imports from any nation engaging in uncompensated expropriation of American property in the future.

title: The Sudan Swings Left
description: With the overthrow of General Nimeiry, the Sudan clearly has lurched to the left; but what this will mean in specific policies must await further actions of the new sevenman Command Council. Only two immediate results seem certain: restoration of full freedom of maneuver for the largest Communist movement in Africa and the Arab world, and another setback for Arab unity, already battered by Iraq's break with Jordan and Morocco's charges of Libyan complicity in the abortive coup against King Hassan II.

title: ACF Gets Boxcar Order
description: ACF Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it had received an order from the St. LouisSan Francisco Railway for 350 boxcars costing about $6.8million.

title: Jet Noise in Los Angeles Is Dooming 1,994 Homes
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18The twostory, tileroof house at 8814 Vista Del Mar here seems to have everything: four bedrooms, three baths a huge swimming pool and a spectacular view of the Pacific Ocean.

title: MRS. WOLFGANG JOERG
description: NUTLEY, N. J., July 20Mrs. Hannah Heaton Joerg, widow of Wolfgang L. G. Joerg, the authority on polar geography ;who was chief of the carto!graphic records branch of the National Archives, died yesterday in Clara Maas Hospital, Belleville, after a brief illness. She was 90 years old and lived at 387 Passaic Avenue with a son, Norton C. Joerg.

title: Nixon, Chinaand Wall St.
description: The news of President Nixon's coming trip to Communist China, sensational as it is politically, produced virtually no effect on the stock market. Considering the elation of the President and his closest advisers, the historic importance of this shift in American foreign policy and the enormous play the event was given by the press and television, how can one explain Wall Street's minimal reaction? Was the market simply slow on the uptake? Will a euphoric double take occur later? Or was the financial community wary and doubtful that the President's planned journey was any occasion for joy?

title: Saigon Units Open Drive in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 21  South Vietnam today reportedly launched its largest operation in six months in eastern Cambodia with the announced aim of providing security for the forthcoming South Vietnamese elections.

title: Shellings Reported By Syria and Jordan Near Fedayeen Base
description: RAMTHA, Jordan, July 20Syria and Jordan reported today exchanges of artillery fire at the border here as Arab wrath mounted in the wake of Jordan's offensive against the Arab commandos.

title: Angela Davis Indictment Scored As Result of an Unfair System
description: SAN RAFAEL. Calif., July 20 Attorneys for Angela Davis argued today that the indictment against her for murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy should be dismissed.

title: Miss Beard Upsets Miss Bastanchury In Golf by 2 and 1
description: CHICAGO, July 20 (AP)Kaye Beard of Campbellsville, Ky., pulled a major upset today by eliminating the defending champiop, Jane Bastanchury, in the first round of the women's Western amateur golf tournament.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CHICAGO, July 20At just about half past 1971, The Tormentor Who Never Rests sat at his fiery desk in his nethermost den and wrote in his diary.

title: David Kennedy to Resume Textile Parley in Far East
description: WASHINGTON, July 20President Nixon sent his Ambassador at Large for trade matters, David M. Kennedy, to the Far East today for new discussions on possible voluntary limits on exports of textiles to the United States.

title: Cowles Phasing Out Units Related to Magazine Sales
description: Five subsidiaries of Cowles Communications, Inc., that sell magazines on an Installment basis have begun a program designed to phase out their operations. The companies are Home Reader Service, Educational Book Club, Civic Reading Club, Home Reference Library and Mutual Readers League.

title: M'NAMHARA APOLOGY TO YAHYA REPORTED
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 20 President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan was reported today to have received a letter from Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, expressing regret over the unauthorized publication in the American press of a World Bank report on the situation in East Pakistan.

title: GATE IS PROPOSED IN STEEPLECHASE
description: A starting gate for jumping races, that's what racegoers may see when the New York Racing Association moves its cavalry circus to Saratoga for a 24day meeting starting Aug. 2.

title: Rauch, in Conflict With Bills'
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 20 (AP)John Rauch resigned unexpectedly today as head coach of the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League.

title: Countdown Under Way For Monday Moon Shot
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 20 (UPI)Two years after man first landed on the moon, the countdown started today for next Monday's launching of Apollo 15, the most ambitious lunar voyage yet.

title: C. P. A.'s Propose Tighter Rules On BrokerageFirm Accounting
description: The accounting profession announced here yesterday a proposed tightening of the disclosure requirements of brokerage houses in reporting their financial condition.

title: Connally Presses Lockheed Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr. said today he had high hopes that Congress would act to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from the threat of bankruptcy before starting its summer recess Aug. 6.

title: CHOU EIVIPHASIZES U.S. WAR PULLOUT
description: PEKING, July 20  Premier Chou Enlai has told a group of American graduate students that a complete withdrawal of United States forces from Indochina must take priority over moves to improve ChineseAmerican relations.

title: Oil Gains Top 13%
Backers of Palestinians Denounce Hussein Here
description: The police arrested 10 supporters of the Palestinian guerrillas yesterday after a crowd of 30 tried unsuccessfully to get inside the Jordanian mission to the United Nations to protest King Hussein's crackdown on the guerrillas.

title: Firestone Plans Split
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company yesterday announced plans for a twoforone split of its common stock. Directors also said they intrnd to increase the quarterly dividend rate, after the split, to 21 cents a share. On the present stock the company has been paying 40 cents a share.

title: 4 to Test DeepSea Living in a Pressure Chamber
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP)Four young men plan to enter a highpressure chamber at the University of Pennsylvania Medical Center next week for studies that may Indicate the depths to which man may some day dive into the sea.

title: REAGAN FOE ELECTED TO SENATE ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES. July 20 (AP) Democrats tightened their control of the California Legislature tonight when a Democrat opposed to Gov. Ronald; Reagan's programs won a special State Senate election here.

title: 'Taki 183' Spawns Pen Pals
description: Taki is a Manhattan teenager who writes his name and his street number everywhere he goes. He says it is something he just has to do.

title: Ballet: Stuttgart Returns
Taiwan Stand on U.N. Seat Held Key to U.S. Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Foreign diplomats engaged in consultations with the Nixon Administration said today that the United States hope of keeping Nationalist China in th United Nations might collapse if Taiwan failed to indicate soon how it would react to the anticipated admission of Peking this fall.

title: CHALLENGE FILED ON PAROCHIAL AID
description: Opponents or public aid for parochial schools tiled a Federal law suit yesterday challenging the constitutionality of a $33million education bill approved last month by the State Legislature.

title: Behavioral Expert Is Named To Conant Chair at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassJuly 20  Chris Argyris, an authority on organizational behavior, has been named James Bryant Conant Professor of Education and Organizational Behavior in the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

title: Notes on People
description: Roger W. Heyns, who was chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley for six stormy years, until his resignation last month, has been appointed president of the American Council of Education.

title: The Making of a Myth
description: MEDFORD, MassIn its Pentagon disclosures the press has fallen into the same trap as those who overclassified the study in the first place. Because of its secrecy, the press has treated the study as if it contained astounding revelations, and has conveyed that view to the public. This obscures the simple fact that the Pentagon Papers provide minimal new information and raise more questions than are answered.

title: Neil Armstrong's Town, Two Years Later
description: WAPAKONETA, Ohio, July 20It was almost an ordinary summer's day in this quiet, unassuming town, whose most famous son, Neil A. Armstrong, took man's first steps on the moon two years ago today.

title: House Panel Backs $3.4Billion in Aid; Blocks Reform Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A foreign aid authorization of $3.44billion for the current fiscal year was approved today by the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The amount comprised $1.43billion for economic development loans and grants and $2.01billion for military aid grants and sales on credit.

title: JACK B. VICHINSKY
description: Jack B. Vichinsky, an industrial engineer and past grand chancellor of the Knights of Pythias of the State of New York, died yesterday in his sleep at his home, 1637 42d Street, Brooklyn. He was 61 years old.

title: A CONVICT ADMITS $21MILLION THEFT
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A 29yearold convict told a Senate investigating committee today that he was, as another convict had testified last month, one of the two men responsible for a $21.5million mail theft at Kennedy International Airport in 1968.

title: U. S. Ready for Ties
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 State Department officials said today that there was no reason to believe the coup in the Sudan would affect United States efforts to achieve a Middle East settlement.

title: This Show Is Great Fun, But It's Rated X for Adults
description: First you go into this store that is selling all these birthday cards and party favors and you go down some stairs and ZOWIE.

title: EDUCATION BOARD TO STUDY DRUG USE
description: The Board of Education is planning to make its own study of the extent of drug abuse among pupils here as part of a planned steppedup attack on the problem, Isaiah E. Robinson, the board's president, said yesterday.

title: Joint Panel on Environment
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP)  The House approved today a joint Committee on Environment. The resolution would set up a committee of 11 Representatives and 11 Senators, with the chairmanship rotating every two years between the two branches.

title: Westbury Bars 7 Drivers Tied To Harness Race Investigation
description: WESTBURY, L.I, July 20William (Buddy) Gilmour, Carmine Abbatiello, Ben Webster and four other trainerdrivers have been told by Roosevelt Raceway to go elsewhere when the track opens its summer meeting Friday night.

title: THOMAS RICCOBONO
description: Thomas Riccobono, an assistant state attorney, general, died apparently of a heart attack while on his way to his office at 80 Centre Street Monday morning. He collapsed on the elevated platform of the B.M.T. at Queens Plaza, Long Island City. He was 64 years old and lived at 2110 33d Road, Long Island City, Queens.

title: Vietcong Warn U. S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (UPI)The Vietcong said today that the United States should deal directly with the Vietnamese instead of sending diplomats scurrying around the world to enlist support for an imposed solution to the Indochina war.

title: Court Action Sought in Pier Cleanup
description: An Army Corps of Engineers official said yesterday that the agency had asked the three United States Attorneys whose jurisdictions cover New York harbor to look into the possibility of taking action against the owners of 97 deteriorating piers here.

title: MARGARET RIBBLE, PSYCHOANALYST, 80
description: Dr. Margaret A4 Ribble, a (psychoanalyst and author, who had specialized in the psychology of young children, died (Monday in Warrenton, Va., while on a visit. She was 80 years old and lived at 12 West 12th Street.

title: Bison Spread Out on 3Acre Prairie, Their New Home at Bronx Zoo
description: Eleven American bison at the Bronx Zoo moved yesterday into their new threeacre home, a prairie created over a threeyear period by landfill in what once was the zoo's Lake Agassiz.

title: Wallace Is Shocked by Nixon's Trip
description: WASHINGTON. July 20 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that he would be delighted if President Nixon's announced visit to Peking pays off in world peace, but he added, I have my doubts.

title: WILSON'S SLOOP WINS IN CRUISE
Life Is an Uphill Struggle for the Latins in Paterson
description: PATERSON, N. J.  Close up, it could be Santo Domingo or Santurce or Cali on a hot summer night. The streets are steamy and crowded, spicy tropical smells waft from the kitchens, and the bars and street corners are amurmur with Spanish jokes and flirtations.

title: YIELDS OFF A BIT IN BOND MARKET
Article 1  No Title
description: I was born in a socalled bourgeois community and had some of the better things you could say of life. And I found that even some of the better things of life for black people wasn't too cool. And I found that there was more people starvin than there was people eatin'. And I found there was more people didn't have clothes than did have. clothes.. And I found that I just happened to be one of the few. And I made a commitment to myself that I wouldn't stop doin what I'm doin until all those people were free.

title: Canadian Oil Issues Are Strong on Amex
LEFKOWITZ CHARGES LANAI PRICE RIGGING
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz disclosed yesterday what he described as a fraudulently coordinated manipulation of the price of an overthecounter security by known underworld figures that had cost the public and members of the New York Stock Exchange more than $100,000.

title: SENATE REJECTS ATOM TEST DELAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The Senate refused today to delay an underground nuclear explosion this fall in the Aleutian Islands, which the Defense Department said was intended to test a key element in the Safeguard antiballisticmissile system.

title: Teacher's Sex Change Stirs Contract Review
description: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 20 (AP)An elementary school music teacher changed sex from male to female during the last school year and is having her contract reviewed by the local school board.

title: GASOLINE EXCHANGES DESCRIBED TO PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The president of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio told a Senate panel today that oil companies, including his own, sometimes supply each other with gasoline when the need arises.

title: MOSCOW AFFIRMS ITSTILL OPPOSES INDOCHINA PARLEY
description: MOSCOW, July 20  The Soviet Government today affirmed support for Communist China's admission to the United Nations and opposition to art international conference on Indochina.

title: Roundup: No.1 Fan Sees Senators Win
description: There are 45,016 baseball seats in Washington's Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium. Last night 3,887 of the seats were in use, including three by the nation's first family.

title: Polish Party Plans to Purge Opportunists
description: WARSAW, July 20  Last December, when Poland's Baltic ports were exploding in revolt, a Warsaw worker paused over lunch one day to list his complaints, and presumably those of the workers then sealed off on the coast.

title: New Brooklyn College Post
description: Dr. Sherman Van Solkema, chairman of the music department at Brooklyn College, has been named to the new post of vice president of the college. His duties will include longrange planning and helping to coordinate the academic reorganization of the college into six schools.

title: NEW YACHT TAKES MACKINAC HONORS
Insurance Leader to Retire
description: The head of the nation's 14th largest life insurer, the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company, has announced plans to retire. John J. Magovern Jr., who reached the mandatory retirement age of 65 earlier this year, said he would retire at the end of the year as president and chief executive officer.

title: 6 SHOT TO DEATH IN WISCONSIN CITY
description: SHEBOYGAN, Wis., July 20 (UPI)Two widows and three young sons of one of the women were found shot to death in their homes less than a block apart. The police said the 19yearold son of the second woman was being held as a material witness in protective custody.

title: GERTRUDE LANG
description: MARATHON, Fla., July 20 (UPI)Gertrude Lang, a light opera singer on Broadway in the 1920's and 1930's, died last Wednesday at the age of 73.

title: Counterfeit Money Seized
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) The Secret Service said today it had seized $4million in counterfeit $100 bills at Philadelphia International Airport and arrested the owner and an employe of a printing firm. Arrested were. Claude Forte, 34 years old, of Springfield, and Robert Osborne, 26, Philadelphia.

title: Director of Soviet Film Festival Rules Out the Publicity Seekers
description: MOSCOW, July 20  The head of the Moscow Film Festival told Soviet readers today that movie festivals should he regarded as serious ideological confrontations between bourgeois and Communist views of art and not as places for movie stars to attract publicity.

title: CONFLICT FEARED ON SUBWAY RULES
description: The chairman of the Mayor's special panel studying the tunnel fire in the IRT subway last Friday said yesterday that current emergency procedures were subject to misinterpretations which could lead to conflicts.

title: Sugar Harvest in Cuba Short of Goal 6th Year
description: MIAMI, July 20 (UPI)Cuba ended her 1971 sugar harvest today with a total production of over 5.92 million tonsabout one million tons short of the goal that Premier Fidel Castro set in December.

title: Prices Raised By 6% At Kaiser Aluminum On Some Products
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation yesterday joined the ranks of other companies that have recently announced price increases on certain aluminum products. The company said its increases would average about 6 per cent, effective Sept. 1. Revere Copper & Brass, Inc., made a similar announcement on Monday.

title: Water Pipes Ordered in Rail Tunnels
description: The Penn Central was ordered yesterday to install standpipes for fire protection in its four East River tunnels, which are used principally by the Long Island Railroad.

title: Holzman Will Continue In Dual Job for Knicks
description: The New York Knicks announced yesterday that Red Holzman would continue as coach and general manager of the team through the 197172 National Basketball Association season.

title: MARTIN S. HOUSE, SPECIAL COUNSEL
description: Martin S. House, a lawyer who as special counsel to the State Insurance Department investigated abuses in unionmanagement welfare and pension funds and helped draft legislation to correct them, died Monday of a heart attack at his home, 969 Park Avenue. Ha was 66 years old.

title: MAIL UNIONS GAIN $1BILLION RAISE IN TWOYEAR PACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 The United States Postal Service and seven postal unions signed today a contract covering more than 650,000 workers the first collective bargaining agreement in the history of the post office.

title: Gold Trading Examined
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (Reuters)  The Treasury has begun a formal investigation into gold futures trading by the West Coast Commodity Exchange that could lead to prosecution by the United States Attorney, a Treasury spokesman said today.

title: Colombo's Son Condemns Police View of Shooting
description: The Police Department was bitterly attacked by Anthony Colombo yesterday for going the scapegoat route in asserting that the shooting of his father erupted out of a power struggle within the Mafia.

title: Dr. Isidore Lattman, 77, Pediatric Radiologist, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, July 20Dr. Isidore Lattman, chief pediatric radiologist at the Children's Hospital here, died yesterday at Suburban Hospital, Bethesda, Md., of complications resulting from a fall. He was 77 years old and lived at 2800 Woodley Road, N.W.

title: Embargo Is Placed On Horse Shipments
description: The New York Racing Association yesterday placed an embargo, until further notice, on horses shipping into Saratoga, Belmont Park and Aqueduct from 11 states, Mexico, Central America and portions of South America.

title: Chemical Concern in Texas Sued by U.S. on Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The Justice Department filed suit today against Rohm & Haas Company, a 'Texas chemical manufacturer, to halt alleged pollution of the Houston ship channel.

title: ARMY SET TO BURN TONS OF WAR GAS
description: DENVER, July 20The Army completed today the last of its tests on equipment to be used in disposing of 3,071 tons of mustard gas stored since World War II in steel cylinders at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal

title: BRIDGES EXPECTS LONG COAST TIEUP
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 20Harry Bridges, president of the striking International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, told delegates to the International Longshoremen's Association convention here today that he expected his union's 21dayold tieup of West Coast ports to go on for two or three more months.

title: 2 in House Say U. S. Hides Extent of C.I. Drug Use
description: WASHINGTON; July 20Two Representatives who recently visited Vietnam and reported that heroin users made up 10 to 15 per cent of all American servicemen there accused the Nixon Administration today of trying to sweep the problem under the rug.

title: U.S. and Britain in Accord To Exchange Planning Data
description: LONDON, July 20  The United States and Britain agreed today to a regular exchange of information in the field of planning and community development.

title: Nixon Says His Preference On Convention Site Is Open
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) President Nixon told Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, chairman of the Republican National Committee, that he had no personal preference today as to the site for the party's national convention next year.

title: The Big Message From Rome: Real Clothes Are Back in Style
description: ROME, July 20The message on the runways, as the Italian highfashion showings chug along, is that real clothes are back. But the men's undershirt is the most popular style among the spectators. The women spectators, of course. The English girls pick them up on Carnaby Street for about a dollar in the most extraordinary colors. They suspect that they were originally men's white undershirts because the dye appears on the label, too.

title: Bridge : Roth and Barbara Rappaport Lead in Life Master Pairs
description: CHICAGO, July 20One of the world's strongest mixed partnerships led the field of 84 pairs into the final session of the life master pair cliampionship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here tonight.

title: Industrial Operations Put at 73% of Capacity
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The nation's manufacturers operated on average at 73.2 per cent of capacity in the second quarter, little changed from the low level of the first quarter, the Federal Re serve Board reported today.

title: An Experimental Safety Vehicle Will Be Built by Ford for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Government will pay the Ford Motor Company a token one dollar to build an experi, mental safety vehicle, under terms of a contract signed today by Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe and Henry Ford 2d, chairman of the board of the Ford company.

title: Mrs. Florence S. Anspctcher, Papp Theater Benefactor, Dies
description: Mrs. Florence Sutro An spacher, whoss? 1959 gift of $10,000 was decisive in estab lishing free summer Shake speare performances In Cen tral Park, died yesterday at her dome, 171 West 57th Street, after a long illness. The widow of Louis K. Anspacher, play wright, poet and lecturer who died in 1947, she was 84 years old.

title: PRICES ARE DOWN IN CORN FUTURES
description: Corn futures prices for the more distant contracts contin ued downward on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday aft er the July delivery dropped to almost 8 cents a bushel.

title: Amateurs Leading Field as 21 Seek to Be Jersey City Mayor
description: JERSEY CITY, July 21City Clerk Thomas F. X. Smith looked at the 35,000 new nomi nating petitions that had just arrived from the printers today and said, We may need two voting machines if this election comes off.

title: Museum Acquiring Figurine for Cross
description: In a deal with an unprece dented safety clause, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Oslo Museum of Ap plied Art have entered into an agreement by which the two parts of a major work of art, formerly divided be tween the two institutions, will be reunited as the prop erty of the Metropolitan.

title: BLACK SCHOOLS GET AID FROM FORD FUND
description: Howard University and At lanta University, two of the country's major predominantly black universities, were each the recipients yesterday of $1.75million grants from the Ford Foundation to help finance graduate social science pro grams.

title: Trevino Wit as Dry as Links
Article 3  No Title
description: BONN, July 21 (Reuters)The Government today an nounced proposals to prevent large German and international companies from adding to the flow into West Germany of speculative money, particularly dollars, having an inflationary impact on the economy.

title: Detroit Seeks Negro Police
description: DETROIT, July 21 (AP) The Detroit Police Department has set a goal of 45 per cent black officers by 1980, it was announced today by the de partment's director of person nel and placement, Thomas G.. Ferrebee. The department's current percentage of black policemen is 13 per cent, Mr. Ferrebee said. To meet the goal, he said, five of every eight re cruits from now till 1980 will have to be black.

title: Crew of Apollo 15 Is Fine for Launch
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 21The Apollo 15 astronauts passed their preflight medical examinations with flying coi 1 ors today and continued prep arations for the launching of their moonlanding mission at 9:34 A.M. Eastern daylight time next Monday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a physician directly involved in cancer research, I have ambivalent feelings about the proposed Conquest of Cancer agency. On the one hand, I feel that its creation will be instru mental in moving us closer to discov ering not a cure but cures for cancer, which is a multifaceted pathologic con cept that encompasses many types and classifications. At the same time I feel that its creation has strong po litical incentive and that the American people should be aware of these mo tives before accepting them as altru istic on the part of President Nixon, Senator Javits and others. [Editorial July 11.]

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 21There is a striking difference between the re actions in this country and in China to President Nixon's announcement of his forthcoming visit to Peking. Here there are banner headlines, an out burst of optimism about the future and warm congratulations for the President,

title: GIEREK SAYS WEST HAS CONFLICT, TOO
description: WARSAW, July 21Edward Gierek, the Communist party leader, told the nation's restive youth today that problems at home sh,,uld be weighed against the serious economic, moral and social shortcomings of capi talist society.

title: Eurodollar Borrowings Fall
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (Reuters)  Eurodollar borrow ings by United States banks dropped $453million in the week ended July 14 to 1,722, 000,000 outstanding, the Fed eral Reserve reported. The de cline followed a $750million increase the week earlier and the new balance outstanding indicates a $103million upward revision in the balance reported last week.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Oklahoma View Is Similar
description: In Oklahoma, the state elec tion board secretary, Lee Slater, has advised county election of ficials that residence require ments for students are the same as those for others.

title: Winthrop Rockefeller Thinks Nation Wastes Its ExGovernors
description: WINROCK FARM, Ark., July 19The United States wastes its former Governors, according to Winthrop Rockefeller, the Republican former Governor of Arkansas.

title: Aiding Beleaguered Industries
description: After he was canned earlier this year as creative director of the Al Paul Lefton Com pany, Joseph A. Viverito didn't even look for another agency spot. He had another thing in mind.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 21Kiyo Tanabe of Japan, a student at Oral Roberts Uni versity in Tulsa, Okla., upset fifthseeded Len Schloss of Baltimore today, 62, 64, and reached the quarterfinals of the Port Washington open tennis tournament with Gene Scott of New York and Tony Pala fox of Port Washington.

title: Personal Finance
For Some, Life Begins With Lost Job
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21When Robert Hansen, physicist, was laid off from his aerospace job in Janu ary, 1970, he was in the same situation as thousands of other scientists and engi neers put out of work by the recession in the industry. Soon, though, he began to see his predicament as an oppor tunity.

title: 90,000 Phone Strikers Defy BacktoWork Orders of Leaders
description: About 90,000 striking Bell System telephone workers yes terday defied backtowork or ders by their national union leaders.

title: George Hamilton Stars in Evel Knievel
Gleason's Control Is Discussed Behind Scenes at I. L. A. Parley
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 21 Beneath the speeches and other routine business of the 42d convention of the International Longshoremen's Association lie a host of problems that face not only the union, but alsoand especiallyits president.

title: S.E.C. Wins Memorex Curb
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday in Washington that a New York Federal District Court had granted its request for a per manent injunction against the Memorex Corporation and two principals. The S.E.C. had ac cused them of violations of the antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws. Memorex said it had agreed to the consent judgment, noting that the company has already adopted a form report and an account ing method acceptable to the S.E.C.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Sunlight filtered through the oak trees into Barn 9 Belmont Park, illuminating the devil's red and blue motif of Calumet Farm.

title: Pakistan Accuses India
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 21  The Pakistani Government charged today that Indian artil lery shelled Comilla, a town in East Pakistan, yesterday and killed a number of persons. A brief Government announce ment said shells had destroyed a number of shops, killing an unspecified number of persons and wounding many others. Comilla, southeast of Dacca, the provincial capital, is almost on the Indian border,

title: Mayor Hails Fiddler At 2,845th Performance
description: Last night, after Fiddler on the Roof had given its 2,845th performance, making it the longestrunning mu sical ever on Broadway, Mayor Lindsay walked on the stage and said that two years from now, he's going to play the leading role in the show.

title: Mets Beaten,117, Despite 19 Hits
description: CHICAGO, July 21Not even their highest hit total of the year could save the New York Mets today as their pitchers gave up runs faster than the batters could make them, the result being an 117 loss to the Chicago Cubs.

title: 400 Searching for Boy Lost in Adirondacks
description: NEWCOMB, N.Y., July 21 More than 400 people, ranging from expert woods men to longhaired students, tramped methodically through the Adirondack Mountain forests today in search of 8yearold Douglass Legg, who went for a walk near here 12 days ago and has not been heard from since.

title: Tax Bill Voted in Bay State
description: BOSTON, July 21 (AP) The Massachusette legislature accepted a compromise bill to night proposing $187million in new taxes. The House accepted the compromise version on a voice vote with no debate. The Senate approved it on a 22to 12 rollcall after about two hours of debate.

title: In a Tudor Ballet, Psychological Complexity
description: Will Caroline pull through? Balletgoers have been asking this question about the de spairing heroine of Antony Tudor's Jardin aux Lilas since the Englishborn chore ographer arranged a marriage of convenience for her 35 years ago.

title: Constance A. Hennessy Is Married
description: In St. James Episcopal Church here yesterday after noon, Miss Constance Anne Hennessy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Hennessy of New York, was married to Michael McKay Cone, son of Col. Montie F. Cone, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Cone of Falls Church, Va. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. Almus Thorpe.

title: FINANCING SOUGHT BY BIG CONCERNS
PRODUCER ORDERS STEEL SHUTDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's ninth largest steel producer, an nounced today that it would begin shutting down its plants in anticipation of a strike on Aug. 1.

title: U.S. REPORT TELLS OF GAINS BY ENEMY
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 A new assessment of the internal security of South Vietnam by the United States Embassy in Saigon shows that the enemy is gaining strength in upcoun try areas evacuated by Ameri can forces as well as in parts of the densely populated Me kong River Delta.

title: 22 Members of NEGRO Leave For Soviet Goodwill Trip Today
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, with his usual dramatic flair, brought Government officials froni the United States and the SoViet Union to an old Harlem warehouse yesterday to brief members of his organization who leave today on a trip to Russia.

title: Boeing Sells Jets Abroad
description: Two overseas airlines have ordered 11 Boeing 737 jets for delivery next year. Malaysian Airlines, Ltd., expects delivery of six of the planes in October, 1972. Saudi Arabian Airlines has ordered five planes for de livery in the first half of 1972.

title: Books of The Times
description: In our most meaningful writers from Emerson to Norman Mailer, says Theodore Gross, idealism warred against authority. There was a moral imperative in these men that ran counter to the accepted values of their society. He goes even further. What was best in their works derived from the tension set up between their impulse and the force from the outside. And conversely, where a writer did not oppose the habits of thought of his immediate culture, he produced no body of work of serious merit.

title: Violence Hits Rochester In Area of 1964 Riot
description: ROCHESTER, Thursday, July 22Groups of youths threw stones and bottles at autos and other targets in a predominant ly black section on the West Side of this city last night.

title: Reston Continues Recovery
description: PEKING, July 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  James Res ton, vice president and column ist of The New York Times, was recovering satisfactorily in Peking's AntiImperialist Hos pital today after an emergency appendix operation Saturday. Among his visitors were mem bers of the Chinese Foreign Ministry, diplomats and foreign journalists. A physician, Dr. Chu Yu, said that postoperative acupuncture treatment, which had been given to ease Mr. Res ton's discomfort, was stopped Yesterday.

title: Cliff Edwards, 76, Ukulele Ike Of Stage and Film, Dies on Coast
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 21 (AP) Cliff Edwards, the singer and stage and film performer wide ly known as Ukulele Ike, died in a nursing home here on Saturday. He was 76 years old.

title: Insiders'
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stockholdings by major stockowners, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange yesterday said it had no list available this week.

title: Building a Better Can Opener
description: The most discussed new portable appliance intro duced at the National House wares Show held recently in Chicago was the Westing house Electric Corporation's electric can opener called the Sesame. It removes the lid with its rim so that it can be replaced snugly on cans that are able to be stored after only part of their con tents have been used. Since the blade never comes in contact with the food, it remains clean.

title: Boy, 15, Killed by Train
description: Joel Verna, 15 years old, of 15402 Sanford Avenue, was killed by a Long Island Rail road train yesterday, the police said. The accident took place about 5 P.M. near the Broad way, station in Flushing on the Port Washington line. Young Verna was with another boy who was not hurt and whose name was not disclosed.

title: Pennsy Narrows Loss;
description: The trustees of the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company said yesterday that the bank rupt carrier should be able to operate throughout the rest of, this year if there is no steel strike or widespread railroad shutdown.

title: MAN SLAIN HERE LINKED TO MAFIA
description: A man shot fatally on a Brooklyn street on Tuesday was identified by the police yesterday as a buddy of a former member of the Joseph Profaci Mafia family in Brook lyn.

title: One Jets'
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21 There he was, Roger Fin nie, the burly 250pound line man waiting for the start of the daily morning workout of the Jets when he was ap proached by Buddy Ryan, the defensive line coach.

title: MISS DAVIS SEEKING TO ACT AS ATTORNEY
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 21 (AP)Angela Davis made her own plea in court today to be allowed to act as her own at torney or cocounsel.

title: Market Place: Street Awaits Martin Report
description: The study of Wall Street shortly to be issued by Wil liam McChesney Martin Jr. may well have a longrange impact on most of the na tion's 31 million investors.

title: Criminal justice British Style
description: LONDONOne of the Englishman's prized privileges is that of keeping his freedom although accused of crime. Indeed, the extent to which an ac cused person remains at liberty while awaiting trial is a prime determinant of a civilized legal system. To be kept in custody pending trial is both to hamper the preparation of an accused person's defense as well as to prejudge the outcome, at least marginally.

title: Ft. Dix Finds Growing Number Of Recruits Arrive as Addicts
description: FORT DIX, N. J., July 21Army officials say that an in creasing number of recruits from Northeastern cities are bringing their civilianacquired heroin addiction with them to this sprawling training center.

title: Deficit in Payments Set Peak in Quarter
description: The deficit in the United States international balance of payments soared to a record in the second quarter, the Mor gan Guaranty Trust Company estimated yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Won't Go to Chicago
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) Chicago has withdrawn its bid for the 1972 Republican Na tional Convention. Jack Reilly, the city's director of special events, said today prior com mitments made both McCor mick Place and the Internation al Amphitheatre unavailable the week of Aug 22. Chicago, Miami Beach and San Diego were reported to have been approved by President Nixon as possible sites.

title: DOLLAR IN EUROPE SLIPS AS GOLD RISES
description: LONDON, July 21  There were signs of further monetary unease today as the dollar weakened against the German mark and the French franc, and the price of gold leaped to its highest price in many months.

title: American Brands Net Rose 16% in Quarter, 22% in Half
description: Net income of American Brands, Inc., advanced 16 per cent in the second quarter and 22 per cent in the first half, the company announced yes terday.

title: Congress Reconsiders Bill On Appalachian Program
description: WASHINGTON; July 21 (AP)Congress has reintroduced the Appalachian regional devel opment bill. The new bill no longer includes a section creat ing jobs.

title: HARLEM PROJECT APPROVED BY U.S.
description: A $42.6million development in East Harlem to provide housing for lowand moderate income families as well as a variety of community services has received tentative approval from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Develop ment.

title: Ox Ridge Poloists Win, 102; Gain Semifinals in Tourney
Mrs. Probert Leads in Golf
description: BERNARDSVILLE. N. J., July 21  Mrs. Edward Probert, the host club entry, shot a 40, 3777 and lifted her score to 13 points today to continue leading the Garden States Women's Golf Association Elizabeth Goss roundrobin tournament at the Somerset Hills Country Club..

title: Pension Hearings Planned
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, announced today that the first hearings in an inquiry into pri vate pension plans would be held next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Senator Wil liams, chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, said testi mony would be taken from workers who participated in union and industry pension plans but did not receive the benefits they had been led to expect.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The apparent tongueIncheek atti tude with which a faculty member of the Jewish Theological Seminary, Anne Lapidus Lerner suggests that a stand ard handgun of U.S. manufacture should be issued every voting regis trant in New York City in Make Mine Semiautomatic, OpEd, July 5, is certainly most surprising in view of the proliferation of firearms among private Israeli citizens.

title: Mobile Recreation Swings Off to Start With City Hall Show
description: Fun City, an illusion for some New Yorkers, turned into real ity yesterdayright on Mayor Lindsay's doorstep at City Hall.

title: A Return to Elegance
description: ROME, July 21The nineteenforties look has receded for a spell, giving the press and buyers attending the cou ture shows here a chance to worry about something other than their lost youth. Both Heinz Riva and Mila Schon returned to couture ele gance with a vengeance. The question is, are we ready for it?

title: COMPUTERS FAIL Al 9 OTB OFFICES
description: The New York Offtrack Bet ting Corporation's computers tripped coming out of the start mg gate yesterday morning, forcing an almost complete halt in operations for more than nine hours at nine OTB offices.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN SLOW TRADING
Dillon and Sacks Gain Final In Westchester Title Golf
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 21 George S. (Sandy) Dillon Jr. of Sleepy Hollow, the 1968 champion and a coleader in Monday's qualifying round, and Dr. Jerry Sacks of Briar Hall, who got into match play only after winning a fiveway play off for the final berth, won the semifinals of the 52d amateur championship of the Westches ter County Golf Association today.

title: DR. FRANK MOSKOWITZ
description: Dr. Frank Moskowitz, at tending surgeon at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, died Sunday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 75 years old and lived at 835 Ocean Avenue in the borough.

title: BON VIVANT HELD LAX ON CAN HUNT
description: The regional director of the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that little, any, of the suspected stocks Bon Vivant soups had been re turned and that court action might be needed.

title: Eastman Kodak Hits Peak
description: The Eastman Kodak Compa ny achieved record sales and earnings in the second quar ter with 9 per cent increases, but halfyear earnings declined despite peak sales for the pe riod, the midyear report from Rochester headquarters dis closed yesterday.

title: TAXSHARING PLAN ALTERED TO HEED BIGCITY DEMANDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Administration has worked out a new formula that would go far toward meeting the de mands of bigcity Democrats that financial needs of local governments be taken into ac count in distributing general revenuesharing funds.

title: Most Placed in Projects
description: About 750 out of 1,138 wel fare families that were living in hotels four months ago have been moved into Housing Au thority projects or into per manent apartments in private structures, Mayor Lindsay an nounced yesterday.

title: Natural Gas Pricing Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) Senator John G. Tower, Re, publican of Texas, introduced a, bill yesterday to take natural, gas pricing powers away from, the Federal Power Commission., Gas rates should be set by the free market, Senator Tower, said.

title: U.S. Seeks to Shift Conservation Suits Out of Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 21To the dismay of conservation ists, the Administration is seek ing to move major environmen tal lawsuits out of Washington.

title: AMEX PRICES SUP AS VOLUME RISES
EmptyFreight Train Is Swept by a Blaze In West Side Tunnel
description: Fires reportedly set by van dals in six cars of a Penn Central train of 79 refrigerator cars stored in a tunnel under Riverside Park sent dense smoke rushing up through gratings late yesterday and in directly caused a massive rush hour traffic tieup.

title: Odetta's Program Increases Delight With GameTunes
description: Although Odetta began her Tuesday evening concert at the Metropolitan Museum with a contemporary romance by Buffy SainteMarie, and dotted the rest of the program with new compositions of her own, she basically remained true to the folk traditions that sparked her career some 15 years ago. For this old fans were duly appre ciative, enjoying to the full her distinctive versions of work, songs, prison blues, chanties and gospel chants.

title: Newsman Gets City Post
description: Abel Silver, former chief of the City Hall bureau for The New York Post, was appointed yesterday as assistant commis sioner for public affairs in the city's new Taxi and Limousine Commission. Michael J. Lazar, a former City Councilman, is chairman.

title: FM Glows Lustily Despite the Recession
description: FM radio, broadcasting's ob stinate orphan, which refused to perish from commercial mal nutrition, is displaying eco nomic bounce. The recession is proving an unexpected para dox; FM's builtin austerity has an attraction for those with 1971 allergy to the high costs of AM radio and television. Such disparate FM broadcasters as the Mormon Church and the General Tire and Rubber Company are making notes on the profit side of their ledgers, which not all AM titans can do. The bid ding for frequency modulation outlets is much more lively than for amplitude modulation stations. Moreover, rating serv yes now integrate FM stations along with AM stations, the ultimate in electronic recogni tion.

title: T.W.A., American Gain
description: American Airlines and Trans World Airlines issued their June and firsthalf income ac counts yesterday. Both showed profits for the month but large losses for the sixmonth period.

title: City Study Finds 0 to 7% Pork In 10 PorkandBean Products
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that a study of 10 leading brands of pork and beans showed that the pork content ranged from 7 per cent down to zero.

title: Watteau Is Mark of Champion In Smooth Fox Terrier Breed
description: Few kennels have had the Impact on a breed that Wat teau has had on the smooth fox terrier. Watteau repre sentatives not only have been big winners in their native England, but also have played leading roles on the Conti nent, in the United States, South Africa, South America and Australia. In February, Robert A. Fisher's Ch. Watteau Musical Box was the best smooth at the American Fox Terrier Club's specialty here for the third time. A week earlier, at Cruft's, 28 of 51 smooths shown had Watteau breeding in their pedigrees. Both the dog and bitch challenge cer tificate winners had as their grandsire Ch.Watteau Snuff Box.

title: Miss Beard Gains in Western Golf, 1 Up
description: CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) Kaye Beard along with two Curtis Cup players advanced to the quarterfinals of the 71st women's western amateur golf tournament today.

title: Peking's Role in Vietnam Peace
description: President Nixon is wise to discourage speculation about the effect of his new China policy on Vietnam. Euphoric hopes in the country, stirred in part by earlier White House comments, could boomerang badly if the war not ended. But equally dangerous is the effect Mr. Nixon's own hopes for Chinese aid may have on his strategy for peace in Southeast Asia.

title: RAYMOND E. HAAS
description: BALTIMORE, July 21Ray mond E. Haas, a marine engi neer with M. Rosenblatt & Son, Inc., naval architects, of 350 Broadway, New York, died on Sunday in the University of Maryland Hospital of injuries received in an automobile ac cient on June 30. He was 35 years old.

title: She Learned How to Cook as a Girl in Hanoi
description: I wish I could go back home, Minh Chau Gallagher said, but I won't until the war is over.

title: $25,000 Schweitzer Bribe Alleged by Senate Witness
description: An admitted stock manipula, for told the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee in Washington yesterday that he paid more than $25,000 to State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer 15 years ago to give him a light jail sentence.

title: Chess: Petrosian's Opening Game With Korchnoi a Dull Draw
INDIANA STANDARD PLANS ACQUISITION
Notes on People
description: His sonorous voice in fine form, Laurence Olivier made his maiden speech before Britain's House of Lords, and he gave it some neoshake spearean cadences. I fear your lordships may find grim cause to reflect upon the prescient genius of the intro ducer of this tenderest of courtesies, he said. And if I fail to achieve it then must beg to suggest to your lordships that it would be most contrary to the chival ry for which your lordships house is so famous to with hold your gallantry and re fuse to indulge a maiden of 64. Lord Olivier took the floor to speak in support of an industrial relations bill that would aid actors. When he was done, his peers ap plauded warmly, but they turned out to be a cold audi ence. When the vote on the Oliviersponsored bill came, it went down to defeat, 102

title: Buckley Admits Secrets Hoax; Many in News Media Taken In
description: William F. Buckley Jr., the publisher of National Review, acknowledged yesterday that the magazine's published col lection of highly classified documents was a hoax. It had fooled a large segment of the American news media.

title: CORWIN'S ALALA VICTOR IN CRUISE
3,000 Jurists From 114 Lands Meet in Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 21  Some 3,000 lawyers and judges from 114 countries met today under the auspices of the World Peace Through Law Cen ter, in what was said to be the largest international conference of the legal profession ever held.

title: ISRAELIS RESETTLE SOME GAZA ARABS
description: TEL AVIV, July 21  The Israeli authorities have evacu ated an undisclosed number of Palestinian refugees from the densely populated Jabaliya camp and have resettled them elsewhere in the occupied Gaza Strip, it was disclosed here today.

title: William B. Lodge, Executive At C.B.S., Plans Retirement
description: William B. Lodge, the Co lumbia Broadcasting System's vice president in charge of re lations with the network's af filiated television stations, is retiring around the first of next year to make his home in St. Croix, Virgin Islands.

title: Official Denounces U.S.
description: PEKING, July 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  Deputy Pre mier Li Hsiennien said tonight that the Chinese people will liberate Taiwan.

title: Last U.S. Combat Unit Below DMZ Pulls Out
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 22  The last American combat battalion was withdrawn from the area just below the demilitarized zone as Communist shellings of the bases now manned by South Vietnamese continued today, military sources said.

title: Waterways Ensemble Begins Its Annual Series of Concerts
description: The good barge Hughes 136 rocked and rolled at its dockside moorings, the band struck up a waterlogged version of Down by the Riverside, and the Amer ican Waterways Wind Or chestra launched its annual series of concerts in the New York area with a con cert at East River Park.

title: Crop Aid Limit of $55,000 Is Approved by Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  A SenateHouse conference committee on the Agriculture Department appropriation bill agreed today to retain the present $55,000 ceiling on crop subsidy payments to farmers.

title: Tunex Tunes Up Well
description: Tunex of the Hobeau Farms expected to start in Saturday's $100,000 added Brooklyn Hand icap, worked out in the morn ing at Belmont Park. He cm, lered the halfmile in 0:4745 and the six furlongs in 1:1215.

title: Volcker Comments
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Paul A. Volcker, Under Secre tary of the Treasury for Mone tary Affairs, said today that the Treasury would take whatever steps are necessary to halt the new trading on the West Coast Commodity Ex change in goldcoin futures.

title: Proposed Chairman of the A.E.C. James Rodney Schlesinger
description: WASHINGTON, July 21James R. Schlesinger seldom leaves home without consult ing a road map. Even if he and his wife are just going to a dinner party a few miles away, he finds the spot on the map and works out the best route to get there. Then, with his wife shivering beside him (there is no heater in their faded blue 1964 Falcon), they drive straight to their destination.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The denials by Ambassador Vitsaxis and press service director Kamarineas [letters July 5 and July 15] that politi cal prisoners and torture exist in Greece surpass even the junta's usual impudence.

title: Kaiser Steel Corp.
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21Losses from Canadian coal min ing operations offset domestic profits of the Kaiser Steel Cor poration in the second quarter and first half of this year, the Oakland, Calif based company reported yesterday.

title: Ecologists Battle a New Indian Pt. Plant
description: CRUGERS, N. Y., July 21  Environmentalists chal lenged today the adequacy of the state's emergency plans in case of a nuclear accident as they attempted to set a precedent here and deny Consolidated Edison the use of its new atomic power plant.

title: SEABORG RESIGNS AS HEAD OF A.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 President Nixon accepted today the resignation of Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, the Nobel chemist who has been chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission for a decade.

title: Advertising:
description: Over at Hearst Magazines David A. McCann is going from Good to Beautiful. Or, less romantically, less color fully, less descriptively but perhaps more accurately, the 42yearold publishing official has been named the new publisher of House Beautiful from his present job of Eastern advertising manager of Good Housekeeping.

title: Norman Singer New Head Of Dance and Song Society
description: Norman Singer, executive di rector of the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., has been elected president of the Country Dance and Song Soci ety of America, it was an nounced yesterday by May Gadd, national director.

title: Short Interest Declines 5.9% On the Big Board for Month
Car Swallowed Up As Road Caves In On Riverside Drive
description: An automobile suddenly dropped from sight on River side Drive at 97th Street about 5 P.M. yesterday when a 20 by30foot section of the pave ment opened up beneath it.

title: RESIDENCE CHOICE HELD VOTER RIGHT
description: BOSTON, July 21The Mas sachusetts Attorney General ruled today that voters under 21 years of age have a right to choose their own place of residence for purposes of vot ing.

title: South Vietnamese Reported Reoccupying Corridor in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21  South Vietnamese troops in eastern Cambodia were reported today to be re occupying part of a Communist infiltration corridor that they had left open after a retreat early in June.

title: RUSSIANS ENDORSE CRITICISM OF U.S. AND CHINA ON TRIP
description: MOSCOW, July 21A lead ing Soviet newspaper published an assertion today that Presi dent Nixon's planned visit to Peking was the result of anti Soviet maneuvering by both the United States and Communist China.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a college student who resides at school, I read with interest the July 12 news article entitled College Town :Puzzle: 18YearOld Vote.

title: Roundup: Aaron Hits 27th and 28th Home Runs
Laos Acts on Drugs
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 21 (UPI)  The government has taken steps to curb the cultiva tion of opium and the illicit traffic in drugs after the United States Embassy threatened to cut off aid, Laotian officials said today.

title: LAW FIRM IS TOLD TO CUT U.M.W. TIE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The United States Court of Ap peals for the District of Co lumbia issued a procedural re buke today to one of this city's most prestigious law firms, Williams, Connolly and Cali fano.

title: NIXON ASKS ACTION ON SEABED TREATY
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)  President Nixon asked the Senate today to ratify treaty prohibiting the installa tion of nuclear weapons on the ocean floor.

title: U.M.W. Trustee Named
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of United States District Court here has approved the selec tion of Paul Dean, former head of the Georgetown Law Cen ter, to be the third trustee of the $152million United Mine Workers Welfare and Retire ment Fund.

title: Dunning by Phone Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) Congress was asked today to outraw telephone calls in which pressure is applied to collect disputed debts. Representative Fred B. Rooney, Democrat of Pennsylvania, introduced two bills that together would make such calls punishable by up to six months in jail or a $500 fine.

title: Florida Governor Charges Misuse of U.S. Grants
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida and other Florida officials re lated today a long story of mismanagement, improper use and waste of funds granted to their state by the Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Admin istration.

title: SHOOTING WITNESS TO SEEK FREEDOM
description: Counsel for Patricia Green, who is being held as a material witness in the machinegun shooting May 19 of two police men guarding the home of Dis trict Attorney Frank S. Hogan, will move today before Sup reme Court Justice Xavier C. Riccobono for her release from detention in Civil Jail.

title: In Short, Why Did the Class Fail?
description: COLUMBIA, Mo.And now, like it or not, I'd like to say a few parting words.

title: Mary Bookis Bride At Athens College
description: Miss Mary Angela Bookis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Bookis of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Con stantine N. Canonis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas G. Canonis of Athens. The Greek Orthodox ceremony was performed in the Chapel of the Taxiarchs of Athens College. The college campus is in Psychico on the out skirts of Athens.

title: SCHOOLS REDUCE FARE SUBSIDIES
description: The Board of Education last night eliminated reducedfare transportation for 50,000 high school students who live less than a mile and a half from school.

title: Morrison: Now He's Tight End
description: BROOKVILLE, LI., July 21 Joe Walton coach of the New York Giants offensive ends, gained acclaim as one of the finest tight ends in the National Football League. Y.A. Tittle used to refer to him as the best thirddown receiver in the game.

title: Cairo Team Reported Sent to Sudan
description: CAIRO, July 21An Egyptian factfinding mission was re ported todaY to be conducting urgent inquiries in Khartoum, the:capital of the Sudan, into the seizure of power Monday by a group of leftwing officers. The new rulers appear to op pose plans to link the Sudan ultimately with Egypt, Libya and Syria in a federation.

title: Taiwanese Here Press Drive for Independence
description: Leaders of the Taiwan inde pendence movement pressed their campaign yesterday for the creation of a separate state of Taiwan, or Formosa, gov erned by natives of the island.

title: Sato Says He'd Go To Peking for Talks On Closer Relations
description: TOKYO, July 21 (AP)Pre mier Eisaku Sato, put on the defensive by President Nixon's planned trip to China, said to day he too was willing to go to Peking to discuss improvement of relations.

title: Testimony on War Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) If the present approach to Mao and Chou had taken place 25 years ago, we might have been spared two wars, John Paton Davies said here today.

title: Kraftco Corp.
description: Secondquarter earnings of the Kraftco Corp.ration rose 4 per cent to $19,797,000, or 71 cents a share, from $19, 085,000, or 69 cents a share, in the yearago period. Sales advanced 6 per cent to $723, 208,000 from $683,184,000.

title: Saigon Will Tighten Its Rules On Press Coverage of War
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21 (Reuters)The South Viet namese command said today that it planned to issue a set of ground rules for the press that will very much restrict reporting on military opera tions.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, July 21A spokesman for the World Bank said today that Mr. McNamara had apologized for the publica tion of the report on East Pakistan in The New York Times but had not, as the As sociated Press of Pakistan, said earlier this week, characterized the report as biased and provocative or made any com ment at all on the substance of the report.

title: A NewOld China Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Within a month two parts of the Administration have given us two quite different criteria for establishing and conducting rela tions with foreign states. The State Department told both the House and Senate:

title: Free Health Tests Given at Harlem Block Party
description: Hundreds of black children and their parents showed up yesterday for free medical ex aminations at miniclinics set up in Central Harlem as part of a super block party organ ized by Dr. Benjamin Watkins, fionOrary mayor of Harlem.

title: 4 Nations Sustain an Aid Effort Without Waiting for U.S. to Act
description: WASHINGTON, July 21Four industrial aidgiving na tions have made voluntary con tributions totaling $110million to the World Bank to help sus tain an important lending operation pending action by Congress.

title: Singer Co.
description: Second quarter earnings of the Singer Co. pany fell 25 per cent to $13,911,000, or 75 cents a share, from $18,658,000, or $1.06 a share, in the corre sponding period of 1970. Sales rose fractionally to $538,032, 000 from $535,606,000.

title: Aleri Twins Make Hay While the Shoe Shines
description: The Yankees almost com pleted one of the strangest outs of the year yesterday after George Mitterwald of the Twins hit a sharp ground er to third base in the eighth inning. Jerry Kenney threw the ball to first and it went over John Ellis's head, but Horace Clarke retrieved it and threw to the pitcher, Steve Kline, who was cover ing the bag.

title: Jordan Announces the Release of 2,000 Commandos
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 21A Jordanian Government spokes man announced tonight that the Government had freed 2,000 Arab commandos who had been seized during the recent fighting in northern Jor dan,

title: Jersey Standard Net Is Up;
description: Net income of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) rose sharply in the second quarter and first six months of 1971, the petroleum giant reported yesterday.

title: Birch Bayh Is in Search of an Identity
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, July 21  Gov. J. J. Excin of Nebraska called on his colleagues and several hundred diners today to give a warm Siouxland wel come to the Hon. Birch Bayh, and a spotlight picked up a man standing midway down the darkened auditorium. He was applauded warmly.

title: Effectiveness of Mood Drugs Sold Over Counters Is Studied
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Food and Drug Adminis tration is organizing a major study of overthecounter mood drugs to see if they really are effective as sedatives, sleep aids or stimulants, as their ad vertisements contend.

title: Rosewall Upset, 75, 75
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 21 (UN)  An aggressive serve volley attack carried 20yearold John Alexander to a sur prising 75, 75 victory over Ken Rosewall in the second round of the $50,000 First Na tional tennis tournament today.

title: 2 JUNIORS SCORE UPSETS IN TENNIS
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., July 21 (UPI)Jim Connors of Bell, Ill., and Harold Solomon of Silver Springs, Md., the two topranked junior players, up set a pair of seeded stars in the third round of the $25,000 Tanglewood international ten nis tournament today.

title: H. Howard Babcock, Lawyer And Boys Club Chairman, Dies
description: H. Howard Babcock, a law yer better known as chairman of the Madison Square Boys Club since 1952, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack at his home, 502 Park Avenue. He was 86 years old and had an office at 350 Park Avenue.

title: PIPE LINE COMPANY INCREASES EARNINGS
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation yester day reported gains in operating revenues and net income for the three months ended June 30.

title: Dunning Has Flair in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 21 A new terrorist organization has taken to the streets here recently. Although they are not rightist or leftist bomb throw ers and work only during busi ness hours, their impact is far more profound than that of the antiGovernment guerrillas.

title: Nixon's Secrecy Criticized
description: TOKYO, July 21 (UPI)Premier Sato criticized Presi dent Nixon today for having kept to himself his plan to visit China until his announcement last Thursday. We are ready to keep a secret, Mr. Sato said in the lower house. There should have been full consulta tions in advance.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The big gest question mark in the Democratic party today is Edward M. Kennedy. Is he going to be a candidate, or is he not? And if he is, is he the strongest opponent for Mr. Nixon that the Democrats could put up?

title: MRS. MICHAEL COLL
description: Mrs. Eleanor Rogan Coll, the wife of Michael Coll, art direc tor of The Sunday News Color oto Magazine, died yesterday in University Hospital after a long illness. She was 45 years old and lived at 900 West 190th Street.

title: Florence Wessels Dead; ExReporter for Journal
description: Florence Wessels, who gave up a show business career to become a newspaper reporter, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Queens. She was 72 years old.

title: AIR FORCE GUARDS RAND SECRET DATA
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Air/Force disclosed today that the Rand Corporation has custody of more than 170,000 confidential documents.

title: ARNOLD MORDKOFF OF N.Y.U. PSYCHOLOGY
description: Dr. Arnold M. Mordkoff, an associate professor of psychol ogy at New York University, drowned while swimming off the coast of Norway last week end. He was 35 years old and lived at 100 Bleecker Street.

title: 25 Killed and 100 Injured as Express Is Derailed in West Germany
description: KARLSRUHE, West Ger many, July 21 (AP)  The eightcar Switzerland Ex press, with 300 to 400 passen gers aboard, jumped the tracks on a curve south of Rheinweiler, south of here to day, gilling at least 25 per sons and injuring about 100, the police said.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CLEAR LAKE, Me.  A strong southwest wind was raising small waves on the windward shores of Clear Lake when the four of us launched our 20foot Old Town canoe.

title: ARMY DISMISSES ATROCITY CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) The Army announced today the dismissal of charges against Col. Joseph R. Franklin, who had been accused by another officer of covering up atrocities in Vietnam.

title: Senate Panel Rebuffs Nixon on Radio Free Europe
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee today defeated a Nixon, Administration plan to finance) and operate Radio Free Europel, and Radio Liberty under al taxexempt corporation char tered by Congress.

title: Heath Says Britain Can Aid Peace by Joining Market
