description: LONDON, July 21  Prime Minister Heath today hailed the rapid movement toward (16 tente in the world and said that Britain could best play her part as a member of the Common Market.

title: Bridge: Roth and Barbara Rappaport Win Life Master Pair Title
description: CHICAGO, July 21The life master championship ended here late last night in a victory for Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rap paport of East Orange, N. J. This was Roth's second vic tory in the event, and Mrs. Rappaport added her name to the short list of distin guished women players who have won this famous title.

title: Teachers Union Fines Given to City by Court
description: The State Supreme Court truled yesterday that New York City, rather than the state, should be the benefi ciary of the fines levied against the United Federation of Teachers and its presi dent, Albert Shanker, as a result of the 1967 teachers strike here.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES LOAN TO LOCKHEED
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The House Banking Committee nar rowly approved today an emer gency loanguarantee program designed to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bank ruptcy.

title: Midwest Governors See Nixon Gaining From Trip
description: SOUTH SIOUX CITY, Neb., July 21  Many Midwestern Governors believe that Presi dent Nixon has gained politi cally in their region as a result of his planned trip to Commu nist China but that the gains could quickly evaporate if there was no improvement in the re gion's economy by next year.

title: NET EARNINGS DROP IN BANK TRUST UNITS
description: A profit squeeze reduced slightly the net earnings in the trust departments of 10 major New York City banks last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The net trust earnings of the 10 banksFirst National City, Chase Manhattan, Manufac turers Hanover, Morgan Guar anty, Chemical, Bankers, Irving, Marine Midland, Bank of New York and United States Trustcame to $123.7million in 1970, down from $123.9million the year earlier.

title: Mayor Reported to Be Actively Planning Presidential Campaign
description: Amid recurring reports that he is about to change parties as a prelude to a Presidential candidacy, Mayor Lindsay dis cussed his political future with a leading fundraiser at a Gra cie Mansion meeting within the last week.

title: POLICE EXONERATE SUSPECT IN RAPES
description: The Police Department an nounced yesterday that a 29yearold father of four had been cleared of suspicion of committing dozens of rapes in fashionable apartment houses in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County and possibly other counties in the metro politan area.

title: PAKISTAN STILL IRKED AT THE WORLD BANK
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 21 Pakistan has acknowledged a message of regret sent by Robert S. MacNamara, presi dent of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Devel opment, regarding the unau thorized disclosure of a bank report highly critical of the Pakistani Government.

title: COUNTESS GUARDABASSI
description: BEVERLY, Mass., July 21 (UPI)  Countess Guardabassi, the widow of Count Francesco Guardabassi of Perugia, Italy, an Italian artist and opera singer, died yesterday ap parently of a heart attack suf fered over the weekend at her home here. Her age was 82.

title: THOMAS L GRACE, HEADED AIR LINES
description: ATLANTA, July 21 (UPI)Thomas L. Grace, chairman and chief executive officer of Ozark Air Lines, Inc., died today at Piedmont Hospital, where he had undergone heart surgery last week. He was 66 years old.

title: 21 Die in Copter Crash
description: SAIGON, Thursday, July 22 (Reuters)Twentyone South Vietnamese rangers were killed and 36 other soldiers, including five American advisers, were injured when a United States Chinook helicopter crashed in northern Quangtin Province yesterday, the Saigon high command said today. A spokes man attributed the crash to technical causes.

title: Textron, Inc.
description: Secondquarter profits of Textron, Inc., rose to $18,331, 000, or 52 cents a share, from $16,671,000, or 47 cents a share, in the yearago period. Sales also advanced to $426,312,000 from $403,819,000.

title: The Best Crop
description: When Franklin D. Roosevelt and Henry A. Wallace started the farm subsidy program in 1933, the objective was to save the family farm. The man with 160 acres who did not have the financial resources to survive sharp swings in prices in a free market was to get the Govern ment as his silent, stabilizing partner.

title: Bendix Corp.
description: Net income of the Bendix Corporation increased 32 per cent in the third fiscal quar ter ended June 30 to $10,148, 000, or 62 cents a share, from $7,787,000, or 47 cents a share, in the yearago period. Sales, royalties and other operating income, however, eased to $418,992,000 from $429,331, 000.

title: Screen Actors Guild Backs New Pact With Producers
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 21 (AP) The Screen Actors Guild, in a 363255 advisory vote, has approved a newly negotiated contract with motion picture and television producers.

title: SUFFOLK APPROVAL WON BY CITY BANK
description: The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recom mendation of William T. Dent zer Jr., the State Superintend ent of Banks, approved yester day the expansion of the First National City Corporation into Suffolk County and the forma tion of a new bank holding company by the State Bank of Albany and the Liberty Nation al Bank and Trust Company of Buffalo.

title: Badillo and Burden Push A Challenge to Rossetti
description: Representative Herman Ba dillo and City Councilman Car ter Burden are encouraging a potentially serious challenge to Assemblyman Frank G. Rosset ti's Manhattan Democratic lead ership.

title: College Aides Study Business
description: BOSTON, July 21  The idea was to reduce the $2.6 million deficit anticipated by the Midwest Institute of Technology, a fictitious en gineering school whose vital statistics had been pro gramed into a computer.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The current campaign spending practices, including skyrocketing costs for TV, mean that no one can afford to run for political office unless he is extremely wealthy or is willing to ac cept very large contributions from other sources, which generally have the strings of special interest attached.

title: Workmen Still Fighting Rising Kentucky River
description: MOREHEAD, Ky., July 21, (UPI)Workers piled sand bags on top of a temporary earthen coffer dam today to keep the rainswollen Licking River from spilling over the top and pouring tons of water over thousands of acres of tobacco farmland.

title: Problems in Brooklyn
description: Despite Mayor Lindsay's statement yesterday that con siderable progress had been made in reducing welfare cases in hotels, a veritable dumping ground for welfare families has developed in at least seven hotels in a small sector of the attractive Brooklyn Heights neighborhood.

title: WOMEN'S CAUCUS MAY ENLIST MEN
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 The new National Women's Po litical Caucus has had so many inquiries from men asking how they could help achieve its aims that the organization is consid ering forming a Friends of the Caucus, Representative Bella S. Abzug said today.

title: PARTICIPANTS LISTED IN DREYFUS ACCORD
description: A list of the 10 original shareholders in the Dreyfus Corporation who have agreed to return part of the money they received from the sale of their stock in 1965 was ob tained yesterday by The New York Times.

title: McGovern Takes Back Attack on Party Official
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP)Senator George Mc Govern of South Dakota apol ogized to the Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, today for charg ing that Robert Strauss, the party treasurer, had violated neutrality in the campaign for the Democratic Presiden tial nomination.

title: New York State Wins Dispute On Murder Case Near Border
description: A Westchester County grand jury is about to hear the case of the killing of a Stamford woman who was found so close to the Connecticut border that surveyors were called in to de termine which state had juris diction.

title: National Cash Register
description: Despite larger sales, earnings of the National Cash Register Company declined sharply in the three and six months ended June 30, reflecting higher oper ating costs and reduced domes tic orders, the midyear report disclosed yesterday.

title: G.E. TO LAY OFF ENGINE WORKERS
description: The General Electric Corn ipany said yesterday that its air craft engine group expects to Ilay off more than 7,000 em ployes this year. It blamed the combination of a decline in the growth rate of air travel together with the cancellation of United States supersonic transport program.

title: Parents of Dead Marine Lose Suit on Illegal War
description: NEW HAVEN, July 21 (UPI) A United States District Court judge has dismissed a $500,000 damage suit against the Government by a Danbury (couple who contend their son's death in Vietnam's illegal war violated his constitutional rights.

title: Boubouroche Due in Fall
description: Boubouroche, a comedy by George Courteline, will be presented off Broadway in No vember by Richard Hughes. Jerry Stiller has been engaged for the title role. Walt Witcover will direct.

title: Righting a Blunder on I.L.O.
description: The Senate has acted to undo the mistake Congress made last year in cutting off payments to the Interna tional Labor Organization. It has voted to restore the full 25 per cent contribution this country normally makes to the I.L.O. budgeta contribution that was withheld primarily because of the pique of George Meany and the A.F.L.C.I.O. over the designation of a Russian as one the I.L.O.'s five assistant directors.

title: TUNNELPIPE ORDER FOUGHT BY RAILROAD
description: Robert F. Lawson, the gen eral manager of the Penn Cen tral, said yesterday that the rail road would be derelict in our responsibilities if we were to accede to the orders of the Fire Department requiring the installation of a standpipe sys tem in four East River Tun nels.

title: Screen: Honor and 'The Horsemen':Afghan Tale Opens at Local Theaters Lead Roles Shared by Sharif and Palance
description: The time is now and Uraz (Omar Sharif), the son of Tursen (Jack Palance), the master of the stable for one of Afghanistan's feudal lords, is meant to seem a classic hero to those of us for whom life's most intense physical tests come in occasional races for seats on the IRT, often against feeble old ladies.Uraz is a master horseman, brave to the point of selfdestruction, who lives by a primitive code. He puts such stress on his honor that when he loses the buzkashi, an extraordinarily brutal riding tournament staged for the king at Kabul, he does penance by riding home, accompanied by his syce (man servant), by the most difficult possible mountain route. His broken leg, which is encased in a plaster cast he calls "the evil box," begins to putrify, but Uraz hardly flinches when it is amputated with an ax.John Frankenheimer, who directed "The Horsemen," and Dalton Trumbo, who adapted Joseph Kessel's novel, never do tell us what the Chapandaz, the Afghan horsemen, call amputation. However, they fill their film with so much other local color having to do with words, with taboos, with sports, with food, and even with handicrafts, that "The Horsemen" comes to resemble one of those approved, quite humorless comic strips that are intendend to instruct while they entertain.The film, which opened yesterday at theaters throughout the city, is not entirely humorless. Quite early on, I was moved to senseless giggles by the King James dialogue ("Peace on you, oh master of the stables") that Trumbo has more or less preservedor cannedfrom the book. However, that rather thin, low pleasure was immediately succeeded by the thought that maybe that's just the way the Chapandaz would sound to an Afghan-speaking foreigner and, for all I know, how they sound to each other.More off-putting, at least to me, is the kind of romance that "The Horsemen," both as a novel and as a film, represents. Here is fiction designed to glorify machismo of the most ignorant, savage sort, the cult of manliness that has, I suspect, its closest civilized equivalent in the totalitarian political movements of the 1930's, which put so much stress on style and very little on content.This may be taking "The Horsemen" a lot more seriously than was ever intended, but the thought arises since the film is an extension of two other recent Frankenheimer films, "Grand Prix" and "The Gypsy Moths." Both of these movies also had to do with machismo, with men testing themselves, pushing themselves to new limits of endurance, not because of any special financial or material gains, but because of those mysterious, antisocial ego needs sometimes called honor.Wrong-headedness can occasionally be moving and tragic, but "The Horsemen" is a remote, choppy adventure, chiefly interesting as the work of a director who, though his strength is contemporary melodrama ("The Young Savages," "The Manchurian Candidate"), persists in pretending he's a romantic.Some of the movie was shot in Afghanistan, which you don't often see in movies these days, and some in Spain, which you do, but I'm not sure I could always tell the difference. After a while, all postcards look alike. In addition to Sharif and Palance, the cast includes Leigh Taylor-Young who, in other movies, has shown herself to be a promising comedienne. Here she plays an Untouchable whose problem is that everyone feels free to touch her, just about any time and any place.

title: Rae Bourbon, a Protege Of Mae West, Dead at 78
description: BIG SPRING, Tex., July 21 (AP)Rae Bourbon, onetime vaudeville star, female imper sonator and protg of Mae West, died of a heart ailment Monday at the age of 78.

title: Copeland Charges Fraud, Forgery in Banking Deals
description: Lammot du Pont Copeland Jr., the du Pont heir who last October filed under the Federal Bankruptcy Act with $62.8mil lion in personal liabilities and $25.9million in assets, charges that his signature was forged on a document used to borrow $100,000 from a bank in Ohio.

title: Prairie Dog Fleas Sprayed
description: GUNNISON, Colo., July 21 (UPI)Public Health workers have dusted about 1,500 prairie dog burrows west of Gunnison with insectiside in the hope of killing fleas that carry bubonic plague. The area is near the Elk Creek campground, which has been closed to the public since nine prairie dogs were found to have the plague July 14.

title: Justice Schweitzer's Reputation Is One of Hard Work and Humor
description: I've been called a thief and a crook and those things are never pleasant, but my first duty is to the law and to my conscience, State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer told an interviewer in 1959.

title: Executive Changes
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., named Edward F. Ryan a senior vice president and chief financial officer, effective at year end.

title: SIR BRONSON ALBERY; BRITISH STAGE AIDE
description: LONDON, July 21Sir Bron son Albery, an influential fig ure in British theater manage ment, died here today in a hos pital. He was 90 years old.

title: DONALD G. PRICE
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., July 21 Donald G. Price, executive director of the New York Heart Association from 1946 to 1964, died at his summer home here on Sunday evening. He was 78 years old.

title: AMF, Inc.
description: Profits of AMF, Inc., rose 13 per cent in the second quarter to a record $9,386,000, or 52 cents a share, from $8,280,000, or 46 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1970. Revenues also reached a new high by advancing 6 per cent to $172,920,000 from $162, 624,000.

title: Minnesota Mining
description: Strong growth in interna tional operations and gradually improving demand for products serving domestic markets re sulted in record sales and earn ings of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company in the three and six months ended June 30, it was reported yester day from St. Paul, Minn., head quarters.

title: Logue Proposes a Town Over Sunnyside Rail Yards
description: A proposal for a new town with homes for 60,000 people and office and industrial space for 35,000 employes, to be built over the Sunnyside railroad yards in Long Island City, Queens, was presented yesterday by the Urban Devel opment Corporation.

title: Bayh and Humphrey Urge U.S. Relief for Counties
description: MILWAUKEE, July 21Two of the leading Democratic Presidential aspirants told county leaders today what the local officials wanted to hear about revenue sharing: that the nation needs a comprehensive plan that provides relief for the counties as well as the cities and states.

title: PUERTO RICO NAMES LABOR AGENCY AIDE
description: Nico Lugo Jr., a 28yearold former businessman here and la graduate of the InterAmeri can University in Puerto Rico, was named yesterday to head the migration division of the Puerto Rican Department of Labor.

title: Florida Aide Names Hentz In $5Million Damage Suit
G.I. Drug Test in Germany
description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many, July 21 (UPI)  The United States Army said today that it would carry out a ran dom survey later this month of 5,000 servicemen stationed in West Germany to check on drug abuse.

title: U.S. IS RESUMING LONGTERM BONDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Government offered today its first longterm bond issue in six years, bearing 7 per cent inter est, and opened the offer to subscriptions by individual in vestors of up to $10,000.

title: Tentative Agreement
description: CHICAGO, Thursday. July 22 (AP)The Chicago & North Western Railway and the United Transportation Union reached a tentative agreement early today on a new 42month contract covering wages, fringe benefits and work rules, spokesman for the railroad said.

title: J. SPERRY KANE
description: EAST DORSET, Vt., July 21 J. Sperry Kane, a retired vice president of the Chase Man hattan Bank who had headed the trust department in its Park Avenue branch for many years, died at his home here yester day after a short illness. His age was 87. He has a winter home in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Rumania Praises Move
description: VIENNA, July 21 (Reuters) Rumania today welcomed President Nixon's coming visit to China as a new and im portant step in keeping with contemporary political realities.

title: Peace Corps Measure Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a oneyear extension of the Peace Corps today with an authorization of $77.2million. The Administra tion had requested $82million for the agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Whatever one may think of the morality of prostitution, I suspect that virtually no one will deny that those engaged in this profession have no justifiable claim to tax exemption.

title: Mills to Visit New England
description: LACONIA, N. H., July 21 (AP)Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, who has been mentioned as a possible candidate for the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomina tion, has accepted an invitation to address the fall meeting of the Laconia Chamber of Com merce Oct. 13.

title: House Votes to Let Wider Buses Use Federal Highways
description: WASHINGTON, July 21A bill to permit wider buses to operate on the nation's inter state highways was approved today by the House.

title: Forrest Buys 6 Yearlings At Keeneland for $690,0000
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 21 (AP)Henry Forrest, who trained the 1966 Kentucky Derby winner, Kawaiking, con cluded his first venture in buy ing last night by running his total to $690,000 for six year lings at Keeneland's summer sale. His top bid was $200,000 for a daughter of Herbager being sold by Mrs. George G. Proskauer of Akron, Ohio.

title: Triumph in Postal Bargaining
description: The agreements covering 650,000 postal workers repre sent a victory for collective bargaining in its first critical test in the newly created United States Postal Service. They mark a splendid start for this semiautonomous public agency. They also indicate that a statutory require ment for compulsory arbitration as the end of the line in labor disputes can serve as a spur to effective bargain ing, rather than as its death knell, provided both sides are animated by a genuine desire to make independent decisionmaking work.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I find the current crackdown on prostitutes, sex shows and pornog raphy a source of bitter amusement. New York City is moribund. Its air is unbreathable, its surrounding waters are degraded into stinking sludge, its racial situation is volcanic, its schools are detention centers run by incompe tents supervising illiterates, its housing is disintegrating, its public transporta tion is a public menace, its streets no more than dogfouled causeways be tween craters of earsplitting cacoph ony, its parks are lethal clusters of decay.

title: TAIPEI REPORTED REVIEWING POLICY
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 21Senior Government officials of Nationalist China are believed to be engaged in a major review of foreign policy in the light of President Nixon's plan to visit Peking.

title: STATE TASK FORCE ENTERS BET STUDY
description: ALBANY, July 21  The state's Organized Crime Task Force entered today the in vestigation of alleged race rig ging at Yonkers Raceway.

title: That Constant Creak in Dubai's Port Is Just the Ring of Smugglers'
description: DUBAI, July 1  The tim bers of the great dhows creak loudly in this humid, low lying Persian Gulf port. They  creak with the wind, they creak with the tide and they creak with the weight of smugglers gold.

title: $22.60 SHOT WINS GREAT AMERICAN
description: Chevron Flight showed com mendable closing ability to take the $35,000 Great American at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Senate Unit Acts to Repeal Taiwan Defense Measure
description: WASHINGTON, July 21The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted unanimously today for a proposal to repeal a 1955 Congressional resolution giving the President author ity to employ United States forces to defend Taiwan and smaller islands off Mainland China held by the Chinese Nationalists.

title: Utility Serving Rockland Gets Temporary Rate Rise
description: ALBANY, July 21 (AP)The Public Service Commission granted a temporary $3.4mil lion electric rate increase to day to Orange and Rockland Utilities, which serves 119,000 customers in Rockland County and portions of Orange and Sullivan Counties.

title: LARSEN'S CHOICE IS FISCHER'S GAIN
U.S. AIDES ACCUSED ON VIETNAM VOTE
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 Congressional investigators heard testimony today that United States officials in Sai gon were seeking to influence next October's national election in favor of President Nguyen Van Thieu and that the ballot ing would be a mockery of the democratic

title: A Double Bill of Horror Arrives on Local Screens
description: Incredible, even an indulgent viewer must conclude, is the precise word for "The Incredible Two-Headed Transplant" and "The House That Screamed," the dual helping of jerry-built horrors that was dished up in pleasing colors at local houses yesterday. Unfortunately, this potentially mixed bag of abnormal surgery and abnormal education merely adds up to tepid, not divertingly chilling fare.In the Spanish-made, largely English-dubbed "House That Screamed," Lilli Palmer, as the militantly strict widowed operator of a turn-of-the-century French school for teen-aged girls is faced with a variety of strange problems. Her pupils obviously care more for a visiting woodsman, other girls and her son, John Moulder Brown, a strange, Peeping Tom type, than they do for Molire, sewing or the niceties of cuisine. And, they can't be blamed for wanting to break out of this gloomy manse, since several of their classmates already have mysteriously disappeared."I want you to live a normal life," the anxious but suspicious Miss Palmer fervently assures her son. However, it gorily turns out, young Mr. Brown is far from the normal, placid, handsome teen-ager he seems to be. Miss Palmer and moviegoer deserve all the sympathy they can get.On the other hand, Bruce Dern, as the dour scalpelwielder responsible for "The Incredible Two-Headed Transplant," really doesn't rate much sympathy. As a dedicated researcher who has clicked with two-headed snakes, rabbits and monkeys, if not with his photogenic, blonde wife, Pat Priest, he might have demurred in using a sex-crazed, homicidal maniac and a giant, mentally retarded farm hand for his human experiment. Movie plots notwithstanding, it soon becomes obvious that the best results he could expect would constitute an economy size menace to the community."Too much imagination can destroy a man," Dern's best friend warns long before the monster destroys a half-dozen citizens. Illustrating, in short, that two flawed heads, like two flawed films, are not better than one.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a radio interview here recently, Walt W. Rostow complained bitterly against publication of the Penta gon papers by The Times on the ground that they represented a dis tortion, being incomplete, and accom panied by commentary which he viewed as misinterpretation.

title: Jurists Urge Curbs on Cloud Seeding
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22  The World Conference on Peace Through Law gave tentative approval today to a proposed treaty to control cloud seeding and other forms of weather modification, althouth an official of the World Me teorological Organization said that weatherchanging efforts usually do not work.

title: JEAN RICHET WALKER
description: Mrs. Jean Richet Walker, former women's page editor of The Portland Oregonian and The Oregon Journal, who had also been a pianist and com poser, died Wednesday night in Binghamton, N.Y., where she lived. Her age was 87.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Sports of The Times
description: Number 10's helmet looks too big. It dwarfs his narrow shoulders and on the football field, wearing gray shorts, he appears to be a high school sprinter who is having fling with the New York Giants at their training camp.

title: TREASON TRIAL DUE FOR FOES OF SADAT
description: CAIRO, July 22The leaders of a challenge to the authority of President Anwar elSadat last May will be tried on charges of high treason, the prosecutor of Egypt, Dr. Mus tafa Abu Zeid Fahmy, said during a television broadcast tonight.

title: Learning to Make Things the Way the American Indians Did
description: I want you to know, this is the first time I've strung beads since I got out of kin dergarten, said the stock broker, as he leaned for ward to pick up another tiny bead and slide it over a long needle and down a white thread.

title: Bug on Mosquitoes Enjoys Infested Jersey Sanctuary
description: ELDORA, N. J.Dr. C. Brooke Worth is an eminent scientist, an author who has been published in seven, lan guages, a fine husband, a loving father, a charming host and a seeming sensible man.

title: PACKERS TRADE DETER TO BEARS
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 22 (UPI)Bob Jeter, a defensive halfback who has been in the doghouse of the Green Bay Pack ers coach, Dan Devine, since last spring, was traded today to the Chicago Bears for a running back, Ross Montgom ery.

title: Collision Closes River
description: MEMPHIS, July 22 (AP)Two towboats, one pushing two empty ammonia barges, col lided about 22 miles south of Memphis on the Mississippi River last night. There were no injuries. The river was closed to navigation for 5 hours because of the potential danger of gas leakage from the two ammonia barges, according to a Coast Guard spokesman.

title: Teachers Play Pupils to Learn OpenClassroom Theory
description: Ruth Lopez, small and blond, was beside herself with joy. She danced elfishly about the classroom, hardly noticing her companions bus ily playing with sand and printing block letters on posters.

title: McCarthy Said to Lean Toward Entering Several Democratic Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy and a group of veterans from his 1968 cam paign for the Democratic Presidential nomination met in New York's St. Regis Hotel yesterday and for six hours discussed what he should do in 1972. Some of the participants came away con vinced that Mr. McCarthy was, as one of them put it, leaning in the direction of running in several Democratic pri maries.

title: OTB COMPUTERS FAIL FOR 2D DAY
description: Offtrack horseplayers had to do their wagering by the man ual system yesterday after the Offtrack Betting Corporation's computers broke down for the second day in a row.

title: Fourth Yosemite Victim
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., July 22 (UPI) A youth swept over 315foothigh Vernal Falls was the fourth per son to die in an accident in volving Yosemite's waterfalls within the last two weeks. Wit nesses said the youth, whose identity has not yet been dis closed, was playing in the water of the Merced Itiver, Tuesday when he slipped and plunged over the rim of thel folic

title: Wustenchef Wins Hurdles Stakes at Aqueduct
ValentinoQuiet but Beguiling, Tailored but Feminine
description: ROME, July 22It's not easy being king of anything, as many monarchs have ob served, but Valentino man ages. He never falls on his face. With a fall collection that is pure, classic and tailored, he secures his crown for another year. It doesn't hit you over the head the way his last one did when he brought back the nineteen forties with Glenn Miller as background music, but it will do.

title: Francis R. St. John Dies at 63; ExChief Librarian in Brooklyn
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., July 22 Francis R. St. John, chief librarian of the Brooklyn Pub lic Library from 1949 through 1963, died Monday after a long illness. His age was 63.

title: Yonkers Figures Decline
description: YONKERS, July 22Yonkers Raceway's second of three home stands ended tonight with 20,072 fans on hand. Sandy LobeII won the feature handicap onemile trot in 2:05 35, paying $7.80 for $2 to win.

title: ATTELY CRAIG
description: Attely Craig, owner of At tely's Model Agency, 515 Madi son Avenue, and the wife of Lee Solomon, died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after hav ing suffered a stroke. She was 51 years old and lived in Plain ville, N. Y.

title: UTILITY INCREASES PROFITS TO PEAKS
description: The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday records in net income and per share earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30 and for the month of June.

title: CHOLERA REPORTED IN SPANISH PROVINCE
description: MADRID, July 22 (UPI)The Government confirmed tonight that there was an outbreak of cholera in northeastern Spain, but said that the situation was under control.

title: RESTRAINTS FELT IN MONEY MARKET
Formation of Yugoslav Cabinet Blocked Over Inflation Policy
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22  Disagreement over how to cool Yugoslavia's inflated economy is blocking formation of the new Government that is due to be sworn in here within a week, Borba, the semi official Communist party news paper, reported today.

title: WestBank Arab Leaders Planning to Meet Soon
description: Sheik Mohammed Ali Jaa bari, the Mayor of Hebron, outlined plans for a conven tion next month of mayors and business leaders of communi ties in the occupied area of Jordan on the west bank of the Jordan River. The conven tion, he said, would initially take a stand on economic re lations with other Arab coun tries, but would, he hoped, turned into the nucleus of an effective political body.

title: Witness Links Schweitzer To 2d Bribe of $25,000
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A witness who said he spent 20 years on the shady side of the securities field and businesses related to it told a Senate subcommittee today of a sec ond instance in which he al legedly bribed Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer of the New York Supreme Court.

title: Moscow's Dilemma
description: Despite the oftproved capabilities of the Soviet Intel ligence services, the Kremlin evidently was as surprised as everybody else when the Nixon trip to China was announced. The surprise was implicit in the reserved manner with which the Soviet press presented the news. That there was no Moscow line on the subject became clear earlier in the week when sharply different reactions appeared in Warsaw and Sofia. The Poles welcomed the news while the Bulgarians raised the specter of a Sino American alliance against the Soviet Union.

title: New 7% Treasury Bonds Given a Mild Reception
Hanoi Aide in Paris Accuses U.S. of Perfidious Maneuvers
description: PARIS, July 22North Viet nam's chief delegate, Xuan Thuy, apparently alluding to President Nixon's plans to visit Peking, accused the United States today of seeking to divide the Communist world by perfidious maneuvers in a false offensive for peace in Vietnam.

title: Newsprint Cosumption Off
description: Newsprint consumption in the United States in June amounted to 761,754 tons, down 2.2 per cent from the total consumed in June of last year, according to the American Newspaper Publishers Associa tion. It said that the total con sumption of newsprint in this country during the first six months of 1971 totaled 4,637, 628 tons.

title: 14 HURT IN A BEAST AT NEWARK PLANT
description: NEWARK, July 22Fourteen persons were injured today, five of them seriously, in an explosion in a resinfabricating building of the Minnesota Min ing and Manufacturing Compa ny plant here.

title: McCartney and Wife Sued On Another Day Recording
description: Two music publishing com panies sued Paul McCartney, his wife, Linda, and others for $1.05million in State supreme court here yesterday, charging that the defendants had vio lated an exclusive rights agree ment for the song Another Day.

title: 22Week Fetus Is Given Blood; Boy Delivered 24 Hours Later
description: A 22weekold fetus with Rh disease and anemia was par tially delivered by Caesarean section Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center, given a complete blood transfusion through the neck artery and returned to the womb to con tinue gestation.

title: Notes on People
description: I have never heard such language in the House, said Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, as he demanded that Representative William Clay, a Missouri Democrat, apolog ize for remarks about Vice President Agnew.

title: Advertising: Magazineland Picks Its Bigwig
description: Gib McCabe, a Newsweek man for 29 years, once its publisher and now its vice chairman, will be getting the Henry Johnson Fisher Award. It's the biggest thing in the magazine industry, the Pub lisher of the Year.

title: House Vote on Integration Aid Held Unlikely Until September
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A House vote on President Nixon's bill to give Federal money to school districts that are desegregating appeared to day to have been delayed at least until the beginning of school in September.

title: U.S. Urges Soviet to Join In a Missiles Moratorium
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 American negotiators have pro posed to the Soviet Union an arms control agreement that would halt construction of both landbased missiles and missile submarines.

title: Makers of Planes In France to Merge
description: PARIS, July 22The Das sault Company and the Breguet Company, two large builders of airplanes in France, announced today they would merge into a new $300 million a year enterprise to be called the Marcel DassaultBreguet Avia tion Company.

title: A REAGAN PROPOSAL ON MEDICAID BARED
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Under pressure from welfare rights activists, the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare disclosed for public com ment today a controversial pro posal by Gov. Ronald Reagan of California for special exemp tion from some Federal Medic aid regulations for his state.

title: The Beat Picks Up for Daytime Jazz
description: Jazz, traditionally a noc turnal art, is turning up more and more as a daytime diver tisement. This is not precisely a new turn of events. Six years ago businessmen began blowing off their jazz steam at weekly jam sessions called Jazz at Noon at Chuck's Composite, a restaurant on East 53d Street.

title: PATTI HOGAN GAINS ENGLISH NET FINAL
description: LEICESTER, England, July 22 (UPI)Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., defeated a limping Mrs. Judy Dalton of Australia, 36, 86, 64, today to gain the final in the Midland tennis tournament.

title: Lerman Quits Joffrey Ballet
description: Omar K. Lerman, general di rector of the City Center Jof frey Ballet for the last three years, has submitted his resig nation for personal reasons to the company's board of di rectors. The resignation will go into effect Sept. 19. No successor has been named. The company will open its fall sea son here on Oct. 6.

title: ACCUSER OF JUDGE SOUGHT BY COURT
description: The Court on the Judiciary will attempt to question a wit ness who told a Senate sub committee of two occasions that he had bribed State Sup preme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

title: ExchangetoSuspendTrading In Stocks of Cudahy Company
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to suspend trading in the common and $1.25 Series A cumulative con vertible preferred stock of the Cudahy Company. The suspen sion becomes effective Aug. 2, but beginning today all trans actions in these issues will be on a cash basis.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA ABluefish, from 5 to 12 pounds, are being found in quantity on Barne gat Ridge by boats chumming with ground mossbunkers. Anglers are using butterfish, smelt and bunkerbacks. School tuna, 12 to 25 pounds, are being captured in smaller amounts in the same area. Fluke, 2 to 6 pounds, are fairly plentiful in the Spring LakeSeaside Park regions. They are being taken with squid, spearing and smelt. The Jamaica II, out of Bo gan's Basin, returned with a large catch of tilefish found about 85 miles southeast of Manasquan Inlet after a nighthours trip.

title: World Order
description: BELGRADEEven in times of high civilization, such as classical Greece, Renaissance Italy and seventeenth century Europe, foreign war and civil strife were almost constant. Some historians refer to the century prior to 1914 as the long peace. But even in that relatively quiet period there occurred the LatlnAmerican, Italian and Balkan wars of liberation, the American Civil War, the three wars of German unification, the wars in the Crimea, Balkans and the Far East arising from Russian and Japanese expansion, and countless wars in Asia and Africa resulting from European colonialism.

title: Teamster's Car Blown Up
description: DETROIT, July 22 (UPI) The car of a teamster local vice president was torn apart today by four to six sticks of dyna mite, the police said. The Farm ington Township police said the fourdoor sedan belonging to James Clift, vice president of teamster local 337, was parked in front of his apartment in Farmington, a Detroit suburb.

title: U.S. Jury Clears Jersey Teamster Chief
description: NEWARK, July 22Acting on information supplied by Sal vatore Provenzano, president of the New Jersey Joint Team sters Council, a Federal grand jury has deleted his name from a counterfeiting indictment and substituted that of his local's business agent.

title: 983879 Wins in Jersey
description: BUDD LAKE, N. J., July 22 (UPI)The winning number in this week's New Jersey state lottery is 983879. The number was chosen in ceremonies at Budd Lake this morning.

title: Rep. Steele Asserts Gen. Dzu Is Linked To Looting of Bases
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI)  Representative Robert H. Steele said today that the South Vietnamese general he accused of being a heroin trafficker was also being investigated in con nection with the looting of two abandoned United States mili tary bases.

title: Armco Planning to Lay Off 250 at Ashland, Ky., Plant
description: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, July 22 (UPI)  The Armco Steel Corporation reported today it would lay off 250 regular em ployes next week at its Ash land, Ky., works because of de clining demand for flat rolled products.

title: U.S. Official Testifies That Law Enforcement Assistance Program Is Mismanaged and Wasteful
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A senior official of a Con gressional watchdog agency de livered an indictment Coda}, of the Law Enforcement As sistance Administration, a ma jor Federal project to help states to combat crime.

title: WILLIAM O'DONOVAN OF CELANESE SALES
description: TORRANCE, Calif., July 22William L. O'Donovan, a vice president for sales of the Cela nese Corporation of America from 1951 to 1961, died here yesterday after a stroke. He was 64 years old.

title: Two by Two Ending Run
description: Two by Two, the Richard Rodgers Peter Stone Martin Charnin musical starring Dan ny Kaye, will end its Broadway run at the Imperial Theater on Sept. 11. Mr. Kaye's oneyear contract with the show expires on that date. The musical will have played a total of 352 performances.

title: Chile Is Increasing Her Imports To Offset a Shortage of Meat
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 22Chileans are eating increasing amounts of Danish pork French poultry and Argentine beef imported to offset local shortages.

title: JOHNSON REPORTS; END QUITS GIANTS
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 22 The Giants lost their fine de fensive end prospect, Wes Grant, today following an ar gument, but tonight gained Ron Johnson, the club's first 1,000 yard runner, who reported to camp following a threeday holdout.

title: REFINERY PROPOSAL REJECTED IN MAINE
description: AUGUSTA, Me., July 22The Maine Environmental Im lprovement Commission yester day denied the application of Maine Clean Fuels, Inc., to construct a $150million oil refinery on tiny, uninhabited Sears Island, in Penobscot Bay.

title: GICOMBAT DEATHS LOWEST SINCE '65
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22American battle deaths last week were the lowest in nearly six years, the United States command announced to day. It said the total reflected the continuing withdrawal of American troops and the low level of combat.

title: Jersey Central Power Sues G.E. For a Nuclear Generator Delay
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company sued the Gen eral Electric Company yester day for $62.8million in dam ages allegedly suffered from the delayed completion of the Oy ster Creek, N.J., nuclear gen erating station.

title: U.S. QUINTET TAKES WHEELCHAIR FINAL
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 22 Tom Brown, a graduate stu dent at the University of Illinois, scored 25 points today to lead the United States basketball team to a 6650 vic tory over Argentina in the final of the third PanAmerican Wheelchair Games.

title: HENTZ SAYS IT MET LAW ON STOCK SALE
description: H. Hentz & Co., Inc., re sponding to a $5million law suit filed against it by the Insurance Commissioner of Florida, Aaid yesterday that it had complied with all legal requirements and New York Stock Exchange rules in han dling sales for an insurance company.

title: Elks Parley Keeps Word White In Its Membership Requirements
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 22 (AP)Delegates to the Elks national convention rejected today a resolution to remove the word white from the or ganization's membership re quirements.

title: GEORGE E. NOLD, 72, A PHYSICS PROFESSOR
description: ORLANDO, Fla., July 22George E. Nold, retired assist ant professor of physics at the State Agriculture and Technical College, Farmingdale, L. I., died of cancer yesterday. He was 72 years old and had been liv ing here since his retirement in 1968.

title: ExFloor Broker Acquitted
description: A Federal Court jury yes terday acquitted Alfred Peter Avasso, a former floor broker at the American Stock Ex change, of charges of knowing ly transporting two stolen $100,000 United States Treas ury bills to Switzerland. Mr. Avasso, who is 31 years old, was indicted April 6. He lives at 162.08 86th Street, Howard Beach, Queens.

title: EXACTA NOT TOPIC, TRACK AIDE SAYS
description: A Yonkers Raceway director Who chatted in the track's din ing room with Nicholas (Cock eye Nick) Rattenni shortly be fore a suspicious exacta race on June 7 denied under oath 68 stevday that he had any im proper association with the re puted Westchester County un derworld boss.

title: G.O.P. WILL OPEN DOORS TO WOMEN
description: DENVER, July 22Republi can leaders prepared today for a radical increase in the number of women delegates at their national convention next year and a modest rise in repre sentation for black and young people.

title: STOCKS RETREAT THROUGHOUT DAY
Illness Reports Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) Horse owners in all parts of the country were asked today to report any cases of recently ill horses as part of a new ef fort to halt the spread of sleep ing sickness.

title: TREASURY HALTS TRADING IN GOLD
Wilson Apologizes for Accusation in Market Debate
description: LONDON, July 22  The House of Commons debate on British entry into the Common Market brought an unusual apology today from Harold Wil son, leader of the Labor party Opposition.

title: Delta Charged in a Suit With Job Discrimination
description: ATLANTA, July 22 (AP) Delta Air Lines, Inc., has been charged with discrimination against blacks in hiring prac tices in a suit filed in Federal District Court.

title: MICHAEL SOMOGYI, EXPERT ON DIABETES
description: CRESTWOOD, Mo., July 22 (AP)Dr. Michael Somogyi, biochemist known for his dia betes research, died yesterday at the age of 88.

title: S1ow Meal in Fine Setting
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and & car (four triangles to none).

title: BERNAYS ANNOUNCES1 FREEDOM LECTURES
description: A series of lectures by vari ous communication leaders on Freedom of ExpressionFoun dation of American Liberties wilt be sponsored by the Ed ward L. Bernays Foundation of Cambridge, Mass., it was an nounced yesterday by Mr. Bernays.

title: ALABAMA ORDERED TO HOLD ELECTION
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 22  A threejudge Federal court warned the Alabama Leg islature today to be prepared to hold special midterm elec tions next year to meet the constitutional demands of legis lative apportionment.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Marine Midland Bank yesterday an nounced the election of Ulric St. Clair Haynes Jr. as a director. Mr. Haynes is senior vice president of Spencer Stuart & Associaees, management consultants. He is a visit ing lecturer at the Har vard Business School, and a member of the ad visory committee of the National Urban League's Black Executive Ex change Program. Mr. Haynes is a graduate of Amherst College and the Yale University Law School. He completed the Harvard University Ad vanced Management Pro gram in 1966. Mr. Haynes is also a trustee of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, the Wooster School in Danbury, Conn., and the Hampton Insti tute in Hampton, Va., and a director of the Overseas Development Council, the Fresh Air Fund, and the Eisenhower Exchange Fellowships.

title: Sabena
description: BRUSSELS, July 22 (Reuters) The Belgian national airline, Sabena, said today its net loss in 1970 widened to 565 million francs ($11,300,000) from 472 million francs ($9,440,000) in 1969.

title: Patriots Set to Give Up on Kapp
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 22 Such are the uncertainties of pro football that Mike Taliaferro, forgotten, alien ated and asking to be traded a few days ago, is suddenly the No. 1 quarterback of the New England Patriots, a team with a future and 46, 000 season tickets sold for its new stadium.

title: 49ers Settle in Candlestick
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 22 (AP) The San Francisco 49ers said today they would play all 1971 home football games in Candlestick Park.

title: 2 Bronfmans Get Top Seagrams Posts
description: The two sons of the late Samuel Bronfman, founder and president of DistillersSea grams, Ltd.  Edgar M. Bronf man and Charles R. Bronfman  were elected at a directors meeting yesterday to the top executive posts of the Mont realbased liquor concern.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Cahill Dedicates New Bridge
description: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., July 22 (AP)  Gov. William T. Cahill today dedicated a new bridge over the Delaware River, link ing New Hope, Pa.,with Lambert ville. The span is upriver from an existing bridge that carries U.S. Route 202 over the Del aware. The new bridge, built by the Delaware River Joint Toll Bridge Commission, was need ed to carry traffic around the two towns, which become jammed with tourists on week ends and holidays.

title: Wisconsin Youth Charged In Five Shooting Deaths
description: SHEBOYGAN, Wis., July 22 (AP)  Five charges of first degree murder were filed against a Sheboygan youth today, alleging that he shot and killed his widowed mother and the mother and three brothers of a former girl friend.

title: MURPHY IS TRYING NEW POLICE RATIO
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, in an experiment to see whether tighter supervision will mean better police service and less corruption, yesterday ordered a vast increase in the number of sergeants assigned to four widely scattered pre cincts.

title: Britain Bids Libya Apologize For Ordering Plane to Land
description: LONDON, July 22 Britain demanded today that Libya apologize for causing a British Overseas Airways Corporation VC10 airliner to land at Ben ghazi.

title: Canadian Bills Auctioned
description: OTTAWA, July 22 (Canadian Press)The Government today auctioned $170million of new 91day Treasury bills at an average price of 99.130 and average yield of 3.52 per cent, compared with last week's 99.122 and 3.55 per cent. To day's $45million of 182day bills brought 98.122 and 3.84 per cent,

title: Chinese Ceramics Add Color to Museum Show
description: A goat with bright blue horns would be a sport in nature; as a creation in por celain in the hands of by gone Chinese potters, it be comes a work of art and delectable whimsey.

title: 80,000 REMAIN OUT IN PHONE STRIKE
description: About 80,000 dissident tele phone workers in the country remained away from their jobs yesterday, continuing their de fiance of national leaders of the Communications Workers of America.

title: FAIR AMERICAN VICTOR IN CRUISE
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 22  Fair American, a new Etchellsdesigned 34foot sloop owned by an American Yacht Club syndicate of six, today broke Troon's domination of Division I on the 40th annual American Y.C. cruise.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans is quoted (news story July 11) in his defense of the killing of seals in Alaska as stating:

title: NEGRO Group Off to Moscow
description: Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, president of the National Eco nomic GrOwth and Reconstruc tion Organization (NEGRO), left last night with 20 members of his group for an 18day stay in the Soviet Union. Dr. Mat thew and his party will visit Moscow, Leningrad, Tashkent and Samarkand.

title: No Credibility Gap On National Review At the White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The newspapers and news agencies that accepted as genuine the topsecret papers on Vietnam published by National Review this week were not the only ones embarrassed when William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative magazine's publisher, admitted yesterday that he had perpe trated a hoax. They had high official company.

title: A Technological Pearl Harbor
description: Our responsibility since World War IIa responsibility thrust upon us by history and one from which we cannot as a practical matter declinehas been to be the principal instrument for con taining the outward thrust of the Com munist powers. We have succeeded time and againwitness the Berlin crisis and the Cuban missile confronta tionin causing the Soviets to back away from confrontations which might have ignited a third world war precise ly because we had the military power to make the Soviets avoid a test of strength. Our military might, in other words, has been a principal factor in our ability to maintain the tenuous peace which by and large has existed since the end of the Second World War.

title: SOVIET BIDS ISRAEL LOOSEN U.S. LINKS
description: MOSCOW, July 22  A Soviet publication advised Israel today to take advantage of a unique possibility for peace in the Middle East and to loosen her dependence on the United States.

title: Black Caucus Asks Nixon To Check Vote Registration
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)The Congressional Black Caucus asked President Nixon today to send Federal exam iners into Mississippi to check on the recent reregistration of voters in 26 counties..

title: 3 ARE CONVICTED IN JERSEY BRIBERY
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J.. July 22A Burlington County jury here late today found a Hud son County police captain and two Northern New Jersey gam bling figures guilty of con spiracy and bribery in the pro tection of gambling rackets

title: Jet Adopts WeightandSee Attitude
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, July 22 Winston Hill, the Jets 278 pound allpro tackle, may be the best customer for the scale in the Hofstra field house. He checks his weight four times daily.

title: PUBLIC TV TO CUT DOCUMENTARIES
description: There will be more news and interpretation but fewer docu mentaries on public television next season.

title: DurableGoods Orders Down in June
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 New orders for durable goods, an important leading indi cator of the economy, declined in June after increasing in May, the Commerce Department re ported today.

title: Clash in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, July 22 (AP)South Vietnamese troops sweeping through eastern Cambodia in a new drive clashed for the first time today with North Viet namese forces.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your perceptive editorial on July 3, Avoiding Another Money Crisis, urges improvement in the flexibility and stability of the world monetary system. This is a critical need not only to avoid monetary crises but also to allow the U.S. and other countries in dependence in the management of their domestic economies. We can ill afford to allow foreign payments to tie our hands with regard to interest rates or other aspects of full employ ment.

title: YANKEES'
description: Fiveyearold Monty Gibbs, wearing a juniorsized Yankee uniform, stood in the middle of the New York clubhouse after yesterday's game and evoked boisterous laughs from the bigger boys in regular sized Yankee uniforms by imitating Horace Clarke at bat.

title: Mills Reaffirms Opposition To Tax Sharing by States
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, reaffirmed today his opposi tion to letting the states participate in the benefits of revenue sharing, or whatever new form of direct financial aid to local governments ulti mately emerges from his com mittee.

title: City Starts 7Day Methadone Program
description: A new ambulatory detoxifica tion program, featuring treat ment with methadone for sev enday periods and aimed at reaching 36,000 of the city's es timated total of 150,000 heroin addicts, was announced by Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: MRS. JOHN F. CORNELL
description: BRADENTON, Fla., July 22 Mrs. Jane Bevan Cornell, former real estate broker in Mamaroneck, N.Y., wife of John F. Cornell, former pub lisher of Paper Mill News, died Tuesday at the age of 85.

title: Heller Dramatizes His Catch22 on L.I.
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I have been chagrined lately to see such eminent spokesmen as Cyrus S. Eaton (letter July 10) use the argu ment that since the North Vietna mese were better informed about Washington actions and policies than the American people, Congress should insure that more secret information is bared to the American public.

title: The Dance: A Decorative Petrushka
description: American Ballet Theater's production of Fokine's Pe trushka is a beautiful and tactful realization of a mod ern classic.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $721million, up 9 per cent from the year earlier $663million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,459,000,000, up 7 per cent from $6,982,000,000.

title: TELEPHONE TOWER APPROVED BY CITY
description: Plans for a redesigned 540 foot high New York Telephone Company equipment center, which would dominate an area just north of the Brooklyn Bridge, were approved yester day by the Board of Estimate.

title: 3 Arrested Here by F.B.I. In StolenSecurities Case
description: The arrest of three men here on charges of possessing stolen securities valued at over $100, 000 was disclosed yesterday by Federal agents here.

title: Revival of Cleopatra Due on Ziegfeld Screen
description: Cleopatra has been booked into the Ziegfeld Theater for an exclusive, re vival run beginning Wednes day.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: TORONTO, July 22 (Canadian Press)Jim Thorpe, the flanker from Hofstra who was acquired by the Winnipeg Blue Bombers yesterday from the Toronto Ar gonauts, said before he left for Winnipeg today he had hoped to be waived out of the Cana dian League so he could accept an offer from the Los Angeles Rams.

title: 2 Beatles'
description: Thousands of patronsmost ly youths in informal attirewaited overnight Wednesday at Madison Square Garden and at more than 100 Ticketron out lets for tickets to two benefit shows featuring two of the four Beatles, George Harrison and Ringo Starr, and the Indian sitar player Ravi Shankar.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CHICAGO, July 22 (UPI) Jack Tatum, an allAmerica cornerback last season at Ohio State University, has signed multiyear contract with the Oakland Raiders, the club an nounced today. He is practic ing here for the College AllStar game.

title: ALBION H. KOESTLER
description: Albion H. Koestler, president of ReplyOLetter Company, specializing in directmail ad vertising, from 1937 to 1968, died Monday of a heart ailment in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 75 Central Park West.

title: Fischer Now a Chess Hero in the Soviet
description: MOSCOW, July 22Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, who is now only one step from challenging the Soviet grand master Boris Spassky for the world chess title, has sudden ly become a celebrity in the chesscrazy Soviet Union.

title: Chief Expected to Leave Kentucky Fried Chicken
description: Conjecture in New York fi nancial circles late yesterday indicated that John Y. Brown Jr., chairman of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, is expected to resign that post shortly and become a top exec utive and principal of Lum's, Inc.

title: HOTEL LIFE UPSETS RELIEF FAMILIES
description: William Rivera, 12 years old, stood guard over the family belongings in the lobby of the ConcoursePlaza Hotel in the Bronx. The Rivera possessions were packed in suitcases, in cartons, in plastic garbage bags. Some were piled in food carts.

title: Japan Faces Major Shift In Policy Toward China
description: TOKYO, July 22From conservatives to radicals, a con sensus seems to be shaping up that, as a result of President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Peking, Japan confronts a major change in her China policy, and perhaps in her policy toward the United States as well.

title: Roundup: Giants Win in 10th
description: The San Francisco Giants show no signs of cracking in their bid to finish first in the National League's Western Division. Yesterday Ken Henderson and Jimmy Rosario combined to lead. them to an 87 victory over Pittsburgh's Eastern Division leaders in 10 innings. It was San Francisco's 11th triumph in 14 extrainning games.

title: TWO PARTIES URGE YOUNG VOTER AID
description: State leaders of the Demo cratic and Liberal parties yes terday urged a liberalization of the state election laws to per mit more newly enfranchised 18to21yearold voters to par ticipate in next year's Presiden tial primaries.

title: For Wood, the Handwriting Is on the Board
Bridge: TopSeeded Teams Begin Play After Bye Rounds in Spingold
description: CHICAGO, July 22 The topranked teams went into action in the Spingold knock out team championship this afternoon after enjoying a byeround yesterday in the feature of the American Con tract Bridge League's Sum mer Nationals.

title: Market Place: Critic Decries Fund Insurance
description: Insurance against losses in the stock market would be very nice indeed, so the an nouncement by National Se curities and Research that it would offer such protection attracted considerable atten tion.

title: FOOD STAMP PLAN BROADLY REVISED
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Nixon Administration backed down today on a con troversial proposal that would have cut an estimated 275,000 welfare recipients from the Fed eral food stamp program.

title: BREWER &
description: Brewer & Shipley, a folk singing duo who live on a farm, outside Kansas City, are play ing through Monday at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: Saudis Back Hussein
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22Saudi Arabia today became the first Arab country to extend support to King Hussein of Jor dan in his conflict with the fedayeen.

title: The Last Refuge
description: The House Banking Committee has approved a bill that would authorize $2 billion in Government loan guarantees for companies in trouble, especially for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which says it must have $250 million immediately to save it from bankruptcy.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ROMEItaly's political enfant ter rible, Giorgio Almirante, is an avowed exFascist whose adversaries call him neoFascist and who is certainly at least quasiFascist. Mild mannered, quiet, he prefers to think of himself as a qualitative democrat who fa vors liberty for everybody except the Communists, whom he would outlaw. He wants constitutional amendments to give the president strong executive powers, and providing for arbitration of labor disputes.

title: RALSTON DEFEATS RIESSEN IN TENNIS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 22 (UPI)  Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., making ef fective use of drop shots, toppled fifthseeded Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 64, 63, today to continue the wave of upsets in the $50,000 First National tennis tournament.

title: RailTon Mileage Declined By 4.3% During the Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 22Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended July 17 fell to an estimated 13.9 billion tonmiles, 4.3 per cent below the corresponding week a year ago.

title: A PLANT RETURNS TO CITY FROM L.I.
description: At a time when some other companies have been leaving New York City for the suburbs, a manufacturer of office furni ture has moved from Valley Stream, L.I., to the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn. A previous owner moved the plant from Ithe city in 1964.

title: Fund Redemption Total
description: Net redemptions of mutual fund shares totaled $121million in May, according to the In vestment Company Institute. Because of a typographical er ror in yesterday's Market Place column, the May total was er roneously reported to be $12 million.

title: Mills Is Reported Helping In Talks on Steel Imports
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, despite the White House's playing down of his foreign trade negotiating role, is help ing the State Department in difficult discussions on im ported steel, according to Con gressional sources.

title: Good Day for Black Rock
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 22 The Black Rock Yacht Club crew of Bridgeport, captained by Macy Nelson, won the Law Cup today in the Indian Har bor Yacht Club's annual ju nior invitation regatta.

title: Union Carbide Reports Lower Profits on an Increase in Sales
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion, the nation's second largest chemical company, following the industry leader E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., had lower profits in the quarter and six months that ended June 30, despite slightly higher sales, it was reported yesterday. A company spokesman said that this reflected, primarily, lower income from investments and nonoperating activities and the costprice squeeze.

title: Sweig Begins Sentence for Perjury
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., July 22 (AP)  Martin Sweig, who was chief administrative aide to former House Speaker John W. McCormack, entered the Federal penitentiary here today to begin a 30month sentence for lying to a Fed eral grand jury that was in vestigating influence ped dling and for misuse of the Speaker's office.

title: Mrs. Kennedy Is 81
description: HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 22 (UPI)Mrs. Joseph P. Ken nedy celebrated her 81st birth day today. She spent it quietly with Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy and her daughter, Mrs. Sargent Shriver.

title: Technicians Busy as Apollo 15's Countdown Continues
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 22 Despite thundershowers and the threat of lightning strikes, launching pad techni cians continued preparations tonight for Apollo 15, the moonlanding mission set for liftoff next Monday.

title: YOUTH IS FREED IN MUGGING CASE
description: A 17yearold honor student who was erroneously identified as an assailant in a mugging in the Bronx was exonerated yesterday after the police ar rested a lookalike suspect.

title: Diversified Tobacco Concern at PeakArmco Net Off
Challenge: Second Life for a Play
description: The odds against scoring a hit with a new stage pro duction either on or off Broadway are estimated to be about 10 to 1. The chances of succeeding with a revival, according to Theodore Mann, founderproducerdirector of the Circle in the Square, are in 1,000.challenge they offer. But, on further consideration, he added:

title: Franulovic, Belkin Advance
description: WINSTON SALEM, N. C., July 22 (AP)Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia and Mike Belkin of Canada gained spots today in the semifinals of the Tangle wood international tennis tour nament.

title: Riot Trauma Lingers in Detroit
description: DETROIT, July 22Nobody talks any more about the great riot that began here exactly four years ago to morrow, bathing the streets in the warm glow of burning buildings and familiarizing the city folk with the pop pop of machinegun bullets and the buzzing of the chop pers. There was so much discus sion and analy sis, said Detroit's Mayor, Roman Gribbs. Every cause factor, every need, every lapse, the pluses and the negatives, solutions pro posed.... It's been talked through.

title: U.S. Says Foe Is Building Road Across Buffer Zone
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The State Department said today that North Vietnam was building a road across the demilitarized zone into the northern section of South Vietnam, but refused to say whether such action violates the 1968 understanding that led to the end of United States bombing of North Vietnam.

title: BANKERS WILL LEND TO MINORITY BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) Commercial banks have set up an investment company called Minibanc with projected assets of $3million to $10mil lion to lend capital to minority owned banks, the American Bankers Association announced yesterday.

title: MORRIS UMANSKY
description: Morris Umansky, who re tired in 1941 as a judge of the First District Court of Hudson County, Jersey City, died yes terday of heart failure in Christ Hospital, Jersey City. He was 85 years old and lived at 309 Monastery Place, Union City.

title: OMO AFRICA TROUPE OPENS DANCE SERIES
description: Omo Africa is a small, eager company of a dozen dancers and musicians who have interested themselves in the use and development of ethnic dance materials. While their enthusiasm is commend able, their expertise trails be hind at some considerable dis tance. The company presented a program of mixed works at the Manhattan Theater Club Wednesday evening to open a black dance series that is sched uled to run through August.

title: Big Four Meet on Berlin; Slow Progress Reported
description: BERLIN, July 22The Am bassadors of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union held a thorny and rela tively brief session today in their protracted effort to re solve some of their differences over Berlin.

title: Palmer Leads by a Stroke With 64
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 22 Arnold Palmer, who has been resting from tournament golf, put together a 64 today, his low round of the year, to lead the $250,000 Westchester Clas Sic by a stroke.

title: Shore Top Man in Europe
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 22 (UPI)Bill Shore of the United States topped the overall stand ing in the European Lightning Class championships today, guiding his craft Finesse to 149 points in the six races con ducted this week.

title: San Quentin's Death House
description: TAMAL, Calif.I came to San Quentin's death house in August, 1969, after being convicted of murder in Bakersfield, Calif. My case is be fore the California Supreme Court on appeal.

title: Puerto Rico's Envoy Nick Lugo Jr.
description: At the age of only 28, the new occupant of the post that is tantamount to being Puerto Rico's ambassador to the mainland United States exemplifies the thrusting sec ond generation of the city's Puerto Rican community.

title: LOAN CLAIM BARRED BY SLATER OF I.O.S.
description: GENEVA, July 22  Robert E. Slater, president of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., has re jected the claim that this embattled financial group is in default on a $5million loan, from a subsidiary of the Inter national Controls Corporation of Plainfield, N. J., it was learned today.

title: Commandos Based in Syria Increase Attacks on Northern Jordan
description: RAMTHA, Jordan, July 22Syrianbased Arab commandos stepped up their attacks on northern Jordanian border areas last night and today, despite statement by King Hussein that life had returned to normal in Jordan.

title: Horse Virus Feared in 3 More States
description: HOUSTON, July 22A virus that has killed more than 1,000 horses in Texas may have es tablished a foothold in three other statesOklahoma, Loui siana and Arkansasthe Unit ed States Department of Agri culture said today.

title: BEACHES ARE SHUT BY NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 22The Westchester County beach at Glen Island was closed today after the New Rochelle Health Department found what it called an unsafe bacterial count.

title: COALITION ACTING ON THE A.S.P.C.A.
description: Members of humane organi zations here have formed a co alition to effect a 'thorough reformation of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which they contend is itself cruel to animals.

title: SUIT FILED BY HOLDER FOR FUND OF AMERICA
description: Philip Halbfinger, a share holder in the Fund of America, filed suit here yesterday to re cover damages on behalf of the fund and its shareholders. He requested a trial by jury.

title: Rail Union Accepts a Pact With Work Rule Changes
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 The Chicago & North West ern Railway and the United Transportation Union reached agreement today on a new contract. It was the first major breakthrough in the long dis pute between the union and the nation's railroads.

title: Lifeguards and State Will Meet on Strike
description: Representatives of the Long Island State Park Commission and union lifeguards, who have refused to work at Long Island's state beaches since the season began six weeks ago, will meet today for the first time since June 30 to discuss their contract dispute.

title: Kennedy Hints U.S. May Plan To Help Police East Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, chairman of the judiciary sub  committee on refugees, publicly implied today that the United States was planning to send police teams to East Pakistan.

title: Priest and 6 Filipinos Saved After 37 Days Adrift at Sea
description: RABAUL, New Britain, July 22A Canadian priest and six young Filipinos landed here in perfect health after having drifted in a disabled boat for 1,200 miles in 37 days before they were rescued by a Japa nese ship.

title: An Offbeat Barbecue: Skewered Shrimp and Lime
description: In the menus below dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: EXPANDED TRADE WITH RED NATIONS SET BY CONFEREES
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 House and Senate conferees agreed today to open the way for a further expansion of trade with Communist coun tries, including China, by au thorizing the ExportImport Bank to supply export credits for shipments to those coun tries.

title: A REPUTED MAFIOSO SEIZED IN BROOKLYN
description: Anthony Augello, a reputed Mafia figure, was arrested last night after the police allegedly found two loaded.38caliber pistols in the car he was driv ing in the Sheepshead Bay sec tion of Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Lester Markel believes that an inde pendent, wellfunded, innovative pub lic TV, once it is weaned from Capi tol Hill and Corporation Heights, could make average citizens more knowledgeable. [OpEd July 8.]

title: ANTIRED CRUSADERS WARY OF NIXON TRIP
description: MANILA, July 22Anti Communist crusaders from 45 nations began their annual convention here today deter mined to carry on despite the thaw in relations between the United States and China.

title: DR. KARL W. ASCHER
description: Dr. Karl W. Ascher, associ ate professor emeritus of ophthalmology at the Univer sity of Cincinnati Medical Col lege, died Saturday in Cincin nati at the age of 84.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS TRADING EASES
Studies Link Drug Use to Parents'
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 Three recent largescale studies in the United States and Cana da indicate that illicit drug use is far higher than average among teenagers whose par ents use tranquilizers or stim ulant medications regularly, leader in one of the studies said today.

title: HOUSE INCREASES SUM FOR SPEAKER
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The House by voice vote to day increased by $50,000 a year the clerical allowance for the office of Speaker Carl. Albert, Democrat of Oklahoma.

title: Calcutta! 2d Edition Due
description: A second edition of Oh! Calcutta! is being planned by Hillard Elkins, producer of the current Broadway musical. Mr. Elkins, who also is the pro ducer of The Rothschilds, is in Europe collecting materialsketches and musical numbers for the second edition, which is expected to be done here in the fall.

title: Convulsions in Khartoum
description: General Nimeiry's reported return to power only three days after he was ousted by a junta of leftleaning officers underscores the continuing instability of the Sudanindeed, of the whole Arab world.

title: N.Y. State Harness Group Bans Horses From Texas
description: The New York State Harness Commission yesterday ordered all tracks under its jurisdiction to refuse admittance to any horses being shipped from Texas if the horses were in that state on or after July 9.

title: WESTBURY STAND TO OPEN TONIGHT
description: WESTBURY, L.I., July 22 Roosevelt Raceway opens a 72 program harnessracing meet ing tomorrow night with its innovative triple again added to the customary win, place, show, daily double and exacta wagering.

title: Senate Sets Vote on Limiting Debate on LockheedLoan Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Senate agreed today to vote Monday on a move to limit debate on legislation de signed to aid the financially pressed Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration.

title: U.S. Arms Agency Still Seeks OnSite Inspection
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 The Arms Control and Disarma ment Agency maintained today that despite recent progress in seismic detection, the United States must still insist upon some onsite inspections to monitor a ban on underground nuclear tests.

title: Nimeiry Regains Control in Sudan as Rivals Are Detained in Libya
description: CAIRO, July 22The Suda nese leader who was deposed in a coup d'etat Monday reclaimed power today after neighboring Libya ordered plane carrying two of his ri vals down and took them into custody.

title: Creedmoor's Chief Testifies on Income
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 22The director of Creedmoor State Hospital testified today that he had supplemented his $37,500 annual state salary with $28,200 in outside fees.

title: AntiWar Veteran Accused of Exploiting P. O.W. Issue
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)A number of wives of American prisoners of war lashed out today at John F. Kerry, the peacegroup lead er, accusing him of using the prisoner issue as a spring board to political office.

title: Nixon's China Goal: Genuine Diplomatic Turning Point
description: WASHINGTON, July 22A week has passed since Presi dent Nixon scheduled his jour ney to Peking and shook up the world of diplomacy.

title: Football Hall of Fame Evokes Cahill Inquiry
description: TRENTON, July 22 (UPI)Gov. William T. Cahill has asked for a full financial disclosure on the proposed College Football Hall of Fame to be built on property belonging to Rutgers, the state university.

title: Dutch, in.a Shift, Won't Dump 600 Tons of Chemicals Into Sea
description: LONDON, July 22A Dutch chemical company recalled one of its tankers to Rotterdam to night after protests by six Governments over plans to dump 600 tons of chemical wastes in the North Atlantic.

title: Microwave Ovens, At a Rate of 1 in 10, Held to Be Leaking
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Public Health Service estimates that one out of every 10 micro wave ovens in home use in the United States last year proba bly leaked radiation in excess of the industry's own voluntary limits.

title: Senate Confirms Neaher As a Federal Judge Here
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Edward R. Neaher as a Federal judge for the Eastern District of New York. The district covers Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

title: Mr. Agnew and the World
description: Vice President Agnew no longer can qualify as an innocent abroad. Given the office he holds, his third foreign trip is bound to affect the interests of this country in the world. Why was it that his itinerary took him almost exclusively to countries under authori tarian rule, rather than to some of the democracies along the route?

title: Rogers Confers With President On Policy in the U.N. on China
description: WASHINGTON, July 22President Nixon and Secretary of State William P. Rogers con ferred at the White House to day in an attempt to define United States policy on the thorny problem of Chinese, representation at the United Nations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is difficult to know when and how the Scarpetta v. De Martino case and the fate of Baby Lenore will ulti mately be settled, but as a board mem ber of the SpenceChapin Adoption Service, I can no longer refrain from making a strong protest of the treat ment accorded the agency by the press.

title: Salami Is Recalled From U.S. Stores After 9 Become Ill
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP)  Genoa Salami, an Armour & Company product, is being re called from stores because nine persons became ill from eating it, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Temporary Solution
description: The question of where students under 21 should vote has farreaching implications, involving a delicate balance of equities. A number of cases are already before the courts. While these are pending, a good interim step would be the one proposed by Senator Cranston of Cali fornia.
