He would give students the choice of voting for Federal officials either in their school districts or their family's home district, while their voting residence for local elections would be left to the determination of the several states.

title: Sudan at a Glance
description: THE COUNTRYLargest in Africa, 967,275 square milesabout twothirds the size of Indiaa sprawling plateau that encompasses disparate environments, from the northern deserts to central grassy plains and tropical swamps and rain forests in the south. It has a 400mile Red Sea coastline and is bordered also by Egypt, Ethiopia, Kenya, Uganda, the Congo, Chad, Libya and the Central African Republic.

title: KENT STATE STUDY CITES GUARDSMEN
description: A privately researched report on the Kent State University shootings, which is being widely circulated by a church group, contends that a small group of Ohio National Guardsmen had agreed among themselves to punish students and opened fire on a signal. The report ap peals for a Federal grand jury investigation.

title: Oil Companies Register Advances in Quarter and Six Months
description: Texaco, Inc., and the Getty Oil Company yeserday an nounced earnings gains for the quarter and first six months of 1971.

title: FT.C. CRITICIZED ON GAS RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, July 22The general manager of the American Public Gas Associa tion charged before a Congres sional committee today that the Federal Power Commission had failed to protect consumer in terests when it approved a $44 billion increase in gas rates. It acted, he said, on the basis of questionable evidence.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.3 From WeekAgo Level
Bayh Is Heckled and Spat On at Florida Airport
description: ORLANDO, Fla., July 22 (UPI)Shouting demonstrators heckled Senator Birch Bayh and one of them spat in his face today when the Indiana Democrat arrived here to test Florida support for a possible 1972 Presidential bid.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's such a brilliant ideawhy hadn't someone thought of it before? To walk through the Louvre with some of today's most interesting artists and try to get them to say what they see. Imagine what they could tell us about the relation between those works on the walls and their own. An art critic who is as much an enthusiast as a scholar, who stimulates his partners instead of interviewing them, Pierre Schnei der would seem to be the perfect host for these strolls through the incredible land scape of the Louvre.

title: CITY TRANSIT UNIT USING DRUG TESTS
description: The New York City Transit Authority has begun using uri nalysis to determine whether job applicants are drug users, and is rejecting those whose test results are positive.

title: PAN AM AIRWAYS REPORTS DEFICIT
description: Pan American World Air ways reported yesterday a $2, 387,000 net loss for June and a deficit of $15,589,000 for the second quarter. For the six months ended June 30, the defi cit reached $39,465,000.

title: Delta Air Lines
description: Delta Air Lines, the nation's fifth largest domestic trunkline (in terms of revenuepassenger miles), reported yesterday a net income of $11,372,000, or 59 cents a share, for the quarter to June 30. In the corresponding quarter last year, the compapy had earnings of $14,022,000, or 73 cents a share,

title: Seaver Sets Back Cubs, 51
Ali Watts Parade Marshal
description: LOS ANGELES, July 23 (UPI) Muhammad Ali was named today as grand marshal at the Watts Summer Festival parade next month.

title: Chrysler Official Retires
description: John D. Leary announced in Detroit yesterday his retire ment as vice president in charge of administration of the Chrysler Corporation, effective Oct. 1. Mr. Leary has been Chrysler's chief labor nego tiator for about 20 years. He joined the Chrysler labor rela tions staff in 1941, and was elected vice president in charge of personnel in 1958, and as vice president in charge of administration in 1963. He has been a Chrysler director since 1959.

title: Agnews Stay Aloof at Spanish Resort
description: SOTOGRANDE, Spain, July 23We have quite a lot of counts here, Mrs. Ann Clay, the English publicrelations woman for Sotogrande, said as she turned down the offer of an orange slice for her second glass of Sangria.

title: San Diegans Expressing Some Misgivings
description: SAN DIEGO, July 23The Republican party's decision to hold its 1972 convention in San Diego was greeted tonight with scattered cheers and considera ble misgivings among this city's 700,000 citizens despite their predominantly Republican loyalties.

title: A Game Left Over From a Gentler Age
description: PHELPS, N. Y., July 23 (AP)Summer is a delight for Anna Salisbury. Every other Thursday she gets out her club and ball and heads for the course. Golf? No!

title: Philadelphia Bar Tax Out
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP)City Council refused to day to reconsider a 10 per cent acrossthebar liquor tax bill, thereby upholding the veto of Mayor James H. J. Tate.

title: Saratoga Springs Sprucing Up for Season
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Despite a windstorm, soft economic conditions and bathless bathhouses, this old resort is turning a sunnily optimistic face toward the season.

title: Resignation Denied By K.F.C. Chairman
description: John Y. Brown Jr., denied yesterday reports that he planned to resign as chairman of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, the nation's largest commercial foodservice com pany.

title: Six Killed as Fire Strikes a New Orleans Hotel
description: NEW ORLEANS July 23 (AP)Fire raced through the 12th floor of the downtown Howard Johnson Motor Lodge today, killing six per sons and forcing some guests to escape by swinging down four stories from balcony to balcony.

title: Exacta Payoff Provokes Fans at Monmouth Park
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 23 (UPI)  Fans created a dis turbance at Monmouth Park to day when the third race exacta payoff was $63.40 after the winning horse paid $34.60 straight.

title: Tubman of Liberia
description: William V. S. Tubman's long tenure as the autocratic but sometimes benevolent President of Liberia, now ended at 75, must be judged against the unique and checkered history of the African republic founded by freed American slaves. Given that origin, Liberia has never been able entirely to escape the stigma of being something of a ward of the United States.

title: Times Will Syndicate Articles by Astronauts
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 23 (UPI) The special fea tures division of The New York Times will syndicate bylined articles by the three Apollo 15 astronauts and one of their backups, in the United States and abroad, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration an nounced today.

title: $100,000 Bail Set; Judge Tells Suspect It Keeps Him Alive
description: Anthony Augello, who the police say is an associate of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., was held in $100,000 bail in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yes terday, charged with illegal possessing weapons.

title: Dance: Tudor's Verona
description: When Antony Tudor's Ro meo and Juliet was first performed in 1943, it was a landmark in American ballet. I remember when I saw it three years laterNora Kaye had replaced Alicia Markova as Juliet, but Hugh Laing was still the Romeo  it struck me as one of the purest and most poetic bal lets I had ever seen. And yet when American Ballet The ater, after many years of ef fort, revived it at the New York State Theater on Thurs day night I was oddly dis appointed.

title: SPAIN SEEKS SUPPLY OF CHOLERA VACCINE
description: MADRID, July 23Spain has asked the United States for 10 million doses of anticholera vaccine, according to informed sources here.

title: Moscow Says Industrial Output Grows Faster Than Expected
description: MOSCOW, July 23The So viet Union reported today that its industry continued to per form at a higher rate than planned for the first six months of the year.

title: IRWIN J. COHEN
description: Irwin J. Cohen, a lawyer who specialized in immigration law and maintained an office in New York's Chinatown sec tion for 25 years, died in his sleep yesterday. He was 64 years old and lived at 1124 East 38th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Palmer Widens Edge to 2 Shots on 134
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 23Lee Trevino, the Texan whose spectacular golf swept the United States, Canadian and British Open championships during the last month, failed by one stroke today to qualify for the last 36 holes of the $250,000 Westchester Classic as Arnold Palmer continued to set the pace.

title: The Talk of Hebron
description: HEBRON, IsraeliOccu pied Jordan, July 21On a rocky hillside at the edge of this ancient city of the Pa triarchs an extraordinary apartment house is nearing completion.

title: 14.46% of Fund's Holders Call for Fee Justification
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  A substantial minority of the shareholders of the Fidelity Trend Fund voted today to re quire this mutual fund to make public a detailed justification of the annual fee it pays to its managers.

title: HARRY CHAPIN SINGS GORGEOUS BALLADS
description: Harry Chapin, who usually composes for his brothers' rock group, The Chapins, now is playing and singing his own songs.

title: Search for Cans Speeded as 6 More Lots of Bon Vivant Soups Are Found to Be Underprocessed
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 The Food and Drug Administra tion moved today to accelerate the collection of Bon Vivant soups and other food products after finding evidence of under processing in the company's black bean soup and in more of its vichyssoise.

title: Oliver Drops Out Again
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., July 23. (UPI)Chip Oliver, the Oakland linebacker who quit football a year ago to join a commune, left the Raiders' training camp, ending his comeback as a 185pound safetyman.

title: SALES TAX EFFECT FELT IN CITY INDEX
description: Spurred by the increase in the state sales tax, the Con sumer Price Index in the met ropolitan area rose sharply in June, the Bureau of Labor Sta tistics reported yesterday.

title: Banks Deny Allegation
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) Officials of two Chicago banks denied today accusations of a witness, who has since been identified as Michael Raymond, who told a Senate subcommit tee that the banks had made questionable loans to crime syndicate figures.

title: Deegan Traffic Jammed
description: Congestion in southbound vehicular traffic on the Major Deegan Highway eased at 6:30 P.M. yesterday after a truck got stuck partly on a ramp near 176th Street, slowing traffic for five hours.

title: Louisiana City Warned
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP)  The Environmental Protec tion Agency told Bogalusa, La., today to start cleaning up its river pollution within 180 days or face possible court action.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF AS VOLUME EASES Index Down 0.03Declines Exceed Gains, 480 to 338
description: Prices drifted lower again on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, with the index clos ing at 25.44, down 0.03. A week ago the index stood at 25.61.

title: Premier of Russian Republic Loses Post
description: MOSCOW, July 23Gennadi I. Voronov, a member of the ruling Communist party Polit buro, today lost his post as head of the Russian Republic's government and was trans ferred to a less important ministerial assignment.

title: EASING IS SHOWN BY STOCK PRICES Some Wall Street Analysts Describe the Market as Currently Indecisive AVON SHARES PLUMMET Level Tumbles 5 Points to Finish Day at 99 After Trading as Low as 95
description: In a market dominated by earnings reports and earnings prospects, stock prices edged lower yesterday. On Wall Street, some analysts described the market as currently inde cisive.

title: U.S. Group Leaves Peking
description: HONG KONG, July 23 (Reu tersA delegation of 13 mem bers of the Committee of Con cerned American Scholars left Peking today after a month's visit to China, Hsin Hua, the Chinese press agency reported. The group is due here tomor row.

title: DRAFT MAY TURN TO EXSTUDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Gov ernment might be forced to start conscripting men previous ly deferred from the draft un less Congress passed a draft extension bill by September.

title: HIJACKER TRIPPED A METAL SENSOR
description: The man who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner at La Guardia Airport yester day had aroused the suspicions of airline employes enough to make them search a small bag he was carrying aboard the plane. But no weapon was found, so the line's agents let him board the aircraft.

title: Contenders Running Fast
description: SAIGON, July 23Contend ers for South Vietnam's presi dency are filling the air these days with charges and counter charges, some aimed at the United States, some at each other. A few are even intended to influence the voters.

title: WILSON OF ASTROS HALTS METS, 5 TO 1
description: A crowd of 37,227 went out to Shea Stadium last night to see if it was true, and it was.

title: State Department Primer On the War Discontinued
description: Once upon a time, there was a curious child who wrote a letter to a city called Washington, where the Pres ident lives, asking if some one would tell him, please, about this thing called Viet nam that the grownups were talking about all the time.

title: Wedgies Revived
description: They used to be known as landlady's shoes and Woolworth's has been stocking them for 20 years. They have rubber soles and canvas tops and were bought mainly by older women because they were soft and comfortable. Now they've traded their littleoldladyin tennisshoes image and have become camp to the young.

title: SECURITIES TAKEN, BANK CLERK SEIZED
description: A 25yearold clerk employed by the Bankers Trust Company was seized yesterday on a busy street in the financial district as he sought to sell $1.2million in negotiable securities for $40,000, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: MORE ARMS HELP TO PAKISTAN SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Senator Stuart Symington dis closed today that the Admin istration still intended to per mit approximately $15million in arms to be shipped to Pakis tan despite repeated official statements implying that a total embargo had been imposed on arms since civil war broke out in East Pakistan March 25.

title: F.C.C. Hearings on WPIX Are Stayed for 2 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Further sessions in a Federal Communications Commission hearing on a challenge to the license of television station WPIX in New York were stayed today for two weeks.

title: CONSUMER PRICES INCREASE SHARPLY FOR SECOND MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Consumer prices rose strongly in June for the second consecu tive month, following four months of slackened inflation, the Labor Department report ed today.

title: 2 Batteries Are Replaced on Apollo 15
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 23The Apollo 15 countdown continued without interruption tonight after launching crews overcame a battery problem in the lunar landing vehicle.

title: Van Heflin, Actor, Dead at 60; Won Fame in Film and on Stage
description: HOLLYWOOD, July 23 (UPI)  van Heflin, one of Holly wood's most versatile actors, died at Cedars of Lebanon Hos pital today at the age of 60.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WINCHESTER, Va., July 23 (UPI)Betsy Rawls shot a threeunderpar 69 today in the opening round of the $20,000 O'Sullivan women's open golf tournament at Winchester Country Club. She had a stroke lead over Margie Masters and Kathy Ahearn.

title: Leaders of Chile and Argentina Meeting to Discuss Problems
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 23 President Salvador Allende Gos sens, leader of Chile's leftwing Government, and General Ale jandro Agustin Lanusse, Argen tina's military President, began a twoday meeting today on a wide range of common prob lems.

title: Steinkraus Takes $2,400 In London Show Jumpoff
description: LONDON, July 23 (Reuters) Bill Steinkraus of the United States won the $2,400 top prize tonight in the richest event at the Royal Interna tional horse show. Steinkraus rode Fleet Apple to the only faultless round in a fivehorse jumpoff for the John Player Trophy.

title: Boise Cascade Reports
description: The Boise Cascade Corpora tion announced yesterday net losses for the quarter and six months ended June 30 resulting from inclusion of a $44million extraordinary charge.

title: Insurance Leader Resigns
description: O. Kelley Anderson has re signed as chairman and director of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston, effective Aug. 2, anti cipating his normal retirement in 1972, it was announced yesterday. His function as chairman will be assumed by Abram T. Collier, president.

title: Governor, in Capital, Replies to Foes of Tax Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 Governor Rockefeller answered the two most powerful enemies of revenue sharing today, Rep resentative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and the committee's ranking Republi can, John W. Byrnes of Wis consin.

title: Red Tide Returns in Force to Tampa Bay Area
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 23After a fiveday lull, Tam pa Bay's socalled red tide, a neurotoxin that discolors sea water and in heavy concentra tions kills fish, returned in force today.

title: Arrest in Jersey Case
description: CAMDEN, July 23 (AP)A 55yearold Cinnaminson man was arrested and charged with possession of $1million worth of stolen securities today, the F.B.I. said.

title: Antiques: Folk Art Show
description: Pennsylvania folk art is on display in a small but com prehensive exhibition on the third floor of the NewYork Historical Society at 170 Cen tral Park West.

title: Robert Jenks, Yale Graduate, Weds Miss Joya Utermohlen
description: The chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting here yester day for the marriage of Miss Joya Utermohlen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Theo door Utermohlen of New York, to Robert Darrah Jenks, son of Mrs. Meylan Jenks of Wilton, Conn., and the late Edward North Jenks. The Rev. Kenneth O. Jones per formed the ceremony.

title: Roundup: Phils Defeat Cubs With a Money Wallop, 4 to 3
description: There are socalled mon ey players in every sport, and the Philadelphia Phillies not only have one, he even bears the name. Last night in Veterans Stadium, Don Money hit his sixth homer of the season to provide the decisive run in the Phillies' 4.3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Convicts End Sitdown
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 23 (UPI)About 600 inmates at the Federal penitentiary here ended today a sitdown strike that began Wednesday over grievances.

title: Delegate Apportionment For G.O.P. Convention
description: DENVER, July 23 (AP) Following is the unofficial apportionment of delegates from each state to the 1972 Republican National Conven tion, subject to formal issu ance of the call to the con vention by the national committee later this year:

title: Kahane Gets 5Year Suspended Sentence in Bomb Plot
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane received a fiveyear suspended sen tence, was fined $5,000 and was placed on probation for five years here yesterday for plotting to make a bomb.

title: Quiet Voices in Carolina
description: CHARLESTON, S. C.Though some South Carolinians complain that the pace of desegregation is too fast or too slow, the vast majority of black and white citizens are adjusting in good temper to changing times. With a few lamentable exceptions, this state has avoided the kind of angry confron tations that have been commonplace in other regions.

title: Ali Gets Down to Serious Work
description: HOUSTON, July 23In the heat of the Astrohall, Mu hammad Ali flopped back on a rubbing table today after his workout.

title: Man in the News
description: Huang Hua, who arrived in Ottawa yesterday to become the first Chinese Communist Ambassador to Canada, is one of Peking's most trusted dip lomats.

title: When They Go Shopping, It's in the Garage
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.America's latest weekend sport is tag sales, also known as garage sales since that is where they are most frequently held. In the East, tag sales abound throughout spring, summer and fall in suburban areas of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut. They are going con cerns in California, and elsewhere in the country they are growing rapidly.

title: Pacific Telephone Seeks Capital for Construction
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said yes terday at San Francisco that it would most likely have to raise about $500million of new capital next year to fi nance its construction pro gram. This would be in addi tion to the $300million it exp pects to raise from an offering of common shares in Septem ber.

title: L.I.R. May Be Struck Monday Unless Ronan Joins Bargaining
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 23The United Transportation Union, which represents 1,600 Long Island Railroad trainmen, announced today that it would strike the railroad at 5 P.M. on Monday unless Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Met ropolitan Transportation Au thority, which owns the line, enters contract negotiations.

title: Needless Affliction
description: The city of Los Angeles is committing itself to pay $200 million, including interest charges, to buy up some 2,000 houses whose inhabitants have been driven des perate by jet planes using the nearby municipal airport. The victims are to be congratulated on their release from a tortured existence, but what is to be said for the reasoning processes of a society that can waste money at that rate which might more readily have been used to soften the noise of jet planes to the point of making them endurable?

title: 7 BANNED DRIVERS FIND WORK SCARCE
description: New York's banned harness racing stars are being given the cold shoulder by other tracks, a phone check disclosed yesterday.

title: Peking Envoy Pledges Friendly Canadian Ties
description: OTTAWA, July 23Huang Hua, Peking's first Ambassa dor to Canada, arrived here today pledging that he and his colleagues would do our utmost to develop friendly relations between the two countries.

title: Charges of Illegal Wiretaps Detailed in Ellsberg Brief
description: BOSTON, July 23 (UPI)  Lawyers for Daniel Ellsberg filed a ninepage brief with Federal magistrate today, de tailing their contention that be cause of illegally obtained wire tap evidence Dr. Ellsberg should not stand trial for leaking the Pentagon papers.

title: Computers Fail Again, But OTB Betting Rises
description: A balky computer system confronted offtrack bettors again yesterday, forcing the Offtrack Betting Corporation to rely on manual issuance of tickets at all 14 sites.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GENEVA, July 23The Swiss Federal Health Service recom mended today that all persons intending to visit Spain under go an anticholera vaccination.

title: Landlord Says Hijacker Hoped to Marry in Italy
description: CLIFTON, N. J., July 23Richard A. Obergfell, who was identified as the man who tried to hijack a T.W.A. jet to Italy today, spoke fluent Italian and had a girlfriend in Italy that he hoped to marry.

title: Fierce Countermove Seen
description: PARIS, July 23Two Sudan ese diplomats proclaiming loy alty to Premier Nimeiry said today that the Communists had tried to depose him be cause time was running out against them, and predicted that the counterstroke would be fierce.

title: Twice Worthy Favored in Brooklyn Handicap
description: The Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct today will have a gross value of $117,100 if all 14 overnight entrants go. The winner of the 1mile test will earn $70,260. Listed for its 83d running, the Brooklyn is the third part of the New York Racing Association's handicap triple crown, which has been won only three times.

title: Texaco Drills Deep Well
description: Texaco, Inc., said yesterday that it had completed the world's deepest producing well in the GomezEllenburger Fields near Fort Stockston, Tex. The well was perforated to the depth of 21,837 feet to 24,040 feet.

title: TED FIO RITO DIES; BIGBAND LEADER
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., July 23 (UPI)  Ted Fio Rito, big band leader of the 1930's and a composer of many popular tunes, died last night at Baptist Memorial hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Nixon Hails Leadership
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) President Nixon said today that Mr. Tubman worked tire lessly for the unity of Liberia's diverse peoples and for the country.

title: Screen: 'The 7 Minutes':Court Is Focus of Russ Meyer's Latest
description: Among the people who take him seriously, it is widely accepted dogma that the really good Russ Meyer disappeared with the last of his independent exploitationswith, among others, "Lorna" and "Vixen" and "Harry, Cherry and Raquel"and that it has not re-emerged since he left the Devil and sold his soul to 20th Century-Fox with "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls." None of the evidence disputes this judgment.And yet, I suspect that the theory is wrong, though the facts are right, that one bad movie doesn't make a falien idol, and that Russ Meyer will triumph even over clothes and nice-girl heroines and medium-budget respectabilityas he begins to do in "The Seven Minutes," another bad movie, which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.Unlike most of his colleagues in the sex-and-violence field, Meyer appreciates his subject not just for kicks or as theme, but rather as a mode of personal expressiona little specialized, of course, but none the less real for all that. He has never been so much concerned with undressing his girls (there are maybe five seconds of nudity in "The Seven Minutes") as admiring their appetites, their overwhelming proportions (but not so much their seductive flesh), their often destructive and self-destructive wills.Against them he matches men, often inadequate to the women but overpowering to everything else, who booze and brawl and with a kind of gigantic clumsy gracefulness establish the profound parody of elemental force that is the basis for action in the Russ Meyer world. It is that world, and its wonderful specific manifestations in the north woods, in Southern backwaters, in a kind of small-business subdomesticity of the Los Angeles suburbs, that is most fatally lacking in "The Seven Minutes."The film is based on an unreadable Irving Wallace novel that millions of Americans have read, for all I know, with pleasure. The subject is obscenity law and the method is to quote every authority on the subject from Richard Kuh on up. It has a story in which a bright, young lawyer loses his fiance and his fortune but finds his soul (and another girl) while defending in court a novel called "The Seven Minutes," by one J J Jadway. Meyer keeps the story, keeps a rather depressing number of the quotations, and though he slightly spices up everybody's private life, he centers his attention on the court case and its ramifications.I don't think that a court of law is the right Russ Meyer arena, and "The Seven Minutes," which had started out pretty well, bogs down hopelessly in its courtroom legalisms and its absolutely non-cliff-hanging rush to unearth the real identity of the mythical J J Jadway. The plot is very complicated, and the cast of characters is enormous (and in at least one case  Wayne Maunder as the lawyer  rather good) and none of it is really amenable to that reduction to monumental simplicities that is near the center of Meyer's dramaturgy.On some of the peripheries, the film does well enough, however. For example, any Russ Meyer fan will appreciate the symbolic background musicwhen, in the gung-ho prosecuting attorney's office, a portrait of General MacArthur behind the desk, we begin to hear the Field Artillery Song on the sound track; or when, in a distinguished Columbia University professor's office, books lining the walls and Morningside Heights outside the window, softly we begin to hear "Far Above Cayuga's Waters." Or at one point when the search for J J Jadway takes our hero to a pornographic movie studio, just in passing we catch, tussling naked on a bed before the cameras, a guy, a girl and a gorilla.Several recent Russ Meyer films have featured an extra, semisubliminal added attraction in the form of an absolutely incredible girl wandering through who has nothing to do with the story but whom one would like to see more of. The girl in "The Seven Minutes" is Mora Gray, who plays a certain Miss Novickthe lawyer's secretaryand one would like to see more of her.

title: Picken Takes First Place In Windmill Class Regatta
description: BELLPORT, L. I., July 23 Kent Picken of the host Bellport Bay Yacht Club had a first and a second today and took the lead in the Windmill Class Inter national championship regatta. Jim Pardee, of Lakeland, Fla., is second.

title: Only One Smith in Classic, But He Plays Like Jones
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 23 Although he didn't need to, for this tournament, Bob E. Smith always insists on using his middle initial.

title: Talks Seek to Avert A Rail Strike Today Against 2 Carriers
description: WASHINGTON, July 23A strike appeared probable to night against two more major railroads tomorrow morning, as negotiators for the rail carriers and the United Transportation Union failed to break a dead lock at the bargaining table to day.

title: Washington: For the Record
AT HOME ABROAD
description: We mean business. Because over the next year, the next 10 years, the next 20 years the unity of Europe is going to be forged, and geography and history and interest and sentiment alike demand that we play our part in forging it. Harold Wilson, 1967

title: 130 TO START TODAY IN YACHTING CRUISE
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 23 A squadron of 130 craft will launch the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise tomorrow morning with a traditional sail from Newport, R. I., to Padana ram, Mass.

title: Interfaith Group Reports Gains In Soviet on Return From Trip
description: A fourman delegation of American church and syna gogue leaders, just returned from a weeklong trip to the Soviet Union, reported yester day that they look to the fu ture of religion in the Soviet Union with cautious optimism.

title: Friendship And Our U.S. Envoys
description: SALISBURY, Conn.Among the staggering problems that face the President on the day he takes office, the appointment of ambassadors might be considered among the less urgent. Embassies can run for some time on their own momentum, but eventually the President will have to sit down with his Secretary of State and divide up the embassies between career of ficers and political friends.

title: Foe Attacks a South Vienatnese Command Post
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (AP)A band of 15 enemy demolition men staged an attack early today on the headquarters in South Vietnam for the recently begun South Vietnamese sweep in eastern Cambodia.

title: TROTS CHIEF GIVES DRIVERS PEP TALK
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 23 As Roosevelt Raceway reop ened its doors tonight for the start of a 72card summer meeting, George Morton Levy, the president, foresaw drops of 5 per cent each in both at tendance and wagering during the stand, which will last through Oct. 14. Offtrack bet ting, Levy said, would be the cause of the slumps.

title: President Tubman of Liberia Is Dead
description: LONDON, July 23President William V. S. Tubman of Li beria, leader of Africa's oldest independent republic, died to day at the London Clinic. He was 75 years old.

title: And Who Is Bobby Fischer?
description: For reasons that go deep into American history and the national psyche, chess has never attained the status in the United States of baseball or football or even bridge. Compared with the multitudes to whom Babe Ruth or Red Grange or Eli Culbertson were intimately familiar names, how many Americans have ever heard of Paul Morphy or Frank J. Marshall?

title: Brandt Sees Accord By Big4 on Berlin During the Autumn
description: BONN, July 23Chancellor Willy Brandt indicated today that he expected a fourpower settlement of the Berlin prob lem during the autumn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rick Cash Breaks Leg
description: IRVINE, Calif., July 23 (UPI) Rick Cash, figured to be the Los Angeles Rams' starting defensive tackle, suffered a fractured left leg in a scrim mage with the San Diego Chargers yesterday. Dr. Jules Rasinski, the team physician, said Cash would be out for the season.

title: HAROLD BURTON, A G.O.P. LEADER
description: LongTime Politician Active in Harlem Dies at 82

title: PENTAGON STATES CASE FOR ATESTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Defense Department today argued publicly, as it has been contending privately, that nu clear testing must be continued to assure the reliability of the United States' atomic arsenal.

title: Most London Critics Are Cool To Modern Anastasia Ballet
description: LONDON, July 23With one notable exception among the London critics, Kenneth Mac Millan's new fulllength ballet Anastasia, received a gloomy reception today.

title: Market Place:   Auch Explains  Fund Insurance
description: Walter E. Auch says some misunderstandings exist about insurance against losses in mutual funds. He should know. He is president of National Securites and Re search, which offers such protection to buyers of its Fairfield Fund.

title: Better Reporting Practices Urged by Accountant
description: A leading authority on ac counting called on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to play a more militant role in promoting good corporate re porting practices.

title: Ali Takes I.R.S. to Court
description: HOUSTON, July 23 (AP)Ali asked a Federal judge to day to prevent the Internal Revenue Service from seiz ing part of Monday's gate re ceipts as tax prepayment. Ali is to receive $450,000 or 45 per cent of the live gate and television proceeds.

title: C. W. CHATTAWAY, 62, OF BREWERS GROUP
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., July 23 Charles W. Chattaway, ad ministrator of the Metropolitan Brewers Institute and executive secretary of the New York State Brewers Association, died today in Phelps Memorial Hos pital, after a long illness. He was 62 years old and lived at 49 Roundabend Road.

title: Books of The Times
description: REGULATING THE POOR. The Functions of Public Welfare. By Frances Fox Piven and Richard A. Cloward. 389 pages. Pantheon Books. $10.

title: An Epileptic Boy, 9, Eludes Searchers In Wyoming Wilds
description: CASPER, Wyo., July 23  Two professional trappers searched rugged country on 7,900foot Casper Mountain today for a 9yearold retarded and epileptic boy who has eluded the rescue attempts of 2,000 searchers, six specially trained dogs and handlers, two Air Force helicopters and a fixedwing aircraft.

title: Du Pont Plans to Buy Land In Puerto Rico for Dye Plant
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. yesterday announced plans to purchase land in Puerto Rico, with the exact location to be decided in a month.

title: The Deaf Now Hear Mao's Thought
description: PARISFew visitors to China go to Tientsin, but I was fortunate to be there three times.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Manning Signs With the Saints;
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss., July 23 (AP)  The New Orleans Saints of the National Football League signed Archie Manning, their No. 1 draft choice, to a multiyear contract today.

title: Boston Station Gets Stay
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission told television sta tion WHDH, Inc., to continue operating Channel 5 in Boston until further notice.

title: U.S. FEARS POISON IN SEE CHICKENS
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 The Department of Agriculture announced today a search in 12 states for broiler chickens and chicken feed that may be contaminated by an industrial chemical.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: SYRACUSE, July 23 (AP)Mike Slipko of Niagara Falls carded a 73 today to take threestroke lead at 215 after 54 holes of the New York State men's amateur golf champion ship at Cavalry Club.

title: STATE NEARS END OF NEWTON TRIAL
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 23 The prosecution prepared to rest its case today against Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader who is being tried a sec ond time for the fatal shooting of an Oakland policeman.

title: Young Conductors Sought For the Julius Rudel Grant
description: Applications for the Julius Rudel grant for young conduc tors are now being received, it was announced yesterday by the New York City Opera.

title: Venture in Japan Planned
description: Johnson & Johnson's Chico pee textile division has agreed to establish a joint venture with the Kuraray Company, Ltd., of Osaka, Japan, to manu facture and sell nonwoven products in Japan, it was an nounced yesterday. The new enterprise will be called the KurarayChicopee Company, Ltd.

title: Passaic Man Wins $50,000 a 2d Time
description: PASSAIC, N. J., July 23 Leo Berna, a 67yearold Pas saic resident and former res taurant owner who retired last year, now holds a winning $50,000 New Jersey lottery tick et on the drawing held yester day after having won another $50,000 last Jan. 28.

title: Yanks' Stottlemyre Beats Brewers, 62
description: MILWAUKEE, July 23 While Bo Diddley, Chuck Berry and Little Richard rocked and rolled at Milwaukee's Summer fest on the shores of Lake Michigan tonight, the Yankees beat out a rhythm of tworun singles and defeated the Brewers, 62.

title: Michigan to Give 18YearOlds Adults' Legal Rights and Duties
description: LANSING, Mich., July 23 Next January, Michigan's 18 yearolds will assume virtually all the legal rights and duties of adults.

title: Mrs. Doppelt Retains Title
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., July 23 Mrs. Mandel Doppelt of Brae Burn Country Club retained the Women's TriCounty Golf Association championship to day. Playing her home course, Mrs. Doppelt defeated Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill, 3 and 2, in a scheduled 36hole match. Mrs. Doppelt was 7 up at the turn.

title: Court on Judiciary to Receive Report on Schweitzer Investigation in September
description: The results of an investiga tion into alleged wrongdoing by State Supreme Court Jus tice Mitchell D. Schweitzer will be reported to the Court on the Judiciary by the end of Sep tember, the counsel for the court said yesterday.

title: NEW ISSUES FALL ON A BROAD FRONT Prices Decline as 6 Concerns Attract Little Interest
description: Prices on new stock issues retreated across a broad front this week in quiet trading ac tivity.

title: MidJuly Auto Sales Rose 29%, a Record for Period
description: DETROIT, July 23The automobile makers today re ported their dealers delivered 260,990 Americantype cars in midJuly, up 29 per cent from 202,966 a year before and a record for the July 1120 pe riod.

title: Eased China Trade Opens Bidding to Get Giant Pandas
description: Most of the nation's major zoos are in keen but under cover competition to obtain a giant pandapreferably youngfrom China, as a re sult of the Nixon Administra tion's recent easing of trade restrictions with the Com munist nation.

title: MISS HAGER REACHES WESTERN FINAL, 1 UP
description: CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) Nancy Hager of Dallas and Beth Barry or Dauphin Island, Ala., reached the final of the 71st annual women's Western amateur golf tournament today at Flossmoor Country Club.

title: LAIRD IS OPPOSED TO LOCKHEED BILL But Defense Chief Supports Measure That Would Aid Aircraft Maker Only
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Acknowledging a rift in Ad ministration ranks, Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird an nounced today his opposition to a loanguarantee bill in Con gress designed to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Chemical Bank announced yesterday the appointment of six vice presidents. All had been assistant vice presidents, and all, except one, are with the bank's national division. The exception is Robert A. McBride of the metropolitan division. The other vice presidents are John A. Farnsworth, William C. Pierce, Robert L. Thornton 3d, Warren T. Upson and Royall Victor 3d.

title: W. Ross Thatcher, ExPremier Of Saskatchewan, 54, Is Dead
description: OTTAWA, July 23W. Ross Thatcher, who was defeated for reelection as Premier of Sas katchewan just one month ago, died of a heart attack at his Regina home today. He was 54 years old.

title: BlackBusiness Hearing Airs Complaints
description: The focus was on com plaints in a meeting room at the Federal Building yester day, where the Federal Trade Commission and the Small Business Administration held a session for minority small business men.

title: TIMES ITEM CALLED A SECURITY BREACH
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The State Department said today that a report in The New York Times that the United States had proposed to the Soviet Un ion a moratorium on the con struction of landbased missiles and missile submarines was an unfortunate breach of security. The department did not chal lenge the accuracy of the re port, which appeared this morn ing under a Washington date line.

title: Ox Ridge Tops Myopia, 98, To Gain Final of Title Polo
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 23 Jim McCarthy scored in sud dendeath overtime today to give the Ox Ridge Hunt Club a 98 upset victory over Myo pia of Hamilton, Mass., in a semifinalround game of the National Intracircuit polo cham pionship at the Fairfield Coun ty Hunt Club. Ox Ridge will meet Fairfield for the title Sun day at Fairfield at 3 P.M.

title: A REVALUED MARK IS KEPT POSSIBLE Brandt Says a New Parity May Come After Float
description: BONN, West Germany, July 23 (AP)  Chancellor Willy Brandt kept open today the pos sibility that West Germany might revalue the mark when it ends the floating of its cur rency in the world's money markets.

title: Hijacker Killed by F.B.I. Agent at Kennedy
description: A hijacker with a gun at the back of a terrified stewardess was shot and killed on a Ken nedy Airport runway yesterday as he moved toward a Trans World Airlines jet he had or dered for a flight to Milan, Italy, his second air piracy of the day.

title: Mitchell Deciding Whether He'll Call A Kent State Jury
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The Justice Department said today that Attorney General John N. Mitchell would soon announce a decision on whether to con vene a Federal grand jury to investigate last year's shooting at Kent State University in Ohio.

title: Reading of Pentagon Papers Set for Thursday on WBAI
description: WBAI, New York's listener supported FM radio station, is planning a marathon reading of the controversial Pentagon papers, beginning Thursday at 10 A.M. and continuing until all the documents have been read. The reading will be in terrupted by the news, the war summary, musical breaks and excerpts from Tolstoy's War and Peace.

title: Elaine Summers Is Improvising In Program of Modern Dances
description: Elaine Summers, a longtime and productive choreographer at the leading edge of vanguard modern dance, is dallying with improvisation within a broad choreographic frameworkbut she produces more effective dances when she determines the entire shape of the piece.

title: Thieu Declares His Candidacy and Names a New Running Mate
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, July 24President Ngu yen Van Thieu formally de clared his intention to run for reelection this morning and announced that his running mate would be Tran Van Huong, a former Premier who is highly respected in South Vietnamese politics.

title: TALKS ON RUNNING WNJR CONTINUING City Expects Broadcasting Will Be Resumed Shortly
description: WNJR, Newark's blackor iented radio station, was still off the air yesterday, but a spokesman for the city govern ment said negotiations with the previous owners were con tinuing and resumption of broadcasting was expected shortly.

title: HUGHES GETS ORDER FOR NEW MISSILES
description: The Air Force has awarded the Hughes Aircraft Company a $69.9million contract to build a new televisionguided missile to be fired by fighter planes against tanks, artillery and other ground targets.

title: Processor Voices Regret
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) Andrew Paretti, president of Bon Vivant, expressed regret today at the new finding of underprocessing, but said he was gratified that no additional botulin had been found.

title: Some Things Every Newspaper Should Know
description: History is not woven with innocent hands, wrote Lord Acton. Among all the causes which degrade and de moralize men, power is the most con stant and most active.

title: Friedman Leads Advance In U.S. 35Division Tennis
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 23 Charles Friedman of Rego Park, Queens, James McMillen of Locust Valley, L. I., Dr. Reg inald Weir of Fair Lawn, N. J., and Morton Greenberg of Bal timore were among the win ners today as a field of 145 began play in the United States 35years division claycourt tennis championships at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

title: AdTowing Plane Crashes
description: HAVERHILL, Mass., July 23 (AP)A plane used to tow ad vertising banners crashed to day at Slavit's Airport in East Haverhill as the pilot prepared to pick up a banner.

title: Test of Paint Finds 10% Has Illegal Lead Content
description: About 10 per cent of the paint offered for sale in New York City for interior use con tains more lead than is al lowed by law, according to a high city official who warned that the paint could cause lead poisoning of children.

title: C. Maynard Nichols Dies at 62; Puzzle Expert Was Times Aide
description: C. Maynard Nichols, an editor in the Sunday depart ment of The New York Times from 1944 until his retirement in 1967, died Thursday, appar ently of a heart attack, as he was leaving Yankee Stadium, after a baseball game. He was 62 years old and lived at 21 North Van Dien Avenue, Ridge wood, N. J.

title: Thant Pays Tribute
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23  Secretary General Thant led the diplomatic com munity here today in expressing condolences to the people and Government of Liberia over the death of President Tubman.

title: A Tireless Executive
description: A portly, dapper man with a taste for Havana cigars and Scotch, William Vacanarat Shadrach Tubman was a tal ented, tireless executive who devoted his six terms as 18th President of Liberia to obliter ating his nation's internal dif ferences and to fostering its economic health. He was elected to a seventh term last May.

title: Air Pollution Code Delayed To Allow for Implementation
description: The city's comprehensive air pollutioncontrol code, which was passed by the City Council on July 13, will not be signed into law until Aug. 21, in order to give the Environmental Pro tection Administration time to set up machinery to enforce it, Mayor Lindsay announced yes terday.

title: PRICES OF GRAINS LOWER IN CHICAGO Soybean Futures Decline by 7 to 9 Cents a Bushel
description: Wheat and corn were lower, oats fractionally lower and soy beans substantially lower at the close today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Sadat Terms '71 Year of Decision for War With Israel
description: CAIRO, July 23President Anwar elSadat declared to night that he would not allow 1971 to lapse without a deci sion for war against Israel un less agreement was achieved for a withdrawal by Israeli troops from all Arab territories oc cupied in 1967.

title: Treasury Widens Leeway In Judging Dumping Cases
description: The Treasury Department said yesterday that it had abandoned its 25 per cent rule in determining whether a foreign manufacturer was dumping merchandise in this country. Dumping is selling a product abroad below the price charged in its country of origin.

title: Vice Arrests Follow Knapp Bribe Inquiry
description: Detectives arrested 12 per sons early yesterday morning in a luxurious East Side pent house that allegedly was the center of a $100anight call girl operation.

title: Mexico Says Inquiry Fails To Identify Students' Killers
description: MEXICO CITY, July 23At torney General Julio Snchez Vargas announced last night that an official investigation had failed to identify the right wing extremists who fired upon leftist student demonstrators on June 10, killing 13.

title: Uruguayan House Votes to Impeach President Pacheco
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 23 (AP)  The House of Deputies voted today to im peach President Jorge Pacheco Areco but the move failed to obtain the twothirds majority needed to immediately oust him.

title: SUDANESE REPORT EXECUTION OF 4 WHO HELPED COUP
description: CAIRO, July 23  Four of the leftist officers in the Su dan who ousted Premier Gaa far alNimeiry Monday and in turn were overthrown yester day were executed by a firing squad in Khartoum today, the official Sudanese radio report ed.

title: Japan, China and the U.S.
description: The abrupt announcement of President Nixon's planned visit to China has caused acute embarrassment to the Government of Japan, imposing unfortunate and largely unnecessary new strains on United States relations with its most Important ally in Asia.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. CONVENTION GOES TO SAN DIEGO
description: DENVER, July 23The Re publican party decided tonight to hold its 1972 Presidential convention in San Diego, deep in politically conservative Southern California and con veniently near the summer White House in San Clemente.

title: U.S. Steel Sets a Round Of Operations Cutbacks
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced yester day another round of operating cutbacks stemming from a weak demand for steel. Three of 20 operating coke batteries will be shut down and rolling mill schedules reduced at its Clairton, Pa., facilities. Steel union sources said about 230 men would be laid off.

title: Bridge: 3 New York Teams Facing Difficult Spingold Matches
description: CHICAGO, July 23Three topranked teams headed by New York experts faced tough matches in the third round of the Spingold knock out team play at the Ameri can Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here this afternoon.

title: Starr to Undergo Arm Surgery
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 23 (AP)  Surgeons will replace part of a tendon in Bart Starr's aching throwing arm, the Green Bay Packers announced today.

title: MURPHY REPORTS SOME CRIMES HERE
description: There was a 7.5 per cent in crease in the number of mur ders, rapes robberies and as saultscrimes against the per sonreported to the Police De partment last month, Commis sioner Patrick V. Murphy an nounced yesterday.

title: Shop Talk
description: Yet another collection of colorsplashed, boldly pat terned patchwork skirts has arrived in town from yet an other Appalachian cottage in dustries program. Not the least of the virtues of the 50 oneofakind fashions from the Patch Blossom Exclusive collection that are at Altman's are the moderate prices for the eye catching designs. On view in the thirdfloor Studio III shop are minis, $50; midis, $60, and maxis, $70. As with so many quilt inspired fashions and furnish ings today, these skirts up date traditional patterns by using fewer and clearer col ors and stronger patterns. On one appealing patchwrok skirt, for instance, bright pink hearts and dark green wedding rings stand out clearly against a floral print background of an even darker green.

title: Kent Suit Dismissed
description: CLEVELAND, July 23 (UPI) A Federal judge dismissed to day a $4million wrongfuldeath suit filed by the father of one of the four students killed at Kent State.

title: Washington Officials Tour Harlem in Drug Study
description: A group of highranking State Department officials and mem bers of the House Foreign Af fairs Committee walked around one of the seamiest blocks in Harlem yesterday as part of a tour to see what the end of the heroin pipeline looks like, to meet with addicts and to see them.

title: OIL SPILL FEARED IN DRILLING PLANS Ecological Agency Studies Santa Barbara Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 The Environmental Protection Agency raised the specter to day of another disastrous oil spill off Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Philbin Wed to C. R. Rohrberg
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 23 Miss Linda Marie Philbin and C. Richard Rohrberg were married here this even ing at the Curtis Arboretum by the Rev. James Donahue, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: STATE FACILITIES CALLED PHANTOM
description: HAUPPAGE, L. I., July 23 The former director of a state mental hospital that had a staff but no facilities testified today that at least three such hos pitals and five state schools exist throughout the state.

title: U.S. Marine Guard Wounded
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters)  A United States Marine guard was wounded by crossfire in Khartoum during the countercoup there yester day, the State Department re ported today. The guard, whose wounds were superficial, was stationed at the United States Embassy.

title: Steel Sales at Peak
description: The LykesYoungstown Cor poration reported yesterday secondquarter earnings of $10.3million, up 152 per cent from the yearearlier period.

title: British Embassy Under Fire
description: LONDON, July 23 (AP)A Foreign Office spokesman said that the British Embassy in Khartoum came under tank fire today but that the four persons inside were unhurt.

title: MORE PHONE MEN RETURN TO WORK 90% of Workers Still Out Are in New York State
description: The telephone strike became concentrated in New York State yesterday as large blocs of workers in New Jersey and Connecticut settled with their companies and went back on the job.

title: Nun Wins a Contempt Appeal In L.I. Theft of F.B.I. Papers
description: A Roman Catholic nun won her court battle yesterday to avoid going to jail for refusing to testify about documents stol en from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Notes on People
description: President Tito of Yugo slavia will visit the United States in October, to return the visit President Nixon made to Yugoslavia last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Lawrence Marie; Headed Dominican Sisters
description: Mother Lawrence Marie Malanphy former Mother Gen eral of the Dominican Sisters of Blauvelt, N.Y., and former president of the Dominican College of Blauvelt, died Wednesday in the Atlantic City Hospital.

title: 116 Planes Hijacked In U.S. Since 1961
description: WASHINGTON, July 23Since 1961, a total of 150 per sons have been accused of 115 hijackings of United States aircraft, and one of foreign registry, engaged in air commerce in this country, the Federal Aviation Admini stration said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Mets are back in town, but you a re advised not to rattle the dishes for a while because they came back with the world's worst headache.

title: NIXON URGED TO AID ENVIRONMENT CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The head of a leading environmen tal organization has urged Pres ident Nixon to support William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protec tion Agency, in his struggle against Administration officials who want to relax enforcement of the 1970 Clean Air Act.

title: Pravda Finds Little Big Man Exposes Crimes of Capitalism
description: MOSCOW, July 23  Arthur Penn, the American film direc tor, today received praise from Pravda, the Communist party paper, for his Little Big Man, which the paper described as having exposed the enormous crimes against mankind that have marked the path of capi talism from the beginning to our days.

title: A.E.C. IN 4 CONTRACTS FOR FUEL URANIUM
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., July 23 The Atomic Energy Commis sion has signed four new con tracts to provide $323,886,496 in uranium enrichment services to the nuclear power industry. These bring the total of all contracts to approximately $4 billion.

title: Auto Production Slips
description: DETROIT, July 23 (UPI) United States auto production declined again this week and will drop further in the coming weeks because of model changeovers, Ward's Automo tive reports said today.

title: N.B.C. Appeals for Rehearing Of Esso Ad Fairness Ruling
description: The National Broadcasting Company has petitioned the Federal Communications Com mission for a rehearing on the agency's ruling that Esso ads carried on the network pro moted one side of a controver sial issue.

title: Did Hayes Save Landry?
description: DALLAS, July 23 (AP)Bob Hayes, Dallas Cowboys wide receiver, says he paid $200 to keep an extortionist from kid naping his daughter and bomb ing the homes of Coach Tom Landry and the club president, Tex Schramm.

title: A.E.C. Ordered to Revise Its Rules on Environment
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Co lumbia ruled today that the Atomic Energy Commission's regulations regarding the en vironment have made a mock ery of the National Environ ment Protection Act, and or dered the agency to completely revise its rules.

title: Burns Says Inflation Curb Is Making Scant Progress
description: WASHINGTON, July 23The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board confessed to Congress today that there had been very little progress in checking inflation and said this lack of progress constituted a grave obstacle to a rapid recovery in production and employment.

title: GOULD TROPHY WON BY FAIR AMERICAN
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., July 23  Kendrick R. Wilson Jr.'s Troon, a Whitby45 of the host club fleet, won her third daily squadron run on the 40th an nual American Yacht Club, cruise today. But the boat she beat by more than 5 minutes of corrected time in the final race of the sixday voyage wound up as the series cham pion in the International Off shore Rule Division.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 An instant transaction sys tem is designed to transfer money from one bank ac count to another by tele phone. A depositor will be able to select a purchase in a shop, have his bank credit the necessary funds to the store and walk away with his parcel and a printed sales re ceipt. Arnold M. Wolf, pres ident of the Electrospace Corporation, Westbury, L. I., and John G. Richter, direc tor of engineering, were granted Patent 3,594,503 this week for the decoding cir cuit of what is called the Instantran.

title: Verity Archer Bride on L. I.
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., July 23 Miss Verity Ann Archer of New York was married here tonight to Dennis Wayne Powers of Centre Is land, Oyster Bay. The Rev. W. Cameron Allan performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church.

title: COMSAT RECORDS GAINS IN INCOME Revenues Also Climb During Quarter and Six Months
description: The Communications Satel lite Corporation reported yes terday gains in revenues and net income for the quarters and six months ended June 30. The report placed revenues for the June quarter at $22,229,000 up from $16,793,000 a year ear lier. Comsat's net income rose to $5,454,000, or 55 cents a share, from $3,974,000, or 40 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1970.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: McCarthy in the Race?
description: Three years ago Senator Eugene J. McCarthy ran for President primarily to educate the American people on the nature of the Vietnam wara mission he per formed with a high degree of success. By all accounts he is thinking very seriously of running again, this time, it would seem, with the more commonplace objective of becoming President of the United States.

title: HODGSON PLEDGES SPEEDY JOBS AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 23  Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson announced today that the Nixon Administration was ready to begin disbursing emer gency job funds to 700 state and local governments as soon as Congress provided the money.

title: Polarization Peril in Uruguay
description: I've had to do things to this country that no one ever should have to do, President Jorge Pacheco Areco told a visitor to Uruguay last year. He meant that he had felt compelled to impose drastic measures utterly foreign to South America's most durable democracy in an effort to recharge an economy plagued by inflation, inefficiency and strikes, and to maintain public order against the urban terrorism of the Tupamaro revolutionaries.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 24 Joe Namath completed four of five passes for 70 yards during the Jets' first intrasquad scrim mage today at Hofstra Univer sity.

title: Joan Marguerite McGrath Engaged
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., July 24Miss Joan Mar guerite McGrath, ownerdi rector of the Joan McGrath Studio of the Dance here, plans to be married on Sept. 18 to H. Gregg Greve, who is area sales managernorth east U.S.A. and Canada for InterContinental Hotels.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: SAIGON ANNOUNCES NEW CAMBODIA DRIVE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 (AP)The South Viet namese command today an nounced a second new drive inside Cambodia and said the troops had met no resistance so far.

title: ROBERT SHEEHAN, FORTUNE EDITOR
description: Robert Wade Sheehan, a member of the board of editors of Fortune magazine from 1959 to 1968, who wrote many articles on corporate business, particularly insurance and the automobile industry, died Fri day in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 63 East Ninth Street.

title: WHITBY45 CAPTURES 25MILE DAY RACE
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 24Jack Hirsch's Dyna mite, a Whiby45 from the Sheldrake Yacht Club, won overall honors today in Knick erbocker Yacht Club's 10th an nual 25mile day race on Long Island Sound.

title: Miss Schaefer Has Wedding
description: WIANNO, Mass., July 24 Miss Frances B. Schaefer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic M. Schaefer, was married here this afternoon to J. Griffin Doyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Doyle of Larchmont, N. Y. The cere monly in St. Peter's Episcopal Chapel was performed by the Rev. Clark K. Oler of Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in New York and the Rev. Mi chael G. Pierce, a Jesuit priest from Boston.

title: Steinkraus to Retire As HorseShow Rider
description: WEMBLEY, England, July 24 (AP)I'm retiring soon, Bill Steinkraus, the United States' top show jumping rider, said today. I may stay on until the Munich Olympics next August, but it's distinct ly possible I'll get out before then.

title: Executive Volunteers
description: When a small businessman needs first aid for his ailing company he can get more than an aspirin's worth of free advice from a group called the Executive Volun teer Corps, sponsored by New York City.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: How to look like a late late movie
description: Well, we're right up to our collarbones in the nineteenforties revival. Literally. The latest manifestation is the sweetheart neckline. It demands softly curled hair just hitting the shoulders for the veritable forties look. If you want to go all the way, add pearls or a heartshaped pendant, try a hat decorated with cherries, carry a nosegay of sweetheart roses, and don't forget the platform sandals with ankle straps. You'll look as if you stepped off the Silver Screenor out of the TV tube.

title: Miss Randilyn Woodruff Wed To James Gilliam Jr., a Lawyer
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 24Miss Randilyn Harriet Woodruff, daughter of Mrs. Harriet Davis Woodruff of New Rochelle and John Woodruff of Cranbury, N.J., was married here this after noon to James H. Gilliam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilliam of Wilmington, Del.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The proposal currently be ing debated before the Con gress to initiate a Recon struction Finance Corpora tion type guaranteeing agen cy threatens to open a Pan dora's Box, which it would be extremely difficult to close.

title: Hassan Entertains Agnew At Site of Attempted Coup
description: RABAT, Morocco, July 24 King Hassan II of Morocco gave an outdoor luncheon for Vice President Agnew today. The setting was the same as that of the King's birthday recep tion two weeks ago when 97 guests were killed in an at tempted coup.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: STANKY, 55, TO PLAY IN OLDTIMERS' GAME
description: Acceptances from Eddie Stanky, Whitey Kurowski and Frank McCormick have corn uleted the infield for the Right handers (betters and pitchers) in the Old Timers game sched uled for Veterans Stadium on Saturday night, Aug. 21.

title: Women Working in L.I. Hospital Are Taught Art of SelfDefense
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., July 24Women employes at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center here are being taught how to scream, gouge, kick, punch and scratch and perform other forms of karate and ju jitsu to defend themselves.

title: Sime, 35, May Bid for Olympic Spot
description: A 35yearold ophthalmologist, who was setting world records while Delano Meri wether was still in high school, has pro duced the latest miracle in track and field this year.

title: Mail:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: About Motor Sports
description: In the light of previous at tempts, it takes brave men to televise a road race live, especially when the event is as complex as a CanAm and when the audience is as de manding as sophisticated CanAm fans are. Yet it is about to happentoday. After more than three years of trying to get the Can Am on the tube, the Sports Car Club of America, which administers the $1  million CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup, has found an organiza tion ready and willing to take the risks.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: The subordination of pub lic relations to advertising in the corporate scheme of things is coming to an end.

title: EXPLOITATION
description: To The Editor:

title: Money Puts Dundee in Ellis's Corner
description: HOUSTON, July 24For what the promoters have labeled the inevitable fight, Angelo Dundee made the inevitable decision. He is Muhammad Ali's trainer, but he is Jimmy Ellis's man ager, and on Monday night in the Astrodome he will he in Ellis's corner.

title: Southampton's Older Generation: Alone but Not Lonely
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.They are very often alone and, to many observers, this indicates loneliness. Most of them are anything but lonely. Their lives have a slow but paced rhythm, and the sum mers here offer them the scent of sea air and gardens in bloom together with the faint perfume of past memories.

title: Presidency Is Declined
description: KENT, Ohio, July 24 (AP) Dr. Calvin B. T. Lee, 37 years old, executive vice president of Boston University, withdrew today as a candidate for the presidency of Kent State. He cited personal reasons. The presidency will become vacant in September.

title: Hinchberger Named Coach
description: TAMPA, Fla., July 24 (AP) Lloyd Hinchberger has been named coach of the Tampa St. Petersburg Eastern Hockey League team. Hinchberger, 40 years old, has been in hockey for 22 years and coached the defunct Nashville Dixie Flyers of the E.H.L. the last four years. His clubs won playoff berths three times.

title: Absolute Zero By Ernest Tidyman. 182 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $5.95.
description: Ernest Tidyman has such a flair for inventing quirky char acters, that it is a pity he can't think of suitably interest ing things for them to do. Con sider: Adam True Blessing, mastermind of a cryogenics combine and the offspring of midgetswho are iced away in his private office. Consider: a staff of employes recruited from the uniquely handi capped, like a battery  pow ered basket case on wheels, an 800pound former circus fat lady, et al. Blessing seems to have a crush on the lady at the municipal employment agency who helped him recruit these nonconformists, and his frozen traffic involves him in trouble with the law. All of these intriguing potentials lead eventually to absolute zero a novel in which rhetoric is offered in place of involve ment.

title: Philbin Beefs Up for a Full Jet Season
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 24  Gerry Philbin, the Jets' defensive end, polished off a lunch of tomato juice, broiled fish, potatoes, peas and carrots, Jello, apple sauce and canteloupe, at Hof stra University and ex pressed contentment.

title: WorkRule Reform
description: The conflict over railroad work rules, which has been sharpening ever since the railroads lost their monopoly on intercity freight move ments, may possibly have moved out of the realm of economic pushing, shoving and shouting into a labora tory demonstration of just how an accord could be reached.

title: Apollo 15
description: The Apollo program is so much a victim of its own enormous success that there has been relatively little excitement these past days and weeks as preparations for tomorrow's scheduled launching of Apollo 15 gathered momentum. Yet the flight that astronauts David Scott, Alfred Worden and James Irwin plan to take is one of the greatest scientific voyages of all time, a journey which is of an order of magnitude and danger comparable to that of its three historic predecessors, Apollos 11, 12 and 14.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Where drought has caused problems with annuals of if they have bloomed themselves out, cut back the plants about onethird, add a watersoluble fertilizer and water well.  Tie house plants in large plastic food bags before vacation; water well first and keep out of direct sunlight.  Drought may mean blossomend rot on tomatoes; water well, and mulch.  Continue herb drying.

title: Congressmen Demanding New Kent State Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  A quiet and thus far unsuccessful campaign is being waged by Congressmen to persuade the Justice Department to begin a Federal grand jury investigation of the shooting last year of 13 students by National Guards men at Kent State University.

title: Turks'Leader Says Closer Greek Ties Depend on Cyprus
description: ATHENS, July 24Premier Nihat Erim of Turkey told the Greeks in an interview today that there could be no real friendship and cooperation be tween Greece and Turkey until the Cyprus problem was solved. He appealed to the friends of the two neighboring nations to help them overcome this obstacle.

title: Pirates Build 4Run Lead, Then Withstand a Rally by Padres to Win, 4 to 3
description: SAN DIEGO, July 24 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pirates piled up a fourrun lead, then with stood a ninthinning rally by the San Diego Padres for a 43 victory today.

title: Author's Query
description: I am eager to hear from any one with information about American baritone, Alfred Chigi.

title: Space /Science
description: Apollo 15 probably marks the end of the supremacy of the racing car drivers in spacethe men who spring beyond our atmosphere for national prestige, for flex ing engineering muscle, for adventure or just for getting there. With this flight, scien tists have finally won parity, with, if not ascendancy over, engineers and publicists. Apollo 15, more than any of the previous manned moon missions, tunes to science.

title: SENATOR ASSAILS CLOSE BRAZIL TIES
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Senator Frank Church, Demo crat of Idaho, criticized today what he described as the too close identification of the United States with the Brazil ian Government headed by Gen. Emilio G. Mdici.

title: Sir Alan Moncrieff Dead at 69; World Authority on Pediatrics
description: LONDON, July 24 (AP)  Sir Alan Moncrieff, an inter national authority on pediatrics known in Britain as the chil dren's doctor, died today. He was 69 years old.

title: BRUISE ON CHEST IS BOYS' SOUVENIR
description: MILWAUKEE, July 24Rick Born, a 7yearold Milwaukee Brewer fan, was recuperating today after a visit to County Stadium that netted him two baseballs, a sore chest and a story that will fascinate his friends for years to come.

title: Flying, for Many, Now Just Another Trip
description: LOS ANGELES, July 21 Mona Clemons sat cross legged in her blue slacks on the hard tile floor of the Western Airlines terminal at Los Angeles International Airport the other day, casu ally playing cards with three teenage friends from sub urban Baldwin Park.

title: U.A.W. Urges End to Car Excise Tax
description: DETROIT, July 24  The United Automobile Workers gave its support this week to a proposal to eliminate the 7 per cent automobile excise tax. This is the second time recently that the union has been allied with the auto industry and with Michigan Republicans in an effort to spur the automobile business.

title: Rochester Police Seize 3 in Unrest
description: ROCHESTER, July 24Three men were arrested last night in the third straight night of rock throwing and firebombing dis turbances in this city's pre dominantly black Third Ward. The streets were calm this af ternoon, however.

title: The Dance: A Durable Lilac Garden
description: Tudor's Lilac Garden still, 35 years after its premiere, makes its same im pact. I am tempted to think that it is one of the most successful of dramatic bal lets, as well as one of the least overtly dramatic. It is a French garden at the turn of the century. The lilac is in bloom. A girl is about to be forced to marry a man she does not love and is say ing a hurried, frustrated goodbye to her real lover. Nothing more.

title: Dispute on Queens School Zones Going to State Appellate Court
description: A dispute over the zone lines of Andrew Jackson High School in Queens, which could also affect the boundaries of many other secondary schools in the borough, is headed for the state's Appellate Division.

title: Editorial Cartoon 6  No Title
Headliners
description: Back to Berkeley

title: The World
description: LONDONThe midday sun blazes particularly fiercely in Khartoum, Sudan's capital, at this season. By 2:30 P.M. the offices are emptying and people think only of a leisurely lunch and an afternoon nap. The sen tries on duty at the more im portant buildings are drowsy.

title: Addisleigh Park Life Attracts Top Blacks
description: Addisleigh Park, a 30block enclave of handsome homes sandwiched between work ingclass South Jamaica and middleclass St. Albans in Queens, has been a synonym for gracious suburban living among many black New Yorkers.

title: Police Find Teacher. 79. Murdered in Trenton Home
description: TRENTON, July 24 (AP)An elderly schoolteacher was found murdered in her home here early today by the police as they responded to an anony mous telephone call.

title: City Policeman Is Killed In Orange County Argument
description: CENTRAL VALLEY, N.Y., July 24  Patrolman Manfred Fischer, 33 years old, assigned to the police laboratory in New York City, was stabbed to death yesterday during an argument in a house in this Orange County town.

title: ROBERTI WILL HEAD COLLEGIATE GROUP
description: Gene Roberti, baseball coach at Iona College, has been elected president of the Metro politan College Baseball Con ference.

title: Stamps
description: A PRESTIGIOUS panel of a dozen philatelic ad visers has been col lected to counsel the American Revolution Bicen tennial Commission on the planning of the 1976 celebra tion of the 1778 rbellion that separated the American colonies from England.

title: Yuh JaeDo Stops Naito In 6th to Take Orient Title
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 24 (AP)Yuh JaeDo of Korea won the Orient middleweight title to night by scoring a sixthround knockout over Cassius Naito of Japan in a scheduled 12round bout.

title: PARK'S ELECTION FOE LOSES IN PARTY VOTE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 24 Kim Dae Jung, the unsucess ful candidate in last April's presidential election against the incumbent Park Chung Hee, was defeated this week in a contest for chairmanship of the Opposi tion New Democratic party.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Ralph Brozans Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Brozan of New York and Fair Harbor. Fire Island, N.Y., on July 17 in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Brozan, is the former Miss Nadine C. Ullmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Georges D. Ullmann of Great Neck, L.I. The child, whose father is a partner in the New York law firm of Brozan & Brozan, is named Alexander Michael.

title: 11 Die in Rains in Japan
description: KAGOSHIMA, Japan, July 24 (AP)Eleven persons were re ported killed and a 12th was missing today folowing heavy overnight rains in Kagoshima in southern Japan, the police said.

title: Brazil Bars Mein Kampf
description: RIO DE JANERIO, July 24  Hitler's Mein Kampf has been barred from Brazil on the ground that it incites racial prejudice. The ban followed a federal police report that there was a plan for publishing the book in Brazil.

title: Boultbee Takes 3d Race In Luders16 Competition
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 Arthur H. Boultbee won his third Luders16 Class race of the championship season with Bonito on Long Island Sound today in the Belle Haven Club's 23d regatta of the Yacht Rac ing Association season for fleets based east of Rye. Boult ee beat Albert G. Preston Jr. and his Davada by just over two minutes and by 15 lengths in the eightmile race.

title: Down the Fairway and Into the Bank
description: Skiing and squash may look more virile. Corporate budgets may be agonizingly reappraised. Yet even in a summer of economic discon tent, the love affair between American business and the socalled gentlemen's game of golf waxes increasingly ar dent.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Jane E. McCall Plans Nuptials To Mauro Politi
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 24  Mr. and Mrs. Howard Weaver McCall Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ewart McCall, to Mauro Politi, son of Col. and Mrs. Adelio Politi of Florence, Italy, where the father of the future bridegroom is with the Carabinieri.

title: Higher Order of Energy
description: MWANDISHI (Warner Brothers) is music that will take you by surprise. It sounds like jazz, but it comes across to you with the evocative, personal directness of song. Once you are oriented, it is accessible to any kind of mu sical sensibility rock, clas sical or jazz. It is the work of a group of six musicians led by 31yearold electric pianistandcomposer Herbie Hancock. It is new jazz.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The Midwest Oil Corpora tion, like many another com pany, saw its stock price sag in May, 1970. But the situation for this Denver based producer of oil and gas was somewhat different.

title: Patrolman Fatally Stabbed on Street in Brownsville; Witnesses Beat Suspect
description: A 26yearold patrolman was stabbed twice in the throat early yesteray morning as he left a grocery in the Browns ville section of Brooklyn after having purchased a package of cigarettes.

title: Coins
description: THE growing interest In numismatics among youth and the impetus given the hobby by the sincerity and energy of hun dreds of young newcomers is reflected in the program ar ranged for the 80th anniver sary convention of the Ameri can Numismatic Association. The ANA's big annual show will be held in the nation's capital Aug 1014, with the Washington Hilton as its Headquarters.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Ronald Wilford: Muscle Man Behind the Maestros
description: THE ego behind the ego of Herbert von Kara jan, Seiji Ozawa, Eu gene Ormandy, Ra fael Kubelik, Thomas Sohip pers, Andre Kostelanetz and 70 other conductors is a manager who is more widely feared, envied and disliked than any of his superstar maestros.

title: The Liberal Crisis
