description: WASHINGTONIn its bewildered state, the Democratic party has a cer tain resemblance to the unstable gov ernment of an underdeveloped coun try. As Presidential candidacies pro liferate, it is as if every Democratic politician like every Arab colonel feels he might as well fly his jet plane through the primaries and see if he is lucky enough to carry off the Presidency.

title: Bill to Ease Tariff On Rumania Gets Administration Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The Administration has given en couragement to Senate sup porters of legislation that would elevate Rumania to the special trade status among Communist countries of most favored nation.

title: Satellite Tournaments Provide Outlet for New Talent in Tennis
description: A new word has appeared in the tennis lexiconsatellite.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: It takes various attributes to make money in the stock market. Skill, luck, patience. And, of course, some cash for a starter.

title: Humphreys, 19, Takes English Title, 9 and 8
description: BURNHAM, England, July 24(AP)Warren Humphreys, a 19yearold golfer, became the youngest player to win the English Amateur cham pionship today when he de feated John Davies, 9 and 8.

title: Apollo 15 Is Ready for LiftOff Tomorrow
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 24  The countdown for Apollo 15 moved into its final and most critical hours tonight as preparations continued to run smoothly for a scheduled launching Monday of the na tion's fourth and most ambi tious moonlanding mission.

title: How Colleges Ranked On Doctorate Degrees
description: The following chart ranks 20 colleges and universities according to the number of undergraduates who went on to earn doctorates in the years 1920 through 1970, and also shows the rank of the colleges during the 196570 period:

title: Foreign Notes
description: Uncle Shad

title: Letters
description: The glibness with which Walter Goodman (The Choice for Thousands: Heroin or Methadone? June 13) dis misses the radical critique of the pharmacologically oriented theory of addiction  the basis of methadone main tenanceresults in a rather shallow analysis of America's heroin crisis and in a peculiar way distorts the truly remark able possibilities of metha done.

title: NEW YORK TEAMS LOSE IN BRIDGE
description: CHICAGO, July 24Third round play last night in the Spingold knockout team cham pionship, the premier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, led to the ouster of four topranked teams headed by New York stars.

title: Elusive Music But a Pleasant Place to Be
description: GRAHAM NASH: Songs For Beginners (Atlan tic). Graham Nash al ways came across as the most quiet and unassum ing of the Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young combine. There was and isa charming reti cence to his manner that made pleasant contrast to the more charismatic qualities of the other group members.

title: The World
description: A few days before Christmas, 1963, friction between the Greek majority and the Turkish mi nority in Cyprus broke into open violence. Peace was restored and has since been maintained with the help of a United Nations truce force.

title: RAIL STRIKE SHUTS TWO MORE LINES; 120,000 NOW IDLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 24The United Transportation Union struck the Southern Pacific Company and the Norfolk & Western Railway today, bring ing to four the number of major rail carriers it has now shut down.

title: Miss Goldsmith Bride of Doctor
description: Miss Corinne Elizabeth Goldsmith, daughter of Mrs. Berkley Hill Jr. of Ridgefield, Conn., and Clifford H. Gold smith of New York, was mar ried here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Philemon Dickinson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Meredith Moore Dickinson of Gardin er, Me.

title: A Preview of Munich
description: On Feb. 25, 1951, a heavy thunderstorm forced postpone ment of the opening ceremonies in the first Pan American Games in Buenos Aires.

title: Cruiser Has Stuff of Which Dreamboats Are Made
description: For boatmen who like to go to sea in $600,000 yachts, sleep in kingsized beds lined with handknit red, white and blue afghans and stroll on Burmateak decks, the 95 foot streamlined Dutchbuilt motor cruiser moored at the Great Kills Marina on Staten Island may be just the dream boat.

title: Six Race Horses Perish In Fire at Cahokia Downs
description: CENTERVILLE, Ill., July 24 (AP)Six race horses burned to death today when fire swept through a section of a barn at Cohokia Downs race track.

title: Miss Wofford To Be a Bride In September
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., July 24Dr. and Mrs. James J. Range have announced the engagement of Mrs. Range's daughter, Miss Florence Jen nings Wofford, to Donald Roger Brooke Liddell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Lid dell Jr. of New York and Englewod, N.J.

title: WITH RULES EASED, G.I.'S STAY AT BASE
description: CANTHO, South Vietnam, July 19The G.I.'s are not vis iting the Toots Short Bar and Scientific Massage Parlor the way they used to, and the cyclo drivers and the urchins who of fer heroin for sale on the streets of this dirty delta city cannot remember when the price has been so low.

title: Princeton to Start Building Indoor Rowing Tank in Fall
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 24 The Princeton University Athletic Department announced this week that construction of an enclosed rowing tank for the crew program would begin early in the fall.

title: The World
description: BUENOS AIRES  In a huge banquet hall here a fortnight ago, thousands of Argentines bel lowed a rhythmic chant of loy alty to Juan Domingo Peron, the exiled leader of the Peronist movement. Peron, Great Con ductor, you are first among the workers! Peron, Peron, how great you are! These were the words sung endlessly by men and women standing on top of tables, jumping up and down and, in some cases, crying.

title: Escaped Convict Tells Of Desalting Invention
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 24 (UPI)  Warren George Briggs, 34 years old, who made the first successful escape from the United States Penitentiary at Marion, Ill., in what he said was an effort to gain recognition for an invention he had conceived in prison, gave himself up to the authorities today.

title: Miss Robin Lichten Prospective Bride
description: MARGATE, N. J., July 24 Miss Robin Anne Lichten and Gilbert Wolf Palley will he married Sept. 12 in Ventnor.

title: $2 Profit From Lemonade Stand Sweetens Fresh Air Fund Kitty
description: Alix and Henry Whittery, aged 8 and 5 respectively had a lemonade sale one recent Saturday outside their home in a small town in Massachusetts. They squeezed eight lemons into a pitcher, added too much sugar and not enough water, sold every drop to friends and relatives, and made $2.

title: First Things, Last Things By Eric Hoffer. 132 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $4.95.
description: At the outset I must admit that, for me, Eric Hoffer is a hard philo sophical cargo to handle. In a time when policemen are called pigs, when everyday work and experience is being demeaned, and the laborer is depicted as the celluloid Joe, Hof fer's common earthiness and tough ness are not only desirable but needed. In short, he calls up the silent majority of most of my life's experience.

title: The World
description: RABATThe best table in Morocco is unquestionably the one set by King Hassan  for distinguished guests. But a cer tain ambiguity hovered over the luncheon that was served yester day to Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: Moscow Avows It Desires Better U.S. and China Ties
description: MOSCOW, Sunday, July 25 The Soviet Union said today that it sought better relations with Communist China and the United States but warned both powers against antiSoviet col laboration.

title: Slain Hijacker Got Psychiatric Help
description: The hijacker who was shot and killed at Kennedy Airport Friday as he attempted his sec ond air piracy of the day had a history of mental illness for which he had been treated as recently as the last few weeks, sources close to the investiga tion said yesterday.

title: Movies
description: AMUSEMENT is a cheap high; being entertained means never having to face the truth. We lie to each other in order to keep reality's terrors at arm's length. One can hope things will get better before the world gets wise. Meanwhile we con each other with harmless (we think) pretensions.

title: Shaker Village: God Is in the Details
description: HANCOCK, Mass.For many peo ple, historical restorations are rated on what might be called the Williamsburg scale, with highest marks going to the maximum nostalgia quotient. There is no question of relevance ever rearing its ugly head.

title: Heath's Yacht Set for Admiral's Cup
description: In the opening days of 1970. which turned out to be election year in Britain, Red Beath was in Australia with his crew of five on board his 34foot miniocean racer Morning Cloud. They had en tered the toughest blue wa ter classic of them all, the Sydney to Hobart race, about 680 miles in length and tak ing about five days from start to finish.

title: Miss Schmidt Wed To Robert K. Brady
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 24Miss Rosamond Evelyn Schmidt and Robert Kings bury Brady, both of New York, were married here this afternoon at the Round Hill Community Church by the Rev. Dr. Jesse Thomas, a Methodist minister. A recep tion was held at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Danforth Starr, uncle and aunt of the bride.

title: Hamilton of Miami Leads Windmill Class by Point
description: BELLPORT, L I., July 24 Pat Hamilton of Miami, who has won three of the five races sailed, led the Windmill Class international championship regatta, today, with only to morrow's race remaining.

title: WALCOTT LEADS ENSIGN CLASS RACE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 24 C. Raymond Westcott, the defending champion from the host Greenwich Cove Racing Association, won both races with Eaglet today when the Ensign Class Long Island Sound championship regatta began in light easterly breezes over Olympic courses of 5 and 9 miles. One race tomorrow com pletes the series, which drew entries from the seven L.I.S. fleets.

title: REGENTS FILE SUIT ON TEXAS U. PAPER
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 24A monthlong struggle to control the University of Texas student newspaper got into state court this week.

title: Lebanese Is Chosen Miss Universe
description: MIAMI BEACH, July 24 (UPI)  Georgina Rizk, a brownhaired, greeneyed, 19 yearold model from Beirut, Lebanon, was chosen Miss Universe of 1971 tonight at the 20th annual Miss Uni verse Beauty Pageant here.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Everybody on Wall Street loves a turnaround situation, and that's the tag some mar ket observers have put on Swift & Co., the biggest meat packer in the world.

title: Christian wheat and Christian chaff
description: Strange things appear to be hap pening to man's religiousness in our time, at least in the West. To cite but one paradox, during the decade from 1957 to 1967 the number of Americans who saw religion as los ing its influence jumped from 14 to 57 per cent; concomitantly our soci ologists of religion told us that we are in the midst of a religious revival.

title: Celtics to Play Memphis
description: MEMPHIS (AP)A preseason game here against the Boston Celtics of the National Basket ball Association has been an nounced for Oct. 6 by the Memphis Pros of the American Basketball Association.

title: The World
description: SAIGONWhen a top Ameri can pacification official heard that Gen. Duong Van Big Minh had charged his political rival, President Nguyen Van Thieu, with using the Phoenix counterinsurgency program to suppress political opposition, he laughed. If that's what Big Minh thinks, the American said derisively, he doesn't know the Phoenix program, because it isn't good enough to do that.

title: Stokes Returns to Ashland
description: ASHLAND, Ohio, July 24 (UPI)Bob Stokes, former Ash land College head basketball coach, will return to the school as athletic director.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bougainvilleans Offered Shares in a Rich Mine
description: PANGUNA, Bougainville, July 20Rot bilong balim sere, says a chapter heading in a slickly printed booklet being passed around among the black villagers of this tropical vol canic island in the Southwest Pacific between New Guinea and the British Solomons.

title: Income Tax Stirs Outcry Throughout Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, July 24  The Connecticut state income tax, which slipped through the Gen eral Assembly in the early hours of July 1, has provoked the big gest political storm in the state's history.

title: Art
description: LAST year I learned from a number of book reviews that Florentine painting, if not exactly in the dog house, had become sort of a bore to people nowadays. This was a sur prise, since I had become accustomed to thinking of Masaccio, Botticelli, and all those others as arthistorical con stants, and had never imagined the Uffizi as the House of Yawns. Now, hav ing wasted some months cultivating an uptotheminute postBerenson ennui, I discover that either the Metropolitan and the Cleveland Museum of Art are still behind the times or the pendulum has gone into its return swing. Both museums have installed Florentine shows.

title: Robyn Smith Adds Touch of Glamour to New Faces in Big A Winner's Circle
description: Robyn Smith, the only rider striking a whip for women's liberation on the New York racing scene, helped the cause yesterday of other female riders hoping to get mounts at major tracks when she brought home two winners at Aqueduct.

title: The World
Faroux of France Captures World Moth Championship
description: CANNES, France, July 24 (AP)  Jacques Faroux of France won the world moth class yacht championship to day and David Mackay of Aus tralia was second.

title: Editorial Cartoon 4  No Title
POLICE KILLED 54 IN THE CITY IN 1970
description: Fiftyfour persons were killed and 238 were injured by city policemen in 1970, according to the first Police Department study of its kind made here, on the use of police firearms.

title: Curtis Lynch Weds Jacqueline Fisher
description: Miss Jacqueline Dale Fisher and Curtis Lynch were mar ried here last night at the St. RegisSheraton by Rabbl Ed ward Klein.

title: U.S. Beaten by Rumania In 2Day Gymnastics Meet
description: BUCHAREST, July 24 (AP) Americans could do no better than finish fourth as Rumania defeated the United States in a twoday gymnastics meet, the Rumanian press agency, Ager pres, reported today.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
RECORD 21,925 SEE SAMMARTINO SCORE
description: After an absence of several months, Bruno Sammartino stepped into the wrestling ring at Madison Square Garden last night just long enough to say hello to his fans.

title: Jobless Aid Bill Introduced
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, has introduced a bill to extend the duration of unemployment benefits from 26 weeks to 52 in states that have an unem ployment rate of 7.5 per cent or higher.

title: Gowanus Canal Bridge Put Back in Operation
description: The 82yearold Carroll Street Bridge, a 45foot draw bridge on the Gowanus Canal In Brooklyn, despite plans to the contrary, has been put back in operation.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: First College Basketball Was Game Played in 1895
description: In the first basketball game between college teams, Minne sota State School of Agricul ture defeated Hamline, 93, in February of 1895.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: POSTAL CLERK HURT AS BOMB EXPLODES
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 24 (AP)A postal clerk was seri ously injured today when a bomb exploded while he was emptying a mail bag in the large Providence Post Office, the police said.

title: American kids, American poverty, American unity, American advice
description: Any historical chronicle of the war against povertyor, more pre cisely, of the skirmish against pov erty which, under the Nixon Admin istration, poverty is winninghas present and future political implica tions. And this is particularly true when, as is the case with Richard Poston's study of The Gang and the Establishment, a book records a failure.

title: Conservatives on L. I. Face County Legislature Shutout
description: The Conservative party, which scored its most spec tacular local electoral vic tory by capturing five of the 18 Suffolk County Legisla ture posts in 1969, is faced this year with virtual elim ination from the Legislature as a result of a Democratic Republican agreement to ban crossendorsements.

title: Susan Schildkraut Is Affianced
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., July 24Mrs. Nathan Nelson Schildkraut has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Susan Schild knout, to Kenneth Lee Wal lach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira D. Wallach of Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Once again I was deeply touched by the plight of a landlord when I read [July 11] the statement by Samuel J. Lefrak we've been kicked for a long tiine. How can we be doing this again, I cried. Have we no mercy? I must do something to equalize things.

title: CLAIR ROSKAM DIES; A TV PRODUCER, 44
description: Clair D. Roskam, a television producer and writer for the audiovisual department of the Universal Education Corpora tion, died of cancer Friday at his summer home in Skowhe gan, Maine. He was 44 years old and lived at 118 Riverside Drive.

title: Miss Wyckoff And A. D. Platt Wed in Suburb
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 24Miss Carolyn Hays Wy ckoff and Alexander Dana Platt were married here this afternoon in St. Thomas' Episcopal Church by the Rev. G. Clayton Melling.

title: Miss Nathan Engaged
description: Miss Eugenie Lancia Na than, daughter of Mrs. Cynthia Rice Nathan and Hans A. Nathan, both of Ar lington, Va., plan to be mar ried in the Chapel of Mag dalen College, Oxford Uni versity, England, on Aug. 26 to Robert William Barton, who is a student at Magdalen.

title: The Cassandras in America
description: The cry of calamity is contagious. Repeatedly in the public prints and in conversation, we have read and heard that fascism or neofascisnr is just around the corner for the United States. This shadow flung across the immediate future portends a police state with rigid censorship, suppres sion of all opposition, a oneparty system and complete nullification of our democratic procedures.

title: The new religion, with caution, alarm and hope
description: In dark basements and luxury highrise apartments, from Califor nia's openair communes to the dor mitories of Eastern state universities, religious fervor again sweeps across America. True, organized church at tendance lags. True, these are the more extreme forms of spiritual ex pression: astrology, pentecostalism, witchcraft, spiritualism, drug litur gies, Zen Buddhism. True, they are elitist and their special appeal is to the young, the alienated, the suscep tible, characteristics, one should note, of any new religious movement. A significant common element of al most all of these outbursts of religi ous concern is their emotionalism and, indeed, antiintellectualism. Three noted religious observers have recently examined these phenomena: John Cooper views them with cau tion, Andrew Greeley with alarm, and Chad Walsh, less observer than celebrant, responds somewhat more hopefully.

title: For Garfield's, No More Noshes
description: A cavernous room with huge abstract mosaics. Mirrored walls. Marbleized floors. Enormous round pil lars where recessed ceiling lights glinted off encrusted gold, black and red designs.

title: Drysdale and Okker Gain Final in $50,000 Louisville Tennis Tournament
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 24 (UPI)Thirdseeded Cliff Drys dale of South Africa and fourth seeded Tom Okker of the Neth erlands reached the $10,000 final match of the $50,000 First National tennis tourna ment today.

title: Peter Cohns Have a Son
description: BOSTON, July 24A son was born June 30 to Dr. and Mrs. Peter Cohn in the Rich ardson House here. Mrs. Cohn is the former Miss Joan Ellen Kirschenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Kirschen baum of Rye, N. Y.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Last month in Munich, West Germany, representa tives from 68 West German companies, two Swiss com panies and one British com pany sat down for two days to explore the opportunities and possible problems sur rounding direct investment in the United States.

title: Mrs. Sanford Has Son
description: A son was born on July 14 to Mr. and Mrs. Steven Sanford of New York in Doc tors Hospital. Mrs. Sanford is the former Miss Pamela Gail Bender of Neponsit, Queens, Her husband is chairman of the board and president of International Foodservice Sys tems, Inc. The child has been named Michael Hayden.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Manhattan Head Rejects StudentFaculty Vote to Revive Varsity Football
description: Manhattan College's intercol legiate football will remain a club activity for the present time, Brother Gregory Nugent, F.S.C., president of the River dale institution, announced yes terday.

title: RomeWomanMiscarries With Total of 15 Fetuses
description: ROME, July 24The 35 yearold wife of a Rome busi nessman miscarried with 15 fetuses Thursday, her doctor announced today. The wom an is reported to be in seri ous condition.

title: 221 BOATS BEGIN MACKINAC RACE
description: PORT HURON, Mich., July 24 (UPI)A fleet of 221 boats battled fog, haze and a wind out of the North today after starting the 235mile sail up Lake Huron to Mackinac Island.

title: Nickel Shortage Ends
description: What might a tennis rac quet, a patio chair and a kitchen sink have in com mon? If these consumer prod ucts are the stainlesssteel type, they contain nickel.

title: Cubs Beat Phillies, 21
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (UPI)Ferguson Jenkins be came the first 16game winner in the National League tonight, pitching the Chicago Cubs to a 21 victory over the Philadel phia Phillies.

title: Senate Authorizes Funds For Indochina War Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) The Senate today adopted a resolution authorizing its Foreign Relations Committee to spend $100,000 on an inves tigation of policymaking relat ing to United States involve ment in Southeast Asia.

title: Royals' Rookie Excels
description: CLEVELAND, July 24 (UPI) Jim York, a rookie, hurled onehit shutout ball in relief for eight innings and slammed a threerun homer to cap a five run fourth today as the Kansas City Royals defeated the Cleve Indians, 61.

title: Stamps
description: ARISTOCRATS of philately is the name assigned to the gems of Stamp collecting. A dozen or more of these will he on ex hibition from Nov. 26 to Dec. 1 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel, here, when the Collectors Club of New York celebrates its 75th birthday with an ex hibition, ANPHILEX '71.

title: Plans for LowIncome Housing In Forest Hills Barred by Court
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice in Queens has issued temporary restraining order barring plans to proceed on a lowincome housing project in the Forest Hills section.

title: Boyer Says Handshake Led to Tiff With Police
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 24 (UPI)Clete Boyer said he was just trying to shake a fellow's hand for standing up for his rights when he was arrested for disorderly conduct in a hotel early yes terday morning. He was re leased on bail.

title: Sewerls a Boomerang in Forest Hills
description: The residents of a usually placid corner of Forest Hills, Queens, have received a jolt ing object lesson in The tru ism that progress is a dou bleedged sword.

title: Weekend Millions on Wheels Relax at Campgrounds
description: GUERNEVILLE, Calif., July 20Smells and sounds of summer. Sun tan oil rubbing into pink skin, charcoal smoke drifting in dim light, moist woods breathing morning air. Popcorn popping, laughers laughing, people talking: Honey, get me a beer  kids, get out of the water  dear, dry the dishes. Every summer weekend mil lions of Americans leave home, looking for amuse ment. With the tremendous boom in recreational vehicles campers, trailers, motor homes  many come to a place like this, the River Bend trailer park, a fouracre patch of wellworn grass on the banks of the Russian River,. about an hour and a half north of San Francisco.

title: Van Nostrand Sails Dollfin To Triumph in Finn Class
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., July 24 David Van Nostrand in Dollfin captured Finn Class honors today in the opening race of the Wet Pants Association in vitation regatta. Another first day winner was Bill Ludlum's Nevermor in the Raven Class.

title: Art
description: PARIS has a host of littleknown museums tucked away in unfa miliar streets, and un til recently one of the least frequented was the Muse Marmottan at No. 2, Rue LouisBoilly, just off the Bou levard Suchet, a former pri vate house bequeathed in the 1930's by a rich businessman to the Academie des Beaux Arts, together with the large and highly miscellaneous col lection he had assembled dur ing the course of a lifetime Flemish and Spanish primi tives, Gothic tapestries, furni ture and bronzes of the First Empire. It did not open every day of the week; and, al though it may perhaps have favored lovers' meetings, it attracted very few tourists.

title: How Waldorf Handles Those Banquets for Hundreds With Military Precision
description: Jimmy O'Rourke grills 108 prime filet mignons at once. He flips them, 36 at a time, and when they're grilled on both sides, they go into a heater where they will continue cooking for a nice medium to rare. On this night, he's preparing more than 800.

title: Visiting City Judge Cites Injustices in South Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 Back from a South Africa visit, a New York Criminal Court judge has been giving his im pressions to a United Nations committee inquiring into South Africa's racial separation prac tices.

title: Pforzheimers Have Child
description: A daughter was born July 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pforzheimer of Port Jervis, N. Y., in Sunnyside Hospital there. The child will be named Trenholm Baylow. Mrs. Pforzheimer is the former Trenny Robb, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Robb of Milwaukee. She is the sister of Charles Robb, who married the for mer Lynda Bird Johnson, daughter of former President and Mrs. Lyndon Baines Johnson.

title: On the Schedule
description: APRACTICAL workshop on the care of house plants will begin at The Greenhouse, 254 East 51st Street, New York, tomorrow. Enrollment will be limited to six persons and classes will meet in two evening sessions from 6:30 to 8 P.M. The fee is $10. Ad vance registration is re quired. For details, tele phone: PL 95543.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Urban Studies Center, in Shift, to Stress Specific Problems
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 24 The pioneering HarvardM.I.T. Joint Center for Urban Studies, in a radical change, will give up broad, general research this fall to concentrate instead on specific urban problems.

title: Touching with gentle satire the oafishness, buffoonery and pathos of shtetl life
description: The title of this beautifully written memoir of a Jewish childhood in the tiny Polish dorps of Leoncin and Bilgoraj at the turn of the last cen tury is misleading. Jewish village life in Poland was destroyed by the Third Reich, but for Israel Joshua Singer, elder brother of Isaac Bashe vis by some eleven years and his acknowledged master, it ceased to exist the moment he became aware that his impulses and the dogmas of the tribe were in conflict. In his earli est memory he recalls crying disrup tively at the local ceremony for the coronation of Czar Nicholas II which his autocratically religious family were obliged to celebrate, as Czarist functionaries, even as they later obliged him to attend various heders and to study Hebrew with various incompetent and/or fanatic meta muds (Hebrew teachers).

title: LEGAL ABORTIONS SOUGHT IN ITALY
description: ROME, July 20A year ago the word abortion was taboo; now everyone speaks about it, pro or con, Alma Sabatini says in measuring the progress of Italy's fledgling women's liberation movement.

title: Clothes That Catch Fire
description: One day, all textiles prob ably wil be flameretardant, and there wil be a dramatic reduction in the number of fatalities from garments and home furnishings that catch fire. Such deaths total more than 4,000 a year, to say nothing of about 150,000 injuries from the same cause.

title: Army of Volunteers Provides Logistics for Westchester Classic
description: HARRISON, N.Y., July 24 (AP)A $100,000ayear president gets up at 6 A.M., rushes to the golf course and spends the next 12 hours serving as a parking lot attendant.

title: Mail:
description: To the Editor:

title: Dismissal of Challenge Upheld In Democratic Delegates' Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 24A Federal appeals court has up held a lower court ruling that dismissed a challenge by former Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia to the Democratic party's new formula for allocat ing 1972 convention delegates among the states.

title: Black Aide Criticizes Nixon on Rights
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 24  A black official in the Nixon Administration said today that the President's Southern strat egy was now denying many Negroes in the South the right to vote.

title: The World
Soviet Press, Taken In, Silent on Buckley Hoax
description: MOSCOW, July 24 (AP) The Soviet press has pub lished articles on the Na tional Review's report last week about secret Penta gon papers, but has not told its readers that the report was a hoax.

title: Miss Hembling Becomes Bride Of Clifford Hemphill, Teacher
description: RUMSON, N. J., July 24 Miss, Donna Christine Hem bling, who teaches art in the Holmdel school sytsem, was married here this afternoon to Clifford Joseph Hemphill, a teacher at the Forestdale School in Rumson. The Rev. Rollo A. Michael, pastor of the United Methodist Church of Red Bank, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: SYLVANUS D. WARD
description: Sylvanus D. Ward, a New York estate lawyer who retired in 1969, died yesterday in a nursing home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 91 years old and lived at 122 East 82d Street.

title: 6 of 15 in Auto Die As Car Overturns Near New Britain
description: BERLIN, Conn., July 24Six persons, three of them chil dren, were killed early today when an automobile carrying 15 persons went out of con trol, hit an embankment and overturned.

title: Miss Lippincott and R. A. Jones, Journalists on Coast, to Be Wed
description: RYE, N.Y., July 24Wil liam J. Lippincott, president of Lord & Taylor, and Mrs. Lippincott have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helene Mc Cord Lippincott, to Robert Alan Jones, son of Mrs. Henry Ashcraft Jones of Memphis, and the late Mr. Jones.

title: Brenda Beauty First in Sorority Stakes
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 24 A late cry of Who's that horse on the inside? provided the key clue to Brenda Beauty's victory today at Monmouth Park in the 16th running of the $112,280 Sorority Stakes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In an article July 11 it is reported that the decontrol of vacant apartments has not yet had a marked effect in stimulating plans for new residential construction in New York City. There will be marked beneficial effects from vacancy decontrol, but to look for miraculous im provements in 11 days is to court disappointment. Real estate plans simply are not developed that rapidly.

title: Gondelman In 3d Round
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 24 Pat Di Blasio of Howard Beach, Queens, and George Gondelman of Great Neck won two matches apiece to reach the third round of the United States claycourt tennis cham pionship for men 35 years and over at the Shelter Rock Ten nis Club today

title: '71 COPPER ESTIMATE FOR CHILE IS CUT 18%
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24  A Soviet technical mission has estimated Chile's copper pro duction for this year at 825,000 metric tons, about 18 per cent below the planned output. A metric tons is the equivalent of 2,204 pounds.

title: COAST TV STATION FIGHTS MEXICO TIE
description: The American Broadcasting Company's viewers in San Diego may have to tune in a Mexican station to see the probable renomination of Pres ident Nixon in their own city. Though the Mexican Govern ment may resolve the anomaly itself, this potential situation was set up Friday when the Republicans announced that their national convention next year would be held in San Diego.

title: Grand Prix Race Sponsor Withdraws 1972 Support
description: Sponsorship of a Grand Prix race for Formula One cars, scheduled for April 19, 1972, at Ontario (Calif.) Motor Speed way, has been withdrawn by the Questor Corporation, a con glomerate based in Toledo, Ohio.

title: Troopers Scatter Blacks At Georgia Demonstration
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., July 24 (UPI)A force of 100 state troopers and city policemen, armed with clubs, broke up a crowd of about 200 blacks as they were dispersing from a demonstration in front of police headquarters tonight.

title: Jeanne Evert Wins Title
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 24 (APJeanne Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won the na tional tennis title for girls 14 years and younger today by defeating Carrie Fleming of Fort Lauderdale, 75, 61.

title: Amchitka Island Awaits a New Atomic Test
description: AMCHITKA ISLAND, Alaska, July 24One day soon, an Air Force jet cargo plane will swoop down through the fog onto the air strip here and, amid great security precautions, unload its controversial cargo.

title: Manila Reviews Links to U.S. In Light of New China Policy
description: MANILA, July 24  The an nouncement of President Nix on's forthcoming visit to Peking has raised doubts among Philip pine leaders about continued American support, and they have called for a complete re view of Philippine relations with the United States.

title: Running Tide N.Y.Y.C Victor on Corrected Time
News Executive Donates $3Million to U. of Miami
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., July 24 (UPI)James L. Knight, the newspaper executive, has do nated $3million to construct a building that will house the University of Miami's program for continuing education.

description: To the Financial Editor:

title: English Cocker Spaniel Is Named Best of 1,139 Dogs at Putnam Club's Show
description: CARMEL, N. Y., July 24 Four years ago Pamela Hall of Oceanside, L. I., was competing in junior handling and striving to earn a place in the ?? at Madison Square Garden. Today the junior handling paid off.

title: A State Inquiry on the Judiciary Urged
description: State Senator John H. Hughes, chairman of the Senate Com mittee on the Judiciary, urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to appoint a commission to investigate claims of judicial incompetence, special influence and corruption in the state's court system.

title: Betlige's Privation Is Ahead For Green Star Class Title
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., July 24 Peter Bethge of the Southern Long Island Sound fleet took the lead in the annual Green Star Class championships today.

title: PRESIDENT URGES PROMPT PASSAGE OF LOCKHEED AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  President Nixon, apparently seeking to dispel any impres sion of a division within his Administration, urged Congress today to pass promptly legis lation guaranteeing loans to failing major businesses includ ing the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration.

title: City to Speed Disposal of Bail Warrants in Fall
description: A new program to dispose of the tens of thousands of out standing bail warrants in the city will be started this fall by the New York City Criminal Court.

title: Everyone was going to be a Writer, a Great Writer
description: I can take anyone off the street and turn him into a writera burn, the biggest drunk in town, anyone, Lowney Handy said.

title: Red Sox Triumph Over Twins, 63, On 3Run Outbursts in Eighth and Ninth
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 24 (AP)George Scott, who started a threerun, eighthin ning rally with a double, drove in the tiebreaking run on a single in the ninth today as the Boston Red Sox beat the Min nesota Twins, 63.

title: 5 More Strikes Threatened
description: CLEVELAND, July 24 (AP) Charles Luna, the union presi dent, announced that five more railroads had been notified they would be struck Aug. 6 if the contract dispute is not settled. The five are the Chi cago, Rock Island & Pacific; the MissouriKansasTexas; the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific and the Baltimore & Ohio and Chesapeake & Ohio.

title: Homer Jones Announces Retirement From Football
description: ST. LOUIS, July 24 (UPI) Homer Jones was the property of the St. Louis Cardinals for only two weeks before he in formed the management he planned to retire from football.

title: Huwiler Quits as Ski Coach
description: SEATTLE, July 24 (UPI) Peter Huwiler has resigned as University of Washington ski coach to devote his attention to business interests. The school, in turn, indicated that the sport might be dropped.

title: Medicine
description: In the tradition of giant, impersonal bureaucracies, the system of Veterans Ad ministration hospitals  the largest in the nation  has tended to rely on rigid rules and oldfashioned ways. But times are changing.

title: Son to the MacFarquhars
description: A son was born July 9 in London to Mr. and Mrs. Roderick MacFarquhar of London, where the child's father is a journalist. Mrs. MacFarquhar is the former Miss Emily Jane Cohen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul W. Cohen of the Bronx. The child, who has been named Rory, is the grandson also of Sir Alexander and Lady MacFarquhar of Kings tononThames, England. Sir Alexander is a former Under Secretary with the United Nations in New York.

title: Bruce L. Paisner, Time Aide, Fiance of Miss Nicole Pilotaz
description: Miss Nicole Pilotaz, a li brarian with the New York Public Library, and Bruce L. Paisner, general manager of TimeLife Video, the pre recorded television division of Time Inc., will be married Sept. 12 in New York.

title: U.S. Bred Mill Reef Scores by 6 Lengths in $130,659 King George at Ascot
description: ASCOT, England, July 24 (UPI)Pau Mellon's Mill Reef moved away from the pack with two furlongs to go today to score the first victory by an Americanbred horse in the $137,659 King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes.

title: STUDENTS IN INDIA PAY CHEATING FEE
description: CALCUTTA, India, July 24 In an examination ball at Cal cutta University one day last month, a proctor stopped in front of a student who was copying answers from a book.

title: There's the And There's
description: IT began at the Athens airport. There were two lines: one for Greek nationals, the other for tourists. I recalled the pure ani mal despair of foreigners arriving at Kennedy in New York, facing acres of bureaucratic entrapment and blockade. Here Americans walked through like ambassadors, as my wife and I did, a chalk mark on our un opened suitcases. It was the Greeks who were herded into line.

title: What are the oppressed without the oppressors?
description: Experience by now has shown that building an independent nation is almost as difficult as initially winning independence. The paradox is only apparent. Before liberation, the oppressed assert themselves against the oppressor. They strain against the solid pillars of the colonial structure, which simultaneously supports and crushes, to a point where the colonized are de fined as much in relation to the imperial power as in their own right. By depending entirely upon the colonizer, they thus become his shadow and consciously or not, this is intended. Take, for example, the concept of Negritude, which un til now has been more negative than positive and deals above all with relationships to whites.

title: Rival Unions and G.M. Sign Pact to Resolve Disputes
description: DETROIT, July 24 (UPI) The United Auto Workers, a rival union and the General Motors Corporation, have an nounced the signing of a three party agreement for resolving union jurisdictional disputes in volving plastic tooling work.

title: Apollo Crew's Emblem Was Designed by Pucci
description: When the Apollo 15 astro nauts are launched tomorrow, they will be wearing a red, white and blue Apollo 15 emblem designed by the couturier Emilio Pucci.

title: Process Shot to Be Retired
description: This is the last year of racing for Process Shot. She will be retired at the end of the season, but her breeding plans are not complete, according to J. Bowes Bond, who trains the filly for David A. (Sonny) Werblin.

title: 3 on Princeton Swim Team Make Coaches' AllAmerica
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 24 (AP)Three Princeton students were named today to the Na tional Collegiate Coaches' all American swimming team for 197071.

title: Well Mannered Triumphs
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) Well Mannered, owned and bred by Millard Waldheim of St. Louis, galloped to a 4length victory today in the $56,000 Washington Park Handicap at Arlington Park.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., Britain Quietly Back Military BuildUp of Iran
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Iran's military power on land, in the air and on the sea is be ing built up in the Middle East under a billiondollar defense program quietly underwritten by the United States and Britain in preparation for the British withdrawal from the Persian Gulf later this year.

title: Gambino: Quiet Man in Spotlight
description: Since he came to the United States as a stowaway 50 years ago, Carlo Gambino has repor tedly had an unusually success ful career in the underworld.

title: Patents Adding To Earnings
description: WASHINGTON  American corporations, which own more than half a million live United States patents and an uncounted number issued by foreign governments, often find it profitable to license others to use at least part of their patented technology.

title: BALTIMORE FINDS CRIME DATA FALSE
description: BALTIMORE, July 24An in vestigation by the police depart ment here appears to confirm charges that reports of serious crimes have been downgrad ed, creating a false reduction in the city's major crime rate.

title: Getting Hustled by the Big Hustle
description: IT was with a certain amount of surprise that I read an ad in The New York Times last week for Ingmar Bergman's new film, The Touch, which included an endorsement that went as follows:

title: the traveler's world
description: TORONTO  This city has been enjoying a continuing building boom, so that over the past few years there has been an abun dance of good clean landfill excavated in preparing skyscraper foundations. Be ing an industrious, frugal people, the Canadians did not let this fill go to waste but dumped it neatly into Lake Ontario across the highway from the Canadian National Exposition grounds. They sank three old freighters into a semicircular breakwater to protect the fill from the waves and proceeded to build five small islands. And a few weeks ago the Province of Ontario, of which Toronto is the capital, opened there just offshore something they proudly call Ontario Place.

title: Fairway No Freeway, Ken Harrelson Warned
description: BRETTON WOODS, N. H., July 24 (AP)Dave Marr, the professional golfer, says he will be surprised if Ken Har relson is successful to any great degree in his switch from baseball to golf.

title: AllSTAR GAMES NO HIT IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, July 24 (UPI)Ex cept for the record nine con secutive strikeouts by the Han shin Tigers' southpaw, Yutuka Enatsu, in the first three in nings of the first game, the three Japanese allstar games this year were unsatisfactory to the fans.

title: Was the reform betrayed by the reformers?; The Decline and Fall Of Radical Catholicism By James Hitchcock. 228 pp. New York: Herder and Herder. $6.50.
description: The Catholic euphoria of the early sixties is now dissipated. Pope John and Vatican  were supposed to usher in a bright new age in Rome, just as President John and Camelot signaled a golden time for Washing ton. Both visions have faded; but some who once held them are still dazzled. They think the achievement of the Princes was all undone by Demon SuccessorsPaul  in Rome, L.B.J. in Washington. This angel devil sequence is actually a devil angeldevil sequence: before the two Johns took over, liberals held that the basic system was sound, it would work, if only the right men could be brought forward to replace Dopey Dwight and Patrician Plus.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: G. B. Currier, Bates Graduate, Marries Susan C. Villanueva
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 24  Miss Susan Car penter Villanueva, a 1971 graduate of Wheaton College in Norton, was married here this morning to Gregory Ban ister Currier, a Bates College graduate, who received an M.A. degree in physics last month from Williams College. The ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church was per formed by the Rev. Douglas G. Burgoyne.

title: Husband of Jersey Woman Is Held in Her Murder
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 24 Colin C. Capir, the estranged husband of a 37yearold wom an whose body was found in the East River in New York City on June 11, was arrested tonight and charged with his wife's murder.

title: Malaysian Would Visit China
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, July 24 (Reuters)Prime Min ister Abdul Razak has told par liament that he would consider visiting China if Peking invited him. Malaysia has proposed that Southeast Asia become a neutral zone guaranteed by China, the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Ouster Over Smoking Upheld
description: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., July 24 (UPI)The Montgom ery County Circuit Court has upheld the dismissal of a high school teacher who allowed students to smoke in school. Judge Howard A. Sommer said the Western Community School Board exercised its Adminis trative rights in dismissing Terrance Doran, a teacher of English at Wells High School.

title: Oral Roberts U. in N.C.A.A.
description: TULSA, Okla., July 24 (AP) Oral Roberts University has been elected to membership in the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONI wish, said Arthur F. Burns in his somewhat highpitched voice last week to the Congressional Joint Econom ic Committee, that I could re port that we are making sub stantial progress in dampening the inflationary spiral. I cannot do so.

title: CARL V. BERTSCHE
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 24 Carl V. Betsche, founder and retired managing partner of the Lawyers and Merchants Trans lation Bureau of New York City, died today in St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston. He was 90 years old and lived at 530 Valley Road.

title: U.S. Policy on Vaccinations Eased
description: MOST TRAVELERS going abroad this summer have one less thing to worry about: smallpox vaccinations. Officially, returning United States citizens still must have a smallpox vaccination no more than three years old, but because of a new policy of the Public Health Service you can ignore the requirement, for no one is going to check your yellow certif icate unless you have been to one of the following places: Afghanistan, India, Indonesia, Nepal, West Pakistan or certain African countries. The list varies as smallpox eradication progresses. Recently the only African countries reporting smallpox cases were the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ethiopia, Kenya, the Sudan and Uganda.

title: An Andrew Wyeth kind
description: House hunters keep driving up to this farmhouse in northern Con necticut and asking if it's for sale. The reason is always the same: the austere Andrew Wyeth qual ity that so charmed architect Tim Prentice and his family when they bought it six years ago that they decided never to change the exterior. The gray, weathered clapboards are never painted, simply given a thin whitewash to retain the ghosttown atmosphere of the little fourstructure complex (shown at left). Inside, though, the Prentices' six years of remodeling is delightfully apparent. A war ren of six tiny rooms in the orig inal house, c. 1790, was turned into one enormous room with ex posed beams and rafters. The old kitchen fireplace was framed with a bright red partition (shown at right) that screens an overhead sleeping balcony. Where Prentice added new architectural elements, such as staircases or partitions, he outlined them in vibrant pri mary colors. It's a symbol of respect to the first builders, he explains. The color is a way of stating: I added this and ab solves them from blame.

title: Briton Abroad
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J. The new lightweight Syl vania razors use Wilkinson singleedge bladesand that's a handsacrossthesea story in reverse.

title: Helsinki and Moscow Back on Good Terms After Trouble Caused by Split Among Finnish Communists
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 17 Finland appears to be sail ing on calm waters again in her relations with her power ful neighbor, the Soviet Union, after half a year of difficulty.

title: No More Crying the Blue Leaves Blues
description: EARLY in the spring of 1966, John Guare wrote the first act of a wild comedy, The House of Blue Leaves, to be performed at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Play wrights' Conference in Waterford, Conn., that summer. The actors in that staged reading were Peggy Pope, Kay Michaels and the author. I wasn't there, but at the end, so the legend goes, the audience shouted Author! Author! and when John stepped out to bow, he heard No! No! We want the author! But I am the author! said John.

title: Music
description: THINGS were happening at the Met ropolitan Opera while I was in Europe. Goeran Gentele, the PrinceRegent of the Met, an nounced that his musical adviser would be Rafael Kubelik, a move that seemed to be greeted with approbation on all sides. Kubelik, in this city, is far better known as a symphonic, rather than operatic, conductor, but in Europe he has been associated with many opera houses. Like all European conductors of standing, he has been weaned on opera, making the progression from provincial to major companies as his career ad vanced. He is a musician of standing, and will have a good deal to say about repertory and casting.

title: Mischief Becomes Her, Too
description: STRATFORD, CONN.

title: Dixie Barely Tops Intime in Shields Class Race
Miss Mary Fitzsimmons Will Be Bride
description: Miss Mary Louise Anne Fitzsimmons, a director of corporate fund raising for the United Fund of Greater New York, plans to be mar ried on Aug. 7 to David William Morgan, who is with the advertising department at Seventeen Magazine.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon Admin istration is faced with a cruel economic dilemma, caught as it is between the devil of, unemployment and the deep blue sea of inflation. But the President's decision to hold fast to his present line of actionor inaction, as the Demo crats would have itdoes not seem to satisfy even his own. Administration; it gives his opponents an easy political target; and for one important segment of the population, the blacks, it prob ably looks like one more decision taken in disregard or ignorance of their interests.

title: Books: On Investing
description: IF THEY'RE SO SMART, HOW COME YOU'RE NOT RICH? By John L. Springer. Henry Regnery Company. 235 pages. $5.95.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: AUGUSTO DE CASTRO, EDITOR IN PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, July 24Augusto de Castro, a prominent Portuguese journalist, author and diplomat, died today at the age of 88 apparently of heart attack. A nurse found him this morning where he had fallen beside his bed in the Hotel Palacio at the resort of Estoril, where he usually spent his summer holi days.

title: CRENSHAW CAPTURES SOUTHERN AMATEUR
description: PINEHURST, N.C., July 24 (AP)Ben Crenshaw, the Na tional Collegiate champion from the University of Texas, shot a par 72 today and won the Southern Amateur golf tourna ment with a 281 total by four strokes.

title: Juliana to Visit Indonesia
description: THE HAGUE, July 24 (AP) Queen Juliana and Prince Bern hard will pay a state visit to Indonesia from Aug. 26 to Sept. 5. the Foreign Ministry has announced.

title: Tigers Reactivate Brown
description: DETROIT, July 24 (AP) Gates Brown, a pinchhitting specialist, was resored to active duty by the Detroit Tigers to day after being on the disabled hamstring muscle.

title: Art Notes
description: PIER 18, a rinkydink Hudson River structure recently ravaged fur ther by fire, is hardly what you'd call a prime art showcase. But last winter it served as the setting for one of the season's liveliest art occasionsa twomonth af fair for which each of 27 con ceptoriented artists created a piece related to the pier.

title: Emperor George?
description: DO you recall Claudius, the disease ridden ruler of first  century Rome? Well, if you don't, George C. Scott will help refresh your memory. He has agreed to play that aqueduct  building, Briton  battling em peror in a movie to be directed by Tony Richardson for the production team of Hal Landers and Bobby Roberts. The screenplay, based on Robert Graves' 1934 novel, I, Claudius, has been written by British playwright John Mor timer. And, according to producer Lan ders, the role of the villainous Caligula, whose assassination brought Claudius to the throne, will be played by the red hot Jack Nicholson.

title: Photography
description: A COMPACT new camera and matching film in troduced recently by the Polaroid Corpora tion enables users to take pictureinaminute color pho tos for about 25 per cent less than the former cost of such pictures. Called the Square Shooter, the new camera takes a smaller, square pic ture that measures 3 by 3 inches, as compared to the conventional 3 by 4 inches of current color film packs for other Polaroid cam eras. To fit the the camera, there is also a new Type 88 Colorpack film  identical to the other color packs, except in size and price ($3.99 in stead of $5.49).

title: SKIING AT SAPPORO GETS GREEN LIGHT
description: PARIS, June 24It happened quietly, with little fanfare, where it was least expected, but at last it seems the longest running feud since Hatfield McCoy has ended and skiers will be coming round the mountains in future Olympics.

title: Law
description: In the 1600's in England, villagers were allowed to send to the next hamlet any new arrival who looked as though he might become a public ward. In New York, in the 1970's, if Governor Rockefeller has his way, it would be slightly more sub tle: The indigent new arrival would first have to say he needed public help; and then he'd have a choice either go somewhere else on bus money provided by the state, or stay and fend for himself.

title: Sailors Unhappy About Shedding BellBottoms; Officers Want to Keep Their Uniforms Distinctive
description: SAN DIEGO, July 24Sea man 2d class Carl Hoffmann from Lima, Ohio, tossed off his beer and slid a half dollar across the sticky bar of the Davey Jones Tavern on Market Street.

title: Photography
description: WHO is that elegant but unfashionable artist so handsomely installed in a series of galleries overlooking the garden of the Museum of Modern Art? Is it the Ameri can Impressionist painter Thomas Dewing parading his dreamy ladies in gauzy gowns across the Modern's relent lessly uptodate walls? Is it a pupil of the BeauxArts sculptor Lorado Taft filling gardens and fountains with nymphs and laughing fauns? Is it the popular illustrator of the 90's, Edward Austin Abbey, trailing his gorgeous ly costumed actresses through all the tenderer moments of Shakespeare's plays?

title: Griffith: Just One More Time
description: According to George Kan ter, his interpreter, Nessim (Max) Cohen, the French middleweight champion, has but one goal in life and that's to fight for the world title.

title: Marilyn Hughes, 1964 Debutante, Will Be a Bride
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 24Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Hughes, to Harold Lear Leddy the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Hughes, to Harold Lear Leddy Jr. Mr. Hughes, the Mayor of Bronxville, is a vice president and general counsel of Caltex Petroleum Corporation, New York.

title: The U.N., China, and the U.S.
description: President Nixon's decision on the admission of Com munist China to the United Nations, although still with held, is predictable after the Kissinger visit to Peking and the President's projected voyage there. The United States undoubtedly will support Peking's admission. The troublesome question is what to do about Taiwan.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Anyone who prizes political sanity in this country, might do well to pray for nothing less than a landslide victoryfor either partyin the 1972 elections.

title: EARLY A'S ATTACK BEATS TIGERS, 72
description: DETROIT, July 24 (AP)The Oakland A's jumped on Les Cain for five runs on three hits in the first two innings, three on a homer by Sal Bando, and crushed the Detroit Tigers today, 72.

title: QUARRY DEFEATS DOYLE ON POINTS
description: LAKE GENEVA, Wis., July 24 (UPI)Jerry Quarry, punch ing like a windmill, avenged one of four draws on his record tonight with a unanimous 10 round decision over Tony Doyle.

title: FRANKT. ACE,$3.40, WINS TAR BOY PACE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 Leaving nothing to the imagina tion, Frank T. Ace covered a mile in 1 minute 59 seconds and captured the $15,000 Tar Boy Pace before 29,481 at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: Mrs. Lawrence, J. S. Tennant 3d Will Be Married
description: SUMMIT, N. J,, July 24 Mrs. Kathryn Foster Lawrence and John Selden Tennant 3d have become engaged and plan to be married here Sept. 11.

description: WINSTONSALEM, July 24 (UPI)  Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia won a berth in the final of the $25,000 Tanglewood international tennis tournament today by defeating Mike Belkin of Canada, 63, 76.

description: WARSAW, July 24An art ist in the Old Town offered a tourist one of his sketches for 300 zlotys and added quickly: Or $5.

The World
description: LONDONThe House of Commons began last week what Prime Minister Heath called its historic debate on British mem bership in the European Eco nomic Community. But when the House assembled, the inter est lay less in the European is sue itself than in the split it had provoked in the Labor par ty. So undisguised was the di vision that there was an almost ludicrous air to the proceed ings.

title: Bormann Son Plans to Wed
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 24 (UPI)The Rev. Martin Bormann, a 41yearold Roman Catholic priest and son of Hitler's deputy, has asked to leave the ministry to marry a nun, church officials said today.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mr. Roth proposes a fast acting products of combus tion fire detection system as the primary solution to the high rise building fire problem. This theory of fire control is right out of the advertising literature of the manufacturers of product of combustion detectors. According to the theory, the detector will detect fire dur ing the first two stages of fire, which may represent 80 per cent of the total fire time.

title: McCabe & Mrs. Miller: A SneakyGreat Movie
description: NOT least important of the people who have lately been missing the point of Robert Altman's sneakygreat new movie, McCabe & Mrs. Miller, is the projectionist at Loew's Cin East. Or who ever it Is who works the lights there. On two recent occasions when I was in the audience, this gentleman brought up the houselights a full minute or more before the film was over. Which caused among the patrons a kind of sedate pandemonium  standing and stretching, hesitating, moving toward the aisles, finally jostling to a dead stop and craning for a look at the stubbornly luminous screenthat was a little bit amusing the first time, less so the second.

title: SKI RANKINGS HEADED BY COCHRAN SISTERS
description: BERN, Switzerland, July 24 (AP)The Cochran sisters of Richmond, Vt., hold top spots and Tyler Palmer of Kearsarge, N. H., moved into sixth place in the men's special slalom, ac cording to the new Internation al Ski Federation rankings.

title: Miss Betty Harris Is Lawyer's Bride
description: Miss Betty Bernice Harris was married here yesterday afternoon to Frank Louis Langhammer 3d. The Rev. S. Hughes Garvin performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Ralph R. Warren, assisted.

title: How Britain Quit Rescues
description: LONDON  Not so many weeks ago, John Davies, the British Government's first ministerial overlord for in dustry, found an official re port in his in tray that must have caused a wry smile. A group of leading industrialists had made pub lic its belief that companies should have continuing ac cess to the Exchequer when the financial services of the City of London appeared in adequate.

title: Space Mission Objectives Are Most Ambitious Yet
description: As though to make up for the moon landings that have been canceled, planners of to morrow's Apollo 15 mission have crammed an extraordi nary amount or exploration and scientific observation into its program.

title: 15 ARE ARRESTED IN WEAPON RAIDS
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (UPI)  Treasury agents seized at least 1,300 weapons and arrested 15 persons today in a series of raids in Illinois and Wisconsin that were called the biggest action to date against persons charged with illicit gun deal ing.

title: Whittingham: West's Horseman of '71
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24While Western racing fans are still arguing who is the better horseAck Ack or Cougar there's little doubt about the West's most impor tant horseman this year. He's controversial Charlie Whit tingham, who trains them both.

title: For Young Readers
description: Once the unlamented Civil War centennial was over, the makers of books almost overlooked the centen nial of Reconstruction. Junior Ameri cans, who must live through their elders' self  congratulatory celebra tions of such milestones, can surely learn more lessons from Reconstruc tion than from the world's first mod em war.

title: Okla. State Signs Pacts
description: STILLWATER, Okla., July 24 (UPI)  The signing of North Texas State and Wichita State to fouryear pacts has com pleted an 11game football schedule for Oklahoma State University through 1945, the coach and athletic director, Floyd Gass, announced today.

title: All the virtues, including
description: Owing to some limitations of my own which will become clear, in a moment, I am unable to do more with a large part of this book than describe it, which I had better do forthwith: It contains an Introduc tion by the author; 39 poems in Rus sian with his own translations, some of them annotated; 14 poems written in English; 18 chess problems; solu tions to these; and a bibliography of the poems.

title: He Puts Fire to It
description: IAM a chauvinist when it comes to music; Black is best. Having spent most of the Saturday after noons of my childhood listen ing to Milton Cross bleat along with opera on his radio show, and because as a yoang violinist I had Euro pean musical expressions stuffed into my brain like so much cultural spinach, and finally, because listening to rock is like listening to mobs of robbers trying to pass off the sound of Black music and speech as their own, because of all this history I am con vinced that the very least of Charlie Parker's extended choruses, the briefest phrase by Billie Holiday, or a mis take by Herbie Nichols will do more for the lost humanity of this country than all the Wagner, Brahms or Grand Funk Railroads born or yet to come.

title: TELEPHONE STRIKE BY 50,000 GOES ON
description: There was no change yes terday in the telephone strike, which has kept 50,000 workers in several branches of the Bell System away from their jobs for 10 days.

title: Interlude
description: Late July brings an air of serenity to the countryside. The rush of spring has largely spent itself. Now there is the measured reach toward maturity, the leaf fully green, the new stem complete, the early blossom a ripening pod. The rush for a place in the sun is over. Grapes, both wild and tame, fatten on the vine. Early apples show a faint blush. Meadows mowed a month ago for the year's first hay are lush and green again, promising a second cutting in early August. Wild black berries ripen. Day lilies are in blossom, hotcountry orange, and chickory has opened its babyeye blue blossoms at the sandy roadside.

title: Braxton Signs With Bills
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 24 (AP)Jim Braxton, a 22 yearold running back from West Virginia University, signed a contract with the Buffalo Bills today. The Bills have only one rookie unsigned. Jan White, a tight end from Ohio State.

title: Can Merger Fuel a Second Korvette TakeOff?
description: If one merger didn't quite work, will another?

title: EDWARD F. WHITE
description: CINCINNATI, July 24Prof. Edward F. White of the Univer sity of Cincinnati department of mathematics, died here yester day at the age of 60.

title: L. L. TOWN PLANS ECOLOGY ZONING
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 24 This spirited Suffolk County town, which keeps a record of its firsts, plans to start de veloping the first municipal ecologically based zoning pro gram this fall, whether or not it can get the Federal funds it is seeking to implement it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Richard Roth, who wrote a point of view article on how highrise buildings should be fireprotected [July 4] deserves crredit for recognizing the problem and taking an interest in trying to solve it. But he does not show a basic understanding of the subject of fire science.

description: CHICAGOJohn J. Nevin, rising young star at the Ford Motor Company until two months ago, when he was suddenly snatched away and made president of the Ze nith Radio Corporation, says he's too old to be student radical and too young to be a philosopher.

description: The Brooklyn section of the city's third annual Phy sical Fitness Pentathlon for youngsters between 6 and 18 years old will be opened to morrow at Kaiser Park, Nep tune Avenue and West 28th Street.

title: The Nation
description: MILWAUKEEFor 200 years. the counties have been the dark continent of American politics, said William J. Conner, County Executive of New Castle, Del. But all that is changing. We're a force to be reckoned with. The cities and the states will have to sit up and take notice.

description: ROMETwo external events are ex pected by the highest level of this Government to play a significant part in improving Italy's internal situation and strengthening both democratic confidence and economic stability.

description: WILTON, N. H., July 24 Miss Jane Isabelle Bonynge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Bonynge Jr. of West Wilton, was married here this afternoon to Mark Philip Wisan, son of Mrs. Jesse H. Wisan of New York and the late Mr. Wisan. The Rev Charles O. Richardson Jr. performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church.

title: African Nation to Add Troops
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, July 24 (Agence FrancePresse)The Cabinet of the Central African Republic under President Jean Bedel Bo kassa, has decided to double the size of the country's armed forces by next year. The armed forces number about 3,000 men at present.

title: Impact of Sickle Cell Anemia Fight Grows
description: Some years ago. Mrs. Dina Jacobs, a Brooklyn house wife, spent several weeks visiting physicians before she found a doctor who cor rectly diagnosed the cause of her yearold son's recurrent colds and severe joint pains.

title: Sports of The Times
description: In clipped British accents, the broad caster from London offers spot news over the Norwegian radio every morning in an Englishlanguage roundup. A few weeks ago, this vacationing sportsviewer heard the news in Norway that the United States Supreme Court had unanimously reversed the draft conviction of Cassius Clay. The British, you see, are a trifle slow to accept the Muhammad Ali label and prefer the more readily recognizable Cassius Clay. It really doesn't matter. The news was much more important than the name.

title: Reader's Report
description: This English working  class family history is most note worthy to me for its appreci ation of beer. Beer as it is found in its ideal habitat, wooden kegs tapped and pumpedfrom a deeply redolent cellar. (When you breathed in deeply, the taste of beer swept into your lungs, and when you came upstairs you could feel it settle on your face.) The cellar is beneath a provincial pub called The Throstle's Nestthe fulfillment of Jo seph Talentire's dreams of be ing his own man. Having been a footman, cobbler, mill hand, R.A.F. airman and insurance salesman, Talentire sees his main chance in a franchise as publican for a local brewery. Melvyn Bragg describes the technique of drawing, pouring, tapping, sluicing and the mi nutiae of saloonkeeping with the kind of occupational gusto Melville devoted to the dispo sition of blubber.

title: Gardens
description: SEDUMS are succulent plants that grow around the world mostly in temperate and colder regions. Sometimes they are called live forevers. Small but numerous pointedpet aled flowers are prevailingly yellow, white or some shade of red.

title: MAILORDER ABUSE SCORED AT PARLEY
description: A persistent consumer com plaintthat some prepaid mer chandise is delayed overlong by some mailorder companies or even fails to arrivewas the subject of a oneday conference hero last week attended by more than 300 businessmen and government officials.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: BENNY SEAMON
description: Benny Seamon, whose brother Mannie was the trainer for Joe Louis, died Friday of cancer in Miami Beach. He was 78 years old.

title: The Last Word: Writers as ShowBiz
description: On an ordinary evening a couple of weeks ago television viewers were fortuitously treated to a pride of literary lions the major evening talk shows. David Frost led off, facing a new battery: Margaret Mead and James Baldwin, who rapped on their latest, A Rap on Race. After an hour break for the Dean Martin Show, or whatever (you're on your own time), and the 11 o'clock news, the Big TwoDick Cavett and Johnny Carson weighed in with no less than four scriveners. (Mery Griffin was still searching for the snows of yesteryear.) Indeed, due probably to a scheduling foulup, Cavett had nothing but writers.

title: Miss Goldman to Wed
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 24Announcement has been made by Joel H. Gold man of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Ronnie Lynn Goldman, to Peter Rosenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Rosenberg of Merrick. Miss Goldman is a daughter also of the late Mrs. Isabelle Gold man. The wedding is planned for December.

title: Mayor Kenneth Gibson says Wherever the Central Cities Are Going, Newark Is Going to Get There First
description: NEWARK is a study in the evils, tensions and frustrations that beset the central cities of America. It is a city of 375,000, an estimated 61 per cent Negro, 11 per cent Puerto Rican. It is a city with an overall unemployment rate of 14 per cent (25 to 30 per cent among blacks and Puerto Ricans); around 25 per cent of those who are employed work only parttime, and there are virtually no summer jobs and few programs for the city's 80,000 school children, who now roam the streets. As a result, one of every three Newarkers is getting some form of public assistance. There are, by conservative estimate, 20,000 drug addicts in the city, and only 7 per cent of them are being treated. New ark has the highest crime rate of any city in the nation; the highest per centage of substandard housing; the highest rates of venereal disease, new tuberculosis cases and maternal mor tality, and it is second in infant mor tality. Most of these rates, like the crime rate, are still rising. In the Cen tral Ward, perhaps the worst ghetto in the East, decent black families live as virtual prisoners in housing authority projects, afraid to let their children outside even to play. The city's first black Mayor, Kenneth A. Gibson, often says: Wherever the central cities of America are going, Newark is going to get there first.

title: Football Cards Drop Two
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 24 (UPI)Rodger Bird, a safety man, and a rookie quarterback, Tim Von Dulm, were released today by the St. Louis Cardi nals after they failed to pass their physicals. Bird has signed as a free agent this season. Von Dulm played with Portland State last year.

title: SovietIndonesian Study Set
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 24 (Reuters)The Soviet Union and Indonesia have signed an agreement for a study on the chances of resuming two So viet industrial projects, a steel mill and a phosphate plant abandoned after the army took over in Indonesia in 1965.

title: An Increase in Payload Requires Many Changes on Apollo Flight
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 24 The five main Saturn 5 rockets, each 13 stories high, will be set to burn just four tenths of a second longer than on past moon missions.

description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 24The elderly woman sat quietly in the empty lobby of the onceresplendent Gar den City Hotel earlier this week and mused over past events and an uncertain fu ture.

description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 24Lack of wind canceled today's Cow Bay area Yacht Racing Association of Long Is land Sound competition at the Port Washington Yacht Club. Racing was scheduled tomor row.

description: DACCA, Pakistan, July 24 Foreigners here were warned this week to avoid Chinese res taurants, which have apparent ly become the latest targets for separatist guerillas.

description: There is a neighborhood in New York City where the residents do not worry about being mugged, where chil dren play ball in the streets or fish near the house, where the air is fresh and honking automobile horns are rare.

title: Princeton Swimmers Cited
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 24 Three members of Princeton's varsity swimming teamJack Garretson of Hamilton, Ohio, a senior freestyle; John Huffstut ler of Lafayette, Calif., a senior diver, and Charles Campbell of Pasadena, Calif., a junior back strokerwere named today to the National Collegiate Athletic Association allAmerica team.

title: The World
description: There's been nothing like this since the announcement of the Soviet German nonaggression pact in August, 1939, said a veteran diplomat last week.

title: Ceausescu Still Opposes Full East Bloc Integration
description: VIENNA, July 24 (AP) President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania said today that he still opposes full East European economic integration, which he considers an infringement of sovereignty.

title: Yanks Top Brewers, 43, Win 11 th Game in Last 15
description: MILWAUKEE, July 24Mike Kekich, the tennisplaying, motorcycleriding pitcher, was saved by Lindy McDaniel, the Biblereading, gospelpreaching pitcher, today and the Yan kees edged the Milwaukee Brewers, 43, for their 11th victory in the last 15 games. The triumph, their eighth in 10 games with the Brewers this season, moved the Yankees to within two games of a .500 record, the first time they've been at that wonlost level since May 19, when they were 1618.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THERE was little reason for any great exhilaration or disappointment eitherin the financial and economic worlds after analysts had scrutinzed the secondquarter reports on industrial production, personal income, housing and the gross national product that were issued in the last two weeks.

title: Bonfiglio,C.W.Post Student, Is Victor in OneHour Run
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 24 Phil Bonfiglio of the Long Island Athletic Club won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union onehour run today at C. W. Post College. The finish ers were decided by the dis tance they covered during the hour.

title: Pugatch Princeton Captain
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July 24  T. Scott Pugatch, a 21yearold senior from Baltimore, has been elected captain of Princeton University's 1972 golf team. A twoyear regular, Pugatch was a consistent performer on last spring's team that had 12 vic tories and one tie in 15 matches.

title: Beach Ban Is Debated in Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., July 24While a State Supreme Court justice weighs the va lidity of a local law closing this city's beaches to non residents, leaders in the bat tle over the law say the fu ture of Long Beach may be determined by the outcome.

title: ALFA ROMEO WINS ENDURANCE RACE
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 24An Alfa Romeo prototype won today the Watkins Glen Six Hours of Endurance on a rainsoaked track, marking the third time this season the Ital ian make has defeated the Ger man Porsche in the World Championship of Manufactur ers. Alfa is the only car to have defeated Porsche this year.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  The steady deterioration of the United States trade balance with the rest of the world is, according to one expert estimate, costing the country $8billion in the gross na tional product and sixtenths of 1 per cent on the unem ployment rate.

title: Reader's Report
description: Some of the admittedly By zantine features of the art mu seum world are documented in a good natured satire by this former executive of the Museum of Modern Art. In Car ter's book, a moderately inno vative director named Lloyd Thatcher comes out of the West to take the helm of a New York art museum. He steers immediately into the turbulent waters of trustee politics and public policy. The president of the board of trus tees doesn't tell Thatcher enough about his intentions and a freelance bunch of art revolutionaries tells him too much about theirs. In support of Thatcher, who has plans to liberalize the museum (a rev olution in the teaching of art appreciation), is a staff as im movable as a tower of Jello. When Thatcher collaborates with the apparatchiks in stag ing Dimensions, an exhibit of urban environments com plete with builtin hostility, his own environment undergoes a drastic change. The author calls this a collage of mu seum experience; interested readers will be able to pick out recognizable bits and pieces.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: National Parks: A Report on the Range War at Generation Gap
description: WHEN L. E. Curran of Houston, Tex., returned from Yosemite National Park last year, he was furious. His vacation had been ruined. So he wrote to the National Park Service to complain about those greasyheaded Spock spooks who were invading Yosemite. I suggest using tran quilizer guns and pellets on them, he said in his letter.

title: Miss Fragala Married Here
description: Miss Donna Barbara Fra gala and Vincent Moore De Orchis were married here yesterday afternoon in the Fordham University Chapel. The Rev. Edward Berbusse conducted the Roman Catho lic ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.
