description: WINCHESTER, Va., July 24 (AP)Judy Kimball shot a 4 underpar 68 today to take a threestroke lead after the second round of the 54hole Ladies Professional Golf Associ ation O'Sullivan open. Miss Kimball has a 36hole total of 139 over the par72 Winchester Country Club course.

title: Miss Carole Williams Is Affianced
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 24The engagement of Miss Carole Elizabeth Williams to Peter Wyman Segal has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. L. Roger Williams of Bronx ville and Bethesda, Md., parents of the prospective bride. Her fianc is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Segal of Boston.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: HOUSE AND SENATE conferees agreed to open the way for a further expansion of trade with Communist countries, including China, by authorizing the Export Import Bank to supply export credits for shipments those countries.  The House Banking Committee nar rowly approved an emergency loanguarantee program de signed to save Lockheed from bankruptcy. The Senate, meanwhile, put aside other matters to begin consideration of an identical bill that would authorize a total of $2billion in loan guaranteeswith a limit of $250million for one companyto major businesses in financial difficulty.

title: Sudan Coup Raises Question on ArabRed Tie
description: CAIRO, July 24The Com munistoriented coup d'tat in the Sudan Monday that lasted until Premier Gaafar alNimeiry was restored to power in a countercoup Thursday has raised a serious question among Arabs about their relationship with Communist countries.

title: U.S. Group to Participate In Alberta Speedway Races
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, July 17The participation of a United States group in the management of Edmonton In ternational Speedway was an nounced here last week. The speedway includes a roadrac ing course and a drag strip.

title: Lindsay: It's Funny, John, You Don't Look Like a Democrat

Later, in the car, she turned to her companion and said: Can you imagine anyone being a Democrat?

title: Joyleg By Avram Davidson and Ward Moore. 223 pp. New York: Walker and Co. $5.95.

Davidson and Moore posed these questions original ly in a sciencefiction maga zine, and have expanded them into a refreshing bit of politi cal fantasy.

title: Mr. Nixon Sits Tight
description: After a year and a half of recession, sluggish recovery and unemployment, inflation in the United States is not fading away. In June the Consumer Price Index climbed by sixtenths of 1 per cent, its sharpest rise in 15 months. Seasonally adjusted, this represented an annual rate of increase of 6 per cent.

title: Bridge Should conscience be your guide or common sense?
description: EXPERIENCED players often find that their common sense and their consciences are in conflict dur ing the auction. Suppose you hold the South hand shown in the diagram and your partner opens one club, using standard bidding methods. Your right  hand opponent passes, and you must make a decision.

title: 3 BANNED FOR LIFE IN GERMAN SOCCER
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 24 (AP)The West Ger man Football Federation handed lifetime suspensions to two professional soccer players and the president of a soccer club today after finding them guilty of trying to fix matches.

title: American kids, American poverty, American unity, American advice
description: For several years now, writing books about youth has been some thing of an industry. As Arlo Guthrie might say it, the young have been analyzed, categorized, computerized, mobilized, propagandized, chastised, and, occasionally, canonized. Natu rally, with each passing year it be comes increasingly difficult to say anything new or interesting on the subject. Thomas Cottle, however, has an uncommonly refreshing idea; he listens to the young. Really listens. Which means he does not bring to his encounters with youth an aca demic or a political ideology he hopes they will represent. He comes with a wish to hear and record the widest possible range of their feel ings and needs. And that means he is prepared to hear what other com mentators on youth have so often missed: ambiguity, ambivalence, con tradiction, complexityin a word, humanity.

title: Stamps
description: A BOISE, Idaho, collector has discovered a com plete pane of the 8c Flag stamp issued in May that has no perforations. The multicolored Flag stamp is in more or less con stant production on the high speed Huck Press at the Bu reau of Engraving and Print ing Washington. The Huck functions in a sequence printing, perforating, add ing the Iuminiscent tagging, and cutting the continuous roll of printed stamps into post office panes of 100 stamps.

title: TWO ARE WOUNDED IN NEW HIJACKING
description: MIAMI. July 24 (AP)A hi jacker shot a National Airlines stewardess and a passenger in midflight today when he corn marideered a DC8 jet with 83 persons aboard to Cuba.

title: IsraeliVatican Difference Over Jerusalem Widened
description: JERUSALEM, July 24Israel and the Vatican are trading angry public charges these days about the safety and sanctity of Christian holy places in Je rusalem.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Lois R. Peterson Bride Of Frank Cavanagh Jr.
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 24 Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this morning for the marriage of Miss Lois Ruth Peterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward K. Peterson of Ridgewood and Southampton, L. I., to Frank B. Cavanagh Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cavanagh of New York and Southampton.

title: There are 1,000,000 secret swingers in America today
description: I always thought group sex meant me and another person. Which only goes to show how one can com pletely miss an American Social Phe nomenon that is taking place right under one's very nose. Group sex, I have recently learned from my read ing, refers, in fact, to everything from your Eskimo partnerexchange, to your basic WifeSwapping to the traditional Menage  Trois to the even more timehonored tradition of the Orgy. Apparently there is a mush rooming, nationwide cult of swing ers (that's what one properly terms a groupsexist), unearthed only in the past ten months by the Book Publish ing Industry.

title: U. S. and Britain Revive International Polo
description: LONDON, July 24Polo players from the United States and Britain take the field tomorrow for a game that will revive international polo competition in Britain.

title: 2 CONCERNS SETTLE IN COPPER WALKOUT
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 24 The 24dayold copper strike was officially ended in two major segments of the industry tonight as the union's 500 member Nonferrous Metals Con ference ratified contract agree ments with the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Miami Copper Company, affect ing 13,000 men.

title: Democratic Race Is Confused as Hopefuls Abound
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 With the Democratic National Convention of 1972 still a year off, the race for the party's Presidential nomination is both much further advanced and much more confused than is usual at this stage.

title: White Sox, Senators Split
description: CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) Frank Howard, who had four hits in the opener including his 17th home run, rapped a two run, tiebreaking double in the ninth inning of the second game to give the Washington Senators a 53 victory over the Chicago White Sox and a split of their doubleheader today.

title: RUMANIANS CALM ABOUT MINIPURGE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24  Rumania's twoweekold drive to purge her culture of foreign influence and her peo ple of ideological lassitude has cast a pall over Bucharest night life, but does not alarm liberal writers and artists there who think the crackdown may ac tually give them more freedom to experiment.

title: Royal Owl Captures $158,250 Hollywood Juvenile Stakes and Returns $4.20
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (UPI)Royal Owl took the lead shortly after the start today and raced to an easy victory in the 32d running of the $158,250 Hollywood Juvenile Champion ship for 2yearolds at Holly wood Park.

title: Home Improvement
description: OUTDATED or inade quate old lighting fix tures can be quickly and easily replaced with more attractive and more efficient models by any home handyman capable of following a few common sense rules, and equipped with only a screwdriver and a pair of pliers. Not only does this result in upgrading the light in that particular room, it also provides a com paratively inexpensive and simple way to enhance the decorative scheme in his home.

title: Recordings
description: THE Lazarus Case to the contrary notwithstand ing, revivals are diffi cult to pull off. In music, someone is always laying hands on a seemingly defunct work and command ing it to walk again, and occasionally the miracle does take place. But most often, the dead continue to sleep, or if reused momentarily to some form of simulated life, take the first opportunity to slide back into the cool of history's grave. Even when a work seems incontestably good, or at least better than many popular pieces, some mysterious force seems to militate against its rejoining the concert repertory. The great heyday of repertory filling may be over.

title: TeenAge Aides Sought By Long Beach Hospital
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., July 24Long Beach Memorial Hospital is seeking teen agers to work as volunteers during the summer season.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Three recent thrillersJohn Quigley's THE LAST CHECK POINT (McCall, $5.95), LAST POST FOR A PARTISAN by Clive Egleton (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $5.95) and FORCE RED by Milton R. Bass (Put nam, $5.95) approach science fiction in that they take place in the future. It is the im mediate future, however, with which all three are concerned and the extrapolations draw upon events of our own day.

title: Sudan Executes 3 More In Aftermath of Revolt
description: CAIRO, JULY 24Three more Sudanese officers were executed by firing squad in Khartoum today for involve ment in the coup d'tat that briefly deposed Premier Ga afar alNimeiry.

title: Planes Fly Out of the Past to Reunion
description: SHIRLEY, L. I., July 24 More than 8,000 spectators viewed 50 planes participat ing in the ninth annual fly in of the Antique Airplane Club of New York at Brook haven Airport earlier this week. But the Red Baron could not make it.

title: Scott Triumphs Over Ross; Lowman Also Tennis Victor
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 24Gene Scott of New York, the topseeded player, John Lowman of Darien, Conn. reached the final of the $1,000 Port Washington open tennis tournament at the Port Wash ington tennis academy today. This is a satellite tournament of the United States Lawn Ten nis Association.

title: Gambler's Choice Scores
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 24  Corneliuc Culkin of Troy rode the winner and thirdplace finisher in the preliminary jumper class today at the Lake Placid horse show.

title: Suddenly, Don Siegel's High Campus
description: GODARD called me an artist. Well, that's all right. John Cassavetes introduced us at a party in Hollywood. Here was this dark little French man telling me what a great director I was and all I could do was stand there stupidly saying, Thank you very much. I hadn't seen anything he'd done.

title: For Salad
description: THE supreme salad vege table for fall is prob ably the long Chi nese cabbage. A cylin der of closelyfitted leaves, a foot or more long, Chinese cabbage is hardier than let tuce, more refined and more delicate in taste than com mon cabbage.

title: In Slack Economy, Office Spaces on Suffolk's Route 110 Go Begging for Tenants
description: MELVILLE, L. I., July 24 Almost two dozen office buildings line both sides of Route 110, the major north south artery in Suffolk Coun ty. But many of them, con ceived in the days of a boom ing economy, lack tenants and their owners are now desperately searching for tenants in these recession days to fill thousands of square feet of space.

title: The World
description: AMMAN, JordanThe feda yeen are finished, the fedayeen are finished, bystanders mur mured as Jordanian Army trucks carried hundreds of captive Arab commandos off to exile in Syria and Iraq last week. There were no cheers from the fedayeen's supporters as the guerrillas passed. Their departure seemed to seal the final crushing of the commandos as an independent force in Jordan. With the army in the saddle, the Palestinians' cheering had to stop.

title: Reader's Report
description: In March, 1944, the British were bombing Germany by night, and the Americans were bombing by day, in a crescen do preparatory to invasion. Spencer Dunmore compresses this holocaust into the flight of one British Lancaster bomber, intercepted and pursued by a lone Messerschmitt fighter on its homeward run from Berlin. The pilot of the Lancaster is a veteran of 32 missions whose capacity for pessimistic intro spection has increased as his tour of duty has lengthened. The pilot of the Messerschmitt is a youth who has just learned that his parents were killed in a bombing raid. Dun more tells us what happens to the aircraft and to the minds of the men within them as MMother and its nemesis run for the English coast. This is a screamingly taut narrative that carries a burden of sensi tive reflection.

title: ASTROS LOSE, 93, AS GARRETT STARS
description: The New York Mets, who have tried everything but voo doo lately to break loose from their slump, resorted to some oldfashioned pitching and hit ting yesterday to swat out a 93 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Business Index Down
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Busi ness Activity fell to 374.5 from 377.5 a week earlier. A year ago it was 366.5.

title: A Great Way to Watch SkyDivingFrom Below
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J.  Droning like giant bumble bee, the old blue and white monoplane circled slowly 2,500 feet above the little country airport here. Overhead, the sky was pale blue, frosted with a delicate white haze. The scene was pretty and peace ful. Suddenly the plane's single engine seemed to die. On the ground, we glanced up worriedlyjust in time to see a tiny figure detach itself from the aircraft and fall away. As the plane's engine roared back to life, a red and black parachute blossomed over the tiny stick figure.

title: LUXURY BUILDINGS VOTED FOR QUEENS
description: The Board of ?? has given final ?? for con struction of two controversial highrise luxury buildings near Parkway Village, a Queens gar denapartment development housing many United Nations families.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Editorial Cartoon 9  No Title
China's New Mood Relaxation, SelfConfidence
description: I WENT to China this year by way of Pakistan. Familiarity, I find, never blunts the shock of meeting the Dark Ages in the Indian subcon tinent. I said as much to a German making the same journey who had mentioned in the plane that he had had a house in South China before the 1949 revolution. He assented and added, But, you know, this is what the Chinese had to start fromfratri cidal war, famine, plague, corruption.   I put in, And the same hope lessness, I suppose. Oh, no, he re plied; the Communists were always quite certain they could change things!

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: First Boy Scouts from U.S. Reach Japan for Jamborees
description: TOKYO, July 24The first four of 35 charted commer cial airliners, carrying 1,000 American Boy Scouts to the 13th World Jamboree in Japan, arrived here today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL SLICK IS FOUND ALONG BEACH ON L.I.
description: An oil slick approximately, half a mile in length washed up yesterday on parts of the beachfront at Atlantic Beach, L. I., the Coast Guard said last night.

title: NADER IS SEEKING TO UNITE ANGLERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 24  Ralph Nader, advocate of con sumer and environmental pro tection, announced today a plan to create a national coa lition of sports and commer cial fishermen to bring organ ized voting power into the fight for clean water.

title: Space /Science
description: Man's ability to set off nuclear explosions remains one of his most ambivalent powers with its twofaced potential for military destruc tion and peaceful progress. Last week both faces were on public view.

title: Saga of a Brooklyn Heights Rock Group
description: The Chapins of Brooklyn Heights, a folk and rock group whose members oc cupy part of the building at 136 Hicks Street, have com pletely taken over the Village Gate in Greenwich Village.

title: Avi Weiner to Marry Miss Mary Tashman
description: Miss Mary Beth Tashman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Malcolm Tashman of New York and Stamford, Conn., plans to be married in Israel on Aug. 3 to Avi Weiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shabtay Weiner of Ashke lon, Israel.

title: Tito's Hand Seen in Expulsion of 2 Croatian Nationalists From Communist Party
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24The expulsion yesterday of two leading Croatian national ists from the Communist party is viewed here as a result of intervention by President Tito to squelch a separatist move ment among intellectuals and students in Yugoslavia's sec ond largest republic.

title: UTILITY CHALLENGES ENVIRONMENT BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) An electric power company has filed suit here seeking to nullify a Federal agency's re quirement for cooling towers on an atomic power plant un der construction.

title: PLIGHT OF WHITES IN SOUTH STUDIED
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 24A yearold Goverment report that has just come to light illus trates an old fact of Southern life that has been obscured by the Negro civil rights move ment: not all the poor people in the Deep South are black.

title: Giants Win on 6Run 6th
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 (UPI)Don Carrithers hurled a fivehitter and singled home two runs in a sixrun sixth in ning today to pace the San Francisco Giants to a 61 vic tory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: RESIDENTS FIGHT SITE FOR SCHOOL
description: Block No. 3949 in Brooklyn, as the official city maps call it, contains 22 twofamily homes, two sixfamily houses and nine businesses employing nearly 200 people.

title: Giants Trade Grant to Dolphins
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 24 Wes Grant, who stalked out of the Giants' football camp at C. W. Post College here last Thursday after a heated argu ment with Coach Alex Webster, was traded today to Miami for the Dolphins' thirdround draft pick next year.

title: Statement on Party Switch Drafted by Lindsay Staff
description: Mayor Lindsay's staff has prepared a statement announc ing that he will switch political parties and is considering run ning for President as a Demo crat next year. But the Mayor himself has not yet approved the statement and may have made no final decision on his political future.

title: Thurston's Dusty Captures Snipe Class Sailing Honors
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., July 24 Fred Thurston's Dusty won again in Snipe Class competi tion today in drifting north westerly winds on Hempstead Harbor.

title: About Pro Football
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 24 Pete Rozelle takes insults from people like John Elliott Cook, Joe Kapp's attorney; Bernie Parrish, the former Cleveland player who has a muckraking book coming out; Ellis Rubin, the Miami at torney seeking to lift the Super Bowl local television blackout, or Johnny Sample, the inventive former Jet. But those within the family of the National Football League pay only homage to their leader.

title: News of Dogs
The Many Americas Shall Be One By Harrison E. Salisbury. 204 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $6.50.
description: A tribute to Harrison Salisbury appears near the end of A Long Journey, a recently published auto biography by a former functionary in the American Communist party. After the writer, George Charney, left the C.P., he and a handful of similarly broken men would meet from time to time for political discussion and lec tures. On one occasion the guest speaker was Salisbury. The New York Times correspondent had been de rided by party people as a kind of imperialist lackey for his reportage from the Soviet Union (as he was attacked by rightwingers for being soft on Communism), but now the meeting society of party exes had turned so bitterly antiRed that Salis bury's lecture on deStalinization during the Khrushchev era was a trifle more constructive  than some of us were prepared to accept, Charney writes. At a moment when we were most critical of the Soviet Union, Salisbury's talk restored our sense of balance. He woodenly con cludes, In a way it was ironic.

title: Education
description: Day care for preschool children  the concept of combining early educational benefits with supervised play  is moving closer to reali ty in the United States. Pres ident Nixon has espoused the idea, and Congress has taken a major step in the same di rection.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Research and development on Seventh Avenue? There is a great deal of it, but mainly in connection with styling. One of its strongest expo nents is Milton Rattet, presi dent of Four Corners Sports wear, Inc.

title: Nuptials Held For Miss Hall
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 24Miss Suzanne Louise Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Hall of Garden City, was married here this afternoon to Brian Chafin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett W. Chafin of Copake, N. Y.

title: Some Sopranos Just Love Those Lurid Roles
description: THE Opera Society of Washington has always had fresh ideas about repertory and staging, and these will not change when it moves this fall into the capital's first ade quate opera house, in the new John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Doyle. Scarlett Gain Final Of Jersey 35ers' Tennis
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 24 Al Doyle of New York and Bill Scarlett of Milburn gained the final of the New Jersey State tennis championships for men 35 years and over today.

title: THIRD ROUND OF 68
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 24 Arnold Palmer complained about the slow play on the course, but his momentum increased his lead to three strokes today in the $250,000 Westchester Classic.

title: Voluntary Ban on Pep Pills, Backed by Most Huntington Physicians, Is Spreading Through Suffolk
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 24 Dr. Melville G. Rosen of Deer Park is so convinced that am phetamines are unnecessary and hazardous for many pa tients that he has taken to pre scribing sugarcoated aspirin for some who insist they need a pill to wake them up or sub due their appetites.

title: MOON TELEVISION: LIVE AND IN COLOR
description: The Apollo 15 mission will give earthbound moon buffs the first live telecast of a take off from the lunar surface.

title: TEACHERS OPPOSE COLLEGE'S BUDGET
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 24A proposed budget for Nassau Community College that would hold the line on taxes was sub mitted this week to the Board of Supervisors by County Ex ecutive Ralph G. Caso. The budget immediately drew the fire of faculty officers faced with an increase of teaching time.

title: Pamela Noyes Has Wedding
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 24Miss Pamela Anne Noyes and Gordon Paul Engelbrecht were married here this after noon at the Good Shepherd Lutheran Church by the Rev. Carl W. Beyer.

title: Group to Weigh Future of Brooklyn and Queens Catholic Schools
description: Early next month a com mittee of Brooklyn and Queens Roman Catholicsteachers, parents, students and admin istratorswill begin an ex tensive examination of each of the 230 parochial schools in the Brooklyn Diocese's ed ucational system, which cov ers both Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Art
description: PERHAPS at no time since World War II has the imminent on set of a New York art season presented as joy less and uncertain a prospect as it does this year. In place of the usual mood of anxious optimism, an aura of cynicism, truculence and gloom per vades the local art world, which, though traditionally a somewhat hysterical milieu, has rarely appeared so thor oughly disorganized and dis enchanted. Two obvious caus es of this malaise are the ex pectation of unprecedented political militance on the part of artists and the shaky state of the economy.

title: Dance
description: WHEN, more than a year ago, Britain's Royal Ballet said farewell to New York, it was saying farewell for the last time under the artistic management that had governed its destinies right from its foundation in 1931. The company had been founded, of course, by Ninette de Valois, who was its first director until 1965, when she stepped down in favor of her principal choreographer al most from the beginning, Sir Frederick Ashton.

title: National Notes
description: War of the Words

title: Webster's Aides Keep Giants Honed
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 24The stop watch, the decimal point and the rules for execution have become a major factor in instruction at the New York Giants' train ing camp under Coach Alex Webster. The human factor, though, still remains im portant.

title: Grant for Safety Studies
description: The United States Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare has awarded a five year grant of $775,000 to the Center for Safety at New York University to support graduate training of specialists in oc cupational safety and health. It will provide tuition for nine fulltime and parttime students earning a master's degree and support one fulltime post doctoral student.

title: Diamond Firm Aids Stakes
description: De Beers Consolidated ?? Ltd., the diamond company, will enable the King George  and Queen Elizabeth Stakes at Ascot in 1972 to become the richest race on the British racing calendar by contributing a $72,000 sponsorship to bring the value to $168,000 in added

title: Chess
description: WITH the attention of the entire chess world focused on the Candidates' matches now be ing played to select a chal lenger to world champion Boris Spassky, the progress of a similar series of events to select a new challenger to the women's world champion has been unjustly neglected. The first women's Interzonal, concluded recently at Ohrid, Yugoslavia, produced three prospective challengers: Nona Alexandria of the U. S. S. R., who won the tournament with 13 points out of 17, T. Zatulov skaya (U. S. S. R.), and M. Lazarevic (Yugoslavia).

title: 6 Die in Mali Air Crash
description: BAMAKO, Mali, July 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  All six crew members of an Air Senegal DC3 died when the plane crashed near here today, official sources said.

title: Youthful Disorder Is Worrying Officials of Tunis and Algiers
description: TUNIS. July 15From an unexpected quarter the Gov ernments of Tunisia and Algeria have been experiencing a wor risome threat to order and stability on the part of their youthful populations.

title: Bridgehamoton Group Cancels 2 Race Events
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., July 24Bridgehampton Race Circuit announced last week the cancellation of two rac ing eventsLa United States Auto Club road race on Sept. 1112, and an American Mo torcycle Association moto cross on Aug. 1.

title: GUSTAVUS A. GINTER
description: CINCINNATI, July 24Gus tavus A. Ginter, a former city attorney and director of the Kroger Company, a grocery chain, died here yesterday. His age was 90.

title: Allende and Lanusse Agree On Ideological Pluralism
description: SALTA, Argentina, July 24 (AP)Salvador Allende Gos sens, Chile's Marxist President, and Alejandro Agustin Lanusse, the military President of Ar gentina, today ratified a policy of ideological pluralism in in ternational relations.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Clap Hands, Here Comes Anything
description: HAROLD'S dream be gan years ago, in the early days of tele vision, in the dimly remembered time of Strike It Rich and Queen for a Day.

title: Stewart Wins Pole for CanAm at Watkins Glen Today
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 24Jackie Stewart, who has won one CanAm race this sea son, qualified today for the pole position in tomorrow's running of the Watkins Glen CanAm. Stewart set the pace in his L&M Lola T260Chevro let at 134.58 miles an hour over the newly remodeled Watkins Glen road course of 2.4 miles.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: A Prescient Maine Guide
description: EYELET POND, Me.Push ing our way through a stand of spruce, we arrived at Eye let Pond and found a sturdy cedarlog raft tethered to the shore.

title: Search Is Resumed For Epileptic Child In Wyoming Wilds
description: CASPER, Wyo., July 24 The search resumed at day break today for 9yearold Kevin Dye, a mentally retarded boy, who has been missing since last Sunday.

title: Bedford Quits in an Assault On Clarke's 10,000 Mark
description: LONDON, July 24 (UPI) David Bedford failed in an at tempt today at Australian Ron Clarke's world 5,000meter rec ord of 13 minutes 16.6 seconds when he was forced to quit with a strained hamstring.

title: How to Throw the Ultimate Fast Ball
description: OAKLAND, Calif. THE room as still dark and shrouded by sleep when the first telephone call of the day comes jangling across the wires. Dutifully, Tommy Davis raises him self and goes groping for the receiver. He plucks it off the cradle gently and speaks in subdued tones. In the other room Vida Blue is resting and must not be disturbed. He is baseball's new Wunderkind, and he must not lose sleep.

title: U.S. to Give Spain Vaccine
description: MADRID, July 24 (UPI) Spain has accepted a United States offer of 10 million chol ers vaccine units but will not need them right now because the health situation is well un der control, an official spokes man said today.

title: New York's Bucolic Byway Of Surpassing Beauty (Government Certified)
description: ANCRAM, N. Y.  this the time to visit the most beautiful rural road in the United States (as certified by the Federal High way Administration of the Department of Transportation after a nationwide competition in 1969)? Well, why not? It's only 120 miles north of New York City. You can get there by driving up the Taconic State Parkway through Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties and about halfway into the terra incognita of Columbia County.

title: Johnson &
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. Johnson & Johnson is one of those cradletograve com panies that figures if it doesn't get you at one stage of your life, it surely will at the next.

title: Jews of Morocco Shaken by the Attack on Hassan
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, July 24In midafternoon on Satur day, July 10, the Rabat radio switched to martial music.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: MARGIN IS A NECK
description: With Bobby Ussery urging him into the lead just after the start, Sigmud Sommer's Never Bow was first across the finish line in the $115,100 Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct yester day.

title: Drive in Boston May Bring A New Urban Transit Mix
description: BOSTON, July 24An unu sual coalition organized to re sist highway construction here has moved Massachusetts to the verge of a basic change in urban transportation. The cam paign is emerging as a text book case for similar efforts around the country.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: City College's Graduates Rank Second in Nation in Doctorates
description: City College of the City Uni versity of New York ranks sec ond only to the University of California at Berkeley in the number of undergraduates who went on to earn doctorates from 1920 through 1970.

title: CARDINALS BEAT EXPOS BY 87, 93
description: MONTREAL, July 24 (AP) Joe Torre drove in seven runs and clouted his 15th and 16th homers of the season tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals swept a doubleheader from the Montreal Expos, 87, in 14 innings and 93.

title: Dr. Micheels Wins Twice In Regatta Off Bridgeport
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 24 Dr. Louis J. Micheels of Cedar Point Yacht Club, West port, sailed Try to two victories today when the annual Eastern Connecticut area championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound began in light south easterly breezes off Black Rock Y.C. With 3223 points, he led by 513 with one race remain ing to be sailed tomorrow.

title: Spray Paint Adds to Graffiti Damage
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24  The signatures of Cornbread. Cool Earl and Chewy are as ubiquitous here as Taki's in New York and Kilroy's during World War .

title: Mr. Heath Gambles for Growth
description: The British Government has made a decisive change in the direction of its economic policy. Instead of stick ing with his scheme for slow economic growth and a handsoff attitude toward wages and prices, Prime Minis ter Heath has now committed himself to stimulative tax cuts combined with an incomes policy that will start with a voluntary effort on the part of British industry to hold its prices down. Mr. Heath hopes that the trade unions will follow by moderating their wage demands.

title: The King's Fountain By Lloyd Alexander. Illustrated by Ezra Jack Keats. Unpaged. New York: E. P. Dutton & Co. $5.95. (Ages 4 to 8)
description: In a long ago time and faraway place (the Near East), a king decides to build a fountain in his garden for the glory of his name. Unfor tunately for the city, it would elim inate the water supply. A poor man tries to find someone with wisdom, courage and persuasive speech to point out to the king the disastrous consequences of the plan. Everyone lets him down: the learned scholar's words are unintelligible; the honey tongued merchants are afraid; the brawny metalsmith lacks good sense.

title: $55,660 RACE WON BY DOUBLE DELTA
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 24 James Drymond's and Vance Greenslit's Double Delta extend ed her string of stakes tri umphs to three with a three length triumph over the Walnut Hill Farm's Dedicated to Sue in the $55,650 Susquehanna Handicap for fillies and mares today at Liberty Bell.

title: NEW LEAGUE HEAD STUDYING GHETTOS
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the 35 yearold Negro lawyer from Atlanta who will take over the job of executive director of the National Urban League in Jan uary, has said he is making an intensive, personal study of the Northern, black ghetto experience.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Miss Wedemeyer Plans Bridal
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., July 24Miss Isabelle Dolo res Wedemeyer, a reporter for The Associated Press in New York and Donald Rede Carse Jr., assistant treasurer of the international division of Bankers Trust Company in New York, plan to be married on Aug. 23 in the Fifth Ave nue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Dollar Goal Draws Two Approaches
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 24 Steve Melnyk has been a professional golfer as long as Lanny Wadkins has been, but Melnyk thinks he learned one very important lesson be fore his colleague did.

title: Virginia M. Zock Plans To Be Married Aug. 14
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 24Mr. and Mrs. An thony Nicholas Zock have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Vir ginia Maria Zock, to Jean Philippe de Bourbon. He is a son of Mrs. Fulco de Bourbon of Patterson, N. Y., and the late Fulco de Bourbon, who was a grandson of Don Carlos de Bourbon, once pretender to the Spanish throne.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Television
description: THERE was a time of change just after the Civil War when many black men filled high offices across the country. In one county in South Carolina a Federal judgeship was available, and the word came down: Get a Negro. The local politicians re plied, All the reading Nigras got jobs. But the word came back: We're coming to see. On the night before Federal rep resentatives were to arrive, the local politicians invited all Negroes who were known to read to a special dinner. The Negroes were led into a dark room and locked in for the night. A taunting voice cried out: The carpetbaggers will see you in the morning.

title: Cyclist Shot Dead, A Second Wounded In S.I. Gang Fight
description: A member of a motorcycle gang was killed and a second cut and beaten on Staten Island yesterday in what the police said was another chapter in a continuing feud between rival gangs.

title: An Inch Is a Ton
description: Almost since Congress began the interstate highway system in 1956, the trucking interests have been lobby ing for a change in the law to permit wider trucks. A wider truck is also a heavier and therefore more profit able vehicle. But not even a highway built to interstate standards can sustain the wear and tear of heavier trucks pounding over its surface day after day. Inevitably they mean a shorter life for the highway and a bigger highway repair bill for the taxpayer. Thus, the plea for a wider truck limit is not an innocuous request. It, is really a disguised raid on the public treasury by the trucking interests.

title: Cecelia Hale and Charles Ziff, U. of Alabama Graduates, Wed
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., July 25Miss Cecelia Hale and Charles J. Ziff, both grad uates of the University of Alabama, were married here this afternoon at the Univer sity Club of the University of Alabama.

title: Dance: A Romeo and Juliet Fresco
description: Tudor's Renaissance fres co of a Romeo and Juliet was given again by the American Ballet Theater at the State Theater, Lincoln Center, on Saturday night, and I must say I enjoyed it a great deal more than I did on its first appearance a couple of days earlier.

title: Subversion
description: There are many ways to subvert free governmentthe violence of the saboteur, the espionage techniques of the spy, the propaganda of the totalitarian. But it can also, be subverted by those chosen to be its guardians in the White House and the Congress. By waste and cynicism, by contempt for public opinion and by emulation of totalitarian methods, they can subvert the confidence of ordinary citizens in their own institutions of government.

title: Coles Takes German Open By Four Strokes With 279
description: BREMENCARLSTEDT, Ger many, July 25 (AP)Neil Coles of Britain shot a courserecord 68 today to win the German open golf championship with a total of 279. Peter Thomson of Australia was second four strokes back.

title: G.O.P. Letter Says O'Brien Aids Muskie Behind Scenes
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) The Republican party's Na tional Newsletter today accused the Democratic National Chair man, Lawrence F. O'Brien, of working behind the scenes to secure the party's Presidential nomination for Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine.

title: Problems Abound at Stratford Fete
description: STRATFORD, Conn.This is the 17th summer of the American Shakespeare Festi val and the third summer that Michael Kahn has been the artistic director. Before he took over Stratford (af ter several years directing plays off Broadway and in regional theaters including Stratford), the festival had slipped slowly into, disrepute.

title: CITY BALLET GROUP APPEARS AT PRISON
description: DANNEMORA, N. Y., July 25 Six members of the New York City Ballet performed here yes terday for a large, enthusiastic audience that seemed generally unfamiliar with the company's artthe more than 700 maxi mumsecurity prisoners at Clin ton State Correctional Facility.

title: Freudian Analysts Gather For First Time in Vienna
description: VIENNA, July 25  A land mark fiveday meeting of 2,000 Freudian analysts begins here tomorrow in the Hofburg, a massive baroque palace once the administrative seat of the AustroHungarian Empire.

title: Nimeiry Describes Escape
description: KHARTOUM, July 25Pre mier Nimeiry, in a news con ference today, described in detail his two and a half days of captivity in the Presidential Palace after rebel officers seized power last Monday and his escape in the confusion that followed the loyalist counter strike on Thursday.

title: SCOTT TURNS BACK LOWMAN, 61, 62, 76
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 25Gene Scott of New York defeated John Lowman of Darien, Conn., 61, 62, 76, in the final of the Port Washing ton open tennis tournament to day at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Rikers Island Reformatory Scored in Board's Report
description: The New York City Board of Correction assailed the city's Rikers Island Reformatory yesterday as a human ware house where youthful offend ers serving indeterminate sen tences were denied adequate training and rehabilitation and subjected to empty days and useless work.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Revson and Hulme Finish 1,2 in CanAm Auto Race
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 25  Peter Revson has probably never shown such exuberance in public.

title: HeartLung Transplant Is Performed by Barnard
description: CAPETOWN, July 25 (AP) Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard and his team of surgeons transplant ed both lungs and a heart to day into a man bedridden for two years with an incurable lung condition that had weak ened his heart.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, July 25  The American Bar Association has come and gone from London in all its thousands. The assemblies and the dinners and the garden parties served their purpose of celebrating the common origin of Eng lish and American law. An Indiana lawyer visiting Westminster Hall or the Inns of Court could not help but feel a relationship to an ancient tradi tion.

title: Quake Shakes Chilean Area
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 25 (AP)A strong earth tremor shook Valparaiso, Chile's second largest city, and surrounding areas this morning. There were no reports of injuries.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: IMOLA, Italy, July 25 (AP) Carlos Pace of Brazil piloted his Marche 712 round the 56 Saps of the Imola Track at an average speed of 115.7 miles an hour today to win the Shell Formula II Grand Prix.

title: People Blame Strrip Mines for Floods in Kentucky
description: McROBERTS, Ky., July 25  People here were angry last week when mud and water rushed through their hillside neighborhood, and most of them blamed the strip miners, who have bulldozed and drilled the mountains above their homes.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 25 The final of the New Jersey State tennis championship for men 35 years and over was postponed today because of wetness and rescheduled for tomorrow. The finalists are Al Doyle of New York and Bill Scarlett of Millburn.

title: OkkerTops Drysdale in Final
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 25 (UPI)Tom Okker of the Neth erlands took command after a 45minute rain delay today and defeated Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 36, 64, 61, in the final of the $50,000 First National tennis tournament. The first prize was $10,000.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Poll Finds Nixon Rating Is Up 6 Points Over China Trip
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  A telephone survey by the Re publican National Committee's polling organization shows that President Nixon's approval rat ing was 6 percentage points higher after he announced his proposed trip to Communist China than it was two months earlier.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL LIFTS PROFIT 73%
description: The Republic Steel Corpora tion, the nation's third largest steel producer, reported from Cleveland over the weekend that secondquarter earnings were 73 per cent higher than the same period last year.

title: SLAIN PATROLMAN TO GET FULL HONORS
description: A funeral service will be held Wednesday for Patrolman Robert Denton, who was stabbed to death early Satur day morning outside a grocery in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn after having pur chased a package of cigarettes.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you're buying a house, you know you'll pay a legal fee if you hire a lawyer to represent you.

title: $500Million in Narcotics Seized by Customs in Year.
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Narcotics worth nearly half a billion dollars were seized by United States Customs in the year ended June 30 and in cluded 937 pounds of heroin worth $409million on the street, the Bureau of Customs announced today.

title: LEROY J. ROBERTSON
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 25 (AP)Leroy J. Roberston, win ner of the Reichold Award for musical composition, died to day, apparently of heart trouble. He was 74 years old.

title: Advertising:
description: Although it's been only a couple of weeks since he joined his old pals from Holi day at Travel & Leisure, John S. Connors, the publisher, already has some important announcements to make. One has to do with regional edi tions and the other is the new ad director to head the beefedup staff.

title: A Major Yippie Theorist Seized on Drug Charges
description: A young man arrested re cently in Madison, Wis., as a marijuana dealer has turned out to be a major theoretician and behindthescenes leader of the underground youth move ment.

title: COSMOS AND METROS PLAY 22 DRAW HERE
description: The New York Cosmos gained ground in the Northern Division of the North American Soccer League yesterday by tying the Toronto Metros, 22, before 2,132 fans at Yankee Stadium.

title: YearOld Hospital Unit Is Praised and Assailed
description: After one year, the city's new Health and Hospitals Corpora tion has received both official praise for management ef ficiency and criticism from many quarters that none of the gains have trickled down to the sick poor in the wards.

title: Retail Jewelry Industry Finds a Sparkle in the Business Outlook
description: The nation's retail jewelry in dustry, one of those most beset by the recession in 1970, Is be ginning to glow again.

title: Berlin Flight Fails; 1 Killed
description: BERLIN, July 25 (UPI)East German border guards opened fire last night on three men attempting to flee to West Ber lin, killing one and wounding another, the West Berlin police reported today. The third man was captured.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 25 The topseeded players went into action today in the United States 35yearsandover clay court tennis championship at the Shelter Rock Club.

title: Elms's Boat, 47 Years Old, Wins in South Bay Race
description: WESTHAMPTON, L. I., July 25Lester Elms of the Mor iches Yacht Club sailed his Shore Bird No. 23 to victory on both elapsed and corrected time today in the annual oldtimers race of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

title: Games Cold Warriors Play
description: In weighing the chances of success for the projected Visit of President Nixon to Peking, it is essential to view his mission in the light of the estab lished American strategy and com mitments in Asia. The situation in that regard is all too clear, given especially the revelations of the Pentagon Papers.

title: Hometowns Here Acclaim Their Stuttgart Dancers
description: For the 11 young American dancers in the Stuttgart Bal let, the German company's second and current tour of the United States has meant a big splash in their own hometowns.

title: Stumble Kills Survivor Of a Plunge of 70 Feet
description: FRESNO, Calif., July 25 (UPI)  A man survived a 70foot plunge over a water fall In Sequoia National Forest but was killed when he stumbled backward and hit his head on a rock, the coroner's office reported to day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Estelle Cohen Remarried
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 25Mrs. Estelle Cohen of New York and Deal, widow of Louis N. Cohen, a textile executive, was married here this noon to Dr. Henry H. Kessler of South Orange in Temple B'Nai Jeshurun by Rabbi Barry Green.

title: Louis, Soviet Journalist, In U.S. for a 30Day Visit
description: WASHINGTON, July 25, (Reuters) Victor Louis; a Soviet journalist said to have good connections in the Krem lin, was reported in the United States today, prompting specu lation he might be on a diplo matic mission for the Soviet government.

title: Treason Trial Goes on in Morocco
description: MARRAKESH, Morocco, July 23  The bloody revolt that nearly toppled the throne of Morocco two weeks ago sent a shortlived surge of hope through the crowded jail beside the criminal court here.

title: Big Board's Block Plan Includes Amex Stocks
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that securities listed on the American Stock Exchange had been included in the Big Board's Block Automation System, an automated net work for communicating in formation on selling big blocks of stock.

title: Rules and Advice for Bicyclists Will Be Issued in City Booklet
description: Prompted by a sharp in crease in the use of bicycles, the City Department of Trans portation is preparing an infor mational folder containing rules and advice for bicyclists.

title: Fairfield Downs Neighbor
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 25Adie Von Gontard 3d, a tall, 18yearold shooter, found the range for eight goals today to lead the Fair field County Hunt Club to a 178 victory over Ox Ridge in the final of the national intracircuit eightgoal cham pionships.

title: Pan Am Cargo Jet Crashes In the Philippines, Killing 4
description: MANILA, Monday, July 26 (AP)The wreckage of a miss ing Pan American Airways jet cargo plane was found today and all four crewmen aboard were dead, the Manila Rescue Coordinating Center reported.

title: GasStation Man Stabbed To Death as He Starts Job
description: A 24yearold service station attendant was found stabbed to death early yesterday out side an allnight gas station in the Bronx. It was his first night on the job.

title: Wahini and Syrinx Win Again as Light Air Stalls 2 Classes in N.Y.Y C. Sail
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 25A fleet of 67 yachts had to battle light air in today's second round of the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise through New England waters. Only 25 boats, all in Classes III and IV, were able to finish.

title: Roundup: Blue Wins 19th, Dobson Bows
description: Vida Blue and Chuck Dob son had won 27 games and lost three between them. That's what Manager Dick Williams of the. Oakland Ath letics served up to the De troit Tigers yesterday and 55,565 fans, one of the larg est, crowds of the major league season, went to Tiger Stadium in Detroit.

title: City Pressing SlumAid Review; May Payon Some Jobs This Week
description: Housing and Development Commissioner Albert A. Walsh said yesterday that he expect ed to resume payments this week to contractors for a few rehabilitation projects under the Municipal Loan Program.

title: Aca, an 8YearOld, Excels in 2 Classes Of Horse Show
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 25Aca, an 8yearold brown gelding owned by Crys Jones of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., ex celed in two divisions today at the concluding session of the second annual Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: U.S. Beats England in Polo Renewal
description: COWDRAY PARK, Eng land, July 25 (AP)Joe Barry scored four goals and Billy Linfoot three today to lead the United States to a 96 victory over England for the Coronation Cup. It was the first international polo match between the countries since 1939.

title: News Analysis
description: MOSCOW, July 25After 10 days of studying the startling turn in ChineseAmerican re lations, the Soviet Union has published in Pravda some in itial, cautious conclusions for its own people, for its allies and for Peking and Washington.

title: ALDEN H. CLARK, A TEXTBOOK AIDE
description: WILTON, Conn., July 25 Alden H. Clark, executive di rector of the Association of American University Presses, died yesterday of cancer in Norwalk Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 82 Catal pa Road.

title: A Frightened Boy Plays HideandSeek With His Searchers in Wilds
description: CASPER, Wyo., July 25For a week now, 9yearold Kevin Dye has been lost, running frightened through the forests and dodging the helping hands that reach for him.

title: Healey Warns of Trade War
description: LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) Denis Healey, Defense Minister in the former Labor Govern ment, warned today of the dangers of a trade war between the United States and the Euro pean Economic Community. Mr. Healey, who has not announced his position on British entry into the Common Market, said in The Sunday Times that the strongest argument for enlarg ing [it] is that Britain could swing the balance of opinion inside the Community against the regional protectionism which has contributed so much in recent years to the danger of a trade war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The following is a list of national loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Miss Kimball Wins Virginia Golf For First Victory in Nine Years
description: WINCHESTER, Va., July 25 (UPI)Judy Kimball ended a nineyear losing streak today when she posted an evenpar 72 to win the $20,000 O'Sul livan women's open golf tour nament by one stroke.

title: A Green Plague Bugs East 23d Street District
description: Mysterious swarming clouds of winged things descended on the East Side around 23d Street yesterday afternoon, pes tering residents of Peter Cooper Village and patients at Bellevue Hospital far into the night.

title: NEW SUPERVISION OF BROKERS ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, July 25A special investigator for a House Commerce subcommittee has concluded that many more re forms are needed in the regula tion of the securities industry if a new wave of bankruptcies of brokerage firms is to be pre vented.

title: Caesars Palace Beckons to the Nobility
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 25 After 72 hours of festivi ties, the score at Caesars Pal ace today was two $100,000 galas and a surprise wedding gown and a plane trip to the Grand Canyon to go, but as William S. Weinberger said, I can't see why anyone would get excited. It's like this every day.

title: New Breed of American Missionaries Bears the Gospel in Many New Ways
description: John Allen is a 43yearold airplane mechanic, and Bap tist layman who heard at a church conference about a need for missionaries and de cided to sign up.

title: Wilhelm Victor as Starter
description: SPOKANE, Wash., July 28 (AP) Hoyt Wilhelm, the 20 year major leaguer, pitched threehit ball for seven innings last night as a starter and picked up his second victory without defeat as Spokane edged Salt Lake, 21, in a Pacific Coast League game. Wilhelm is 47 years old.

title: Fire Sweeps Sumatra Town
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 25 (Reuters)The southern Su matra town of Pagar Alam was almost wiped out by a fire that destroyed 992 homes and stores, the Antara news agency reported today. There were no reports of casualties.

title: STEEL BACKLOGS REDUCING ORDERS
description: PITTSBURGH, July 25If the steel union does not strike Aug. 1, many users will.

title: VAST REPRESSION OF NEGRO FEARED
description: DETROIT, July 25The act ing executive director of the National Urban League said to day the greatest danger fac ing blacks in the United States was the possibility of massive repression by a general society frustrated over national and in ternational failures.

title: Australian Aborigine Leader Sees HomeGrown Racism
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 25 (Reuters)An aborigine leader has attacked what he termed the homegrown racism of several Australian state gov ernments.

title: Papal Document Expected To Raise Age of Confirmation
description: ROME, July 25 (UPI)Pope Paul  announced today, that he would soon issue a new document on the sacrament of confirmation. Vatican sources said it would increase the age at which children are brought into the full life of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: SHARP RISE URGED IN HEALTH FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 An amendment to be offered Tuesday in the House of Rep resentatives asks for a sharp increase in a health, education, welfare and labor appropria tions bill that already goes sub stantially beyond the Adminis tration's budget requests.

title: Thoughts on Society:
description: BELGRADE  The word conver gence has become fashionable. Since 1968 when the wellknown theses of Soviet academician Sakharov ap peared, polemics about the conver gence of the two systems have not ceased.

title: YANKS TAKE PAIR, REACH .500 LEVEL
description: MILWAUKEE, July 25Most teams gain their excitement from their proximity to first place, but the Yankees have to settle for lesser thrills.

title: Palmer Wins Westchester Golf By 5 Shots With a 68 for 270
description: HARRISON, N.Y., July 25 Arnold Palmer posted a record winning score of 270 in the Westchester Golf Classic today and said, a little rest and a lot of good putting contributed to his fivestroke victory.

title: Books of The Times
description: STORIES AND PROSE POEMS. By Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. Translated by Michael Glenny. 267 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $7.95.

title: Hussein's Precarious Victory
description: King Hussein's victory over, the remaining Palestinian guerrilla strongholds in Jordan could have been achieved only in the context of continuing hope among important segments of Arab opinion for a peaceful settlement of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

title: Baldwin Trophy Winner In Wet Pants Sail Series
description: SAYVILLE, L. L., July 25 Gorton Baldwin, in Firewater, utilized a first and a second to capture the Asa B. Smith Trophy today as the leading Narrasketuck in the annual in vitation regatta of the Wet Pants Association.

title: Princeton Library Gets Documents on Rossetti
description: PRINCETON, N. J., July. 25  A collection of about 3,300 documents relating to the family of Dante Gabriel Rossetti and other leading figures in the 19thcentury preRaphaelite literary move ment has been acquired by Princeton University, Dr. William Dix, the university librarian, announced today.

title: The Proceedings In the Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Apar theid  10:30 A.M.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising:
description: Patch is back. Onofio Paccione, the temperamental and talented art director, who left Leber, Katz, Paccione last September, has bought into Robert E. Launey Advertising.

title: MEDINA FACES TRIAL TODAY IN 102 DEATHS
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., July 25 (UPI)  Capt. Ernest L. Medina goes on trial tomorrow charged with murdering 102 persons when soldiers under his command swept through the village of Mylai in March, 1968.

title: Ali and Ellis to Spar for Keeps Tonight
description: HOUSTON, July 25With out a prediction and without his usual flair, Muhammad Ali will oppose Jimmy Ellis tomorrow night at the Astro dome in a 12round bout containing more mystery than mystique.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Ellen Rosenbaum Married in Jersey
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 25Miss Ellen Terry Rosenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Rosen baum of West Orange, was married here today to James N. Ellowitch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon H. Ellowitch of Springfield. Rabbi Charles Annes performed the cere mony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Feller, grand parents of the bride.

title: Lubash Gets 7 Goals
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., July 25 Bob Lubash tallied a sea son high of seven goals in leading Brookville to a 10 3 triumph over Oyster Bay today in the opening match of the Rothman invitation tournament at Bethpage State Park.

title: Donor Awaited Several Days
description: CAPETOWN, July 25 (Reu ters)Mr. Herbert waited on standby for a donor for sev eral days, hospital sources said.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANAGRAMS. By David R. Slavitt. 335 pages. Doubleday. $6.95.

title: Mrs. Penelope Kramer Married
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., July 25 The marriage of Mrs. Penelope Kramer to Larry Kent Starkey took place here this evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Elihu Schott, parents of the bride. The Rev. Bonnie L. Jones of the United Methodist Church in Amity ville, L. I., performed the ceremony, which was attend ed only by members of the immediate families and a few close friends.

title: Soviet Aide's Auto Is Hit by Fire Bomb At Far Rockaway
description: An auto belonging to an attach of the Soviet delega tion to the United Nations was firebombed and slightly dam aged early yesterday morning outside the cottage used by the Soviet staff at 127 Beach 27th Street, Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: AIRMAN IN BANGKOK HELD ON SPY CHARGE
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 25 (AP)A United States Embassy spokesman disclosed that an Air Force sergeant had been ar rested in Bangkok on charges that he had conspired to com mit espionage with the Soviet Union.

title: STEPHEN J. MORAN, 53 YEARS AT TIMES
description: Stephen J. Moran, super visor of copyboys and news assistants at The New York Times, died yesterday in Deep dale Hospital, Queens, after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 20924 Hillside Avenue, Queens Village.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Can a poor, goodhearted ItalianAmerican boy from Brooklyn find true love and happiness as a member of one of the American Midwest's most aristocratic families, the Chicago Cubs?

title: Beirut Picks Military Chief
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 (AP)Brig. Gen. Iskandar Gha nem was appointed today Com mander in Chief of the Lebanese armed forces. He succeeded Maj. Gen. Jean Njaim, who was killed in a helicopter crash yes terday. An extraordinary Cabi net meeting called by President Suleiman Franjieh decided to recall General Ghanem to duty and raised his rank to major general. He had retired recently.

title: Hamilton Earns World Title In Windmill Class Sailing
description: BELLPORT, L. I., July 25  Pat Hamilton of Miami, the 1968 national champion, added the Windmill Class interna tional title today, outpointing 42 other skippers.

title: Social Goals Called Costly to Taxpayer
description: The average American tax payer will have to pay $300 more each year if the United States in the nineteenseventies is to make social improvements on a scale frequently proposed by those advocating a reor dering of national priorities, according to a New York Uni versity economist.

title: Chess: West Germans and British Meet in Team Competition
description: One type of chess event popular in Europe is the kind of team match that pits one country against another on a fairly large number of boards, usually 10 to 20. Several such matchesthe one between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia, for example, or the one between Britain and the Netherlands  are played annually and attract considerable attention.

title: KY, CAMPAIGNING, HINTS HE'LL QUIT
description: GIAKIEM, South Vietnam, July 25Vice President Ngu yeo Cao Ky held out the pos sibility today of dropping out of the race for the presidency in a deal with Gen. Duong Van Minh, a possible candidate.

title: California County Fair Reflects Both Continuity of Farm Life and Changing Times
description: RED BLUFF, Calif., July 25 Mrs. Jock Roney deftly dipped her spoon into a jar of homemade boysenberry jam, tasted thoughtfully for a few seconds, and went on to the next one. After 14 jars she wrote down her choices, took a sip of tea and started on the blackberry preserves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fillol Tanglewood Victor, Beating Richey, Franulovic
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., July 25 (AP)Jaime Fillol of Chile beat Cliff Richey of Sarasota, Fla., and Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia in that order to capture the $25,000 Tanglewood international tennis tournament today.

title: Flush Toilet a Growing Concern for Environmentalists
description: The flush toilet has been stirring increasing concern be cause of the damage it has done and is continuing to do to the environment.

title: Sadat Development Plan Aims for A New Man
description: CAIRO, July 25President Anwar elSadat has drafted a 10year program to stimulate economic and social develop ment aimed at creating a new man in Egypt.

title: Credit Market Holds Own;
description: Bond prices declined late last week, largely in response to the Government's report that the Consumer Price Index had climbed sharply in June.

title: Michael O'Sullivan, 37, Dies; Actor Had Roles on Broadway
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (UPI)Michael O'Sullivan, who appeared in stage plays in Lon don and New York, was found dead in his home yesterday. His age was 37.

title: Quake Hits Pacific Isle
description: RABAUL, New Britain, Mon day, July 26 (Reuters)  An earthquake and three tidal waves struck Rabaul today, bringing chaos and panic to the town's already uneasy popula tion. Several persons were be lieved to have been injured on this island, which is in the Pa cific Ocean off the east coast of New Guinea. Three tidal waves swept into Rabaul's main street, flooding shops and hotels. Several cars were swept into the sea.

title: Unit Shifted to Coast
description: CLEVELAND July 25 (AP) The Republic Steel Corporation's manufacturing division is mov ing its Western division from Chicago to Los Angeles to take advantage of the West Coast market.

title: Vapors in Vineyards
description: Taking off from Rome's appropri ately named Da Vinci Airport, one imagines that the great Leonardo would have poured all his genius into art, leaving mechanical wonders to his inferiors, could he have foreseen what machinery would one day do to his lovely land. The beauty is still there in the vineyards, the medieval towns perched on the Tuscan hills, the perspectives of Venice, the richness of Florence, the Homeric rocks erupting out of the waters around Capri. It is all there but somehow compromised by the industrial surge that in a single generation has turned Goethe's Land wo die Citronen blhn into one of the world's leading refiners of oil and producers of steel.

title: June Shipments Up 4.8% For Noncelluosic Fibers
description: Fiber producers shipped a to tal 366.9 million pounds of non celluosic yarn and fiber in June, an increase of 4.8 per cent over the corresponding month in 1970, it was announced yester day by the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., statistical organi zation for the industry.

title: Agnew Congratulates Hassan on His Courage
description: SOTOGRANDE, Spain, July 25Vice President Agnew said on his departure from Morocco today that he had congratulated King Hassan  on behalf of President Nixon and himself for the King's courage during the at tempted coup against him on July 10. The King's life was threatened during the attack on his seaside Skhirat sum mer palace, when 97 guests at his birthday reception were killed and 130 wounded.

title: Cohen in Garden Debut Against Griffith Tonight
description: Nessim (Max) Cohen, the middleweight champion of France, makes his Madison Square Garden debut tonight in a 10round bout against Emile Griffith, who has held the middleweight and welter weight titles.

title: Peasants Flocking to Acapulco For Work Find Mostly Misery
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, July 14 Thousands of peasants trek king to this Pacific coast re sort each year in search of employment and a better life are bringing with them serious social problems that Acapulco is illequipped to handle.

title: SusanJane Finkel Is Bride in Jersey
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 25  Miss SusanJane Finkel, daughter of Mrs. Emanuel B. Finkel of Livingston and the late Mr. Finkel, was married here this noon to Jerome Lawrence Merin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Merin of Elizabeth.

title: Tax Aid for Blood Donors
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) Legislation that would allow tax deductions for individuals donating blood will be intro duced tomorrow by Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. His bill would pro vide a $20 deduction for each donation, with a $60 annual ceiling.

title: BATHER MISSING AT JONES BEACH
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 25A 19yearold Manhattan youth was missing and presumed drowned in treacherous surf at Jones Beach this afternoon. The drowning would be the fourth this year at the beaches run by the Long Island Park Commission, where lifeguards have been on strike since the season opened.

title: Embassy in Saigon Calls Babies of G.I's A Serious Concern
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The United States Embassy in Sai gon has informed the State De partment that responsibility for Americanfathered illegiti mate children in South Viet nam has become a matter of serious and continuing con cern.

title: Vending Industry Is Widening Its Horizons
description: The vending industry, which grew 9.5 per cent last year to an estimated $8.5 billion in food sales, has come a long way from being the mere provider of cigarettes and chewing gum it once was.

title: Philip Morris, Inc., Set a Profit Record In Second Quarter
description: Record sales and earnings in both the second quarter and the first six months of 1971 were reported yesterday by Philip Morris, Inc.

title: 3 Men Are Wounded By Gunfire in Brooklyn
description: Three men were wounded late last night in a quarrel on Throop Avenue in the BedfordStuyve sant section of Brooklyn.

title: New President Is Named For Economic Unit in Canada
description: OTTAWA, July 25 Arthur J. R. Smith, chairman of the Economic Council of Canada since 1967, has been named president of the Conference Board in Canada, a New York based economic research or ganization supported by busi ness concerns, labor unions, academic institutions and gov ernment agencies.

title: Man in the News
description: VIENNA, July 25  When the 27th congress of the In ternational Psychoanalytic Association opens here to morrow, Dr. Leo Rangell, a genial, gregarious New Yorker turned Californian Who has been its president for two years, will preside.

title: Urban Coalition Names ExProfessor as Head
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP)M. Carl Homan, vice president of the National Urban Coalition, was named today to succeed Jack H. Vaughn as president of the organization.

title: Staten Island Cricket Victor
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club defeated St. Vincent's C.C. by 117 runs yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island. The scores: Staten Island 170 for 6, St. Vincent's 53.

title: APOLL0 15 POISED FOR MOON LIFTOFF AT 9:34 A.M. TODAY
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 25The Apollo 15 astronauts and their complex moonland ing machinery were declared ready to go tonight for the scheduled launching tomorrow morning of the 12day expedi tion to the foot of the rugged lunar Apennine Mountains.

title: Robbers Paralyze French Student Here
description: What was to have been a onenight stay in the city be came, for a 24yearold ex change student from France, a time of terror during which he was robbed and shot in the neck by two men.

title: Mackinac Races Test Mettle of Landlockecl Sailors
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 25Long Island Sound is just as smooth as a millpond compared to Lake Michigan, scoffed a Chicago advertising executive the other night over a glass of whisky at the Pink Pony Lounge here. I've seen rougher seas in Kansas.

title: INCOMES POLICY URGED BY ACKLEY
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 Gardner Ackley, a former chair man of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, proposed today a fourpart incomes pol icy to check inflation in the United States, including perma nent standby authority for the President to impose compulsory wage and price controls.

title: Head Start Is Improving the Lives of Many Mothers, Too
description: Head Start's work among preschool children of low income or noincome families has often been hailed. But the effect that the program is having on the children's mothers has received little attention. Yet it is almost as dramatic.

title: Snead Defies Time With Blazing Finish
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 25 Mike Souchak, another star golfer, once said that Sam Snead would still be winning tournaments when he was 60 years old. The next year will tell if that prediction comes true.

title: Laura Pakter And Engineer Are Wed Here
description: Miss Laura Pakter, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Pakter of New York, was married here yesterday noon to Cristian Fernandez, son of Mr. and Mrs. Amaro Fernan dez of Buenos Aires. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Dr. Clarence H. Graham Dead; Taught Psychology at Columbia
description: Professor Possessed National Name as Expert on Visual Sensation and Perception

title: HUSSEIN MEETING FAISAL IN JIDDA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 King Hussein of Jordan flew to Saudi Arabia today for talks with King Faisal on Jordanian conditions and the general Arab situation.

title: Weatherly Leads in Mackinac Race
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 25 (UPI)Weatherly, pac ing a fleet of 215 racing yachts into the final stretch of the Bayview Yacht Club's 47th Port HurontoMackinac race, was expected to be the first across the finish line tonight.

title: Undermining the Budget
description: Senate and House conferees, completing a bill to expand the lending authority of the ExportImport Bank, have agreed to permit the bank to supply credits for shipping American goods to Communist countries includ ing China. President Nixon would, however, retain the power to decide whether to let the bank make particular loans to Communist countries.

title: The Monorail Crashes In Seattle, Injuring 16
description: SEATTLE, July 25 (AP) At least 16 persons were in jured tonight when the Mono rall crashed into a steel gir der at its Seattle Center terminal.

title: Faulty Jet Radar System Linked to MidAir Collision
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (Reu ters)  A Phantom jet had a faulty radar system when it collided with an airliner near Los Angeles last June 6, killing 50 persons, a report said today.

title: Connally Hints Nixon May Be His '72 Choice
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)Secretary of the Trea sury John B. Connally Jr. left open the possibility to day that he might support President Nixon in next year's election.

title: Nixon Cans Astronauts; Wishes Them Godspeed
description: THURMONT, Md., July 25 (AP)  President Nixon, who plans to watch the Apollo 15 liftoff tomorrow morning on television from his mountain retreat here at Camp David, telephoned the three astro nauts today to wish them godspeed.

title: Expos Deactivate Mashore
description: MONTREAL, July 25 (AP) The Montreal Expos placed Clyde Mashore, outfielder, on the 21day disabled list today for minor surgery to remove a bone spur in his left thumb. Mashore's place will be taken by Jim Briton, a pitcher.

title: NIXON AIDE FINDS RAIL ACCORD NEAR AS TALKS ADVANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Monday, July 26The Nixon Administra tion's chief troubleshooter in the national railroad labor talks held out hope yesterday of an imminent solution to the dis pute that has already shut down four major railroads and threatens to halt 11 more in the next two weeks.

title: Better Smile Takes Title At Old Westbury Show
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 25StaStill Farms's Better Smile, ridden by Mrs. Sarah Steall, captured one class and finished second and fourth in two others today to score 9 points and win the green work ing hunter championship of the Old Westbury Horse Show.

title: Columbus, Ga., Mayor Asks People to Keep Off Streets
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., July 25 (UPI)Mayor J. R. Allen, warn ing that stricter measures could follow, called upon the public tonight to stay off the streets to prevent further racial vio lence.

title: Archbishop Sheen Preaches at Marble Church
description: More than 3,000 worshipers yesterday crowded into Marble Collegiate Church on a hot, muggy day to see and hear Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, the first Roman Catholic priest to preach there at a regular serv ice of worship.

title: Decline of Black Farmers Found; Report Blames Federal Policies
description: ATLANTA, July 25  The number of farms operated by Negroes in the United States has decreased in the last two decades from more than half a million to fewer than 100, 000, a report by the National Sharecroppers Fund said today.

title: Mathay, Belgian Auto Driver, Is Killed in 24Hour Race at Francorchamps
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 25 (UPI)A Ford Capri came through today to win the 24hour Francorchamps tourism car race that was marred by the fatal crash of a Belgian driver, Raymond Mathay.

title: DR. VITO SALERNO, ENGINEER, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Vito L. Salerno, presi dent of Applied Technology Associates, Inc., an engineer ing research concern in Ram sey, N. J., who was dean of the College of Science and En gineering of Fairleigh Dickin son University from 1958 to 1962, died Saturday of a heart attack in Pelham Bay General Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 2430 Laconia Ave nue, the Bronx.

title: SIR WILLIAM TROTT
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 25 (Reuters)  Sir William James Howard Trott, one of this British colony's most re spected former statesmen, died at his home here today. He was 88 years old.

title: A Transfer of Polish Workers To East Germany Is Arranged
description: WARSAW, July 25An or ganized transfer of labor from Poland to East Germany is about to begin under a pro tocol of cooperation signed recently by the two Govern ments. It is believed to be the first such arrangement in East ern Europe.

title: Russians Silent on Flight
description: MOSCOW, July 25 (AP) Most Russians did not know tonight that America's most ambitious lunar flight begins tomorrow. As with their own space ventures, the Soviet au thorities have kept all advance word of the Apollo 15 mission out of the controlled press. The few Russians who knew about it obtained the news from broadcasts by the Voice of America of the British Broad casting Corporation.

title: 27 ARE APPOINTED TO JUSTICE PANEL
description: The names, of the 27 per sons judges, lawyers, public officials and others  who will serve on an advisory com mittee for a oneyear study of juvenile justice to be coordin ated by the Institute of Judi cial Administration were made public yesterday.

title: They're Farming Catfish by the Acre, but Supply Is Still Short
description: DUMAS, Ark.  On top of all its other troubles, New York is outside the catfish belt.

title: Now, About My Operation in Peking
description: PEKING, July 25There is something a little absurd about a man publishing an obituary notice on his own appendix, but for the last 10 days this correspondent has had a chance to learn a lit tle about the professional and political direction of a major Chinese hospital from the in side, and this is a report on how I got there and what found.

title: Israeli Cabinet Reaffirms Unity On Eve of Visit by U.S. Official
description: JERUSALEM, July 25Is rael's 18member Cabinet reaf firmed its solidarity today on the country's negotiating posi tion toward the Arab nations in preparation for a visit this week by Joseph J. Sisco, the United States Assistant Secre tary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs.

title: GREAT PYRENEES IS BEST IN SHOW
Bridge: Spingold QuarterFinals Find New York Well Represented
description: CHICAGO, July 25  The Spingold knockout team championship quarterfinals began here this afternoon with New York represented on all but one of the sur viving teams.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Talk of Christopher Street
description: It began life before the Revolution as the bosky Skinner Road, running east through the Warren Farm from the little riverbank set tlement of Upper Gkeenwich. For a century it was the main street of what Was then called. a forgotten back water and is now Green wich Village.
