To day's Christopher Street, running between the Ave nue of the Amer icas and the Hud son, is called the birthplace of the Gay Liberation move meat, a paradise for cruising.

title: Cars Tested for Monoxide In Drive for Cleaner Air
description: A preliminary analysis of the breath power of 249 automo biles in the Bronx showed that nearly half of them emit quan tities of carbon monoxide detri mental to health.

title: Town Hall Recitals Offer Jazz From Ragtime to AvantGarde
description: Jazz piano styles ranging from the ragtime era to the contemporary avant  garde were heard at Town Hall on Saturday evening as an un usual array of pianists passed across the stage. They included Eubie Blake, Robert Greene, Teddy Wilson, Billy Taylor, Bill Evans and Cecil Taylor. The occasion was the third in Town Hall's weekly con noisseur Jazz Series.

title: Sudan Rejects British Plea
description: CAIRO, July 25Premier Nimeiry of the Sudan today rejected a British plea for clemency for two rebel leaders seized from a Britisn airliner in Libya last week.

title: Mrs. King Doubles Victor
description: KITZBUEHEL, Austria, July 25 (Reuters)Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals of California won the women's doubles title and a new com bination of Clark Graebner of New York and Ion Tiriac of Rumania captured the men's crown in the Austrian open tennis championships today.

title: News Analysis
description: The scheduled live color tele cast from Apollo 15, including the first scenes of a takeoff shot from the surface of the moon, brings to an ironic climax one of the epic battles of tele vision.

title: Camper Killed by Bear
description: GRAND LAKE, Colo., July 25 (AP)  A Denver man was at tacked and killed by a black bear this morning at a campsite near Grand Lake. He was iden tified as John H. Richardson, 31 years old.

title: Orders for Machine Tools Grew. 22.8% During June
description: New orders for American machine tools, an important indicator of the future capital spending plans of industry, rose in June by 22.8 per cent, compared with bookings in May.

title: Hot Grounder Hurts Santo
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) Ron Santo, the Chicago Cubs' third baseman, left today's game with the Philadelphia Phillies after he was struck on the back of the right hand by a hard ground ball hit by Don Money in the seventh inning. He will be Xrayed in Montreal tomorrow.

title: Shop Talk'
description: The name  Juicy Miss Lucy'slooks a little incon gruous on the patchworkquilt banner outside 316 East 49th Street. The shop, with its pastelpainted railing and its wicker plant stand, looks as trim as the white lace curtain that screens off a small win dow crowded with greenery. furniture, a flowery rug and white walls with a dado of painted hollyhocks. There is no Miss Lucy, of course. The shopkeeper is a blonde in her 20's with a tousled hairdo, who usually dresses in jeans. Carene Beatty explained that the name comes from a nineteenfifties song and that she and her partner, Lisa Price, chose it just for fun. Miss Price, daughter of the late Georgie Price, the vau devillian, is the business manager and is currently in London shopping for fabrics she has very good taste, Miss Beatty said.

title: METS WIN 3D GAME IN LAST 4, BARELY
description: Try as they might, the New York Mets could not add yes terday's game at Shea Stadium to their list of recent disasters. They won it, 76, despite a dazzling assortment of late inning attempts to foist it on the Houston Astros.

title: 5 GUERRILLAS KILLED IN GAZA, ISRAELIS SAY
description: TEL AVIV, July 25Five armed Palestinian guerrillas who entrenched themselves last night in a girls' school in Gaza were killed today after a battle of several hours with Israeli forces, an official statement here said.

title: Oil Spill Closes Two Beaches
description: ATLANTIC BEACH, L. I., July 25The beach here and at neighboring Long Beach were closed for several hours this morning while workers cleaned up an oil slick, believed by the Coast Guard to be the result of bilge pumping by some passing tanker.

title: Lowenstein's New Cause: Young Voters
description: WASHINGTON, July 25  Allard K. Lowenstein special izes in turning what most peo ple consider lost causes into winners or very close things.

title: Humphrey Is Critical
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI)  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Min nesota, said today that President Nixon's program to fight drug abuse was not moving fast enough or effectively enough to solve the problem.

title: At ThaiBurmese Border, Opium Eases Way for Petty Smugglers
description: TACHILEK, Burma, July 23The border officer smiled at the happy clickclack as two wooden balls, dangling on the ends of a string he held, knocked against each other.

title: Eurobond Prices Decline
description: BRUSSELS, July 25Inter national bond prices declined last week as renewed specula tion on the future of the West German mark, and, to some degree, the French franc, have shaken loose some sell orders. But the price decline has done nothing to impede the steady flow of new issues.

title: 50 VIETCONG ATTACK HAMLET IN THE DELTA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (AP)About 50 Vietcong soldiers slipped into a Mekong Delta hamlet today and at tacked sleeping villagers with hand grenades and rifle fire.

title: 275 Continue Hunt for Boy Lost in Mountains 15 Days
description: NEWCOMB, N.Y., July 25 About 275 people, including 40 Green Berets, members of the Army's Special Forces, and 34 rangers from the New York State Conservation Department, continued to search today for 8 yearold Douglas Legg, who disappeared on a walk into the Adirondack Mountain forest near here 15 days ago.

title: Envoy to U.S. Says Taiwan Will Not Share a Seat in the U.N. With Peking Under Any Circumstances
description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Chinese Nationalist Ambassador to the United States, James C. H. Shen, said today that his country could not under any circumstances share a seat in the United Nations with Com munist China.

title: 3 Blazes Laid to Fire Bombs
description: WOBURN, Mass., July 25 (AP)Three fires, all of them ignited by fire bombs, leveled the 300footlong warehouse and slightly damaged a church and a store early today, the authorities said.

title: In Memory of Louis E. Austin
description: DURHAM, N. C.For all practical purposes and reasons meaningful to his existence, Louis E. Austin was born in 1927. That was the year, with a $250 loan, he bought The Caro lina Times newspaper. It was the only black newspaper in Durham, North Carolina and, at that time, one of two in the immediate area.

title: Notes on People
description: The most crushing con sideration in his decision not to seek the 1972 Presiden tial nomination, said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was the possibility of an assassina tion attempt.

title: RCA COMPUTER BASE IS SET UP IN LONDON
description: The RCA Corporation, the only major American computer manufacturer without an inde pendent marketing organiza tion in Europe, announced yes terday the establishment of a major electronic data process ing sales, management and technical operation in England.

title: BON VIVANT FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: NEWARK, July 26 (AP) Bon Vivant, Inc., whose entire line of canned food was re called by the Federal Food and Drug Administration, filed to day for bankruptcy.

title: Griffith Posts Lopsided Victory Over Cohen in 10 Rounds Here
description: Emile Griffith, as agile, dura ble and knowledgeable as ever after 14 years of professional boxing, spoiled the Madison Square Garden debut of Nessim (Max) Cohen of Paris last night before 13,500 fans.

title: Foreign Aid Improved
description: The $3.4billion foreign aid bill approved by the House Foreign Affairs Committee last week is inadequate and unbalanced but it is still an improvement over aid pro posals belatedly submitted by the Administration in April.

title: Piping Rock Pair Win in Golf
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., July 26 Mrs. Thorne Dempsey and Mrs. F. K. Thayer Jr. of Piping Rock scored 37, 3875 to .win the Women's CrossCounty Golf Association's 36hole bet ter ball or partner's champion ship at the Sands Point club today. Mrs. Dempsey and Mrs. Thayer bested Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of the Creek and Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedar Brook, who had 39, 3978 over the 5,630 yard par 36, 3672 course.

title: CHARLES SCHLESINGER
description: Charles Schlesinger, president of Penrose Knitwear, died yes terday in his home at 220 Madi son Avenue after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Theater: Anne Baxter
description: Remember that scene in All About Eve when Anne Baxter, as mousy Eve Har rington, swept up Bette DavisMargo Channing's cos tume, held it in front of her and bowed to her asyet nonexistent audience? It was at that instant that Eve showed her mettleand soon she was sweeping up every thing from Margo: her men, her roles. Now she has even stolen her Applause.

title: LOAN FUND ACTION URGED BY GARELIK
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik called on the chairmen of the Council's Fi nance and Housing Committees yesterday to take a good hard look at the city's Municipal Loan Fund.

title: RollCall Vote in Senate On Lockheed Closure
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)Following is the roll call by which the Senate refused today to invoke closure on a bill to provide Federal loan guarantees for the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration and other financially troubled corporations:

title: Rally to Honor Mills
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) A $5  a  head appreciation rally, with hot dogs and soft drinks is planned in Little Rock on Aug. 26 for Representative Wilbur D. Mills. Aides of the Arkansas Democrat said today that about 50 Congressmen were expected to attend. The aides expect a crowd of 25,000 at the rally.

title: Twins Top Red Sox, 21
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 26 (UPI)A basesloaded sac rifice fly with one out in the ninth inning by Jim Holt scored Rich Reese to give the Minne sota Twins a 21 victory to night over the Boston Red Sox.

title: POLICEMAN'S KILLING IS DENIED BY NEWTON
description: OAKLAND, Calif., July 26 (AP)Huey P. Newton, a Black Panther party, cofounder, took the witness stand today, as the defense opened its case, to deny that he had killed an Oak land policeman, John Frey.

title: $10MILLION GIVEN TO AID ALCOHOLICS
description: Roosevelt Hospital has re ceived a gift of $10million for the treatment and rehabilita tion of alcoholics, H. Whitfield Carhart; the president of the West Side institution, an nounced yesterday.

title: Peace Is the One Cause
description: SAIGONI would like to take this opportunity to present some of my basic ideas on the problem of peace, which is by far the most important problem facing our nation today.

title: Men in News
description: Ask David Randolph Scott why we are going back to the moon and his boyish face flushes with excitement as he describes the new and improved features of this trip.

title: News Analysis
description: NEW DELHI, July 26 There's no place to go but up, said one proAmerican Indian the other day, referring to the depths into which relations be tween India and the United States have recently plunged.

title: Marketplace: Martin's Draft Of Report Ready
description: William McChesney Martin Jr. has completed a draft of his heralded report on the securities industry. He turned It over yesterday to the com mittee of Wall Street leaders who had advised him on it.

title: Charles Poore, Book Reviewer For The Times Till '69, Dies
description: Charles Poore, who reviewed books for The New York Times for nearly 40 years, died of heart failure yesterday at his home, at 210 West 69th Street, Mr. Poore, who retired from The Times in 1969, was 68 years old.

title: Mets Beaten by Cards, 40, As Gibson Hurls 5Hitter
description: Bob Gibson, a pitcher who can be described as being in a class by himself in several respects, established that status in another category last night by beating the New York Mets, 40, for the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium.

title: U.S. Negroes in Moscow Offer Plan for Jews' Exit
description: MOSCOW, July 26 (UPI) A group of American Negroes touring the Soviet Union said today that they had urged So viet officials to let Jews leave on the condition that they did not go to Israel for two years.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF BY 3.1% LAST WEEK
description: Steel production continued its sharp downward trend last week, falling 3.1 per cent be low output the week before. The extremely low operating rate was attributed mainly to market weakness.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Rise at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Civilian Observers Ride Prowl Cars in City Test
description: An electrical engineer, a doorman, a receptionist, a housewife and a halfdozen other civilians turned out with the radio car patrolmen of the 24th Precinct last night and cruised the Upper West Side for two hours of watching their escorts in action.

title: MRS. BACKER DIES; SOCIETY FIGURE
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., July 26 Mrs. George Backer, an in ternational hostess well known in the. worlds of society, poli tics and the arts, and a suc cessful interior decorator, died at her home here tonight after a long illness. She was 64 years old.

title: Lord GeorgeBrovvn Attacks Wilson on the Market
description: LONDON, July 26  Lord GeorgeBrown, who served as Foreign Secretary when Harold Wilson was Prime Minister, said today that Mr. Wilson is bound in honor to accept the negotiated terms for British en try into the European Common Market unless he never meant the exercise seriously in the first place.

title: A Census Report
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Following a decade of sub stantial gains, black people in America in 1970 remained far behind whites in most social and economic areas, a Govern ment report revealed today.

title: Will the Words Go: To the Women Down at Mory's?
description: NEW HAVEN, July 26 Women have liberated Yale, but they have not yet lib erated Mory's, the tavern that puts so much of the ale into Yale.

title: Thursday Matinees Planned
description: The Me Nobody Knows, the Jeff Britton musical pro duction, has scheduled Thurs day matinees starting Sept. 16 at the Helen Hayes Theater. The Thursday night perform ance will be eliminated. In ad dition, the show will give matinees on Wednesday, Sat urday and Sunday.

title: GATEWAY PROJECT GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Senate Interior Committee unanimously approved today the establishment of an ex panded Gateway National Rec reation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor.

title: Fulbright Will Seek Voice on the Funds Of State Department
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that he would propose that the State Department be required to obtain an annual legislative authorization for its appropriations that would be passed upon by the Senate Foreign Relations and House Foreign Affairs Committees.

title: HEAVY RAINS HERE CAUSE PROBLEMS
description: A blackout in Queens, a tele phone failure in and around Bellevue Hospital, hazardous driving and airtraffic delays were the by products of a thunderstorm here yesterday morning that dumped nearly half an inch of rain in 45 min utes.

title: SADAT IS GRANTED A WIDE MANDATE
description: CAIRO, July 26President Anwar elSadat asked Egypt's political organization tonight for full powers for any ac tion he deemed fit against Israel to recover the territories occupied in the sixday war of, 1967.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN CHICAGO GRAINS
description: Wheat closed mixed, corn higher, oats fractionally higher and soybeans substantially low er on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Launching Screens Robbery
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI)Three gunmen, waiting until most persons present were watching the launching of the Apollo 15, held up the cashier's office at Lankeanau Hospital today and escaped with about $1,000. The hospital is in the Philadelphia suburb of Lowe Merion, Pa.

title: Thoughts on Society: II
description: BELGRADEWhat to do? How to live? In what to believe? Is there the smallest hope that in our confused time there is a real answer to these questions?

title: United Nations of the Moon
description: Apollo 15 blasted off on schedule yesterday for what is planned to be the most scientifically productive manned trip to the moon that has yet been made. Only two years have passed since Neil Armstrong first set foot on the lunar surface, but already the historic accom plishments of the Apollo 11 crew begin to look as though they belonged to the ModelT era of moon exploration.

title: RAIL TALKS FAIL; NIXON AIDES WEIGH PLEA TO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Negotiations between the na tion's railroads and the strik ing United Transportation Union collapsed today, with no settlement in sight.

title: WITTER PLANNING PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Dean Witter & Co., Inc., topranking brokerage house and the largest based on the West Coast, announced yester day preliminary plans to sell its stock to the public.

title: McMillan Sets Back Alexander In Tennis at Quebec, 75, 76
description: QUEBEC, July 26 (Canadian Press)A grueling, twohour match between John Alexander of Australia and Frew McMillan of South Africa highlighted the firstround singles play today at the Quebec international tennis open.

title: Grain and Coal Hard Hit By Expanding Rail TieUp
description: The effects of the railroad strike were felt most sharply yesterday by the grain and coal industries, poultry pro ducers, manufacturers of grain products, steel mills and plants making automobiles. plants making automobiles.

title: Racial Tensions in Columbus, Ga., Bring City to the Brink of Schizophrenia
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., July 26 Lingering racial tensions, deep ly embedded in its collective personality, have brought this troubled city to a state of near schizophrenia.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WALDWICK, N. J., July 26 Bill Scarlett of Millburn, N. J., the fifthseeded player, defeated thirdranked Al Doyle of New York, 61, 63, today in the final of the New Jersey State men's 35 years and over tennis cham pionship at the Waldwick cov ered courts.

title: Economic Analysis
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25 Housing has been one of the few segments of the economy to cheer the Nixon Administra tion as it looks for signs that the recession is waning. Indeed, housing starts showed surpris ing strength last year and have continued strong so far this year. The latest statistics re leased last week recorded another increase in hous ing starts across the nation in June to an annual rate of 1,982,000 units. That was up 1.2 per cent from the preced ing month and compared with an annual rate of 1,393,000 in June, 1970.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MONTAUK, L. I., July 26 Montauk charter boat cap tains specializing in bringing big billfsh to gaff are sud denly finding themselves with mates convinced they have just cause to write to Con gress over the local bluefish dilemma.

title: Books of The Times
description: NEW AMERICAN REVIEW #12. Edited by Theodore Solotaroff. Simon & Schuster. Pa perback. 252 pages. $1.95.

title: Rebels Tell East Pakistanis to Flee Dacca
description: DACCA, Pakistan, July 26 Handbills prepared by Bengali separatist guerrillas appeared in Dacca today warning the population to begin evacuation of the city in preparation for a terrorist campaign against the Pakistani Army in East Pakis tan.

title: CHINESE AIDE HOPES FOR 180 TURN BY U.S.
description: PEKING, July 26Kuo Mojo, a highranking official, said yesterday that if President Nixon was sincere in his desire for improved relations with China, he would have to ac cept the Chinese position on a number of key issues, includ ing Taiwan.

title: Bonn Denounces German Reds, Calls Killing at Wallan Outrage
description: BONN, July 26The West German Government officially expressed outrage today over Communist border guards' kill ing of an East German who tried to escape Saturday night from East to West Berlin across the wall.

title: Austrians, at Last, Pay Lavish Tribute to Freud
description: VIENNA, July 26Sigmund Freud today received the Aus trian and Viennese acclaim de nied him in his lifetime as the 27th congress of the Interna tional Psychoanalytical Associa tion opened in a former im perial reception hall, in the presence of his 75yearold daughter, Anna.

title: Peking Reported Interested In Contacts With Israelis
description: PARIS, July 26Communist China has expressed interest in establishing some contacts with Israel, according to a reliable report of a conversation that was held here Saturday be tween a member of the Chinese Embassy and a leftwing mem ber of the Israeli Government coalition.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Democratic party's reform movement, which grew out of the divisive and uproarious 1968 convention in Chicago, may yet succeed in averting similar hostilities in 1972. Or, ironically, it may create new tensions.

title: Advertising:
description: Because its 66yearold Boston office's profits are not meeting longterm cor porate objectives, N. W. Ayer & Son has agreed to sell it to Culver Advertising, a Boston industrial agency, on Sept. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.I. USE OF HEROIN IS REPORTED CUT
description: WASHINGTON. July 26,  Representative Robert H. Steele, the Connecticut Republican who has been at odds with the Nixon Administration over the extent of heroin use in Viet nam, said today that very substantial progress had been made in controlling service, men's use of the drug.

title: Pfizer Inc. Agrees to Stop Dumping Sludge Into Sound
description: The United States Environ mental Protection Agency has won agreement from. Pfizer Inc. to cease dumping industrial sludge into Long Island Sound, it was announced yesterday.

title: Bonwit Teller Tests Use of Lie Detectors
description: Polygraph interviews, or liedetector tests, have been administered to about 30 em ployes of Bonwit Teller, the Fifth Avenue specialty store, as an experimental step in the fight against pilferage by store personnel.

title: PETROSIAN PREVAILS IN MOSCOW CHESS
description: MOSCOW, July 26 (AP)Tig ran Petrosian, a Soviet chess grandmaster, won his semifinal match tonight against Viktor Korchnoi in a tournament to pick a challenger for the world chess championship.

title: Dow Jones Plans to Build New Facility in Bay State
description: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., an nounced yesterday plans for new facility in Chicopee, Mass., for its circulation service de partment and related opera tions. The company plans to build a twostory structure at a cost of more than $3million.

title: East German Version
description: BERLIN, July 26 (AP)East Germany said today that two German men shot by East Ben lin guards were West Berlin provocateurs trying to enter Communist territory.

title: Urban Plus Suburban Equals?
description: The road shows and lobbying activity put on by the Legislative Action Committee of the United States Conference of Mayors appear to be succeeding enough to win emulation. The National Association of Counties has created a Council of Elected County Executives which will try to enlist aid in the solution of suburban problems, as the Mayors' Committee has been doing for the big cities.

title: Advertising:
description: When Bell & Howell an nounced a couple of weeks back that it had selected N. W. Ayer & Son as its new agency it meant that Co ordinated Communications, Inc., was once again a brides maid.

title: U.S.BACKED LOANS SLIP INTO DEFAULT
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) A growing number of Govern mentbacked loans to private companies and individuals are slipping into default as bor rowers are hit by the lagging economy.

title: New Head Selected for City U.
description: Robert J. Kibbee, a vice president of CarnegieMellon University and president of the Pittsburgh Board of Education, is scheduled to be named chan cellor of the City University today by the Board of Higher Education.

title: Times Marketing Director Leaving for New Interests
description: Paul D. Townsend, director of marketing of The New York Times, will be leaving for other business interests, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher, announced yesterday in a staff memorandum.

title: Yankees Aiming To Use .500 Plateau As Launching Pad
description: CHICAGO, July 26  Now that they've finally attained the .500 level that has frus tratingly eluded them for more than two months, the Yankees prefer to think of it not as their final goal of the season but rather as a mile stone along the way to a more prestigious plateau.

title: Austrian Final to Mrs. King
description: KITZBITHEL, Austria, July 26 (AP)Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., won the women's singles title of the Austrian international cham pionships today, defeating Laura Roussoin. of South Africa, 62, 46, 75.

title: World Health Unit Finds Spain Free of Cholera
description: MADRID, July 26 (Reuter)  The World Health Or ganization has told Spain that she is now free of cholera, government officials said here today.

title: Dance: Paul Taylor's Company at Connecticut College Festival
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 26  The American Dance Festival held annually at Connecticut College here is traditionally a place for ad venture, a stage for growth. Since the festival started in 1948 the list of world pre mieres it has staged is formi dable. This season is no ex ception. One of the major attractions has been the Paul Taylor Dance Company, which gave the first per formances of Mr. Taylor's latest work, The Book of Beasts, at the Palmer Auditorium on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Northern Light, Gem, Crusader and Appledore II Win. in New York Y. C. Sail
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., July. 26 Northern Light, Gem, Cru sader and Appledore II were the winners today in the New York Yacht Club's shortened 18mile cruise to Martha's Vine yard.

title: INMATES CHARGES ON RIOT REJECTED
description: Charges of brutality by guards who were accused of using excessive force to quell rioting by inmates at the Queens House of Detention for Men last fall were rejected in Fed eral Court yesterday as a gigantic hoax and fraud.

title: Indian Shelling Reported
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 26 The Indian armed forces to day shelled the town of Comilla on the eastern border of East Pakistan, killing several civil ans and injuring many more, it was officially announced to day in Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan.

title: 2 Americans Advance
description: HILVERSUM, The Nether lands, July 26 (AP)Two Americans posted first round victories today in the Dutch open.

title: N.Y. Phone Reports
description: The New York Telephone Company reported last night that secondquarter net income amounted to $43,562,000, equal to 29 cents a share, or slightly higher than the $42,425,000, or 35 cents a share, earned on fewer shares outstanding in the three months ended June 30, 1970.

title: Continental Casualty Will Sell Medical Malpractice Insurance
description: CHICAGO, July 26  The Continental Casualty Company said here today that it would soon begin selling medical mal practice insurance under an agreement with the American Medical Association.

title: Washington: For the Record
Restructured Fares On New Haven Line Approved by M.T.A
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority yesterday ap proved a restructuring of fares on the New Haven Di vision of the Penn Central that would serve principally to in crease the price of 10  trip tickets.

title: Jets' ManonRun Facing A Battle From 3 Rookies
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 26  Outside the Hofstra Uni versity field house, tireless young autograph  seekers compared signatures today as the New York Jets clumped in from their morn ing workout.

title: City Museum Is Shaping a New Role
description: Plans for a wing for the Museum of the City of New York are on the drawing board, and a fiveyear cam paign has begun to raise $6.3 million for a program of over all expansion and refurbish ing and restructuring of the museum's role.

title: OILCONCERN PROFITS SHOW A MIXED TREND
description: Oil companies' earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30 were mixed, re ports showed yesterday.

title: Special Police Volunteer Teams Used to Fight Muggings Here
description: The Police Department said yesterday that patrolmen, dressed in civilan clothes, were being used on antimugging patrols in all 76 precincts, par ticularly during the peak crime hours of 6 P.M. to 2 A.M.

title: Sales Also a Record
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation re ported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings and a rec ord June 30 backlog for manu facturing orders.

title: StrikeHit N.&W. Gets RailPact Aid
description: The Norfolk & Western Rail way, one of four railroads that have been closed by the strike of the United Transportation Union, is well prepared for it, according to the railroad's president, John P. Fishwick.

title: Goodman Cautions on Interpreting Vote on Stanton
description: Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Com pany, believes television should not draw unduly optimistic conclusions from the refusal of the House of Representatives to cite Dr. Frank Stanton, presi dent of the Columbia Broad casting System, for contempt of Congress.

title: Fisheries Year Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  President Nixon has pro claimed 1971 as Fisheries Cen tennial Year and urged the people to support Federal and state officials and private or ganizations in protecting and enhancing the nation's fisheries.

title: CHARISMA TAKES SAIL TO MACKINAC
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 26  Jesse Philips came back with another Charisma to day to record his second con secutive overall triumph in the Bayview Yacht Club's Macki nac Island sailing race.

title: MINH ANNOUNCES HIS ENTRY IN RACE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26Duong Van Minh, the retired general who led the 1963 coup d'tat against President Ngo Dinh Diem, announced for mally today that he would run against President Nguyen Van Thieu in the Oct. 3 election.

title: Credit Markets: the Refinancing By Treasury Slows Even More
description: The Treasury's $5.1billion refinancing operation, which got off to an inauspicious start last Thursday, slowed down even more yesterday.

title: TV: Tour Around the Dials of Europe
description: Talk, if you're so inclined, about the busman's holiday and then consider for a touch ing moment the vacation of the television critic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Brakes Blamed in Crash
description: SEATTLE, July 26 (AP)The crash of Seattle's monorail train that injured 27 per sons yesterday was apparently caused by a failure of its brak ing system, officials said today. They said that the West Ger manbuilt trains were equipped with air brakes and that the system was designed to apply the brakes automatically if the air pressure failed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Spectacle in Fall to Mark Persia's 2,500 Years
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 14 Monument builders, historians, entertainers, hotel managers and the imperial Government are working at top speed to finish preparations for a royal party in October that promises to be spectacular.

title: 2 GUNMEN THREATEN 75 IN SUPERMARKET
description: Two robbers held 75 to 100 customers at gunpoint yester day afternoon while their two partners emptied cash registers at the Speedway Supermarket at 840 East New York Avenue in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: A Federal Judge Overturns Kentucky Redistricting Plan
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., July 26 (UPI)A Federal judge struck down today Kentucky's new legislative redistricting law.

title: Heart and Lung Recipient Satisfactory in Capetown
description: CAPETOWN, July 26 (Reu ters)  Adrian Herbert was re ported in a very satisfactory condition today following an operation that gave him a new heart and lungs.

title: BIG BOARD'S COSTS ON FAILURES RISE
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed yesterday that the cost of memberfirm failures might be as much as $20mil lion higher than anticipated, mainly because of additional expenses connected with the liquidations of Blair & Co.

title: Colleen Dewhurst to Star
description: Colleen Dewhurst has been signed to star in Jay Broad's new play, The Big CocaCola Swamp in the Sky, which James B. McKenzie and Spof ford J. Beadle will produce on Broadway in association with Edward Padula. Jose Quintero will direct.

title: Zinc Prices Increased; Newsprint Rises Loom
description: The price of newsprint  the paper on which newspapers are printedappeared yester day to be heading higher, while the price of zinc was definitely raised by at least two pro ducers.

title: LittleKnown State Bureau Gives Consumer the Edge
description: Alvis Rogers of Hollis, Queens, felt he had got a raw deal on his new Chevro let and he was angry.

title: The Talk of Praric Creek State Park
description: PRAIRIE CREEK RED WOODS STATE PARK, Calif., Ed Schroeder sells insur ance, and his wife, Pat, is a school teacher in Sacramento, Calif. The other day the Schroeders and their two children sat on a log watching Prairie Creek slip lazily by. The late afternoon sun filtered through the mas sive redwoods, splashing the water with light. Back home so much of your time is synchronized, said Mr. Schroeder, who has given up shaving for vacation. Out here you really don't plan where you're going to go, you just follow the mood. There are no schedules, no timetables. We listen to mu sic on the radio and I haven't seen a newspaper since we left.

title: President Asserts Flight Draws Man On to His Destiny
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  President Nixon said god speed today to the Apollo 15 astronauts.

title: APOLLO 15 HEADS FOR MOON AFTER SMOOTH LAUNCHING AND DOCKING WITH MODULE
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Tues day, July 27Three American astronauts, the men of Apollo 15, soared toward the moon today after a spectacular launching that was called the smoothest and most nearly flawless start of any of the na tion's lunar adventures.

title: PHILIP Y. EVERETT, SHIPPING OFFICIAL
description: Philip V. Everett, a former New York shipping executive with 50 years of experience in the marine field, who had served as a vice president of States Marine Lines, died Sun day at his home, 300 Central Park West. He was 73 years old.

title: A TOP RED HANGED BY THE SUDANESE
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 26Officials said today that noted Communist leader had been hanged and that they had captured another, who is to go on trial tomorrow for his role in the abortive leftist coup d'tat last week.

title: Chamber Study Critical
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that a study it had sponsored indicat ed President Nixon's welfare re form plan would discourage re lief recipients from working and could add as much as $3 billion a year to welfare costs.

title: Vorster Visiting Bantustans
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, July 26Prime Minister John Vorster began a fiveday tour of African tribal home lands, or Bantustans, in the northern Transvaal today.

title: Toxic Gas Leaves Okinawa
description: TOKYO, July 26 (AP) The United States Navy transport Sea Lift left Okinawa, for Johns ton Island in the midPacific with the first shipment of toxic gas weapons from Okinawa, the Kyodo news service reported today. The weapons will be stored on Johnston Island, 700 miles southwest of Hawaii.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: Trading was dull and prices were down on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Vol ume drifted to 2,542,160 shares from Friday's 2,782,980. The in dex was off 0.06 to 25.38.

title: Soviet Publishes a Book
description: MOSCOW, July 26 (AP)The Soviet Union has published a book on the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

title: HouseSitting Is a Growing VacationTime Occupation
description: LOS ANGELESMrs. Mar garet Seeley, a grandmother, has had a full life. She has pur sued careers as an actress and a stage manager, was a secretary for 14 years at a movie studio, has made five crosscountry trips in her 1958 Plymouth and has trav eled to Europe, Africa and Asia.

title: and Delayed
description: An important facet of President Nixon's foreign aid policy, which in the past has received strong encourage ment from some members of Congress, has been the effort to channel more American assistance through multilateral institutions such as the World Bank. The use of international aid agencies serves Mr. Nixon's objective of lowering the United States profile abroad while encouraging other advanced nations to share more fully the burden of promoting international development.

title: GILMOUR GRANTED TIME TO TESTIFY AT HEARING TODAY
description: William (Buddy) Gilmour, the nation's leading harness racing money winner this year, will appear today before a grand jury at the United States Court House in Foley Square.

title: Saint Laurent on Wild Side, Dior on the Elegant
description: PARIS, July 26Yves Saint Laurent presented outrageous collection on the first day of the fall and winter fashion showings here, and everybody's going to copy him. So be prepared for gigantic shoulders, lamp shade dresses, stockings with black seams and quilted satin evening jackets.

title: Medina's First Juror Is Tentatively Accepted as Mylai CourtMartial Opens
description: FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., July 26The trial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, accused by the Army of responsibility for the Mylai massacre, opened today in a small stuffy courtroom at Third Army Headquarters.

title: Knicks Sign Davis, 610
description: The New York Knickerbock ers announced yesterday the signing of Danny Davis of Hen derson State, a 6foot10 pivot man and a seventhround choice in last ?? National Basketball Association draft. Davis averaged 20.1 points and 10.3 rebounds a game last season.

title: Postal Workers' Rally Becomes Melee
description: A meeting of more than 3, 300 postal clerks and letter carriers at Manhattan Center yesterday erupted into a shout ing, brawling melee as the workers expressed their dissat isfaction with a new national contract.

title: 2 Deputies Held 8 Hours in New Orleans Jail
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 26  Two sheriff's deputies were held as hostages eight hours in the New Orleans jail today by a prisoner group that included several Black Panthers on trial on charges of trying to kill policemen.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 26 John Mangan of Rye, N. Y., defeated Joseph Abrahamson of Florham Park, N. J., 61, 62, to reach the round of 16 in the United States men's 35 years and over clay court tennis championships today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

title: MARGARET ADLER
description: Margaret Adler, a former teacher of pottery and the arts at the Ethical Culture School here, who had also been active in prison reform endeavors, died Sunday at her home, 755 Park Avenue. Her age was 82.

title: Matriarchy Denied
description: DETROIT, July 26A report on The Strengths of Black Families, issued today by the National Urban League, con tradicted what it called widely circulated studies saying that Negro families were matri archal, disorganized, patholog ical and disintegrating.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTONThe Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot pri mary prices for the week ended July 20.

title: Astronauts and Houston Track Down Short Circuit
description: HOUSTON, July 26At one of the moments of highest exhilaration, as the Apollo 15 astronauts set their course toward the moon today, a warning light flashed inklings of serious trouble.

title: Ramesh S. Sanghvi, Author and Lawyer Here and Overseas
description: Ramesh Sankalchand Sangh vi, a book publisher, author, public relations counsel and lawyer of London and Bombay, died of cancer Sunday in Uni versity Hospital. His age was 50 and his New York residence was at 1175 York Avenue.

title: Sports of The Times
description: HOUSTON, July 26Undertrained and overweight, Muhammad Ali still did what he was supposed to do in the Astrodome tonight. He beat Jimmy Ellis, his onetime sparring partner, just as he had done so often in a thousand rounds of training exercises over the years.

title: JUDGE MAY TALK TO SENATE PANEL
description: State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer, under investigation for alleged judi cial impropriety, met yesterday with his attorney, Bernard Bo tein, to discuss the possibility of appearing before a Senate subcommittee that is conduct ing an inquiry into organized crime.

title: Executive Changes
description: Texaco, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Howard W. McCall Jr., as a director. Mr. McCall is president and director of the Chemical New York Corporation and Chemical Bank.

title: Doris Siegel, Services Director At Mt. Sinai Hospital, Dies at 57
description: Doris Siegel, director of social service at Mount Sinai Hospital since 1954, died there Sunday after a long illness. She was 57 years old and lived at 140 East 81st Street.

title: Macy's Agrees to Remove Union Label Called Bogus
description: Macy's has agreed to remove an allegedly bogus union made label from a line of imported suits offered at some of its stores, the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America said yesterday.

title: Frazier Is Unimpressed
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI)  Joe Frazier, the heavy weight champion, said he was unimpressed with the bout be tween Muhammad Ali and Jimmy Ellis.

title: VAST RELIEF ROLL IS FEARED BY LONG
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)  Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, charged today that President Nixon's welfare proposals might build a permanent welfare subcul ture with as many as 50 mil lion or 100 million persons on relief.

title: Murphy Acquits an ExPolice Inspector
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday acquitted a former deputy inspector of department Charges of giving evasive answers to a grand jury investigating alleged pay offs to the police by a con victed gambler, Hugh Mulligan.

title: C.B.S. Sets Drug Program
description: If You Turn On, an Emmy Awardwinning special with Carol Burnett, Greg Morris, Arte Johnson and a group of medical authorities, and young people discussing the drug problem, will be televised Tues day, Aug. 17, at 7:30 P.M. on the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem network. The onehour pro gram, originally produced by and presented on KNXT, the C.B.S.owned station in Los Angeles will examine major as pects of the drug problem, in cluding roads to acquiring a habit and stopping it.

title: Moment of Launch: Its Special Meaning
description: CAPE KENNEDY, July 26 The special meaning of the launch to the millions who come to the beachthe true mysterybecomes clear and part of the mind forever in the merest unmeasurable part of a split second.

title: PROFIT DOWN 25% AT PHELPS DODGE
description: Two of the nation's largest primarycopper producers re ported sharp declines yesterday in their secondquarter earn ings.

title: Receiver Named
description: NEWARK, July 26 (UPI) William H. Tallyn, a Federal bankruptcy referee, appointed Joseph Walsh, a Newark law yer, as receiver and directed him to come up with a reorgan ization plan.

title: Victor, at 220, in Command of Houston Bout
description: HOUSTON, July 26The inevitable fight, as the pro moters branded it, produced the inevitable result.

title: Westchester County Golfers Triumph in Stoddard Cup
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 26  Westchester County Golf Association team won the Stoddard Cup at Quaker Ridge Golf Club today in the annual metropolitan triangular inter sectional match against teams from the New Jersey and Long Island golf associations.

title: AQUEDUCT SPRINT TO TWIST THE AXE
description: A daring, heady ride by Bobby Woodhouse enabled the Pastorale Stables Twist the Axe to take the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday before a crowd of 28,091. The event, a sevenfurlong sprint for older horses, attracted a half dozen contestants and the fans made the Hobeau Farm's Handsome Kid the favorite. He finished third, back of Howard Kane's Jerry Crow.

title: Wall CaveIn Kills Worker
description: JERSEY CITY, July 26 (UPI) One workman was killed and two others injured here today when a railroad retaining wall collapsed into a ditch where they were laying pipeline. The dead man was Antonio A. Cos teira, 28 years old, of 229 Gar side Street, Newark. The con struction site is at Henderson Avenue and Sixth Street.

title: 2 DANCERS MAKE BOW IN COPPELIA
description: Copplia is by far and away the lightestweight entry in the select pantheon of popu lar 19thcentury ballets both thematically and choreographi cally. However, its very fluffi ness makes it a specially de manding ballet to perform since it requires substantial stage magnetism to fill its outlines. Terry Orr and Diana Weber of American Ballet Theater danced the lead roles for the first time Sunday afternoon at the State Theater.

title: Rate of Emigration of Soviet Jews Declines, But It Still Exceeds Last Year's
description: MOSCOW, July 26The So viet authorities have apparently reduced the flow of Jews per mitted to emigrate to Israel this month, but the rate con tinues to exceed last year's, reliable Western sources said today.

title: Men in News
description: Ten years ago James Ben son Irwin was flat on his back in a hospital bed. As a result of a plane crash he had two broken legs, a broken jaw and a brain con cussion that had wiped out his memory.

title: First Woman Sails Ship Nonstop Across Atlantic
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 26 (AP)  A 28yearold British psychologist brought her 30 foot sloop to port today and became the first woman to sail nonstop across the At lantic Ocean.

title: Huge Bomb Found in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 26, (Reuters)  British troops today uncovered what was termed the biggest bomb ever planted in Northern Ire land. The bomb, made up of 234 pounds of explosives, mostly gelignite, was concealed by a roadside near Londonderry where British patrols pass.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Election year 1972 is beginning to look like one of the most remarkable in history, not so much for who may win as for how victory will be sought. Are we at some turningpoint of our politics, after which things will be significantly different?

title: 6 More States Quarantined As Horse Disease Spreads
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) The Agriculture Department has extended a horse quaran tine to six more states in an attempt to halt the northward spread of a disease that has killed more than 1,300 horses.

title: Over the Counter, 161, Takes $138,150 Sunset Handicap
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 26 H. T. Sheridan's Over the Coun ter, a 161 outsider, beat the highly regarded Cougar II by a halflength today in winning the $138,150 Sunset Handicap at two miles on the Hollywood Park turf.

title: Plans for Book Depository
description: DALLAS, July 26 (AP)The Texas School Book Depository, from which were fired the shots that killed President Ken nedy in 1963, will be turned into a museum housing more than 150,000 items associated with the slain President, its owner, Aubrey Mayhen, said today.

title: Final Moon Flight in Summertime Draws Crowd of Young Apollo Watchers
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 26The schoolage population joined parents and uncles and peers in flocking to beaches and other vantage areas in greater numbers than expected for the launching today of Apollo 15.

title: Statehood for the City Is Seen as Impractical
description: A report prepared for the Citizens Union yesterday crit icized the proposal of state hood for New York City as an idea whose time has passed.

title: MORRIS COHON DEAD; BROKERAGE PARTNER
description: Morris Cohon, senior partner since 1935 in the investment brokerage firm of Morris Cohon & Co., died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short ill ness. He was 67 years old and lived at 90 Booth Avenue, En glewood, N. J.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WHEELCHAIR FIVE ADVANCES IN BRITAIN
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, Eng land, July 26 (UPI)The United States opened defense of its basketball title at the 20th in ternational Stoke Mandeville wheelchair games today by routing Britain, 5738.

title: Nelson Leads in Series For Junior Sail Qualifiers
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 26 Macy Nelson of the Black Rock Y.C. took the lead in the Long Island Sound Junior Yacht Rac ing Association junior cham pionship qualifying series today after four races.

title: ASTROS TOP PHILS IN 15 INNINGS, 74
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (UPI)Cesar Cedeno, who had tied the game in the eighth and 10th innings, singled and scored the goahead run in the 15th tonight as the Houston Astros defeated the Philadel phia Phillies, 74.

title: U.S. Delays Release of Pentagon Study
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has decided to delay re lease of any of the Pentagon papers because of legal and security problems.

title: LOCKHEED LOSES 2 SENATE TESTS; CLOSURE BARRED
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Legislation to rescue the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation from impending bankruptcy and to authorize similar rescues, in the future, of other large com panies suffered two setbacks in the Senate today.

title: Tubman's Funeral Is Set For Thursday in Liberia
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 26 (UPI)A funeral service for President William V. S. Tub man will be held Thursday at Monrovia's centennial Memo rial Pavilion, the Government announced today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bridge: MatheRubin Spingold Match Ends at 5 A.M. After Clashes
description: CHICAGO, July 26  The semifinal stage on the Spin gold knockout team cham pionship began here this af ternoon with one team rather short of sleep. Protests and arguments in the quarter final match between teams led by Lew Mathe of Los An geles and Ira Rubin of Para mus, N.J., delayed matters to such an extent that the match ended about 5 A.M., long after the three other matches had been concluded.

title: Crime a Growing Problem for Africa; Robberies Bringing Harsh Punishment
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 26 Crime has become a growing problem and a public preoccu pation in Africa, but in most cities few residents are fright ened to walk the streets at night or to move freely in any section.

title: John Updike Completes a Sequel to Rabbit, Run
description: MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass.An air of happy re pose is floating through John Updike's summer cottage here, a human complement to the effortless flight of the seagulls gliding over Menem sha Bay outside.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hugh D. Lavery, President Of Sales Directions, Was 63
description: Hugh D. Lavery, president of Sales Directions, Inc., and an advertising executive for many years, died of a sudden illness while playing golf on Sunday at the Huntington (L.I.) Coun try Club. He was 63 years old and had homes at 25 East 67th Street and Lloyds Neck Har bor, L.I.

title: $50,000 Prize Puts Palmer Third in 1971 Golf Earnings
description: Arnold Palmer's $50,000 vic tor in the Westchester Classic moved him into third place in the race for the year's top money winner on the pro gel tour. He has not finished ?? since 1963.

title: DANNY SIMON WRITES PLAY ABOUT BROTHER
description: Danny Simon, brother of Neil Simon, has written a semiautobiographical comedy, Only the Shadow Knows, which will be produced on Broadway in the fall by Zev Bufman.

title: RESERVE PROPOSES NEW MARGIN RULES
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (Reu ters)  The Federal Reserve Bank has proposed that margin regulations in securities trans actions, which previously ap plied only to lenders, be extended to borrowers.

title: Some U.S. Analysts Believe Peking Could Not Help Settle the Vietnam War Except on Hanoi's Terms
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  Mounting North Vietnamese and Vietcong attacks on Presi dent Nixon's new policy toward China have led some United States Government analysts to conclude that Peking, even if it so desired, would be unable to help settle the Vietnam war ex cept on Hanoi's terms.

title: CLANCY QUITTING AS A SURROGATE
description: Queens Surrogate John T. Clancy will resign Thursday and touch off a round of political musical chairs that will involve a dozen top Queens officeholders in a se ries of bipartisan agreements.

title: 600 JAPANESE HURT IN CLASH AT AIRPORT
description: NARITA, Japan, July 26 (Reuters)  More than 600 policemen and demonstrators were injured today in a 12 hour battle for possession of land needed to complete con struction of Tokyo's second in ternational airport.

title: Scientists Warn of a Disaster From Nuclear Reactor System
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 26 (AP)  A group of scientists said today that a backup safety system widely used in nuclear reactors was likely to fail to prevent a major dis aster if an emergency occurred.

title: Standardized Orchestra Pitch Urged for Europe
description: PARIS, July 26As part of efforts to draw European nations closer together, a move is under way to stand ardize the pitch of orches tras so that the same Beet hoven symphony will not be heard in different keys.

title: Let's Hear It for the Moon and Space
description: SCHENECTADY  After fourteen years of technological achievements wholly unprecedented in the history of mancapped by yesterday's Apollo moon shotthe United States space program is losing ground to outspoken critics who advocate shifting funds from space to societal programs which appear on the surface to have a more direct and immediate impact on our national economy and well being.

title: MRS. PHILIP C. JOSLIN
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 26 Mrs. Dorothy Aisenberg Joslin, widow of Philip C. Joslin, a former judge of the Superior Court of Rhode Island, died to day at the age of 77.

title: Daniels Is Awarded Victory Over Ramos by Decision
description: HOUSTON, July 26  Terry Daniels of Dallas, a 195pound former football linebacker at Southern Methodist University, earned a unanimous 10round decision over Manuel Ramos, the 214pound Mexican heavy weight champion, in a semifinal to tonight's AliEllis bout.

title: U.S. Lifts Saigon Unit to Mountains Near Ashau
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (UPI) United States heli copters lifted a battalion of Government troops into moun tains southeast of the Ashau Valley today. Almost immediate contact with enemy troops was reported.

title: PRICES EDGE DOM ON STOCK MARKET
description: Wall Street's old saying  It's not a stock market but a market of stocks  was borne out yesterday by the widely divergent action of in dividual issues.

title: U.S. Reserves Fell in June To Lowest Level Since '38
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 United States monetary reserve assets declined an additional $307million in June to $13, 504,000,000, the Treasury re ported today.

title: BOARD ACTS TO CUT HOSPITAL WAITING
description: The city's Health and Hos pitals Corporation has voted to take whatever steps are nec essacy to insure that patients be seen by a physician within 15 minutes of their arrival in an emergency room and within 30 minutes in an outpatient department.

title: Tentative Agreement Reached by Lifeguards
description: The Long Island State Park Commission and the union representing 360 striking life guards reached a tentative agreement early today, Law rence Byrne, president of the union, reported.

title: Cubs Down Expos, 52
description: MONTREAL, July 26 (UPI) Jim Hickman collected three hits and drove in two runs to back the fivehit pitching of Milt Pappas tonight as the Chi cago Cubs scored a 52 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Catholics Defer Creating Body To Share Top DecisionMaking
description: POMFRET, Conn., July 26 A special committee of the United States Catholic Confer ence Advisory Council has de cided that it is not feasible now to create a fully developed na tional pastoral council to let laymen and priests join bishops in church decision making.

title: Shapp Aides Agree to Negotiate on Gettysburg Tower
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 26 Lawyers for Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania ap peared to retreat today from a weeklong courtroom and press campaign by the Gover nor against construction of a 307foothigh commercial ob servation tower at Gettysburg National Military Park.

title: Toy Makers Yield to F.T.C. On DeceptiveAd Complaint
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion said today that two toy makers had agreed to stop al legedly deceptive television commercials for three products.

title: Men in News
description: Unlike, it seems, every other astronaut, Alfred Mer rill Worden never had much of an interest in flying as a child. In fact, during his school days, the third man aboard Apollo 15the one who won't land on the moon was more interested in the piano.

title: Loss of a Few Eagles
description: The bald eagle, traditional symbol of the United States, is under imminent threat of extinctionwith the tacit encouragement and active participation of the Depart ment of the Interior.

title: Castro, Marking Revolution, Bars Reconciliation With U.S.
description: MIAMI, July 26Premier Fi del Castro today ruled out any rapprochement with the United States.

title: ExKorvette Head at Sprayregen
description: Leonard Blackman, former president of the Korvette dis count department stores, has joined Sprayregen & Co., an investment concern, to start a new subsidiary, Sprayregen & Blackman, Inc:

title: AMEX GROUP NAMED FOR STUDY REPORT
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the ap pointment of a special commit tee to study the report on the securities industry being pre pared by William. McChesney Martin Jr.

title: Leader of New Mexico Land Grant Fight Freed From Prison
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 26Reies Lopez Tijerina re, turned home today after morel than two years in Federal prisons.

title: CHILE ESCUDO SLIPS IN PARITY TO DOLLAR
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 26 New central bank regulations, reflecting the deterioration of the Chilean escudo, went into effect today raising the price of dollars for Chilean travelers. with a parallel rise in the black market for dollars.

title: NAVY WILL REVIEW GRUMMAN'S COSTS
description: BETHPAGE, L. I, July 26 The Pentagon sent a 40man team of Navy investigators here today to begin a three month investigation of the costs of three major naval aircraft production programs at the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, including produc tion of the F14 fighter air craft.

title: Mackell Names U.S. Aide to Head Crime Unit
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens announced the appointment yesterday of Anthony V. Lombardino, who has been chief of the criminal divison of the office of the Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, to head a newly appointed or ganized crime and rackets bu reau.

title: Allegheny Ludlum
description: PITTSBURGH, July 26  Al legheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., reported today that earn ings for the second quarter were $3,780,000, or 48 cents share, on sales of $141,955,000.

title: The U.M.W. Mystery
description: WASHINGTON, July 26We all talk about justice, but few of us are ever in a position to seek justice at the risk of our lives. Jock Yablonski was one who did.

title: Winged Insect Invaders Vanish From 23d Street
description: The swarms of tiny, winged insects that mysteriously de scended on the East Side around 23d Street Sunday just as mysteriously dis appeared yesterday, accord ing to some residents and the police.

title: New England Utilities Get Preliminary F.P.C. Permit
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)  The Federal Power Com mission issued today a three year preliminary permit to three New England utilities for the proposed Canaan Mountain pumpedstorage hydroelectric plant in Connecticut.

title: Conferees Vote SST Fund
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) SenateHouse conferees agreed today on a $58.5million appro priation to reimburse airlines for their contribution to a pro gram, since discontinued by the Government, to develop a super sonic transport plane.

title: Agnew Meets Portugal's Premier and President
description: LISBON, July 26Vice Pres ident Agnew conferred today with Premier Marcello Caetano in the last stop of the Vice President's diplomatic world tour.

title: Forgotten Man on Giants Playing a Waiting Game
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 26  With his good friend Tucker Frederickson return ing, Ernie Koy reverted today to his role as chief substitute among the Giants' running backs.

title: Charles J. McLennan Dies; Racing Official in Maryland
description: BALTIMORE, July 26 (AP) Charles James McLennan, the first man to serve as racing secretary at Maryland's three major thoroughbred racetracks, died yesterday at a Baltimore hospital after a long illness. His age was 66.

title: FORD'S PROFIT UP ON RECORD SALES
DR. KEITH SEElE, EGYPTOLOGIST, 73
description: CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) Dr. Keith C. Seele, professor emeritus of Egyptology in the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, who for merly directed the institute's Nubian program and the uni versity's archeological expedi tions in Egypt and other parts of the Middle East, died here Saturday at the age of 73. His widow survives.

title: PUBLICIST AND WIFE DIE IN PLANE CRASH
description: MADISON, Conn., July 26 Thomas C.F. Bright, a Philadel phia advertising and public relations executive, and his wife, the former Margaret Fleming Biddle, were killed this morning when his light plane in which she was the only passenger struck a water tower in heavy fog here. Their home was at 401 Conestoga Road, St. Davids, Pa.

title: U.S. Forces in Vietnam Now Down to 229,200
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (UPI)  The United States military command said today that 4,100 Ameri can servicemen were pulled out of the war zone last week, reducing American troop strength in Vietnam to 229,200.

title: CITY UNION SCORED ON JUNE DISRUPTION
description: Ralph C. Gross, president of the Commerce and Industry Association, warned last night that when public employe unions have too much power ... it's bad for the people.

title: Market Place: Small Investors Look at Rates
description: Many small investors say they are up in arms over the commissionrate increases proposed by the New York Stock Exchange for small transactions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CORN PRICES FALL IN HEAVY TRADING
description: With generally favorable Government corn crop develop ment and harvest reports, trad ers apparently believed there was less risk in selling than in buying and corn futures prices broke more than 5 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade.

title: APOLLO CLEARED FOR MOON LANDING AS ROCKET FIRES
description: HOUSTON, July 27A brief, successful firing of Apollo 15's main rocket today gave', the three astronautsand Mission Control hereconfidence that sawed electrical switch should not jeopardize the mission's planned landing on the moon.

title: Ky Declares He Won't Quit Election in Favor of Minh
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 (Reuters)  Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said tonight that he would not bow out of South Vietnam's presidential election, scheduled to be held Oct. 3, and throw his support behind Duong, Van Minh, the retired general is considered President Nguyen Van Thieu's strongest challenger.

title: Union at Goodyear Forgoes Wage Increase for 2 Years
description: WINDSOR, Vt., July 27 (AP) The Goodyear Tire & Rub ber Co. and the United Rubber Workers Union announced yes terday that hourly employes would forgo wage increases for the next two years in exchange for continued production schedules at the shoe products plant here.

title: U.S. and China Are Likely To Discuss Trip in Ottawa
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Diplomatic discussions in prep aration for President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Peking are expected to be conducted main, ly through the Chinese Embas sy in Canada, Nixon Adminis tration officials said privately today.

title: Maynard Miller, Furrier, Dies; Operator in RealEstate Market
description: Maynard M. Miller, long prominent in the fur and other businesses in this city, died yes terday in the Lido Beach Ho tel, Lido Beach, L. I., where he had been on vacation. He was in his 70's and lives at 118 East 60th Street.

title: West Side Story Bows With AllHispanic Cast
description: About 2,500 people at tended the outdoor opening performance of West Side Story last night at Dam rosch Park in Lincoln Center, including Mayor Lindsay.

title: Rikers Island Boy, 16, Is Dead In His Third Suicide Attempt
description: A 16yearold inmate, who attempted suicide twice in the last month, hanged himself ear ly yesterday in his cell at the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island, prison officials reported.

title: Destroyer Runs Aground
description: SANDWICH, Mass., July 27 (AP)The Harlan R. Dickson, a destroyer carrying a crew of nine officers and 126 enlisted men, went aground near the entrance to the Cape Cod Canal today. The Navy said the ship was in no immediate danger. The accident occurred because of a power failure aboard the destroyer, the spokesman said.

title: RAIL ARBITRATION REQUESTED BY U.S.; UNION REJECTS IT
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 The Nixon Administration called on the nation's railroads and the striking United Transporta tion Union today to accept binding arbitration to end their long, bitter contract dispute.

title: THE VILLAGE VOICE IS SPLIT OVER ADS
description: A distinct difference of opinion has arisen at The Vil lage Voice between the old guard and the new owners over classified masseur and model advertisements, which some contend are simply the offer ings of prostitutes.

title: WarnerLambert Ahead
description: The WarnerLambert Compa ny, a diversified drug, consum erproducts, scientific and med icalinstruments producer, post ed record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30 and raised the quarterly dividend for the 19th consecutive year, Stuart K. Hensley, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: POEMS FOR THE GAME OF SILENCE 1960 1970. By Jerome Rothenberg. 204 pages. The Dial Press. $7.50. Paperback. $2.45.

title: GILMOUR DEFENDS HARNESS RECORD AT INQUIRY HERE
description: Maintaining that his track record speaks for itself, William (Buddy) Gilmour testi fied for 15 minutes yesterday before a Federal grand jury investigating possible fixed harness races.

title: State Acts to Raise Rates on Insurance Against Vandalism
description: The New York Insurance De partment announced yesterday that in an effort to make cov erage against vandalism avail able quickly, it would act in the next 10 days on an indus try request for a 39.7 per cent rate increase.

title: Homer in 12th Beats Yanks, 96
description: CHICAGO, July 27It was Mug Night at White Sox Park tonight, and New York was mugged as painfully as two Yankees were in the team's last two visits to Chicago.

title: If You Want It, They've Got ItFrom a Penny Candy to a Pet Snake
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn.Does anybody need a duck press? Or a live boa constrictor? Coffee from Kenya? A good book? Knitting yarn? Soy beans? A doll house? A bag of penny candy? A water color? An antique chair? A length of dress fabric or garden hose? They're all to be found under one large wooden roof at the Bazaar, on the Green at Heritage Vil lage, the complex of retire ment homes here. Many of the Bazaar's customers are Village residents, but outsid ers from miles away pile the kids into the car and come to wander through the 20 shops that make up the Bazaar. It's almost as fascinating as the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, and a lot more convenient.

title: Geoffrion, Gilbert, Villemure To Play in Exhibition Here
description: Boom Boom Geoffrion will suit up again for Montreal against New York tomorrow night.

title: POLICEMAN SOUGHT IN $143,000 HOLDUP
description: The Police Department last night issued a national alarm for a patrolman who is wanted with two other men in the shooting of two Brinks guards and an elevator operator in a Municipal Building holdup that netted $143,000 three weeks ago.

title: GOLD PRICE RISES TO A 2YEAR HIGH
description: PARIS, July 27Fresh wor ries about the dollar intensified market activity in gold today, lifting the price to about $42 an ounce, the highest level in two years.

title: England, India Draw in Test
description: LONDON, July 27 (Reuters) England and India drew their opening cricket test when rain ended the match today. India needed 183 to win before Eng land reached 145 for eight at tea runs short of victory when the rain washed out the final session.

title: DR. EDGAR ZWILLING, AN EMBRYOLOGIST, 58
description: BOSTON, July 27Dr. Edgar Zwilling, Goodman Professor of Biology at Brandeis University in Waltham and a leading em bryologist, died Friday in Mas sachusetts General Hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONAn extraordinary political aspect of this era is the ascendancy of the minority leader who, despite absence of clearcut national backing, audaciously pushes through programs of momentous import. The three out standing cases in point are U.S. Presi dent Nixon, British Prime Minister Heath, and West German Chancellor Willy Brandt.

title: Numbers Still OddsOn Favorite As Harlem Gets Offtrack Parlor
description: Offtrack betting came to Harlem yesterday, but the let ters that designated the horses failed to stir as much excitement among the people as the numbers game, the area's favorite pastime.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: What Is Happening to the Aged?
description: If a society is to be judged by the care it takes of its oldest members, the United States is inviting a harsh appraisal. Figures presented by Senator Percy of Illinois show that onefourth of all Americans over 65 now live on a povertylevel income and that theirs is the only age group in the country that is getting poorer by the year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y.U. Filmmaking: A Strong Image
description: One of the energy centers of filmmaking in the United States lies, not very inviting ly, just beyond an orange walled lobby and through pair of purple portals.

title: For Want of a Whip, Aqueduct Race Is Lost
description: Somewhat sheepishly, Jerry Samuels tied a rubber band round the middle finger of his right hand and attached his whip to it before the eighth race at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: F.B.I. Agent Kills Attacker
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 27 (UPI)A Federal Bureau of ?? vestigation agent shoe ?? killed today a former ?? patient who slashed a ?? with a knife, the bureau ?? The victim was Walter ?? years old, of Jacksonville ?? was shot by John D. Watson as the agent was attempting to arrest him. Cox had walked up to a car and struck another agent seated inside, the bureau said.

title: BANK LINK BACKED FOR CONNECTICUT
description: William B. Camp, the United States Controller of the Curren cy, approved yesterday the pro posed merger of the Connecti cut National Bank, Bridgeport, and the First New Haven Na tional Bank. The combined in stitution would have more than $625million in assets and 70 offices across the state.

title: Arab Reds Confer
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 27 Arab Communist leaders have been meeting here secretly to discuss what is generally re garded as a Communist disaster in the Sudan.

title: Pentagon Data Cited as Parley Of Congress War Foes Opens
LERAY W. BERDEAU, A RETIRED ENGINEER
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., July 27  LeRay William Berd eau, a retired engineer who was part of the United States Army construction unit that built the Panama Canal, died at a hospi tal here yesterday. He was 83.

title: N.A.S.D. Expels Coast Firm
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 27 (UPI)May & Co., a Portland brokerage firm, has been ex pelled from the National Asso ciation of Securities Dealers, the organization that regulates over  the  counter securities firms. The firm went out of business several months ago but exists as a corporate shell pending settlement of some legal matters. The N.A.S.D. said the expulsion was based on May's handling of a stock issue for Fibers, Inc., Washougal, Wash., also now defunct.

title: CITY WINS SANCTION TO FINE POLICEMEN
description: A threejudge special panel sitting in Federal Court in Man hattan took under consideration yesterday the contention of city policemen that their constitu tional rigths had been violated by punishment without a hear ing after the Jan. 14 to 19 strike.

title: Apollo's TV Show Begins in the Dark And Ends in Puzzle
description: HOUSTON, July 27 (AP) The first television show from the Apollo 15 lunar module Falcon began today like silent movie filmed in a dark garage, until a hot microphone caught two of the astronauts unawares.

title: Fewer Apollo Newsmen
description: HOUSTON, July 27 (UPI) From a high of 1,200 for the Apollo 11 voyage, the number of accredited newsmen covering the moon landing project has steadily gone downhill. Officials reported today that 402 had signed up to cover the ambi tious Apollo 15 flight.

title: Housing Inspector, A G.O.P. Leader, Accused of Graft
description: A city housing inspector who is also a Republican district leader in the Bronx was ar raigned yesterday on charges of conspiracy, extortion, bribe receiving and official miscon duct.

title: Alps Cable Car Traps 65
description: CHAMONIX, France, July 27 (AP)  Sixtyfive tourists, in cluding a number of children, were trapped for hours today in a stormtossed cable car 5,000 feet up the slope of an Alpine peak. The car stalled when another car jumped the cable and crashed to the ground, killing its sole occu pant. The other passengers were brought to the ground on an escape cable.

title: U.S. Steel Cuts Payout as Profit Rises
description: The United States Steel Cor poration, the nation's largest steel producer, announced yes terday that it would cut its quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 60 cents, even though the concern also report ed that secondquarter earn ings were nearly double the yearearlier level.

title: YOUNG IS MISSED BY URBAN LEAGUE
description: DETROIT, July 27  A pros perouslooking black man stepped into an elevator in De troit's newest hotel and said to the lone black passenger, whom he did not know:

title: Mets Win, 32, on Dyer Hit in 9th;
description: The New York Mets finally beat somebody besides them selves last night, and they did it in their longlost soapopera stylefour singles that pro duced a tworun rally in the ninth inning and overturned the St. Louis Cardinals, 32.

title: Justice Refuses to Postone Virginia Redistricting Order
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court refused today to stay a Federal court order reapportioning Virginia's leg islature while the state prepares an appeal.

title: A Fair Rail Settlement Waiting
description: The plea of Secretary of Labor Hodgson for voluntary action by the United Transportation Union and the nation's railroads to arbitrate their long dispute over work rules represents a despairing Administration effort to avoid recourse to Congress once again for emergency legislation to end strikes in this industry. In a real sense, there is nothing to arbitrate. The ingredients for a fair settlement were laid down eight months ago by a Presi dential factfinding board.

title: Suit Now Asks $6.3Billion
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) A private antitrust suit against the Penn Central Com pany and its subsidiary, the Penn Central Transportation Company, originally asking $3.6billion in triple damages for Penn Central stockholders, has been amended in the Fed eral District Court here to seek $6.3billion instead.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Roundup: Dobson's 14th Makes Him Orioles' No. 1
description: If the Baltimore Orioles represent the American League in the 1971 World Series, the club's vice presi dent and director of player personnel, Harry Dalton, can take credit for his perspica city.

title: G.O.P. Group Censures Nixon on Trip to China
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 27 (UPI)The Orange County chapter of the California Re publican Assembly, the oldest party volunteer organization in the state, has voted to censure President Nixon for betrayal of principles in his decision to visit Com munist China.

title: Rough Riders Win Opener
description: OTTAWA, July 27 (AP) Gary Wood passed 52 yards for one touchdown and ran for an other tonight as the Ottawa Rough Riders defeated the Ed monton Eskimoes, 2211, in the opening Canadian Footaball League game of the season.

title: Go for Apollo 15
description: A feeling of relief swept around the world yesterday, wherever Apollowatchers were gathered, when the Apollo 15 propulsion engine fired as it was supposed to, thus ending concern that a flickering signal light might indicate fundamental difficulties that would require aborting the moon landing. For those directly involved the astronauts and the numerous ground technicians working with themthe hours of apprehension before the problem had been resolved must have been particu larly agonizing since everything else had gone so well at the outset.

title: Halt to Whale Killing Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Declaring that one whale is killed every 12 minutes, con servationists have appealed to Congress for legislation to im pose a 10year moratorium on whale hunting to save them from extinction. Opponents of the legislation, including Stuart Blow of the State Department's Ocean Affairs Division and Dr. Douglas Chapman of the Uni versity of Washington, said a moratorium on United States whalers would have little effect on depletion.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES SHOWS PROFIT DROP
description: Eastern Air Lines reported yesterday a net income of $3.2 million, or 21 cents a share, for the second quarter and a net income of $459,000 for the first six months. Because of pre ferred dividend requirements, there were no commonshare earnings for the half.

title: THREE SUSPENDED Al POCONO TRACK
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., July 27 (AP)  The State Harness Rac ing Commission ordered the in definite suspension today of three men as a result of its continuing investigation into al leged irregularities at Pocono Downs.

title: Rabbi Jacob KalianeShapiro Of Brooklyn Seminary, 80
description: TEL AVIV, July 27  Rabbi Jacob KahaneShapiro, a found er and dean of Yavne Jew ish Theological Seminary, 510 Dahill Road, Brooklyn, died yes terday in a hospital near here at the age of 80.

title: DR. JOHN J. O'CONNOR
