description: Dr. John J. O'Connor Jr., a member of the urology depart ment at the New York Univer sity Medical Center, died Mon day of cancer in St. Mary's Hos pital, Hoboken, N. J., where he was chief of urology. He was 47 years old, practiced in Union City, N.J., and resided in Le onia, N. J.

title: Protests by French Reds
description: PARIS, July 27The French Communist party preceded the Soviet Union by almost a day in protesting the arrests and executions of Communists in the Sudan. L'Humanite, the party newspaper, published the text of a cablegram sent by the party yesterday, asking the Sudanese to halt immediately, these massacres.

title: PAKISTAN SAYS INDIA KILLED 5 IN SHELLING
description: DACCA, Pakistan, July 27  Pakistani authorities charged today that an Indian artillery barrage killed five civilians and wounded 13 in the district capi tal of Comilla in East Pakistan.

title: 3 Prisoners Demand Trial By Jury of Other Convicts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 (UPI)Three convicts accused of murdering a prison guard demanded today a trial by jury composed of other pris oners.

title: American Express Tour 410 in Moscow Is Impressed
description: MOSCOW, July 27The 37 members of American Ex press Tour 410 took a vote yesterday on their last morn ing in the Soviet Union: Len in's Tomb or the Kremlin churches.

title: Ali Angered as U.S. Takes $130,000 in Withholding Tax
description: HOUSTON, July 27Muham mad Ali attacked the Internal Revenue Service today for seiz ing $130,000 as a tax prepay ment from his $450,000 guar antee for his 12thround knock out of Jimmy Ellis at the Astro dome last night.

title: LOCKHEED BILL GETS BREATHER IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Sup porters of legislation to rescue the nearbankrupt Lockheed Air craft Corporation sought and received a breather today after suffering two setbacks in the Senate yesterday.

title: Move on South Africa Fails
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reu ters)  The Senate today re jected an effort led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy to stop South African sugar exports to the United States. Mr. Kennedy, in a protest against the repub lic's racial policies, sought to delete South Africa from pending bill allocating sugar quotas to 32 nations.

title: CHIEF MEYERS DIES; STENGEL TEAMMATE
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 27 (AP)  John (Chief) Meyers, who threw out a record number of 12 runners while catching for the New York Giants in the 1911 World Series, died Sunday, four days before his 91st birthday.

title: G.M.'s Net Surges on Record Volume;
description: DETROIT, July 27The Gen eral Motors Corporation today reported $566.9million, or $1.97 a share, in secondquar ter earnings, up nearly 20 per cent from $472.6million, or $1.64 a year before.

title: 15 INDICTED HERE ON S.E.C. CHARGES
description: Two stock brokerage com panies, four lawyers and 11 other persons were indicted here yesterday on charges that they took part in a complex conspiracy to obstruct an in vestigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: G.O.P. Bid for Minorities' Convention Role Raises Political Problem
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Republicans' efforts to reform their national convention by in cluding more blacks and other, minority group members as del egates are creating more politi cal problems than they are solving.

title: The Lessons of Khartoum
description: A Soviet scholar described the Arab world to a group of visiting Americans last year as a very large area close to our borders which cannot be controlled by any power.

title: Arrest of 2 Starts Disturbance by 100 In Brooklyn Area
description: The arrest of two burglary suspects in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn last night touched off a firesetting, brick throwing disorder by a large group of Puerto Rican residents.

title: New City U. Head Seeks Rise in Level of Teaching
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, a Pittsburgh educator who was named chancellor of the City University yesterday, has called for a substantial improvement in the quality of the teaching at the university.

title: PRICE CO. RAISES NEWSPRINT COST
description: The trend toward higher prices for newsprint, zinc and aluminum mill products con tinued yesterday as did lower costs for cadmium.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The General Electric Com pany was awarded yesterday a $117.4million Navy contract for nuclear ship reactor com partment components.

title: Sharks at Splashdown To Face New Weapon
description: ABOARD U.S.S. OKINAWA, at Sea, July 27 (AP) Navy swimmers assigned to pick up the Apollo 15 astronauts when they splash down in the Pacific Ocean have a new weapon for dealing with sharks.

title: Israel Seeking to Put Her Scientific Advantage in Mideast to Profitable Use
description: JERUSALEM, July 27Israel is striving to expand and fur ther profit from her already dominant position as the most scientifically advanced nation in the Middle East.

title: FRENCH EMBARGO PERILS BIG TROT
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 27 The $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway Aug. 21 appeared today to be in jeopardy. A shortgage of standardbreds, because of an embargo on horses entering France, is at the root of the problem.

title: OKKER ADVANCES IN QUEBEC TENNIS
description: QUEBEC, July 27 (Canadian Press)Tom Okker of the Neth erlands and Roy Emerson and Bob Carmichael of Australia advanced to the second round today at the Quebec interna, tional tennis open.

title: Colts Favored in Reno
description: RENO, July 27 (UPI)Har rah's race book rated the Balti more Colts today as 10point favorites to defeat the College AllStars in their football game at Chicago Friday.

title: MAYOR IS EVASIVE ON PARTY SWITCH
description: Grinning all the while, Mayor Lindsay deflected persistent at tempts to draw him into con versation yesterday on the ru mors that he is about to de clare himself a Democrat and, perhaps, a candidate for the Presidential nomination.

title: JERSEY SUSPENDS LAW PRACTICE OF 3
description: TRENTON, July 27David J. Friedland, the Assembly minor ity leader, and two other law yers were suspended from the practice of law today by the State Supreme Court, which found them guiltty of unethical conduct in having charges against an alleged loanshark dropped.

title: Con Ed Profit Hits Peak;
description: The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday records in operating revenues and net income for the first half. Net income rose by 12.8 per cent on a gain of 17 per cent in operating revenues.

title: Quarter Net Up 21.1%
description: W. Graham Claytor Jr., pres ident of the Southern Railway, disclosed yesterday that, under the industry's mutual aid pact, his 6,000mile system would collect about $635,000 daily if the strike that closed it 12 days ago lasts a full month.

title: G.M. and U.S. Steel Report Rise in Profit
description: The General Motors Corpora tion and the United States Steel Corporation reported sharply improved quarterly profits yes terday.

title: O'Neal Reelected by 4A's
description: Frederick O'Neal, president of Actors Equity Association, has been reelected president of the Associated Actors and Artists of America. He was elected as president of the in ternational body of performer unions i n1970, to fill the un expired term of the late Conrad Nagel.

title: Excerpts From Addresses by Dr. Kibbee
description: Following are excerpts front recent addresses delivered by Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, newly appointed chancellor of the City University of New York:

title: Ford Sets Steel Strip Mill
description: The Ford Motor Company, the only domestic auto manufac turer that has its own inte grated steel plant, announced yesterday in Dearborn, Mich., that it would build a new mill to make hotrolled strip steel, a product used widely in care and appliances. Ford did not disclose the projected capital in vestment, but such a mill would cost several million dollars.

title: Argentine Minister Pledges Free Elections by May '73
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 27 (UPI)  Interior Minister Ar turo Mor Roig promised today that Argentina's next freely elected President would be in the door of Government House by May, 1973.

title: MINORITIES GAIN IN FEDERAL JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The Civil Service Commission said today that minority group members held 19.6 per cent of Federal jobs last November, up from 19.2 per cent a year ear lier.

title: Dissident I.O.S. Unit Fails To Oust Vesco as Director
description: The Overseas Development Bank, a Swiss subsidiary of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., was unsuccessful in its attempt to remove Robert L. Vesco, chairman of I.O.S., and two associates as directors of the bank, I.O.S. said yesterday.

title: 64 South Koreans Killed In Landslides and Floods
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 27At least 64 persons were killed in landslides and floods caused by torrential rains that swept the central and south western areas of South Korea in the last two days.

title: WALTER L. TODD, LED CHECKWRITING FIRM
description: ROCHESTER, July 27Wal ter L. Todd, a former president of the Todd Company, makers of checkwriting devices and other banking products, died in Genesee Hospital last night. He was 85 years old and lived in Pittsford, N. Y.

title: Bronx Landlord Sentenced In Arson Deaths of 3 Boys
description: Albert Epstein, a Bronx land lord convicted of arson that caused the deaths of three teenaged boys last year, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to an indeterminate term of up to 10 years in prison.

title: James J. Newman Is Dead; Former Goodrich Executive
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., July 27 James J. Newman, who re tired as a vice president of B. F. Goodrich Company in 1953, died today. He was 82 years old.

title: Peril to Children Seen In Detergent Package
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration told the Col gate Palmolive Company to day that it must not market a new dishwasher detergent in a package resembling a milk carton.

title: MRS. ROBERT E. LEE
description: Mrs. Hermine Schurig Lee, widow of Robert E. Lee, a rug importer, died Monday after a long illness at her home, 30 Bogardus Place. She was 70 years old.

title: Patient Shows Progress After HeartLung Implant
description: CAPETOWN, July 27 (UPI) Adrian Herbert, 51 years old, recipient of the transplanted heart and lungs of another man, showed quite satisfactory progress today and began drink ing fluidsnormally, doctors at Groote Schuur Hospital said.

title: Taiwan Has Trade Surplus
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 27 (UPI)Nationalist China had a favorable trade balance of $54.9million in the first six months of this year, the Board of Foreign Trade said today. Exports totaled $993.6million and imports $938.7million. Taiwan's two major trading partners were the United States and Japan.

title: PEKING
description: PEKING, July 27The extraordinary thing about this oldest civilization in the world is that it seems so young. You do not have the feeling here so depressing and oppressive in some other parts of the Orientof weari ness, sickness and death, of old men and women, spent before their time, struggling against hopeless odds.

title: Sports of The Times
description: HOUSTON, July 27If there was one unanswered question that troubled those who watched the Muhammad AliJimmy Ellis fight in the Astrodome last night, it was this: Why did it take Ali so long to score his knockout? Not until 50 seconds before the final bell of the 12rounder did the referee mercifully intercede, halting the slaughter of a helpless Ellis.

title: RAYMOND LEGUELT
description: PARIS, July 27 (AP)Ray mond Leguelt a painter and former head teacher at the BeauxArts School, died yester day at the age of 73. Among his works were murals in the Paris Opera.

title: Pan Am Bars Tours for Safaris To Hunt Endangered Species
description: Pan American World Air ways will no longer promote or take part in safari tours that involve the killing of ani mals classified by the World Wildlife Fund as endangered species.

title: Crompton & Knowles Sets Deal for a CibaGeigy Unit
description: The Crompton & Knowles Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the CibaGeigy Corpora tion to acquire that company's Intracolor Corporation subsidi ary. The acquisition will be made through a combination of cash and nonvoting preferred stock totaling about $20mil lion.

title: Big Board Lists Merrill Lynch
description: I guess I should really be buying an odd lot, quipped Donald T. Regan, the chair man of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., shortly before he stepped up yester day to make the traditional purchase of the first 100 shares of a company new to the New York Stock Ex change.

title: EDWARD H. ZIMMERMAN
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 27  Edward H. Zimmerman, re tired founder and treasurer of the Imperial Coal Company died in his sleep yesterday at his home, 17 Rockledge Road. He was 85 years old.

title: GLOOM PERVADES LISTLESS MARKET
description: The stock market dropped steadily yesterday as a falling, dispirited price trend seemed to feed on its own weakness.

title: SCHWEITZER SAYS HE TOOK NO BRIBES
description: State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer de clared yesterday that it would be inappropriate for him to appear before a Senate sub committee to answer what he called baseless charges that he accepted $50,000 in bribes from a convicted stock manip ulator.

title: Plan for a Jetport in Westhampton Is Assailed
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 27 Nearly 100 residents of the Hamptons jammed the County Center here today to tell the Suffolk County Legis lature that they opposed plans to turn the Suffolk Airport at Westhampton Beach Into New York's fourth jetport.

title: Vietnamese Plan to Resume Shifting Hill Tribesmen
description: DALAT, South Vietnam, July 23Vietnamese province chiefs and military authorities in the Central Highlands are planning to resume a controversial pro gram of transferring tens of thousands of primitive hill tribesmen out of Communist controlled areas.

title: Strike by L.I. Lifeguards Ends After Eight Weeks
description: WANTAGH. L. I., July 27 An eightweek strike by life guards at the Robert Moses and Jones Beach State Parks ended today with an agree ment by union negotiators and the Long Island State Park Commission.

title: Columbus, Ga., Gets Funds For PoliceCommunity Ties
description: ATLANTA, July 27 (AP)An immediate Federal grant of $58,000 was pledged to the city of Columbus, Ga., today to establish a police community relations commission in the racially tense city.

title: First Black Ambassador To South Africa Named
description: ZOMBA, Malawi, July 27 (Reuters) Malawi today ap pointed Joe Kachingwe as Ambassador to South Africa the first black African ambassador to the white governed republic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Arab Unity: The Elusive Dream
description: News Analysis

title: Cardin: One Foot in Future, the Other Planted Firmly in Today
description: PARIS, July 27So far, the couturiers here have been conveniently taking sides. Dior stands up for the estab lishment, Saint Laurent for the protesters and, this morn ing, Pierre Cardin for the modernists. Hooray for Car din.

title: CHANDLER HOVEY, EXYACHTSMAN, 91
description: BOSTON, July 27Chandler Hovey, a yachtsman, died to day. He was 91 years old and lived in suburban Chestnut Hill.

title: Pentagon Said to Penalize. Officers on Racial Policy
description: DETROIT, July 27Frank W. Render 2d, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, said to day that 10 or 12 military of ficers, from general down to company grade, had been relieved of command, trans ferred or reprimanded for fail ure to enforce adequately the regulations aimed to improve race relations or guarantee equal opportunity within the armed services.

title: Dissident I.O.S. Unit Fails To Oust Vesco as Director
description: The Overseas Development Bank, a Swiss subsidiary of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., was unsuccessful in its attempt to remove Robert L. Vesco, chairman of I.O.S., and two associates as directors of the bank, I.O.S. said yesterday.

title: Corona Pleads Not Guilty In 25 Slayings at Yuba City
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., July 27 (UPI)Juan V. Corona pleaded not guilty today to charges of slaying 25 transient farm labor ers along the Feather River.

title: Mary Travers in Debut on Her Own
description: Under a dark, ominous sky that oozed an occasional drop of rain, Mary Travers made her New York debut Monday night at the Wollman Rink in Central Park. Miss Travers has appeared frequently in New York during the last 10 years as the third member of Peter, Paul and Mary. But her performance at the Schaefer Music Festival was her first since she left the trio to pur sue a solo career.

title: HEALTH FUND RISE PASSED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The House passed tonight by a vote of 372 to 25 an appropriations bill that would give the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare about $447million more than requested by the President's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1972.

title: Giants Get Workout on the Rules
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 27 After a hard morning work out under a hot sun and their usual modest lunch, the New York Giants gathered in a large classroom at C. W. Post College today and took a quiz.

title: CONVERTING OF COAL INTO GAS IS BACKED
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  The New York Public Service Commission chairman, Joseph C. Swidler, urged Congress to day to approve legislation that would encourage the develop ment of a method to obtain natural gas from coal.

title: HOUSE BACKS NIXON ON SUBVERSIVE ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  The House voted today to support President Nixon's move to give the nearly dormant Sub versive Activities Control Board some work in determining whether a score of organiza tions should be ilsted as sub versive.

title: Rockland Investigates a Prisoner's Fatal Overdose
description: Rockland County authorities have undertaken an investiga tion to determine how a county jail prisoner could have re ceived a fatal narcotics over dose while in jail.

title: Angela Davis Enters Plea; Trial Is to Begin Sept. 27
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 27 (AP)Angela Davis formally pleaded not guilty today to charges of murder, kidnapping and conspiracy. The judge or dered her trial to begin Sept. 27.

title: ARTHUR J. DAVIDSON
description: Arthur J. Davidson, for the last 18 years a copywriter with the ThompsonKoch Company, Inc., an advertising agency for Sterling Drug, Inc., died of a heart attack at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital on Mon day evening. He was 55 years old and lived at 1 University Place and Cornwall Bridge, Conn.

title: BIRTH DROP BRINGS TEACHER SURPLUS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The World War II baby boom has passed through the nation's public schools, leaving in its, wake the worst job market for teachers since the Depression.

title: Bank Plans Units Abroad
description: The Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angelesone of the nation's 10 largest bankshas applied to the Federal Reserve Board for permission to open branch offices in Tokyo and Frankfurt.

title: FAULTS FOUND IN AID TO MINORITY GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Government investigators re ported today that antipoverty programs designed to help mi nority groups set up their own businesses were only partly successful, largely because of a lack of managerial com petence.

title: Advertising
description: The word from our Scat of Government yesterday is that Smokey the Bear will not be the only denizen of our woodlands on Civil Service. That worldrenowned (but furry) fireprevention special ist is being joined by Wood sy, an owl, whose message will be Give a HootDon't Pollute.

title: Oil Refinery Agrees to Halt Pollution of Newtown Creek
description: A refinery accused of pollut ing Newtown Creek has agreed to halt discharge of oil and human waste into the stream by next April 12.

title: Laird Says Draft Will Call 100,000 Men This Fiscal Year, 50,000 Fewer Than Last
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that about 100,000 men would be drafted in the fiscal year 1972, a de crease of more than 50,000 men from the 1971 fiscal year.

title: TV: Offbeat World of Jules Feiffer
description: A dance, of journalistic sorts, to Jules Feiffer:

title: Badillo Attacks Troy on Queens Judgeship Pacts
description: Representative Herman Badillo charged yesterday that Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Democratic leader, showed an absolute, contempt for the people of Queens when he made series of agreements with the Republicans for the election of judges and others there.

title: CHILEAN OPPOSES U.S. COMPENSATION
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 27  The leader of the Socialist party, the largest in Chile's leftwing coalition Government, said today that United States investors should receive no compensation for nationaliza tion of copper mines here.

title: Mortgage Prices Decline At Fanny May's Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Mortgage prices declined further and yields correspondingly rose in a newtype auction of the Federal National Mortgage As sociation, it announced today.

title: 8 ACQUITTED IN TEST OF MAYDAY ARRESTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Eight persons arrested on the Capitol steps May 5 during antiwar demonstrations were acquitted today by a Superior Court jury of disorderly parad ing and unlawful entry.

title: Thoughts on Society: III
description: BELGRADEIn the last century Dostoyevsky sought to prove that there exists only one idea without which human life is impossible, and that is the idea of immortality of the soul. In our century Teillard de Char din took the same view. But in rela tion to the whole of mankind it is impossible to believe in progress and the future of mankind without belief in the immortality of mankind.

title: Notes on People
description: The first Eisenhower silver dollar to be minted was pre sented to Mrs. Dwight D. Ei senhower in a ceremony at the White House. Of limited coinage the new Ike dollar is only 40 per cent silver and you can't buy one for a dol lar. It cost $10, but in 25 years, President Nixon said, they'll bring enormous amounts from collectors. Asked to tilt a case contain ing Mrs. Eisenhower's dollar for photographers, Mr. Nixon protested mildly that it might fall out. If it does, he said, I'm going to catch it. Any dollar worth $10 I'm going to catch it.

title: Tucker, 25, Dies of Injuries Suffered in Bout With Cantin
description: MONTREAL, July 27 (AP) Danny Tucker died in a hospi tal today of injuries suffered in a junior welterweight bout last night with the Canadian champion, Reynald Cantin.

title: Bridge: Aces Defeated in the Spingold By Mathe Team's Late Rally
description: CHICAGO, July 27  Lew Mathe's foursome, which came from behind last night to oust the world champion Aces of Dallas from the Spin gold knockout team cham pionship, clashed in the final here today with the defend ing champions, headed by Joel Stuart.

title: U.S. Steel Cuts Payout as Profit Rises
description: The United States Steel Cor poration, the nation's largest steel producer, announced yes terday that it would cut its quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 60 cents, even though the concern also report ed that secondquarter earn ings were nearly double the yearearlier level.

title: One F.C.C. Telpak Ruling Is Affirmed, One Reversed
description: The Federal Appeals Court here has affirmed a ruling of the Federal Communications Commission that the Telpak rates offered by the American Telephone and Telegraph Com pany and the Western Union Corporation are discriminatory. However, the court reversed the F.C.C.'s ruling that would have required unlimited sharing.

title: SENATORS HOSTILE TO WELFARE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) The Senate Finance Committee opened hearings today on Presi dent Nixon's welfare reform plan, and conservative and lib eral members alike gave it a hostile reception despite an Ad ministration appeal for speedy action.

title: 5 Medina Jurors Are Selected For Tentative Quorum in Trial
Ecologists at a Hearing Score Stream Dredging
description: WASHINGTON, July 27A Senate subcommittee began looking today into an old and widespread conservation prac tice that is increasingly draw ing the opposition of the new conservationists.

title: Mars Shots on Course
description: MOSCOW, July 27 (AP)The Soviet Union reported today that its two Mars shots, launched May 19 an 28, are on course and operating according to program. The Mars crafts are expected to reach the planet in November.

title: LLOYD SANDFORD, 54, NATURE ILLUSTRATOR
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., July 27Lloyd Sandford, a profes sional illustrator of nature sub jects, died yesterday in Hack ensack Hospital of injuries re ceived in an automobile acci dent. He was 54 years old and lived at 3103 Garrison Terrace, Fair Lawn.

title: Demilitarizer of the Campus
description: Man in the News

title: Smut Drive To Include New Tactic
description: As part of their crackdown on obscenity, plainclothes po licemen armed with movie cameras and tape recorders will go into theaters showing allegedly pornographic films and make movies of the movies. The reproductions will then be brought before a judge for him to determine whether the original films should be seized.

title: ShangriLa to Bow Out
description: BOSTON, July 27 (Reuters) The aircraft carrier ShangriLa will be decommissioned at the Boston Navy Yard Friday. The 40,000ton vessel, launched Sept. 15, 1944, saw service in World War II, the Korean War and was on active duty in the Tonkin Gulf in support of troops in Vietnam. She will re main in the reserve fleet.

title: Betting Office Repays Part of City Loan
description: The Offtrack Betting Corpor ation made the first payment yesterday on its $4.8million loan from the city.

title: The Ambassador to Bow In London as a Musical
description: A new musical, The Ambas sadors. based on the Henry James novel. The Ambassa dors, will be presented in Lon don this season by three Ameri can producers, Gene Dincrenary, Miranda d'Ancona and Nancy Levering. Howard Keel and Da nielle Derrieux have been signed for costarring roles.

title: Feed Found Contaminated; 77,000 Chickens Are Killed
description: WILKESBORO, N. C., July 27 (AP)At least 77,000 broiler chickens have been destroyed by a packing company here after tests showed that some of them had been contamin ated by a chemical suspected of causing birth defects and liver damage in experiments on mice.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, July 27 (Reu ters)The East Pakistan refu gee problem has no parallel in human history, Col. M. D. Erla of the League of Red Cross So cieties said here today. Colonel Erla, a Norwegian, is here to help the Indian Red Cross aid the seven million refugees who have crossed from East Paki stan.

title: ENEMY BLOWS UP 4 U.S. HELICOPTERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 28 (AP) Enemy demolition men stole into an allied base 30 miles north of here in predawn dark ness yesterday, blew up four American helicopters and dam aged a fifth.

title: GATT Economic Study Sees Japan Ending Bogeyman Role
description: GENEVA, July 27  Vast changes that are looming in Japan's economy should mean that this new industrial giant will be shedding the role of bogeyman for the other devel oped countries in world mar kets, according to international trade authorities.

title: Urban Renewal Threatens Seattle Market
description: SEATTLEThe Pike Place Market is a remnant of an other age, another, simpler America. Now it is caught up in a community struggle that is peculiar to the late years of the 20th century.

title: President Appointed At Sperry Rand Corp.
description: The Sperry Rand Corpora tion yesterday named J. Paul Lyet as president, allowing J. Frank Forster to remove one of his three corporate hats. Mr. Forster will remain chair man and chief executive of ficer.

title: The Case of The Petal Paper
description: FAIRHOPE, Ala. At 8 o'clock on the morning of Nov. 26, 1921, I was born in the small town of Columbia, Miss. In less than a week my mother had let me for adoption.

title: Nock of Jets Is Artful About Football
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 27 Because the Mets have first call on Shea Stadium, the Jets will have to play out of town during the month of Septem ber. However, George Nock will be on exhibit that month in New York at Madison Square Garden.

title: 16YearOld Tried Suicide at Girls Center Here
description: A 16yearold girl who was abandoned when she was 7 and has been in childcare in stitutions most of her life at tempted suicide on July 16 at Callagy Hall, a cityoperated shelter for troubled and home less girls.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVING PERCUSSION BY TJADER QUINTET
description: Although Cal Tjader's quin tet is classified as a Latinjazz group, it would be more ac curate to call it a fiveman rhythm section.

title: Peru Presses Reform by Blending Cooperatives and Capitalism
description: LIMA, July 27Chile has a Socialist President and Bolivia has a leftist assembly, but the 33monthold military Govern ment of Peru has gone farther and faster toward decreeing radical social change than its leftist neighbors while remain ing hard to place on the tradi tional political spectrum.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: ALBANY, July 27A former Nassau County racketsbureau chief said today the licenses of Yonkers Raceway officers should be revoked if the cur rent harnessracing investiga tion proves that underworld figures were allowed to fre quent the track.

title: Uniroyal Recalls Tire
description: Uniroyal Inc. yesterday re called 3,200 of its Fastrak dual white sidewall tires he cause of possible defects that might result in bulging of the treads or loss of pieces of the tread stock. The tires recalled are size L 7815 with the serial identification number V3C4 231. made in June.

title: Discount Rate Cut to 5%
description: TOKYO, July 27 (UPI)The Bank of Japan announced today the lowering of the central bank interest rate for the fourth time in nine months to help stimulate Japan's sluggish economy.

title: Lockheed: Politics and Principles
description: The Administration has run into much heavier Con gressional opposition than it expected in its effort to push through a bill authorizing $2 billion in loan guaran tees for companies in serious financial trouble, with $250 million earmarked for the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Cambodians Open Drive
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 27 (AP)The Cambodian com mand announced a drive by 5,000 Government troops about 40 miles north of the capital today.

title: City Housing Loan Board Is Sworn In
description: A new housing board created by the Legislature at its recent session and authorized to lend $700million for housing for lowincome families was sworn in yesterday at City Hall by Mayor Lindsay.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I.R. to Meet With Trainmen; A Walkout Today Is Postponed
description: Officials of the Long Island Railroad and a union represent ing 1,600 of its trainmen are to meet in Washington this morning in an attempt to reach agreement on a contract.

title: The 14th Execution
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Wednesday, July 28The Om durman radio announced today that the head of the Sudanese Communist party, Abdel Kha lek Mahgoub had been hanged. The announcement came a few hours after the execution was reported of Joseph G'aratig, a former Sudanese cabinet min ister.

title: Swindler Tells Senators How He Gained Millions
description: WASHINGTON, July 27A confidence man from Boston, who turned state's evidence after he was convicted in a securities fraud case, enter tained the Senate Permanent Investigations Subcommittee today with tales of stolen and counterfeit securities, loan sharking, credit card swindles, car theft rings and gambling junkets.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortgage Prices Decline At Fanny May's Auction
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Mortgage prices declined further and yields correspondingly rose in a newtype auction of the Federal National Mortgage As sociation, it announced today.

title: 50,000 Phone Workers Continue Strike in State
description: Fifty thousand telephone workers in the state remained on strike yesterday as leaders of 16 upstate locals of the Com munications Workers of Amer ica met in Albany to coordinate activities with locals in the metropolitan area.

title: Students' Poems of Anguish Become Song Lyrics
description: A year ago, they were poets. Today, they are song writers.

title: SOCIAL ORIENTATION URGED ON FREUDIANS
description: VIENNA, July 27  Freudi ans were warned today that all our theories are going to be carried away by history unless psychoanalysis is ap plied to social problems.

title: Soviet Stages Protests
description: MOSCOW, July 27The So viet Union today began a na tionwide protest against the antiCommunist campaign in the Sudan and appealed to the Khartoum authorities to spare the life of Mohammed Abdel Khalek Mahgoub, head of the Communist party.

title: U.S. Antipoverty Chief Shifted To a High Post in Budget Office
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 For the second time in eight months, the Office of Econom ic Opportunity lost its direc tor to the White House today.

title: DR. MICHAILOVSKY
description: Dr. Benjamin Michailovsky, a physician who practiced here from 1908 to 1966, died Mon day in a Huntington (L.I.) nurs ing home at the age of 91.

title: 3,000 on Welfare Assigned to Work For City Agencies
description: The city's Human Resources Administrator announced yes terday that 3,000 welfare re cipients would be assigned to publicworks projects for city agencies in August.

title: BOLT WILL DIRECT G.E.'S FIRST FILM
description: Tomorrow Entertainment, Inc., the show business subsidiary of General Electric incorporated last December, will produce its first motion picture, Lamb, in association with Pulsar Produc tions, Ltd., of London, and Vides Cinematographica SaS of Rome.

title: 40 Feared Drowned in India
description: NEW DELHI, July 27 (UPI) At least 40 persons crossing the Kharia River in West Bengal were feared drowned when their boat sank in midstream today, the Press Trust of India reported. The accident occurred near Palashipara about 100 miles north of Calcutta, the news agency said. Fifteen other passengers swam ashore.

title: Pennsy Gain Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 James M. Beggs, the Under Secretary of Transportation, expressed confidence today in the Penn Central railroad's delicate improvement since it filed for reorganization and said the Nixon Administration would look favorably on new Government loans to advance the railroad's recovery next year.

title: State Approves $35Million Manhattan Hospital
description: The State Health Department announced approval yesterday of 27 construction and renova tion proiects in hospitals and other health facilities here, in cluding the construction of a new $35million hospital in Manhattan.

title: First U.S. Deficit in Trade Since '93 Called Possible
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans warned Congress to day that the United States might have a negative balance Of trade this year for the first time in this century.

title: CHARLES A. SMITH, 69, NEWSMAN IN LONDON
description: LONDON, July 27  Charles' A. Smith, senior American newspaper correspondent in London, died here last night at the age of 69. He was the Lon don representative of Hearst newspapers and of King Fea tures Syndicate.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF AS VOLUME RISES
description: After a dull morning, stocks on the American Stock Ex change dropped sharply yester day in a busy afternoon session. The index closed at 25.18, down 0.20, the sharpest decline since June 21. Volume jumped from 2,542,160 shares on Monday to 3,340,210.

title: Rules of Economics
description: Economic Analysis

title: Tucker, 25, Dies of Injuries Suffered in Bout With Cantin
description: MONTREAL, July 27 (AP) Danny Tucker died in a hospi tal today of injuries suffered in a junior welterweight bout last night with the Canadian champion, Reynald Cantin.

title: 3 FOREIGNERS ADMIT BOMB PLOT IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, July 27Three women were convicted by a military court today in connec tion with a plot to bomb a dozen crowded hotels during the EasterPassover season.

title: Treasury Bill Yields Rise at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Yields on United States Treas ury bills rose in the Gov ernment's monthly competi tive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Red Tide Sweeps Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, July 27 (AP) A noxious, fishkilling red tide has swept into Southern California coastal sections. The tide, resulting from dying plank tan microorganisms is harm less to humans. It flourishes in warm air and water tempera tures.

title: Workshop Festival Presents Program Of Dance Oddities
description: In the second week of its summer festival, Dance Thea ter Workshop presented a pro gram of choreographic oddities. These ranged from the mysti cally still LightPart V by Kei Takei to the cartoon gro tesque Eulalie/Ulalume by John Wilson, and all were seen at the American Theater Labo ratory on Monday evening.

title: Senate G.O.P. Chief Backs Restrictions on President's Warmaking Powers
description: WASHINGTON, July 27  Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate Republican leader, threw his support today behind proposals to put legislative re strictions on the warmaking powers of the Presidency.

title: Mitchell Creates a New Strike Force on Crime
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI)  A new anticrime strike force of five Federal lawyers went into action today. Justice Department sources said its target was a key figure in crime syndicate infiltration of legitimate financial circles.

title: MiddleAged BlueCollar Workers Tell Senate Panel They Lost Pension Rights
description: WASHINGTON, July 27A succession of bluecollar wit nesses, mostly union workers in their late forties and fifties, told the Senate Subcommittee on Labor today that they had lost their pension rights.

title: Advertising
description: Among the graduates of Fairleigh Dickinson's College of Business in May was John Schaffer, a 22yearold from Elizabeth, N. J., with an eye toward an advertising career. He picked some year for it.

title: AUGUST L. FRANKE
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 27 August L. Franke, a founding partner in QW Laboratories, makers of specialty items for the travel business, died today in Muhlenberg Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 935 Myrtle Avenue.

title: CHAIRMAN ELECTED AT BROWNFORMAN
description: Robinson S. Brown Jr., 54 years old, has been elected chairman of the BrownForman Distillers Corporation, it was announced yesterday in Louis ville, Ky. He was formerly executive vice president and director of marketing. He suc ceeds his cousin, W. L. Lyons Brown, 65, who retired.

title: Italian Party Acts
description: ROME, July 27The Italian, Communist party today con demned the execution of lead ers of last week's coup in the Sudan and urged an end to, repression.

title: Comecon Premiers Convene On Economic Integration
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, July 27Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union and the premiers of seven other Com munist member countries of Comecon, the East European economic alliance, met here this morning to draw up a plan for economic integration that would satisfy both its proponents and opponents. Yugoslavia is at tending as an observer.

title: Yorty Bids O'Brien Resign
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles called today for the resignation of the Demo cratic national chairman, Law rence F. O'Brien, for what Mr. Yorty said was Mr. O'Brien's refusal to list him among po tential Presidential candidates in the 1972 election. O'Brien does not consult with us when he lists the candidates or meets with them, Mr. Yorty said at a news conference.

title: Newark's Policemen and Firemen Get No Raises in First Pact
description: NEWARK, July 27Police men and firemen signed their first contracts with the city today but received no salary increases.

title: Soviet Launches Satellite
description: MOSCOW, July 28 (Reuters) The Soviet Union launched today another Molniya 1 com munications satellite, the of ficial press agency, Tass, report ed.

title: Cindy Lyon Captures Title In Resail of Y.R.A. Series
description: MORICHES, L. I., July 28 Cindy Lyon of the Wet Pants Association captured the re sail series for the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association women's championship today, winning by half a point from Mrs. Louise Rice Baker of the Westhampton Yacht Squadron. Miss Lyon, had 21 points.

title: Notes on People
description: Throwing caution, not to mention himself, to the winds, Prince Charles, the 22yearold heir to the Brit ish throne, parachuted from a plane 1,200 feet over the English Channel.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif., July 28 (UPI)Daryle Lamonica ended his 10day holdout today by agreeing to a twoyear contract with the Oakland Raiders. The 30yearold quarterback would not disclose the amount he was being paid but it was reported to be $68,000 a year. He will be starting his ninth pro season.

title: COLOMBIANS ORDER HILTON COMPANY OUT
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, July 28 (AP)Hilton International has been ordered out of Colombia before it could open its 40 Story hotel here.

title: Light in Ulster
description: WASHINGTON, July 28Ireland was the first British colony and the first to break free. When the British gave independence to Southern Ireland in 1922, after four years of terrorism and guerrilla warfare, they started down the long road of imperial with drawal that was to wind through India, Palestine, Kenya and Cyprus.

title: Lockheed Greek Role Reported
description: PARIS, July 28 (AP) Aristotle Onassis's Olympic Airways, the financially troubled Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration and Les Avions Mar cel Dassault of France are pro posing creation of an infant Greek aviation industry in co operation with the military gov ernment, industry sources re ported today.

title: U.S. Not Disturbed
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 United States officials had no public comment today on Pre mier Chou's conditions for es tablishing relations with Wash ington. Privately, however, au thoritative officials said the White House and the State De partment were not disturbed over Mr. Chou's statements.

title: Credit Markets: Bond Prices Advance,
description: The corporate bond market, which had been drifting down ward for more than a week, rallied yesterday in the face of news that could have been ex pected to push interest rates higher.

title: Gasoline Station Operators Sue To Bar Tax on Leaded Products
description: Associations representing New York City gasoline serv ice station operators filed suit in State Supreme Court yester day to block the imposition of a special centagallon city tax on leaded gasoline sold here beginning Aug. 1.

title: COURT ROUND LOST BY I.O.S. CHAIRMAN
description: NEWARK, July 28Federal District Judge Reynier J. Wor tendyke Jr. signed papers here yesterday directing the Securi ties and Exchange Commission to submit a proposed judgment against Robert L. Vesco, chair man of Investors Overseas Serv ices, Ltd., and of the InternaI tional Controls Corporation, Fairfield, N. J.

title: HILLMAN BISHOP, 69, OF CITY COLLEGE DIES
description: Prof. Hillman M. Bishop, who taught political science at City College for 39 years, died yes terday of a heart attack in his residence in Butler Hall, 400 West 119th Street. He was 69 years old.

title: House Banking Group Backs $960Million for World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, July 28An important element of President Nixon's foreign aid program cleared its first Congressional hurdle today.

title: U.S. Poloists Win
description: MIDHURST, England, July 28 (AP)  Greenhill Farm, an American polo team, scored a 55 victory over Windsor Park, led by Prince Philip, in the first round of the Cowd ray Park Challenge Cup today. Philip scored one goal.

title: No Rabies Found in Bear
description: DENVER, July 28 (UPI)  The Colorado Health Depart ment said today that a series of tests had failed to show any signs of rabies in a black bear that is believed to have mauled to death John H. Richardson, 31 years old, of Denver. The bear was shot to death Monday about two miles from the Grand Lake area camp in the Colorado Rockies where the attack oc curred. Mr. Richardson's fiance, Linda More, 27, of Van Nuys, Calif., was bitten.

title: Ulster: the Gap Widens
description: Every moment of light and hope in Northern Ireland seems to be followed inexorably by fresh bloodshed that intensifies the sectarian strife and polarizes fur ther the politics of the volatile province. Discussion Prime Minister Faulkner's plans for revamping the Stormont Parliament to give the Catholic minority a share in policymaking was halted abruptly by new outbreaks that took the lives of two Catholic youths and two British soldiers.

title: WILLIAM OSBORN SR. OF PHELPS DODGE, 76
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 28 William H. Osborn Sr., a re tired officer of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, copper pro ducer and fabricator, died in his sleep today. He was 76 years old and lived also at East 77th Street, New York.

title: American Indians Must Not Stop Running
description: ST. FRANCIS, S. D.Whenever there is a break in the weather, the teenagers start running on the Rose bud Sioux Reservation. Indian boys are racing through South Dakota pastures with atavistic dignity and ease, never landing on a cow chip but never seeming to avoid them, speeding but somehow not seeming to hurry. There is an unreal, Fellinilike quality to the silent scene when they reach a distant field and sail around a turn, visible but unheard. The girls are run ning too, down the Spring Creek road, and charting their mileage on a high school poster. They are special young people with special surnames like Black Spotted Horse, Eagleman, Owns Fire Crow Good Voice.

title: Senate Vote in 2d Try For Lockheed Closure
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)Following is the roll call by which the Senate failed today to invoke closure (twothirds majority required) to limit debate on the Lock heed loanguarantee bill:

title: BOARD RULES OUT BERRIGAN PAROLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The United States Board of Parole decided today not to parole the Rev. Philip F. Berri gan and the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, Roman Catholic priests imprisoned for destroy ing draft board records.

title: Doubling of U. S. Funds for Arts And Humanities Nears Passage
description: In an impressive demonstra tion of bipartisan support for the nation's arts and humani ties, a conference committee of the Senate and House has agreed to appropriate $61.21 million for the National Arts and Humanities Endowments in fiscal 1972.

title: Moscow's Cautious Reaction
description: It took the Soviet Union's Politburo more than a week to make up its mind how to react to the news of Presi dent Nixon's invitation to visit Peking. That reaction, printed in Pravda, is cautious and reserved, aimed pri marily at reassuring the Soviet people while keeping all of Moscow's options open. If Pravda is to be believed, the Kremlin rulers are not excited about the news, are anxious to have good relations with both Peking and Washington, and will keep their eyes open to make sure Soviet interests are guarded against any possible future SinoAmerican machinations.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue a list yesterday.

title: A PLAN IS OFFERED ON TROOP PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Nixon Administration and Senate conferees were reported today to have worked out a compromise on the amendment on troop withdrawals from Vietnam that they hope will be acceptable to the House con ferees and Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader.

title: STOCKS RETREAT ON ABROAD FRONT
description: A barrage of bad news bat tered the stock market yester day, shooting holes in individ ual issues and sending popular averages to their lowest levels in more than five months.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: LIBERTY, Mo., July 28 (UPI), E. J. Holub, who has had nine operations on his legs, has left the Kansas City Chiefs' training camp after suffering another knee injury.

title: RailAirBus Center Planned by M.T. A. At Republic Airport
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 28 Plans for the nation's first railairbusauto center, to be built at Republic Airport here, were announced today by Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority.

title: Myron B. Bush, Councilman In Cincinnati, Is Dead at 60
description: CINCINNATI, July 29My ron B. Bush, who was serving his seventh year in the City Council, died here last night at Jewish Hospital, after a cere bral hemorrhage. His age was 60.

title: Executive Changes
description: The American Can Company announced yesterday the election of Lawrence Lachman to the board directors. Mr. Lachman is chairman and chief exec utive officer of Bloomingdale's, a division of Fed erated Department Stores, Inc. He is a trustee the Dry Dock Savings Bank and chairman of the New York Better Business Bureau.

title: $5,299.20 Doable Opens Del Mar's 43Day Meet
description: DEL MAR, Calif., July 28 (UPI)Party Suit and Bold Thrust produced a record Del Mar Race Track daily double payoff of $5,299.20 today, the opening day of a 43day meeting.

title: Work Rules Called Key to Pennsy Gain
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Trustees of the Penn Central told the Senate today that with modern work rulesincluding a basic threeman crew in freight service  they would never need another Govern ment loan and could be op erating the bankrupt railroad profitably as soon as 1973.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 28President Nixon's approach to Peking, no mat ter how welcome it may be, was planned in secrecy, decided by Presi dential fiat, carried out clandestinely and finally announced only as accom plished fact. Thus, whatever else it was, this grand diplomatic undertak ing was another exercise in executive omnipotence. Though aimed at peace, the operation so far has not been much different from the hidden proc esses that carried the nation into the war in Vietnam, and its consequences could be even more farreaching.

title: Couturiers (2d Team) Also Shine
description: PARIS, July 28The Paris couture sent in its second team today, most of the big guns having sent off their rockets earlier in the week. Only Givenchy and Courrges among the major houses have not yet shown their wares.

title: U.S. Bars Some Flammable Sleepwear
description: WASHINGTON, July 28  The Commerce Department im posed regulations today that ban the sale of flammable sleepwear for children after July, 1973.

title: What's a Big Trend at Fancy Foods Show? Organic, Naturally
description: Corks popped from bottles of non alcoholic champagne. And as 12,000 fancy food retailers strolled by more than 1,000 booths at the Coliseum this week, they inspected, and sometimes tasted, new and old sweetmeats and specialties ranging from a new kind of pacifier made in France out of gelatin candy to spicy Japanese cocktail crack ers called NipNaks.

title: Preminger Joining Nizer For SpyTrial TV Movie
description: Otto Preminger and Louis Nizer, two stars in different firmaments, will collaborate on a fictionalized twohour tele vision film based on the trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the executed atomsecret spies.

title: 2 U.S. Copters Downed
description: SAIGON, Thursday, July 29 (Reuters)Two United States helicopters were shot down and destroyed in two separate inci dents in the Mekong Delta yes terday, a military spokesman said here today.

title: June Trade Gap Widened;
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 The alreadypoor United States foreign trade figures worsened further in June, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Group Here to Begin Search For Evidence of Human Soul
description: Man's search for his im mortal soul may lead him next to a fivestory town house at 5 West 73d Street, home of the American So ciety for Psychical Research.

title: California Standard Gains
description: Net income of the Standard Oil Company of California in this year's second quarter rose to $127,043,000, or $1.50 a share from $107,401,000, or $1.27 a share, in the second period, a year ago.

title: AUSTERITY PROGRAM URGED IN BELGRADE
description: BELGRADE, July. 28Yugo slavia's outgoing Cabinet asked end  of  session parliamentary approval today for a package of urgent austerity measures designed to curb the country's 14 per cent costofliving rise and reduce the paymonts defi cit that has reached nearly $700million this year.

title: MRS. GANDHI SEEKS TO WIDEN POWERS
description: NEW DELHI, July 28The Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi moved today to empower parliament to over ride fundamental rights guar anteed by the Indian Constitu tion.

title: Bethlehem's Net Up 82%;
description: Three more steel companies reported yesterday sharp in creases in secondquarter earn ings, compared with those of the yearearlier period. They were:

title: GOVERNOR SCORES U.S. POLLUTION AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 Governor Rockefeller charged today that the Nixon Adminis tration's uncoordinated efforts were causing confusion and delay in the battle against wa ter pollution.

title: City Reports Epidemic Of Food ShortWeighting
description: Consumer Affairs Com missioner Bess Myerson dis closed yesterday that 87 per cent of more than 2,000 food items bought by her depart ment at the city's leading chain supermarkets recently were shortweighted.

title: Sudan Says 1,000 May Still Stand Trial
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 28The Sudanese Information Minister said today that morel than 1,000 persons still faced possible prosecution for com plicity in the shortlived leftist coup d'Uat against Premier Gaafar alNimeiry last week.

title: Jane's Says U.S. Fleet Declines While Soviet Has a Supernavy
description: LONDON, Thursday, July 29 (AP)A British military expert said today that American naval strength is in a serious decline while the Soviet fleet has ex panded into a supernavy with a greatly increased sphere of influence.

title: Personal Finance
description: For some years there has been a little sex discrimina tion in some aspects of the tax law. One involves wives and their husbands' fraud or other deficiency in reporting income.

LloydJones, executive vice president for finance.

title: Farmingdale Is Split Over Terminal
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 28  Three and a half years ago, Frank, the only name he's known by to his customers, bought the Blue Dolphin Restaurant, across from Re public Field.

description: LONDON, July 28 (Reuters) Three underground magazine editors were found guilty of obscenity today. They were Richard Neville, James Ander son and Felix Dennis of the magazine Oz.

title: SILVER FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Silver, reflecting gold's strength, was up in price and actively traded yesterday in New York's commodity mar kets yesterday. Gold has gone up to $42 an ounce in Europe, a twoyear high.

description: Chainstore sales in June rose 11.2 per cent, compared to those of yearago month, ac cording to a survey by The New York Times. Sales for the first six months went ahead of the 1970 half by 9.3 per cent.

title: Five Die in Maryland Crash
description: CONOWINGO, Md., July 28 (AP)  Five persons died early today when a tractortrailer collided with two passenger cars on U.S. 222 onequarter mile south of the Pennsylvania state line. Killed were James K. Adams, 20 years old, of Not tingham, Pa.; Warren E. Green, 22, of Peach Bottom, Pa.; Ray mond W. Carr Jr., 19, of Con owingo; Raymond H. Blakely, 20, of Colora, Md., and Roy D. Thompson, 17, of Port Deposit, Md., the state police said.

title: Lawyers in the People's Republic
description: There are about 350,000 lawyers in the United States with 20,000 more persons admitted to practice each year. Much of our legal theory and structure is built around the fact that large numbers of specialists are avail able to staff the legal system and act as advisers to the public.

title: Stage: Ewell In Waiting for Godot
description: Tom Ewell played Vladimir in the first American produc tion of Waiting for Godot in Miami Beach in 1956, but before Godot reached Broadway, both he and the director, Alan Schneider, had left the show. Last February, Schneider finally staged Godot in New York and re cently Ewell joined the cast. Last night, at the Sheridan Square Playhouse, he faced the New York critics for the first time in the part he cre ated. Ewell's Vladimir is, un questionably, the greatest performance of his career.

title: MobilIranian Oil Hunt Set
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation has signed a partnership agree ment with the National Iranian Oil Company to explore about 1,500 square miles off Iran in the Strait of Hormoz, at the eastern end of the Persian Gulf.

title: Tannen and Co. Add Fuel to Jet Title Hopes
description: HEMPSTEAD, LI., July 28 I wouldnt want to say too much before the season even began, but right now they're looking so good out there that it scares me, said Walt Michaels, the New York Jets' assistant coach in charge of the line backers and the defensive back field.

title: Sisco Arrives in Israel

Khrushchev proposed a meeting with him that Mr. Kennedy first seemed to sup port but rejected later in the day.

The Navy said the Dickson, on a training cruise for Naval re servists, was floated free at 2:40 A.M. today after having lost steering control and gone aground at 4 P.M. yesterday.

title: Variations in Gravity Complicate Flight
description: HOUSTON, July 28  The Apollo 15 astronauts are sail ing toward their destination through a sea of moving and contending gravitational fields. As on no previous space flight, the success of their mission de pends on accurate analysis of those fields and of their ef fects.

description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 28  Mayor Lindsay of New York, described by smiling aides as a nonpolitical college lecturer, picked the issue on which President Nixon is thought to be most politically vulnerable  the economy  for a sharp attack here tonight.

description: A patrolman who is being sought with two other men in a $143,000 robbery at the Mu nicipal Building on July 9 was described yesterday by his col leagues, friends and neighbors as the kind of man who could do no wrong.

description: Jim Dawson, a folk singer from Denver now living in New York, is appearing through Sunday at Folk City, 130 West Third Street.

title: PRICES ON AMEX OFF FOR 5TH DAY
description: Prices continued to weaken yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, taking the in dex down to 25.00, or 0.181 below Tuesday's close. It was the fifth losing session in a row.

title: A Misguided 'Billy Jack'
description: For a picture that preaches pacifism, "Billy Jack" seems fascinated by violence, of which it is full. The title hero of this well-aimed but misguided drama is a muscular young Indian, an ex-Green Beret, who periodically appears to save a "freedom school," a group of idealistic young people, from bald harassment by small-town bigots and worse.That's the set-up of the film, nicely photographed in color. And some of the sensible utterances of the harassed youngsters have the quiet, authoritative ring of truth. While Tom Laughlin is a stoically effective Billy, the strongest thing about the film is Delores Taylor, as the school head. A plain-faced young woman, making her first movie, she somehow makes a flat, singsong monotone as penetrating as a lance.But the rest of the picture works none too well, under the rather studied direction of T. C. Frank. And some of the non-professional delivery of lines in the script by Mr. Frank and Teresa Christina is incredibly awful.Furthermore, the violence commences to pile on predictably and endlessly, with an assortment of town bullies and psychopaths right out of Western stereotypes. As for the folks out at the school, which often amounts to a stockade, they certainly are a genial, harmless bunch, bent on doing their own thing. But some of their guitar whimpering is terrible and several of those "now" pantomimes, meant to be amusing, are too cute for words.The whole picture nicely conveys a Southwestern atmosphere. But much too often, at the cost of plain credibility, it stacks its cards, characters and even credo like any rootin', tootin' Western.

title: Von Richthofen and Brown' Opens
description: "Von Richthofen and Brown," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is an extraordinarily impressive movie by a filmmaker whose career has not always been marked by success, or even noble failure. Everyone identifies Roger Corman as a director of horror and action, and almost everyone knows the underground reputation according to which, say, "XThe Man With X-ray Eyes" becomes a phenomenological investigation, and "The Masque of the Red Death" a major essay in cinematic style.But people tend to forget the Corman movies that only make money, if that, of which there have been a fair number recently and to which "Von Richthofen and Brown" stands in gratifying contrast.In outline it is a film of great simplicity, following the careers of the German, Manfred Freiherr von Richthofen and the Canadian, Arthur Royal Brown from the time they join their respective fighter-plane units near the front during World War I until the day in April, 1918, when von Richthofen is killed in the air, presumably by a bullet fired from Brown's Sopwith Camel.Much of the film's material must have originated in the minds of Corman or his screen writers, but its major events appear to be factincluding the final, near magical landing of the red Fokker triplane almost intact, carrying the body of the dead baron.By this last most beautiful and mysterious transformationin a film that rather specializes in mysterious, beautiful transformationsvon Richthofen is made still in time, having become his own memorial. And Brown, the type of the modern man ("I'm just a technician. I change things. Put a man and a plane in front of me and I change them into a wreck and a corpse . . .") has become the creator of that memorial. The accounts I have read of air war are of course full of von Richthofen; but they mention Brown only in connection with von Richthofen's death.However, it is not the film's intention to reproduce history so much as it is to produce something more like a philosophical meditation on historical process, interpreted dramatically and interspersed with episodes of mortal combat. The project may seem all too easy, with von Richthofen, the reckless aristocrat and former cavalry officer done in by the efficient, common Brownand often enough it is too easy as von Richthofen (John Phillip Law) is exactly balanced by Brown (Don Stroud, the best of several good performances), many of whose lines seem composed as if in dialogue with a man he never meets.But if you can take the idea of a philosophical meditation seriously, as I think the film does, then something happens, not so much to the talk as to the framework, to the magnificent aerial fights, which are important not for their suspense (they are not very suspenseful) or for their beauty but for their quality of almost disembodied freedom.They are very realin the sense that they capture the feeling of flight as a privileged way of being rather than as superheated adventure. But they are also very strange. And Corman uses them for his most mystical demonstrations of how one thing becomes another, in which what goes up never comes down quite the same.There are a good many embarrassments in the film, and not the least is the decision to have all the Germans speak rather slangy English but with heavy German accents. Language itself becomes a problem in one scene, in which von Richthofen is introduced to his famous Fokker, which is identified with a gorgeously seductive blonde (typically, Brown's female contact is a French girl who has lost a leg) who sings him a song that begins, I swear, "High is up, my hero, like a fabled knight of old. . . ."This is either terrible translation or, given the general drift of "Von Richthofen and Brown," the first stage in a teleological argument.

title: On Any Sunday':Bruce Brown's Documentary Studies the Motorcyclist's View of Racing
description: Some men hunt the great white shark. Some men join roller derbies, while others go to the moon. Some men like to knit. Some are freefall parachutists. Some spend their lives searching for the perfect woman or the perfect movie or the perfect wave. With the possible exception of knitting, all of these endeavors involve an element of risk, either physical or psychological, to such an extent that the attainment of the end becomes less important than the excitation provided by the pursuit itself.Five years ago Bruce Brown recorded one, round-the-world search for the perfect wave in "The Endless Summer," which was a very beautiful movie to look at (especially from the relative safety of a cloudy smoking section) andI've now come to thinkmuch less simple-minded than it originally sounded.On the basis of his new film, "On Any Sunday," a feature-length documentary about motorcycles and the men who ride them in apparent pleasurable competition, Brown stands in way of becoming the unofficial poet of the sports world. He not only records and shares with us the often extraordinary physical sensations experienced by the cyclists, but he also manages to suggest, in the absolutely flat language of the nonverbal participants, that the joy of the sport may also be the mask that hides a curse.Like clean-cut, monosyllabic Flying Dutchmen, Mert Lawwill and Malcolm Smith, the professional cyclists whose exploits Brown follows through the film, lead lives of enchanted circularity: the winning of one event is not as much a goal as the preface to still another competition, and another after that. The monetary rewards are never great and, often enough, the prizes are simply trophies. At the end of one race in which death might not have been too far removed, Brown, as his own narrator, is likely to say with his unerring knack for the anticlimactic comment: "There stands Malcolm with a big grin."Malcolm himself is likely to say: "That was really neat:"It is not as silly as it sounds because the shape of the lives recorded by Brown are almost necessarily anticlimactic; that is, until someone gets hurt or (off-screen) killed.The movie itself is anything but anticlimactic. By putting his cameras on the cycles, Brown achieves audience-participation effects with speed that amount to marvelous delirium. The camera work is fancy, but it's a fanciness for a specific purpose, and "On Any Sunday" is the first film I can remember in months in which I thoroughly enjoyed the slow-motion, the zooms, the helicopter shots, the superimpositions and all those other techniques that are the tired rhetoric of the narrative cinema.There is, I suspect, no other way by which to communicate the sense of the intoxication that is the real goal of the cyclists, and that can only be realized through the intensification of all the perceptions.Brown records just about every kind of cycling competition there is, going from southern California to Spain and back again, catching drivers who insist on racing with broken legs, broken noses, and, in one instance, with a back broken six weeks before in an especially hazardous competition. "What kind of men are these?" Brown asks, and the answer comes not from what anyone says, but from the crazy, sensational motion of the film, which is, I feel, in its own way, a remarkable adventure, as simple and as unique to film as the picturization of movement."On Any Sunday" which opened yesterday at the Murray Hill, was, I understand, financed by Steve McQueen, who also shows up in the film from time to time as the very creditable cyclist he is.

title: NAGY IN PEAK FORM DANCING IN ETUDES
description: Harald Lander's ballet, Etudes, serves two useful purposes. By taking ordinary classroom exercises out of the studio and into the theater, it offers a Reader's Digest type of compressed view of the dancer's training that never fails to exert some fascination over the uninitiated. On an other level, it becomes a show case for the entire company and its soloists.

title: Screen:

description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 29.No kickoffs, no punts, no runbacks and precious few running backs will be seen in the New York Giants' controlled scrimmage here Saturday morning, but a crowd of about 8,000 still is expected at the C. W. Post campus to see how a football team prepares for a season.

title: METROMEDIA BUYS TWIN CITIES STATION
description: Metromedia, Inc., which owns and operates WNEWTV here, announced yesterday that it had purchased from ChrisCraft Industries, Inc., all issued and outstanding stock of WTCNTV in MinneapolisSt. Paul. The pur chase, for $18million in cash, is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Com mission.

title: SENATE UNIT ACTS ON SECRECY ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, countering what it considers secrecy in the execu tive branch, has moved to sus pend all foreign military aid unless the Defense Department supplies its fiveyear plans for the military assistance pro gram.

title: Saigon Panel Lifts Ban On 65 House Candidates
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29  A number of anti Government candidates won permission today on appeal to run in South Vietnam's lower house elections next month.

title: IMPORT CHARGES URGED BY MILLS
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Representative Wilbur D. Mills proposed today that every consideration be given to im position by the United States of an acrosstheboard sur charge on imports and an equivalent rebate on exports as a means of improving the United States balance of trade and hence the overall balance of international payments.

title: Concern Voiced in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Friday, July 30  Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the influential Cairo editor, ex pressed concern today about wave of brutality and vio lence that has swept the Arab world in the last several weeks.

title: PESTICIDES UNABLE TO HALT MOSQUITO
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 29 (AP)A type of mosquito that can infect humans with deadly sleeping sickness is reported out of control in California because it has developed im munity to all known pesticides.

title: Contesting Papal Authority
description: The authority of the Pope is now being hotly contested by Dr. Hans Kling. In particular, the selection of conservative as the new bishop of Rotterdam has been depicted by Dr. Kling as a misuse of papal authority. With ever greater urgency, basic ques tions are now raised. Does orthodoxy require each Catholic to hail all deci sions of the Pope, even if some of them seem ill advised? Is dissent from papal authority morally possible?

title: PRICES ARE LOWER FOR TAXEXEMPTS
description: Taxexempt bond prices, which had advanced for a month, declined this week, push ing The Bond Buyer's yield in dex higher yesterday for the first time since midJune.

title: Labor's Fateful Decision
description: The Labor party's National Executive Committee has voted even more decisivelysixteen to sixagainst Brit ish membership in the European Economic Community than had generally been predicted. This margin reflects a measure of success for Harold Wilson's effort to per suade proCommunity colleagues to vote against their convictions in the interests of shortrun political advan tage and the appearance of party unity.

title: Japan Easing Curbs
description: TOKYO, July 2l The For eign Investment Council recom mended today that 151 Japa nese industries be opened to 100 per cent direct foreign in vestment and that all but seven industries on a socalled nega tive list be freed for 50 per cent direct foreign investment.

title: FOX FILM SHOWS 3MONTH PROFIT
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation continued its recovery with the second con secutive quarterly profit, ac cording to the midyear report yesterday of William T. Gos sett, chairman, and Dennis C. Stanfill, president.

title: CHEMICALS MERGER PLANNED IN FRANCE
description: The boards of Societ des Produits Chimiques Pechiney Saint Gobain and Societ Pro gil, both controlled by Rhone Poulenc, S.A., announced merg er plans yesterday in Paris.

title: Seminars Tell How Not to Be a Crime Victim
description: Five years ago a young German girl came to New York to become a nurse. She brought luggage and a new portable typewriter. In due course she acquired an apart ment, a tape recorder and an assortment of costume jewel ry girls dote on.

title: Screen:
description: On the morning of May 25, 1928, the Italian airship Italia, under the command of Gen. Umberto Nobile, crashlanded on pack ice north of Spits bergen while returning from a flight over the North Pole. It was not until midJuly, after great hardships and the death of many in Nobile's party, and, among the rescu ers, the loss of Roald Amund sen, the Norwegian Arctic ex plorer, that the last of the Italia survivors were saved by the Soviet icebreaker Krassin, which was dis patched in response to dis tress signals a Russian radio ham had picked up from the downed Italians.

title: 009955 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., July 29 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery was 009955. Holders of tickets with all six numbers in the correct order win $50,000; with the last five numbers, $4,000; the last four, $400, and the last three, $40. Holders of tickets with the last two numbers matching those of the winning number are eligible for a spe cial drawing to be held later this year.

title: Stockholder Sues Memorex
description: A stockholder, Michael D. Wolin, filed yesterday a class action suit against the Memo rex Corporation in Federal District Court here. The suit alleges violation of securities laws.

title: Chief Executive Named At Joseph E. Seagram
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Jack Yogman as president and chief execu tive officer.

title: Miss Goolagong Victor
description: HILVERSUM, Netherlands, July 29 (AP)  Evonne Goola gong of Australia, the Wimble don champion, was extended in defeating Trudy Walhof of the Netherlands in the quarterfinals of the Dutch tennis champion ship today, 36, 61, 75.

title: U.S. Reports 13 Deaths In Combat Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP)United States battle casualties in Indochina continued at nearrecord low levels last week, while South Vietnamese and enemy losses increased, the allied com mands reported today.

title: C.B.S. MAKES SHIFTS IN PROGRAMING AREA
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, which last week shook up its top management, yester day announced major changes in its television programing department.

title: Bache Plans Stock Offer;
description: Bache & Co., Inc., the na tion's second largest brokerage house, announced plans yester day to go public with an offer ing of 2.5 million shares of its common stock at a maximum price of $25 each.

title: The Other Secrets
description: YORK, Me. I have been reluc tant to enter into the scrimmage caused by the publication in The. New York Times and other newspapers of the documents procured from Dr. Daniel Ellsberg. This disinclination has been shattered by the news report that my former colleague, Dean Acheson, has injected himself into the contro versy. For I fear that his exceptional legal talents will be directed against the wrong target.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I have been quite impressed by the present Save a Watt program and read accounts of it in The New York Times.

title: Hornsby, Giants' Choice, Starts for Stars Tonight
description: CHICAGO, July 29In tomor row night's first pro football game of the season, matching the College AllStars and the Baltimore Colts, the player the Giant fans should try to pick out on the television screen is No. 35 wearing blue, white and red stars. That would be Ronnie Hornsby, a middle linebacker from Southeast Louisiana and the only starter among the four Jet and Giant rookies on the 52man AllStar squad.

title: MARKET ENTRY TAKES EDGE IN BRITISH POLL
description: LONDON, July 29 Support for British entry into the Com mon Market took the edge in an opinion poll today for the first time in several years.

title: Guard of Colombo Quoted As Naming Gallo Brothers
description: A bodyguard of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. was quoted yester day as having told Federal agents that the shooting of Co lombo last June 28 was planned, by the Gallos.

title: McGovern to Seek a Floor on Incomes
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 29  Senator George McGovern said today that he would intro duce a bill calling for an ade quate income for every Ameri can and for a minimum of $6,500 a year for an urban fam ily of four.

title: DR. IRWIN SCHIFF
description: Dr. Irwin Schiff, former di rector of pediatrics at Lefferts General, Greenpoint, and Kings ton Aveune Hospitals, Brooklyn, died Wednesday at Bay Harbor Islands, Fla., where he lived. His age was 73 and his office was formerly at 658 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Tito Reelected to a 5Year Term
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 29President Tito was unani mously reelected by the Yu goslav parliament today to a fiveyear term. But he said he might retire before his man date expired if the group of 22 men who were elected to a new collective presidency of the republic under his chair manship worked well together.

title: SOYBEANS DOWN IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Soybeans were the most ac tive commodity on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, with 16,000 contracts traded. Futures prices were down 1 to 3 cents.

title: Senator Buckley Says Nixon Still Has His Support
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Senator James L. Buckley part ed company todayslightly with his brother William F. Buckley Jr. and a group of prominent conservatives by re iterating general support for the Nixon Administration.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: VENICE, Italy, July 29 (UPI) All the seeded players moved to the quarterfinals of the Venice women's open tennis tournament today. Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., had a surprisingly tough fight against Lita Liem of Indonesia, winning by 76, 64.

title: Leaks About Reserve Scored by White House
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A high White House official said today that the leaks earlier this week about possible consideration by President Nixon of a change in the status of the Federal Reserve Board were not a legitimate ex pression of Presidential opin ion.

title: Westinghouse Cites Atom Gains
