description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation's nuclear busi ness will be a very large profit contributor in 1971 and beyond, John W. Simpson, president of the company's power systems operations, said here yesterday. He re ported that its nuclear busi ness made a significant prof it in 1970.

title: A Recipe for the Weekend Chef to Try
description: In the menu below, dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Market Place
description: A Big Board rule that has provoked controversy for years prevents member firms under most circumstances from buying or selling Big Board shares anywhere but on the floor of the stock ex change.

title: Ruling in Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN, July 29  A Superior Court Judge ruled to day that publicity about the aborted trials of Bobby G. Seale would not prevent selec tion of an impartial jury for the trial of two other Black Panthers charged in the mur der of Alex Rackley.

title: D'Amato Files Bankruptcy
description: Cus D'Amato, former man ager of Floyd Patterson, for mer world heavyweight boxing champion, filed for bankruptcy yesterday in Federal District Court. D'Amato said he had li abilities of $30,276 and assets of about $500.

title: Police Here Dismiss Lieutenant In Long Corruption Investigation
description: Francis X. Ward, a lieutenant, who has been a central figure in the 16monthold investiga tion of police corruption here, has been convicted of Police Department charges involving bribery and perjury and has been dismissed from the force without a pension.

title: Mr. Nixon's Red Ink
description: When President Nixon submitted his budget for fiscal 1971 eighteen months ago, he noted that he had pledged to the American people that I would submit a balanced budget for 1971. Indeed, his new budget showed a $1.3 billion surplus. But this week the Government announced that the actual deficit for fiscal 1971 had climbed to $23.2 billion, the second largest deficit since World War II. And Government economists have let it be known informally that the deficit for fiscal 1972, which began July 1, is currently estimated at $25 billion.

title: Laotian Victory Reported
description: VIENTIANE, July 29Laotian troops reoccupied the important provincial capital of Saravane yesterday, sources close to the acting Defense Minister, Sisouk Na Champassak, reported today.

title: Shift at the A. E. C.
description: Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg deserves the high praise Presi dent Nixon voiced in announcing his retirement after a decade of service as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission. The traits a professor of chemistry must have to win the Nobel Prize are rather different from those required to perform well the arduous duties head of the A.E.C. It is a measure of Dr. Seaborg's stature that he excelled in both roles, and that he was able to serve the country effectively under both Demo cratic and Republican Presidents.

title: Ties in Doubt, Nimeiry Says
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 29Premier Nimeiry, said to day that I don't want any deterioration in our relation ship with the Soviet Union and other socialist countries, but if they want to choose that path we will have no alterna tive.

title: White Sox Defeat Yanks, 40;
description: CHICAGO, July 29For the first time in their 69year his tory the Yankees lost tonight to a Latin and Greek scholar who ushers at college basket ball games.

title: COL. L. M. COSGRAVE, SIGNED PEACE PACT
description: KNOWLTON, Quebec, July 29 (Canadian Press)  Col. Lawrence Moore Cosgrave, Canada's official signatory fol lowing the surrender of Japan at the end of the Second World War, died yesterday at his home in this southeastern Quebec community. He was 90 years old.

title: A TREASURY AIDE IS QUITTING POST
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 John S. Nolan, Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Treasury and one of the main architects of the 1969 tax reform bill, has resigned. He will leave the Treasury at the end of August.

title: Man in the News
description: To some who have ob served him since his election to the bench here in 1944, State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell David Schweitzer has appeared to be an effi cient, dedicated, honest, good natured, compassionate and highly intelligent judge. To others he has appeared flam boyant, intimidat ing, cynical, hu morless and inju dicious. During the last year his conduct and as sociations have come under scrutiny by state and Federal officials. Last week a swin dler testifying before a Senate subcommittee in Washington assented to a description of Justice Schweitzer as the best judge money can buy.

title: Phillips Finds Oil Field
description: BARTLESVILLE, Okla, July 29 (UPI)The Phillips Petro leum Company said today that it had discovered a new oil field about four miles south west of the Alamein oil field in the western desert of Egypt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am writing as a private citizen who happens to be an employe of the Bronx Children's Psychiatric Hospital.

title: COSMOS AND BANGU MEET HERE TONIGHT
description: Starting tonight, New York soccer fans will have one of the biggest weekends of the season, with visits to Yankee Stadium by Santos and the famed Pel the exciting Bangu team of Brazil and the defending North American Soccer League cham pion, Rochester Lancers.

title: News Analysis
description: JERUSALEM, July 29As the first anniversary of the successful ceasefire along the Suez Canal approaches, what a high official termed a na tional debate appears to be developing on the question whether Israel's rigid negotiat ing position of the last four years has reached a point of diminishing re turns.

title: Advertising:
description: J. Walter Thompson and Foote, Cone & Belding, both of which are on the Big Board, released firsthalf state ments yesterday. The first was up and the second down.

title: Arab Chiefs Arrive for Talks in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, July 29  The Presidents of Egypt, Syria, Yemen and Southern Yemen arrived here today for an emer gency Arab leadership confer ence on what to do about Jordan.

title: Film Party in a Perfect Place
description: If the folks at the Museum of Modern Art keep on giv ing parties in its Sculpture Garden, they're going to spill the beans on one of the few remaining secrets of life in New York City.

title: For Daring, There's Givenchy
description: PARIS, July 29Hubert de Givenchy ranks up there with Dior as a leading exponent of ladylike clothes. So what do you make of it when he slashes skirts hiphigh, opens wedgeshaped necklines al most to the waist and pre sents a bevy of micromini dresses flecked with sequins?

title: Filipino Pickets Seal U.S. Base, Strand Airmen
description: MANILA, July 29 (AP)  Pickets of a Filipino union, pro tected by a court order against police interference, sealed off Clark Air Force Base today and stranded inside hundreds of air men who live off base.

title: 3 Indicted in Bronx For the Disabling Of Bridges in City
description: Bronx District Attorney Bur ton B. Roberts announced the grand jury indictments yester day of three bridgetenders for disabling bridges during the June 7 job action that snarled traffic all over the city.

title: Tocks IslandLast Chance
description: The highly controversial Tocks Island Dam is to be given a fresh look. It should. Originally conceived as an ideal combination of water conservation, flood control and recreational facility, this project for a 37milelong lake in the beautiful Delaware River Valley evoked doubts among some environmentalists soon after it was author ized by Congress a decade ago. Those doubts have grown into fierce opposition.

title: COMPROMISE PLAN ON LOCKHEED AID FAILS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A compromise aimed at getting immediate Congressional ac tion on legislation to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy fell through tonight after a day of intense negotiations.

title: BILL WITHERS PLAYS IN SOULFOLK STYLE
description: Soul folk music? It feels good to run out of pigeonholes some times, to encounter a performer who makes categorization dif ficult.

title: Myril Hoag, ExOutfielder In the Major League, Dies
description: HIGH SPRINGS, Fla., July 29 (UPI)  Myril Hoag, former major league outfielder, died last night at his home appar ently of an emphysema attack. He was, 63 years old.

title: Text of Governor's Letter on Schweitzer
description: Following is the text of a letter dated July 29 from Governor Rockefeller to State Senator John H. Hughes con cerning charges of miscon duct against Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweit zer:

title: Exchange Trading Halted As Argentina Weighs Move
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 29 Exchange operations were halt ed throughout Argentina today after a Cabinet meeting pre sided over by President Alejan dro A. Lanusse.

title: PEKING
description: PEKING, July 29The Hsinhua News Bulletin, a mimeographed col lection of state information in English, is delivered to your door at the Hsin Chiao Hotel here every morning with a quotation from Chairman Mao Tse tung printed in red at the top of the first page.

title: Union Pacific Net Up 16% in Quarter
description: The Union Pacific Corpora tion, parent of the Union Paci fic rail system, hit by a strike two weeks ago by the United Transportation Union, reported secondquarter earnings yester day of $22.4million, or $1 share, up 16.3 per cent from $19.2million, or 86 cents share, in comparable quarter of 1970.

title: House Votes $58.5Million To Return SST Funds
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UN) The House voted today to appropriate $58.5million to repay 30 airlines for their in vestments in the defunct super sonic transport project.

title: The Worst Drug Problem
description: This country's worst drug problemin terms of num ber of individuals seriously affected, annual economic loss and similar indicesis neither heroin nor marijuana nor any other of the drugs newly come to fashion. Rather it is that terrible old and reliable destroyer of lives: alcohol.

title: Potter Sues I.B.M.
description: The Potter Insrument Com pany said yesterday that it and two of its subsidiaries had filed a suit against the International Business Machines Corporation in the State Supreme Court in Nassau County. The company asks the court to declare I.B.M.'s new fixedterm leases on computer peripheral equip ment against public policy, illegal and void.

title: Occidental and Shell Group Sign Venezuela Oil Pacts
description: CARACUS, Venezuela, July 29 (UPI)  The Venezuelan Government today formally signed oilservice contracts with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Royal Dutch Shell Group, ending 3 years of arduous negotiations and a 14year wait to open new oil fields to private com panies here.

title: Sentence Is Flag Duty
description: ALEXANDRIA, La. (UPI) Dennis G. Hohm, 19 years old, an airman who admitted, he stole an American flag from a residence as a prank on July 4th, was sentenced to flag duty and jail for 20 days.

title: Ford and Chrysler Expect To Raise '72 Prices $200
description: DETROIT, July 29Two automobile companies, Ford and Chrysler, are planning to raise car prices 5 per cent this fall, or about $200 a car, another sign that inflation is continuing.

title: Negro Who Scored Nixon Policy Is Dismissed From H. U. D. Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Robert Lee Grant, the only black official of the Nixon Ad ministration to criticize Admin istration policies openly, has been dismissed from his job with the Department of Hous ing and Urban Development.

title: Tap Dancers Learn to Hop to It
description: The Dance Masters of America, Inc., had the floor at the Stater Hilton here yesterday, and it knew what to do with it: ballet, fox trots, jazz steps, even splits and cartwheels.

title: Afghanistan Flood Toll Put at 1,000
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 29 (AP)More than 1,000 people were killed when flood water swept away a village after a landslide, according to reports reaching here today.

title: Welfare Island Water Cut
description: A pile driver broke a water main on Welfare Island yester day morning, the Fire Depart ment reported, leaving the northern end of the island with out water. A fireboat was sent to Bird S. Coler Memorial Hos pital and Home to meet any emergency situation there. A Fire Department spokesman said the Conduit Corporation had been sinking a pile at Ninth Road, some 50 feet west of East Road, when the pile driver broke the water main.

title: Siderowf, Defender, Paces Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 29Dick Siderowf of the Golf Club of Aspetuck at Easton, Conn., began a quest for fourth straight Metropolitan amateur championship today by winning two matches by 7 and 6 over the West course at Winged Foot.

title: Landing Site Ringed by High Peaks and Steep Canyon
description: HOUSTON, July 29When the men of Apollo 15 attempt to land on the moon tomorrow, they will be aiming for a rela tively small patch of level ground surrounded by tower ing mountains and a steep walled canyon some 1,200 feet deep and almost a mile wide.

title: 2 Restaurants Where Cuisine Is Haute
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and ddcor (four triangles to none).

title: Gun to Foil Robberies Taken by Holdup Men
description: Officials of a Jamaica, Queens, savings institution, after seven holdups in the last 10 years, decided to arm their guard with a shotgun, the police of the Jamaica sta tion reported.

title: Junior Working Title Goes To Sandsablaze in Westport
description: WESTPORT, Conn., July 29 Ann Francis's Sandsablaze cap tured the stake and finished second in the undersaddle event to score 8 points and win the junior working hunter championship yesterday at the Fairfield Bridle Trails Associa tion horse show at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

title: Bridge: Stuart's Team Is 4th to Make Successful Spingold Defense
description: The Spingold knockout team victory earlier this week was only the fourth time in the 37year history of the event that a team has successfully defended its title. Stuart, Peter Weichsel, Steve Altman and Gene Neiger, all of New York, and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., are also one of the two youngest groups to have won the Spin gold.

title: Value of Orders in Half Up 13%
description: The value of contracts awarded for all kinds of con struction projects throughout the country in June totaled $8,076,653,000, a rise of 22 per cent over $6,641,583,000 a year before, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill In formation Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Cranis Gains Semifinal
description: MANHASSET, L. L, July 29 Topseeded Paul Cranis, the New York lefthander, defeated Bob Barker of Sands Point, 64, 63, to reach the semifinals of the United States claycourt championship for men 35 years and over at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club today.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The capital is now rushing to ward a summer recess, the nearest thing to a formal vaca tion that the President and Congress have had in years. By chance, the August break comes at a moment of generally suspended judgment here about the economy, about the war, about the new approach to China and about the old quarrels over crime and poverty. Fateful policies are in train, but no one expects significant returns until fall.

title: S.E.C. Accuses 13 in Court Of CorporateShell Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed a com plaint in Federal District Court here against 13 companies and individuals seeking an enjoin ment from further violations of Federal securities laws.

title: APOLLO 15'S CREW ORBITS THE MOON; 2 TO LAND TODAY
description: HOUSTON, July 29  The astronauts of Apollo 15 swept into an orbit of the moon to daythree excited men seeing a desolate world of craters and rugged mountains below and exclaiming that it was abso lutely overwhelming, absolutely mindboggling.

title: SCHOOL UNIT WARNED ON RACIAL LISTINGS
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has ordered officials of Community School District in the Bronx to refrain in the future from issuing personnel lists that identify individuals by race or ethnic background in connection with hiring, re hiring or promotion.

title: Recht Named A.B.A. Aide
description: Mike Becht, a sports writer for The Associated Press for nine years, has been named public relations director of the American Basketball Associa tion, Commissioner Jack Dolph announced yesterday.

title: Roundup: Brewers Add To Red Sox Woes, 30
description: Marty Pattin, who once struck out 22 batters in nineinning college game, yesterday pitched a fourhit shutout to give the Milwau kee Brewers a 30 victory over Boston.

title: Advertising:
description: Mickey Smith, who works for a big Midwestern book maker, was in town yester day and he had plenty to say. You can bet on it.

title: Mayor Stepping Up Drive On Prostitutes and Smut
description: Pornography pushers, pimps, prostitutes and others allied with these businesses will be hit with charges of everything from tax evasion to littering under plans discussed yester day by Mayor Lindsay's cabi netlevel task force established to drive prostitution and por nography out of midManhat tan.

title: LESTER C. MORROW, M'GRAWHILL EDITOR
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., July 29 Lester C. Morrow, an editor and executive of McGrawHill until his retirement in 1958, died yesterday at the Hunterdon Medical Center. He was 82 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President had a morning meeting with Senator John G. Tower, Re publican of Texas, and then discussed veterans affairs with Representative Olin F. Teague and Charles M. Teague and with Donald Johnson, veterans administra tor. At noon he met with 13 high school students who are directors of Distributive Education Clubs of America, an organization for high school and junior college stu dents interested in marketing careers.

title: Federico Castellon, 56, Painter And a Lecturer on Art, Is Dead
description: Federico Castellon, a painter who had had many shows and who had toured South America on a State Department lecture exhibition, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 85 State Street in the Brooklyn Heights section.

title: SCHWEITZER ASKS TO LEAVE BENCH TILL INQUIRY ENDS
description: State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer asked yesterday to be relieved of his duties pending the conclusion of a court investigation into his judicial conduct.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Textron, Inc., received yes terday a fifth and final pay ment of $26.2million on a five year Army production contract for OH58A helicopters.

title: Fishing and Boating Prospects for the Weekend
description: Fishing Report

title: Store Sales Up 8%
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partment store sales at $717 million, up 8 per cent from the yearearlier $661million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,434,000,000, also up 8 per cent from $6,900,000, 000. The reports on rail freight carloadings and truck tonnage were not available.

title: Rail Strike Key: New Crew Every 100 Miles
description: DETROIT, July 29  When Joseph Kerr, a conductor on the Penn Central Railroad, gets ready for work, he packs a suit case full of clothes and crams a briefcase with rulebooks weighing three pounds that spell out his job in in finitesimal detail.

title: A Book on Jews Stirs Japanese
description: TOKYO, July 29Premier Eisaku Sato has read it. Former Trade Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has read it. Promi nent businessmen, critics, professors, rightists, leftists and radical students quote from it, even as they wonder about the author's identity. The hook in question, The Japanese and the Jews, has been a runaway best seller, for more than a year, and now it is to be translated into English.

title: HEALTH OF DOLLAR STIRS NEW WORRY
description: PARIS, July 29Gold, silver and the strong European cur rencies were in demand in Eu ropean markets today amid new anxieties over the health of the dollar.

title: Battle of the Generation Gap Sweeps Into a Babylon Park
description: BABYLON, L. I., July 29 Argyle Park with its three placid lakes and tranquil shores has become the fa vorite nocturnal refuge of many of the young people of Babylon.

title: 3 British Experts Report Fakes In Pottery in Leading Museums
description: LONDON, July 29  Three British experts claimed today to have proved that many ex amples of Anatolian neolithic pottery in the world's leading museums are fakes.

title: TEXTILE PRODUCERS CRITICIZE NEW RULE
description: The American Textile Manu facturers Institute said yester day that the Commerce Depart ment's newly issued regulation for children's sleepwear does not meet a requirement in the amended Flammable Fabrics Act for adopting a standard based on findings that are rea sonable, technologically practi cal and appropriate.

title: BOWATER RAISES NEWSPRINT PRICE
description: The Bowater Sales Company, Inc., yesterday joined the grow ing list of newsprint producers who are raising prices by $8 a ton, effective Nov. 1. The announcement came from the Old Greenwich, Conn., office of the subsidiary of the giant Bo water Paper Corporation, Ltd. It said the increase was es sential to cover the increased costs borne by all Bowater mills in North America.

title: W. I. BAUMANN, 71, A LANDING AGENT
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 29 Walter I. Baumann, a land ing agent with the Holland America line for 46 years until his retirement in 1965, died yesterday in Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow. He was 71 years old and lived at 291 Carolina Avenue.

title: 161 Feared Killed As 2 Panes Collide Over North Japan
description: MORIOKA, Japan, Friday, July 30 (UPI)A Japanese selfdefense Force F86 jet fighter and an AllNippon Air ways 727 jetliner carrying 161 persons collided over northern Japan today. The two crewmen of the fighter parachuted to safety, but there were appar ently no survivors in the jet liner, officials said.

title: Washington Names Negro
description: SEATTLE, July 29 (UPI) The University of Washington today appointed Robert E. (Bob) Gillum, 36 years old, as assistant basketball coach. Gil lum, a native of San Francisco, becomes the first black to coach basketball at Washington.

title: Airmen Back Strike
description: MANILA, July 29 (UPI)  A group of American airmen picketed the base commander's quarters at Clark today to force him to yield to strikers' demands.

title: Son of Chavez Is Cleared In a Draft Trial on Coast
description: FRESNO, Calif., July 29 (UPI)A Federal judge today cleared Fernando Chavez, the 22yearold son of Cesar Chavez, of charges of refus ing induction into military service.

title: Court Backs the State on Rules To Thwart Blockbusting Here
description: A State Supreme Court jus tice in Brooklyn yesterday up held the right of the state to prevent real estate brokers from soliciting home sales in areas where blockbusting tac tics are suspected.

title: Algiers Cuts Amman Ties
description: ALGIERS, July 29 (Reuters)  Algeria tonight suspended relations with Jordan and pledged military, financial and diplomatic aid to the Palesti nian guerrillas.

title: New Chief for 7th Air Force
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (UPI)Gen. John D. Lavelle assumed command today of the United States Seventh Air Force which is responsible for American air operations in In dochina.

title: Descent Path Steepened To Clear Apennine Peaks
description: The standard descent path for a lunar landing has been steepened to a precipitous 25 degrees for Apollo 15 to make sure that the Falcon landing craft has safe clearance over the Apennine mountains.

title: Lutz Upsets Ashe
description: QUEBEC, July 29 (AP)Bob Lutz of Los Angeles upset top seeded Arthur Ashe of Miami, 75, 6.3, in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Quebec internation al tennis tournament today.

title: GORMAN DEFEATS COVEN BY 76, 76
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 29 (UPI)Tom Gorman of Seattle and Jim Connors of Belleville, Ill., the 18yearold star, won quarterfinal matches in the $20,000 Buckeye tennis tourna ment today.

title: El Paso Gas Raises Profits in Quarter And for 6 Months
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in op erating revenues and net in come for the quarter and six months ended June 30. The, quarterly report placed oper ating revenues at $254,148,000 up from $230,079,000 a year ago. Net income rose to $13, 087,000, or 42 cents a share, from $11,258,000, or 38 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30, 1970.

title: Committee's Proposal
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, July 29Representatives of Canada's stock exchanges and investment dealers recommend ed today that foreign controlled securties houses be permitted to expand only if they eventually become 75 per cent Canadian owned.

title: TELEPHONE TERMS OPPOSED AT RALLY
description: Striking telephone workers at a noisy rally here yesterday shouted their opposition to ac ceptance of a tentative con tract with the New York Tele phone Company.

title: Britain Is Delaying the Export Of Titian Sold to U.S. Museum
description: LONDON, July 29A spokes man for the J. Paul Getty Mu seum of Malibu, Calif., which purchased Titian's 16thcentury masterpiece The Death of Ac taeon here a month ago, said today that Britain had placed a threemonth embargo on the painting's leaving the country.

title: Rail Strike Leaves Pile of Wheat in Nebraska Street
description: STAPLETON, Neb., July 29 From Logan County's mod ern, lowbuilt brick court house, the sign and the Amer ican flag on the brand new building of the Bank of Staple ton across the way are barely visible as they peep over the top of the mound of wheat that fills a block on the south end of this town's drowsy Main Street.

title: WHELAN'S OUSTER UPHELD BY COURT
description: JERSEY CITY, July 29  A Superior Court judge ruled to day that Thomas J. Whelan and Thomas Flaherty automatically forfeited their offices as Mayor and City Council President here when they were convicted of extortion earlier this month.

title: RUSK DENIES U.S. PLAN FOR WAR DECEPTION
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI)  Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that President Lyndon B. Johnson did not have any plans to widen the Vietnam war before the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin inci dent.

title: DR. JACOB L. CHIVIAN
description: ORANGE, N.J., July 29Dr. Jacob L. Chivian, a dentist who was a founder of the Hebrew Dental School in Jerusalem, died today of a coronary attack at his home. He was 70 years old and lived at 749 Scotland Road. His office was in South Orange.

title: Connecticut Residency Rule For Welfare Is Overturned
description: HARTFORD, Conn., July 29 (AP)  A threejudge Federal panel ruled today that Con necticut's oneyear residency requirements for welfare recip ients was unconstitutional.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Co lonialismsubcommittee on Caribbean territories10:30 A.M.

title: Emmett York, 68, Chief Of Choctaw Indian Tribe
description: Emmett York, chief of the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians since 1965 and presi dent of the Southeastern Tribes since March 1, died Monday in Philadelphia, Miss., at the age of 68.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Theodore Sorensen's excuse that the Pentagon papers provide the modern citizen with hindsight that was un available to those responsible for the Vietnamese escalation [OpEd July 13] is another attempt to perpetuate a pernicious myththat American lead ership was unaware of the idiocy of such involvement. The advice against committing troops on the Asian main land that was offered by such diverse generals as Eisenhower, MacArthur and Ridgway is well known; but per haps forgotten by Mr. Sorensen was a perceptive speech on the Senate floor made on April 6, 1954, by Sen ator John F. Kennedy.

title: Notes on People
description: It must be getting lonely for former President Johnson down there on the ranch on the banks of the Pedernales. He's invited the public to visit him and Mrs. Johnson at the Johnson Library in Austin Sunday afternoon, and the director of the library said they will be available to meet with visitors and to autograph books and mate rial available at the library.

title: POLICEMAN GUILTY IN NARCOTICS CASE
description: A suspended policeman was convicted in Federal Court here last night on a charge of con spiracy to sell cocaine while he was a patrolman in Brook lyn.

title: S.E.C. Hits Firm on Loans
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Bache & Co., Inc., was censured today by the Securities and Ex change Commission for alleged ly violating the securities laws in connection with its attempts to raise capital for the firm last year and earlier this year.

title: 2 ALLEN EXECUTIVES LEAVING REA BOARD
description: Two vice presidents of Allen & Co., an investment banking firm, are resigning as directors of REA Express, Inc., because of a conflict of interest with Allen's other transportation holdings.

title: Books of The Times
description: Those who think of Italian fiction as a single exercise in realism from Verga to Moravia, with poetic andelegiac interludes by Dino Buzzati and Giorgio Bassani, will find something new, something unItalian in the writings of Tommaso Landolfi. The characteristics of the stories gathered in Cancerqneen are evident enough, but far from easy to convey. He is a sharply ob servant writer, for example, and his de scriptions of a dolce vita party, of a dog worrying a rodent, of a man contemplating the killing of his woman companion, have a geometric exactness and clarity that no realism will surpass. Nevertheless, these details are put to other uses. It's what he does with them that distinguishes his fic tion. And it is here that any easy charac terization of his work falters.

title: Newark and Paterson Will Get More Aid in Model Cities Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 The Nixon Administration announced today that it would give 20 cities, including New ark and Paterson, N.J., more money for Model Cities pro grams and wider latitude in deciding how to use it as a test of the revenuesharing con cept.

title: Big Board Votes Increase In Ceiling of Trust Fund
description: The New York Stock Ex change Board of Governors yesterday approved an amend ment to the exchange consti tution increasing the ceiling of of the exchange's special trust fund.

title: Indicted Lawyer Found Dead In Garage at Merrick Home
description: MERRICK, L.I., July 29 (UPI) A Manhattan lawyer who was charged last Tuesday with lying to a Manhattan grand jury was found dead today in the garage of his home here.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Not even the glorious ghosts from the past have been able to find resting places in collegiate football's Hall Fame at Rutgers. It still is a pie in the sky, a hole in the ground, an unfulfilled idea. The immortals already chosen for residence wander in a limbo of sorts while waiting with growing impatience for their heavenly haven to take substance.

title: Commerce Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (Reu ters)President Nixon today accepted the resignation of W. Robert McClellan as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for do mestic and international busi ness, a post he had held since last August. Before that he was Deputy Assistant Commerce Secretary. Mr. McClellan cited personal reasons for his resig nation.

title: Here's an Idea: Forced Savings
description: Inflation, which is felt daily by virtually all Americans, is far from an exclusively American problem. In fact, the International Monetary Fund pointed out recently that consumer price increases in the industrial coun tries last year were the steepest since the Korean war boom.

title: Money Supply Continues Rapid Rate of Expansion
description: The nation's money supply continues to expand at a very rapid pace, despite professed attempts by the Federal Re serve System to curb it, data published by the central bank indicated yesterday.

title: Mao's Poem Urges Drive On Virulent Snail Fever
description: PEKING, July 29Snail fe ver, a parasitic disease related to the use of human excrement as fertilizer, is China's most serious health problem, accord ing to doctors in Peking's Anti Imperialist Hospital.

title: Mr. and Mrs. 3 Million on Metroliner
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  Amtrak's publicists staged an elaborate production today in honor of the Metroliner's three millionth passenger and got more, including more trouble, than they had bargained for.

title: 21 Prince of Truth Posts Victory on Aqueduct Turf
description: Prince of Truth made a trip to Aqueduct from Monmouth Park yesterday and James Tucker's 3yearold gelding turned the visit into a success ful venture. Established the late favorite by the astute members of crowd of 25,438, Prince of Truth contributed to the day's generally satisfactory form picture by winning easily.

title: Will U.S Have to Look at Cuban Heels?
description: CALI, Colombia, July 29  Dr. Delano Meriwether crouched intently in the starting blocks, counted com mands to himself, then bolted quickly down the red Tartan track.

title: ExBolshoi Dancer, 80, Is Slain Here by a Mugger
description: An 80yearold ballet teacher who danced with the Bolshoi Ballet before the Russian Revo lution was mugged in her Car negie Hall studio on Monday and died two days later of in juries sustained in the attack.

title: LEADERS OF AFRICA AT RITES FOR TUBMAN
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, July 29 (UPI)World leaders and hun dreds of thousands of his coun trymen paid final tribute today to President William V. S. Tubman, Liberia's leader of almost three decades.

title: 7 Panthers Indicted in Slaying Of a Party Official in Corona
description: Seven New York City Black Panthers, including two of the defendants in the recent bomb ing conspiracy case here, have been indicted by a Queens County grand jury in the kill ing of a West Coast Panther official whose bulletriddled body was found in a party of fice in Corona on April 17.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Contradictions abound in Harry Schwartz's recent columns on doctors and medicine.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS VOLUME RISES
description: Registering the sharpest price drop in two months, the Ameri can Stock Exchange index closed at 24.72 yesterday, down 0.28 from the previous day. The last time the index fell as much as 0.28 was on May 17.

title: Most Countries Absent
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 The Tripoli radio tonight re ported the arrival in the Libyan capital of Yasir Arafat, the dominant Palestinian guerrilla leader.

title: Elinor Kaine Bride Of Angel A. Penna
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., July 29Miss Elinor Graham Kaine and Angel A. Penna were married here today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Donoghue by Justice of the Peace Frank P. deLuca.

title: POLICEMAN INJURED, 5 SEIZED IN MELEE
description: Five persons were reported arrested and one policeman was injured last night when groups of youths threw stones and bottles in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The assistant editor of the National Rifle Association's American Rifleman cites the proliferation of firearms among private Israeli citizens [letter July 22] as rebuttal to the antiprolifer ation article of a faculty member of the Jewish Theological Seminary (Op Ed July 5). What chutzpa.

title: Adelphi to Drop Football After '71 in Economy Step
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 29 Acting in line with general budget reductions, the board of trustees of Adelphi Uni versity has voted to discontinue intercollegiate football after the 1971 season.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES PLUMMET AGAIN
description: Stock prices, dropping stead ily for the last three sessions, plunged through support levels yesterday to reach a new low since late January.

title: France Picks Route for First AirCushion Train
description: PARIS, July 29The French Government gave a powerful stimulus to aircushion rail travel today by deciding to proceed with the greatest speed to build a line from Paris to the burgeoning west ern suburb of CergyPontoise.

title: LOAN FUND AIDES BEING QUESTIONED
description: Former employes of the Mu nicipal Loan Fund for the re habilitation of slums are being called in for questioning by the city's Department of Investiga tion as the result of new in formation supplied by private citizens who are coming for ward, Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin said yesterday.

title: Proposal for a Metric Sysfem in U.S. Fails to Stir Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, July 29A proposal by the Nixon Admin istration that the United States adopt the metric system caused about as much stir on Capitol Hill today as the first metrica tion suggestion made to Con gress by John Quincy Adams 150 years ago.

title: RAYMOND F. HYLAND, POLICE REPORTER, 62
description: Raymond F. Hyland, an As sociated Press reporter who had covered Manhattan police headquarters since 1944, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 6937 66th Place, Glen dale, Queens. His age was 62.

title: LINDSAY DEFENDS OPEN ENROLLMENT
description: VAIL, Colo., July 29Lean ing against a chalky black board, Mayor Lindsay defended the City University of New York's openenrollment policy today against charges that it was not adequate.

title: Another Settlement
description: TUCSON, Ariz., July 29 (AP) The Phelps Dodge Corpora tion and striking copper unions reached a tentative agreement here late tonight. It calls for pay increase of 92 cents an hour over three years, unlimited costofliving clause and other benefits.

title: AIRLINES RECEIVE FIRST DC10 JETS
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., July 29 The McDonnellDouglas Cor poration today delivered its newest jet aircraft, the DC10, a widebodied, threeengine plane, to American Airlines and United Airlines.

title: Murphy to Name New Antigraft Chief
description: Assistant Chief Inspector Sydney C. Cooper, who has the reputation of being the toughest corruption fighter in the Police Department, has been selected to take command of the unit charged with com bating graft.

title: Jets Count Two Rookies as Blessings
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 29 Combining luck and per ception, the Jets apparently have been twice blessed at their training camp here at Hofstra University.

title: UNION SAID TO BAR FIRST STEEL OFFER
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The major steel companies have reportedly made their first firm economic offer to the steelwork ers union as a strike deadline set for midnight Saturday draws nearer.

title: Lincoln Center Appoints Director of Operations
description: Patrick B. McGinnis has been appointed director of opera tions for Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc., it was announced yesterday by John Mazzola, the center's managing director.

title: NIXON CALLS TALK ON RAIL WALKOUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 President Nixon tonight called on officials of the nation's rail roads and the striking United Transportation Union to appear at the White House tomorrow morning to discuss the in creasing economic impact aris ing from the continuation and expansion of the rail strike.

title: Pound Circulation Increased 6.9Million in the Week
description: LONDON, July 29 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday (in thou sands of pounds):

title: Executive Changes
description: The Gerber Products Company announced yes terday the election of Dan Gerber as chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Gerber will be suc ceeded as chairman of the board by John C. Suerth, who has been president. Arthur J. Frens has been appointed president and William L. McKinley be comes executive vice president of the baby food company.

title: Police Seek Rapist of Teacher In C.C.N.Y. Campus Building
description: The police yesterday were seeking a man who entered building on the City College campus and raped a young art lecturer.

title: S.E.C. IS TIGHTENING INSIDER DATA USE
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an opinion that imposed new restrictions on the use of inside information, held today that investment man agers who knowingly receive such information may not le gally act upon it.

title: CONSUMER AGENCY IS URGED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Ralph Nader, the consumer ad vocate, proposed today the es tablishment of an autonomous Cabinetlevel agency with broad regulatory powers to protect consumer interests.

title: U.S. WOULD DISCUSS GIVING ATOM SECRETS
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The United States announced today that it was prepared to undertake discussions with 10 nonCommunist nations on the possibility of sharing its secret technology for producing fis sionable uranium235 for use in atomic power reactors.

title: Northern Light, Belerion Win N.Y.Y.C. Races and Trophies
description: BOURNE, Mass., July 29 It was cupracing time on Buz zards Bay today for the 64 boats in the New York Yacht Club cruise, and all four of the events encountered stiff breezes, the first ones in five days.

title: JUDGE UNDER FIRE IN NASSAU RESIGNS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 29 State Supreme Court Justice Michael M. D'Auria, who was under investigation by the Court on the Judiciary for al leged misconduct, has submit ted his resignation.

title: Apollo 15 Crew Used Earth as Laboratory to Train for Scientific Mission on Moon
description: HOUSTON, July 29  The mission of Apollo 15 is science the close study of a region of the moon offering a major mountain range, the Apennines, and a deep, meandering canyon called the Hadley Rille, and all the features of the largest cir cular lunar basin, Mare Im brium.

title: Small Tornado Strikes Putnam County Village
description: LAKE MAHOPAC, N. Y., July 29  A small tornado tore roofs off houses, over turned mobile homes and lifted several houses from their foundations here shortly before 7 o'clock tonight.

title: Poultry Found Safe for Eating Despite Contamination of Feed
description: WASHINGTON, July 29  The Department of Agriculture announced today that tests had turned up no evidence that chickens given a feed contami nated with an industrial chemi cal were unsafe to eat.

title: Welcome Wagon Is Sold To Gillette Co. by FAS
description: FAS International, Inc., which last month said it was attempting to sell subsidiaries to raise money for interest pay ments on $22.52million of debt, announced yesterday that it had sold Welcome Wagon In ternational, Inc., to the Gillette Company for an undisclosed amount of cash that would per mit it to meet its obligations.

title: New A.F.L.C.I.O. Unit Head
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The Metal Trades Depart ment of the American Federa tion of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations an nounced today the election of Paul J. Burnsky as its presi dent. Mr. Burnsky, 49yearold native of Throop, Pa., will take office Sept. 1.

title: 8 REMAIN ELIGIBLE FOR $124,249 TROT
description: WESTBURY. L. I., July 29  At a cost of $2,000 for each, eight colts were kept eligible this morning for the Dexter Cup Trot to be presented at Roosevelt Raceway on Aug. 7. The onemile event, which will offer a gross purse of $124. 249 will be the final major race for 3yearold trotters be fore the Hambletonian at Du Quoin, Ill., Sept. I.

title: Role of Nixon's Old Firm in Bond Issue Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 Representative Morris K. Udall charged today that a law firm in which President Nixon was once a partner stood to make millions of dollars as bond attorneys for the first issue of United States Postal Service bonds.

title: Mets Lose Rain Marathon, 31
description: It never rains but it pours, all right. The Mets lost for the 20th time in 27 games last night when they were defeated by the St. Louis Cardinals, 3.1, in an eightinning game that was in terrupted by rain three times and took 4 hours to play.

title: Malawi's Envoy Is First Black To Take Post in South Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, July 29The first black ambas sador to South Africa, Joe Ka chingwe of Malawi, arrived to day and said he believed con tact and not isolation was the solution to the racial problems in South Africa.

title: Pakistani Regime Is Preparing For Long Guerrilla War in East
description: DACCA, Pakistan, July 29 Pakistan's military Government is waiting for what it fears may be a protracted guerrilla war, in East Pakistan, and Govern ment strategists are drawing from the writings of Mao Tse tung and other experts in their plans.

title: NEW ENVOY TO CHILE NOMINATED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (Reu ters)  President Nixon today nominated a career diplomat, Nathaniel Davis, as Ambassador to Chile, replacing Edward M. Korry, who has served four years in the post.

title: 12 HOSTAGES SAFE IN BANK SHOOTOUT
description: As a dozen terrified hostages dropped to the sidewalk after being held at gunpoint by five bank robbers, policemen shot and killed one suspect and wounded two others in cross fire yesterday morning on Up per Broadway.

title: Copper Contracts Ratified
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 29 (UPI)The copper strike ended in Utah today when two hold out unions ratified new con tracts, marking the biggest breakthrough in a nationwide dispute that idled 39,000 work ers in seven states.

title: New Factory Index to Gauge Output
description: WASHLNGTON. July 29The Federal Reserve Board an nounced today major revisions in one of the key indicators of the economy the industrial production index.

title: O'DWYER HITS BOARD ON BERRIGAN PAROLE
description: The United States Board of Parole was accused yesterday of trying to cripple the voice of dissent in America by deny ing early release from prison to the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and the Rev. Daniel J. Berri gan, Roman Catholic priests serving jail terms for destroy ing draft board records.

title: 2 Die in Jersey Plane Crash
description: WANAQUE, N. J., July 29 (UPI)Two men were killed when their private plane crashed and burned early today in a densely wooded area here. Au thorities identified the victims as Reginald B. Johnson, 41 years old, of Woodbridge, the owner and pilot of the singleengined Piper Cherokee, and Edward Piasecki, 46, of Watchung.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The cat is out of the bag, and a luxurious great fat pussy cat she is. (Like Pavlov's dogs, I automatically describe her as female.) In the midst of all the recent newspaper gossip about street walkers and their ilk, some soliciting (a crime), some loiter ing (no crime), now you see them, now you don't, and all the rest of that chaotic tommy rot, one great truth has been slightly obscuredthe role of men in the game.

title: Queens Democrats and G.O.P. Nominate Laurino as Surrogate
description: The Queens Democratic and Republican organizations nom inated Judge Louis D. Laurino of the State Court of Claims yesterday to succeed John T. Clancy, who resigned earlier in the day.

title: Body of Space Agency Aide Found in the Andes Range
description: QUITO, Ecuador, July 28 (Reuters)The body of William Morrison, a technician at space agency tracking station near here, was found last night at the foot of a 300foothigh ledge in the Andes range. He had been missing for more than two days.

title: Dr. Raymond H. Hartigan Dies; Chemist Aided Food Processor
description: Dr. Raymond H. Hartigan, a vice president of Kraftco Cor poration, food processors, who had been president of its re search and development divi sion since 1965, died Wednes day of a heart attack in Lake Forest, Ill., where he lived. His age was 55.

title: CLYDE SHIPYARDS FACE DRASTIC CUT
description: LONDON, July 29Amid an uproar in the House of Com mons, the Government an nounced a severe cutback to day in shipbuilding jobs and operations on the Clyde River near Glasgow.

title: List of Road Bottlenecks
description: Motorists driving in and out of the metropolitan area this weekend may encounter delays because of construc tion work at the following points listed by the Automobile Club of New York:

title: Western Electric Reaches Accord on Union Contract
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  The International Brother hood of Electrical Workers re ported contract agreements today with the Western Elec tric Company that would give the union's 80,000 employes of the Bell System subsidiary wage and benefit increases ranging up to more than 40 per cent above current levels.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONThe mood of Britain vis Avis the momentous subject of join ing the Common Market is no longer analagous to that of the famous char acter in the rhyme, out again and in again, Finnegan begin again. Britain stayed out of the market at its incep tion, which was a very bad mistake, and subsequently was twice kept out by de Gaulle. But now it looks as if it is going into stay.

title: South Vietnamese Report a Sharp Clash in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, July 30 (AP)A South Vietnamese task force in east ern Cambodia reported yester day that it had fought a wide spread fourhour battle with enemy forces, the first sizable contact since it began its sweep the day before.

title: Fight on Lamprey Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Representative John A. Blat nik, Democrat of Minnesota, called today for an increase in funds for the sea lamprey con trol program on the Great Lakes.

title: Bruce Ends Role at Talks With Deadlock Unbroken
description: PARIS. July 29  David K. E. Bruce retired as chief American delegate to the Viet nam peace talks today in an at mosphere of disappointment and recrimination.

title: FATHER OF 3 PLEADS GUILTY IN A MURDER
description: A 42yearold father of three pleaded guilty in Bronx Crim inal Court yesterday to the murder of a Columbia Univer sity secretary whose fianc had originally been charged with the crime.

title: Sudanese Curb on Soviet Advisers Reported
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 30Diplomatic sources said to day that the Sudanese Govern ment had asked Soviet experts in the Sudan in recent days to restrict or suspend their activ ities.

title: O'Sullivan, Actor, Honored
description: A Michael O'Sullivan Memo rial Scholarship, in honor of the actor who died last week, was announced yesterday by William Ball, general director of the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco. A fund has been established by the actor's friends and family to help young actors and stu dents. Contributions can be made to the ACT Michael O'Sullivan Memorial Fund, 450 Geary Street, San Francisco.

title: TWO ASTRONAUTS LAND ON MOON NEAR MOUNTAINS AND A CANYON; EXPLORATION WILL BEGIN TODAY
description: HOUSTON, July 30Two American astronauts rode their craft to a smooth land ing on the moon tonight, com ing to rest in a valley at the foot of spectacular mountains and near the rim of a deep canyon, Hadley Rille.

title: GAS UTILITY RAISES 12MONTH EARNINGS
description: The American Natural Gas Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in op erating revenues and net in come for the 12 months ended June 30.

title: Vietnam Tests Indicate 5.5% G. I. Addiction, Panel Told
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 President Nixon's special con sultant on narcotics and dan gerous drugs told Senate inves tigators today that 5.5 per cent of servicemen tested in South Vietnam had shown indications of heroin addiction.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Worker Militancy Hard to Find as Steel Talks Near a Decision
description: EAST CHICAGO, Ind. At the start of the 116day steel strike in 1959, hundreds of steel workers had their families packed into camp ers outside the gate of the giant Inland Steel Company plant.

title: PalmerNicklaus Duo Cards 62 for Stroke Lead in National Pro Team Golf
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 30  Over a course still heavy from the rain that caused yester day's postponement, Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus joined forces today for a betterball score of 62 to lead the national professional team golf cham pionship.

title: HARVEY O. CLIFFORD
description: FLORAL PARK, L. I., July 30 Harvey G. Clifford, a retired assistant treasurer of the Con solidated Edison Company of New York, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 69 years old and lived at 116 West Poplar Street.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., received a basic patent this week for a gas laser that is already in wide use by industry ana government. The carbon di oxide laser, as it is known, creates an invisible beam of radiation that can be made powerful enough to burn holes through steel plates. Dr. C. Kumar N. Patel, di rector of the electronics re search laboratory at Holmdel, N. J., was granted Patent 3,596,202, for which he first applied in 1964. Bell regards the patent as giving it a dominant licensing position among makers of such lasers.

title: Postal Men Here Ask Bargaining Unit
description: Metropolitanarea postal workers, who are not satisfied with the recently negotiated national postal agreement, are seeking recognition on an area basis that would enable them to bargain separately.

title: Michele Mottola, Publisher Of Milan's Leading Daily
description: ROME, July 30  Michele Mottola, copublisher of Mi lan's leading newspaper Cor riere della Sera, died today in a Milan Clinic at the age of 67.

title: Judge Here Frees Indians Of StatueDefacing Charge
description: Charges against five Indians who had been accused of splashing red paint on the bronze statue of Teddy Roose velt outside the Museum of Natural History last June 13 were dropped yesterday.

title: U.S. Orders Removal of Debris Dumped by the National Guard
description: The state's National Guard was ordered yesterday to re move two acres of debris that it had dumped into a Hudson River tidal marsh adjoining Camp Smith, near Peekskill, N. Y.

title: July Farm Prices Steady
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) Prices received by farmers for raw products remained steady in July for the second straight month but averaged one per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Depart ment announced today.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that the following serv icemen from the New York area had been killed in the war in Southeast Asia:

title: COURT ORDER SHUTS AFTERHOURS CLUB.
description: The Haven, one of the more controversial of the Greenwich Village after hours clubs, was ordered immediately and per manently closed yesterday by the State Supreme Court.

title: Jessel Is Cut Off on TV Show Over Reference to Newspapers
description: An interview with George Jes sel on the Today show yes terday was cut short when Ed win Newman objected to state ments the entertainer made about The New York Times and The Washington Post, linking them with Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper.

title: Rain Forces Revised Slate In Met Amateur Golf Play
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 30Heavy rains forced post ponement today in the Metro politan Golf Association's 69th amateur championship at Winged Foot.

title: Venezuela's Oil Bill Signed
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 30 (UPI)President Rafael Cal dera today signed into law Venezuela's controversial oil reversion bill, affecting United States and other foreign oil company properties here. The law stipulates that all oil com pany assets directly used to ex ploit the 40year concessions be taken over by the Govern ment without compensation when the concessions expire, mostly in 198384.

title: Sauer Drops In on Jets, Then Drops Out Again
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 30 George Sauer visited the New York Jets' training camp last night. But to his former teammates' dismay, he did not stay.

title: ZELLERBACH JOINS IN NEWSPRINT RISE
description: The Crown Zellerbach Cor poration and its 91 per cent owned subsidiary, Crown Zel lerbach Canada, Ltd., the Great Lakes Paper Company and Brit ish Columbia Forest Products. Ltd., became yesterday the latest newsprint producers to announce $8aton price in creases, effective Nov. 1.

title: Midlantio Is Disappointed Over Merger Bid Rejection
description: Midlantic Banks, Inc., a Newarkbased bank holding company, which was turned down Thursday by the Federal Reserve Board in a bid to ac quire the $217million Citizens National Bank, Englewood, said yesterday that the decision came as a substantial disap pointment.

title: Pauline Lawrence Is Dead; Designed Limon Costumes
description: Pauline Lawrence, who had designed costumes for many of the dance productions of her husband, Jose Limn, and had acted as his representative, died July 16 at their home in Stockton, N. J. Her age was 70.

title: Miss Goolagong in Final
description: HILVERSUM, Netherlands, July 30 (AP)Evonne Goola gong, the Wimbledon champion from Australia, advanced to day to the final of the Dutch open tennis championship by defeating Kora Schwediwy of West Germany, 63, 62.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Patrolman Wanted In $143,000 Holdup Surrenders Here
description: Patrolman John R. Crocker, who was being sought in con nection with a $143,000 rob bery and shooting in the Municipal Building on July 9, surrendered yesterday at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

title: Stocks Decline Again on Amex; Two Oil Issues Top Active List
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined again yesterday. The index closed at 24.61, off 0.11. For the week the decline totaled 0.83, a sharp drop.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Toward Reality
description: The recent twentyhour conversation between Chou Enlai and Henry Kis singer is a harbinger of things to come. After more than twenty years of non relations, a great desire to become re acquainted is about to develop on both sides. Many talks at many levels will probably take place between Chinese and Americans during the months and years ahead.

title: Small Village Upstate Stunned by Freak Tornado
description: MAHOPAC, N. Y., July 30 This little Putnam County vil lage was still buzzing today about a freak local tornado that swept a 30yardwide swath through it last evening, leveling trees and causing scat tered property damage.

title: U.S. Five Takes 3d Place In Wheelchair Olympics
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, Eng land, July 30 (AP)The United States basketball team defeat ed Britain, 5239, in a playoff for third place at the wheel chair Olympics today.

title: Wildcatters Seek Curbs
description: HOUSTON, July 30A group of independent oil and gas ex ploration companies has pro posed stricter controls by the Securities and Exchange Com mission of their outside financ ing as one way to attract more investors into oil and gas wild catting.

title: NEW U.S. 7% BONDS LACKING IN APPEAL
description: Relatively few Investors were attracted by the Treasury's new 10year 7 per cent bonds offered earlier this week.

title: B. LEO SCHWARZ, 75, TRIAL LAWYER, DIES
description: B. Leo Schwarz, a trial law yer, who sold more than $100 million worth of Liberty and War Bonds in both World Wars, died yesterday in French Hos pital. He was 75 years old and lived at 155 East 38th Street.

title: Huang Visits Canadian Aide
description: OTTAWA, July 30Ambas sador Huang paid a courtesy call today on Mitchell W. Sharp, Secretary of State for External Affairs, and discussed some of the background of President Nixon's coming journey to Peking.

title: 3 Democrats Ally In Struggle to Oust Manhattan Leader
description: Three wellknown Democrats yesterday opened a battle to oust Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti as Manhattan Demo cratic leader when they en dorsed an opponent for his dis trict leadership in East Harlem.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Falls to 108.3 from 108.5
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 108.3 from 108.5 last week.

title: Joint Bid Made to Start Greece Aircraft Industry
description: ATHENS, July 30 (AP)  Aristotle Onassis's Olympic Air ways confirmed today that it had bid, along with an Ameri can and a French aviation com pany, to build Greece's first aircraft industry.

title: Farr Signs 3Year Pact
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., July 30 (UPI)Mel Farr ended a 13day holdout today by sign ing a threeyear contract for an undisclosed sum, the Detroit Lions announced. The speedy running back led all Detroit runners with 717 yards in 166 attempts last season for an average of 4.3 yards a carry.

title: Manila Softens Stand
description: MANILA, July 30The Phil ippines today moved toward an accommodation with China.

title: Cosmos Game Rained Out
description: The North American Soccer League game between the New York Cosmos and Bangu of Brazil scheduled to be played last night at Yankee Stadium was postponed because of rain. A date for the game has not been scheduled.

title: Dance: The Miraculous Mandarin
description: Bartk's The Miraculous Mandarin is one of those ballets that always seem better in the prospect than in the event. Since its first production in 1926, which was banned on grounds of immorality, as were most early versions, there have been literally dozens of at tempts to bring this very re warding stage music to the atrical life.

title: ONLY 1% ON RELIEF HELD EMPLOYABLE
description: Possibly as few as 6,000 New York City welfare recipients less than 1 per cent of the total number of people on wel fare hereare actually employ able at this time, a study by social services organization has tentatively found.

title: Crew Will Photograph Lunokhod Site
description: HOUSTON, July 30In addi tion to the many spectacular and complex scientific studies that Apollo 15 is scheduled to carry out, there are a number of smaller, simpler experiments that, while not an important part of the mission, may prove just as fascinating.

title: Reinforced Border Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 Persons arriving here from Amman, Jordan, said today that Jordan had reinforced her forces along the northern bor der with Syria.

title: Argentine Peso Cut 6.4%;
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 30A significant new devaluation of the Argentine peso and meas ures that limit imports, foreign travel, and the flight of dol lars went into effect today.

title: DRAFT CONFEREES AGREE ON A POLICY ON TROOP PULLOUT
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  House and Senate conferees broke the deadlock that has stalled the draft extension bill for the last month by reaching agreement today on a compro mise version of the Senate's Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS DECLINES SHARPLY
description: DETROIT, July 30 (AP)The nation's auto makers produced the fewest number of cars this week since the week ended last Jan. 2, Automotive News re ported today.

title: Falcon on the Moon
description: O.K., Houston, the Falcon is on the plain at Hadley. Astronaut David R. Scott's voice betrayed no emotion as he uttered those words but he knew he was making history. He was announcing man's fourth successful landing on the moon.

title: REDS' IRADE BLOC SElS INTEGRATION
description: PRAGUE, July 30Eastern Europe's trade bloc, the Coun cil for Mutual Economic Assist ance, has reportedly agreed on a complex plan for economic integration, including a con vertible currency.

title: Measles Up 300% Here, but Peak Is Believed Passed
description: Cases of measles, the harmless childhood disease that can kill, are occurring here at four times the rate recorded last year, but the peak of the outbreak ap pears to have passed.

title: Interfering in Italy?
description: The United States has a natural affinity for the parties of the democratic center in Italy, and there cer tainly is no reason why marginal assistance should not be given to help Premier Colombo's hardpressed Gov ernment over some formidable economic hurdles. How ever, anything that smacks of outright interference in Italian party politics is certain to prove counterproduc tive both for the United States and for Italy's demo cratic forces.

title: ARCHER SARGENT OF NATIONAL LEAD
description: Archer D. Sargent, who re tired recently as assistant vice presidentfinance of N L In dustries, Inc., the former Na tional Lead Company, died Thursday evening at Memorial Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 177 North Chestnut Street, Westfield, N. J.

title: India, Rumania Tied, 11
description: NEW DELHI, July 30 (UPI) India and Rumania split the opening singles matches in their interzone Davis Cup ten nis semifinal today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SIR JAMES KIRBY, 72, INDUSTRIALIST, DIES
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 30 Sir James Kirby, Australian industrialist, died tonight at his home in a suburb of Sydney. He was 72 years old.

title: Rover, Lunokhod and Other Concepts Moon Vehicle
description: The lunar rover, the 460 pound wirewheeled vehicle rigged to unfold this morning from the side of the Apollo 15 landing craft, gives American space men a mobility never available before.

title: 37 Killed in French Crash
description: PAU, France, July 30 (Reu ters)A French military trans port carrying 34 paratroopers and 3 crewmen plunged to earth here today, killing all 37 aboard.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Just What Is It, Raggedy Ann, That Makes You So Lovable?
description: At the age of 53, Raggedy Ann is making a comeback. Not that she ever suffered complete obscurity, but in re cent years her popularity has been zooming.

title: GEORGE L. BEST DIES; A.T.&T. EXECUTIVE, 7!
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 30  George L. Best, retired vice president of the American Telephone and Tele graph Company, died yesterday in South Nassau Communities Hospital, Oceanside, after brief illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 20 Arrandale Road.

title: THREE SHARE BOUNTY ON POLLUTION FINE
description: PITTSBURGH, July 30  A Federal judge awarded $4,998 bounty today to three citizens who had furnished river pollu tion information to the United States Attorney.

title: 60,000 See Games Open at Cali
description: CALI, Colombia, July 30 While athletes from the United States and Cuba stood less than an arm's length from each other on a grassy infield, the sixth PanAmerican Games began to day in a dazzling display of Latin color and beauty.

title: WWJR Returns to the Air With Interim Newark Permit
description: WNJR, Newark's black oriented radio station, returned to the air Thursday after a 12 day silence during which city officials negotiated for use of its facilities with its previous owners.

title: Cosmos 431
description: MOSCOW, July 30 (AP) The Soviet Union has launched Cosmos 431, another satellite in its secret Cosmos program, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

title: 6 Arab Leaders in Libya End Truncated Meeting
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, July 30A truncated conference of five Arab heads of state and Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Pales tine Liberation Organization, opened and closed here today. It threatened practical meas ures against Jordan for seeking to liquidate the Pal estinian commando movement, but fell short of proposing im mediate sanctions.

title: 14 ENTERED TODAY IN TIDAL HANDICAP
description: Getaway day at Aqueduct to day will have as its feature race the Tidal Handicap, a 1 mile turf test listed for its eighth running. Thoroughbred activity in this state then will shift to Saratoga for the regu lar 24day meeting from Mon day through Aug. 28.

title: 162 Die in Japan in Worst Air Crash on Record
description: MORIOKA, Japan, Saturday, July 31A Japanese Air Force jet fighter with a student pilot at the controls collided with a Japanese jet airliner over the Japanese Alps yesterday killing 162 persons in the worst air disaster on record.

title: Adm. Roscoe Schuirrnann, 80, Headed Fourth Naval District
description: BETHESDA, Md., July. 30 Rear Adm. Roscoe E. Schuir mann, who retired in 1951 after two years of service as com mandant of the Fourth Naval District, Philadelphia, died Tues day in Bethesda Naval Hos pital. He was 80, years old.

title: Yanks Win, 119, From Twins
description: BLOOMINGDALE, Minn., July 30Even seeing wasn't believ ing tonight.

title: DEMOCRATS VOTE RULE ON LOYALTY
description: WASHINGTON. July 30  The Democratic Rules Commis sion finished drafting revised regulations for the 1972 con vention today by adding a new loyalty requirement for dele gates.

title: DR. LEWI I. TONKS, 74, AN ATOMIC PHYSICIST
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 30Dr. Lewi I. Tonks, an atomic physicist whose career spanned half a century, died today of a heart ailment in Glen Ridge Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 407 Oak Ridge Drive.

title: Antiques: Old Pinchbeck
description: Pinchbeck, a name given most basemetal imitations of gold made before 1860, is at tracting the interest of col lectors more concerned with acquiring fascinating de sign than precious metal.

title: Desalting Project Extended
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) President Nixon signed today a bill extending the life of the Federal Saline Water Conver sion program for six years. The program, run by the Interior Department, involves research and development of lowcost methods of desalting water.

title: 2 Arrested in Theft of $209,600 in Mexican Pesos
description: Two men were arrested early yesterday morning and $209,600 of Mexican currency stolen from a South Bronx printing plant was recovered as detectives ended a three week surveillance of the sus pects.

title: Canadian Asserts Peking Feels Nixon Must Yield
description: HONG KONG, July 30 (AP) Robert L. Stanfield, leader of Canada's opposition Con servatives, said here today that he had been told in Peking that unless President Nixon was prepared to make significant concessions, there would be hardly any beneficial results from his visit.

title: The Who Play First Program Of '71 Here Despite Downpour
description: The Who tied, rubber blocks to their shoes to avoid elec trocution and played a long concert in a steady rain Thurs day at the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium in Queens.

title: YUGOSLAVS INSTALL PREMIER AND CABINET
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30Dzemal Bijedic, a 54year old Bosnian, was sworn in to day as Yugoslavia's new Pre mier. He pledged his Govern ment to a policy of longterm sacrifices to end inflation and stabilize the economy.

title: Five Youths Arrested Here On DrugSmuggling Charge
description: The arrest of five youths from Westchester County and Connecticut communities on charges of conspiring to smug gle 67 pounds of marijuana in to the country was announced yesterday by Myles J. Ambrose, United States Commissioner of Customs.

title: DOW INDEX FALLS BY 2.99 TO 858.43
description: The stock market resumed its slide yesterday with abated intensity after a halfhearted rally attempt lifted prices in early trading.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 In this labor business, says I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of Amer ica, you have to be a fair fisherman. You have to have the ability to sit back and wait for a bite.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, July 30In March, 1960, a Soviet biochemist interested in the process of aging, Jaures Medvedev, had a letter from California. It invited him to attend the fifth International Congress of Gerontology in San Fran cisco the following August. Dr. Med vedev, delighted, set about obtaining the necessary approval for his trip.

title: Tigers Obtain Perranoski From Twins on Waivers
description: DETROIT, July 30 (UPI) Ron Perranoski, fireman of the year with Billy Martin's Min nesota Twins in 1969, was ac lquired today by the Tigers to help fill Detroit's need for re lief pitching.

title: France Is Ready to Oppose Wider Use of Paper Gold
description: PARIS, July 30French Fi nance Minister Valry Giscard d'Estaing served notice today that France will oppose a new distribution of Special Draw ing Rights  the paper gold used to supplement reserves in the monetary systemand will seek to convince her Common Market partners to do likewise.

title: VAN DILLEN VICTOR OVER FRANULOVIC
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio. July 30 (UPI)Erik Van Dillen fought off five set points in the first set and went on to upset top seeded Zeljko Franulovic of Yugloslavia, 76, 76, in a quar terfinal tiebreaker battle at the $20,000 Buckeye tennis tourna ment today.

title: SHOW BOAT REVIVAL IS A HIT IN LONDON
description: LONDON, July 30 (AP) Jerome Kern's 1927 musical Show Boat was revived at the Ade1phi Theater last night, and today the critics agreed it's likely to stay for years.

title: Mrs. Helen Brown Wed Aboard Yacht
description: Mrs. Helen Niblack Brown and Dr. Allan McNeill Mc Kelvie, both of Washington, were married yesterday after noon aboard a yacht off Antigua, W. I. Sydney Chris tian, a barristeratlaw, per formed the ceremony.

title: ROBERT CHERNUCHIN
description: Dr. Robert S. Chernuchin, a plastic surgeon who retired five years ago, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Palm Beach, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived at 25 Sutton Place South and in Palm Beach.

title: New York Magazine Publisher Resigns
description: George A. Hirsch, who helped found New York maga zine three years ago, has re signed as publisher and presi dent in an apparent disagree ment with its editor, Clay S. Felker.

title: MISS HAYNIE SHARES 3WAY LEAD IN GOLF
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 30 (UPI)Playing in a steady driz zle, Sandra Haynie, Sandra Spuzich and Sherry Wilder shot twounderpar 70's to tie for the lead at the start of the $25,000 Bluegrass invitation golf tour nament today.

title: Lindsay Is a Popular Celebrity At Ecology Meeting in Colorado
description: EAGLE'S NEST, Colo., July 30  More than 500 people rode the swaying metal gondo las of a ski lift to a sympos ium today on this 10,000foot high peak above the tourist village of Vail, many of the visitors drawn by the celebrity status of one of their number, New York City's Mayor Lind say.

title: Roundup: Gibson Excels As Cards Triumph, 43
description: His teammates call him Hoot, but Bob Gibson might better be known as The St. Louis Swifty. Last night in Veterans Stadium, Philadel phia, the Cardinal right hander pitched and batted his way to a 43 triumph over the Phillies.

title: '73 SPENDING RISE PUT AT $16BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  President Nixon's planning for his next budget starts with an outer limit on total spending of about $251billion, authori tative official sources disclosed today.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Miller Brewing. Company, a subsidiary of Philip Morris, Inc., announced yesterday the elec tion of Lauren S. Williams as vice president of corporate planning.

title: ONLY 1% ON RELIEF HELD EMPLOYABLE
description: Possibly as few as 6,000 New York City welfare recipients less than 1 per cent of the total number of people on wel fare hereare actually employ able at this time, a study by social services organization has tentatively found.

title: HORSE DISEASE SEEN CONFINED TO TEXAS
description: HOUSTON, July 30The out break of Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis that has alarmed the United States horse industry, may have been con fined to Texas.

title: Governor Going Abroad
description: ALBANY, July 30 (AP)  Governor Rockefeller's office announced today that the Gov ernor, his wife and younger children, would leave Wednes day on an 11day vacation in England and Spain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ups and Downs of City on Rainy Day
description: The summer's most pro tracted period of rain was bad for traffic but a boon for taxis; generally bad for re tailers but rather good for movies; bad for curbside food venders but good for restau rants; bad for the Chinatown Health Fair but good for um brella salesmen.

title: INDIANS RELEASE DARK AS PILOT; IRON GETS POST
description: CLEVELAND, July 30 (AP) Alvin Dark was dismissed as manager of the Cleveland In dians today and replaced by Johnny Upon a coach.

title: Giants Come Up Short in the Backfield
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 30Raindrops kept falling on the heads of the New York Giants at their C. W. Post training camp today and Dom Anile was among those standing on the side lines and hoping for a letup by tomorrow.

title: Mrs. Meir and Sisco Begin FarRanging Talks in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, July 30 Premier Golda Meir conferred here for more than three hours today with Joseph J. Sisco, the United States As sistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, and they decided to continue their farreaching discussions early next week.

title: NIXON IS SUPPORTED ON CONSUMER PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 30  The Nixon Administrations con sumer protection bill received the approval of a segment of the manufacturing industry to day as the Consumer Subcom mittee of the Senate Commerce Committee entered its third day of hearings on product safety.

title: NewIssue Trading Accelerates. As Prices Tend to Move Lower
description: Sixteen companiesthe most in one week for many months ventured to offer their stock to the public for the first time this week: As a result, trading activity picked up a bit in the newissue market, but prices tended to decline.

title: Japanese Fearful on Yen
description: TOKYO, July 30 (Reuters) Financial sources here said to day that deterioration of the United States balanceofpay ments position and a growing surplus in Japan's trade bal ance were reviving fears of yen revaluation.

title: $4.57Billion Works Bill Sent to Senate by House
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The House has passed $4.57billion public works bill but has rejected an amendment cutting off funds for an under ground nuclear explosion this fall in the Aleutian Islands.

title: Colts Beat College Stars, 2417
description: CHICAGO, July 30Earl Mor rell, the 37yearold quarter back who was a College All Star back in 1956, threw three touchdown passes tonight to help the Baltimore Colts, the National Football League cham pions, beat the current edition of the AllStars, 2417, before 52,289 fans at Soldier Field.

title: OUTPUT PER HOUR UP LESS RAPIDLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Productivity in the entire pri vate economy rose much less rapidly in the second quarter of this year than in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President had a morning meeting with labor and management ne gotiators in the railroad strike. He also signed several bills and asked Congress to increase by $458million United States contributions to the InterAmerican De velopment Bank and the In ternational Bank for Recon struction and Development and to add $111million for the Department of Defense for procurement of Air Force planes. The President then flew to Canton, Ohio, to at tend a dinner honoring new members of the professional football Hall of Fame. The President was to stay over night in Akron, Ohio.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Army sought bids yester day from nine companies for the design, development and qualification of a 1,500horse power gas turbine engine for a new generation of helicopter transports.
